Even though these can technically be read as stand alones, there has been some build up for this couple in the last two books so I recommend starting at the beginning not to miss any of it. Plus I am really enjoying this series and characters so recommend jumping in and knowing that you will get sucked in and want to continue.Isabel Romo is a chameleon, a woman of many disguises, and put on facades. But that only hides her vulnerable, damaged core from most. But her closest friends and Trevor Callaghan, a mercenary from Jim Morgan's team, can see under the surface even when she does not want them too. Isabel and Trevor have been together on two previous missions. During the first one she literally saved his life from a suicide mission while he was drowning in depression. But the next time, he was ready to try to explore their chemistry, but she got scared and bolted. But now that months have passed, it is time for her to face him again.When a threat hits too close to home, both Jim and Noelle's teams must work together to get answers and find a team member that has gone missing. From Mexico to Monte Carlo casinos comes a plot of revenge and deception that is full of mysteries, suspense, and action.Trevor and Isabel have such a push and pull--he pushes and she pulls back. She hates being vulnerable and is afraid to open up, risk rejection, or hurt him. But Trevor is not going to let her get away from him. They are both stubborn and definitely both have their own issues, but Trevor is relentless in his pursuit to wear her down. And their chemistry is strong and hard to resist. I loved them together and their flirty rapport. Trevor has grown and healed so much during the series while he in turn just wants to help her heal and move forward.This also features Noelle, Jim, D, Ethan, Liam, Sully, and Holden. And we get to meet Juliet, Sean, and Sofia. It is told in multiple points of view to help tell the full story and the story itself is fast paced and full of mysteries and suspense. I felt like I was part of the team trying to figure out what was going with the missing team member and trying to put all of the pieces together. And this one has some major nail-biting action scenes and some serious emotional fall out. I was held captive the whole book and could not put it down. I am looking forward to more with Ethan and Juliet next and also Jim and Noelle. So much antagonism is brewing under the surface.

I absolutely loved Mase and Reese in their first book When I'm Gone. Now they are ready to continue their relationship together as she relocates to Texas. They have been through a lot together and are committed and in love. Unfortunately there are some new outside influences who would like nothing more but to split them apart and claim one for their own.I have adored Mase all along. He's protective, loyal, dependable, sweet, and sexy. He always took care of his sister Harlow, and now he takes care of his girl, Reese. But he could be a little clueless about things going on around him at times. But he really is the good guy.Reese is determined, loving, and still a bit naive. She has lived through a horrible past, but Mase helped her heal and grow. But she is now in a new place, still coming into her own, and learning to believe in her abilities. She has a sweetness and innocence about her, but at the same time she has a backbone and quiet strength.They are such a sweet, sexy couple when they are together. You can just feel their love, devotion, and need. But due to the interventions of others trying to cast doubts, they have to continue to build trust, prioritize, face demons, and insecurities. And Reese especially is still growing and changing her own life and trying to find her own path. She has new family and new purpose in her life, but is sometimes swayed by others' opinions or manipulation.I liked getting more with Mase and Reese, but at times it seemed like there was some contrived drama. I got a bit frustrated with communication issues and the way that in trying to be protective of each other they ended up making bigger mistakes.The side characters of his "cousins" Aida and Major were prevalent in this story and Blaire's brother "Captain" also was a big part of it. I expect we will be seeing more with Captain and Major in future stories in Rosemary Beach. Even though they could be outspoken, arrogant, rude, and obnoxious...I kind of liked both of the guys. Captain especially seemed to have some hidden aspects to his personality and life. Now Aida, I had no fondness for whatsoever. She definitely gives Nan a run for her money with annoying female characters. The frequent interference of these characters really added to the drama of the story.But I loved that many of our friends from Rosemary Beach, along with Mase's Texas family, Reese's new Chicago family, and Slacker Demon make appearances.Even though Mase and Reese might be the least dramatic of the Rosemary Beach couples, they still have been through a lot together, but still had some new challenges to navigate in their new relationship. There were a few surprising twists in the story, while some things I found a bit predictable. The ending seemed a bit abrupt with a couple of things left hanging, but there were some possible set ups for future stories. Abbi has announced plans for Captain's book, a novella for Dean Finlay (Rush's father), and Nan's book to finish out the series. I am addicted to this series and all of these characters and it was a comfy read for me. I know I can pick up one of these books and get sucked into this world with old friends and enjoy spending time with them.

Not bad...not bad at all. Jon Bon Jovi is a surprisingly decent actor; very relaxed, no awkward or bad acting that most newbie actors that all of a sudden find themselves in front of a camera...The newbies discover that it's much, MUCH, so much, harder to pull it off than they had thought. So how did a Rock Star God, known for his awesome voice (and great hair by the way) pull off a solid performance in (of all things) a vampire flick!?!? Well, ol' Jon had a little practice...I mean, standing on a stage in front of millions of fans for a couple of decades kinda gave him the ability to pull off the "devil may care" attitude with obvious ease. The first Vampires movie with George Clooney and Quinton Terrintino was just a tad bit better than this one, but this part two, Los Muertos was a decent watch. Would I watch it again? Obviously, because this is like, my third time...would I recommend it to a friend to watch? You bet. Was it the greatest movie of all time?..um, no. Not even close. BUT, to be totally honest, I'll probably buy this vid if I run across it somewhere. All the supporting actors/actresses, also, did a good job. It was worth the couple of bucks to rent it.Okay, SHORTSUMMARY (no spoilers)...Another alpha vampire(ss) and her brood, are out hunting and killing. Well, killing is what vampires do, right? Right...but not entirely accurate. This particular Alpha is not only a she vamp, she's old. Among vampires, age is strength, blinding speed and stealth, cunning, she's also very powerful, and kind of a hottie too. But, the worse thing is, she's out to find the hiding place of the "Black Cross" that will give her the most important thing to all vampires...especially to the old ones... The Black Cross will make her a Daywalker. This is huge. The sun is the only reason they haven't come after us yet. The poisonous sunlight is stopping them from feeding and multipling at will until we humans are history. During the day their weak. And when they lie week, they are vulnerable. They MUST HAVE THAT CROSS. The Black Cross is a most precious thing...especially to a vampire that hasn't seen the sun in centuries.

There is just something very profound about this song that I really relate to. I was as wild as they came back in the day. I did a lot of things (that I look back on now) and cringe when I remember,  I look back on a lot of things and bow my head in shame. I see the faces of those that have seen me at my worse. Most of them have been gracious enough to forgive me. I was never a really bad person; never truly cruel...But I sure as hell came really, REALLY close to crossing the line; The Point Of No Return. BUT, I did NOT cross that line. I DID stop...I stopped right before I turned into someone or someTHING that I would NOT have ever been able to forgive. The person that is NOW looking back at me, when I look into the mirror nowadays, is just thankful. Thankful for what I have, and WHO I have...Yup, It's Been Awhile since I was the person that was ashamed when he looked into the mirror.

Every child...er..I mean SHEEP has to learn a few things in life. That's how all of us adult...er...sheep grow up to be wise OLD sheep. In this tale, Shaun, our favorite sheep, learns that hanging with the wrong crowd can make everything go south in a bad way. There will always be a group of people...er...I mean SHEEP, (or Llamas in this case) that seem to be so cool; they're always laughing and pulling tricks on others...they do crazy stuff that seems funny at the time, but in truth, is kinda rude and hurtful to others. Shaun, in a very uncharacteristic lapse in judgement --and totally unlike the Shaun we all know-- does something really dumb... Shaun, whom is normally the epitome of common sense and kindness, in a moment of weakness,  tricks the poor old farmer into buying these three seemingly uber-cool Llamas!? At first, all is crazy antics and wild fun...But very soon, Shaun's friends begin to bear the brunt of the mischievous Llamas hurtful pranks. And the poor farmer is terrified of the big bullies! The Llamas are rude, crude, and destructive. Soon, Shaun watches helplessly as the Llamas make shambles of everything.. Shaun has to make a decision: Does he let this pack of Looney Llamas ruin everything, or does he do what is right? This episode of Shaun the Sheep teaches a very valuable lesson about impressions and the repercussions of one's actions. Oh, and it's also hilarious!

There are two kinds of reviews that I hate to...er...review. #1)The "Oh-my-God-this-freaking-movie-is terrible" review, because I hate writing bad reviews. So, when a really bad one comes my way, I just TRY to ignore it and just kind of hope that it goes away. And the second kind of review.# 2) is the "EVERYBODY-loves-this-movie" ( because it's a classic, and it's been reviewed about a kazillion times. Millions of fans (like myself) have watched the Austin Powers' series over and over again because of the comedic super powers (no pun intended) that Mike Myers has, so it's kind of futile to write a review for this, or the other International Man Of Mystery movies. This movie has probably been reviewed more times than Obama's birth certificate!  Well I am going to go ahead and throw my review in there (a small drop in a huge ocean) because I feel I owe it to Mr. Myers. He has brought us, side splitting, choke on your popcorn, blow slushies out of your nose, and laughing until the screen is a blur because your eyes are filled with tears.--FUNNY! And that panicky feeling you start to get when you are about to suffocate because you can't stop laughing long enough to gasp for a breath of air!?!? Huh!?!? Yeah, you know that type of funny. Well, Mike Myers will (as Austin Powers, or Fat Bastard, or, of course, DR. EVIL)  always be (to me) one of the funniest persons ever borne. That guy (Myers) just KILLS me. Literally. Almost.

Oh man, how could I have forgotten THIS song to put in my library! One of the greatest single songs of all time. If you have listened to classic rock, you know the song Free Bird. You know the song Stairway to Heaven. You've heard Hotel California. Aaaaand, you've heard Train Train. The list is actually endless for each individual, but the truth is, you just CAN'T leave this song off the list. Oh, and here is some trivia I heard; "They" say, and I'm not 100% certain it's true because you know how some things that "They" say aren't entirely accurate sometimes, but anyway, "They" say that the band Black foot sold the rights to this song (and others) for a mere pittance...unknowingly duped into letting it go, because they needed the money and had no clue how popular this song would become. The people that bought the song has made a ton of money, but the band got the shaft. I also heard that the band tried to form under another name, but never did manage to make another killer song like Train Train because, well, honestly, they couldn't get over the fact that they practically GAVE several million dollars worth of royalties away. And the song still plays. Somebody still gets paid. But not Blackfoot....Urg...if the story IS true, I'd be sick to death too! If anyone cares to elaborate, I'd love to hear some comments.

PARTIAL SPOILERS: In my last review, I must admit, I got just a wee tad excited and just a wee bit ahead of myself. Um, sorry about that. There is one thing I have discovered about Shannon Mayer: the lady is NOT predictable. I thought I had it all figured out; Lark manages to harness ALL the elements, joins with Rylee in the near future (mind you I have not read Blood of the Lost yet) and together they would open a can of whoop @$$!Simple, right?WRONG... I did not get it right, as such, because Lark doesn't APPEAR to acquire the element of fire...yet..I don't want to spoil anything for anybody, so let's just say that Lark is really starting to grow on me. I loved this book! She is shaping up to be a WISE, as well as, very POWERFUL Elemental.  I have a feeling we have got some real "wow!" moments coming up. Oh, and the exciting look at things through nePeta's eyes (which was so cool, by the way) in the little side novella "Peta" ? Another total blindside by Mayer. It was Sooo unexpected, and Sooo just like something (I'm beginning to realize) Miss Mayer would do! Loved it. As to this latest book, I am still in shock by the ending, because now, one have to pick back up with Rylee's story to catch up...whew!... So I am going to stop right here before I make a fool out of myself...again...I may add a bit more after I've processed this loop that Miss Shannon has thrown at us... in the meantime, I'm going to dig into the newest Rylee adventure. I MIGHT be able to figure out what in the world is going on here! But probably not. You see, I think Miss Mayer does SOMETHING EXTRAORDINARY: She LETS HER CHARACTERS SPEAK AND ACT OF THEIR OWN FREE WILL! Sounds crazy, right? Well just consider this: Rylee, a brash, trash talking powerhouse that will ram a blade down your throat as she cusses until your ears burst into flame too! Do you think Miss Mayer talks like that? I would say, no. But her character, Rylee DOES. Miss Mayer has let Rylee off her leash. And be damned those that can't take it. Some people would say that's over the top. But in truth, that's what GREAT writing is all about. An author doesn't control their characters...no...they let their characters lead, and be themselves. Now, I've got another book to read. Hee  hee!...there goes that maniacal giggle again...**NOTE** To all the cool people on GOODREADS: I really, honestly, appreciate the nods from you guys. I would get on GOODREADS and thank you myself..But unfortunately, I am Facebook phobic. But I always read over your profiles, and I think all of you are most excellent!

I'm giving this latest book by Williams five stars because the quality of the read has noticeably improved since the beginning of the series. The story is solid, and now that someone is proofreading for Mr. Williams, his writing talent can be seen without the distraction caused by bad editing. If your a fan of the apocalyptic genre like myself, your definitely going to like this series.  Mr. Williams has a vision of where this story is headed and it has me wanting to see just how this thing will end up. The story is an accurate account of how civilization would quickly unravel for those that believe that our way of life is set in stone; that the government or other powers that be would make sure that each individuals little part of the rat race would remain undisturbed. Most people are in denial. They believe that the status quo is infallible. I, for one, entertain no such disillusion. I find T.A. Williams style of writing (typos and all) more likely to be a very very accurate model of what one of these disasters would, indeed, be like: 1) if the power and all communication goes down, there will be many that will not ever know what's going on. 2) Suspicion, confusion, panic, and mass hysteria will be rampant. 3) And finally, if our country were to experience an extended state of disarray, SOMEONE, would take advantage of our predicament and begin to pour into the country while we are down with all intentions of making sure that we STAY down. I've read a million stories where huge groups of Americans would pull together and (way too conveniently) thwart any such attempts...the truth of the matter is, the common everyday man would be way to busy trying to survive (by any means necessary) than putting up any resistance against an invading force. Anarchy would reign. The people that are packed into the bigger cities, that have no plan (or belief in such a thing) will be ill prepared for such a contingency. The affluent, those that think monetary security is all they need, will be the first to realize that this is, in fact, not the case.

First, let me say that I am enjoying this series by T.A. Williams, but those readers and reviewers out there that are a stickler when it comes to typos will throw a fit. The series also starts out kind of rough, but it does gain momentum and becomes a decent apocalyptic yarn. The exact cause of the coplete loss of the U.S. power grid remains a mystery. It does not seem to be important HOW the country went dark, but HOW society crashes violently, and quickly; descending into complete anarchy. I am already on book five. So, this IS a good story. I've even put off starting some books by Mayer (my favorite author) because I don't want to put this story down. SUMMARY: A family....Man, a wife and four children. The mother succumbs to cancer just before the country goes dark. The father, can't take the grief and crawls into a bottle...and stays there. Leaving his children pretty much alone. But when the lights go out, the father collects his broken family and flees to the family farm; a farm that has been in the family for generations. It's way out in the country. Maybe they can hide and wait for the world to get back on track...or so everyone hopes...right up until the foreighn soldiers roll in.. . All in all, it's a good read, but the spell check (that can really ruin your writing) was obviously hell bent on wrecking an otherwise, decent story.

This is not a current movie. Ian Keller is young (even though his make up makes him look older) and there are others in this Gothic horror story. The filming is done pretty well for the time that you will recognize. It is not a B movie, but by today's standards, it's kind of hokey. It was worth watching though and I would suggest you watch it just to see these Box Office Big Guys back in their "starving actor's" day. The movie is placed in Nazi occupied territory that is the sight of a massive, ancient, keep. To the horror and detriment of all, The Keep is not built to keep people out, but to keep the malevolent spirt that is traped within, from escaping out into the world. The entity is held prisoner behind vast walls of stone warded by silver glyphs embedded into the stone. When the Nazis (ignoring vehement warnings from the keeps priests, attempt to steal the silver wards...well, let's just say, they should have left the silver alone.

This order was a mistake. I thought I was ordering a DVD, but got a flawless VHS instead! Totally MY bad. I didn't read the offer correctly. It was right there: "VHS" in great big letters!  Oh well...need to wear my glasses, no matter how dorky I look! Anyway, I was at least pleasantly surprised by the VHS that I ended up with though. This VHS was in BRAND NEW CONDITION. luckily, I DO still have an old video cassette player. I drug it out, dusted it off and the tape played as good as it looked. The shipping was super fast. (Thank you Mr. Begley!) Even the sleeve was new looking. I don't know where Mr. Begley dug this old vid up, but it looks like it came straight out of a time capsule! Very pleased considering the circumstances. Those of you whom may like to see this really odd (but funny) video, you will find that it's not simple...or cheap. This particular video is very hard to come by because, The Applegates, aired on a channel that no longer exists, so the copies are few. Loved this show back in the day. Had a huge crush on Christina Applegate.

UPDATE #2: Okay. I was really impressed with these cords when I first got them. And the extra length was great too..HOWEVER, three out of the five that I bought have creased to function. The ENDS BURN OUT. It is not a shorting problem. The cables themselves held up fantastic. But what good is durable cables if the ends are going to smoke out!? My tester says there is no longer continuity end to end. But I tested just the cord and it read fine. So the cord is good the male ends are NOT. Look at the date of my original purchase, you will see that these cords only lasted a couple of months. I've had cheap plastic ones that lasted two years or more. I dropped the rating to three stars. I had one burn out immediately. I thought it was just maybe a fluke. Maybe I accidentally twisted it or something....I guess not. Read on. Start at the bottom if you want to see the original review, and move upward through the updates.UPDATE*** one of these cords has stopped working. Burned out? Shorted? Can't tell. I was not doing anything particularly different with the one that malfunctioned. No smell. No kinks. It just stopped working...very odd. Maybe it was a fluke, but maybe not. I felt it was my duty to update. If anything else happens to any of the others, I will know it's the cord not a fluke. At that point I will redo this review. I'll give them one more chance before dropping stars. END UPDATE**Cheap cords wear out way too soon. Here's the theory behind data exchange and charging cords: the tips of the cords that go into the Universal Service Buss on your devices are made of a softer metal. They are made to wear out. Because if they didn't, then it would wear out the USB PORT itself. In other words, they would render your device useless because the PORT is ruined. But a good quality cord will last longer and would be less prone to shorting out. Especially charging high voltage devices like laptops, and tablets. These cords are different from anything I've ever seen. I have seen braided lines on automobiles and heavy machinery. The design is superior to plastic coated cables. These cords follow the same line of performance. They are longer than most cords, and they seem to have a heavy duty feel to them. I've only had them for a short time but I love how they are performing so far. They transfer 2.0 mAh of power and don't even get warm. I'll update if they fail to perform.

Until now, I've always reviewed Shannon Mayer's Rylee series as if I were trying to "convince" someone who has never read one of her books, how much I like her writing style and how much I love Rylee...well, I can't figure out how to do that SOS this time. So here are the facts.***SPOILER, SPOILER, AND MORE SPOILERS!!! THE WHOLE REVIEW IS ONE GIANT SPOILER!!**So this review is for those who have read the book, not for those who are not a total fan!Okay, wow! I can't wait for the final book, Blood Of The Lost! I am so glad Pam has come to her senses and has stopped feeling guilty, and sorry for herself. I am NOT okay with Faris/Liam winning over Rylee's heart! No way! This is important: I KNEW THAT ELEMENTALLY CHALLENGED (an introduction to Larkspur) WOULD BE RELATIVE TO RYLEE'S FUTURE! And if you'll look at the review you'll see I was right! I hate that Milly is dead, but she died a good death and she died with a clean soul and not as Orions whore! I hate that Frank gets killed because he was a very decent young man. I hate it for Pamela. I am also totally freaked that Alex is and (hopefully) will retain the ability to fully transform...our little Alex is all grown up now, almost. I loved RECURVE and I enjoyed meeting Lark and I can't wait to see how much she will actually help Rylee kick Orion's ass! And I will be very pi$$d if Liam does not come out of the newly opened veil at the end of this thing and he and Rylee DON'T fly off into the sunset on Blaz!! And most of all, I hope little Marcella and Zane follow in their mother's footsteps and start the loop all over again. And last but not least, I dread The Blood Of The Lost, because it will mean that I must part ways with Rylee, her world, and her friends! WOW THAT FELT GOOD! I may get negged right off the reviewers list for this, but I don't care...it felt great!Your the freaking best Miss Mayer! Glory hallelujah, and where's the damned Tylenol!!**NOTE** To all the kind people on GOODREADS: Thank you so much for your "likes". I would go onto Goodreads and thank you personally, but I am Facebook phobic. But I really, honestly appreciate it.

I've reviewed most of this wonderful series series by Dalzelle, I chewed through them and loved every bite. As I said before, the series is like all the good "spacer" movies rolled up in an exciting bundle of PAGE TURNING READING!  Each and every episode is another romp of high SCFI action that has an addictive element that makes me cough up my hard earned bucks and buy them all...But I had to stop and do another review on this particular book because it really shook me up! ***MINOR SPOILER***The story opens with the crew disbanded and scattered!?? I was like, OH $#!+!! And the most disturbing thing was the fact that the Phoenix is GONE!!?? Jason and Lucky the battle synth are the only ones of the old crew still together!? They have relegated themselves to being (what amounts to) glorified delivery men. Their ship is a gawky, ugly, box-like piece of junk that can barely make slip space speed. Their hauling...Lettuce!? Parts!?...I was like, WHAAAA!? That's all I'm going to say about the deal, but I must admit, THIS is one of the best in the WHOLE series...And that IS saying something! I read in the forward by the author that Joshua Dalzelle says that he will keep writing about the Phoenix and her crew as long as HE enjoys doing so, AND as long as his readers enjoy the series...NOTE TO AUTHOR: Mr. Dalzelle, sir. I AM VERY MUCH ENJOYING THIS SERIES. I HOPE THAT YOU ARE AS WELL!!!

I totally agree with the other reviewers that Wesley Snipes is way underrated, and so are these two movies: The Art Of War, and The Art Of War 2... The whole cast did a great job. The directing was done very well also. There is a high quality to these two productions that trumped other movies that made a much bigger ado, but was not NEAR as exciting as TAOW one and two. Anyway, looking for a good vid? If you've never seen these two movies, your in for a great treat! Here's a quick summary without spoiling it: Shaw must dust of his Men In Black suit (metaphorically speaking of course) stretch out the old wounds and broken bones and go after the people that had anything to do with his mentors murder. Very cool Vid. This is one of those vids I would probably buy and watch more than a few times.

I don't know how "great" the older Tommy Hilfiger shorts were. Where they the same price as these? I can only judge  what I know from the product I just received. I read where some of the other reviewers were terribly upset. But if I can get a whole year of decent wear out of these shorts (for this price) I will be cool with that. Heck, if I get a year of good wear out of them, well, they beat some other supposedly "awesome" shorts by a long shot. I have a pair of expensive shorts that I paid the same price I paid for four pairs of the TH's for one pair, ( I will not mention the name of those super duper high quality, high wicking, top of the line shorts that have two letters inverted for obvious reasons) that look like $#!+ and they aren't a year old yet. I was looking for some decent underwear that didn't cost a fortune (singly or in multi packs) after looking at dozens of brands, surprisingly, these Tommy Hilfiger shorts were perfect. The price is reasonable for four pairs. Some brands wanted this much for a single pair of underwear!? That's fine for doctors and lawyers, but I'm just a regular dude. Anyway, they feel great. I was looking to get away from the baggy boxers that bunch. I like the form fitting feel of these, they manage to fit but not too tightly and they stretch in any way that I do, and the material feels nice too, without being decadent; too slick or silky (these are MEN'S underwear, not panties, and yet feel like high quality wicking underwear) ..There are no tags or stitch bumps. I am very pleased. I will be getting another four pack immediately so I will have a pair for every day of the week....all my old baggy, faded shorts will be cut up and start their new life as rags! Great buy.

I was thirteen years old when I saw the first Exorcist staring Linda Blair. It. Freaked. Me. Out! People actually got out of their seats and RAN out of the theater! Not because they didn't like the movie, oh no, they rushed up the isle and out the door because they were SCARED! The first time I saw American Werewolf in London, hearing that creature's scream/howl rolling across the moors made the little YIKES hairs on the back of my neck stand on end! I was afraid to look out of a dark window for months...I was afraid that I would see two HUGE eyes staring back at me. When the first Alien came out, it also scared the beejeebees out of me, it was one of the first movies that actually made me nearly jump clean out of my seat! Well, it's been a long time since I saw a REALLY GOOD horror movie, but this movie Annabelle truly had me jumping like I was a teenager again! And this is what confuses me; the so called "critics" only gave this movie 3 1/2 stars...whaaaa!? That's right, you heard me right...three and a half lousy stars...But these same "critics" gave some really LAME artsy fartsy type foreign horror flick FIVE stars...whaaaa!? I'll not mention the name of the (in my opinion) way overrated movie, but I WILL say that it was no where near the movie that Annabelle is. So, I don't know who these critics are, and I don't know how they fill out their score card, but they need to find a new occupation, because they're total nimrods!! And about 1,500 reviewers agreed with me on that sentiment.  As a matter of fact,  I've started paying NO attention whatsoever to what the "critics" say, because I believe they need to have their medications adjusted. Here's a quick summary of Annabelle: A soon-to-be mother receives a collectable doll for a present from her husband. She loves the doll and adds it to her collection. Things are going beautifully for the newlyweds...until a couple of satanic occult nuts crash into their house! I don't want to spoil anything by saying more, but this movie is supposed to have a kernel of truth somewhere in there concerning the doll (creepy, right!?) It's also based on a concept storyline from the movie, The Conjuring. So, I'll be watching The Conjuring next...hmm...I wonder how the "critics" rated it? I think I will just put my trust in what the reviewers say, because, the other reviewers seem to have better taste than the "professionals". Anyway, watch Annabelle and see what you think. See if you don't jump a time or two!

Before I get to the review, first let me say congratulations to Daniel Radcliffe for shaking off the role that made him a household name and moving on with a surprisingly solid performance in this picture. As I watched the movie, I actually forgot all about his previous character, and was drawn in by this NEW character. Radcliffe is a young man now, and he did a splendid job in this dark ghost story. I must shamefully admit that I almost didn't watch the movie because, I too, could not imagine Harry Potter all grown up and having the audacity to try to pass himself off as anyone else BUT our hero from Hogwarts!  Well, he deserves some serious recognition for his acting skills...Because he CAN act in other roles. He CAN make you forget about the young boy that was a famous wizard! Maybe he will NOT suffer the fate of so many others that were forever doomed by playing such a popular role. It's happened time and again and the young superstar tragically fades away into obscurity. And not only did  Radcliffe do good work in this movie, ALL the actors involved did very well. As a matter of fact, I have a hunch that if more people KNEW how good this movie was they would have watched it. But, they were probably still grieving the end of the famous series by JK Rowling! Anyway, I am confident that we will be seeing a lot more of Radcliffe. ***Here's a short summary on this haunting movie: A young and upcoming lawyer is on the verge of losing his job. The depression brought on by the death of his wife during childbirth is beginning to affect every aspect of his life. He gets one more chance to snap out of it before he loses everything. He is sent to settle the affairs of an old estate. But from the very moment he arrives, he is shunned and avoided by the small towns inhabitants. He is warned to stay away from the house, because if he persists, he will bring about the wrath of a vengeful spirit. ***  This was a pretty cool watch. I thought I'd check it out before watching the recently released, The Woman In Black 2... And I am glad I did. Watch this, it's worth the price of a rental.

Okay, this is the Death Wish movie that I personally liked the best. I've watched it time and again. The first two were good also, but when they made this movie, everything about the series was just working really well. When Bronson's character, Paul Kersey, brings out "Willy" the awesome Wildey.475 Magnum, it was just (to me) the epitome of the series. The first Death Wish movie that started it all, had this "rawness" about it: The bizarre background music, the garish seventies styles, and there was little monologue to make the acting too complicated for a cast that were expected to get it right in one or two "takes". The "stylish seventies" fashion that Paul Kersey lives in during the movie,  was displayed so that his character was presented as very "civilized" and a very "modern" type of person, so that when he begins his silent wrathful vengeance, the viewer could grasp the change from the happy and lavish lifestyle of an educated and well off individual, to a fallen down, broken and grieving man who resorts to retribution and vengeance to deal with the futility and impotent rage that all victims are forced to deal with when senseless violence destroys their lives. It's human nature to want revenge, an eye for an eye type justice is very appealing to those that can't get closure or justice for crimes committed against them. But entertaining that fantasy is exactly what made this movie so popular then, AND now. Obviously, in real life, EVERYONE cannot become a vigilante, the days of wild west frontier justice ended for a good reason. But the ideal of taking out your rage on the deserving, is what Death Wish is all about. The sales for the Wildey Magnum would spike every time the rerun of Death Wish 3 would air. It's a shame that Death Wish 4 went so badly. They tried to change a style that the series had established to this point...it did not work. DW 4 was the "jumping the shark" for the Death Wish. The end. Pity.

Oh man, this Death Wish movie was really bad. And I mean 'bad' in a horrible way. The first three movies were vintage Bronson and were each consecutively BETTER: The first Death Wish was a classic, like old muscle cars and old Godzilla movies. It was limited by early seventies cinematography, and the acting and directing were borderline at best, but it a had a certain "style" about it. The bizarre background music, the flashy/gaudy fashion of the day, it was cool because it just all worked together. The second Death Wish was a bit better; the plot just a continuance of the first. Death Wish three was THE BEST. Especially when Bronson "sends for Willy" the monstrous Wildey Magnum Pistol. The third movie reminded me much of Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry movies. BUT, this fourth one was just awful. I surmise that, after acquiring a bigger budget, I think that the producers tried to to change up the directing. I think that this is one of those times that if it's not broken, don't try to fix it, and they lost that rawness prevalent in the first three. Pair the ill attempt to throw more money at the popular Death Wish series to try and make it 'better' and the horribly corny eighties vibe (I think they were going a for futurisic, or a more 'modern' look and feel) then mix in the god-awful acting, and they ended up with really REALLY baaaaaad movie. The first three relied on Bronsons steely gaze, and he portrayed the quite desperation of a victim, a helpless widower pushed over the edge into vigilantism, really well. THIS movie portrays Kersey as being almost as bad as the people he usually deals with in these type of circumstances. They should have left it alone.

Jason Statham is known for his tremendous physically charged action movies and I don't think he ever made a movie that I didn't like. But, for some reason, this particular movie is my favorite I think. His interaction with Young Catherine Chan as Mei was some of his best acting. In most of his films, he's the cool headed, emotionless, lethal powerhouse. His explosive martial arts prowess is pretty dampened impressive. You just can't choreograph talent like he displays. Oh, I'm sure the action segments and fight scenes were indeed choreographed, but you can't just 'teach' that kind of skills 'on the set' ..no...Mr. Statham is a genuine, highly trained individual whom has obviously devoted an amazing amount of effort and determination to his discipline to be that bad @$$. We've established that. But the way he portrayed being 'saved' from a shattered life, a murdered wife, and the razors edge of suicide because the hopeless little Mei needs him; gives him a purpose to not give in to despair but get up and fight, and fight HARD for her is just ...well...great! Here's a quick summary: Stathan's character is an ex police officer that has been betrayed by a corrupt department. They hang him out to dry, letting all the criminals (especially the Russian mafia he'd gone afoul of) tear his life to peices...They let him live. But it's no life. Anyone he talks to, will die. Anyone he gets close to, they'll die. He is not even allowed to live anywhere or it will be destroyed. ..Mei, a small child that has an amazing photographic mind. ANY number, ANY, no matter how long or complex, she can remember it ...perfectly. Flawlessly. The Chinese Mafia use her as a human numbers book. All operations, all payments, all COMBINATIONS, are stored on the wet ware that is her brain. No paper trail. No computers to hack. There's just Mei and her mind. When the information in her head becomes too valuable to let her continue to live less she be compromised and forced to reveal immeasurable wealth and power, she has to flee certain death from her former "fathers"  --vicious gangsters that would blow her brains out in an instant-- knowing this horrible truth about her situation,  she makes a run for it...And she runs smack into Statham just before he makes that fatal 'last step' of his life.... Their eyes meet. The connection made. Both desperate, Both about to die...thinking he's going to die anyway, he wonders, can he do one last meaningful thing before he goes? Freaking awesome! Watch this movie!

I have a (high school) lacrosse player, and he keeps a goal in the side yard.  It's well used - he takes shots on it probably 9 months a year.  After he had had it for about 2 years, there were holes in the net and it looked ratty. At that time I bought him a standard replacement net which he had to string into the goal; it took him a while and a fair bit of cursing.Two years later, that net was looking dingy and ratty.  I kept suggesting he get a new one and he kept resisting-- he didn't want to deal with the replacement.  Then I came across this bungee net and snapped it up (I bought the 'lacrosse' size and it fits a standard lacrosse goal).  Wow, brilliant!  I wish I'd thought of it!Once the ratty net was off, he slipped this new net on in seriously one minute.  It looks great, it stands up to his 18yo varsity attackman shots, and it couldn't be easier.  As an added bonus, it was so easy to slip on that I predict he will take it off for the winter months (something he's never bothered to do before), which will help it to last a long time.  Love it.

I have 2 of these in green - bought from Ikea - that I keep oils and vinegars in near my stove.  I love them!  Super cute, easy to keep clean with a wipe, a good handy size, and they work well standalone or hanging (I have 1 standing on the counter and 1 hanging on a rail right above).I thought I might put some on my bathroom wall as well, so I came here looking to pick up a few more.  I was disappointed to see that a simple $16  enamel 'condiment stand' is selling here for $37.This is a review of the stand, not the price, hence 5 stars.  But buyer beware -- they are half this price at Ikea and come in other colors as well.  If you have an Ikea near you, it's worth the trip.

BEWARE:  DOES NOT COME with access code needed for online homework assignments.  I did call amazon CS and (to my shock, after literally 15 years of all good experiences) I was told nothing can be done, too bad, I should have spent more money if I wanted the full book.  I now HAVE to spend $100 to get access to the rest of the book.  I'm extremely unsatisfied.Note: it does say that the book may not include supplemental materials, which in my lexicon means extra DVDs/CDs, etc.  It does NOT mean that the book is incomplete, but in fact this book did come incomplete.

I used Rosebud Salve in my younger days, and was THRILLED to discover it again when I was searching for a lower cost alternative to Baume de Rose by Terry.  I was thrilled when I got the Rosebud Salve... it smells great, glides on so smoothly, and feels soooo soft.Then, sadly, I read the ingredients: petrolatum, cotton seed oil, and scent.  Petrolatum is petroleum jelly... vaseline!  This is basically perfumed vaseline.Google petroleum products, which are by-products of processing crude oil.  Many think they are carcinogenic. There are a lot of risks to using petrol based products on your face (& mouth!).  Even if you don't believe in the risks, the scientific fact is that petroleum jelly is occlusive and hydrophobic.  Here is one quote: "Petroleum jelly can create the illusion of moisturized, hydrated skin, all the while suffocating your pores. It's water-repellant and not water-soluble, meaning it merely seals the barrier so that moisture does not leave the skin. So while you might feel the instant gratification of a softened surface, you're actually drying out your pores by keeping out air and moisture. "There are tons of natural ingredients, that don't pose the risks of petrol products - such as shea butter, beeswax, coconut oil - that lip balms can be made from.  I for one do not want petroleum jelly on my mouth.

My 17 yo son just bought his first car - a Ford truck with 165,000 miles on it.  I was worried about the battery in this old car, especially since my son doesn't drive every day, so I picked this up for him.  I actually thought it was a battery charger, for a dead battery (it cannot do this if your battery is fully dead) - but he uses it as a battery tender, to keep the battery charged when not in use.PROS, per son:- Easy to attach in 2 ways (clips or washers)- No sparks- No danger of attaching the wrong positive/negative -- it has reverse polarity protection- Plug and play, so to speak -- which is to say, easy to useCONS:- Will not charge a fully dead batteryBOTTOM LINE:  Easy to use and very handy if you have a car that isn't driven regularly

I picked this food up because it's Grain-Free, which is all I feed my fogs, and because I know rabbit to be a quality food source for dogs.  However, further research has made me realize that this formula is only nutritionally 'okay'.  Meat, which dogs need, is not a star here.The first ingredient is potato.  Potatoes are a grain-free carb source, but they are nutritionally empty for dogs!  Further, while rabbit is the second ingredient, it is the only meat in the food.  Most GF foods, by comparison, have multiple meat-sources of protein (e.g. turkey, duck meal, chicken fat, etc). And, raw rabbit has a high water content, which means that after cooking it, the meat content is vastly reduced.  And the third ingredient is potato protein, which is a cheaper plant-based source of protein than meat; it has a lower biological value.  All in all, this food does not offer dogs a good amount of meat.My 2 dog however, loved the taste.  They give it 5 stars.Bottom line:  A decent dog food which apparently is delicious.  But if you're picky about your dog's nutrition, you will find this formula lacking.

I have 2 large dogs, and, like many dog-owners, I stopped buying their favorite jerky treats because of the rash of recalls of toxic jerkies made in China.  I make my own jerky sometimes but it's laborious, so basically jerky has been off the table for a while.So I was happy to see these treats- they are made in the USA, and they are Grain-Free.... which is all I feed my dogs.  My happiness doesn't compare to the rapture of my dogs though!  As soon as I opened they bag they jumped, they wagged, they grinned, they shook with anticipation, they went into paroxysms of joy.So I'm happy that these are a healthy treat, the dogs are ecstatic to get jerky again, and the only downside is that they stink to high heaven.

I got these pants for my son, who needed some dressy pants and liked the look of these.  He's extremely happy with them and wants them in another color too.  He says the waistband, while not elasticized, doesn't pinch or bind.  And he likes that that they pass as dressy while still feeling comfy and looking somewhat casual and cool.  Actually, I'm pretty sure he's never talked this much about a pair of pants in his life.  A big win!

This liner is everything you could want in a shower curtain liner:+ It's heavy, so it doesn't billow out (and let cold air in or water out).+ It's well made and sturdy, and seems highly unlikely to tear; it certainly won't bunch up.+ Mildew-free!  Yay!  Especially b/c it lives in the nasty bathroom of my teen son.+ Rust-proof grommets, yay!What more can you ask for in a shower curtain liner?  I'm happy.

I got these for when my niece is here on the weekends.  My sister-in-law loves them and bought some herself already!PROS:+ Lightweight+ Nipple is shaped like hospital pacifiers+ Shape of the shield fits better under baby's nose+ Seems easy to hold on to without droppingCONS:- None so farBOTTOM LINE:  For my (10 week old) niece anyway, the perfect pacifier!

I picked this shirt up for my 17 yo son; he's a 3-sport varsity athlete and they are required to dress up for game days.  It's a little more casual than some dress shirts I buy him (CK on sale at discount stores), but it looks great on him.PROS:+ The "fitted" cut is like a slim cut (but not an "extreme" slim cut which we bought once by mistake and my son hated). Looks great on an athletic build. I got the 17 neck because his winter sport is wrestling and he has a thick neck.+ Looks great untucked, not sloppy like longer-tailed shirts.  I actually wouldn't have thought of this (single mom, doing my best) except that the product picture shows it untucked.+ Looks great with the top button unbuttoned, not sloppy- just "cool".+ Not completely wrinkle free - but good enough for a teenager if we hang it right after the dryer.BE AWARE:I don't know the "man" name for it, but the collar doesn't look right with a tie.  So if you need a button-to-the-top, wear-with-a-tie shirt, you may not like this.  But for a bit of a casual flair in your dress shirt, this is great.CONS:- As others have said, very thin.  I didn't think I'd care because my son always wears an undershirt with dress shirts anyway... but it also feels really thin (not soft).  Doesn't bother my teen but I don't love it.BOTTOM LINE:Not super-dressy, not super-fitted, just right for slightly dressing up.  In women's terms I'd call this Casual Dressy.

This is a slim case that adds a very small "footprint" to your 5c. Like all slim cases it adds minimal protection, but it gives as much protection as possible given it's style.THE GOOD:+ Covers top and bottom, not just sides (though of course there are holes for your ports etc)+ Cover extends forward a bit to at least somewhat protect your screen should you drop your phone face-down+ Not a brittle plastic, it has a soft texture which makes the phone easier to grip and I think protects it better if dropped+ Semi-translucent back sort of shows off your cute 5c colorBE AWARE:- Screen protector not included- Back is semi-translucent only, not completely clearBOTTOM LINE: Probably as good as you're going to get if you want a slim case.

I'm past my student years, but I use binders at work and they get heavy, heavy use.  They rarely last a year.  So when I'm replacing them I look first for durability, even before other features.  This binder has what I'm looking for, namely:+ 2 pockets on both the inside front and the inside back covers... so 4 inner pockets.  I love this.+ "One touch" opening of rings. It's not that binder rings without this feature are hard labor, but this does make it easy to put pages in and out.+ So far very durable, with reinforced seams.+ You can slide your own pages/covers into the front, back, and spine.  Nice.Bottom Line: Has everything I want in a binder.

My back yard belongs to my dogs, but my front yard belongs to me, and I have several gardens and feeders there; this is by far the best feeder I have.  It's solid, easy to manage, attractive, and very versatile- because the feeder holes are adjustable.THE GOOD:+ Solid and heavy... although it's summer now I imagine that it will withstand bad weather+ SIX feeding ports with perches, so I often have more than one guest hanging out at a time, which I love+ Ports are adjustable - they rotate so you can control size of the hole (and therefore tailor it to your preferred seed)+ Clear tube so you can see your feed level easily+ Looks nice in the front garden+ Handle is also solid-feeling; manages the weight of naughty squirrels who hang on+ Easy to manage: comes assembled, easy to understand the rotating ports, easy to fill if you've ever filled a tube feeder before (ie use a funnel!).BE AWARE:- No squirrel baffleBOTTOM LINE:  A quality feeder, should serve your winged guests well for a long time

We are a competitive game-playing family, especially on vacations.  We have some favorites (Quarto, Bananagrams, Othello), but we are always looking for new favorites too.  This is a nice fast game that everyone enjoys.THE GOOD:+ Easy to learn, without complicated persnickety rules.  5 minutes from unboxing to play.+ Fun!  It's a dice matching game that is part luck and part strategy.+ Moves fast, which my teenagers like.+ Portable, which makes it easy to travel with.  Comes in a small box that holds everything.+ Easy enough for kids to learn, strategic enough to be played by adults.THE BAD:- Really fun to play for a while, but not compelling enough to reach for every day.BOTTOM LINE:Easy to learn, fun to play, moves fast.  A great game for the whole family.

After enduring years of droid-mockery from my teenagers, I finally joined the i-family; I got a 5c because they're cute.  So I didn't want to cover the cuteness up!  I was happy with the look of the (topaz) case, but not with the protection.THE GOOD:+ Cute color with a glossy look+ Very slim profile adds no bulkTHE BAD:- Cheap brittle plastic is not sturdy enough to protect anything- No screen protection- Very little edge protection- wide open at top and bottomBOTTOM LINE:The slim profile is because there is no protection. Can't recommend.

I use a tablecloth probably once or twice a month - for dinner parties, or any special dinner, for birthdays and holidays.  My number one priority is that they be washable.  And when washed I need them to come out of the washer completely clean, and come out of the dryer unwrinkled, unpilled, and looking as they did when they went in.  Second priority: that they look nice, and add something special to my table.  This tablecloth is better at the second than the first.THE GOOD:+ Gorgeous. I have the red/green Jardine and it looks exactly as pictured (not more 'muted').  The colors are lovely and the design is eye-catching.+ It is machine-washable, and colorfast (in cold).+ Yes okay it comes out a little wrinkly, but if you get it right from the dryer and smooth it a bit as you lay it out, you don't need to iron it.  Well, *I* don't iron it... you might if you're a better housekeeper than I (a low bar).  But I don't think it needs it.+ Busy pattern hides small stainsTHE BAD:- Although it's washable, it's not stain-resistant.  Regular stains come out but grease stains do not.  I have fun parties... things get spilled.  And I'm a shoddy housekeeper, as described above, so I don't go over my tablecloth inch by inch looking for stains to pre-treat... I just throw it in.  So I have a small grease stain on it after just a few weeks of use.  I did take one star off for this because I think that in real life, tablecloths get spilled on; they should be able to take it.BOTTOM LINE:  Pretty....a bit impractical if you 're friends with people who spill...

I also own the Rachel Ray lasagna-lugger, so I knew before I got this that I would love it.  Both products carry a variety of dishes safely, and keep them either hot or cold. I love to cook, and I love to bring treats to parties... this RR carrier makes it easy.THE GOOD:+ Holds your dishes safely.  A 9 x 13 brownie/lasagna pan fits perfectly... but you can put smaller dishes in and cushion with a towel.+ Keeps food warm or cold for 2-3 hours.+ Handle makes it easy to manage when you're juggling lots of bags etc+ Inside and out wipe clean+ Smushes flat when not in use...easy to storeTHE BAD:No bad here.BOTTOM LINE:The answer to your prayers if you struggle with how to get your food to pot-lucks.

I picked this CLEAR shampoo up for my teenaged son, who struggles with an itchy flaky scalp- though he doesn't want me to say so online.  We waited 2 weeks to review it so as to give a fair try.  He likes how his scalp feels after he uses it; I don't love the amount of ingredients/chemicals.HE LIKES:+ His scalp feels clean and isn't itchy or flaky+ The light and pleasant smell+ The rich lather+ The easy rinse+ That it's shampoo only, with no conditionerI DON'T LOVE:There are a LOT of ingredients, of which ginseng, tea tree, and mint are pretty much last.  And I know that the rich lather is from a lot of chemicals.  I feel that the botanical-y picture on the front is misleading.BOTTOM LINE:The person who uses it, like it.

I am a frequent baker, and was very happy to pick this plastic spatula up so I could remove brownies/bars neatly, but without scratching my aluminum pans.  It works great in this capacity, though I don't really enjoy cutting the brownies with it.PROS:+ As advertised, it's flexible enough to slip beneath a brownie yet firm enough to lift the brownie/bar neatly out+ It's plastic, so no scratching of my good aluminum bakeware+ It's a good width (not too wide like many plastic spatulas) for a single serving of a bar or brownie+ Beveled edges do a neat job of working the edges away from the pan+ Lightweight yet solid-feeling, comfortable in the handCONS:- It says you can cut your brownies with it, and I guess you technically can, but it's awkward.  I use a plastic knife to cut, and the spatula to lift out.BOTTOM LINE:Great size, great that it's plastic, perfect for lifting baked bars neatly out of a pan without scratching it.  Not fabulous at cutting the bars.

I picked up this BOOMco Blaster for my college son, whose obsession is his Humans vs Zombies Club (a nerf battle club, very big on college campuses).  He was THRILLED to get it.  He says the guns are better than Nerf Guns and his only concern is if they will be 'legal' for his club (more on that below).THE GOOD- PER HvZ PLAYER:+ Much faster shooting than nerf guns, because instead of cock-fire-reload, you cock and fire (and the reload happens automatically).  The only limitation on your firing speed is how fast you can move your arm back and forth.+ Special dart cartridge can't jam, and is fast because the pulling back you do to cock the gun moves the cartridge along and you are instantly ready to fire.+ Surprise one-time-use multi-firing ability.  If you preload 3 darts, they will fire simultaneously, while you're regularly firing, when you trigger it.+ Same distance and accuracy as a nerf gun; faster dart speed+ Sticky tips of dart stick well to targets and other BOOMco surfaces- including your pop-up 'blast shield' (so you can capture your opponent's darts!).+ Plastic darts are sleeker, cleaner, and easier to clean than foam dartsTHE WE'LL SEE:Darts are a light plastic, not foam, and the guns do NOT take Nerf darts. (I didn't mark off for this because they don't claim that they will.)  My son immediately posted on his group's page, asking if he'll be able to use these guns and darts in the HvZ battles.  Apparently their leader had already heard of these guns and has ordered some to trial, to see if they'll be ok.  I will update with the verdict.BOTTOM LINE:New style dart-gun, with several excellent features that make it faster and easier to fire.  Darts are plastic, not foam.

I'm a PT and also the Mom of a fairly hard-core athlete.  Between us we enjoy trying various workout tools and gadgets.  I liked the idea of the Push-Up Pump as a way for people who can't do push-ups on their own to enjoy the benefits that push-ups offer.  But this thing is so bulky and cumbersome that it may not be worthwhile.THE PROS:+ Not too hard to set up - about 20 minutes+ It does indeed allow almost anyone to do a push-up with good form, because it supports you at the chest and you push your arms down and up+ 3 positions for your hands, to get at different muscles+ Comes with 3 resistance bands so that the stronger athlete can also benefitTHE CONS:- This is not small or foldable in any way. It's bulky and oddly shaped and it doesn't just tuck away anywhere.- Your body does not go all the way down, as it would with a traditional push-up.  As a result, most of the work comes from shoulders and arms, and less from your chest.- Does not actually give a "full body" workout,  I would argue that it gives LESS of a full body work-out than a regular push-up (which will work your core).  Core and legs are not worked.BOTTOM LINE:  Can help a beginner to do a push-up with good form, but since it doesn't precisely mimic a push-up (doesn't fully work chest, doesn't work core) and since it's kind of cumbersome, it may be more worth your time to start with modified push-ups.

Wow is this nasty. It's like old popcorn with flavored chalk dust coating it, and gagging you with every bite.  I ate half the bag for the purpose of the review and then went and brushed my teeth 3 times and thought about gargling with bleach. Blech.THE GOOD:+ Ummmm....I guess it's technically edible?THE BAD:- It's not only gross tasting, it's gross FEELING in your mouth, coating your tongue with chalk-dust in a gag-worthy manner.BOTTOM LINE:Cannot recommend to anyone, at all.

I'm a middle-aged woman, and I have dry dry skin and dry dry hair.  Yuck.  I use this luxurious blend of 10 oils on my skin (face & body) and on my hair (as a leave-in conditioner) and it's like a magical moisture-elixir.THE GOOD:+ Blend of 10 nourishing oils+ Rich without being unpleasantly thick+ Makes both skin and hair soft and supple and pliant+ A little goes a long way: 1 pump for face, 2-3 for body, 1/2 pump for hairTHE BAD:No bad here.  Not even the cost - because it lasts a long time.BOTTOM LINE:Softens, smooths, saturates with moisture.  Love!

I have 2 cats, and 2 litter boxes.  I am on the perpetual quest for the perfect litter system... I have not found such a thing (*sigh*) but this Litter Genie at least helps.  It makes it convenient to scoop, and it reduces odor. Love.THE GOOD:+ Once set up, this is very easy to use.  You scoop your box, open the lid & drop your scoops in, and slide a handle to seal the odors away.  When full, toss the whole bag without touching anything yucky.+ Lasts about 2 weeks days before being full+ Makes it SUPER convenient to scoop... you don't have to hunt around for a bag, you don't have to go throw your bag in the outside trash, the genie is right there waiting to accept your nuggets of yuck.+ Saves on plastic... I use one plastic bag for 14+ days (instead of 14 bags)!+ Seals smells away+ You don't need to use the Litter Genie refills.  I use scented kitchen bags.THE BAD:- I found it confusing to set up the first timeBOTTOM LINE:Anything that makes litterbox cleaning more convenient is good for you and your cats!

I cook a lot, and I use tea towels for the following purposes: to throw over my shoulder as I cook; to cover rising doughs; to hang on the oven handle to dry hands; to lay on the counter for hand-washed items to drip dry on.  These towels perform well in all 4 capacities - and they're pretty!WHAT WORKS:+ I mostly use tea towels over one shoulder as I cook, to wipe my hands on as I handle ingredients.  These towels work great in this capacity because they are big (20" x 30") so they don't fall off - as shorter towels often do when I bend to open the oven, etc.+ I also make a lot of dough - pizza dough, bread dough, sticky buns, etc.  When dough rises it has to be left in a warm place and covered.  Again, these towels are excellent in this capacity as they are big enough to cover a baking pan, a large bowl, whatever.+ When not in use as above, I hang my tea towels on the oven handle for people to dry their hands on after washing.  While these towels are not super-absorbent, they are certainly absorbent enough to dry hands.+ The few items I don't throw in the dishwasher (knives, vitamix, etc), I like to lie on a tea towel to drip dry.  Doubled, these towels are absorbent enough for this task, and they're not so "slippy" that items slide off of them.+ They are machine washable, or I would never use them.  They say (like all linen) that they need to be ironed, but I don't iron these as they are functional more than decorative, and I don't care about a few wrinkles.+ They are a pretty splash of color (albeit a bit reminiscent of Sleeping with the Enemy towels!)WHAT MAY NOT WORK:- If you intend to dry really sopping wet things with them, they may not be absorbent enough to handle this- If you use your tea towels (instead of potholders) to take things out of the oven with - they may not be thick enough to handle this- I see some reviewers talking about using these on their dining table, which I don't totally understand as they are for kitchen use- they are not napkins... but if you want to use them on a formal table you'd probably have to iron them or take them immediately out of a hot dryer.BOTTOM LINE:Oversized and pretty, they work well for everything I use a tea towel for.  They may not be thick or absorbent enough for what you use a tea towel for.

About a year ago I got a fancy new Samsung dishwasher, but I was so disappointed because, from the start, things were not getting very clean. The knives especially were coming out with baked-on crud all over them.  I called the store to complain about my defective new dishwasher, and they told me to try Cascade Pacs instead of the liquid that I was using.  And it worked!  The new dw immediately started to perform, and everything comes out shiny and clean, every time.Why I use them:*** My dishes get perfectly spotlessly clean.  That's the bottom line for me, and everything else is just extra.Also nice:* Throwing a tab in is super convenient* I like the bucket because it squats patiently under my sink, never tipping over or taking on leaks, and it can be re-purposed (crayons! legos!) or recycled.note: these are phosphate-free, my old cascade pacs were phosphate-free, they get the dishes perfectly clean, and phosphate-free is good for the planet.BOTTOM LINE: They work.  The best.  If you want clean dishes, they won't fail you.

This is my first time using a Natural Spectrum lamp, though I've been considering getting one for years - I moved to the East Coast from CA and still miss all that good CA sunshine.I use it a little in the morning but honestly I rush around so much in the mornings that I don't know that I get any benefit at that time; I don't feel any different.  However where I do note a difference is when I use it after work... you know, when you've worked all day and picked up your kids and made dinner and you just want to collapse and veg but sometimes you still have work or bills or what have you?  Those times?  THAT'S when I notice a difference.  Placebo or not, I feel more energized for a few hours.Note: I do not use it as a reading light in bed because I'm getting ready to be asleep and usually don't use any light at all (Kinde paperwhite).  I also have not used it in the winter because I have only had it for a month.What I like is that it has a small footprint and also that it does work for me in the afternoons.  What I question, based on superficial research, is whether 5000 lux is enough.  Some sites say that 10,000 lux is ideal.BOTTOM LINE: Portable, easy to use, and I do feel more energized when using it.

I chose this bath rug for my college son's bathroom, because even during his infrequent visits he manages to leave the bathmat sopping on the floor to the point that the baseboards are starting to rot.  I wanted a rug that was absorbent and dried quickly, but that also was flexible enough to be hung up to dry (memory foam mats, for example, are hard to hang).  This bathmat meets those criteria AND is super soft on the tootsies.  Win.THE GOOD:+ Very very soft on the toes of drippy careless boys+ Sucks the water off of drippy careless boys+ Keeps water trapped inside without soaking through to the floor+ Dries quickly if left on the floor, but also can easily be thrown over the shower bar to dry+ Machine washableTHE BAD:- No bad yetBOTTOM LINE:Soft, absorbent, quick-drying.  Awesome.

I love Fekkai hair products - they have a hair mask that is incredible - and this Pot de Creme product is no exception.  I am middle-aged, with dry middle-aged, over processed hair.  It can look really scraggy, ugh.  And it can feel stiff and cotton-candyish, double ugh.  I use the Pot de Creme 2-3 times a week, primarily as a leave-in conditioner (ie on damp hair).  It makes my yucky hair so pretty!  And it isn't greasy.  Love.PROS:+ Smells fantastic, like all Fekkai products.+ Makes your hair very very soft and healthy feeling.  Suddenly I can run my fingers through my hair!+ Does NOT weigh your hair down (and I have very fine hair), or feel sticky.  (Note - I have a chin-length bob and I use a quarter-sized amount, and start about 2" below the roots...)  It really disappears into your hair.+ Tames the East Coast Humidity Frizzies+ Though I consider it more of a conditioner than a styling, aid, it does act as a light styling product, like a light mousse would.CONS:None yet.BOTTOM LINE:Makes me feel like tossing my hair in slow motion as I run through a field of daisies.  Hair is soft, soft, soft-- and smells great!

I'm kind of an organization-phile, and I was excited to get this to keep travel papers (hotel confirmations, mapquest printouts, notes to self, boarding passes, etc) all together on vacation.  But to me it's too flimsy for this; I do not feel comfortable keeping important papers here.  So I use it for recipes, and it works fine for those.THE GOOD:+ 3 full (letter-sized) sections plus a front section+ Front section closes with velcro+ If you do use it for travel it should fit in your carryon (though not your purse!)THE BAD:- Super-flimsy plastic is maddeningly floppy- Super-flimsy little 'tabs' hold the big sections shut- and not very securely- It doesn't feel secure enough to me to use for travel.BOTTOM LINE:OK for organizing some things, but very flimsy.  I use mine for recipes.

I picked this up because I spend a good bit of my life at my kids' sporting events - especially lacrosse.games.  The sun gets brutal.  I bring folding chairs, and this baby clips right on with no trouble (and we somehow have 3 different chairs).  It's weight and versatility are great, but it's a bit small and the clamp works on most chairs - but not all.THE GOOD:+ Lightweight, and comes in it's own carrying bag.  Love this.+ Versatile - clips onto all of our folding chairs.+ Gives good sun protection.+ Swivels; easy to adjust.THE BAD:- Does not clip onto everything- it won't work on my back deck chairs, which I am pretty disappointed about.- It's a bit small, though if you fuss with the positioning you can get pretty good coverage.BOTTOM LINE:  I like it and use it regularly.  I recommend it.  But if it was just a bit bigger and if it worked everywhere, it'd be perfect.

This is an anti-perspirant and deodorant, which bills itself as offering "clinical protection".  It definitely kept me dry during the normal course of my day (kids/dogs/work/walk)... but I can't say that it kept me drier than my regular Dove anti-perspirant.THE GOOD:+ Smooth going on+ Inoffensive smell+ WorksTHE BAD:- Will leave white marks on your shirts- I notice no difference in protection between this and cheaper (non clinical strength) productsTHE WEIRD:Packaging advises putting the product on at bedtime.  Huh?  From everything I've read, wearing these chemical-laden products is bad enough, at least let your skin breathe overnight!  It also says you can put it on at night & take a shower the next day, and not need to reapply.  Which I find scary.BOTTOM LINE:  Works, but not notably better than other anti-perspirant/deodorants.

I make pizza every Sunday.  I've tried many shapes and sorts of pizza wheels, and this is the best ever!  Sharp, nicely weighted, and has special divots to stop sticking.  I use it for more than pizza and I love it!THE GOOD:+ Comfortable in the hand and well-weighted for precision cutting.+ Has "kullens" on the wheel; they help stop the cheese from sticking+ Sharp blade cuts well- no "back and forth" needed+ Cuts through pizza, quesedillas, pastry dough, sausage rolls, hot sandwiches, etc+ Comes in a fancy boxTHE BAD:- I wish there was a cover , to protect the blade- Comes in a fancy box... which looks cool & would be good for gifting, but really who has room for that in their kitchen?  After 2 weeks I recycled it.BOTTOM LINE:  Excellently made pizza wheel that cuts through on the first pass and feels good in the hand.

My 16 yo is a varsity lacrosse player; he wears a mouthguard most days of the year- between fall ball, winter ball, the regular season, and summer tournaments.  We've had a lot of mouthguards.I gave the Challenger to him and after he fitted it to his teeth he declared it the most comfortable mouthguard he's ever used.  He says it's the most breatheable, very easy to put in and take out, and the easiest to talk through he's ever had.  Great!  It's a keeper and we'll buy this brand again the next time we're in the market.

I don't play baseball, but my oldest son does.  I picked these up for him and he reports (from college) that they are the best batting gloves he has ever had.  They are in pre-season now, and he reports:THE GOOD:+ Very comfortable.+ Breathe well and don't get too hot.+ Grippy yet they release well (he says like the boots Cinna designs for Katniss in Mocking Jay).+ Look cool.THE BAD:Nothing.BOTTOM LINE:Baseball-playing son says best gloves ever!

I have dry, damaged, middle-aged, colored-for-forty-years hair, and I need to use an (in-shower) conditioner daily.  I really enjoy this leave-in, but I still need the in-shower conditioner.THE GOOD:+ I love the smell.  Not overpowering but pleasant, with a trace of the tea-tree oil.+ Not heavy or greasy.  At all.+ In the winter it helps with my yucky flyaways.  I assume that in the summer it will help with frizz.  And chlorine.THE HMMMM:- When I use it alone, without an in-shower conditioner, I have knots and tangles and my hair is just not moisturized enough.  When I use it  after a shampoo-and-condition, it does make a nice adjunct, but it isn't enough by itself.BOTTOM LINE:A nice light leave-in, with a nice smell.  Perhaps not enough for you if you have very dry hair.

This is a tea mug without a handle, but with a velvety "touch surface" to protect your hand from heat. It also boasts a (superflous) 'teabag slot'. Sure you can protect your hand with a handle, and you can retrieve your teabag with your spoon, but I just like the heft, the feel of this cup ..so I use it regularly.The GOOD:+ Balanced and smooth, not too thin and not too thick, with interesting touch surface; it just feels good in your hand.+ Touch surfaces protect you from heat.+ Teabag slot for your teabag end.+ Dishwasher safe. I put EVERYTHING -except my good knives- in the dishwasher. I won't own it if it can't go in the dishwasher.THE BAD:- If you like to hold your mug by the handle, well, you can't with this.- Touch surfaces don't protect from boiling water temps.- Teabag slot makes it easy for uncoordinated people like me to spill.BOTTOM LINE: There's nothing here you absolutely need, but if you appreciate how a mug feels in your hand you may love this - as I do.

I have a keurig at home and at work, so I certainly go through a lot of K-cups.  And when I have friends over I like to put out a bowl of different coffees so everyone can make their own.  This nice big box of Brooklyn Beans K-cups certainly fits the bill for those needs.  However,most of the varieties are light-medium and the dark roast varieties are more like medium-dark.THE GOOD:+ GREAT variety!  40 K-cups in 16 varieties!+ Great variety of varieties: about half are 'flavored' coffees (caramel, vanilla, hazelnut, etc) and half are a range of roasts from breakfast to 'dark'.+ Well made cups, no breakage or leakingTHE NITPICK:- I do like the Cyclone and the Fuhgeddaboutit, their darker roasts, but these are in the minority and not deep dark.BOTTOM LINE:If you like a variety or buy for a family or office with different tastes, this is an excellent sampler.  If you like only dark roasts, you may find these brews a bit light for you.

I'm a physical therapist and also a home-exercise junkie.  (And also a mom to a varsity athlete who I am continually 'prescribing' new exercises to).  I use therapy balls pretty much every day at work, and I've gone through many at home. (Sometimes the kids pop them, sometimes the dogs, and sometimes they just die a slow leaky death...)  I was happy to get a new ball for home, and this is an excellent one.THE GOOD:+ Very nice thick durable construction+ Good size that fits both my son (5'11") and me (5'6")+ Exercises printed right on there.  I love this!  Especially if you're working out in front of TV and not with a DVD.THE NOT GREAT:- Comes with a hand pump.  That's a lot of work!  I used my foot pump.THE EXERCISES:There are 11 strength/stability exercises (the ones that say 'reps') and 5 stretches (the ones that say 'hold').  As a PT, I like them all.  You don't need to be a golfer (I am not); these exercises offer strengthening for upper body, lower body, and a lot of core.  The stretches hit the major muscle groups as well.  That said, this is NOT for the brand-new exerciser.  For one thing, while the drawings do demonstrate the exercises to anyone who has worked on a ball before, if you are new to the ball you may not understand or do them correctly.  Additionally, these are some tough exercisers that in my opinion are for the intermediate - advanced exerciser. There are several upper back exercises which have you prone over the ball... super-effective but you'd better be doing it right or you could hurt your neck.  And some of the exercises, like knee tucks and split squats, are too hard for a beginner.BOTTOM LINE:Well-made ball with the great advantage of having 16 well-designed exercises printed right on it to help cue you.  Make sure you have done some ball workouts with a PT or fitness instructor first though, so your form is good and you can manage these tough exercises.

Author Daniel de Vise', the brother-in-law of Don Knotts has written an engaging book on a true-to-life friendship between Andy Griffith and Don Knotts primarily on their classic comedy show The Andy Griffith Show which aired on television during the 1960s.  This was back in the day when comedy on television was truly funny and the success of the show may very well have been due to the real life friendship that existed between the two.This book will be especially interesting to those who remember the relationship between sheriff Andy Taylor and his deputy Barney Fife.  The author relates various episodes of this series and they will be easily remembered by those familiar with the show.  Various other cast members such as Jim Nabors (Gomer Pyle), Francis Bavier (Aunt Bee), Ron Howard (Opie Taylor), and others are introduced into the book as well.  Omitted from those mentioned was the actor who played Briscol Darling and Ernest T. Bass.Both Don and Andy grew up in difficult circumstances and the book relates the difficulty aspiring actors face in gaining employment.  I remember the classic radio show called "Bobby Benson and the B-Bar-B-Riders" and was surprised that it was Don Knotts who spoke the part of Windy Wales who always referred to Bobby as "Little Boss."  Griffith, known for his real life temper mentions that he wished he could behave in real life as he did in the television show.Both Don and Andy were married three times with each one having personal problems that many other individuals have as well.  Even after the show had run its course both men continued to see one another and maintain their friendship.  I guess you could call it a modern day Damon and Pythias relationship.The end of the book summarizes twenty memorable episodes of The Andy Griffith Show that are especially memorable.  Notably absent from my viewpoint is the one where Andy tells Opie that history is difficult and teacher Helen Crump enters the sheriff's office and chastises Andy for butting into her line of work.If you remember The Andy Griffith Show from watching it during its popularity or from reruns you will be sure to enjoy this book.

Author Doug Wilson has scored another hit with his latest biography on Carlton Fisk.  Fisk divided his 24 years behind the plate with both the Boston Red Sox and Chicago White Sox.  What I especially enjoyed about the book is that it wasn't a year-by-year and play-by-play of games in which he took part.
