To me Fisk's two most memorable moments in his baseball career would be his historic home run in game six of the 1975 World Series and his chastising of opposing player Deon Sanders for not running out a pop fly ball.  Any baseball fan would remember game six and where they were at the time but Fisk calling out Sanders for not respecting the game is very memorable to me as well.  Pudge took part in more games behind the bat than any other catcher.  However, in order to accomplish that fete he had to punish his body in the workout room even after catching a full game and for a neophyte like Sanders to disrespect the game was too much for Fisk even though it was a player on the opposing team.Fisk played more games for Chicago than for Boston and there was some question as to which hat he would wear on his Hall of Fame plaque since he left both teams under uncomfortable circumstances.  Fisk initially chose Chicago since he played more games there but later changed his mind to Boston.  Everyone has someone we especially remember in our field of work who influenced us the most and the choice for Fisk was batting coach Walt Hriniak.Whatever one's line of work we need to give our best effort and this book on Carlton Fisk makes good reading for young readers as well to emphasize the importance of respecting our line of work whether it be baseball or anything else.  I have author Doug Wilson's books on Mark Fidrych and Brooks Robinson and his latest effort on Carlton Fisk is another important addition to my library.

Author Dan D'Addona has done a commendable job in reviewing the careers of Sam Crawford, Harry Heilmann, and Heinie Manush of the Detroit Tigers.  The text is 202 pages long and is divided as follows:  Sam Crawford--Page 3 through 123  Harry Heilmann--Page 125 through 168  Heinie Manush--Page169 through 202I do not quibble with the facts the author presents.  However, the book is mainly a season-by-season review of games played loaded with individual play-by-play as to who went 2 for 4 and the final score of games.  This, to me, is not a story of each player.  Rather, it is a review of the seasons of the Detroit Tigers in which each of these players took part.  The author also relies on newspaper accounts of games and a heavy emphasis on statistics.The part I found to be the most interesting was reading about the broadcasting career of Harry Heilmann with the Tigers once his playing career was over,  The author summarizes as to why each player has been largely forgotten by today's fans.If you want to review the seasons each of these hall-of-fame players took part then I am sure you enjoy the book.  However, if you are looking for a story of each of these players then you won't find it in this book.

I have never  heard of author Charles Fountain and I wondered what, if anything, someone else could write about the 1919 World Series that hasn't been covered by another individual in the past.  I believe this book along with "Burying the Black Sox" by Gene Carney do the best job of digging into the archives regarding the Black Sox scandal.  I feel author Fountain has done meticulous research in his search for the truth in regard to those who were involved at the time be they players, owners, or gamblers.  We have American League President Ban Johnson and his once friend and now bitter enemy White Sox owner Charles Comiskey along with another fierce foe, newly-elected Commissioner Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis who has now pushed Johnson into the background of his beloved game.  We also have the eight affected players and the gamblers who ended up double-crossing one another when the money wasn't forthcoming.  Gamblers Abe Attell, Sport Sullivan, Billy Maharg, Nat Evans, and "The Big Bankroll" himself, Arnold Rothstein all have their respective rolls laid out.  Sportswriters such as Ring Lardner, Hugh Fullerton, Jimmy Isaminger, and J. G. Taylor Spink of The Sporting News were featured writers at the time.  Lardner never had the same love for baseball after this scandal came to light and turned his writing to other subjects.Author Charles Fountain acknowledges that several sources are no longer available for research but he does an admirable job with the material that is available.  Each of the eight affected players give their version as to whether or not they played to win.  They admit to taking money but there appears to be questions regarding the effort put forth during the games.  I have two letters from J. G. Taylor Spink of The Sporting News in which I asked him questions regarding the 1919 World Series which I am accompanying with this review in which he states, "They were all guilty."Based on the research available to author Charles Fountain I feel he has provided the reader with a first-rate book on the 1919 World Series.  It is aptly entitled "The Betrayal" since both sides betrayed the other and despite attempts to cover up the scandal it continued to fester during the off-season and into the 1920 season when it burst into full bloom.  The book contains two sections of photographs of several of the prominent individuals involved.

Author Norman Macht has completed his monumental work in his three-part trilogy on Connie Mack.  Part three on the Lean Leader lives up to the previous works and they belong in anyone's baseball library.  What I like about these three books is the ample use of anecdotes about the individuals involved in Mr. Mack's life as opposed to a year-by-year account of games played during the baseball season.  The author uses humor effectively throughout the book which makes for lively reading.  Examples are when Earle Mack would go to the mound to remove a pitcher from the game and say, "Daddy wants you to come out of the game."  The pitcher may reply by saying, "Tell Daddy to go to hell."  Another example is of pitcher Bobo Newsom who was being given a hard time regarding his age by pitcher Ray Scarborough, he of the big nose, and six foot four string bean Sid Hudson in the dugout.  Newsom told them he reminded them of a firetruck--hook and ladder.  The story may or may not be true but I found it to be funny, nonetheless.Mr. Mack had his share of pennant and World Series winners but also had to divest himself of star players when he was unable to pay them what they were worth.  An example would be George Kell who he knew would become a great player but dealt him to Detroit for Barney McCosky.  Mr. Mack was also known to say, although not mentioned in the book, that he dealt off players because "the fans got tired of watching us win."  This I have on a phonograph record entitled  "Baseball--An Action History."  Part three of this trilogy contains many of the lean years of the Philadelphia Athletics involving a number of supernumeraries who passed through the roster of the team.  His players, for the most part, realized he was paying them what he was able to based on the team's finances.  One of his young players was the diminutive Jacob Nelson Fox who eventually went on to stardom with the Chicago White Sox in which the Athletics received catcher Joe Tipton.  The author describes Fox "buzzing around second base like a hungry mosquito in a bedroom at midnight."  I thought this was a beautiful simile.The chapter on the eventual sale of the team to Kansas City interests led by Arnold Johnson I found to be very complicated and I admit to having skimmed through it.  I remember when it took place but the conflict between Earle and Roy Mack made it extremely difficult to follow and get interested in.  I'm quite sure other readers will find it to be as well.Mr. Mack lists his favorite player as Al Simmons and his finest moment to be when he sent his surprise starter Howard Ehmke to pitch the first game of the 1929 World Series in which Ehmke struck out a record thirteen Chicago Cubs.  The book contains numerous photos which I have not seen in other baseball books.  I also enjoyed reading about players I knew only from 1950s baseball cards such as Joe Astroth, Eddie Joost, Carl Scheib, and Gus Zernial.  Author Norman Macht is to be both thanked and congratulated for this three part work which greatly contributes to any individual's baseball library.

A biography on Lesley Gore is needed and author Trevor Tolliver has done a commendable job in relating her life to the reader.  I did feel there was too much of an emphasis on cataloging one song after another and whether or not it became a hit.  I am familiar with about five of her songs and the scouting report, if you will, regarding songs that she sang at one time or another became too tedious to me.Lesley hit it big as a high school student in New Jersey with her signature song entitled "It's My Party."  She experienced some negative feedback from some jealous students at her school as a result.  By the time she was twenty-six years old she became something of a has-been.  When the nostalgia craze for 60s music hit the country once again her music became a hot item.  The author spends some time regarding her thirty year relationship with partner Lois Sasson.I found the book and interesting read but I felt I could have been told more about Lesley Gore's life rather than such a heavy emphasis on several songs I've never heard of.  The book also contains two sets of colored photographs.

Author Ryan D'Agostino has written an interesting book centered around the brutal killing of the wife and two children of Dr. William Petit on July 23, 2007.  Some reviewers may criticize the author spending time on the family prior to the attack but I feel this is necessary to acquaint the reader with their relationship to one another and appreciate the tragic loss which was to follow.  True, not much time is spent on the actual crime nor are the names of the two individuals given prior to the trial itself.  This was fine with me because the importance of the book is on Dr. Petit and his family and subsequent recovery to begin yet a new family and not on the perpetrators of the crime itself.Dr. Petit needed and received a tremendous outpouring of support not only from his Connecticut community but also from those across the country and this is correctly emphasized in the book.  Not only was he beaten and miraculously survived but his wife and two daughters were murdered and his house burned.  It took several years for Dr. Petit to come to grips with such a loss both physically and mentally and with the assistance of others he has managed to go on with his life with a new wife and child.This book is a story of tragedy and survival rather than a concentration of the horrific crime itself.  I would have preferred  larger photos in the book of Dr. Petit's family members and those who played a large part in his life.  I would not need photos of the two individuals responsible for this crime.  The less focus on them the better.

Grover Cleveland Alexander was alcoholic, epileptic, his own worst enemy, and one of the best pitchers ever in baseball history.  Author John Skipper has written a wonderful book on "Old Low and Away" in which the reader is exposed to both the greatness of his pitching abilities and his off-the-field nightmares that Alexander had to live with.  Old Pete toiled for the Philadelphia Phillies, Chicago Cubs, and St. Louis Cardinals.  He didn't get along with new Cubs' manager Joe McCarthy due to his alcohol addiction but what isn't mentioned in the book is that McCarthy, himself, had his own battle with the bottle.  Alexander had to scrounge for any employment he could find while other baseball notables such as National League President Ford Frick and St. Louis Cardinals' owner Sam Breadon did their best to keep Alexander afloat financially for the remainder of his life.  Alex had aged beyond his years due to his hard living with his numerous bouts with alcohol.  His wife Aimee attributed this problem to his experiences in World War I while his problem with epilepsy she attributed to Alex being hit in the head while a base runner when the fielder threw the ball to first base.Following his baseball career Alexander spent a few years with the House of David baseball team and in a Times Square flea circus in which he regaled people with his strikeout of New York Yankee Tony Lazzeri in the 7th inning of the final game of the 1926 World Series. He spent his final days writing letters to his beloved ex-wife Aimee and hating his town of St. Paul, Nebraska, because they would not serve him any alcoholic beverages.Alexander believed he retired with the National League record with 373 victories until a researcher discovered an extra victory entitled to New York Giants' star hurler Christy Mathewson.  Alex wasn't among the charter members of the 1936 election to the Baseball Hall of Fame.  Instead he had to wait until 1938 to be elected and many believe this was due to his off-the-field problems which was felt to be an embarrassment to baseball.  Other players had their own embarrassing moments which didn't taint their earlier election.This book rates a definite five stars and John Skipper has provided the reader with an important book on baseball history.

First off let me say my rating of four stars is based on my background on this subject.  Most certainly author David Preston rates five stars for this monumental amount of research he has done is piecing together the road General Edward Braddock blazed on his way to the disaster that awaited him and his soldiers on their way to the French Fort Duquesne at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela River at present-day Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.  It was a herculean achievement just to blaze a trail and lead this British army 300 miles through the wilderness of the Allegheny mountains in addition to dealing with snakes, mosquitoes, ticks, blistering hot weather, and other annoyances.  By the time they reached approximately twelve miles north of Fort Duquesne on July 9, 1755, many were too tired and worn out to begin fighting the French and their Indian allies.  Braddock was severely injured and died a few days later.I appreciated the fact that the author provided ample maps throughout the book to follow where various places were located.  Other books I have read haven't necessarily provided this service.  Photos of notable individuals were also illustrated, several of which later appeared in America's War for Independence namely George Washington, Thomas Gage, Horatio Gates, and Daniel Morgan.  A sickly George Washington took part in The Battle of the Monongahela and one can't help but wonder what would have been the result of the Revolutionary War had Washington not survived this battle.It wasn't until John Forbes and his men wrested Fort Duquesne away from the French in 1758 who blew up the fort rather than turn it over to the British.  The fort was rebuilt and named Fort Pitt. The American version of The French and Indian War took place in the years 1754--1763 and author David Preston makes history come alive in this very important book.  I learned a lot and I had a lot to learn even though I struggled at times with the book.

With all of the favorable reviews I am going to go out on a limb and rate the book three stars whereas 2 1/2 would be more accurate.  Andy Pafko led the life of a gentleman and stated his Christian faith at the end of the book.  While he considered himself a Cub he also played on  the fabled Brooklyn Dodgers of Roger Kahn's book The Boys of Summer in addition to being dealt to the Braves just as they transferred their team to Milwaukee from Boston.  Therefore, Pafko, a Wisconsin, played most of his career close to home.Why then the low rating for the book?  The captions beneath the photographs were very small and hard to read.  I also found much too much emphasis on game-by-game coverage and I felt over-whelmed by the amount of statistics in the book.  If you don't mind being deluged with each of these items then I'm sure you will enjoy the book more than I did.

I hate to say, "I love it" for such a tragic story as this one.  It is a cliche for one to say they found the book hard to put down but such was the case with this book.  Author Jeannine Cummins relates the story of her bother and their two cousins when the Cummins' family visited their relatives in St. Louis, Missouri.  I need not relate the tragedy here as several reviewers has already done that.  Suffice it to say the cruelty individuals can do to others knows no bounds whatsoever.  The 1924 case of Leopold and Loeb murdering Bobby Franks was solved due to a pair of glasses.  The case in this book was solved due to a flashlight in addition to the survival of Tom Cummins.After all the heartache and difficulties that Tom Cummins had to endure to survive this ordeal the punishment from the St. Louis police department was inexcusable.  Anything to "solve" a case never mind whether we have the correct individual/s or not.The book contains photos of the Cummins and Kerry family in addition to photos of the Chain of Rocks Bridges north of St. Louis.  If you want to find photos of the sickos who are responsible for this heinous crime you'll have to go to the internet.  I can certainly understand author Jeanine Cummins not wanting to contaminate her book by placing photos of these individuals in her book.This book is true crime at its worst.  My sincere sympathy to both the Cummins and Kerry family for what they have had to endure.

I am rating this book two stars whereas 2 1/2 would be more accurate.  Gene Mauch is most definitely a worthy subject for a book but I found the writing to leave a lot to be desired.  I found the book to contain too much game-by-game coverage in addition to including too many paragraphs with only one or two sentences.  I realize Gene Mauch could be a combative individual but I found too much coverage on his on-the-field scraps with opposing players.  Gene modeled the uniform of several teams in his career but I also found too much coverage of every individual who was included in each transaction.  Much of this information could be found by doing research.  The book contains photographs spaced throughout the book.  Page 24 contains the error of Brooklyn Dodgers' infielder Billy Cox referred to as Bobby.  I would like to be able to rate this book higher but I found the book to be a disappointment.

Author Rinker Buck has done a commendable job in relating the journey he, his brother, and their dog took retracing across the trail from St. Joseph, Missouri, to Oregon.  The book provides a brief history of each of the notable landmarks such as Chimney Rock and Scotts' Bluff in Nebraska and Independence Rock in Wyoming and then the author relates their experience in each particular area.  Mules were much preferred as were oxen in leading the wagons as opposed to horses.  Each side of the Platte River in Nebraska were used as a highway westward with the Oregon Trail not being one set of ruts across the plains but was actually a twelve mile trail, six miles on each side of the Platte River.  Cholera was a disease that victimized many of the travelers and was carried by bacteria in water pools along the Platte.I found maps to be helpful which highlighted places mentioned in the text.  Author Rinker Buck was initially going to make the trek himself but his brother insisted on going along as well.  Despite their squabbles along the way the author realizes he never would have been able to  complete the trip without his brother's valuable assistance.  They also had valuable assistance from individuals who lived in the area of the Oregon Trail.  Only once does the author mention a cantankerous couple in the area of Burnt Ranch in Wyoming.I consider this book a valuable addition to my western library.  I did feel the book got a bit long near the end and only for that reason am I rating the book four stars rather than five.

I have to rate this book five stars for the amount of research author Emerson Baker has put into it along with how he organized the chapters throughout the book.  I like the fact the author divided the book into chapters such as a general history of Salem in addition to chapters on those accused of witchcraft, the accusers, the judges, the search for atonement, and modern-day Salem as it relates to its infamous history.Reasons for the 1692 hysteria were many.  Puritans believed their religion was the best and, therefore, the devil would work hardest at destroying it.  Crop failures may be blamed on witchcraft along with the heathen practices of the Indians.  Boredom among the girls, illness which caused an early death, and the intolerance of the Puritans towards those of other religions were many.  To the Puritans the only thing worse than a witch was a Catholic.  Quakers who ventured into the Massachusetts Bay Colony risked execution.  Like today neighbors didn't always get along and vengeance may be gained by accusing another individual as a witch.Author Baker also provides research into the search for forgiveness upon citizens of Salem for seeing the error of their ways.  Interesting tidbits are provided regarding the family tree of of individuals are given such as author Nathaniel Hawthorne being a direct descendant of Judge John Hathorne.  Possible reasons are given  why author Nathaniel added the "w" to his last name are provided.  Israel Putnam, who fought in the Battle of Bunker Hill and author of the quote, "Don't shoot 'til you see the whites of their eyes" would be a descendant of the Salem Putnam family as would patriot Nathan Hale of the Reverend John Hale of Salem.I have read other books on Salem but this newest effort by Emerson Baker I have found to be the most insightful.  If this is a subject of interest to you I would strongly suggest you purchase a copy for your library.  You need not be a scholar of history to enjoy the book.  A general reader like myself found it to be fascinating reading.

What a wonderful job author J. Thomas Hetrick has done in bringing to life the St. Louis Browns of Der Poss Bresident Chris Von der Ahe of the 1880s and 1890s.  The book is not only baseball history but a book loaded with funny anecdotes of the team's owner.  More modern-day past owners such as Charley Finley, George Steinbrenner, and Bill Veeck came to mind.  Von der Ahe knew little, and dare I say nothing, about the game in which he attempted to inject himself into.  His fractured English added amusement to his players and had them imitating him.  He would fine his players for errors and other incidentals which were often forgotten about the following day.  He told his players to avoid hitting the ball in the air and to keep the ball "on the floor" instead.  Von der Ahe watched as a smallish man was having a tryout at Sportsman's Park at third base.  Chris suggested,  "Dot little feller!  Take him out to the Fairgrounds track and make a "hoss yockey" out of him.  That "little feller" was none other than the great John Joseph McGraw.With Charles Comiskey at the helm Von der Ahe's Browns were in their heyday in the mid-to-late 1880s and won the championship of the American Association, known derisively as "The Beer and Whiskey League", and then defeated the Chicago White Sox of the National League in a playoff.  The egotistical Von der Ahe had a trophy made with the inscription "Monarchs of the Sphere."This was an era of loose regulations and umpires often were subjected to a great deal of abuse from fans and players alike.  Many players were fined for their liberal use of alcohol and not being in condition to play.  Von der Ahe had his own personal troubles by having a mistress or more while married to yet another woman.  The Sporting News wrote that he was his own worst enemy and  "An affront to the community."Yes, this book has a heavy price tag but if you are interested in the early days of baseball this book should be a must for you to have in your library.  The book contains a photo of the life-sized statue of Chris Von der Ahe standing on a pedestal appearing to survey his domain which he had commissioned years before his death.  Do yourself a favor and buy the book.  If you like humorous anecdotes this book is loaded with them.

I knew nothing about the subject matter in this book prior to reading it so anything I read was new to me.  The book is a typical mob book whereby mobsters who are supposed to be friends turn against one another and out of paranoia start eliminating those who may turn and begin singing to the authorities.  Henry Hill  is one of those involved and he and his family eventually are targeted.  The book contains the usual mobster profanities and adulterous affairs.  Henry Hill spent the last years of his life speaking to high school groups about what a mistake it is to get involved in a life of crime.  It would have been nice to see what several of the characters in the book look like but the book contains no photos.  There is a glossary of Italian slang as it applies to mobsters which I found to be something I haven't seen in other true crime books.  The book contains a lot of dialogue and I found it to be an interesting read.

I was disappointed with this book.  Each chapter is devoted to various positions within the Washington Nationals' organization.  I have no objection to that but I found myself skimming through each one due to lack of in-depth reporting.  The saving grace of this book was the chapter on General Manager Mike Rizzo which I found to be interesting.  This book will not remain in my baseball library.  Instead I'll send it over to our local public library.

As one of the few surviving members of the fabled "Boys of Summer", Carl Erskine is certainly qualified to write anecdotes about  the Brooklyn Dodgers of the 1950s.  This book is not a story of Erskine's years with the Dodgers but separate individual anecdotes about the players he knew so well.  Erskine has written other books of this sort as well.  Someone who has read several other books on the 1950s Brooklyn Dodgers will find several stories repeated here.  It's great that Erskine has taken the time to relate these stories especially for those who are unfamiliar with this storied team in order to give them some appreciation.  As a baseball fan you won't go wrong reading Erskine's books on his beloved Dodgers but just realize you need to be prepared for some repetition if you've read several other books on the Brooklyn Dodgers.  This book is a quick easy read with photos scattered throughout the book.  I also might add it is refreshing to read a baseball book that contains no profanity.

This is the story of two strong-willed individuals who were at loggerheads for years.  Author James Neff doesn't take sides with either Kennedy or Hoffa.  He presents the role each one played on opposing sides.  Whenever Robert Kennedy was presented with a challenge of any sort he was determined to meet it head-on and placing teamster leader James Hoffa behind bars was a challenge to be met.  Hoffa, on the other hand, viewed Kennedy as a rich kid brat who wanted to make a name for himself  at his (Hoffa's) expense as the President's Attorney General.The book is packed with courtroom drama with both Hoffa and Kennedy achieving victories.  Jury tampering, illicit sexual affairs, and the ever-present J. Edgar Hoover's ability to stave off retirement while John Kennedy was President make for dramatic reading.  Sadly, both Robert Kennedy and James Hoffa came to violent ends.  It has taken decades for much of this information to come out and author James Neff has done his research well.

For those who were of age in 1963 Two Days in June by Andre Cohen is a chance to revisit those historic two days in which President Kennedy accomplished his proudest achievement with the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty with Russia on June 10th with his speech at American University and on June 11th with his speech on Civil Rights.To me the most interesting part of the book was when he addressed the nation on television regarding equal rights for Negroes, as they were referred to at the time because I remember it vividly.  President Kennedy had about two minutes to review the speech prior to going on the air as his speechwriter Ted Sorensen wrote frantically  while his typist pounded out the draft that the President was to read to the nation.  What makes it more poignant today is that voting and other rights are once again under attack for minorities.  While the President was being praised for his speech a Southern bigot, whose name will not be dignified here, lay in wait for Civil Rights activist Medgar Evers to return home from a meeting and murdered him with a rifle shot while he got out of his car in his driveway.In addition to President Kennedy I feel speechwriter Ted Sorensen is a hero of sorts as he drew upon his experience of a paper he wrote in a Nebraska high school for thoughts to include in the Civil Rights speech.  Martin Luther King was thrilled with the speech while Southern Democrats were livid with who they always referred to as "the Kennedys."  The assassination of Medgar Evers was previews of coming attractions with the assassination of President Kennedy, brother Robert, Martin Luther King, and others in the violent 1960s.The book is thoroughly researched and if you lived through this period of our history you will find it to be history revisited for you.

Stan Mikita admits that he has been blessed throughout his life.  Removed from Czechoslovakia to Canada as a young boy Stan was fortunate to have individuals in his life that helped him along the way to becoming one of the Chicago Blackhawks' icons.  Mikita credits goalie Glenn Hall as one who was instrumental in helping him  The book includes numerous photos including the 1961 team photo of their Stanley Cup championship.  I was especially pleased that all of the members are identified in the photo.  I recognize several of the names but since I am not a real hockey fan I didn't know what they looked like.  That said I wish the photos on other pages had the players identified as well.Stan MIkita has been blessed in his post-hockey life as well and he humbly admits to this fact.  I found the part about his reconnection with the Blackhawk hockey team and his family life to be interesting as well.  As I've said although I don't follow hockey there are a number of players whose names I recognize from this time period.  It's good to see Chicago has once again become enamored with their Blackhawks.

The daughter of Joe Black, one of Roger Kahn's Boys of Summer, has provided us with an interesting account of the life of her father.  Joe Black has the distinction of being the first African-American player to win a World Series game which took place in 1952 against the Yankees.  That season proved to be the highlight of Joe's baseball career as he was bedeviled by control problems beginning in 1953 which may have been caused by getting too much advice from others.  Dodgers' manager Charley Dressen took some hits for wanting Joe to develop another pitch.  Dressen had the reputation of wanting to contribute his thoughts into a player who had experienced some success in hopes of getting some of the credit for himself.The book also contains a lot of the racial bigotry that Black experienced during his baseball career.  Black's post-career also included his experiences as a middle-school teacher, his employment with the Greyhound bus line, and his assisting with the organization called BAT which aids in assisting players and their families who are down-and-out in their luck.  Former player Joe Garagiola has been heavily involved in this organization as well.One complaint I have with the book is with the chapters not being arranged chronologically.  The book's chapters skips back and forth from Joe's baseball career to his off-the-field activities.  Some readers may prefer this method but I did not.  Therefore, I rate the book four stars.  However, the content of the book would rate five stars with me.I found two errors in the book.  Already on page 4 the 1948 World Series is mentioned with the Cleveland Indians defeating the Boston Red Sox in six games.  The Boston team listed should be the Boston Braves.  In addition on page 11 the author John Debringer is listed when the correct name is John Drebinger.If you're a baseball fan of this time period you should enjoy this book.  Joe Black is certainly a worthy addition to a book on baseball biographies.

I rate parts 1 and 2 three stars and parts 3 and 4 five stars.  I couldn't put the book down from parts 3 and 4 I found it so riveting.  What I remember about hockey from this time period was the names of the Montreal Canadians' hockey players found in the book and the fact that the Philadelphia Flyers were known as the Broad Street Bullies and had Kate Smith, either in person or recording, sing God Bless America prior to the start of their games.  Also, I  believed that when the highlights of a game were fights I didn't feel you had much of a sport.  I knew nothing about Russia playing a series of games against several National Hockey League teams.That said, I found the game played on December 31, 1975, between the Montreal Canadians and the Russian team to be one of sportsmanship played to a 3 to 3 tie to be, for lack of a better word, heartwarming.  The Canadians had 38 shots on goal compared to only 13 for the Russians but the goal tending of Vladislav Tretiak kept things at a game-ending tie.  When the Russian team moved on to play in Philadelphia the Flyers embarrassed themselves and the United States by their use of thuggery against the Russians in which the Russian coach removed his team from the ice.  The administration of the coup de grace against the Flyers came when the Canadians swept the Flyers out of their rule of NHL champions by defeating them in for the Stanley Cup championship and a return to civilized hockey.The Montreal Canadians selected Tretiak in the draft of 1983 but the Russians would not allow him to compete in the NHL.  Although it was too late for Tretiak the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991 all of the best Russian players are now eligible to join the NHL.  In 2007 Tretiak was on hand to celebrate the retirement of Canadian goal tender Ken Dryden's jersey in Montreal.This book definitely filled a gap in my knowledge of hockey's history that I wasn't aware I was living through at the time it took place.

Marcel Pronovost has been involved in hockey since he was a child in Quebec from a family of 12 children, 9 boys and 3 girls.  The book is an over-sized paperback of 191 pages and contains numerous photographs of his entire career most notably with the Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs.  His hears spent with the Red Wings took place during those five Stanley cup winning seasons with the Production Line of Ted Lindsay, Gordie Howe, and Alex Delvecchio.  The book contains interesting anecdotes about several of his teammates including his close friendship with the late Terry Sawchuk. I found it interesting that Marcel Pronovost had a good relationship with Maple Leaf coach Punch Imlach since some other books I have recently read have found him difficult to get along with.One drawback, at least to me, was a lack of naming the individuals in team pictures.  Only two or three players would be named and I would have liked to know others who I have heard of but didn't recognize due to my very casual interest in hockey during this time period.  If you are a Detroit Red Wings' fan and interested in their glory years of the 1950s I would think this book would be of special interest to you.

Author David Dupuis has written a no-holds barred account on the "troubles and triumphs" of hockey great goalie Terry Sawchuk.  Terry's career found him modeling the uniforms of several teams most notably that of the Detroit Red Wings.  He was without a doubt one of the greatest, if not the greatest, goalie in the history of the National Hockey League.  He also authored the crouched "gorilla" stance used by goalies.  Sawchuk stated he could more easily see through the players' legs with this type of stance.  His use of a face mask became more acceptable around the league after it was first started by Montreal Canadians' goalie Jacques Plante. The fact that he was able to perform despite the numerous injuries he suffered in addition to his addiction to alcohol defies belief.  Sawchuk was able to project a heartfelt personality, but when alcohol wrapped its ugly tentacles around him he became a very abusive individual to both his wife Pat and their seven children.  I felt the author did a wonderful job in juggling these his two personalities which made for a very balanced, I felt, book.For all of the trophies Sawchuk won for his hockey exploits I feel the greatest trophy should go to his wife Pat for managing to take care of seven children while having to endure the suffering inflicted upon her due to Terry's philandering and addiction to alcohol.  Author Dupuis did an excellent job in relating the final incident that led up to Terry's unfortunate demise in a freak accident in an unnecessary encounter with Ron Stewart and Ben Weiner.  Even the funeral of Terry Sawchuk was not without controversy.  I was aware of Terry Sawchuk when he was a player but was unaware of the problems he went through during his short life.

Let me state that the authors did a fine job in this biography of Chicago Black Hawk defense man Pierre Pilote.  I recognized his name from among those who played during his time period of the 1960s and I liked his alliterative name.  Had I been more familiar with Black Hawk hockey I would have rated it higher.  I also thought there was a little too much play-by-play in the book just as there is in some baseball books I have read.Pilote spent 13 years with Chicago before being dealt to the Toronto Maple Leafs where he spent the final year of his career.  Pilote found the change of teams to be a rather uneasy relationship due to fights he had had with players he now had to accept as his teammates.  Defense was Pilote's forte and was often compared with the legendary defense man Doug Harvey of the Montreal Canadians.  Pilote was a good family man and found the transition into life away from hockey to be smooth.If you are a Chicago Black Hawk hockey fan I'm sure you will rate this a five star book.  The fact that I'm rating it four stars is due to the reasons I've listed above.

I have been reading a number of hockey books lately and I found this one to be a gem.  Author Bruce McDougall has done a masterful job in bringing to life the final playoff game for the Stanley Cup between the Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Canadians in 1967.  The book's title comes from the last game played prior to expansion.  Up to this time the N.H.L. had six teams namely Toronto, Montreal, New York, Boston, Detroit, and Chicago.The book is divided into the pregame, 1st period, intermission, 2nd period, intermission, 3rd period, and post-game wrap-up.  What made the book more interesting to me is that the entire book contains nuggets of information regarding the names of players I remember from this time period.  Also included are anecdotes relating to relations between the owners, coaches, and players.  Management would take advantage of starry-eyed youngsters who would like nothing more than to play with their favorite team and sign them for a pittance.  There would also be threats from management to banish a player to the minors a year short of qualifying for a pension for the player having the audacity to ask for a raise in pay.When I first saw how the book was divided into chapters I thought the ones involving the three periods would be merely a play-by-play of the game.  This, thankfully, was not so.  Crucial parts of each period are included but also included are stories involving the players that make the book more interesting.  Maple Leaf's coach George "Punch" Imlach is not viewed favorably in this book.  He certainly would not be a coach I would relate favorably to.  My only complaint with the book is that it doesn't contain any photographs.  I don't follow hockey but I do remember the players involved in this book.  For a true hockey fan this book would be a must for you.

How did you spend New Year's Day?  I spent mine reading this book in its entirety.  I had a difficult time putting it down and I wouldn't know a blue line from a clothes line.  Of course I'm aware that Bobby Orr played hockey for the Boston Bruins but this is a book for both players and parents of any sport their child participates in.  Bobby Orr does not emphasize his numerous accomplishments in hockey.  In fact his greatest memory of the sport is the time he spent playing the game as a child on rinks near his home at Parry Sound, Ontario.  Tennyson once wrote, "I am a part of all that I have met" and Bobby Orr spends a great deal of time in recognizing those who helped him from the time he was a child throughout his career at a professional hockey player.  He realizes that what we accomplish we don't do on our own without the help of significant others along the way.Orr concludes the book by giving his opinions on the state of the game today and mentions suggested rule changes he would make and the reasons for them.  Included also is suggested practical advice for up-and-coming hockey players and questions they should ask themselves if they plan on continuing their dream on playing in the National Hockey League.I am not a hockey fan but for those who have children in any sport I would highly recommend this book to be read by both parents and children.  I also found it refreshing in that there are no profanities in the book.  Hockey fan or not this book is must reading for the reasons I mention above.

Author William Brown has written an interesting and balanced account on the life of Montreal Canadians' defenceman, Doug Harvey.  Harvey has been named number six on the list of the top ten hockey players in the NHL and it is entirely appropriate that a biography is written on him.  I just wished it had been available in a hard cover edition.  Harvey always cherished his reputation of being his own man and doing things his own way which would often conflict with conventional wisdom.  He lived his life with a bipolar disorder which may have contributed to his sometimes "off-the-wall" behavior.  He struggled with alcohol addiction and refused to attend his election to the National Hockey Hall of Fame induction ceremony.  However, he was also often one to assist those he saw to be in need.  I don't follow hockey but I do remember Harvey and his Canadian teammates from the 1950s and '60s and I found it enjoyable to once again familiarize myself with the names from their storied past.

Former Montreal Canadians' goal tender Ken Dryden has written an eloquent book on hockey and his experiences in the game.  He writes from a first-hand point of view as to what it is like to be a net-minder in the National Hockey League and what went on in the dressing room prior to a game and between periods.  I don't claim to be a hockey fan but I do remember the names of several of the players he talks about in the book.  Dryden also provides us with his remembrances of growing up as a child playing hockey on a makeshift rink with his brother and neighborhood kids.  He concludes the book with his opinions as to the state of the game in the year 2003. Counting this one I've read only four hockey books so I don't know whether this is the best one ever written.  It certainly isn't the best sports book ever written.  If you were a hockey fan during the 1970s when Dryden played and of the Montreal Canadians in particular you will be sure to enjoy this book.  I found myself familiar with several of the names of the players he spoke about but as far as following hockey I found myself at a definite disadvantage.  If you have a library of books on sports I would certainly include this one among those on the sport of hockey.

John Unitas Jr. provides the reader with a warts and all rendition of his life as the son of the legendary quarterback of the Baltimore Colts.  If you want to learn about the good and bad John Unitas then this is the book for you to read.  It is not written as a beginning to end biography of his football years.  That is available in other books.  Life is not always the tranquil everything is great in a family of a celebrity and Unitas Jr. tells us about the conflicts in growing up in a family torn by adultery, divorce, and a step-mother he had no use for.  All families have conflicts so we shouldn't be surprised that the Unitas family had there share and more.Quarterback Unitas was in many ways a low-key individual and related well to coach Weeb Eubank who had a similar personality.  Don Shula, on the other hand, was a screamer and Unitas didn't relate well to this type of coach.  To show their contempt for Coach Shula, whenever a family member went to use the bathroom they would often state, "I am going to take (leave?) a Shula."  Anecdotes are provided with teammates such as Lenny Moore, Art Donovan, Raymond Berry, and Jimmy Orr.Each chapter begins with a brief synopsis of a football game played several years ago.  The games don't follow any chronological pattern and don't always involve the Colts so I don't understand the meaning of this.  If you want to read a tell-all book this is one for you to read.  Sometimes I feel that some stories are best left unsaid.

I'm not a hockey fan but I did follow hockey casually from the late 1950s through the 1970s.  Keith Magnuson will always be memorable to me by the cover photo of him on Sports Illustrated minus the teeth.  His job with the Chicago Black Hawks was as a defense man and he was the enforcer which got him involved in numerous fights on the ice.  Keith sacrificed his body by giving a 100% effort at all times and gave that same effort with his employment following the end of his playing career. He may have paraphrased Vince Lombardi who said, "Winning isn't everything, but making the effort to win is." Keith Magnuson phrased it by saying, "Winning isn't everything.  What's everything is whether or not you give 100%."  This is a good reminder for young people who read this book.Yes, the book contains quite a bit on fighting, but due to Magnuson being a defense man fighting went with the job.  I found only one profanity in the book so I would suggest you can give this to a youngster who enjoys hockey whether they like the Chicago Black Hawks or have heard of Keith Magnuson or not.This book also brought back to life the names of a number of hockey players I remembered from this time period but had forgotten about.  Whether you are a hockey fan or just a casual sports fan I believe you will enjoy this book especially if you are familiar with hockey during the 1970s.

Other than "Pitching In A Pinch" and Gene Schoor's 1953 biography on Christy Mathewson I'm surprised it has taken so long for someone to author another biography on Christy Mathewson.  Although I appreciate having a book  written on a baseball player that isn't laced with profanities I thought the early part of this book overdid to some extent his moral character.  As an example Matty slid home and declared himself out  and the catcher asking him why he did that.  Matty answered by saying, "I'm a deacon in the church."  Deacon or not the umpire is the one to make the call.The book rallied at the mid-point to the end which covered Mathewson's career with the storied Giants of John McGraw.  McGraw and Mathewson made up baseball's odd-couple.  Matty being the college-bred All-American boy and McGraw the feisty win-at-all-costs manager who played third base for the rowdy Baltimore Orioles of the 1890s.  Christy's career with the Giants and his entry into the army during World War I are well-covered in addition to the exposure he and Ty Cobb experienced with a mustard gas training session.Of additional interest to me was the inclusion of the life of Mathewson's son, Christy Jr., his experience as a pilot, and how he met his death.  The life of Matty's wife and her friendship with John McGraw's widow, Blanche, was also interesting.  I remember The Sporting News had a photo of Mrs. McGraw leaving the Polo Grounds after the Giants last game there in 1957.  She carried a bouquet of flowers and above the photo it read "So Empty--So Quiet".Author Bob Gaines does rely rather heavily on Larry Ritter's book "The Glory of Their Times."  The book contains 218 pages of text with accompanying photos, some of which I have never seen before.  Also included are three appendixes:1.Memorable games pitched by Mathewson through the years2. Former Giant teammates and what became of them3. Dead ball players in the Hall of FameNotes, bibliography, and index round out the book.I initially had my doubts about the book because it appeared to turn Matty into a saint.  However, as his wife once said that although he was a wonderful man, he wasn't a "goody-goody."This book would be suitable reading for young people.  Their only disadvantage is not having heard of Christy Mathewson or the New York Giants for that matter.  Don't let the price tag scare you.  If you like baseball history I would suggest you buy the book.This book should read as an "Amazon Verified Purchase".  I don't know why it doesn't.

Al Michaels shares a wealth of his experiences in the world of sports and those who have influenced him over his storied career.  We all have those in our lives who have given us a helping hand and Al Michaels first had his father and later on individuals such as Curt Gowdy and John Wooden who proved to be helpful.  On the negative side were Jack Kent Cooke and Chick Hearns.Michaels experienced the polar differences in how teams were run with Sparky Anderson's Big Red Machine and the San Francisco Giants led by manager Charley Fox.  In covering such a variety of sports with different networks Al Michaels worked with a number of different personalities ranging from Howard Cosell, O. J. Simpson, Ken Dryden, John Madden, Tim McCarver, Dan Dierdorf, Jim Palmer, and Frank Gifford to name a few.  The book contains anecdotes on all of them.  My favorite is one involving Howard Cosell on page 139 and 140 that is an absolute classic.  I read it in another book on Cosell and Ali but it certainly warrants a retelling in this book.Anyone who has visions of becoming a sportscaster would do well to read this book.  It's not always the glamorous job that one may envision.  It includes countless meetings and hours of preparation and working well with personalities that may conflict with your own.  I feel if you remember the years during the career of Al Michaels this will be a chance for you to relive the many dramatic moments that he covered in his storied career.  This book is a very worthwhile addition to your sports library.

I chose to read this book because I remember Jacques Plante as being the first goalie to wear a mask in the National Hockey League in the late 1950s.  I don't claim to be a hockey fan but I do remember many of those great French-sounding names that populated the rosters during this time.  It took someone like Plante who possessed a confident personality willing to endure the catcalls from the so-called macho types to become the trail blazer in using a mask for protection against the onslaught of hockey pucks without any facial protection.  The discovery of the slap shot by teammate Bernie "Boom Boom" Geoffrion added several miles-per-hour to the speed in which a puck traveled towards a goalie.  Plante's coach Toe Blake was an old-school type who vigorously fought against Plante's use of the mask.  Soon, however, all goalies except Gump Worsley used one throughout their career.It is unbelievable today to think that hockey players used to play without helmets and goalies were often forced to continue in a game or else use the unqualified "house" goalie provided by the home team.  The game would be stopped sometimes for 20 minutes to a half an hour while a goalie was stitched up for an injury and then returned to the game.Although Plante played for teams such as the New York Rangers, St. Louis Blues, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Boston Bruins he always thought of himself as a Montreal Canadian.  Plante had several accomplishments throughout his career, one of them being five consecutive years winning the Vezina trophy which was awarded to the goalie who successfully defended against the most shots on goal in one season.  However, Jacques Plante will always be remembered  as the goalie who pioneered the use of the mask to protect the face of goalies.I don't claim to be a hockey fan but I did thoroughly enjoy this book and came across the names of a number of players I remember from the 1950s and 1960s that I had forgotten about.  If you claim to be a hockey fan you should familiarize yourself with this pioneer of the game.  If you're not a hockey fan read the book anyway.  You will enjoy it.  This review is from a hardcover and not a paperback as listed.

Cemeteries are interesting places to visit and each headstone involves a life with a story to tell.  Author Chris Enss has written brief a brief biography of old western characters many of which are familiar to most people and others are obscure but still having an interesting tale worthy of inclusion in the book.  I found a quote of Bat Masterson to be especially interesting which read, "There are many in this old world of ours who hold that things break about even for all of us.  I have observed, for example, that we all get the same amount of ice.  The rich get it in the summertime and the poor get it in the winter."  If you enjoy prowling cemeteries this book should interest you.

This book contains 582 pages of text and I read this book for a while and then switched to something else before tackling another section.  There were parts of the book I thoroughly enjoyed such as the baseball, boxing, gangsters, Charles Lindbergh, Flo Ziegfeld, the chapters on the building of the Holland tunnel and George Washington Bridge,  and some of the chapters involved in the construction of buildings such as the Chrysler Building, the baby of Walter Chrysler who said, "I like to build things."  Another chapter I found interesting was the one on S. L. Rothafel, better known as Roxy, who had the Roxy theatre built.  He had a great quote which read, "Don't give the people what they want; give them something better than they expect."I found it interesting to know where some of the historic buildings of the past were located and when they were demolished.  New York is a fascinating city and one could be dropped off most anywhere in the city and know that something historic took place there.  I skimmed parts of the book I didn't especially care for but I'm glad to add this book to my library.

This is the first hockey book I have ever read and I struck gold.  Naturally I have been familiar with Gordie Howe's accomplishments with the Detroit Red Wings and have heard of several of the players mentioned in the book but I wouldn't know a red line from a blue line.  Gordie Howe had the distinction of playing professional hockey in five different decades from the 1940s and into 1980 and his reason for being able to accomplish this fete is due to his love for the game.Howe mentions his feelings of family that the Red Wings' franchise promoted and he bought into but found this not to be true as far as ownership relationships with its players were concerned.  Howe relates his philosophy in dealing with opposing players on the ice and dealing with retribution whenever necessary.A special thrill for Gordie Howe took place when he joined the Houston Aeros of the WHA and teamed up his two of his sons, Mark and Marty, for four seasons.  He concluded his career with two seasons with the New England Whalers of the WHA and the Hartford Whalers of the NHL.  The last chapter is written by his three sons and daughter in which they relate the death of their mother and the trials and tribulations that their father has now been experiencing.  As I write this Gordie Howe has since suffered a stroke and remains in critical condition.  I am not a hockey fan but I chose well in purchasing this book and adding it to my ever-growing library.  I'm sure you will enjoy it as well.

This small paperback book surprised me.  It contains only 111 pages of text in addition to two pages covering Monument Park but briefly covers baseball beginning in 1893 through the Yankees' first World Championship in 1923.  I've never heard of the author, W. Nikola-Lisa, in any of the baseball books I have read but I didn't come across any errors in the book.  I found the bibliography to be impressive and also contains an index.  The photographs are small but then so is the book.  If you want to read a concise history of the events leading up to the New York Yankees' franchise which moved from Baltimore at the turn of the century and bought by two corrupt owners, Bill Devery and Frank Farrell, for the price of $18,000 this book would be a good introduction for the novice reader who is interested in learning about the shenanigans involved in trying to prevent another major league team from invading the hallowed ground of the lordly New York Giants.

I have to admit the cover photo of William Henry Keeler caught my eye.  This book cover the four baseball seasons from 1900--1903 and includes not only star players of this time period such as Keeler, Cy Young, Tommy Leach, Jimmy Collins, and Nap Lajoie among others but players whose names may be obscure at this time who nevertheless had interesting stories to be told.  Included here are summaries, if you will, of each team in the National League in 1900 and both leagues from 1901--1903 with the standings, regular lineups, and leading pitchers of each team.  Also included are a number of photos, some of which I have not seen in numerous other baseball books.  Examples are Cincinnati owner John T. Brush, Clark Griffith with two adopted sons in a photo with President F.D.R., Kid Elberfeld, Mike Donlin, Harry Wolverton, and others.I found it interesting that players were suspended for "indifferent play".  Players like Elberfeld and Donlin had hair-trigger tempers and others were heavy drinkers of alcohol (no surprise here).  Dave Fultz was a model for America's youth because didn't drink alcohol, smoke, curse, and refused to play on Sundays.This was a period in the game's history when Ban Johnson was fighting to bring his Western League onto equal footing with the National League and struggled to place a team into New York City and finally landing a location on a rock pile in upper Manhattan that became known at the Highlanders and now known as the Yankees.  My thanks to author Chuck Kimberly and other members of SABR who write books on players who otherwise would not be included in a baseball book or have a biography written about them.

Clyde Bellecourt and Dennis Banks were co-founders of the American Indian Movement (AIM) in 1968 to address grievances regarding police brutality and injustices in the Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul, Minnesota.This book addresses the takeover of Wounded Knee, South Dakota, in 1973 by member of AIM in protest to Oglala Tribal Chairman Dick Wilson's administration.  This part of the book also describes the dislike of the Wounded Knee Trading Post and Museum run by Clive and Agnes Gildersleeve because it was felt they were benefiting from what happened back in the massacre of 1890 through sales to tourists.  I organized a trip to the Black Hills for a group of Little Leaguers in August of 1974 and Clive Gildersleeve met us at Wounded Knee and gave us his thoughts regarding what took place the year before.  He told us that most of the protesters were from other parts of the country.  We witnessed the damage done to his home along with the museum and trading post.  He also mentioned the wording on the historical marker describing what happened in December of 1890 was offensive to native Americans.  That disgust was exhibited by a huge obscenity painted across the marker.  Mr. Gildersleeve was living in Rushville, Nebraska, at the time.The book's main focus is on a conference at Augustana College in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, in 2012 in which Bellecourt, Banks, and Russell Means and an F.B.I. agent and son discussed what took place and tried to come to a resolution of sorts.  What actually took place back in 1973 probably will never be agreed upon as to who did what and author Stew Magnuson doesn't claim to make any judgments one way or the other.  Each side has their own prejudices and beliefs and it will always remain so with no real progress having been made towards a meeting of the minds.  This book is an interesting read but don't expect to have it reveal any progress from either side agreeing as to who is to blame for what took place in 1973.

Kim Philby exuded charisma among those he came in contact with.  So much so that he pulled the wool over the eyes of the man who thought knew him best, Nicholas Elliott.  Philby was one among five individuals from England who made up what came to be known as the Cambridge Five, those from England who spied for the Soviet Union.  Apparently Philby felt no remorse for sending a significant number of Soviets who spied for England to their deaths when they were requested to return to the Soviet Union.  Philby possessed three significant weaknesses not conducive to spying namely gambling, womanizing, and alcohol.  Yet he could charm a puff adder out of a tree with his ability to relate to other people.I have possessed only a very familiar acquaintance regarding Kim Philby and the Cambridge Five and there were parts of the book that required me to read slowly.  If you fall into this category I still believe you will find the book a rewarding read.  I enjoy books on spies and this biography by author Ben Macintyre  is an important addition to my collection.

I found this book to be a riveting read from beginning to end.  I had never heard of this case prior to reading this book.  All too often among kids the belief that two is company and three is a crowd rings true.  Skylar Neese found herself on the "outs" from her two friends Shelia Eddy and Rachel Shoaf and in a case of extreme behavior Skylar paid for it with her life.This is a book I would recommend to parents of adolescents since the problems encountered are hardly unique to those in this story.  An individual can ruin their own life in addition to those of others by acting on their frustrations first and thinking later.  The answer as to why two girls decided to take the life of one of their best friends is more complex than reasons such as "we just didn't want to be friends with her anymore" or wanting to keep Skylar quiet from exposing the lesbian relationship Shelia and Rachel had with one another.  Authors Darleen Berry and Geoffrey Fuller delve into possible reasons.  One officer believes it was nothing more than a thrill kill.  The authors list ten suggestions for parents to follow in dealing with their adolescent children.One complaint I have with the book is the lack of photographs.  Sprinkled sparingly in the book are a few tiny photos some of which are irrelevant to the story.  The only photos we have of the two girls who committed the murder are a tiny photo of the girls with Skylar.  You have to go on the computer to see additional photos.This book should be must reading for parents and educators alike.  Parenting has becoming increasingly difficult due to computers, cell phones, and other technological devices that children can use away from the watchful eye of their parents.

I usually don't read fiction but the 1954 Topps baseball card of Reno Bertoia on the cover intrigued me.  Author Marty Gervais has written a unique book of a boy who spent most of his time in the attic of his home while being nursed and home-schooled due to polio.  The boy's name is Henry but he develops a fixation on Reno Bertoia of the Detroit Tigers because Bertoia is from Windsor, Ontario, Canada, and Henry used to live there himself.  He adopts the name "Reno" for himself as he spends a lot of time sending letters to sports figures, movie stars, singers, and politicians while hoping for replies and posting them on his attic wall.  However, nothing appears from Bertoia who eventually fades from the boy's interest.The book moves to a period of thirty years later when the boy becomes a doctor. From here I'll let you read the book for yourself.  I know you will enjoy it.  I'm ordering two extra copies for friends who remember Reno Bertoia as a Detroit Tiger. Reno Bertoia played in the first baseball game I ever saw in 1958 at Briggs Stadium in Detroit.  I remember a fan yelling, "Hey Bertoia!  Get a hit and I'll pay your way through the tunnel,"  which connected Detroit with Windsor, Ontario, Canada.  I realize this is a work of fiction.  However, the author has Ernie Harwell announcing for the Detroit Tigers in 1957.  Harwell was with the Baltimore Orioles at the time while Van Patrick did the play-by-play for the Tigers.  Also, take a look at that 1954 Topps baseball card of Bertoia.  He's ready to field a ground ball.  However, instead of watching the ball he's watching the photographer take a photo of him.  I'm sure he's about to be charged with an error for not keeping his eye on the ball.Buy the book.  It's a quick read.  You are in for a treat even though you may not enjoy fiction.

Author Dan Epstein has obviously done a lot of research in writing his recap of the 1976 baseball season.  It is especially interesting for those who enjoy reminiscing about a period in time that they remember.  In addition to the baseball and the individuals such as Mark Fidrych, Charley Finley, Bill Veeck, the New York Yankees, and Cincinnati's Big Red Machine the book includes popular music and political musings as well.  I did find the play-by-play of the playoffs and World Series between the Reds and Yankees to be somewhat overdone.  Others may like this in baseball books but this is a personal irritation of mine.  The book includes numerous anecdotes most of which can be found in other baseball books.  Books on particular seasons have become popular and the 1976 season is worthy of such a book and we can be thankful to Dan Epstein for giving us this one.

This book picks up where the book The Alvin Karpis Story left off.  Karpis spent over 25 years in Alcatraz, longer than any other prisoner.  His book reads like a diary in which he relates his experiences in dealing with fellow inmates, wardens, guards, escape attempts, attacks of one inmate upon another, and various jobs he had while incarcerated.  IN 1958 Karpis was briefly transferred to Leavenworth Prison in Kansas but shortly thereafter sent back to Alcatraz.  No prisoner has ever been granted parole from Alcatraz; they had to be transferred to another prison first.  Karpis gives his opinion of Robert Stroud, the so-called "Birdman of Alcatraz:."  Stroud never had any birds while at Alcatraz.  He gained his reputation from birds he had while at Leavenworth Prison.  Karpis considered Stroud to be a very dangerous individual.  Karpis provides the reader with a lively rendition of the 1946 escape attempt in which three convicts were killed during the attempt with two others executed for their role, with one another given a life in prison sentence.  Karpis entered Alcatraz in 1936 and was transferred to McNeil Island Prison in Washington in 1962. Karpis left feeling prison life did absolutely nothing to reform him from his life of crime.  Alcatraz was closed in 1963.

I found this to be a very entertaining book to read told through the eyes of Alvin Karpis.  Karpis relates his life of crime from one heist to another until his capture in New Orleans in 1936.  Karpis had a big ego in having the audacity to call himself a professional when it came to robbing banks and expressing his disgust for civilians who inadvertently got in his way to make a living by breaking the law.  Karpis absolves Ma Barker of any criminal wrongdoing even though she was aware of the doing of the Karpis/Barker gang.  Prior to his capture Karpis appears to have a foreboding that his "career" was coming to an end. since his cohorts in crime were either deceased or in prison.  John Edgar Hoover, the self-important head of the F. B. I., made himself present when Karpis was captured just as he did when Lepke Buckhalter surrendered in New York City to make sure he took credit for the work his agents did.  Karpis entered Alcatraz prison in August of 1936 and was transferred to McNeil Prison in Puget Sound in Washington.  Having spent 25 years in Alcatraz Karpis spent more time in Alcatraz than any other inmate.  I'm sure an interesting sequel to this book would be the one entitled "On the Rock" which covers Karpis's years on Alcatraz.

Addie Joss spent a relatively short baseball career with the Cleveland Indians at the turn of the 20th century.  At the time of his death in 1911 of bacterial meningitis  he was the first of the great baseball pitchers to pass away.  Addie's career may have been at an end at the time of his death due to a torn ligament in his pitching arm.  Although his Cleveland team never appeared in a World Series Joss was a dominant pitcher in the league in addition to his taking on the role of a newspaper columnist for post-season games.  A rule change was necessary for him to be admitted to the Baseball Hall of Fame since he died prior to playing in his necessary tenth major league season.  A 1977 rule change led to Joss's election in 1978.  An impressive benefit made up of baseball stars raised over $13,000 for the widow of Addie Joss amply demonstrated how highly he was thought among his peers in the game.  Not many baseball fans have even heard of Addie Joss who passed away over 100 years ago and we can thank author Scott Longert for this book on one of the game's foremost pitchers.

What am I going to say that 271 other reviewers haven't already written?  This is the only book I have read on this infamous shady character and it took me a while to pioneer my way through the 429 pages of text.  Authors Kevin Cullen and Shelley Murphy have written what I presume to be the ultimate book on Whitey Bulger since it covers his life on the lam thoroughly.  In some cases I felt I was being told more than I cared to know but that's my problem and not the authors'.  Whitey was a murderer pure and  simple and his relationship as an informant cast a dark shadow over the Boston branch of the F. B. I.  With the demise of Osama bin Laden Whitey became the number one fugitive in the country and his final years were unhappily spent in seclusion,  If you are like me and unfamiliar with Whitey Bulger I feel you will find this book to be a challenging and informative read.

There is sadness all around in this book.  Clearly a story with no winners.  Nothing but tragedy for all family members and for those who cared about them.  Five stars indicate "I love it."  which certainly is not the case.  Those interested in abnormal psychology should find a wealth of information.  Be careful who you marry and don't complicate your life unnecessarily.

Carolyn Goodman has experienced a lot of trials and tribulations in her life and she became an inspiration to countless others by her determination to live her life to the fullest rather than letting bitterness take root in her heart.  She suffered tragedy throughout her life from the time she was a child and then losing one of her three sons to hatred and bigotry.The title of the book "My Mantelpiece" comes from a drawing her son Andy showed her when he was a child and proudly called it "My Mantelpiece" instead of masterpiece.  I found the book hard to put down and read it in two sittings.  She was an inspiration to others who may be growing older and need to feel they still have a place in society to help others rather than just wile away the rest of their life.

There have been a few books dealing with the infamous murder of three civil rights workers by bigots who belonged to the Mississippi Ku Klux Klan 50 years ago this month but now author Don Mitchell has provided a book on the subject for younger middle school readers.  Author Mitchell doesn't dwell on the murders itself but he does present chapters devoted to the three victims Andrew Goodman, James Chaney, and Michael Schwerner in addition to information on those involved in committing the murders and those responsible for bringing the murderers to justice.Young readers should be aware of what took place during those sickening sixties regarding the struggle African-Americans had to achieve basic rights such as the right to vote.  This book is especially timely now due to attempts to suppress the right to vote now that the Supreme Court in its "wisdom" did away with the Voting Rights Act of 1965.  Hate is a terrible thing and the three men who grace the cover of this book paid the ultimate price in the interest of serving others.I would strongly suggest readers also acquire the DVD entitled "Murder in MIssissippi" which deals with this tragic case.  I believe this DVD is superior to "Mississippi Burning" which contains too much profanity to show in schools.  In addition I believe "Murder in Mississippi" does a superior job anyway.  It is a must see movie to go along with this new book The Freedom Summer Murders by Don Mitchell.

It's hard to write anything new that 69 other individuals have not already included.  However, I did find this to be an interesting book and not simply to read about the tragedy (to say the least) that took place at the home of Sharon Tate on August 8, 1969.  Author Greg King does an excellent job in developing the personalities of the individuals involved in this story and not only the victims involved in the murders.  We learn about the relationship that Sharon had with Say Sebring who remained in love with Sharon despite her marriage to Roman Polanski and died defending her.  Sharon felt hurt and may have been contemplating a divorce from her philandering husband at the time of her death.  We get to know the three remaining victims Abigail Folger, Vorteck Frykowski, Steve Parent, and the LaBiancas (Leno and Rosemary) in addition to those that took part in the murders.The book also includes the investigation, the trials, and the attempts the killers have made in gaining parole.  There is a brand new biography of Sharon Tate which I haven't read, but this book, even though it was written in the year 2000, provides one with a good description on the life of Sharon Tate and the tragedy that led to the demise of her and her friends.

This book aptly illustrates how quickly lives can be destroyed.  There are no winners in this book.  Losers include the victim and her family, the murderer and his family, and the community at large all come out on the short end in Little Girl Lost.  Author Tammy Mal is the daughter of a boyhood friend of 13 year-old murderer Myron Semunchich and I feel she did an excellent job in relating the story of 9-year-old Mae Barrett of Vandling, Pennsylvania, who had her life snatched away in January of 1945.Author Mal reminds the reader as to what society's attitudes towards crime were in 1945 as opposed to what they are now.  In addition police interrogation of suspects were different than what they are now.  Murderer Myron Semunchick unconsciously exhibited attitudes common among criminals.  Examples would be trying to assist police (directing traffic), exhibiting overreacting behavior as to what should be done to the murderer (forcefully throwing his knife into the top of a desk), constantly talking about the crime to others, and assuring a friend that "I will walk home with you and I assure you the murderer won't attack you."It appears that God assures the victim in any case that clues will be left that will bring the perpetrator to justice.  In this case it was a right-handed winter glove that was worn by Semunchick who had a deformed little finger that led to the solving of this crime.  In a 1924 crime in Chicago it was a pair of glasses left at the scene that led to the solving of the murder of 14-year-old Bobby Franks.Author Tammy Mal sums up the case in an "Afterword" and "Author's Thoughts" at the end of the book in which she brings up a number of questions regarding this crime.  She gives her opinion regarding many of them while others she admits have no answers.  The book contains five pages of photos.  I never heard of this case before but found this book to be a fascinating read.

I can't say I enjoyed the book since the subject matter is off a horrible nature but the book did hold my interest.  Author Mark Pettit did a thorough job in researching the book in addition to interviewing the young man who murdered these children.  Murderer John Joubert took special satisfaction in being in the presence of others discussing the crimes and not knowing the actual murderer was in their midst.  Special comments are written by a parent of each of the two Omaha victims and the book concentrates on each of them whereas a victim from Portland, Maine, is briefly mentioned at the end of the book.This is a quick reading book and will hold your interest.  I guess the lesson to be learned is that the unlikeliest source can be the place to look for a suspect after a crime has been committed.  This book is disturbing to read but the author has done a commendable job in covering this case.

Five stars mean "I loved It."  However, I hate to say that such a book of depravity could be lovable.  Author Jeff O'Donnell did a good job in covering the Starkweather/Fugate reign of terror throughout the state of Nebraska in January of 1958.  He appears to cover the details of each of the murders as we know them to have taken place.  I have read another book on this subject and this book is the best one.Author O'Donnell appendixes A-H in which he covers questions regarding the efforts of the police, a lengthy question and answer session between Caril Fugate and a Chief Deputy Attorney, letters from Charles Starkweather and his mother, a questions and answers to Starkweather prior to his execution, and a few others.If you want to read a book on this subject I would strongly suggest reading this one.  At least to me it is better than one other one that I read.  It does contain a few spelling errors but I can put up with that.

Although the title of this book is "Roosevelt the Explorer" I feel a more fitting title would be "Roosevelt the Hunter" since a good portion of the book is devoted to Roosevelt's experiences of hunting big game in the African countries of Kenya and Uganda.  Some individuals see a contradiction of sorts in Roosevelt the conservationist and his taking delight in shooting a variety of animals the skins of which were to be used in museums in the United States.  I found it interesting to note that among all the equipment he and his entourage had to pack for their trip he included a goodly portion of classic books to read on his safari.The book spends some time on Roosevelt's youth and his family.  His brother Elliott was alcoholic and ended up taking his own life.  One of Roosevelt's sons, Kermit, suffered the same fate.  Roosevelt's first wife died shortly after the birth of their first child who was named Alice.  Alice could be a rebel during her teen-age years and she married congressman Nicholas Longworth whom Longworth Hall in the United States Capitol building is named after.The book doesn't spend much time on Roosevelt's years as President of the United States.
