Don't let old school office/school supplies flummox ya too much--this is a clunky organizational alternative in a digital age (and has received some needlessly critical reviews). At the end of the day it really does do what it's designed to do. Just rather inelegantly.

I use these for my outgoing address labels for mail art swaps as they're the perfect size for smaller sized correspondence like postcards; the fairly matte finish takes ink and markers well; the rounded corners offer a less generic and utilitarian appearance.Avery makes a similar size that's removable, but I purchased these because the adhesive is mighty. Can you remove them if you just lightly apply them to non paper surfaces? Technically, yes, but it's not their prime function nor would I recommend it.Avery's full sized sheets of this label size, for inkjet printers are, in my experience, usually more trouble than they're worth because the templates are a PITA and rarely as 'universal' as claimed. Unless you need a massive amount of identical labels, these are a more than adequate alternative and adhere far more securely than the adhesive offered on the full sheets.Of course you can also trim these and create smaller labels for little detailed labeling projects. A solid value. There's 4 labels per sheet, 32 sheets, totaling 128 labels. The math works!My local big box office supply store had a very limited number of options in small labels and what they did offer was only sold in bulk. As most individuals don't need a case of these, Amazon to the rescue. These are a pretty old school general purpose item--something you rarely need in a digital age, but it's the kind of product you don't know you need until...you need it.

I'm an avid paper crafter and 'snail mail art' creator. Finding glue that's both easy to work with AND provides a bond that can withstand the rigors of the USPS system is a challenge! The best glue I've found, hands down, is this virtually odorless product by Zig. Let me share why the chisel tip offered here is my MOST favorite of the product line:I adore the versatility of this tip because you can use it while working on just about ANY surface. I frequently do projects just sitting cross-legged in bed, using nothing more than a ratty old king sized pillow as my 'desk'. The other popular tip from Zig, the fine ballpoint squeeze tip, works beautifully for precision jobs but requires a hard surface to press against in order to achieve a consistent flow. Zig's jumbo tip, while superb for larger scale projects or for young hands, is simply too broad for detail work. I love that this tip type and size allows me to work on-the-fly and provides reliability no matter what surface or work condition.For those unfamiliar with the Zig glue system, the pen-style grip is super easy-to-use and offers two bond types: blue (wet) is for a more secure and permanent bond, while applying it when it's white (letting it sit for a few moments before adhering) makes for a more flexible, removable adhesive. Really, it's amazing stuff that doesn't curl thin paper, discolor your project, or suddenly release unpredictable blobs of glue!Old school glue sticks just are too gooey and unforgiving, rubber cement can be a total nightmare, and some glues targeted at scrapbookers I find are either too gentle for permanent bonding or they are too wet to easily work with. But of course even a great product like this has a few pitfalls and the uninitiated should know:Apply swiftly: The glue goes from blue to white in a matter of seconds so if you want a permanent bond, get to it.Work cleanly: If you have ink or paint stained hands and over apply this so that it seeps around the sides of whatever your gluing, this will gum up rather easily and potentially stain your work if your attempt to 'roll' the excess away with your fingers.Use judiciously: It doesn't take much, folks. While it does dry clear, a little goes a long way so don't be tempted to over apply it; exercise patience if you need to remove excess; depending on your material, I've used rubbing alcohol to clean up any excess residue.Go gently: Don't vigorously rub this over your intended target; the tip isn't impervious to damage so it will stain the tip if you use it over dark inks and it can get a little 'chewed up' and raggedy if you go totally bonkers on unorthodox materials and surfaces.Craft patiently: If a permanent bond is what your after, let it dry and more importantly, let it 'set' before immediately applying other techniques or placing your project near other items that might accidentally stick to it and damage your work. Conversely, if you're after a very light bond with plans to peel something off, work in segments after ensuring your glue is good and white.It's a little overpriced for a single stick here on Amazon but the bulk price is amazing. A tube lasts a long time but since this stuff doesn't dry out quickly, consider buying a larger lot-- I suspect you'll be as big a fan as I've become.

I'm an active penpaller and mail artist swapper and so I go through paper supplies like crazy! There was little feedback for these at the time of my purchase, so I wasn't sure what I'd get--plus I was unfamiliar with this brand. Having just left poor feedback for another set of envelopes, I'm all too aware of how much can actually go wrong with a item as deceptively basic as a simple envelope. But these are stellar!The boring but vital stats: These are classic #10 sized 'business' envelopes in "Kraft". Though the description says they're 70lb, nothing on the packaging confirms that and I highly doubt they're that thick because your average scrapbook-quality card stock is about 65lbs--and these are way more flexible than that. However, they aren't too flimsy and I can pack in several sheets of paper and a few pieces of ephemera or a small photo or two without worry. I ordered a 100 pack, I received 100 (I counted). They're all evenly cut, no weird inconsistencies in size, color, or texture. They don't stink of cheap glue (these aren't self adhesive). However, the glue doesn't quite span the entire length of the envelope so you may need little pieces of tape to secure the ends--be aware of that. It's a small gripe but must be mentioned. I also don't suspect these are inkjet printer compatible. Ok, now the fun part.......I have no idea how the average person plans to use these, but I discovered these are AMAZING for those of us who like to do fancy address lettering; they take a pencil, but more importantly, an eraser sooooo well! So forgiving. I go over my pencil work with a Posca metallic pen and outline/highlight with a Gellyroll or Spica Glass--and it looks seriously incredible. The paper is a tad more pulpy than a standard smooth white envelope; it can't take all tip types (some fountain pens may struggle) as if it gets too wet the paper may ball a little and no one likes to drag their nib, but there's no significant bleed through and this accepts virtually all art pens I've tried. I adore how my guide lines just vanish COMPLETELY, without at all compromising the finish of the paper, when I erase them. No more freehand for me!The definition and texture of "Kraft" paper wildly varies so this is my best description::Some cheapy Kraft paper is really flat and basically just like dyed brown standard printer paper--this isn't. Some Kraft paper is more like disposable 'butcher block' paper and has a kind of slickness or blotchiness I can't work with--this isn't. Then finally, some Kraft papers are thick with fibers and 'hairs' and are uneven and rough in texture--this isn't. So I love how ideal these envelopes are for art work. The shade is just a touch lighter than most grocery store sacks.I'll be ordering more and pursuing other paper products from this brand.

I'm an active snail mailer and go through envelopes very quickly; I'm always on the lookout for affordable, but high quality options. I find that 6x9 envelopes--which can be mailed at USPS first class 'letter' postage rates as 6-1/8" is the maximum height for mail qualifying as a 'letter'--are ideal for mail art swaps, any correspondence that requires a little more room, and 5x7 photos. The value here for 50 booklet envelopes, on the day of my purchase, was fairly reasonable...yet I have two small, but not insignificant gripes:The 24lb paper, while nicely bright white, is VERY easy to see through. Based on little feedback reporting this issue, I almost wonder if there's been a change in manufacturing? I certainly don't require lined 'security' envelopes for my correspondence, but I can clearly make out any contents or read any text placed inside these envelopes--even in dim lighting conditions. No bueno. As the package flaunts these are "for all your check and business needs", I would expect a little more. Just way too thin. I have white 24lb printer paper that doesn't suffer from this problem so I except the same from my envelopes.Secondly, the glue strip for sealing (these aren't self adhesive) is not remotely even-- it doesn't span the entire length of the envelope so it requires a little piece of tape on both sides should you desire an actual secure seal; on one side, the glue stops short about an inch from the end, and on the other end, it's about a fourth of an inch short. No biggie to some folks, and I suppose this flimsy seal might make it a breeze for my recipients to open, but I have oodles of envelopes that manage to extend the seal the entire length.I reserve these for lightweight, infrequent use as the quality is suspect. And that's a bummer. Yes, I'm picky. But paper companies don't exactly need to reinvent the wheel to produce a consistent product that I'd be happy to buy time and time again.

I am a total Instax mini junkie so I own (and review) a lot of photo albums. When I initially purchased this, there were zero reviews so I wasn't sure what I'd end up with. For those less interested in reading the gritty details, here's my quick takeaway now that it's in use: it's really lovely, I'd purchase again, and despite some gripes, the album is a superb value.THE SPECS:By Deahun (arrives in open-ended plastic packaging/no tags)External Measurements: approx 7-3/4"H x 6-3/4"W x 1-1/4" DHolds 120 pics/40 pages/3 pics (w/ adjacent blank ruled lines) per pageDoes NOT accommodate Instax Wide/classic Polaroids--APPEARANCE: 5 starsThe leatherette is VERY well done, feels great to the touch--especially compared to similarly priced, cheap vinyl/plastic-y albumsOffered in several beautiful shades from pastels to deeper hues it's the best album I own in terms of overall display...it doesn't feel disposableThe separately affixed brass-colored corners on the album's cover offer a more serious, grown up look--compared to the slew of cutesy, tween-targeted albums on the marketSome people may use this for Polaroid Mio shots, but the majority of folks are using mini Fuji Instax--so the album's embossed "Album de Polaroid" (and the inclusion of "business cards" and "memo" featured on the cover) is a small gripe and reveals this isn't aimed for U.S. consumers--STORAGE/FUNCTION: 5 starsDesigned to generously expand--a fully loaded album isn't too "fat" and holds its shapeThe book-like design makes this stiff enough to store in a bookshelf or stand upright under its own weightAwesome scrapbook-inspired spiral binding (no cheap-o sewn or glued in main seam) means flipping through the pages is easy and satisfying and, best yet, the album doesn't flop open right to the middle--the typical default position in lesser quality albums--INTERIOR: 3 starsThe "DYI" in the description refers to a tiny field of 5 blank-ruled lines that are adjacent (on the left) of each photo sleeve (3 sleeves/fields per page)I like that I can make a note per photo (rather than using a sticker or pen directly on the photo) but the paper is slick so you need to chose your ink wiselyThe plastic sheets are one solid page--meaning individual photo sleeves, per page, are separated by 4 sealed dash-shaped impressions to create the slots; the dashes each measure about a half inch longThe translucent sleeves are a little more prone to wrinkling (see above) than some of my other Instax albums; there's an allowance for easy in/out but to preserve the integrity of the thin sleeve, tread gentlyPhotos fit snugly and securely and no part of the photo will stick out the side of the sleeveThe album's native orientation for landscape shots makes this less ideal for people (like me) who prefer portrait shotsThe paper, under the sleeves, features a very busy chevron pattern that I find quite distracting: a mini Instax photo will not fully cover over this patternBOTTOM LINE: For the price I paid, I am very satisfied and will buy again. The more casual instant photo fan, who hasn't experimented with different album types, should also find this a great option. Lose the chevron print and up the quality of the sleeves and it's a 5 star offering.

Despite acknowledging that Moleskine makes quality products that inspire intense brand loyalty, I've never hopped on the bandwagon; as a notebook enthusiast, I find most Moleskine items a tad overpriced. But when I spied this case on one of my favorite pen & paper websites, I was intrigued. I love all things 'mini' and am an organization junkie to boot. Amazon's price couldn't be beat so I took the plunge.First things first, when Moleskine calls this "XS" they really and truly mean EXTRA SMALL. Similar versions of this case are available in larger sizes so definitely peruse those if you need room for oodles of stuff or for an e-reader, camera, smart phone, etcetera. Double-check the external dimensions as Amazon has them listed under "Product Description" at mid page. My tape measure clocks them at approx 3.5" W x 5" H x 2" D. Deduct a bit for actual internal storage. Yep: Teeny!The possibilities with this case are endless if you carry a lot of tiny items (or just want to protect one or two important things). I ultimately purchased this to store travel-ready mini craft items I use for Fuji instant photography: business card-size blank card stock, mini scissors, mini pen, used film, sticker sheets, washi tape (flat pack), and a few other odds and ends. Yes, a person could use a little zippered pouch or pocket that would serve a similar purpose, but this product allows more for security, basic organization, and mobility.The back of the case has an adjustable attachment feature that allows you to affix the case to a strap--in my case, the handle of my camera bag. It takes up so little room and I appreciate that the adjustable design enables it to be tightened to a flat strap OR rounded handle--it does slide around a bit tho on my slick nylon handle. But the Velcro, a material I'm usually loathe to compliment, is impressively rugged and secure.Inside the shell there's a black terry cloth material with a netted pocket on the bottom of one side and a loop (ostensibly for a key ring) atop the opposite side. The internal features are not configurable/able to be unattached.The shell itself feels great to the touch; it's a nice low profile matte finish. The dual rubber zippers run smoothly. The stitching is well done, and the entire piece is very durable. I cannot speak for shock absorbency but *I'd* trust this with a pricey MP3 player or the like. Perfect for earbuds too.Absolutely love this to pieces and recommend it to anyone who wants to wrangle their bobby pins or hair ties or tweezers or flash drive or gate keys. Understand its limitations re: the size, and you'll never be reaching into your purse or briefcase trying to find that impossibly small item again. Travel convenient and then some. Moleskine hasn't converted me to their notebooks, but I'll definitely consider checking out more of their cases.

Though in my heart I may still swoon for Hello Kitty, the reality is I'm a 40-yr old looking for a sensible, but attractive travel bag for my Instax Neo Classic 90--you know, the instant camera Fuji designed for the grown-ups too. I'd been using one of those ubiquitous after market black hamburger-style cases but I hated the way it looked and functioned. My search for a more appealing and practical carrying case only offered up a dozen highly questionable options, all of them lacking in some frustrating way. The market here doesn't support many Instax accessories so it's slim pickings.Then I stumbled onto this. Prior to ordering, it seemed to fit my specific criteria:-Not pink or pastel or branded in some giddy print-Not vinyl or PU 'leather'-Room for at least one extra film-An external slip pocket-A little bit of cushion/protection in case of dropping-Adaptable to a variety of travel conditions; Vespa-friendly-Comfortable to carry for long outings-Not so bulky that it can't be easily stashed in a larger bag if necessary-Ability to be easily wiped clean due to my dusty, pet-filled home-Proper fit and balance/ease of taking camera in & out quicklyDid it end up delivering? Bottom line, YES! Or read on...BRAND:Sktr bags are a division of a company called Itoya. I did a quick search prior to purchase because I'd never heard of them; discovered stellar reviews for the bags they're apparently known for: portable artist's cases & portfolios.AVAILABILITY:Quite limited; currently not Prime-able; few sellers; low stock on some colors. I ended up NOT purchasing through Amazon due to the inability to verify stock for 3rd party sellers. I purchased at an online camera outlet. I typically don't write reviews here for non-Amazon purchases, but because thorough feedback for this bag is nearly non existent, if you're loathe to purchase in the dark, I hope this helps. IMO this bag is worth the hunt.PACKING/WHAT'S IN THE BOX:My bag arrived with just a hang tag, in a plastic wrap.BUILD QUALITY/MATERIAL:The nylon 'puffy jacket' material is very cool and is of decent quality; thick internal seaming; the stitching at some external seams does pucker a bit but is secure. The dual rubber zippers are substantial and run smoothly but don't quite "seal" the bag quite as tightly as I'd like--when zipping shut, there's a mm or two of a gap.WEIGHT/COMFORT:Super duper lightweight. Adds very little weight to a fairly substantial camera. I can carry this over my shoulder for hours or toss into my handbag.FIT:The fit for my Neo Classic 90, though not truly custom, is roomy; the camera fits in the upper compartment at both the portrait & landscape position WITH room for the charger too. It's not as snug as I'd envisioned, the camera moves around a bit. (Beyond the Fuji Mini 8 and 90, I cannot vouch how this would fit older model Instax or Polaroids. I only suspect this would not work for that new Lomo'Instant OR the Fuji wide 210.)STRAP/LATCHES:The somewhat flimsy adjustable and removable strap is nothing too impressive, but isn't stiff; It will accommodate cross body/shoulder wear for both tall & short folks. The latches are sewn onto the strap securely but are a tad undersized and dinky, some paint chipping has occurred on the black finish.ADDITIONAL SPACE:I can easily fit TWO spare film cartridges and 1 mini card case style album in the bottom zippered compartment--which is separate from the main body of the case; I use the external slip pocket for a variety of little things: small sleeve of stickers, a pen, and some card stock for writing down what settings I used to achieve a shot. Could I technically jam in even more? Yes, but it's not designed to hold the kitchen sink and will sag a bit if overstuffed.ZIP IN & OUT/BALANCE:I can quickly grab my camera without having the balance and topple issues of my stiffer, zippered wrap-around shell case. The 'purse style' is very convenient for grabbing on the go because the perfect shot waits for no man.APPEARANCE:Offered in black, white, and silver. I ordered in silver, which is kinda a fun space age look for an delightfully analog device. Hubby isn't embarrassed to carry it, 'nuff said.PROTECTION:The case provides adequate cushion for the common tumble but I've yet to experience a severe drop. It's not as shock absorbent as a harder shell case. This is the ideal travel bag but probably not designed for hard core protection.SPECS:Overall external dimension is approx 6-1/2" W x 7" H x 4" D.VALUE:Considering all the 'toy' cases floating around at the same price point, this bag is a solid bargain at list price.I love the whimsy that instant photography offers. But at 70 cents a pop for a single shot, most people who stick with Instax for the long haul are invested in the medium as more than a passing fad or nostalgic chuckle......so that's why I believe a fun camera still deserves a serious bag. I'm grateful to have found this.

In order to satisfy a free shipping minimum, I picked up 2 of these, in white & green, when ordering a camera bag from this same brand, Sktr. (I didn't purchase from Amazon as it was one of the rare instances that I found a better price elsewhere; these also aren't currently Prime eligible).Offered in two sizes, I opted for the Small which only holds 20 mini Fuji Instax shots--21 if you count the cover preview window. I have several Instax albums that hold 100+ pics, which are ultimately more practical for storage purposes, but I like that I can utilize this album's modest capacity to curate photos of a single theme or occasion.Additionally, the convenient size makes these ideal for travel or stashing in your camera bag; they're exceptionally lightweight. The bad news is the album is not nearly substantial enough to merit the price.The hard cover linen fabric sets this album apart from all the flexible pleather and vinyl albums out there. Tho I doubt I'd repurchase one of these, some consumers might appreciate a few more color options in darker, richer tones.The internal sleeves are low glare polypropylene, of decent thickness. A lot of other "Instax" albums were actually made as business card holders (since Fuji Instax shares very similar dimensions) but this album appears to be designed specifically for Instax film. Your entire picture is covered by the sleeve; no part of it will hang out the sides. Which may be a good feature for some--but does make grabbing/rearranging your pics a bit more challenging. So far I've not had any sleeve tears or rips.I happen to take far more portrait pics than landscape, so the native orientation of this book is fine for me. (I'm still waiting for a quality Instax album that offers sleeves, on the same page, for both display orientations.)Due to the storage limitations, this album is a cinch to quickly fill up. I think young photographers (or anyone who realizes how pricey the film is) would still feel quite accomplished to complete this album and offer it as a gift w/ a personal touch. It would also work OK for folks who may not take as many pics as I tend to.Unfortunately, the flimsy construction and that slightly disposable "Made in China" quality reduce this to more of a party favor than a must-have item for Instax junkies. Another gripe: the internal binding--it always opens to the middle. I know that's the default position for albums of this ilk but it's a gripe nevertheless. I hate looking at the cheap plastic seam.

I recently purchased and reviewed Volcom's "Lolita" bag--another affordable fabric carry-all featuring the same casual west coast vibe. That bag had everything I wanted in a slouchy piece except for interior organization. So on to the Epic Stranger.I ordered in Astral Aura; the colors are muted blues & purples and true to Amazon's online images. It's 100% cotton and sorta kinda soft...but not nearly as soft as I was hoping. The colors look like a hippie beach towel but the bag doesn't feel plush like one. And unfortunately the burlap-y weave easily snags, ditto for the rope cinchers. (I won't remove a star for how hideously wrinkled my bag arrived--that's an Amazon issue. But the DEEP creases from packing make this economical bag look, well, cheap; they still haven't relaxed even 2 weeks later. So be aware.)The bag is about the size I typically prefer to carry and is true to Amazon's dimensions. I'm not too petite so it doesn't overwhelm me, but some may find it too bulky for everyday use. The cinch top gives the illusion of more structure; however, the bag is overall really slouchy and is a true north/south style. So the 2 interior slip pockets are needed. The lack of a zippered pocket is a slight annoyance but I knew it didn't have one prior to ordering so I can't fault the bag.The double closure may annoy some, it does me. I'm OK with the drawstring but it feels bulky when fully cinched. And you have to kinda fiddle with the over flap to keep the bag looking finished and "shut". (Obviously this style of bag won't keep your purse contents very secure as it's lacking a zipper.) But this incredibly thin, far too narrow piece of fabric Roxy decided to use for the flap is not doing the bag any favors. If you opt to keep the bag uncinched, the flap just hangs there looking sloppy. And I really dislike the super frayed edges on the end of the rope. Looked cute online but not so in person.I picked this up on a deep sale and with an additional holiday promotion. If I'd paid full retail it would have been promptly returned. It's just 'meh' at the end of the day. It'll look decently cute with sandals and a sundress but IMO it's limited to a street fair or trip to the pool. The fabric and cheap-o closure flap just let me down and is, for this already super casual girl, still a touch too casual for a practical every day bag. Think: tween headed to the pool or skatepark. And even for that demographic, the quality doesn't justify the price.

I'm a total Instax junkie and these particular albums are my very favorite to store/browse my MINI instax photos. (This won't work for classic wide instant film.) I'm on my second one, with another coming soon. It's already been pointed out that these really weren't designed as photo albums but rather for business cards. Regardless, these still more than do the trick!This one is a muted cream, not "white". The inside pages are a dark shocking pink--not my favorite color but it does highlight pics really well. This album style is offered in a variety of colors but the color of the cover rarely matches the inside pages...so you'll have to pick a combo that suits you best. The pleather is surprisingly soft and not too vinyl-like, and, because it's synthetic, is sturdy and easy to clean.In cheap photo albums it's actually the binding and spine I worry about more than the outside cover because sometimes the spine or the plastic internal binding is too flimsy, or conversely too stiff--making turning pages really annoying. I want a satisfying, smooth and quick flipping through the pages feel without worrying the whole thing will come apart at the seam or get stuck or hung up after repeated use. This delivers the ease I like.Additionally, the inside sheets and slots in other albums are prone to rip and be brittle or too 'sticky'. Out of 120 slots in this one, I've only had tears on a couple--and that was due more to my carelessness. The slots fit Instax minis perfectly, not too loose nor too snug. Yes, the very end of the pic will stick out about a 1/4 of an inch but personally I prefer this as it makes grabbing them and rearranging them a breeze. Also, if I'm feeling girly or channelling my inner 6-year old, I may decorate some photos; the slots aren't so snug that they won't accommodate a sticker or embellishment or two and the full page doesn't get too weighed down if sliding anything else behind the pics.***If you're a stickler about such things, do note the design of this album means landscape Instax are the native display. I file all my portrait shots at the back of the album and work my way front, thus kinda creating two albums in one and eliminating the need to constantly rotate.Once totally full, the album still closes easily; the simple closure is more than adequate and the album doesn't get so "fat" that it looks weird. Bottom line is these hold up well, fit the pics, is easy to stash in my camera bag but attractive enough to display, and won't break the bank.***For 90 Neo Classic users, here's a little trick I use: because of the extra bells and whistles on this model and because the film ain't cheap, I slide a mini index card behind each photo in this album showing the settings I used/time of day/lighting conditions. This has saved me a few bucks because macro, double imposed, etc., can be surprisingly tricky so it's nice to reference past settings on successful pics.

Pretty cute fingerless hand warmers with just the right amount of sparkle--any more flashy and they might read a little cheap. But the quality is decent, they're sewn well, they're not too scratchy, and they're priced right for what you're getting. Sometimes when little bits are sewn on to knit, you end up with some dangling rhinestones or an unfinished look, but I was impressed by the quality application of the bling. There was just a hint of unraveling at a finger hole or two but nothing that compromised their use.I think there may be a mix up from the warehouse regarding the color. I ordered in charcoal gray but received the midnight blue though it was marked as gray on the external packaging. No biggie, and didn't wanna mess with the return, but if you're a stickler, be warned you may end up with midnight blue if you order gray and vice versa. The midnight blue is actually a very lovely shade and if you don't pair it with actual gray, in low light it reads gray anyway. The midnight blue ended up looking adorable with jeans.The fit is on the small side, something you might pick up in the juniors department. I appreciate the more snug fit as pieces like this tend to easily stretch out from frequent on/off. If you're more sturdy boned, these should still accommodate you but I would first recommend them for more petite frames or even older little girls. My mom is a teeny 5 foot lady, weighs right at 100 lbs and these were still snug on her bony frame.Also, the pair I received was not quite as long as what appears in the online images; they extend well above the wrist but not as far up the arm as on the mannequin.Cute, affordable, and if you don't mind chilly fingers, still way more convenient than most "texting" gloves--those never seem to consistently work. So I recommend!

I recently wrote a lengthy review for the unscented/unflavored 3-pack version of this formula which is my favorite of the Out of Africa lip balms and rescued my lips last winter...making me a die hard fan. The unscented version is more earthy and slightly more difficult to apply if it gets too cold, but at the end of the day I still prefer not to actually taste my lip balm.However, when the unscented formula was unavailable for some time on Amazon, I determined orange cream sounded the most palatable from the remaining options. It contains generous amount of Shea butter (30% for this formula) and, though it indeed tastes just like an orange cream popsicle, the flavor is mild enough to not overwhelm.  Here are the ingredients directly copied from the OOA website:"Ingredients: Pure Unrefined Shea Butter, Sunflower Oil, Candelilla Wax, Grapeseed Oil, Orange Cream Flavor, Cocoa Butter,  Vitamin E, Rosemary Extract, Calendula. No Parabens, Sulfates, Petrolatums or Phthalates. Cruelty Free & Eco-Friendly"It's difficult to find a good lip balm that doesn't contain petroleum, mineral oil, or lanolin. This made in the USA formula doesn't trigger any reactions in my very allergy-prone skin.The application is fairly smooth, my tubes don't have any chunks or too much earthy bits--a common complaint in products that contain a lot of unrefined shea. If you're accustomed to using Vaseline-like lip treatments, you may find it "pulls" a little. It's not thick or greasy tho still too emollient to use right before lipstick. It's colorless but does dull the color of your lips a bit until it absorbs... and also doesn't provide a sheen like some higher end lip treatments, but as I'm after long-lasting true moisture, these are not negatives for me. A few swipes to warm it up is all the application requires; it will sit on the lips for a few minutes until it sinks in. And when it does, it's a true salvation to parched lips.One tube lasts a long time even with daily application. However, because it is so effective, I don't need to reapply several times during the day. I'm down to just overnight application for the summer months. The price is right too.One note: some of these Out of Africa balms are sold as "3-packs" while others are "3-counts". If you order a 3-count you will receive 3 loose tubes. There's no manufacturer packaging at all. No biggie but it did surprise me when 3 tubes just fell right out of the packing envelope. Each tube is individually sealed with a little paper adhesive but not shrink wrapped or with retail packaging. Great for the environment but not so appealing to the germphobe.

I find this to be a fantastic value. I originally purchased this model 4 1/2  years back based solely on price and its size. Threw it into my Amazon cart without reading, at the time, the few available reviews. I just needed a cheap clock for my mom's patio, wasn't picky. Even though this is not designed for outdoor use, we hung it up in her partially covered patio. It kept perfect time, required only a couple of battery changes, and was still going strong through 4 brutal Dallas summers and several freezes until a gust finally sent it shattering. (It had actually fallen several times prior and never actually broke...this thing is the Energizer Bunny of cheap wall clocks!) I ended up buying the exact replacement, thanks to looking it up in my Amazon order history. The new one is just as solid and I anticipate an equally lengthy life.Because it's outdoors, we don't notice any loud ticking but I'd happily chose this model for indoors if the need ever arises. The style fits most decor, the hands and numbers are super easy to read from several yards away, and we're just so impressed by its hardiness and accuracy. I've paid much more for supposedly higher quality clocks that turned out to be duds.

Due to metal sensitives, I'm just trusting the claim that these are 14k and truly nickel-free. I ordered in white gold but because of the miniaturized size--making reading a stamp, if there is one, virtually impossible--and with zero documentation in or on the gift box or internal packaging, your guess is as good as mine. Typically manufacturers include a sticker or more clearly label genuine 14K gold products to justify a price point. These are supposed to be 58.5% pure gold and "hypoallergenic" but that term is flung around as lightly as supermarkets claim their veggies are "organic". Not too worried about it. But it's important to note--especially if giving these as a gift or have an allergy severe enough you need to more definitively ensure the authenticity. What metals comprise the remaining percentage tends to vary by maker. I'd feel better calling these nickel-safe than nickel-free.I got these for a second ear piercing; it's recommended to wear earrings 24/7 the first year. But I'm a side sleeper so that makes most studs uncomfortable for overnight.Based on reading all the reviews I was expecting the itty bitty size--in fact that's solely why I purchased--but obviously these function for me as a cuff rather than a hoop. I have exceptionally average sized ears and yes, while these are indeed dinky tiny, I was still a little surprised that so many people reported these too small for infants. Because technically I think I could get them in my regular ear piercing.  So mileage varies. Be aware of the dimensions and I don't think you'll be disappointed.The on/off is easy peasy and I'm usually all thumbs in that department. However, if you happened to receive a pair that didn't 'click' closed, as they're intended to, these would need to be promptly returned--they could slip off far too easily.  But my pair is made well and comfy and the closing mechanism is solid. Wish I had more certainty regarding the metal content but only time will tell. I like them well enough to consider purchasing in the yellow gold as well.

I'm a bit of a sucker for a supple, high quality leather handbag. But as summer is upon us, I decided I'd look for a fun, more affordable fabric bag that could handle trips to the lake and being flung around in the Jeep floorboard.Firstly, based on the online images, I was expecting this bag to be absolutely gigantic--on the model the proportions look nearly comical. I'm not exactly petite but I did wonder if this thing would dwarf me. However, in person, while definitely on the large side, this isn't some crazy weekend trip/diaper bag. The actual dimensions are true to Amazon's listing but the imposed photography on the model is, IMO, way off. Think big. But not kitchen sink big. Could function as an overnight bag, depending on how one packs for an overnight but there's no way I could pack 2-3 days in this. More of a single towel and swimsuit. Bottom line, size wise, *I* actually found this to be a smidge smaller than I was hoping.I ordered in zebra. When the Lolita arrived I found the print very cute (the white bits aren't glaringly bright white, more of a eggshell white) and the bag very soft but...very, very thin. At this price point that's OK but it could easily rip if you're rough on your bags. Zipper pull works nicely, better than some of my bags that cost 5x more. The dual handles are comfy but too short to crossbody. It's fully lined, that's a nice bonus but......I'm withholding a star due to 0 interior organization. Not a slip pocket, a zippered pouch, nada. Even if your intention isn't to use this as a true everyday purse, most girls need a single pocket to stash a phone, a lipstick, anything you don't want to be fishing around for. I love a sloppy, unstructured hobo bag and that's exactly what I got. A bag, not a purse. It's cute but limited in function. But at Amazon's sale price w/current holiday promotion, it's still a recommend.FROM THE LABEL: 100% rayon; Made in India; wipe with a damp cloth if needed

I'm not an audiophile nor remotely close to an expert on earphones and their accessories. But I am a wife of a guy who loses earbud covers like there's no tomorrow. So the quantity over quality vs price is why I gleefully added these to my Cart. But then when these turned out to be a far higher quality than we were expecting, um, SCORE!Hubby routinely falls asleep wearing his earbuds. He's kinda a violent sleeper so these doodads tend to go missing in the night. He needs a foam cover that not only fits properly but that is comfy; these do the trick. His Sony buds are 14mm. These covers are likely intended for the old school Apple buds--measuring a few mm larger than his Sonys--and while the fit is just ever so slightly loose, these absolutely work. I wouldn't recommend these for earbuds measuring much over 18mm or so....though as I mentioned, I'm no expert.Our local Radio Shack wanted $11 for 2 pair of these--arguably, they were of slightly higher quality, but as this is the sort of item that even reasonably responsible people can easily lose or rip, having an entire bag of these things has proven so helpful. These covers don't muffle the audio, stay put, are comfy, and best yet, you don't have to remortgage the house when your kid steals a couple for miniature dollhouse chair cushions. A solid recommend! Will promptly order more because this 24 pack is about a 6 month supply for us. Who sleeps with earbuds on?!  I'm certain there's a little foam graveyard behind our headboard and Lord knows how many get caught up in pillowcases and put through the washing machine. Heaven help.

The Aranha "Hits ll" is the most current version of this shoe, but this review is for the original. Purchased in the solid black, I received a shiny plastic sandal with glittery bits adorning the upper. The shoe is represented well in Amazon's online images, tho they're more glossy in person.I was anticipating the sandals might have strong chemical odor--like PVC rain boots--but instead, I was greeted by an overwhelming flowery perfume. Not sure if that's just the particular pair I received, but it's really, really strong. My husband tells me that a certain "sweet" smell is associated with some plasticizers. If this it that, YUCK. My pair still isn't fully aired out AND is still so strong that the odor transfers to my feet. Gotta say, I'm not a fan of a plastic scent so strong that it transfers to my actual skin.The fit is TTS in terms of length. I'm a 8.5 in most shoes but ordered the 9 to ensure my piggies had plenty of room. Width is on the narrow side. I wouldn't recommend for a really wide foot tho the plastic certainly has some give. The only part of the sandal I found a tad stiff was the tip of the closed toe, not terribly comfortable. The sole, however, is flexible to the point it goes convex. They'll need some wearing in to eventually conform and "memorize" your foot. The outsole has some basic ribbing, not rugged outdoor gripping, but slippery pavement shouldn't take you out. Of course there's 0 arch support but anyone eyeing the Aranha is probably not planning to walk for miles in these.I have a very, very low instep and bony ankles, so I'm able to fasten these and slip them on and off without messing with the buckle each time. The buckle is a highly shiny, glinty gold which is isn't my favorite finish, but I suppose it "dresses" up the plastic. Several of the holes on the strap were not punched through all the way--something I typically associate with lower quality brands. But once you've worked the notches through, there's about 2-1/2 inches of play in the strap that should accommodate higher insteps or wider ankles. Nicely adjustable.The overall look was a bit more juvenile than I was excepting--not necessarily a bad thing--but I wasn't surprised when I discovered Melissa makes a popular baby/kid line of these exact sandals. Since they're forgiving for Spring puddles, slightly more chic for the beach than most flip flops or Crocs, and are travel friendly, they are a more practical addition to my closet than a fashionable one. They're decently comfy but I should have realized, based on my wardrobe, they aren't the every day sandal I'd convinced myself they'd be. There's matte finishes offered as well, and I suspect those may be more versatile.Even at Amazon's sale price, these sandals may strike most as overpriced for what they are--a 100% synthetic shoe--not unlike those jellies we paid $5 for in the '80s. This version has the VW logo attached onto the t-strap and this is what you're paying for. The quality is moderately good but in a jelly shoe it's a stretch to say your feet know it's "designer". If you want a vegan sandal to hit the boardwalk or feel suffocated by the average galoshes, I recommend. But as a tee and jeans girl in the city, these don't skew as the casual rubber sandal I'd hoped for.

Absolutely adorable. I ordered in Ivory for my mom. I'd admired this little cap since I first spied it on the BCBG site but didn't want to cough up the full price. But Amazon has it marked down so I pounced.It's really great quality, sewn well, and the little sparkly touches on the owl's ears and nose add a nice touch. I guess with the added bling this is as 'sophisticated' as an over-the-ear hat shaped like an owl can get. ;-)The fit on my mom (she's a 7-1/4" hat size) was snug, as these sort of caps should be. The piece is surprisingly heavy but she wore it comfortably. The goal to keep her ears warm was achieved. In style. Much better than bulky ear muffs. The knit is soft but stiff enough to hold its shape. Meaning it won't flop down or lose its shape. No flaccid owl ears here.Every time she wore it out in the recent bitter NYC winter, she was repeatedly complimented. When grumps on the E train are loving it, you know it's a winner. It's just that undeniably cute. If you like cozy, whimsical pieces this is winner. But if you're tempted to purchase for a child, be sure to note this is indeed adult sized.

Based on numerous reviews here (and elsewhere on the Web) claiming this shoe ran very small, I ordered up. Bad choice. Either Bed Stu is producing new stock with more accurate sizing, or I received a weird, accurately sized pair. I typically wear a 8.5-9 but ordered a 9.5 based on the Internet feedback yet the 9.5 was way too long. A 9 or even an 8.5 would have worked.  I also read the strap is so short some people couldn't even get it to buckle across their foot. I had the opposite issue--too long of a strap and if it stretched just a little I'd have to add an additional hole. Granted, I have low instep. But why would you order up if you have a wide foot/instep just to have a shoe too comically long in length? So I wouldn't advise ordering a full size up.As for the shoe itself, I was underwhelmed. I love beat up vintage leather (a la Freebirds, Kickers, or Frye) but the pair I received in "Black Lux" wasn't very weathered and looked exceptionally dull. Just like a regular old dark gray leather flat. One of the rare cases where a shoe is much cuter online than in person. Not to mention the outsole is ridiculously slippery and even on carpet it was like ice skating.Tho my biggest gripe was the stiffness. One of best things about a quality Mary Jane or ballet flat is how soft and pliable they become, virtually conforming to your unique foot. The Shuffle is is not the first pair from this brand that I've found stiff, tough and stubborn. I'm ok with that in a rugged boot but a non malleable Mary Jane is always uncomfortable and I found these rubbed badly against my heel and across the toe bed. Painful. They weren't gonna give no matter how long a break-in period. I love artisan shoe makers but this was a big miss for me. I expected sizing woes but just ended up with an uncomfortable, startlingly blah shoe. Promptly returned.

I sought this out because in winter I hate the bulk of a ring under my leather gloves AND I was sick of snagging expensive knit garments on my rings.WHAT I LIKE:Available in some fun colorsSmooth, quality siliconeMetal-freeFits true to your traditional ring sizePriced only about 10 cents more than knockoffs of questionable quality (stick with pieces actually made by and marked QALO)Saves my winter sweaters from snaggingGreat under gloves, both fashion and safety onesMalleable enough to accommodate those who fluctuate a half ring size or soSmall zippered case is includedWorkout friendlyLightweight, comfortable, not cumbersomeInexpensive so if you lose it, you won't have a coronary episodeTwo different widths available for larger handsQuiet. If you have a jewelry fiddler in your life, buy this!Safe for virtually any career/hobby where a metal band is not idealWHAT I DISLIKE:I hate soap residue and grime under my rings so I always remove jewelry when I wash my hands. Removing this is more of a PITA than my metal rings as it kinda grips on and doesn't  quickly slide off. It fits correctly but it's still not an easy on/off. Lots of wiggling it up and wrangling it off the finger.  Moisture LOVES living under this ring. It's my biggest and basically only gripe. Metal allergies are awful but rashes from trapped moisture aren't fun either.Also, while I like the colors offered, funky colors in a very dull silicone don't necessarily scream 'wedding ring alternative'-- should that be the intent of your purchase (and it certainly seems marketed that way). I'm far from traditional, my hubby and I don't routinely wear wedding rings of any material to declare our status, but I am not confident this rubber-like O ring will meet your mother-in-law's approval or convince that one weird co-worker you are indeed taken. Just saying. Mileage will vary. But even in the rapidly growing world of alternative wedding jewelry this is exceptionally casual.Solid purchase, priced right.

Ordered in the black. I'm a hat junkie and have had success with hats from this brand-- this piece is no exception.SHAPE/LOOK: In a plain black hat, I prefer a round crown as otherwise they tend to skew a bit witchy-poo. So this hat's shape works for me as does the moderately-sized brim (so it doesn't scream vapid starlet at Coachella.) The wireless brim is technically 'floppy' but is ultimately still structured. It's dynamic while remaining a little more low profile. I own one too many menswear-inspired fedoras so was after something more feminine. I love cloches, but they don't jibe with edgier looks. This is a versatile silhouette that can be dressed up or down and ticks all the right boxes as my go-to fall/winter topper.BAND: I wasn't thrilled to discover that the 1" faux leather band is not one solid color all-around; this is not reflected in Amazon's images. In the front: black band. In the back: metallic silver. Not a huge fan of silver--though thankfully it's not too too shiny-- so I may attempt to remove/replace the band. (This is typically not difficult to do as long as you have the correct glue and use a replacement band that is not more narrow than the original.)FIT: As with many BCBGeneration hats, it's adjustable via a kind of pull and tighten string that's threaded into the sweat band. I have a big noggin for a chick (approx 7-1/12) and so this fits me without needing to utilize this feature--I cannot vouch for how effective the adjustability system truly is. However, I feel confident that the circumference will work on all but the most extreme hat sizes.SIZE: Nothing too exaggerated here. The hat may be called Asymmetrical but as far as my own measurements reflect, this hat is not. The brim is a versatile 2-3/4" all around, a fashion brim as opposed to a sun hat. The inner circumference is approx 23". From the base of the band to the top of the crown is approx 4". The floppy-esque brim can be fiddled with a bit but not to the point that I'd call the visual result 'asymmetrical'.MATERIAL/CARE: 100% wool. Fabric care label: NO washing or dry cleaning (despite Amazon's description). It's soft and warm, not scratchy, but quite sturdy. It can be stored without fuss because it doesn't have the classic indented fedora crown, though this isn't really a 'roll and go' packable hat.**SHIPPING: If you're a frequent online purchaser of hats then you probably know that stores tend to absolutely destroy the structure of a hat when they cram it into a box or shipping bag; this trend unfortunately afflicts basement bargain sites to really high end shops. Mercifully, my hat arrived with a full sized heavy plastic inner shaper, a protective band, plastic wrap, and having been placed in an amply sized box. Refreshing. Thanks, Amazon.PRICE/VALUE: It's soft, stylish, comfy, and a great deal cheaper here than most other retailers. I've had other hats from this brand and they wear very well--can take some beating. This is a winner.**ETA 2 months later:  I like this hat so much I ended ordering the wineberry too. (I've worn the living daylights out of the black one and it's held up marvelously). Anyhoo, this hat is indeed great but I wish I hadn't bragged about Amazon's stellar packing; typically I don't include shipping issues in product reviews but as a hat is something that must be packed carefully to prevent possible permanent damage, shipping care is crucial. Different warehouse, different day...because my second hat was completely crushed, flattened, and placed in  2-1/2" high box. Shameful. I will add the color is awesome tho, true to online images. And it's regained its shape, thankfully.

I was startled over how difficult it was to find one of these "old timey" zipper pouches on Amazon. They were a staple of my youth but now they seem rather overpriced and of seriously questionable quality.Sadly, this one is very stiff, even for vinyl--it has not proven helpful in storing the light weight items (mainly stickers) I use in a scrapbook organization binder. I suppose asking for a plastic to be both sturdy yet quite flexible is a feat too daunting. (?!)The punch holes aren't cut widely enough so I have to hold my tongue just right to flip past this in my standard 3-ring binder. If it was more malleable it would prove more useful for my purposes. Yet it's so thin I can't see even using it for a few standard school supplies --as any actual bulk will make the zipper even more stubborn.Speaking of, the 'zipper' is questionable, at best. In my grown up hands I can gently maneuver it; young children will likely grow frustrated attempting to slide it back and forth. Most kids aren't accustomed to 1960s technology. (And this model hasn't been improved upon since.)It's a binder pocket pouch so it's a low expectation kind of item that doesn't exactly merit my harsh criticism. Yet it really doesn't work well... so you find yourself writing 200 words on Amazon warning fellow consumers to skip it and continue their zipper binder pouch quest elsewhere.

Average to below average in every way. I'm hardly a professional musician and I'd venture to guess most folks seeking out this 'always brings a smile' instrument aren't aspiring to the philharmonic, but I know enough about melodicas to decipher this one is nothing special. Most cheap melodicas (and in fairness, often even pricer ones) tend to be delivered already out of tune...or quickly arrive there. Unless you can tolerate sharpness straight out of the gate, with enthusiastic and frequent play, definitely expect to be tuning this frequently. Melodicas are typically not tuned via A 440 so they may sound sharp regardless but they at least should be consistent within that range. (My middle A key was tuned to 'makes the dog howl', not in the A443 stratosphere at all).An exercise in patience, pay no mind to the description claiming it stays in tune, brass reeds, la la la. All melodicas need tuning. Some much sooner rather than much later, like this one.The plastic housing is on par with similarly priced pieces and the keys have a decent heft to them. However, a few keys on mine arrived with an annoying loose 'clicking' and this is unfortunately the quality control issues so many mass produced Made in China/Tawain/etc., instruments suffer. If you stick to the middle octaves it's not so bad, but why add the fuller 37 range if the lower/higher keys sound awful both in tone and in clickety clack construction?Effectively cleaning a melodica is not for the faint of heart and is a PITA in general, but this one proves especially tasking and seems to require a longer than usual drain time. My first melodica was a child's toy by Schoenhut (that still sounds great) and yet cleaning it was/is a dream comparatively. This gives you some indication of how far this model needs to go. "Not really much better than a bona fide toy" is not a ringing endorsement.In that vein, I've used better flex tubes from a melodica purchased in the toy department. This one manages to be both flimsy and stiff all at once: a real feat! While this is an easily replaced item, I still would have appreciated a higher quality extension piece included. Additionally, the plastic mouthpiece (spit valve to some) on my particular instrument was scratched so there's a possibility I received a previously returned product. Or...Hohner, once again, fudges quality control.The oft enthusiastically mentioned gig case is certainly decent. But..it's a textile gig case and kinda hard to mess up. I'd discourage anyone to purchase this on the appeal of the case alone! (Nearly every melodica comes with a surprisingly professional-looking case.)This model is one of the least expensive 37-keys on the market and, feeling frugal, I took the plunge. I wasn't swayed by the brand name because I know it isn't the brand it once was. Because I now only play a handful of times a year, this works well enough for a brief duet session with my hubby. Fun and games. But musically inclined folks who hate out of tune instruments or anyone more seriously exploring the melodica would be better served looking elsewhere.I'm befuddled how it makes the list of 'recommended', even if anemically so, by several melodica sites. So take my bah humbug review with a grain of salt and keep expectations low. And of course, since it's a melodica, it's impossible to not have a little fun! Just don't get dazzled by the Hohner name or you may feel disappointed.

Cursed with a zealously pesky mustache area no girl should have to suffer, and after getting fed up with harsh bleaches and waxes, I began tweezing my upper lip. But...After plucking sessions, I began to experience what appeared to be contact dermatitis--something beyond simple irritation of the follicle. The skin above my lip IS sensitive (thus the cessation of bleaches) but this was an odd, specific, non seeping rash that tended to pop up 48-72 hrs post-plucking. I was using ancient and kinda grody tweezers. And then I recalled that in my 20s (two decades ago) I would get flaky, weird skin right under my brows--literally the only skin problems I ever had--but I was an obsessive brow tweezer. Now as I no longer pluck my brows: Voila, I realized I haven't experienced weird brow flakes/rashes in years! So...an internet search led me to a possible nickel sensitivity; this link between dermatitis & plucking felt too compelling to ignore.I have not seen a dermatologist and by no means do I trust my self-diagnosis. But this brand was recommend by several skin allergy-sufferer sites and so I tossed out my tweezers of unknown metal content. I opted for the pointy tip as for whatever reason I feel I have more control than with the slant tip (plus for splinters and other non-cosmetic tasks the needle tips prove more versatile). I had my hubby sterilize them as these are supposedly surgical grade, and, again, come recommended by nickel allergy suffers. So far, so good!! My follicles aren't hating me thus far and, though I've made sure not to overdo it, after 4 days post-pluck, I've not had a flare up. (Apparently in mild cases, you can eat nickel-laden foods and even use other products containing nickel on other parts of the body but still experience facial reactions, e.g. earrings, tweezers, etc.,.)The balance is good, they're appropriately sharp, and the heft is just right. These are nearly 4-1/2 inches so if you're used to minis or cheapy lightweight tweezers these may take some adjusting to. Whether or not you're exploring these due to sensitivities or you just merely want made-in-Germany quality for your first aid or cosmetic kit, I recommend these.FROM THE PACKAGE: Tweezer, Needle Tips, Anti-Allergic"Destined (sic) for professional use by sterilization"PRINTED ON TWEEZERS: LANCET, Niegeloh, Solingen GermanyStainless Topinox 19018

Read enough reviews of ANY skincare product and you'll encounter a person who experienced an adverse reaction. So, tho this cream reeked absolute havoc on my eyes, take it with a grain of salt as this formula has a lot of fans--and interestingly enough, fans claiming to have sensitive eyes. I'm learning my eyes are just ridiculously sensitive: on the evening of the 3rd day of use, my eyes felt as they'd been doused with chili peppers and then set on actual fire. No good. No good indeed. This went beyond just a 'Ohh this stings a little and feels itchy' kind of sensation. Also, I don't wear contacts. I'd applied it lightly (and correctly) but alas, even up to my eyebrows it was a 4 alarm ordeal.So, though I'm an occasional fan the Basescu line, do beware that the SECOND listed ingredient is a known irritant: Polyglycerylmethacrylate; used as a kind of film-forming agent, it's often downright unkind to truly sensitive eye suffers. I didn't thoroughly explore the ingredients prior to purchase but after my reaction, I hopped on my favorite makeup/skin care reviewing site and discovered I was hardly alone in the '3 days later' reaction. Add in the generous oil content and milia sufferers may wanna consider skipping it too.It went on creamy, the formula can be worn under concealer, and I loved the price. (Though I'm not a huge fan of non-tube packaging). I hate preachy reviews so If it works for you, why shouldn't it be recommended? I just wish it had worked out, but as an unmitigated disaster, it's a 1-star formula for moi.I didn't purchase this on Amazon but as I frequently consult Amazon for product reviews, this is just a heads up to fellow super sensitive-eye gals.From the MB website: Deionized Water (Aqua),Polyglycerylmethacrylate (and) Propylene Glycol,Carnation (Mineral) Oil,Propylene Glycol (and) Water (and) Euphrasia (Euphrasia Officinalis) Extract,Cetearyl Alcohol (and) Ceteareth-20,Vegetable (Olus) Oil, Aloe Vera (Aloe Barbadensis Leaf Juice) Gel, Polyquaternium-24, Hyaluronic Acid

This has what I was looking for: unrefined shea butter as the 1st ingredient (w/other all natural ingredients...tho just because it's natural doesn't mean it's incapable of causing an allergy/irritation so your mileage may vary.) I was trying to avoid fragrance & petroleum so this formula works for me. Despite the exotic moniker, it's made in the USA and sold here as a 3 pack.Researching reviews of this brand on other sites, I saw reports of a grainy texture and a less than ideal application due to it--that may be caused by the product getting a little too cold. For the uninitiated, shea butter can be difficult to work with and as this contains generous amounts of it, it definitely is not a formula you can just mindlessly swipe over the lips--rather, you do need to work with it and warm it up a bit. This means using a finger and that's a negative for some. I don't find it "grainy" as much as I do thick, with occasional earthy-like chunks. Again, not for everyone.Tho it's not greasy, to wear under lipstick you'll need a light application; if you're accustomed to a product that absorbs very quickly, this is not for you. Even with my winter parched lips, a few generous swipes of this sits on the lips for awhile. I prefer this as I want true long-lasting conditioning, not just a lip that feels momentarily, superficially smooth. It's not tacky or too waxy, but it IS robust. After 15 or so minutes it begins slowly absorbing and it feels...awesome and soothing.Aesthetically it doesn't offer a shine like some lip treatments and, because it's buttery balm, until it absorbs it does dull the natural color of your lips. This isn't going to provide a Snow White sheen effect or offer a tint that us cosmetics junkies call "your lips but better". Nope.On initial application I occasionally get a very brief bitter sensation, but not an unnatural taste that lingers even if repeatedly licking your lips. I'm super sensitive to scent, with fragranced lip products as the biggest offender, so this passed my test with flying colors. It is also available in flavored versions like orange, peppermint, strawberry, vanilla cream. Whatever floats your boat.A lot of people have sensitivities to petroleum, mineral oil, and even lanolin so this appears an ideal alternative. It functions as a superb protectant against wind and winter conditions (or sitting under a fan for hours at a time). After a few weeks of use, applying 2x a day, I've not had the typically painful, peeling and flaking lips (and lip line) that has plagued me every previous winter. So it's a real success in my book. And a single tube lasts a long time so the value is solid.Direct from the tube: "Naturally rich in moisture and loaded with antioxidants"Ingredients: Butyrospermum Parkii Fruit (unrefined pure shea butter)' Helianthus Annus (sunflower) seed oil, Vitis Vinifera (grapeseed) oil, Euphorbia Cerifera (candelilla) wax, Theobroma Cacao (cocoa) seed butter, Tocopherol (Vit E), Rosemarmarinus Officinalis (Rosemary) Extract, Calendula Officinalis Flower Extract0.15 Oz (4g)MADE IN USA

NOT WINDCHIMES:First things first, these aren't anywhere in the family of wind chimes, barely a distant cousin. If you're expecting gale force winds and haven't yet evacuated, perhaps you'll hear them peal.FUNCTIONAL?Yep, they ARE functional and I use mine, indoors, to actually summon my own occasional farm animal: the hubby. However, I'd say they were marketed as purely ornamental pieces and I wouldn't expose them to extreme weather or precipitation.SIZE:Will these properly fit in your shabby chic urban farm space? You get 3. They are: 10"w/ a 10" rope; 7" w/ an 8" rope; 5-1/5" w/ a 6" rope. So the total appropriate length of the pieces with the attached noose-style rope would be 20", 15", and 12". These measurements vary from the listed description, but, like precious snowflakes, I doubt any two are just alike. Width is approximately 5", 4", and 3-1/2". They're all imperfect so measurements were tricky and they're a little lopsided too. One is more of true round circumference while the other two are oval-y shaped.FINISH:The goldish color on the outside is pretty brassy, kinda cheap looking and would never pass for a true antique. The intentionally weathered external treatment can, and will, flake off if you mishandle them. If you sport a claw-like manicure, be gentle. The inside of the bell is...well, it's rough. It looks kinda farm legit. Read: dirty. And please, wash your hands. I feel at one point a family of birds may have built their nest inside them.SOUNDS LIKE:The tone they emit is truly pleasant and you may have to look down to check for cow patties underfoot--so true a bona fide cow bell do they mimic. Not cling clangy and annoyingly high pitched (even from the tiny one), but deep and rich and non headache-inducing. The ringer is not very long but there's enough dangling down that you can grab it and give it a good wiggle. But they're designed to be grabbed and shaken all over. Don't rely on the ringer to produce the sound independently.HANGING:The rope is a loop so you'll need a toggle bolt to securely hang these. Or remove the rope and do your own thing. They're not particularly heavy but substantial enough that you shouldn't crudely tack them up with just a nail.ON ARRIVAL:I made the mistake of opening these on my bed. Ugggg. They were packaged decently well but in transport, lots of little chips and shaved bits and dirt of exotic origins spilled out. So do yourself a favor and don't rip into them on the same linens you eat or sleep on, kay? Good.ON THE HANG TAG:Made in India. Item #26719. That's all, folks.VERDICT:Either you'll be all like Hey, Cool 3 Bells for Twenty Smackeroos or Oh...I Paid an Entire Andrew Jackson for These?! Keep expectations low, gain a neat conversation piece for your rustic themed kitchen, and step back in time before home intercoms, texting your family from 2 rooms away, or my fallback: just yelling your head off. Call em to dinner with a cowbell, ma.

Is the Asphalto your first stab at a Kickers brand shoe? Well good luck. I happen to own a few pairs and positively ADORE them: they look beautiful, age gracefully (if not at all), and are lovingly crafted from high quality materials. However...Poke around the reviews of other Kickers styles and discover for yourself how oddly sized they tend to be. I'm well versed in translating UK/US/EU sizes but it's still a total crap shoot when ordering Kickers. The issue is made even more complicated by the FREQUENTLY inaccurate labeling on the box vs the size sticker inside the shoe vs the size stamp on the outsole vs the ACTUAL size they end up being. Confused much? You may receive a pair that says UK 39 on the box with a US 6 on the shoe but they fit like a 7. Fun! Guys, there IS a way to translate shoe sizes, a simple and typically accurate universal conversion chart. Kickers kinda throws that to the wind. Ha!Soooo...these ended up going back because they were waaaay too huge for my mom. She's a US 6.5 and we "think" we received the 37 (it's what we ordered) but when they arrived they fit like rain galoshes and not like the roughly size US 6.5-7 they should have been (and what Amazon called a US6). Oh well. Frankly, even if they'd fit, the style was not her thing; these have a masculine quality. One *I* appreciate in a winter boot but isn't for everyone.The dual zippers are a great touch for easy on/off. The leather is thick, high quality; it's pliable and sturdy without feeling stiff. These are a superlative example of a no nonsense, streamlined boot that will appeal to girls who don't like a lot of bells and whistles or brand advertisement on their footwear. Hardware is a subtle, antiqued brass. Arch support is minimal but there's light padding in the bed. Outsole is a non-slip w/o appearing overly rugged or lug soled. The shaft is about 7 inches; the circumference is narrow so don't expect to tuck jeans in unless it's the skinniest of skinnies. Width is a solid US M (yay, they managed that ok) but you're on your own with the length. Don't give up on his brand, do exercise patience.The Asphalto isn't exactly a moto, engineer, combat, or Chelsea boot. It's is own thing and I adore the simplicity. But I can't recommend it if it's your first foray into Kickers as the sizing is definitely off, perhaps even more so than in their other styles. 5 stars for quality and style, 2 stars for fit.

I ordered these in the black and gray for my mom. She's a 6.5 in nearly every sort of shoe, but based on multiple reviews that this fits really, really small, we sized up a 1/2 size to a 7. Verdict? We definitely could have just ordered in her typical 6.5: the pair we received was not at all undersized. The off-reported, weird 'sewn-in tongue' was also not an issue. Her foot is on the wide side of a standard M--with an incredibly high instep too--and she had zero problems sliding into the shoe...even with the laces only slightly loosened. Arch support/padding is minimal.Our issue is with the outsole. It's dangerously slick. I mean like iceskating on an oil spill slick. Unless you plan to wear these exclusively on carpet, prepare to find some concrete and shuffle vigorously to break-in/roughen up the sole of these puppies before you dare to walk on any hard surface... OR pay your friendly local cobbler to have the sole modified. You wanna mess with that? Prolly not.These shoes at original retail would be a huge 'no thanks' but based on Amazon's current listing, they were basement bottom priced-- that's literally the only reason dear ol' mama's gonna keep them. The style is truly cute: a feminized, fuzzy version of a guy's dress oxford. But we can tell the knit portion will pile horribly. Not to mention the synthetic leather looks, well like synthetic leather. Not all 'vegetarian' leather is created equally. The Shayleen doesn't look expensive but at this price point, our expectations were low. Yours should be too. I don't typically ascribe to disposable fashion but mom's content to stretch 3 months out of them and then toss/donate.

Super cute, well made jacket that's on trend for winter 2014. But know before you buy: the scant photos provided do not represent the accurate color of the piece!I ordered in the gray for my mother (who is fully embracing the fun faux fur/teddy bear textiles this season). We were surprised to find the coat is indeed a lovely (very light) dove grey but with a dark charcoal back; there's actually THREE colors going on here that are impossible to determine from the online images. In the images provided, it looks like a really flat and one dimensional color story. But due to the nature of the pile, it's actually a tri-colored charcoal, ivory, and gray. It's NOT a solid color. Only the bits at the very end of the Sherpa-like fur are truly just gray. Rub the coat a different direction and there's all kinds of other stuff going on. This actually makes it a more versatile jacket, but we were surprised nonetheless.We ordered both a small and an x-small for her petite 5' 1", 106 lbs frame. The small swallowed her. The x-small fits much better but is still generously cut to accommodate bulky winter layers. If between sizes, I'd err on the side of sizing down. This Generation label of BCBG is essentially marketed to juniors so we assumed it would fit a tad smaller, but they've clearly embraced the slightly oversized trend with this piece. However, the sleeve length was not ridiculously oversized; if you're petite you shouldn't experience the waaay too long sleeves that end up hanging down mid-hand. This was appreciated.The addition of roomy-- but virtually invisible pockets--is great touch and it's SUPER soft. Like an infant's first plush toy, soft. The tiny but sturdy eyelet closures (there's 5 or 6 of them) run the entire length of the jacket so it's up to you how fastened up you opt to be. The lining is a silky poly blend on the sleeve and an interesting sweatshirt-like material for the rest. It's warmer than it would appear and it's heavier than we were expecting. The length (slightly longer in person than Amazon's measurements) ensures it covers the rump--you can sport some super skinnies without being on display.If you're ok with the tri-color material, this is a sincerely adorable piece for lovers (of any age) of more whimsical fashion. Curious to read reviews from anyone who buys in ivory to see if that version, too, is more than it appears.

At a whopping half inch smaller than my typical go-to brand, Field Notes, these flexible kraft paper notebooks (made with recycled paper) weigh in at 3.5x5 with a mere 32 pages. Their featherweight stats promise they're even more pocket friendly than competitors. Streamlined for brevity.The brand offers this"Keeper" line that travels beyond the blank/lined/grid notebooks (which they also offer) with themes like "music keeper", "project keeper", etc., but the critic inside me chose the "review keeper" as I love the idea of tracking and reviewing purchases, cheese & beverages I've sampled, new restaurants....whatever can be documented and given, quite literally, a 1-5 star review.Atop each page (printed front and back) there's a thin rectangle shaped box to title your review, followed by the outline of five large stars that you can shade in/circle to reflect your pleasure or lack of, followed by 6 college-ruled lines. The bottom third of the page contains a large, bordered blank field for....well, not sure on that one. For the wordy amongst us (guilty) you may find yourself disappointed that there's so little of the ruled area. The space utilized by the star field is a bit wasted, and, for my purposes, so is the bottom third. I have decent handwriting but I NEED a lined rule or I go all crooked. Perhaps this box at the bottom is meant for a doodle, free form rant, maybe even a large sticker? The idea is you can do whatever you'd like in the space. And that's nice...especially if you're a person of few words or don't want to be limited by them. But I'd prefer more ruled lines.The binding is two staples; you can easily rip out pages but ripping out more than 3 or 4 can, and in my case, does, compromise the integrity of the entire notebook. The notebooks don't lie flat unless you really abuse them or remove pages, but at this price point I wouldn't expect them to. The thick chipboard cover can be ripped too, these aren't indestructible like a Field Notes "Expedition". This flexibility in a cover--roll it up if you want--is a boon in some situations but will discourage more rugged use. It does, however, accommodate a clipped pen w/o the cover rolling down or experiencing serious damage.The front cover is blank except for carrying over the outline of the 5 stars. Back cover provides a field for "belongs to; a contact field; start date/end date". The notebook has rounded edges for easily flipping through. The paper itself is pleasant to write upon, neither slick nor too pulpy. However...Unfortunately, my pen of choice is either a Le Pen or a Stabilo Point 88 and so there is considerable bleed through on the pages. Even tho both these pens are very fine tipped, the Scout books (and in fairness, most of their competitors too) can't handle anything even approaching a felt tip. Stick to a ballpoint and you'll be fine. The pages aren't as lush as Moleskine, obviously not as plasticky as an Expedition, but ultimately far, far superior to any drugstore notepad you'll ever encounter. I haven't tried Rhodia or Word or the handful of other popular pocket notebooks to compare.I have no true gripes and would buy again. (And have). I've enjoyed keeping track of odds and ends and these are fun companions to list lovers and will aid general jotter types who desire more organization or clarity of topic/theme. Sold in very reasonably priced 3-packs, the value is solid and definitely worth a try. Per their website sourced AND made in the USA!

I had assumed the paper would be nearly as vibrant as the cover images. I was very disappointed to discover the gift wrap is quite muted and doesn't remotely pop like the fetching cover. It's still lovely in terms of the print, but I had absolutely fallen in love with that rich pine green. So to find a kind of dull, rather matronly color palette with no sheen---and with hues SEVERAL shades lighter than the cover--was a real bummer. Dull is hardly the word I would associate with William Morris patterns...so this collection is, to me, a disservice to his designs. Yet here it is.Additionally the deep creases in the paper--and mind you I knew it would arrived folded in book form but there's a way to package these where it's still more versatile and serviceable--mean this is suited for wrapping very small gifts. Trinkets really. I am thinking of projects that could somehow utilize the entire sheet without drawing attention to the creases, but even framing it is challenging as the paper is so faded looking. I love kraft papers, when they're marketed as such, so am fine with low gloss or matte wrapping, but these papers look like they've been sun faded to the point that I suspect I received a defective batch.

Diesel is one of my most favorite brands and even tho I'm way too old for their adorable juniors line, I still couldn't resist the price of this beanie.It's very soft, sewn well, and in the black & yellow I ordered, you'll be as impossible to ignore as a bumblebee. However, this is a VERY roomy beanie--huge even. For a chick, I have a large head (sz 7-1/2 in most structured hats) and this kinda swallows me. While in theory the super generous fit should allow for more styling options vs a more conventional slim profile 'stocking cap', if my hair is too squeaky clean I find I can't keep this on my head. Slippage city. You really need to wear it pulled down well over the ear to keep it on...and unfortunately I prefer my beanies to sit back a bit w/the band behind my ear. If my mass of coarse curly hair is less than shower fresh I have more luck keeping it on. But you may want to reach for a bobby pin.At less than the equivalent price of 2 fast food tacos, I hardly regret buying this. On chilly nights I grab it to curl up in front of the TV. But, for me, it's too high maintenance with its sloppy fit to wear out of doors. A 'bohemian' look is one thing, but I think I could fit another whole person's head in here along with mine. And because it's not a super tight knit, it's not ideal for super cold outdoor temps. But it IS super soft and that counts for something and it doesn't seem like it's going to pill badly and it doesn't shed. Oh, and for the sake of a thorough review, there's 27 little knobby 'puffs' sewn on. Yeah, I counted.From the label: size/type UNI; Made in China; 70% acrylic, 30% wool; HAND wash (Amazon's machine wash description is inaccurate), NO tumble dry/do not dry clean; "dry in the shade".
