Decently well made hat at an absolutely awesome price. The color is bright and cheery and totally on point with the current plaid trend, but alas, on my particular head it was just too lumberjack-y. Though there are styling touches that definitely prove it's marketed for women, it turned out to just not be feminine enough and I couldn't help but think it would be cuter on a fashion forward teenage boy. I typically like cadet-style hats but in this color combo I was just waiting for the hubby to yell TIMBER!I wear a L in a Goorin or a Brixton and for a chick, I have a rather big noggin. I buy hats in usually a 7 1/4-1/2. This was snug on me but I suspect this OSFA would fit about 80% of women...making it more of a One Size Fits Most.I ended up returning mine, but for less than a price of a fast food meal, if your wardrobe jibes with red plaid more than mine does, I'd give it a hardy recommend. The side buckle is nice touch, the easy care poly fabric means it's not too fussy, and the bill is flexible enough to pack for travel.

Really cute bag. I've grown weary of the intentional distressing fad, but as a huge fan of Liebeskind, I couldn't resist Amazon's price even if it IS last season's bag, I had to have it. My experience with this brand has only been positive; I'm rough on my purses, especially when I travel, and Liebeskinds hold up really well.Liebeskind's all-leather bags tend to weigh a ton, so I hoped in denim this piece would be comparatively lightweight. It is! The bag is soft, sewn well, and the typical quality I expect from the brand. It's not quite as huge in real life as the proportions appear on Amazon's model, yet roomy enough for all the essentials plus some. The hardware is awesome (not shiny & cheap or needlessly heavy), the zipper pulls buttery smooth, and the distressed rips, holes, and gashes are done just right; the distressing is on the front and the back. The leather accents are quality.I don't use the detachable cross body strap and frankly it's a hair too thin and narrow for the proportion of the bag anyway; it's adjustable but only via a limited belt-style fastener so forget radically adjusting the length if you're petite; there's about 8" of adjustable play to the cross body strap. As for the top handle, regardless of a bag's size I tend to carry all my shoulder/hobo bags like a shopper's tote--just in my hand--or sometimes slung over my wrist. So I can't offer any insight on how long term comfortable/practical the shoulder drop is. I will say that on the rare occasion I carry it over on my shoulder, I like that it's a single strap as maybe I just have slope-y shoulders, but in a double strap I always experience one strap slipping off and/or the straps feel too cumbersome and tricky. I know the drop here will accommodate winter wear without strangling your shoulder blade or interfering with standard movement.**One small issue that has me withholding a star: the TOP zipper opens up into a half pocket--it's large enough for a big wallet, cell phone and a few small items but doesn't run the length of the bag. The FRONT zipper is the main compartment. That's a little weird and can cause some confusion and imbalance issues if the bag is super packed or you carry lots of heavier items. Not a deal breaker for me but the potential customer should be made aware of this rather unorthodox design choice. Things could fall out of any side/front loading bag if you're not careful. Most girls prefer the security and convenience that a true top loading bag provides. You simply can't tell from the online images that there's actually two zippers/separate compartments on the bag.**This isn't a north/south or east/west bag, it's more of a rounded square and not very deep, so it is fairly easy to find your items inside. The fabric lining in a flower power print is kinda garish and doesn't exactly jibe with the edgy exterior.I ordered in the Used Black and it pairs so well with my black/gray-centric winter wardrobe and looks especially fetching with plaids. I personally dislike the 'ladies who lunch' kind of handbag so this very casual bag is great for anyone who favors a more downtown style. Dust bag included.

Ordered the Teal in a 39. I'd hoped it would fit like a generous US 8.5 since in some boots I flirt with a 9. Unfortunately the 39, when paired with socks, fits more like an 8. Worried the 40 will be too big, I'm not sure where the sweet spot is with these fairly adorable boots--I'm in limbo about exchanging them. Width is true, if not a tad on the narrow side; no heel slipping which is great. But I'd say length wise they run a hair small and anyone with a W+ foot wouldn't find them comfy.I'm pleased w/the hardware: not glinty or cheap looking. The side zipper functions well for an easy in and out. The leather is a little thin & flimsy on the shaft yet the leather on the toe is a tad too stiff for my liking, but overall it's a decently well made boot. I'm worried if they get wet that they may bleed a bit of color as the dye job seems more superficial than the techniques used by other 'artisan' shoe brands. I'm also flummoxed how these could be called teal as they're completely green, no blue tone at all. So I would have called them emerald or jade but never... teal. The outsole is urban jungle friendly, no slip risk in winter. Arch support/foot bed padding is minimal, at best.I picked these up during a promotion and frankly, at the original retail, they're seriously overpriced. But if you're a fan of brands like Freebird, Bed St, or Kickers UK you'll be cool with the slight imperfections of this moto x engineer boot. Just size up if planning to wear winter weight socks and maybe wait for a sale.****ETA: I indeed ended up ordering the next whole size up, the 40. It swallowed me. Even with thick socks and an insole, it was a no go. I kept the original sz 39 and just pray that it'll stretch just a bit so my toes don't go numb. Because the more I hang out with these boots, the more I adore them. Hopefully you'll get lucky w/not being exactly between sizes. If you are, prepare to compromise comfort.

While it's wholly possible I just got a dud, this caddy has proven to be a total headache! Quite a few gripes here but I'll start with a compliment or two: it looks lovely from across the room. Simple & stylish. It's quite small so it doesn't take up too much space--forget sticking a bottle of ketchup in it; each of the three flatware slots are only about 3x 2-1/2 inches and the napkin compartment is very narrow. Amazon's listed dimensions for the overall size are nearly accurate.Gripe 1: I have a oodles of bamboo kitchen accessories by various brands, and, nearly without exception, adore them all. Bamboo is typically smooth and pleasant to handle but the handle on this caddy feels a bit like sandpaper. Really odd. The entire piece just feels unfinished and coarse.Gripe 2: Unbalanced and then some! So....were you planning to carry this thing from the kitchen to the table...'cause it is, after all, a caddy? Well good luck! When mine is loaded with a mere flatware for 4 (a cheapie IKEA set, not heavy duty solid silverware) due to the dividing slots being only on one side, the holder tips wildly forward; there's an utter lack of stability/stiffness on the folding handle. So keep steak knives and small children away. Huge fail at weight distribution vs the structure of the handle. Sure, you could place a heavier object in the narrow napkin side to balance it out a little, but that's an unnecessary and impractical extra step you shouldn't have to bother with and there's no way to adjust/tighten up the handle The other option is to carry it from the bottom by not using the handle at all. Again...but it's a caddy. Mobility is the selling point.Gripe 3: Remember how I said this looks nice from across the room? It does. But close up you'll find that when they attached the handle to the holder, they scarred the bamboo on both sides to do so. It looks like two staple gashes.So, I use mine for storage for flatware/straws/cheapie plastic items that needn't travel. Just sitting in one single place, it'll be fine. But I cannot recommend this for a family who wants to occasionally tote their flatware around or is expecting a nice smooth-feeling addition to their bamboo accessories collection. Skip it. You can do much, much better at an even cheaper price.

Do I love my Edison Petit lamp? Yes! Am I equally wild about the shade? Um, nope.There are several one star reviews for this product that are completely unfair due to customers believing they were receiving an actual lamp AND shade. To reiterate: this product page is for a thin piece of plastic that wraps around the corresponding Edison Petit lamp, also sold here on Amazon.The shade arrived in a gigantic box as this shade is packed flat. I was operating under the impression it would be like a cling film or high end removable sticker, but it attaches to the lamp by a series of tabs. It is an exceptionally simple design (not even a single line of instructions included) but while I appreciate that the shade doesn't reduce the light output, the interlocking tab design seems cheapie; a pretty snazzy 21st century lamp with a pretty disappointing optional ornamentation.Because the shade doesn't "stick" to the lamp, one can change out their shade on a whim w/o risk of damaging either the shade or the lamp. The shade pops on in seconds (lace up the tabs first, then slip over the top). My issue is that the tabs stick out at the back like a woman in a corset two sizes too small. Perhaps they will relax with use, but my "Fatima" shade fits awkwardly--because of the exceptional mobility of the Edison, I move the lamp around where/when needed. But take care; the shade, with any handling at all, creeps up immediately so that it leaves the bottom half inch of the lamp 'naked' while the top of the shade sticks up OVER the lamp. Bummer.For just under a Andrew Jackson, you're getting a piece of very thin piece of plastic that very nearly could be brilliant. If you leave your lamp in one spot, always, and plan to turn the ugly lace up tabs to the wall, I'd anemically recommend. I'm ultimately grateful that I wasn't dealing with a sticker that could bubble or crease, but the Fatboy team hasn't quite perfected this one yet. It feels a few millimeters too small--it should fit like the custom glove it's intended to be. This feels more like a kid's toy.PROS: doesn't reduce light output;  easy to use;  if can afford it, can change the look of your lamp as your mood dictatesCONS: pricey for what it is;  doesn't fit as well as it should;  tabs stick out at the back, betraying the sleek modern design of the Edison;  with even light handling, the shade pops up higher than the lamp itself

I purchased these Zig markers with the express purpose of decorating/writing on the very slick surface of Instax pics (photos like Polaroids). I'd hoped to save a few bucks by using "Sharpie CD/DVD Twin Tips" (Amazon ASIN:B0017TKW74) but though they wrote without smudging, the tips dried out sooo quickly and 2 of the colors were dried out upon arrival! Very frustrating. These Zigs are FAR superior and my only gripe is I wish I'd ordered them sooner.I'm thrilled these do exactly what I need them to do. The colors are vibrant, they haven't smudged (I do allow the ink to dry for a few seconds), all 5 colors are properly working w/o drying out, and the write quality is excellent. I don't know that with heavy, more industrial use they'll last for years, but for my light decoration purposes, these are absolutely ideal.Note: the tip is 0.7mm. So not too too fine. I believe the "2mm" in the description refers to the lead holder? I'd love if they made these in a wider version, but unless you need to cover a very large surface or write microscopic, this all purpose tip will do great.Amazon's online image is out-of-date as it appears they've updated the packaging. Also, one of marker caps looks pink but is in fact, purple. Violet. So is not a carnation pink like you might suspect from the online image. You get black, blue, red, violet, and a forest green.Direct from the package:PHOTO SIGNATURE 5 COLOURS SET PS-220/5V  0.7mmAlcohol-based dye/Waterproof/Photo-Safe/Acid Free/Lightfast/Odourless/Xylene Free/PermanentSuitable on paper, plastic, glass, metal, and photoMADE IN JAPANI highly recommend.

Absolutely ADORABLE stickers if you understand what you're getting:-TINY TEENY! Each sheet only measures about 7x4 inches. With an average of 40 stickers per sheet you can expect these to be super small. Amazon's images, if you're unfamiliar with this brand, do not clearly illuminate the scope.(I use these to decorate Instax photos which are the size of credit cards; works awesome for my projects and they'd be great for a small journal. But these won't cover large areas!)-HARD TO PEEL? Aided by long fingernails, I have little difficulty removing these from the sheet. But it can be tricky. Not kid-friendly.- ALL STICKERS? About 98% of a sheet is indeed a peel-off sticker; not every single image on the sheet is. However, once you've completed a sheet, it's possible, tho still challenging, to cut into the background to grab the image you want (that wasn't pre-cut).-ENGLISH? Yes, many cute phrases & words. But some of the adhesives, especially the teeniest ones, include what I believe is Korean lettering. I'm not bilingual so am clueless to their meaning.-ALL CATS? It's primarily kitty-centric so if you're looking for a less specific theme then these may disappoint.-REMOVABLE? Not particularly. Translucent backed, these grab on for dear life. Washi these are not.-VALUE? You get a ton of stickers for the price and I'll find uses for them all.If you're after really small stickers, a fan of kitty cats, and understand the limitations, I think you'll be pretty tickled with this offering. It's darn cute, vibrantly printed, and excellent quality.

I'm a middle aged woman so feel a little silly getting too excited over girly sticker frames. That stated, if you're an Instax mini fanatic of any age, these are very well made and pretty darn fun. I'm sold!The stickers peel off easily without being too fragile; I've yet to rip, crease, or ruin one! I'd love if they were a tad more removable after placement  la washi tape, but basically once they're on, they're on. If you don't press down too hard during your initial placement, it's technically possible to recenter them, but with a careless hand or for a young child, do know these fit the Instax mini photos exactly, with no room to spare. They border the entire photo, perfectly.Though there's several varieties of sticker frames made by this same brand, these particular frames have a space at the bottom for a message/date/label...whatever you desire to write. (I've found that using markers made for writing directly on CD/DVDs work really well to write on the bottom white border space on an Instax. But with these stickers you can use most ordinary pens to write your message without a great fear of smudging.) If you DON'T want sticker frames that include the cutesy blank message field, don't order these because all 20 pieces have them.You actually get a bonus sticker with every frame because the rectangle center part--the piece in the middle that you remove to reveal the frame--can be used to decorate something else. Kinda cool.The online images of the patterns/colors are accurate. The stickers are not glossy. They're not totally flattest matte, but there's zero shine or glitter and have a paper-like finish you'd find in a business label.If I recall correctly, the packaging does not include any English and is clearly not produced for the US market, but that's no biggie as these really don't require instructions!I'd love to find these in less 'precious' and overly tween-centric designs, but they're very well made, stick beautifully without bubbling or creasing, and really add flair to your shots. They're priced right, too. In the price bloated world of anything resembling 'scrapbooking', I feel these are a great value vs cost and a superior alternative to purchasing the expensive pre-printed theme film from FujiSince one of the joys of instant photography is a giving away a pic that is truly unique, with no other copy on earth, jazzing it up with one of these message frames makes it just all the more special. Highly recommend for the young Instax crowd or the folks Instax keeps feeling young.

What you're ordering here:This particular product page is for ONE Skinneeez chicken toy, not 3. Ya can't rely only on the image; Amazon can be tricky like that.Also, the product dimensions listed include the retail packaging--the paper card the toy is attached to. The chicken itself is teeny! About 2x3, maybe just barely.Finally, it is catnip filled, supposedly, but don't expect your cat to respond to it like many other catnip toys by brands like Yeowww or FatCat. If you're purchasing this thinking you'll get a super potent catnip toy, well, nope. This should probably be marketed only as a plush toy.----------------I happen to have a very toy-crazy cat, one of these types that will play with just about anything I offer him. (And frequently with things I do not). As kitties are known to be discriminating, I find it difficult to write reviews for cat toys because what my cat may love, your cat dismisses with scorn. That said...IF your cat enjoys small, not over stuffed plushy toys, this is a real winner. We had a few of these Skinneeez toys in the teaser form ("Ethical Skinneeez Forest Friends Cat Wand" sold here on Amazon) when my guy was a kitten and they were a huge hit! I think his little brain was imprinted with a love of this style/brand of toy. Frankly, we still prefer them in wand form. But my arm isn't titanium so if I'm lazy, just tossing this across the room does the trick.They're well made and though the legs are a thin soft rope material, unless you have a real Jaws on your hands, they aren't easily shredded. As mentioned above, I suspect they have only trace amounts of catnip and even the most potent catnip toy can go stale. Regardless, my guy really gives these chickens the business and seems to thoroughly enjoy tossing/carrying them about. Due to popularity, they get a little...gross and saliva-y. Just sayin'.This version of Skinneeez is so small it's quite easy to lose; one could argue they're overpriced for what they are. But for *some* cats these chickens are total kitty crack. So IMO, it's worth a try if your feline prefers a very soft flat toy over a plastic jingle ball or the stiffer canvas-like catnip toys like Yeowww makes. My cat likes all the above but still seeks out these Skinneeez.Though stuffing-less, if you have a large dog who loves Snowball's toys, be advised of the potential choking hazard. Also, a few reported a nasty chemical smell; we've not encountered that and I'm pretty sensitive to such things.Bawk bawk! Your cat may love em too.

I own the Fuji Instax 90 Neo Classic.WHAT FITS:I can fit the 90 (sans strap), a single foil cartridge of film, and a small package of sticker border frames in this case. I removed the strap from the camera in favor of a thin wrist lanyard because otherwise the case felt overstuffed. If you swap the film cartridge for the wall mount charger, that'll fit too.I'm a little surprised at the overwhelmingly positive reviews as this case has some odd design flaws and questionable craftsmanship.CONS (for me):1. The inside "divider" isn't stitched all the way to the bottom so batteries/pics/stickers will just slide to the other side. The divider does keep, for better or worse, the camera on one single side of the case.2. The zipper wraps completely around the case so there's a risk if you're not holding your tongue just right or being careless by zipping too far, the camera could fall out. It's 'tippy' to say the least, especially if you're removing the camera from the case while it's on your shoulder. I make sure to place the camera in the case the exact same way/direction every time so I know if I'm in a hurry to get a pic, I know which side is weighted. The top of the case is not as deep as the bottom and I'm not sure this aids the design.3. It's a hard case but has virtually no internal padding. I wouldn't trust it to fully protect from a serious drop. It's more than adequate to protect from dust and debris while in a handbag, etc. But I view this case more as a storage option than a security measure.4. Shoddy materials. The included strap is...awful. The huge plastic clips are not only difficult to grip, making it tough to put on/take off the case, but it feels like they'd easily break or crack. And the super cheap, rough material of the strap meant I felt zero guilt when I tossed it out and replaced it. Additionally, on my case the Instax placard is crooked. A small gripe unless you're a bit Type A or get distracted by aesthetics; every time I glance at it, I just wanna re glue it straight!***ETA: I'm now having issues with the zipper catching the fabric of the 'divider'. Having the zipper get stuck as often as it's now occurring may be a deal breaker. I've fiddled with it and experimented with adding/removing different items from the case in hopes it was just an issue with imbalance. Alas, this is just a cheap case and I need to stop expecting it to behave like a case 4X the price. Carry on...WHAT'S TO LIKE:1. It's likely the modest price that people, even picky ones like me, respond to...and the fact that it does provide minimum protection for cameras not known to be the most sturdily built.2. In a world of extremely girly tween-centric Instax accessories, the plain black look of the case kept it off *my* cons list. A lot of people dismiss Instax as a toy, but this case reminds us that indeed, adults like instant photography too.3. It's difficult to find affordable, easily obtained Instax accessories in the US market. If I wanted a truly quality case to custom fit my 90, I'd have to order from an Asian site that would take weeks to arrive or order from a US niche store that charges beaucoup bucks. I need my extra $ for the film! A 2-day ship for under $10 is hard to beat.BOTTOM LINE:A decent starter case. Priced right, even with only minimal protection, I'd recommend for infrequent use or storage. I use my camera a LOT. Like daily. So ultimately I need a better designed and more shock absorbent case. But because there's very little to chose from for us instant photog lovers, this will have to do.

My review would be 5 stars if they were still making the nice super fluffy, fat rainbow-colored poms of a year or so back. The new Chase'm poms we received are noticeably smaller. Which makes me a bit nervous as my cat has been known to swallow things he shouldn't a la his not-so-bright canine siblings.The last 2 packages I've ordered, about 4 months apart, are not like the online images-- rather they're a deep aqua & purple swirl with no white at all. Frankly, the color makes little difference to me (or probably the cat) but with the color change came the size reductions in both dimension and overal fluffiness. I'd say these are no bigger than a shooter marble; if you're not old enough to have any idea what that is, I'd say these are not much bigger than a standard jaw breaker, a Gobstopper.Because my cat adores these and because my cat loses these constantly, we'll likely keep ordering them. But do be advised to the ever shrinking size. Additionally, these 30 balls arrive in a cheap sealed shrink bag with loose, low quality catnip sprinkled inside. The poms themselves are not stuffed with 'nip. Be careful upon opening because you could cause a mess if you haphazardly rip open the bag.We store ours in a cat-proof cupboard because, as the mainly positive reviews reflect here, most cats REALLY dig 'em. It's just unfortunate the manufacturer could be cutting down on material costs in an already very cheap to make product.

I began with just the Give a Hoot shower curtain by Creative Bath but decided to fully commit and buy all the coordinating accessories. The product line may be a tad juvenile for this 30-something, but life is short; whimsy is ageless.The can is VERY heavy, probably a good 5 lbs. I was immediately impressed with the heft and quality of the resin. One of my dogs has rarely met a can he can't topple, but this stymies him. So rest assured, the bin may be pricey but you're getting a solidly made piece. If your bathroom floods, this isn't going to float off too easily!As another reviewer mentioned, the 3 owl figures (in bright pumpkin, oyster white, and Caribbean blue) are only featured on the front of the can. But a cool detail is the brick wall pattern that is carried over from the curtain--it borders both the top & bottom of the can; the fact that it's cut into the resin, not painted on, is a lovely detail that points to high quality workmanship.The color is a pale mint, not the vibrant candy apple green that repeats in the other accessories; the leaves of the branches wouldn't have contrasted as well if the can wasn't lightened to the more subdued green. The finish is nice and glossy making it a breeze to cleanDimensions vary a tad from listed: 8-1/2" W (top), 7-1/2" D, 10" H;  6" W, 4-3/4" D (bottom)I hate using a can liner in this because I want nothing to distract from how adorable these owls are! It's fun for all ages; if you're debating adding more Hoot accessories, this one is a great addition despite being the priciest of the lot.

My review is based on an alternative use for this baking sheet: a giant coaster for my hubby's office/man cave. He reappropriated one of 'my' beautiful, high quality wooden coffee tables for his space; I knew he'd go rogue and it would just be a matter of time before the table was damaged beyond repair.Instead of buying a coaster set that wouldn't conveniently accommodate every size glass/mug or might fail to be used at all, I slapped down this generously sized silicone mat in the middle of the table and voila!  I've got water rings/stains, scratches from his 239 remote controls, and stray ashes from his pipes/cigars all covered in one fell swoop.Cleanup is a breeze, I just wipe off the mat instead of reaching for wood polish every time. It's decently thick, not too flimsy, and low profile. I couldn't have covered so much space, for the same price, with individual pads/coasters. A woven or fabric placemat would be more difficult to clean; the silicone, while not truly non-slip, is much more forgiving than a slippery vinyl or cheap-looking plastic placemat; its utilitarian function/aesthetic works with hubby's dislike of frou frou design.There's plenty of reviews extolling its virtues for baking, but this has turned out to be a really cool purchase for an entirely different purpose!

My husband, like another reviewer, is a HAM operator and this hobby seems to require a lot of space for his ever-growing acquisition of yet more radio/lab stuff. He also collects, of all things, Commodore computers; they're not tiny. So space in his man cave/lab is a commodity.We were VERY pleased with the high quality vs low price of this spacious table. We ordered a lot of other office/lab storage-related items along with this table and they all had a manufacturing defect or packaging issue of some kind. But not this! It was pristine out of the box, secure in both the folded and upright position (VERY sturdy) and the dimensions were 100% accurate as listed. No unwanted surprises=satisfied consumer.The legs are sturdy and well coated. On our ancient and not particularly taut carpet, this stands securely and solid. In hubby's tight work space, if we knock it, we don't fear the table or its contents will go tumbling. Additionally, the support beams don't interfere with leg room on all sides like some similar tables.The extremely thick tabletop is matte with a very slightly textured finish; it's not slick coated so that your items (or a table cloth) go sliding right off. I also appreciate that it doesn't have a cheesy fake marbling pattern like the folding tables of my childhood.We have another similar utility table, by a different manufacturer, in the same room as this model. The difference is like night and day--one feels flimsy and disposable, this one built to last. I'd say the only drawback is that it might be difficult for a single individual to frequently transport it as it's so solid & heavy. It's huge!We love that this brand offers the same table in a variety of dimensions; we'll be back for more because it always seems one is needed for yard sales, swap meets, fairs, pet adoption, additional seating, etc. Just slide under the bed or stick in the garage and you're good to go.A great fuss-free, affordable option. Recommend!

Hubby needed a test lead rack for his home office/electronics lab. The Fluke name, while pricier than many of its competitors, is known for high quality products--making this selection an easy choice.Zero issues on arrival; the listed dimensions are accurate, it has a nice heft/super solid, is well constructed, and mounted perfectly flush. The yellow (more of a orangey yellow than a "safety/caution" yellow) is exceptionally bold...if you'd prefer a rack to blend in, consider another color. But the finish is superior--no chipping paint! Nothing flimsy or disposable here.It can hold additional items like screwdrivers and various other equipment; our rack is mainly used for the intended purpose, but I could see all sorts of alternate uses beyond test lead storage. Anyone who desires organization in their work area will benefit.While this is a pretty standard size for this type of rack, if you have dozens upon dozens of test leads or thicker coax cables, be advised that though each of the 10 slots can hold multiple alligator/banana/mini grabbers/multimeter/oscilloscope leads, etc., a single rack may not do. For typical home lab use, it's more than enough storage and won't hog valuable wall space.You can't wax too poetic about a metal test lead rack. This Fluke model does what it needs to, arrived as described, and, most importantly, is clearly built to last. A solid recommend for an item you want to buy once and then not hassle with ever again.

I'm typically long winded and attempt thoroughness in all my reviews but I'll keep is short and sweet:This is a crate liner. An overpriced one at that. In our household, crate liners and dog beds are TWO COMPLETELY DIFFERENT THINGS. This should be marketed as a crate liner and was not. Full stop. A crate liner.So...as a crate liner, doghouse pad, or travel mat,  this is adequate. As a comfy or remotely supportive dog bed for daily use? Well, my pets can't speak but if they could--and granted, they are grumpy seniors--it would go something like, "Um, NO THANKS".Even if this "bed" had been properly stuffed and cushiony, the "fleece" version has a bight white slick fabric bottom (which is not shown in the photo) and that's the least forgiving color on earth. Again, in a crate:  doable. On the hardwood floors of a multiple pet home? Gracious, me!Sometimes I opt for quantity over quality as I like to replace beds as frequently as possible, but I've picked up less expensive, actual BEDS at big box stores for less. Here's a rare occasion where I'm less than satisfied w/an Amazon purchase. As for the folks who are pleased w/it, I guess my dogs are just insufferably spoiled...

I had been searching for just the right drawer pulls for my recently revamped vanity, when I stumbled onto these. It was more than I wanted to pay for 6 knobs, but I have to admit: these have a 'grandma's costume jewelry' look to them that I found oddly appealing. Had to have 'em! I'd first struck out w/these much higher quality  pink glass knobs but they were just too subdued.I'm not terribly familiar w/Lisbeth Dahl, but searching around I discovered it's a real mixed bag with this line. Some of Dahl's unusual designs look to be of great quality while other items are quite shabbily assembled. What would I get with these flower pulls?Well....hot glue, for starters. Out of 6, 3 of them had really awful threads of hot glue surrounding all the 'stones'. Like strands of it everywhere. It looks cheap, is annoying to remove, and frustrating that $60 got me 'a 6-yr old with his first hot glue gun project' knobs.And we're right back to glue AGAIN because I had to go buy some super glue in order to carefully affix some clusters that had fallen off from the base of the petals. The good news is inside the packaging I located the pieces that had fallen off. If they were missing completely, I definitely would have had to return them. I won't even get to the weird, dark stains/glue residue/burned-like areas that are on the backside of the knobs. I'm just too glued out at this point.A set of 6, some were individually wrapped, others were not. Again, hardly points to high quality. And frankly, based on the provided description, I have no idea what is acrylic vs stone. It all looks the same.The color on the petals is less "mint", as described, and more of a jade. The clusters are a light Caribbean blue.The rough diameter of the knob is just shy of 2-1/2". The screw is also 2-1/2". I have no idea what the "3.54 inches" in the description is referring to. I measured every conceivable part of this knob and nothing equals 3.54?! If you took the circumference of a pentagon (?!), fiddled with every known division of it, you still don't get 3.54. The closest I can come up with is that it's the area. But I'm not sure that including the "area" dimension is particularly practical as it applies to drawer knobs; it could be potentially misleading.Hubby drilled new holes in my vanity drawers but said the mm size of the screw was "standard".These looks pretty cool and kitschy against my glittery gold drawers but only if you don't look at them close up. Additionally, they're a little rough on the hands due to the flower shape and some unevenness, rough edges, and the pointy ends. Irregularity dooms these, to say the least.Low quality materials, even lower quality workmanship, and a staggering price makes these more appealing in online images than in reality. And best believe, I'll be keeping yet more glue handy for the inevitable repairs.

I purchased this for my husband's office/man cave. The room's theme is "industrial site" (biohazard shtick, OSHA compliance signs, safety cones, et cetera) and his predominant color is 'caution' yellow. Initially, I just needed an inexpensive trash can that would match the garish color scheme, but this bin turned out to be pretty awesome! (It's also available in less jolting colors like white and grey).--Size? Because this model is identical in style to the giant-sized garage/curbside bins, the online image may briefly fool you. But it's a 10 gallon container measuring approx 17" H, 15-1/2" diameter (top), 12" diameter (base) w/ 3" long handles.--Sturdy? Yep!  It's incredibly durable and thick (nearly commercial grade plastic) and can easily be hosed out and routinely abused. A good thing...since my husband has never used a plastic bag liner in his life; moreover, he considers food stuffs, of any type, to be appropriate for disposal alongside paper items and your more benign household debris. This is convenient for indoor use but ruggedly forgives carrot cake smothered fax cover sheets.--Lid? Nope. However, Rubbermaid Commercial Brute coordinating lids (#2610) are available and we bought one...because (see above) Hubby's trash is our dogs' 2nd breakfast. I'll review the lid separately but it fits nicely/tightly; I'd recommend a lid for use outdoors so as to reduce odor and discourage vermin. My indoor pests, which we just shorten to "pets", are equally stymied.-- Appearance? This won't win any interior design awards but if you've read this far, you're not after frou frou. It's a nice smooth finish w/o plastic-y frayed bits and has fortifying ridges at the base. The can's "Brute" moniker is a way too visible for my taste--tho it does accurately describe its owner on his worst days-- but we've well established my tastes are irrelevant since my husband actually chose 'toxic waste' as part of his his design story.--Balanced? Very! Sturdiness is great and all, but bins are still prone to topple if poorly designed. This container, on carpet, can survive the across-the-room-over-the-coffee-table 3-point shot without tumbling over. Ray Allen would approve!Not in any way as disposable in quality as the trash it holds, if this solid, easy-to-care for, and reasonably priced bin can survive my man's test lab of a man cave, it should last years at your house too. If it was self-emptying, it would be just about perfect. In yellow, at least it'll get emptied once or twice a decade as it's real hard to miss!!

Because I'm prone to be high strung, I've always found this reversal on the infamous WWII English poster "Keep Calm and Carry On" a more accurate and amusing reality.But on the day of my purchase, no dimensions were listed so I had to order in the dark. I wanted to hang this on an area of my wall that had limited space; poking around, I did manage to locate the dimensions of its sister sign but I just hoped I could keep calm if it arrived grossly undersized or laughably gigantic......it did not. It's conveniently sized at 7" W x 13" H x 1-3/4" D.The soft white lettering is clear and visible from a nice distance. The dark charcoal/off black color shows up nicely on my light walls. The finish/font is meant to look a little weathered but this is not an intentionally 'pre-distressed' piece and the print is smooth to the touch. Thank goodness.The wooden box frame is substantial and crafted beautifully; everything is cut correctly, centered properly, etc. Great construction!There's no wall mount hardware but because the frame is open in back, it hangs easily and securely on a single long nail. It's sturdy enough that it could rest against a wall or sit on a dresser, too.Nothing about this sign makes me panic or freak out. It's just very well made and a pleasant surprise considering the very reasonable price point. I've seen similar signs at 3X the price at trendy shops.This a whimsical reminder that outside times of true crisis, some of us--heck, more than may like to admit to it--are wired a wee bit differently.

From a brand that typically churns out high quality items, I was quite disappointed in this frame.It fits an 8X10 print with a few mm to spare. The wood is of decent quality and cut smoothly. I love the baby pale pink color; it's very charming. The glass is not very thick but fits the frame correctly.Total outside dimensions: 13-1/2" X 10-1/2"The frame arrived in a gigantic cardboard tray with cardboard corners, but not sealed in plastic. So beware if considering it as a gift. Unfortunately, probably due to the lack of a plastic wrapping (by the manufacturer, not Amazon), my frame arrived marred. A nice big blue smudge with an accompany scratch greeted me, right snack dab on the woodwork.I purchased this to hang vertically, as the description says a wall hanger is included. But a good inch of the black easel is visible when hung on the wall. Not a good look to see it poking out.Because there's no civilized or practical way to remove the easel without permanently damaging it, I had to rip it off. So once you've opted to use it as a wall mount, commit fully. This is obviously a non-issue if you plan to only use it in easel mode, but at this price point and based on the claim it's mountable, versatility is expected.The backing is just a cheap poster board material with only 2 clips to hold the backing in place; I have spent far less for frames that provide several clips and that include a velvet or higher quality back.  Additionally, the wall mount rings are the sort you find on frames from the big box discount store--you can bend them with your finger.Feel like a sucker for paying what I did. Because the dimensions are so large, the price may be justified, but many of the materials leave much to be desired and have a disposable quality.A truly high quality frame must not only look presentable from the viewpoint we all see, but also on all the parts we don't.

My mobile of choice is an iPhone 4S. Does this little bean bag securely hold it? Yes, barely. And with limitations.I always use my phone in portrait mode. So naturally I propped it up in the beanbag that way. However, all sounds and tones are completely, fatally muffled in portrait. This is obviously less an issue when placed in landscape, but hey, everyone uses their phone differently and I'm unapologetically a portrait gal.I purchased this to place on my vanity and to use only for a few minutes a day; in the mess of the loose mineral makeup I wear, I needed some kind of perch to keep my phone safe for when it invariably interrupts me. But to use this for daily, frequent use? No can do.The base of the bag doesn't have any texturing or grip so if you're in a rambunctious household, the bag is so lightweight it's easily toppled. Personally, I wouldn't use this while charging.It's cute enough, I ordered in the lovely grass green. But the attached tags, sewn into a seam, are HUGE. And I fear if I remove them (under penalty of law and all) that it will permanently damage the bag. So I have to tuck them under the base; it's rather unsightly.Because beanbags are so malleable, and this truly is just a miniaturized version of the real thing--thus all the "We're using it as Barbie furniture" comments--I like that I can fiddle and press at it to create the ideal pillow for my phone. But it's that same malleability that makes it less than ideal for heavy use.Once the manufacturers weight this down, add a few inches to accommodate the larger screen sizes of non-Apple smart phones, add some simple non-slip material, and tweak the ginormous tags, I think this could make for a dandy storage solution...But with all those needed edits, this feels more like a novelty. I hope they go back to  the drawing board tho. And the price, at the time of my purchase, was quite reasonable vs quality.

I purchased this to affix to a mannequin head as part of an art installation. I'd gladly have tried it on my self, but since I didn't want to be picking silver glitter out of my hair and scalp for days, I passed.On arrival, I found it crammed inside a thin plastic wrapper, stapled shut--the sort of packaging reserved for cheap toys and made in China party favors. Probably because it IS an item you'd buy on the bargain aisle of a party warehouse.The glitter was my real problem; it scatters everywhere and I'd made the mistake of opening it on my bed. I sleep like a fairy princess now as I swear cheap glitter never truly goes away!The hat and headband are separate pieces. There's two crude slits on the flat base of the hat; the hat isn't hollowed out like a 'real' hat. The headband is wrapped in a satin-like light sliver fabric. Be very careful threading the headband through the slots; I felt like I might be crushing the hat in the process.Once on the headband, you can adjust the angle of the hat however you like. I opted for it cocked extremely to one side as it would be (even more) ridiculous to wear it straight up. My mannequin has standards!The veil is detachable; if desired, it can be affixed to the band of the hat via a strip of Velcro. There is also a single string of silver sequins on the hat brim.The veil measures 8" wide by 9" highThe diameter at the base of the hat is 5-1/2". The top of the hat is 3-1/2" at its widest.For a single night's use at a costume party, this may be hardy enough to don. For my mannequin perched 9 feet in the air, it will definitely do. But to repeatedly adjust on one's head, handle frequently, and then find a glitter-friendly area to store it, all without crushing it? Um, NO. I got a real belly laugh from the "dry clean only" instructions listed in the online description.The price? Well in terms of hats and paper currency, it's a good Abraham Lincoln too steep. We're talking cents of materials here: a thick cardboard hat that won't live long.  But the glitter is forever.It's a cheap prop and that's how I used it. This "fascinator" may be best enjoyed with low expectations

I needed a collar for use in an art installation; my purchase was NOT for use on a dog.  However...As a lifelong pet lover who has 3 dogs snoring it up on my bed as I type, I've learned that many collar companies tend to confuse things by how they list collar dimensions. So in case you're new to the game: determine if they only offer a measurement from end-to-end (total length) rather than the measurements for an actual neck size (how it fits buckled).But on the day of my purchase, BOTH sets of measurements were listed so there shouldn't be any confusion or "this doesn't fit" issues. My own tape measure confirms: this will fit a neck size of 11-14".As for the material itself, this is just "PU leather"; in some parts of the world you cannot legally insert the word 'leather' into a PU product because it's such a misrepresentation. This collar, like most all PU is a split/bycast leather that's smothered in polyurethane and then embossed. So it does feel a bit stiff. The good news is PU won't stretch out as much as genuine full leather, it's super easy to clean, and pretty darn durable.The stitching looks decent. The collar has heft. The studs are well done, placed nicely, appear secure, and are pretty shiny. The backside of the studs are smooth, flush, and should not pull out fur. However, the sharpness of the centimeter-long bullet studs that run through the center are disturbingly sharp. Beware. I mean ouch already.Being a multiple dog owner, I personally shudder at the thought of my rambunctious guys roughhousing and poking their eye out on a studded collar. But if you've come to this page  it's safe to say you want your pet to reflect a certain image...and this collar will do it!A tad over priced considering the materials, potentially dangerous depending on your particular breed/its lifestyle, and, like most collars with ornamentation designed to fit a range of necks, the studs will look off center if you fasten it on the loosest notch. But the color is true to the online image, the dimensions accurate, and since genuine leather studded collars go for 3X the price, if you're in need of this style collar, I'd offer an anemic recommendation as PU has its benefits.

These are really sweet, well crafted oval glass knobs. Something about an oval shape makes them seem a bit more special than a boring ole round option.They have a decent heft, arrived with no chipping or flaws, and have a nice vintage look. The listed dimensions are completely accurate and the hardware is quality; installation was a breeze. They feel sturdy in the hand when opening a drawer. I'm impressed. But...Unfortunately, the pink knobs I received are not even remotely as pink as the online images. I know computer monitors can display inaccurate colors from time to time, but every pink knob style offered by this manufacturer is shown to be a lovely carnation pink--not a terribly bold 'in your face' pink but it indeed registers as a definite PINK. Perhaps professional lighting was used for the photos, but on my goldish-beige vanity drawers these barely reflect as pink... they're that faint. From across the room, and with every lamp turned on, these are so very pale. I was hoping the light would play off them and draw out the pink but....nope.The little raised dots that line the outside of the knob don't have as much dimension in person as in the photos. There's no satisfying visual contrast between the center convex and the edge work; it kinda just all runs together.So if you are after a REALLY pale, baby pink with mere a hint of color, these would be ideal. I needed 12 knobs but only ordered a 4-pack to see how they'd look. I'm keeping them but won't be ordering the rest as I was hoping they'd offer a real pop of color. If you're seeking a super subtle shade, that's what you'll get.

I ordered this sweet little basket along with another so called 'shabby chic' utensil caddy from a different manufacturer. I just left a scathing review for the caddy as it was the worst that shabby chic has to offer. (Lately it seems shabby chic is term they just slap on any cheaply made and sloppily distressed item to make it sound more desirable).Thankfully, this basket is VERY well made and a convenient size for displaying a myriad of treasures. The metal finish, tho it appears 'aged' or like a relic of a bygone era, is completely even throughout and not remotely "rusty" as one reviewer experienced. It may be small, but it's sturdy!The listed dimensions are accurate. I'll add that each 'square' of the lattice is a half inch by a half inch. So only super tiny things could fall out.It doesn't have any loose bits or twisted wire pieces that could snag you or your things. It also doesn't give my fingers that awful, dirty metallic odor that comes from handling similarly crafted items.Rather than just glued on, the handles are carved out to accommodate the wire that curves around them; they're sturdy and smooth.This would make an ideal receptacle to present bath soaps, a practical storage option for garlic or dried herbs, or, in my case, to set on a vanity to hold various cosmetics. One reviewer mentioned using it to hold wooden eggs. This would make an adorable Easter basket for a sophisticated tween.If this was on a shelf at any boutique or knickknack shop, I'd expect to literally pay 2X more. I'm tickled pink; I didn't expect to feel so giddy over a silly basket but this one turned out to be especially appealing. All chic, not too shabby.

This mustachioed fella makes a pretty nifty wall hook, plus it's of a substantial weight. And in a world replete with flower/butterfly/bird hooks, it's nice to find a whimsical piece that isn't so girly. The super flat finish stands out nicely in a sea of glossy hooks without looking too utilitarian and bland. Long live the mustache!A lot of reviewers overlooked the dimensions and were surprised at how teeny this guy is. But guess what? The hook I received IS smaller than the listed measurements. Nerd that I am, I whipped out the tape measure and sure enough, it barely made it to 3". True, a half an inch is no big deal, but I'm persnickety about accuracy; it's an already small piece crafted even smaller than claimed.Hardware isn't included but you can play around with the screw tops to give this gentleman an "iris" of any color.Though it's cast iron, I was surprised to see mine had a serious gnawed looking bit on one of the eyes--like someone scraped part of it out. Again, no biggie, but if I was giving it as a gift I'd have to return it. The piece comes boxed so I don't blame the seller/shipper, it's probably a manufacturing issue. So be aware that this kind of design, in this particular material, is not likely to look perfect each time it's cast.I mounted mine my pretty high up on the wall to use with shirt hangers; if it was at eye level, the imperfections might perturb me...but its overall charm wins out. I'm just a tad bummed it didn't meet the dimensions and arrived distractingly flawed. If not for that, it's a 5 star hook.

I purchased this to drape over an antique mirror I have hanging in my vanity/dressing area. I was going for a cheesy boudoir look...and this boa achieved it!When I first opened the package to pull it out, I got a fistful of feathers. A bad sign. However, because I'm not actually planning to wear this, a bit of shedding is no big deal and to be expected with any cheap boa. It's essentially a novelty piece; if you need it for a one time only costume party, great. If you're a nightly burlesque artist, safe to say you have your own supplier. This isn't great grandma's heirloom boa so my rating is based on getting what I expected in a few cents worth of Made in China materials.The color is really gorgeous; it's a deep, rich saturated teal--more blue than green. It's accurately named as teal is sometimes misidentified.The "45 gram" weight meant nothing to me as I wasn't quite sure how heavy I needed or anticipated this boa to be. For the novice like me: it's heavier than those little girl dress up boas that are all fluff; it's definitely lighter and less dense than what was wrapped around Mae West.It's 2 yards but not exactly 6 feet as the dangling feathers aren't an exact science. It's actually softer than I was expecting so that made up for the feather loss. Handled gently, I expect this to last a long time...and I expect it to be self dusting too. No?I'm tickled enough with it to explore other colors; lately I can't seem to get enough frou frou and this makes me smile.

I purchased this to place on my vanity to use as a little carousel for cosmetic items like lip liners and mascaras. I was really exited to start using it and tickled pink that the particular seller I purchased from had wrapped it in girly tissue and even included candies. But that's where the fun ended.The finish is a disaster. I'm quite fond of shabby chic but unfortunately not all shabby chic is created equal. This is all shabby and no chic...The oyster colored paint, already chipped and weathered, would have been perfectly adequate; the addition of a truly ugly shade of dark brown paint, smudged here and there was one step too many. However, what really did me in was the "rust" effect. It seriously looks like someone squeezed on Elmer's glue and then sprinkled it with paprika. It's truly bizarre! This orange 'powder' technique, I can only assume, is to mimic the flakes of genuine rust. Just comical. And you can't make it out in the images.If you can get over the finish, stability is a real issue. Mind you, I'm using this to hold very lightweight items. If you plan on placing actual quality flatware in the 4 baskets, eh, be very careful to balance the weight equally. My piece is held together with a screw and doesn't sit flush.It's possible I received a rather poorly made one, but looking at the reviews for the exact same caddy in the silver/pewter finish, I see I'm not alone in my complaints with stability.For the sake of being thorough, here are the measurements:7-3/4" W and D, 10-3/4" HThe individual baskets are 2-1/2" at the base by 3-1/3" at shortest H and 7-1/2" at tallest H.The scrolled metal work itself is decent enough, tho flimsy, and the cottage-y look would have been awfully sweet if they'd not fussed with the awful distressing process. It's not technically defective so I'm keeping it only because I'm too lazy to return it and would be stuck w/return postage.The description claims this is like a "antique shop find'. Um, not even close. Except for the antique shop price tag!

I'm fond of unusual knickknacks AND a total shoe-aholic. So when I spied this this little brass piece, I knew it would be a perfect addition to my vanity table; it's a really creative way to store my bobby pins.First, it's teeny. I mean if you're a smoker, don't expect to stuff more than a couple of butts in here. It measures 4" L x 1" W x 1" D. See what I mean? Tiny. But that's why I love it. As a functioning ashtray, though it does have a carve out to rest a cigarette, I can't see it being too practical.The shoe was packaged securely and very well bubble wrapped. (Being brass, I wasn't fearful of damage during shipment, but I always appreciate any seller's effort toward proper packaging.) The product looks identical to the online image.The piece is quite heavy for just 4 inches! It would make a nice paper weight too. It's a slipper but not a slip of a thing,The inside of the shoe--mind you this intended for use as an ashtray--is a little tarnished and dirty. I'll polish it out before use, but this an import item and reflects that.I'm really pleased to add this to my collection--another tangible reminder that a girl can't have too many shoes! It's well made, inexpensive, and though I try not to use this word too often, "cute". It really is.

A former problem drinker, my sobriety, while a blessing, left me weary of Diet Cokes, club soda, and cranberry juice. I don't particularly love health smoothies and I can't drink coffee. Most restaurants are woefully unprepared to serve up virgin drinks much beyond kid's stuff or sugary pre-mixes. As I already had all the tools of the trade, I decided to entice my tastebuds right here at home.To best enjoy this title (and really any other virgin drinks books) you should be prepared to:--Already own or be willing invest in essential bar tools (A shaker, zester, strainer, and blender are the items I reach for the most.)--Understand you may spend a tad more than you'd hoped liquor-free drinks would actually cost. Just because you don't need booze doesn't mean fresh fruit/herbs, tea, etc., are cheap.--Experiment with ingredients that may be unfamiliar and visit shops off the beaten path.--Possess a little patience for allowing refrigeration times, infusions, etc., and of course a sense of adventure with new flavors.So now that we've covered that, don't feel discouraged as there are PLENTY of recipes here that don't require more than a regular ole glass, a quick trip to any supermarket, and literally 3 minutes to create!!The book is separated into sections for fruit drinks, hot drinks for winter, dairy, etc. I particularly appreciate that the hardback edition has a spiral binding as the other alcohol-free recipe books I own* do not--and frankly that's a hassle (and potential mess) unless you have a book easel.Of the recipes I've tried, very few are clunkers and the instructions are easy to follow; I don't cook so I cannot understate how vitally I require clear, simple language. I'll whip you up a drink, but I'm very kitchen-challenged. The author hasn't given me too much over my head.There are ample full page photos but there isn't a photo for each drink--so you can use your imagination when it comes to garnish/serving. This isn't all "Martha Stewart-y" where you'll feel easily shamed at your results.I've ended up pairing ingredients I never would have dreamed up on my own. The results: delicious. There's truly something for everyone. There's a few here that I'll literally be making for a lifetime, they're that tasty. Other offerings have a more novelty appeal.There does seem to be an abundance of recipes with Indian-centric ingredients and spices; I happen to live in an area where those are readily offered and not considered exotic, but unlike my other drink books, this title does seem to really emphasize Indian flavor profiles.There are also a lot of vegetable-based drinks which aren't my particular thing but if you're health conscious, you'll be in heaven. This is NOT a "add 4 cups of sugar" title. There's guilty pleasures, yes, but the bulk of recipes are not syrupy horrors.Most of the recipes serve 2, so thankfully (for me anyway) this isn't too punch-heavy or all pitcher drinks intended for batches; fractions ain't my thing. Though just about all the recipes can be modified for 1 or for entertaining.I'd recommend this title to anyone who is bored of the same old same old and is willing to put just a little effort into exciting their taste buds. But this isn't the most ideal book for someone looking for ginger ale based punches, considers paprika to be exotic, or anyone on a super tight budget.*Last month I purchased 4 alcohol-free beverage recipe books. Along with this title I bought "Zero Proof" by Scott, "Ultimate Liquor-Free Drink Guide" by Herbst, and "Green Tea" by Heiss--all titles available here on Amazon. Each guide has something different to offer, but this offering is a great choice, second only in recipes to "Zero Proof" which I'll review separately.But this is an EXCELLENT choice for both the amateur mixologist and veteran alike. It will take me months to create all the recipes, but I'm grateful a good 70% of them are drinks just about everyone can be excited about. Plus this offers a lot of actual info on how to whip up just about any conceivable type of virgin beverage. Recipes w/o practical guidance are kinda useless for me, but straight info w/o yumminess is pointless too. This succeeds at both.

I first spied this tropical wristlet back in the Endless.com days (a moment of silence, please) when it was going for original retail price. Unlike the reviewer who stated this is crafted from "rich leather"--I wish!!-- it's just PVC....so I couldn't justify the price. But now that it's much more reasonable, it can perch on my wrist!Though the outside is plumed and fabulous, the actual capacity is dinky dink. I typically carry the kitchen sink but afterall, this isn't intended as an everyday bag. But just know that if you sport an iPhone in a giant bunny ears case, don't expect to fit much else in here. It's just a very snazzy lipstick, cash and ID holder.The zipper action is good; like most Betsey stuff the quality is pretty decent. The strap is secure...I always worry about hitting the town wearing a wristlet because I'm paranoid the strap will break or the contents will just fall out. This is indeed light weight but substantial enough that you feel you're carrying an actual bag.I'm not positive, but I think this bag made have been manufactured by Betsey before the Steve Madden buy-out. If so, I love it just a teensy bit more. The colors pop, it's buttery (for PVC) and I happen to like little Toucan Sam touches in my life.

I am one of those people that like fruitcake and not specialty ones, just the classic dark ones. I will say the ad for this was good and perhaps set my expectations too high. Overall it was actually bland, especially the candied fruit, almost flavorless. The cake is a little light for fruitcake also bland and lacked that rich taste, it was too dry. It also needed more nuts, more fruit and better quality fruit.Given how small it is, and it is small, I actually had a half inch slice left over and that is very rare for me, I tend to nibble on it between slices until its reduced to a few crumbs.For the cost I expected a lot better, I'll go back to the ones in a tin can from the supermarket next year.Could not recommend to anyone but will say it does not taste bad it is just not good.

This has worked very well in the week or so I have had it, it charges 3 batts as fast as 1, 3 batteries is all I have so until more batts show up 3 is the most I can do right now.What I like is that it has all of the protections you need, over-charge and shorting so you can just hook them up and forget about them until your next flight. I also like how it gives you a positive indication when any given battery is fully charged, the LED for that port turns off and you know it is ready. The one thing I wish it had was a conditioning cycle but I knew it didn't when I bought it so no points off.So far it seems to give each battery a full charge, in fact, I get about 1 minute more flight time than with the charger that came with my quadcopter.You do need to have a USB power source and while you could use your computer I don't think that is the best way, PC USB ports vary in what they can handle and it is also dependent on what else you have plugged into your USB ports. I got a very cheap 21W USB power supply to go with this, it also has protection in it in case this box shorts or pulls too much current.The description says it comes with 4 adapter jumpers but it comes with 5 as pictured as well as the USB cord.I have a UDI 818A Quadcopter and the batts that go with it and this has worked out very well.Pros:Charges 5 Batts in the time of 1Over-Charge Protection (no need to babysit it)Short circuit Protection -- Nice with the stories of batts swelling, leaking and even catching on fire per Amazon reviewsPositive indication when charge cycle is overComplete charge, I got an extra minute on average, which is about 20% longer.Cons:Needs external power from a USB port or charger (although most people have at least one USB charger)No conditioning cycle to restore battsI would easily recommend this to a friend.

This quickly reminds you how well things Made in the USA can be. When my can opener of 40 years finally needed replacing I did not think twice about and just picked one up from the supermarket which lasted less than a year and was never very good to start with. This is the same sturdy construction as my last good one, they are heavy and clearly made with quality steel.This goes through any can lid like a hot knife through butter and really grabs the can, I have not had one walk-offs as I call them when the opener loses its grip and walks off the edge making to reengage it. It so far has easily punctured every can I have tried so far on the first try. The handles are well cushioned and the turning knob is big and easy to get and keep a purchase on even with wet or slippery hands.I would easily recommend these to friends.

I looked for a while before selecting these knives, and not that I have been using them a few weeks I can say I am pretty happy with the set. My set came in perfect condition and the block is very nice, much smaller footprint than my old one so I get a little bit of counter space back. The scissors are pretty handy with jar opener in the handle, flat screwdriver type end and a can opener on the handle end, the scissors are sharp and cut well.Now for the knives, because of my last set I am already in the habit of rinsing and wiping dry after each use so I have no issues with rusting as I saw in a couple reviews, mine came very sharp and seem to be holding the edge reasonably well, like a lot of good knives it does not hurt to hit it with a few swipes on the sharpening stick, again force of habit, I have been still doing that every few uses/The knives have a good feel, not too heavy and certainly not cheesy feeling (think Ginsu) I would put them just one notch down from my older Cutco knives in feel. The lengths and types are just right, nice serrated blade for bread and such, 2 butcher style, one with the little indents that I assume are so potatoes and things like it  don't stick to the blade,  and it sort of works, the other is a smooth blade, classic butcher style.I think the price / performance is perfect on these, not too expensive in cost and not too cheap in the product, I would recommend these to a friend.

This was a major disappointment, my fault for not reading the reviews first. I was very much anticipating this figuring how could I go wrong with Amish Country, their Apple Butter and outstanding. Well they seemed to use the same approach on the pie filling, it was pureed, pure mush with no pieces of rhubarb or strawberry.There is also zero zing to the filling, no real hint of rhubarb at all but oddly not too sweet. Given all of the trouble it takes to make a pie, 10 extra minutes to cut up some real rhubarb when in season is the way to go but I was hoping this would be good out of season. The ad for this should say it is mush with no pieces intact, much like orange juice tells you the pulp content these days. I think everyone pretty much knows the texture and consistency of rhubarb pie and this was way off the mark, enough to rate mentioning.Thankfully I used a Marie Calendar crust, had I made a crust from scratch I would be really unhappy, the crust was clearly the highlight of that pie. If you are looking for real rhubarb type pie filling look somewhere else, you will be disappointed with this for sure.

I was not sure what to expect, after reading a lot of reviews I picked this as the price and features were about right for something I might destroy on my first try. I have no experience with RC cars, planes, or other devices, this is my first remote controlled vehicle but I have used game controllers so the controls were not that hard to pick up.I fired 818A up after charging the battery and just had a blast! It was a lot easier to control than I had expected from the reviews, I had to start in my basement, was very windy and dark out when it was ready to try. It took just a few minutes to get it to reliably hoover but I had to keep adjusting it to keep it in the same spot, I used the trim to take most the drift out but it still drifted a little but was easy enough to control. I manage to do a level flight 360 turn (not flip), but took a 360 degree video of my basement, it looked totally cool on the video.Making your first goal to attain level stable flight really lets you get a feel for the controls without much risk of breaking anything, once I could hold it in a spot then I tried cruising it around, again it is not hard to get the basics, just remember to just kill power if you lose control, at 4' off the floor dropping does not hurt it at all.I had bought and charged 2 extra batteries and was getting 5 - 8 minutes per battery but this is because I was not running it hard, the basement area is 20 feet by 14' with 7' ceiling, most of the time the power was around 30%. The next thing I plan to do is get a few more batteries.As I noted the video was great, it was night and I was in the basement with just the basement lights on and it captured pretty good video.When I first unboxed it, I was pretty worried it was going to break easily, it feels really flimsy, as it turns out this is an strength, everything flexes and bends easily, which comes in really handy as you bounce it off wall, the ceiling, and everything else in range, drop from 7 feet landing upside down on a concrete floor, no problem, just flip it over and go again.I really took some good crashes and not even the propellers broke, so over all I am totally happy with this and it gives you enough "feel" for the hobby to know if you want to drop a grand or more on a more professional grade quadcopter.Pros:- Easy for first timer to fly- Very durable- Comes fully assembled- Can be flown indoors provided you have at least a 10'x10'x6' clear area, I typically hovered at about 4 feet- Spare parts and batteries readily available, this model is for sale everywhere so you can get parts locallyCons:- Battery life, plan on 5 or so minutes, so get several- Trim Control on remote needs to be done every time you turn it on, no way to save it- Manual is a joke -- But has all key info to get it going- Power Charger does not work like the manual says, on mine a red light means it is chargedI would easily recommend this quadcopter for first time flyers, love the size and stability in still air.

This is one of the better Ice Melts and it is not just "salt" as one review suggested, its a chemical blend that is not only more effective than salt but is better for you lawn and concrete. I usually but the 50 pound bags but I bought one of these for the spreader lid.If you have a medium to small area to cover like I do, it is perfect for laying down snow melt pellets for side walks and even the driveway. I just refill it from the bag once the ice melt that came with it. Give great control over the amount and location the pellets go, and refills easily.BTW -- If the lid comes off in shipping you can recover all of it, you just pour it from the box back into the container.

If you are working with SMD's this is a very good tip for spot work and clean-up. I still prefer a wider blade tip for most smd work, I use the smear and hope approach to soldering them in, that is, I preheat the pins and then drag a flat blade tip down the pins. Most of the time that woks perfectly but occasionally it leaves bridges between pins and that is where this time comes in handy. It is small enough to heat just one or 2 pins and I used this tip on my solder remover.This time is also good for any fine / small component work, smd or through-hole. It is not as good on larger parts like relay or switch pins, 1W and larger resistors, and other parts with a lot of bulk to them, the tip is too small to hold the heat, I took no points off for this because I knew it going in and did not get it for big parts.

I got these for my basement window that are embedded in concrete encasements. They are very easy to adjust to the correct width and being black I don't have to worry about them looking dirty over time. Once adjusted they are as solid as an attached pole and while I only hung sheers on them, they could easily hold moderately heavy curtains.

Disclaimer: I did not use these for a tattoo machine.I needed a very small grommet that would give a professional looking finish where I needed to mount 2 trimmer variable resistors to a metal case, so it needed a hole in the center for the screwdriver to be able to adjust the trimmer and enough around the edges to cover up the drill hole area.It was almost like these were custom made for the job, the exactly fit the screw head on the trimmer and exactly fit the holes drilled for the trimmers. It contributed to making the project look store bought and not home made.

This is just right for your next 2.7 gallons of snot depending on your blowing style.Blowing Style Snot Capacity Chart*1 Blow Per Tissue - 1.4 GallonsMulti-Blower Normal - 2.2 GallonsUse every possible dry spot multi-blower - 2.7 gallons *** Pick and wipe will impact the total capacity you will get depending on approach. Pick / Wipe and saving the same tissue for future pick and wipes will help extend the life of the product.** Bubble snot blows will lower the capacity as they tend to wet a larger surface areaDisclaimers:*** Your gallonage may vary.*** Snot observed in this Kleenex may appear smaller than it felt.*** All capacities were rigorously measured using the FDA certified meat scale at a local deli, who asked not to be named for some reason...WARNGING: Known to the Stale of California this probably may cause something, whatever it is, fine, we are in good company with everything else on the planet.

I have been helping a kid fairly new to electronics get a good base collection of parts, this kit is well priced for the selection and it is a good selection that will have the right value caps for all but bigger electrolytic caps. If you are planning projects like power supplies, higher power audio amps, or even 555 circuits where an electrolytic cap is used in an RC network for timing you'll need to augment this kit with some bigger ones.Other than that this has any cap you'll generally need and each value is packed in labeled re-sealable pouch that can be used for years and just refill as needed but have them nicely organized and not need a half a wall of parts bins. Until you get good enough to design around the parts you have or modify designs you find to use them, having a good selection is key to quickly building most of the vast number of published schematics on the net.You can put together your own collection easy enough but unless you are buying a lot, it will be hard to beat the price, I would easily recommend this to anyone starting out, and then hit places like Goldmine Electronic for surplus cap grab bags to refill this kit as you use them.

This is the easiest USB network adaptor I have ever used. I downloaded the latest drivers as they suggested and then plugged it into a USB port on my Lenovo ThinkPad running Win7 64-bit and it just jumped to life, no messing around at all. They supply the drivers on a DVD so you can get them if you don't have a connection yet, I had a wireless to grabbed them from the web site.It had no issues playing Windows Media Center recorded TV files (WTV) from my home network, far better than the wireless does. Also copying 3-4GB WTV files from the network to the laptop was noticeably faster than wireless from the same laptop.Hard not to be happen with it, has network and traffic LED's, is compact and good for travel and best of all just worked out of the box.I would easily recommend this to anyone that needs and easy to install and fast Ethernet to USB adapter.

Overview --I amazed at how slow this is compared to my prior Panasonic model the BDT-210. I got this as I am always looking for faster with Blu-Ray, specifically load to play and navigating. The BDT-210 was such an amazing improvement over the Panasonic I had prior to that so when the BDT-330 touting fast loading and navigation I when in with high expectations.These expectations were lowered to, wonder if it will ever play the disc upon loading the first disc, Gravity in 3D. My expectations were lowered some already from navigating during set-up and then looking to see what might be new over the BDT-210, the menu performance is outright sluggish, enough so that I found myself pushing the button again.Pro's --- It works is the best accolade I can give it.- Set-up was easyCon's --- Slow loading, takes over twice the time as the BDT-210 to load the same disc- Menu navigation, also very very slow- Smart Apps, you guess it, slooooooow- Popping when audio changes- HDMI CEC Turns stuff on randomlyThe defining attribute of this unit is that it is really slow, sorry to have repeated it so many times this early in the review but this is like 2 generations behind in speed. The other thing I did not like was when audio types change, like through the previews or any menu with a sound track it produces a nasty switching pop.For the rest of the review just assume whatever is discussed unless I say otherwise, is slow :)Set-UpSet up for me was a breeze, but this is my 3rd Panasonic Blu-Ray so I am very accustomed to their "style" which is a little different in like selecting option to change, still pretty easy. I let it go wireless first, it had no issues at all, when it found my network if popped up a keyboard to put in the password. For wired network, it just required clicking OK when it was done.The set-up wizard makes set-up pretty easy and given this is HDMI only it should always get what it is hooked to right.RemoteSmall but has all of the keys you use often in good spots and one press. Range is really good, I use it from 12 feet away.Smart Features:It is fully loaded with the typical smart apps, a browser, huluplus, Netflix, Twitter, Skype, facebook, YouTube and many others. The ones I tried all worked but I could not really use them as long as everything takes. Once streaming starts it did very well, I have a wired connection and there were no drops or buffering.MiraCast -- The ability to push the picture out to a table or phone is coolDLNA -- Unusable for most video, this is more the nature of DNLA in general but this kind of the worst of the bad but it does work.HDMI CEC --This is one of those wiz-bang that sounds really good on paper, the theory is that you drop in a Blu-ray disc and it turns on the TV if it is not already on and the AV receiver, and selects the correct input on them so you don't have to mess with the remote. This can work very well, but not in this case. I found that with it enabled that after I shut down everything, driven from the TV's CEC and being turned off, that part worked fine but in the next few minutes the 330 would turn on the receiver and sometimes both the TV and receiver, but oddly did not turn itself on... This behavior goes away as soon as you disable HDMI CEC in the settings menu on the 330.Picture  Audio Quality:The video was very good and on par with most players and the 3D was very clean and well done.
