The 4K up scaling works on some things and not others, like for Top Gun sky scenes it looked really good, like you could see the difference, most of the time on m 55" Samsung F9000 4K TV, audio to me is not quite right but I can't put my finger on the issue, just seems a little washed out, but what is annoying are the sharp click/pops it makes when the audio changesOnce you get to watching a movie the load and nav slowness are not factors, it of course had no issue playing them, with great video and acceptable audio, Streaming wireless was hit and miss, some streamed just fine, Netflix was the best and most consistent, and YouTube not so much. Wireless is probably fine for a movie but I did not test it long enough to see, I use the wired option and that so far has been flawless.Conclusion -- 2 Star, below average not a good value.If this unit was under 100 bucks I would give it 3 perhaps even 4 stars but at this price it is not a good deal when performance is considered and really that is what you mostly pay for when you go mid-range like this. I would look for another unit and am, this is going back.

I have been extremely impressed with this power supply, I tested it from fully loaded on all 3 rails to so marginally loaded it could not measure the current draw and it is amazingly stable and very low ripple. I did have to take two stars off for how it handles over current in Constant Voltage mode. I would have to take all stars off but once you know you can protect against its actions.Pro's --- Readout for each Voltage and Current for both variable supplies (0 - 30VDC / 0 - 5A)- Voltage Stability under varying load- Ripple under all loads was significantly lower than the specs- Flexibility, being able to put them in series, parallel, or independently adjustable is great, doubles the output (0 - 60VDC @ 5A in series and 0 - 30 at up to 10A in parallel.Cons --- When current limit is hit voltage erratically drops to zero, no over current indication, so this is short protection only- Voltage and current adjustments are touchy, a fine adjustment would have been nice- Noisy when adjusting voltage, relays clacking all the time until you are dialed in- Manual, barely covers the basics and covers so many models it is hard to fish what applies to whatThis thing is a real beast measuring about 15" long, 10" wide and 6" high and build like a brick you know what, weighing in at a tad over 20 pounds. That is actually a great attribute, it takes beefy parts to do this job right, and good power supply should be heavy and big.The back is lined top to bottom with massive heat sinks for the regulators and though the vent slots you see a massive toroidally wound transformer that is ideally suited for this type of work and partly explains why you can hit with a 10 amp load change and not see the voltage move much at all.I tested this with various resistive and inductive loads (lights and motors) and it was consistent in providing clean DC power with any load type, I was impressed with the inductive load, had a motor that is 4A @ 12VDC and you hit the supply full force that the 12VDC moved 0.2V for about 10mS and was right back at 12VDC. I also saw no noise from the motor on the other two rails, so it must have some nice filtering going on inside.It also has short protection, it says current limiting but this is not really accurate when compared to how a bench supply should work. When my old bench supply see a short it kill the power to that circuit at once, but if the circuit wants a little more current than I have set it for, it warns me with a light that get brighter the more extra current it wants, it does not give that current and does not change the voltage. Just tells me it wants more and then I can decide to give it or not.When in constant voltage mode, the most common mode, you set the volts to say 12VDC and set the current knob to just past the minimum so you know it is limiting to probably less than 250mA, if your circuit, say after a relay engages it wants 300mA instead of telling you it needs more current the voltage erratically drops to 0 and it is slow about doing it and if you were working on a circuit sensitive to this then the smoke will escape and it will stop working, just as always happens when the smoke escapes from electronic stuff. When I breadboard something I generally keep the current limited to a RCH over what I know it needs and this way if something goes wrong it usually does not smoke anything since it just can't get enough current, this approach is not really viable with this unit.The only way to protect from this is to just turn the current knob all the way up, but at that point you have no current limiting protection and any mistakes will result in a smoked part. It also give you no way to know how much current it is set for in constant voltage mode, you find out when something uses it, until it uses too much in which case it shuts down. In my case when it got low enough that the relay dropped back out it snapped back to 12VDC and then shutdown again as the relay kicked in, I am sure it would have oscillated like this forever had I not stopped it. For something otherwise designed so well this is really a big miss. What I do now is use a resistor to get the current setting I want, then hook it to my circuit and try to ensure I don't cross it.The other thing that takes a little getting used to is there is no fine adjustment for the current or voltage and getting them exactly where you want takes a bit of playing around.The V & I controls have a nice heavy feel, like a very high quality volume control on AV gear, has that fluid feel. The controls, On/Off, Independent / Series / Parallel, and V / I adjustments are all clear and easy to understand although the manual is confusing on how to best rig it when using it in other than independent mode where it is 3 separate power supplies.The 5VDC rail was very tight, measuring 5.002VDC with no load to 5.028 under a full load, no ripple to speak of.Ascetically, the unit I got had the exact brand name on it as the ad, the unit looks a lot better than the picture, and the LED displays are bright and very easy to read and look way better than the picture. I was surprised at this price how solid and clean everything is from the heavy duty detachable power cord to the terminal posts and the very handy handle on the top.Any hobbyist and most pro's will find this supply meet the demands of most project builds and I find more of my projects these days need more than one voltage, typically 5VDC and something else, like 12 or 9 or 24VDC, prior to getting this I had just a one rail supply and it meant setting it to the highest needed voltage and using like 7805's or 7812's to regulate the other voltages I needed, this takes care of that nicely.I have not popped the cover yet but looking through the vent holes it looks very clean inside, well laid out, good wire management, heavy gauge wire where you would expect it and so on.I can't speak to durability as I just got it, the bench supply I had been using I bought in 1976, and it was used military equipment when I bought it surplus, if this lasts half the time I will be happy! This has all of the apparent attributes, the weight, the heat sinks, transformer that one would expect from a device like this if it is well built, so now time will tell.I would recommend this to strangers and even people I know.

These are well priced and work, but they take a long time to be shipped, in my case a month and I did not notice the ship time, being electronic parts where the norm is overnight or 3 days tops I was not paying attention, my bad.Other then that they seem pretty average and so far the ones I have tried all worked so if you have the time to wait, this is a good buy but if your project is laid out on your breadboard and you need this to finish it up or you need this for a repair you don't want to wait a month for then I suggesting hitting one of the US based parts places. (Digi-Key / Jamesco / Mouser / Goldmine...)

Now that these are being banned, at least the manufacturing of them, I bought these for the sole purpose of hoarding them until the worlds supply runs out and then I planned to sell them on E-Bay for thousands of dollars each.Just Kidding!  I only have one light left in the house that is not CFL or LED, I just can't seem to find a color temp in either CFL or LED that does not hurt my eyes when reading (not damage them, just makes them water after an hour or so of reading by them).These came very well packed and I looked at them all, none broken, and they produce that classic incandescent light we all know and love, I can read for hours with no eye strain or watering.

No matter if you are calibrating you big new TV by eye or with test equipment this is a great disc.Almost all TV's 50 inches or bigger can benefit from some calibration to get a better picture, they often come out of the factory a little on the bright side and the colors slightly tweaked to the blue side as that is more appealing to the eye. To be clear, those that never calibrate still get a very nice picture and this is a value add step not a requirement.For those adventurous or those who want to get more out of their picture this is a great Calibration Disc. It contains detailed instructions for not novice and all of the test patterns needed to tune your picture to reference standards or as close as your TV can get.There are 3 levels of tuning the way I look at it, Basic tuning is just using the common controls, Brightness, Contrast, Color, and Tint, the "knobs" all TV's have. This disc will fix you right up and tell you what order to make the adjustments in. Next is Intermediate, where you get into a few more controls to by eye get everything to match what it supposed to look like. Finally there is the Pro tune, this is where test equipment is used to adjust the picture to an objective standard, you can buy or rent the calibration and do it yourself or pay a pro from 300 - 500 to do it (I would advise against hiring a pro unless you are a real purist and videophile, that last ounce of tuning is barely perceivable.No matter which level you are going into this at this disk is one of the best you can get to assit.

If you need a general purpose utility flashlight for the car or around the home this does the job and cheap. Seems in our efforts to save the planet and move to LED flashlight it is getting harder to find one priced suitably for the junk drawer that has a decent sized lens and beam, those micro-LED ones mostly have a tiny little beam, very intense but tiny.Worked perfectly for my use.

I really thought I did my homework on this, read the ad, the reviews, looked at other options and it seemed like it was going to be just right so I bought one of the queen sized ones.Holy No Fill Batman, I put it in a new pillow case just right in size, tossed and on the bed for a test drive and the next thing I know my head is enveloped in the pillow, it had sunk so the pillow where the bank of my head met it was compressed all the way to cover touching cover, the two side had wrapped my head and covered both ears.As a estimate I would guess that with 25% more fill this would be outstanding, I crammed another pillow into the same pillow case and that makes it useable.There is nothing "firm" about this pillow, it is soft to a fault and I am amazed that anyone could find it comfortable but a lot of folks have so perhaps I got a bad one or just have an entirely different notion of how firm applies to pillows.

Pros:- Picture, just stunning!- Controls, outstanding control of every aspect of the picture- Smart Features great if you have a keyboard- Easy Set-up, it does most of the work- Integration with Home Theater receiver and STB- Built in WiFi and Wired Ethernet- 4 HDMI, 3 USB, 1/1 Component/Shared CompositeCons:- Need a stand as wide as the TV, most of the weight falls on the last 4" of each end (5 feet)- Internal speakers - this is pretty much the case with any large TV these days- Need a very wide stand, looks good but needs a stand to fit the full width if not wall mounted.- Annoying error screen when switching sources to tell you there is no HDMI signal (can be bypassed at the cost of other features)Overview:The overall 5 rating is based 90% on picture quality, the rest to me is a small part of the decision,  if I add in Sound from the internal speakers and Smart Features and other measures it drops to a 4+,so an outstanding TV. This 64F8500 is at the top of the game in picture quality and while it offers nearly endless tuning options, you are just fine with your eyes and the basic picture controls we all know well;  Brightness, Contrast, Sharpness, Color, and Tint, and Cell light. The good news is that out of the box you get a stunning picture, and using your preference and eyes you can tune it to your liking just fine so no need to be worried about most of the settings, the factory values are very good. Most are going to be very happy with  some basic adjustments and that will be the last time you need to bother, more on calibration later. When you add in the smart features with the great picture it is hard not to have a smile on your face unless you are watching a sad movie.I have mine on an AV stand, it is not wall mounted but can be with a standard bracket and various styles. I had to get a new stand as this needs to be 6" side, most of the weight sits on the last 4" of each end and I don't think it would do well without the ends resting on the stand. The other option is the wall mount it, it has a standard mount so you can buy most any style.Overall this is by far the best Plasma TV I have owned or any kind of TV for that matter, this brings together the best of LCD/LED and Plasma in one set and should hold me over the few years it will take for OLED to get its act together, I saw no material advantage in OLED, not that you can get a 64/65 inch yet. Not only are the prices too high, they still have a lot of bugs to work out, OLED is only for true early adaptors who enjoy the early flaws and all and have a healthy budget.Picture Quality (PQ): 5This to me is the first and most important measure. Out of the box the picture is just plain stunning before messing with any settings and there are 4 picture "modes", 6 if you are a little adventurous and care to dive into the "forbidden" service menu, the 4 you get are: Dynamic, Standard, Relax, and Movie. Dynamic is typically for use with game consoles or PC's hooked to the TV and on some animated movies like Shrek it can really punch the picture up. Standard covers typical TV viewing, Relax tones things down a little for less eye strain that too bright of a picture can cause (common in LED/LCD sets), and finally Movie which is how Ron Howard thinks it should look :) - this is supposed to align to how the producers wanted it to look. If Ron ever drops by it is nice to know you are all set. Seriously though Movie sets a base line for true reference standards.I found the F8500 Picture after an a few minor adjustments to be as good as the Pani ZT60  for everything from Blu-Ray movies to HDTV from cable, both are just great. There are two places where I think there is a noticeable difference, and to my surprise they were both on the Samsung. The F8500 seems to hold its color better in a room lit well enough to read in, and far better in a sun lit room.  I also liked 3D on the Samsung more than one the ZT60, seemed a lot more vivid.As to the overall picture, you get deep blacks to bright whites, the best whites I have ever seen on a Plasma, true white. The colors look true and I measure that by them not standing out (except where they are supposed to), red things should look red and not make you notice it if you know what I mean. Flesh tones are outstanding, again they look like they should to the point that it does not call your attention to it, they just look right.When watching a blu-ray under darkened conditions the F8500 really starts to show its stuff, when they say a picture tell a thousand words that is an understatement when it comes to the picture and I traded up from a top of the line 50" Panasonic Plasma. The subtle details add a lot to the movies, things in the shadows to spectacular explosions are the best I have ever seen. As for things like dealing with on-screen motion I have found this to be the best set I have owned so far still not perfect but the best to date.Bottom line on picture quality out of the box just does not get much better than the Samsung F8500 series the colors are vibrant without looking cartoonish, the whites are the best I have ever seen on a Plasma set (finally watched a hockey game where the ice was white and not grayish or bluish and approached that of LCD/LED sets, the black depth allows the subtle shadows to show themselves adding the kind of richness and depth usually only seen at a theater.3D PQ: 5++If you are a 3D fan then I would not even consider the Pani it is just too dark to really get the full impact of 3D, the Samsung being brighter has produced the first 3D I have been willing to watch on my home TV, it is near theater quality, it will make you duck! The TV comes with 4 pairs of 3D glasses and additional glasses are reasonably priced. I watched Star Trek - Into the Darkness in the theater 3D and later on the F8500 and WOW is all I can say, while not quite as deep as in the theater I was awed by it, and the most amazing part is how the effects are so clean it does not distract from the movie but adds to as it should.PQ Calibration: 5There are three levels I break picture calibration into, basic settings (brightness, Contrast, Sharpness, Color , Tint and Cell Light) adjusting the picture with live content, ie watching TV, this is how most people adjust the picture, then an intermediate level where it is calibrated by eye with a calibration disc like the Disney WOW disc that gives you the test patterns and advice on how they should look and what "knob" you need to turn,  and finally the professional calibration that runs from 300 - 600 buck and attempts bring it to a reference standard. The F8500 is a 5 for all three, I did use the Disney WOW on mine after 300 hours of running the TV, but this is not required, I just like to know I am at a good starting point before adjusting to what I like.Sound Quality: 3 (internal speakers) / 5 hooked to a home theaterThe sound is very acceptable out of the internal speakers to watch most TV, but is far from ideal, this really takes a surround bar at minimum or surround AV receiver to pull the best sound out and unlike the professional picture calibration talk, it really does require using external speakers and an AV receiver if you want the sound quality to match the picture, however if you start with just the internal speakers or if you are like me and do not always want to fire up the home theater system, this set has sufficient sound quality to enjoy most TV. For sports and movies it really does pay to add the external audio, it truly makes a noticeable difference. This is the same with any TV, so it is not Samsung specific.Smart Features: 3+This has a ton of smart features and are of the same quality and diversity as any TV in this price range, so if you want to stream movies from Amazon or Netflix or a pile of other streaming services you are all set. The Samsung comes with wireless Ethernet or wired, I found the wireless WiFi to be pretty darn good, watching HD movies from a streaming sources was very good, no lags, artifacts, pauses, blocking or other noise. This depends more on the quality and performance of your wireless router and internet service than on the TV. The best connection for streaming is still a wired Ethernet connection if you can swing it and there are a number of ways you can do this without running wire if you are a little adventurous.Once adding a keyboard (about 30 bucks) the browser goes from virtually useless to acceptable but this is the early days and it will get better over time with firmware upgrades. Bottom line, do not count on this to become you mainstream browser.Count on getting a Bluetooth keyboard if you want to get the most out of the smart features, the remote is only practical for very limited use. One downside, not all Smart Apps work with and external keyboard, I just don't use them, the on-screen keyboard or smart pad is too awkward to be usable.Key smart features include:- Things like, YouTube Facebook, Twitter and Skype that works with the built in camera, apps include a number of streaming services like Amazon Video, NetFlix, and several more, these are app paid services, so you get the app for free but the movies generally cost you (except Amazon Prime of course) Other apps include a mix of paid and free things like Weather, News, games, sports and such. If you use the full TV functions you have a full TV guide and you can play content from a USB stick for Photos, Videos & Music: Play back photo, video, and music. Has a pretty cool camera app, nice field of view.- The DLNA is OK and on par with most DLNA clients but it allows you to stream from any DLNA source you might have, I have it hitting my HTPC for movies and other stuff we have recorded using Windows Media Center and a tuner card. If you have a large collection of movies and tv shows the navigation is pretty rough.- Android App, is very hot, if you have a smart phone or tablet then you can control the TV via a free Samsung app, I use it with a Samsung 10" Tab that came with the TV and both Samsung's free App but also a few free/shareware apps. A cool feature is the ability to push whatever you are watching from the TV to the tablet or phone, and keep watching from there while you leave the room for whatever reason, then you don't have to pause the show to wait for someone to come back. It does an amazing job pushing the show to the tablet, very smooth and sounds great. There is also a number of cool remote app.Smart Control Features -Controlling the TV by Voice commands and/or motion gestures I put in the novelty section, yes they sort of work and are very impressive when showing this off to family and friends but on a practical level I found them worse than useless, so turned them all off and only use them now when I am doing a gee-wiz demo for folks. Voice triggers too easily, misses too often and after a while feels like it does when trying to direct a 3 year old on what to do, you repeat yourself a lot. The motion controls are just insane in my view, some may like them but I just can't bring myself to sit there flapping my arms around to control the TV, seriously what are folks thinking... The one gesture I am really good at is not very polite and it does not understand it and when it does it turns the volume up :)Operation: 4 (not counting smart control)I measure operation by ease-of-use, when I want to watch TV I like things simple. Samsung now ships this with 2 remote controls, the little Smart Remote and a big ole conventional remote, I prefer the conventional remote for most of what I use but the smart remote is pretty slick also and often best when using the smart features, I just happen to like a real button for selecting and controlling common functions. The on-screen menus are the best I have ever used, they are generally very well placed and sized, as well as ordered in a way puts the things you want most often one click away. It loses a point on the keyboard deal, given that many of the smart features I like are nearly unusable with the on-screen keyboard or gestures on the keypad, I think one needs to be included, sort of like a new car delivered with no tires.This will interface with your cable/Sat set top box (STB) using the included IR (Infra-Red) blaster that you position in front of your STB, I found this to be very reliable but like any IR blaster will sometimes be a little flakey. I would say that it hits 95% on the first try and the 5% it missed it does not do anything, which is good, this is with a Comcast STB.If you are using an AV receiver for your audio the Samsung will integrate with most newer receivers and allow you to control it thought the Samsung remote, at least for volume and channel, offering a simpler operation experience in not having to juggle remotes, but don't count on getting rid of the AV receiver remote, it is not that complete. You can put the STB remote in a drawer if you use the IR Blaster that is included, so one less thing to mess with while watching TV.It can be a little flakey when using the integrated control to the receiver, I use it with a Sony STR-DA1800 and 99% of the time it is fine, 1% of the time it gets confused and turns off the receiver, or will no longer adjust the volume, but for me it is rare.Final Thoughts:I would easily recommend to friends and if I had to make the decision again today, this is the set I would buy to hold me over until they get the issues worked out with OLED. Now after having this for a couple of months I find I never think about the settings, rarely even change picture mode (which is very easy).My Home Theater:Samsung 64F8500 / Sony STR-DA1800 AV Receiver / Infinity 7.1 Surround Speakers / Panasonic Blu-Ray BDT-210 / Comcast HDTV Set-Top / HTPC computer

If you are looking to see a Sandra Bullock movie you can skip this one, it seemed that she did. This is basically ripping the cop pairing dynmaic from her Miss Congeniality roles and trying to turn it into an entire movie. I rated it a 2 instead of a 1 because I was able to make to the end, but there was more relief that it was over than anything else.Nothing really works in this movie, unlike the last mis-fit cop pairing, you don't end up liking either one of them, and her partners role is so over the top it is just not believable and it does not help that she is a mix between all of the bad things about Betty White and the worst of Rosanne Barr in one loud mouth person that would never be allowed to stay on any police force, not even in GITMO.Very glad I just rented this.

This really looks great and about the only ding I had it that it appeared in the picture to be a little thicker than it was, by no means a deceptive picture, just how I looked at it. This is good for taking the edge off of a cool room and is not too warm for an average temp room. Looks good with business dress attire, sports coat and slacks, and as well with a pair of jeans.

I was looking for something to light up the wall behind a 64" Flat screen TV and this worked perfectly, the ability to lock into a specific color makes it perfect for the job as well as the dimming feature to hit the right light level, since it is LED it does not get hot and can rest on the cables without risk, and when not watching TV it makes a wonderful display in Fade mode going through the rainbow of colors.I am getting 2 more to remove the shadows created by one just one light source.While mine are stashed behind a mountain of electronics, the unit actually looks really great and would look good sitting in view, I also like that it is powered so I do not have to worry about batteries, the construction is also really solid, this is not "cheap" looking or in feel.All in all a great little product.

- APC J25BNote: I added two Customer pictures for this, one that compares Utility Power to the ACP Power on battery and the second is a picture of the J25B unit with the rest of the Home Theater Equipment.Pros:- 865W UPS is well sized for all but the more extreme Home Theater Systems (you want your average load to be about 1/2 the max, so 432.5W)- Power Conditioner for power plus cable and phone line protection, but also plays well with power conditioners if you have one you want to keep- Home Theater PC Integration (USB) with PowerChute to orderly shutdown your HTPC- Form Factor / Style that compliments Home Theater equipment, looks great with the other components (See Picture)- Information Display with -- Batt Run time at current Load, Current Load in Watts, and input Voltage and Frequency- Dead silent when not on Batts, fan only comes on when the batt is charging or if you are running off of batteryCons:- Display does not actually Dim as the manual and ads say, the only display options are On/Off, when Off you need to hit a front panel button to see it, when it is ON it is at full brightness and is too bright for Home Theater setting, I prefer a true dim option as the rest of the components have.- Stepped sine wave, very well done but still stepped, there are some TV's and receivers that do not work well with stepped sine wave power no matter how well done, APC makes a true Sine wave version of this unit but it is very expensive, I would only get if this impacted your system. (See Picture)Review --Having used APC products for over 20 years both at home and the professional grade gear in our data centers I was glad to see an APC UPS in this form factor/style to fit as a component in a typical Home Theater AV stand. Most of the products are more form over function and I knew there was no way APC would just make something just look good and not still have the APC engineering one expects behind the name. The J25B UPS is classic APC put into an AV gear style case at 17" wide and just under 4" high, it looks like the rest of AV components and fits well.I picked the J25B over the J35B because in my opinion less is more when it comes to messing with the power. To adjust utility power means more active parts in the power path, the J25B picks a low and high voltage point and goes on batt, it does not attempt to adjust utility power, less things to go wrong and less things in the main power path. The J25B lets you change the threshold voltage to go on batt and how reactive it should be, I found the defaults just fine.My core components, are a 64" Plasma TV (Samsung 64F8500) and Sony AV Receiver (STR-DA1800ES) on average runs at about 400W and peaks at 720W so this is just the right size. Watching TV it will give me about 15 minutes, everything turned off about 3 hours, which will more than cover most power outages. The 720W peak leaves plenty of room for transient spikes, the J25B will shut everything off is the things plugged into exceed the 865W it is rated, I have not tested it but from prior experience in computer UPS's, it is pretty quick, enough tolerance for power on spikes and not much more.Overall I give this a solid 4 - The lack of real dimming was worth a point to me as it is designed to be in a home theater where it is important.Note: This is the second unit, the first one I got was bad out of the box, it had a 60 cycle hum any time the power drawn hit 450-500W and by 650W it sounded like something was struggling, I unplugged it and removed the battery, then opened a case with APC and Amazon and they exchanged it with free shipping. I have 2 APC Tower UPS's for computer in our home and have been using their UPS's for years and this was the first that ever had an issue, so I went for an exchange and so far so good, this one is absolutely quiet under any load.

This is being used PC that is about 50 feet from living room where we use it (it is a home theater PC). After trying wireless and finding it highly intermittant when it worked at all at 50 feet, I tried this cable to bring the USB port to the living room where we need the remote IR sensor and keyboard to work from and it works great.Given that 50 feet is over 5 times longer than the USB max length of 9 feet for non-powered devices and the IR sensor being senstive it was great to this does exactly was it says it will do.Two notes on installation -- I initially hooked this to a D-Link powered 7-Port hub on the PC side and the cable did not work even though Windows loaded the device driver, I plugged it into a USB port on the PC and it worked. I tried several ports on the Hub and another hub and it did not work unless plugged directly to the PC. This was no big deal, I had a port free, the hub was just easier to get to.Next, put a D-Link 7-Port powered hub on the living room end and plugged the keyboard and IR sensor in and they both work great. So it works fine with a hub on the device side but needs to be plugged directly into the PC on its side.The device driver is the second note, I thought this would just look like a cable and not something the hardware and windows would notice, if you plug in a regular 3 foot USB cable with nothing on the other end, windows nor the PC "knows" you plugged the cable in, when you plug this cable in Windows loads a device driver that it already has. I am using Win7 64-bit, I don't know if the cable works without a driver but you might want to check if the USB port you want to extend is not on a PC or Win7. However, like a plain cable it comes with no manual so you have to hunt around to see what it loaded as device drivers (Composit device).As for durability, after testing it out, it survived being pulled 50 feet, and through the computer room and living room floor. I put a cap on the ending before pulling it, I have a cable tray that runs the length between the rooms in the basement so it did not really get stressed on the pull. I will not be unplugging it often but the connectors on both ends are snug like they should be. The cable is not as stiff as I had expected so it made it easier to manipulate routing and dressing. Thankfully the amp is in the last 10 feet on the cable and not in the middle as the picture might imply so I did not need to pull it through.Overall this really worked exaclty as needed and if I ever need another 50 foot USB 2 cable I would get another one.Devices attached: (Win7 OS)- D-Link 7-Port USB2 Powered Hub  - eHomeTheater WMC IR Receiver  - IOGear Wireless Keyboard Receiver

This is for the 50 Foot HDMI cable. I had tried a couple others, actually more expensive long cables all with poor results, this has out performed them and at a great price.My set-up is tricky as it is HTPC (nVidia GT 440) I need to drive 50 feet from the computer room to the living room and then it hooks to an AV receiver (Sony STR-DA2800ES) and ultimately to a 64" Plasma TV (Samsung 64F8500).I sitll needed a in-line amp and used the Tripp Lite 24Hz model and it worked perfectly with this cable, where it did not work with the other cables I ahd tried. This was the last piece in a long road to eliminating the wireless HDMI I was using before.

I must admit I was not holding out much hope for this after trying a couple others and an in-line amp built into the cable and none of them solved the problems. I slapped this on and it cleared up all of the issues, I can play TV, Recorded TV from Windows Media Center, DHCP protected content, streaming programs from Netflix, Comcast, and Amazon and no issues with any source.I have a 50 foot 24 gauge HDMI cable run from my Home Theater PC (HTPC) to my AV receiver (AVR) and it did not work well at all, I would get 3 main errors, DHCP failure, HDMI failures, and sometimes it would not recognize the receiver at all. I am using a 24 gauge HDMI cable. (do not use anything less than 26AWG, most HDMI cables are 28 gauge and will not work well, Tripp Lite sells a pretty good cable.Installation: This is pretty easy, just place it on the end of the long run cable on the TV/AVR side, make sure to have the "source" side of this plugged into the long cable, and plug a short cable between the other end and the TV/AVR and plug in the power supply, that is it.Don't bother trying it without the supplied power supply, they say it may not be needed but it did not work at all without it and the LED was on without it, just no signal, as soon as I added this the picture popped right up.The Basic Signal chain looks like this:PC NVidia GT440 Video Board ---> 50' 24AWG HDMI cable ---> Tripp Lite Booster ---> HDMI Detective ---> AVR ---> TVIt says you only need it for 75 feet or longer but they really can't say that as each situation will be different, mine definitely needed it.If you are hooking this to an HTPC you might need an EDID stabilizer.The Gefen HDMI Detective is an expensive little box but it keeps the PC from getting confused when you switch sources on your AVR, no more handshake issues or the PC getting confused due to lost EDID. EDID is the code that the TV or AVR tells the source, in my case the HTPC, what it is and what kind of audio and video it can handle. Anytime this gets lost the devices have to renegotiate and that can take up to a couple minutes and often will not work at all, meaning a reboot.Relevant gear:TV -- Samsung PN64F8500, 64" PlasmaAVR -- Sony STR-DA2800ESHTPC - HP Pavilion with a nVidia GT440 video card / RealTek HD AudioEDID Stabilizer -- Gefen HDMI Detective PlusHDMI Booster - Tripp Lite B122-000Note 1: On an HTPC running Win7 it can get real confused and if it does you may have to go into the control panel and put your TV/AVR back into the mix, if it does not see them or does not see them right Windows will disable the device, in this case the Audio to the TV/AVR. If all else failed, reboot.Note 2: HDMI is very tricky at any distance over 16 feet, much depends on how it was implemented in each device in the signal chain, not all HDMI were created equal. There is no sure thing, this may or may not work for your situationNote 3: If you plan on hooking this to a Blu-Ray player I suggest you get the next model up, this only supports 24Hz, not 60Hz. In my use I did not need 60Hz, everything is off the PC and I do not play Blu-Ray from the PC.Warning: While HDMI is technically "hot-pluggable" I strongly suggest powering down the devices while messing with the cables, otherwise you risk frying something (low risk but risk none the less) and if nothing get fried, your PC will get real confused.

It is rare I find something as bad as this, it has every fault IR can have in one nice package.The first issue is that both the reveiver (side you are on) and the transmitter (whatever you what to control side) are highly sensitive to any RF interference, this includes Cell phones, WiFi, within 3 feet of a typical computer, or anywhere near your AV equipment, especially the TV.So while "installing" this is about as easy as it gets, making it work is nearly impossible in a home with things you want to control with it.After an hour of finding quiet RF spots, it finally worked, sort of, it is very spotty on picking up the IR signal and seems to get the command wrong more often than not, you push volume up 10 times you will be lucky to get 3 or 4 actual ticks up.This is going back.BTW -- Batteries are not included so if you decide to chance it and get this anyway have 2 AAA batts handy.

Before it failed completely it would not play protected content from my PC to HTPC receiver/TV. Pull it out and put the wireless back in and it works perfect again, put their cable in and as soon as I show say a recorded TV show it immediatle had a HDCP error and would not play the show.While I was checking options on my PC, the cable just died, nothing even without video playing, my guess is the little in-line amp messed up the HDCP signals before it died completely, thankfully I tested it before routing it. The first 10 mintues and before playing HD content, it seemed like it was going to work.This will be going back, going to try a 50 footer without any gizmo;s this time and see if that works better.My Signal PathPC nVidia Card HDMI Out (7.1 / 1080p / HD ----> Sony STR-DA1800ES (7.1 HD)----> Samsung 64F8500 (1080p HD)Also Tested:Blu-Ray ---> Samsung TV -- No helpSTB --------> Samsung TV -- No helpEach device in the chain is fully HDCP compliant and works with wireles HDMI and other HDMI cables, my new location was down to just under 50 feet and so I thought this would be perfect.Note: HDCP is the copy protection used over HDMI and when a non-compliant device is in the signal path it will not play any protected contect, like all Blu-Ray movies, and all High Def live or recorded TV.

I used these under a entertainment center that weighs a little over 200 pounds with the TV and stereo stuff all loaded into it. I needed to be able to easily get to the back of it to mess with wires once in a while.These unlike the teflon ones have a cloth pad on the bottom which allows for a couple hundred pound stand to be moved without scratching the floor in the event of a little piece of grit gets under it, with the teflon kind a piece of grit turns it in a scribe that marks your floor.

Note: I exchanged the Panasonic 65ZT60 for a Samsung 64F8500 due to the fan noise that for me and my setting was excessive, however I had it for a week while they arranged the exchange. The fan noise is why I gave it a 3 and not a 5, and the picture was why I just could not give it a 1 even though I exchanged it.When I wanted to move from a 50" to a 65" Plasma TV I had little doubt that it was likely going to be Panasonic Plasma, I have been using them since the second year Panasonic made consumer Plasma sets, however for this kind of money I did some pretty deep comparison shopping and research. The selection very quickly came down to the Panasonic 65ZT60 and the Samsung 64F8500, they both have an outstanding picture and roughly equal smart features. The Panasonic is also now the #1 Plasma picture on the market, near perfection to the reference standard. Which sounds great but as they say, a picture is worth a thousand words. After many side-by-side viewings with my own selection of Blu-Ray discs I went with the Panasonic.However, it did not give the best picture under all conditions, in low light to ideal lighting, the Panasonic has to me a better picture and this is untuned out of the box. Tuned up it gets even better. However in a normal sunny day lit room the Samsung was equal and then in a bright room, like curtains open on a sunny day, the Samsung well out performed the Panasonic amd also on 3D, the brightness of the Samsung gives new life to 3D.  The Samsung is a little brighter than the Panasonic so it holds the color better in a room light enough to read in. Also note that to get the near perfect reference picture from either of these requires a professional calibration, but do not worry if you don't get one, they look great out of the box.The delivery guys put in on the stand and I put in the HDMI from the cable box, turned it on, and even before the picture pops up, I hear the fans, and not a steady whirr but an undulating woo-woo sound that some describe as a refrigerator sound.It turns out that it is not just the fans, but also the air flow through the case, there is a rather long discussion on the issue on the AVSForums (they host Audio-Video equipment forums). Panasonic has an official fix which most report as reducing the noise a lot but not eliminating it.To be fair, the ambient noise in a lot of settings may be high enough that you would not hear it, and even if you do hear it, it might not bug ya, but if you are in a quiet setting like I am, make sure you can retuned based on being "unsatisfied", it really did bug me so in the end I exchanged it for the Samsung.

The Good:- Great Mid-Range and Highs- Voice Match to Primus Series is very accurate :)- Size is great for Front-High SpeakersThe Bad:- None for my applicationOverall: 5These sound great mixed with other Infinity Primus speakers, I upgraded my AVR to a Sony STR-DA1800ES and it supports HD-D.C.S. (High Def - Digital Cinema Sound)and requires additional Front L/R speakers that are position above the Main Front L/R speakers adding height to surround depth. I already had Primus speakers for 5.1 surorundm but much larger ones, (Primus 363 Front/163 Surround/351 Center) and needed something go in the new Front High L/R.I was a little worried that these being so small would be tinny and Infinity Voice Match would be more hype than reality, there was nothing to worry about. I mounted these on the wall above the main front speakers (they are front ported which helps) and re-ran the Auto-Calibration on my receiver adding these as Front High L/R. The Auto-Cal hit the distance to the inch and only had a 0.5db offset from the rest of the speakers, so far so good.Next I fired up some reference tones, and was surprizes at how pure these sounded compared to the rest of them, of course they have some limitations on the bass end, no getting around the need to move air to get good low bass. Happy with it all I put in Top Gun cranked it up, 143's were very clean even at high volumes, any bass they might lack was covered by the rest of the speakers so I did no notice.At low volume they are just as clean, and unlike many small speakers there was no tinny sound in these, for my application these were perfect.With a nice sub, these would make a great set of surround speakers where space is an issue.

The Good:- Sound Quality, nothing else matters if this is not right and Sony nailed this.- Sound Fields and decoders, with great Front High Speaker Support HD-DCS Digital Cinima Sound (can't tell you how good this sounds)- Direct control of nearly everything, allowing good integration with Programmable Remotes like HarmonyThe Bad:- The Menu system -- very slow, no volume OS display- Odd exceptions to features, like PIP only working with two sources. Ironically anything can be plugged in to those two making it even stranger.- Auto-Set up getting speaker size wrong and no way to force it to auto-cal with the right size- How hot it runs when in stand-by/off. I use HDMI pass-through and that keeps some of it on all the time and it throws off a lot of heat.Overall: 4The Sony DA1800ES is a very solid AV receiver with great sound but the feature set is a little quirky, there is so much right in this receiver it is a shame that Sony appears to have rushed this to the market to get something in the high quality audio line up at a lower priceIn the end I care most about sound quality and the 1800ES lets you get at a high quality sound on a moderate budget. The ES amp is the star of this show and over-powers its shortcomings in the menu system. Most of the places it falls short are more or less superficial, but annoying none the less.Sound Quality: 5This is where Sony pulled no punches, this is their solid ES series sound, this sounds as good in 5.1 and a lot better in 7.1 than my 2400ES and way better than the Sony 1040. The 1800ES holds solid with a rich and full sound from very low volumes though rocking the house down. Toss in a great pre-amp with one of the widest selections of audio codec's in mid-range systems and the 1800 is a totally winner for sound quality. The highs are crisp, mid-range and voice crystal clear, and deep bass that I could not drive to muddy, and the surround blending is natural not imposed, feels closer to real.I went with 7.1 where the extra two speakers are Front Left and Right High, these are placed above the front main speakers to add height to surround, I thought it would be a gimmick but it is truly amazing. The sound optimizer does a very good job when listing to TV at low volume, usually these really flatten the sound, while flat-er it is not bad and still effective.Set-Up: 3Set-up was so-so, it got the speaker size wrong which is easy enough to fix but nailed distance to the inch. The bigger pain was one of the defaults, you pick from your speaker arrangement with the high speakers and he defaults another setting to where it does not work, forcing you back to the manual (more on this later. One really odd one is when you pick front high speaker arrangements, and another setting defaults to a mode where 7.1 does not work, back to the manual again... Pass-Though HDMI also did not default On and Set-up does not walk you through these, you need to go find them.Controls/Operation: 2I have had Sony receivers for over 20 years now and this just does not have the same attention to detail and flexibility usually found on Sony receivers. There are a lot of caveats to certain features, like PIP (picture in picture) only works if you have DVD or BD selected as the source?? (the PIP is also too small to really make it practical. Or when the On Screen Display works and does not work, that they can't figure out an overlay on a Blu-Ray HD movie so it kills the video when you need to change something. When you change volume you get no on-screen display, the manual is your friend with this unit, I don't usually need the manual much, but with this I did. Tip on the manual, get the PDF, makes life a lot easier.The good news is once you are using the receiver normally other than the lack of OSD for volume changes, you don't really interact with the menu's a lot.One highpoint in the controls is the Sony Tablet / Phone app for controlling the receiver, one of the better ones I have used, I have a Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 dedicated to our Home Theater system. Integration with remotes like Harmony or pro RS-232 systems is outstanding and sure beats using Sony's menu's.Features: 4This is almost a 5 but had to take a point off for the menu again, your path to the features. What a great balance, 3D, 5 Movie and 12 Music Sound fields, HD-Cinema (Front-High), Air-Play Wireless/Wired WAN, Streaming music and AirPlay. The DLNA is a little weak I think and of course music only, but gets the job done, 24p pass-through, HDMI pass-through in standby, 6 HDMI ports, 4K passthrough, and the list goes on, once you finally find them or get to them, the features make this a very flexible AVR.Our Home Theater Setting:25 x 20 Room (no special treatments) / Samsung 64F8500 Plasma TV / Sony STR-DA1800ES AVR / Panasonic BDT210 Blu-Ray / HP HTPC / Infinity Primus speakers 7.1Front L/R -- Front L/R High -- Front Center -- Surround L/R -- Subwoofer.

I just put in a home theater system and needed these to dress the cables (make them neat) and put them out of sight, these did the trick perfectly, I just stuck them where needed then ran black zip ties through them.I took it down 1 star for what royal pain the thin plastic that protects the sticky side are to remove, there is no cut corner or anything to get a purchase on it to pull it off. I finally found a trick, using a box cutter blade I would pierce just a tad with the razor at the corner and then "flip" it up quickly and that would lift it in a try or two. Would be nice if these came with black foam, the white makes them jump out so I used a black magic marker on the edges before sticking them onto something. (no points off but it would be nice)The foam tape on the back of these is wickedly sticky and hold a lot without peeling off, at the biggest point I these hold a bundle holding 6 HDMI, 2 RGB Component, 2 TOSLINK Optical, Coax Cable, and Sub-woofer cable spaced 6" apart on wood and they are holding great, and another with 8 power cords also routed mostly on wood and a few on metal.

OK the case is a tad on the marginal side but not bad for the price and unlike some of the good ones, it has all of the right cut outs for connections, speakers, and even the IR sender. It has just the right collection of USB and audio adaptors as well as a car charger and home charger.The individual parts would run well over 50 bucks and these seem reasonably solid enough, so far it all words great and the little bag is actually pretty handy for keeping it all together.Just what I needed.

These stick very well to wood and painted walls and amazingly come off with no damage when you need to remove one.I am using this to run speaker wire along the wall, being trandparent is really nice as they don't jump out at you and keep the wires looking neat where the option to totally hide them is not viable. For me this is from where the wires come out of the wall to the speaker itself.

I am using this under the 6 legs of a home entertainment stand that clocks in at about 240 pounds loaded up. I need to very occaisionally slide the stand away from the wall to change wires so did not want the legs welding themselves to the floor or scratching it when I needed to most the stand.These did the job and with the "carpet" like bottom if it goes over some bit of grit is does not scratch the floor like when those teflon/hard surface type do. I added a little scare of high strength double sided stick tape between the cup and bottom of the leg to prevent one or more from slipping out from under a leg.

Overall: OutstandingMy Application: From Comcast High Def Cable Box (Pace ENG-110) Component+TOSLINK to HDMI to the TV (Samsung PN64F8500)The Good: Does the job very well on both SD and HD channels and on HD passes 5.1 Surround perfectlyThe Bad: HDMI has to do a handshake on resolution changes , this results in 1-2 seconds of a black screen (this is the nature of HDMI not the box)The Annoying: Radically bright power LED on the box for a home theater application, small piece of electrical tape took care of that, no light now.What you need: This box + RGB Component cable with RCA connectors, TOSLINK Optical or Coax cable, and an HDMI Cable.Installation: Pretty simple, plug in your RGB + TOSLINK(Optical or Coax)cables to the box, then HDMI between the box and the TV, then Power from the included slim line wall wart to the box. I added a piece of electrical tape over the power light and that took care of the insanely bright level they used for this applicaion. The box feels solid, little brick, the connectors are nice and tight and nothing wiggles, appears to be very well built.Use: It has so far worked perfectly watching TV, since this box does not upscale to a common resolution, when resolution / screen format changes there is a 1-2 second delay for HDMI to renegotiate, this is a short blank screen. For me this happens always when going from SD to HD or the other way, I do not do this while flipping channels so not an issue, occaisionally HD channels will change resolution or screen format and blank for a second also, but that is rare. Also rare is being on one channel and have it change resolution between the show and the commercials, but it happens and like going from SD to HD, you will get a second of so of blank screen.If you can't live with this then you should consider a converter that also upscales, but get ready to drop about 200 bucks to get one that does that and not mess up the video overall. This is way better for picture quality unless you getr a top of the line unit, like from Gefen, I have tried cheap ones and they are just not worth it.If you must upscale do it through a good device like a mid to high end AV receiver.This introduces no blurs or lag, does not alter the color, brightness or any other video attribute. It also takes Digital Dolby 5.1 surround from the oiptical cable and puts it on the HDMI and does that perfectly also.All in all this is pretty good investment if you need to get component to HDMI, the max resolution is 1080i, which is also the max for component so no quality loss in any video mode.

If you are looking for as little reminder of those saturday mornings filled with cartoons, when as kids in the 50's we got control of the only TV in the house, well until about 10AM when we were thrown out of the house for the day, they used to call that going outside and play :)Besides the full season of episode cliff hangers there are the "and Friends", Improbable History with Mr. Peabody and his Boy Sherman, my personal favorite Fractured Fairy Tales, Aesop & Son, these break up the episodes of Rocky just as they used to, the only thing missing are the commercials for pure sugar breakfast cerial. (Illegal in all 50 states now :)I have this DVD in a second player and a number of other Sat morning cartoons and like to start a movie off with with a cartoon like the Drive-In, the kids love it but surprizingly so far nearly everyone we have done it with (adults) like the added touch to a home theater movie, add some Sugar Pops and Coco-PuffsRocky and Bullwinkle have two shows built into one, the political barbs and commentary in off-handed remarks is amazing all buried in there for the adults watching, the more you know the history of that era the more fun these are, and if not Rocky and Bullwinkle stand on their own at face value just fine.The good and the bad, on the great side is picture quality, they look great the video is fantastic, the audio is great also but it is modified from the original at times due to the original being to degraded to restore, frankly I had no idea, seemed like the original to me but I am not a pro on Sat morning cartoons from the 50's and the music is not different enough for the average bear to notice...All and all a great value, lots of fun.BTW -- If you are a prime member you can watch this on-line for free, I did that first.

I thoroughly enjoyed reading All American Favorites Recipe book! I love how the authors put a personal spin on every dish. And how I really looked forward to reading about the next one!Each recipe is thoroughly explained and versatility and creativity are both encouraged. You may love your fish tacos with ketchup and I might love them with mayonnaise. This recipe guide gives you the knowledge and encouragement to find your flavor. I really like that. I recommend you grab this recipe book and get creative today! Well Done!

I've never had one of these before, so I can't compare it to other mandolines, but it sure beats slicing thinly by hand or with a hand grater. So far I have used it for firm vegetables, potatoes, apples, cucumbers. I'm sure it will work with a firm cheese. It's easy to set the blade depth and very easy to clean and store. That said, it's not for everything. The hand guard is about 3inches in diameter, so if you wanted to slice a cucumber or zucchini long-ways, you would be able to use the guard sitting on top of the vegetable, so I think near the last slices when that vegetable is thin, it probably wouldn't work as well. But, improvising with some other type of hand protection might work... I think it will work great for 90% of what these are normally used for, so I am pleased with it and I could afford it.

The Paleo Epigenetic Diet Bible is an excellent source of quality expert information you can use to transform your body for life! Beran is a notified expert in the field of natural health and wellness and has proven once again you can only gain from reading her books!This guide takes to you start to finish through all the aspects you need to consider to lose weight and get healthy. From what macronutrients your body needs to shopping lists, meal plans and recipes, you get all of it with this guide.For me it was all the recipes that impressed-WOW! I recommend if you are looking to improve your health that you you grab this bible and start learning. Bravo!

Prepare!Publish!Promote! is a take action guide written in a step-by-step format to help quality books get noticed! If you want to make money on your books they MUST look professional. Gary is highly regarded in the book industry. And with his latest book he shows you everything from editing your masterpiece to formatting it, ISBN numbers, and even getting it up in both digital and paperback formats. The links splattered throughout this book are excellent for further information and practical examples. Seeing is believing for many people!As an author and book publisher I can assure you there's great useful information in here, something for everyone to learn. Information is knowledge and knowledge is power. Webb gives you the power to succeed in book publishing. The rest is up to you! I look forward to the next book!

Nutrition, Fitness, Diet & Lifestyle Hacks is a quality guide that will inspire you to want to get healthy. It's loaded with useful information to help you make better exercise, eating, and life decisions.As a health and wellness expert I can appreciate the messages showing you how to find your healthy. My thoughts are this guide is for people that have some knowledge of eating right and how to exercise to get results. If you are a beginner I'm afraid you may get overwhelmed with all the take action information inside.My recommendation is if you are ready to take your health and wellness to the next level I think you should buy this guide and get started. Good Stuff!

The Apple Watch is just the latest re-invention by Apple to make zillons of dollars and provide people with the latest techno gadget. Talk about a brilliant company. And this guide highlights all the features of the newest craze in electronics. The guide is well written with lots of exciting highlights that will get you pumped. Looks like Apple has taken the iPhone, which I love, and transformed it into a stylish watch. Definitely the fashion jewelry piece everyone wants. I enjoyed learning from this guide and you will too. Well Done!

This vegan spring roll recipe guide is a great introduction to a little Vietnamese cooking. I've always loved spring rolls but never thought I could make my own. With this guide I can and it's actually pretty easy. The author gives you simple instructions with ingredients that won't be hard to find at the market. I think you should try a few of these recipes out and let the author know what you loved. I would have liked to see the nutritional information included just to know exactly what im eating in a spring roll. But his doesn't take away from the quality of this recipe book. Im ready for the next one!

This sheet pan recipe guide really is neat. It introduces a little different method of cooking that I believe is just as easy and healthy as crockpot cooking. Although it may take a little time to get used to it!The author does a great job serving up interesting tasty sheet pan meals in an organized fashion. I like how the recipes are categorized in the table of contents. Makes it easy to find what you are looking for. Bottom line is I suggest you test these recipes out sheet pan style and see if it works for you. Yummy!

No bad ideas? I agree! How to be More Creative is a guide outlining factors to help you step outside the hardened box of reality and escape. This book is written in a knowledgeable and inviting manner. Just enough to help you see there is so much more to thinking when you take control.I enjoyed reading this take-action guide and believe you will too. Nicely Done!

The Prince and the Thief is a beautifully written story of a Princess born into privilege looking to escape that life and find herself. Ironically she ends up fleeing into the arms of the Nightcrawler, a thief similar to RobinHood, stealing from the rich, the Kingdom, without shedding blood.I love the way this story flows start to finish, smooth and thorough, with a strong plot and layered characters. Simple and powerful is how I'll describe it. My recommendation is you read this book and let the author know what you liked best. Bravo!

How to Get Rich After 50 is a well written guide opening your mind to different strategies to make money. The author talks a lot about residual income, which I think is ideal because not many people want to rely on working every day of their life for money! Not me anyway!With this guide the author opens your mind to a wealth of opportunity and I think you should read it and see where it leads. Nice job!

This is an excellent mindfulness guide to get you started understanding how to look closer within yourself through meditation. It's all about becoming more aware of the internal you for better health and the author does a nice job making his concept easy to understand. Step by step you are introduced to tactics and strategies to help you become more mindful.If you are looking to understand mindfulness and it's advantages for you I recommend you start with this guide. Bravo!

Add a little fun to your cooking with this low sugar cooking recipe guide with personality. The author writes with energy and makes this creative recipe guide fun to read. It's easy to follow, has oodles of creative recipes, and includes the nutritional information many books leave out. Crucial if you are serious about staying healthy and happy.My recommendation is you grab this guide, test out a few of the recipes, and let the author know just how much of a recipe junkie you are. Nice!

This stock trading guide gives you everything you need to know to understand what stocks are and how to trade them successfully, in theory anyway! Lol. It's a game of chance but the more you know the better.The author does a thorough job taking key points and making them easy to understand. Take action points that will help you make decisions to turn left, right, or floor it right through the stop sign! I recommend you read this guide if stocks is something you want as your next money making adventure.

Atkinson definitely knows his stuff!! It won't take you reading more than a few pages to figure that out! Talk about thorough! I'm also a health and fitness trainer and have nowhere near the knowledge about the details of building healthy muscle naturally that this book does. The attention to detail goes way beyond the call of duty.I love the fact the author makes this guide personable and Interesting to read. It's a take action guide that will get you results with a step by step action plan. So much to learn to help you reach you bodybuilding goals. I recommend this book if bodybuilding is your focus. Time for you to get building. Well Done!

Information is knowledge and knowledge is power. Cocaine is a serious disease and something that everyone should be aware of. Prevention is everything and this guide will show you how. I enjoyed reading this book. It delivers the basics in an engaging and informative way, leaving out the fluff many other guides have.My suggestion is you read this good and let the author know what you learned. Nicely Done!

This Holistic and Natural Depression Cure guide impressively delivers everything you need to know to prevent and battle depression. Love the down to earth way the author writes and how she uses her knowledge and experience to deliver take-action information. There's no fluff here!I recommend you read the book and let the author know what you gained!

Wow! If you are looking for diversity a plenty, this recipe guide is for you! It's loaded with vegan dishes that are sure to please. The author has done a great job making sure each recipe is easy to follow. They all have pictures and the fat and calories are included. Be careful though because some of the dishes are high fat.Bottom line is I'm impressed! I recommend you grab this recipe book and start cooking. Good Stuff!

The author had my attention up front dropping the f bomb! This story is written straight up so you can relate. If it needs to be said it will! I'm not about to retell the story for you but I will reflect on the "big picture" of this book. It's a little less subjective. What the author does is cleverly and expertly open your mind to new lifestyles and beliefs. Or maybe not "new" but rather less accepted. Judging is a serious problem in our world today that creates heartache and pain for many. The author reminds up that growing up is tough, figuring out your identity, especially when it does conform to traditional societal expectations is even tougher, heartbreaking in some cases.Maldon does such a great job levelling the playing field with great characters, descriptions and plot. You can't help but relate on some level and before you know it you are opening up and understanding and even cheering. Or maybe that's just me! Lol Wouldn't the world be such a better place if we were ALL supported in who we are? Gay or straight, black or white, it shouldn't matter, not ever. Before I get rambling on I better stop.Bottom line-READ THIS BOOK AND ENJOY! Well Done!

If you are looking for a murder mystery to keep you up at night, look no further! Berg does a great job capturing your attention start to finish and getting you all keyed up to go on a little vacation. I think what drew me in most was the laid back writing style. Having a powerful, beautiful, strong loving women didn't hurt either. A book you aren't going to predict with many twists and turns is exactly what you get.I love easy going with suspense and that's exactly what Berg delivers. If you are looking to step into fantasy land for a bit I recommend you do it with this book. Sweet!

The mind is a powerful thing and this philosophical book uncovers the wisdom of the great Rufus.Nothing in life is ever clear cut and neither are the historical teachings in this deep book. To me it's like taking in tongues and it does cause frustration, but when you actually "get it" its marvelous! Funny how the older a get the more interest I have in understanding how our great worldly philosopher's thought. It truly is incredible how accurate many of their visions were. If you are interested in some deep quality thinking this is the book for you.I recommend you read through this book and reflect, then let the author know what you think. Well done!

This isn't the usual kind of book I read but I was very glad I did. Miller is skilled in connecting with the audience, capturing undivided attention and most importantly keeping it real. To me that means everything in a book.His descriptions are so detailed they make you think you're right there. I love how the author plays with your mind right off the bat. Inside a young boys head that doesn't understand the reality of war and straight into what war really is. All sensationalism aside and heartache and pain sets in.Truly an incredible story I recommend you "get real" and read. Bravo!

This vegetarian soup recipe guide is well written start to finish. The author does a nice job describing first how the recipes are going to be laid out and then dives right in.Each recipe is creative and easy to follow and the pictures and nutritional information is hugely helpful. Having a convincing note on how you can eat vegetarian and still get all the essential nutrients to keep you healthy would have been great. Many people don't realize vegetarian eating isnt heathy unless you do it right!Bottom line is I recommend this recipe guide for your virtual recipe shelf. Nicely Done!

I started reading this autography, got partway through and had to go back again. I was wondering to myself if such theatrics written could really have truth. The more I read the more the author convinced me what I was reading was indeed fact. You see I don't see myself as a believer in mediums, reincarnation and all of that psychic stuff.This book helped open my mind to understanding and accepting or rather challenging my beliefs to make myself a more accepting and understanding person.I read this book start to finish and enjoyed every challenging moment of right from the beginning where Mary was born of three, with a s***-faced doctor on hand, and rejected by her own mother. I'm not giving anything else away on this one. I suggest you take an hour to read this incredible journey and reflect. Bravo!

I really loved reading this Minecraft school book. Maybe that's because I love the little whippersnapper Jeb? Lol I've read quite a few of these Minecraft books by Mayer and I can safely say this was up with the best of them. I think it's the calmness  and straightforward layout of this book that got me. Right off the bat the author CLEARLY states what's going on and breaks up the story with funny handwritten thoughts.This book will grab your attention and keep it as the author writes in an informational entertaining style. Always educating on all the nooks and crannies of the Minecraft game successfully. Gamer or no gamer I suggest you read this guide and reflect. The author does a great job!

This HTML guide is something I believe every writer needs to understand. All it's going to do is enhance your writing and make your reader want more! The author does a nice job keeping it simple and explaining what you need to know and leaving all the technical stuff by the wayside.Titles, descriptions and headings are critical in any online writing and this book shows you how to do it.I enjoyed learning from this guide and you will too!

This Diabetes guide delivers practical important information you need to be aware of in order to prevent and treat diabetes. The author points out every thing from symptoms and signals to take action approaches to get your diabetes under control. I don't have diabetes in my family but I have a few god friends that have lost family members to this relentless and often preventable disease. This guide gives you the information you need to make healthier choices in your life that will help prevent diabetes from taking a bite out of you and your loved ones.The first step is to understand what it is and what to do about it. This guide gives you ability to do this and more. Excellent!

This Italian Recipe Cookbook is a flavourful Paolo style guide to bring the funk back into your meals. He author does a great job putting personality into this guide along with tasty creative recipes. This isn't your everyday boring recipe guide that's for sure! If you are looking to add a whole whack of spice to your mealtimes this is the book for you.Always love reading crazy and talented Chef Paolo and invite you to do the same!

How to Dye Your Own Fabric is a solid well written guide that covers everything you need to understand about dying your fabric. The author takes her personal experience and backs it up with credible links to ensure the reader is getting all the correct information. She adds personality which makes the guide that much better in my opinion.I think you should grab this book and let the author know what you think. Good Stuff!

This Slow Cooker Heaven guide is loaded with creative and simple to follow crockpot recipes that will keep you excited to eat for years to come! The book dives right into the goods so you aren't wasting any time getting started. I do wish there were some photos but that doesn't take away from the great take action value of this book. You're even going to get he nutritional information which is excellent. I'm not kidding you, there's a recipe for every day of the year! lolMy advice is you crap the recipe book and start slow cooking today!

The Original Thai Paleo Diet is an excellent informational guide to get you started eating right to lose weight the healthy way. Bravo!

This teaching English in Spain guide is an excellent overview to help you understand just how easy it is to do. Help! I'm in Love with a Narcissist is an entertaining and informative guide to help you spot and understand better a person with this disorder.Ha! Ask them if they think they're a narcissist? LolThis guide is written in a light and inviting tone which leaves you wanting to learn more. It just makes sense.I really enjoyed gaining from this guide and you will to. Read it and see for yourself! Nice job!

Really loved reading this! It starts off with positive energy and a sweet little trips the kids went on with miniature horses. The reading level is about grade 4 - short enough to keep my kids attention and leave them wanting more!Really loved the interactive quiz at the end. My kids were really excited for that.Great educational guide that will tap into your child's imagination. Well done!

The Introverts Advantage is a light hearted inviting guide discussing all the ins and outs of being an introvert. Of course extroverts are covered too but they aren't the main attraction.The author does a great job delivering useful information that makes sense in a practical manner. So many people seem to judge Introverts negatively when in fact I see plenty of advantages.Bottom line is you'll enjoy learning from this book and that's what it's all about!

Reiki and Reiki Meditation is an excellent guide that delivers everything you need to know about Reiki to get started. What I love most is the fact the author personalizes this guide by sharing her story. It's touching and makes the messages more real in this book.Something in here for everyone to learn. Good Stuff!

This Paleo Bundle is an impressive 2 book series by well know recipe writer Patrick Smith. It's loaded with creative and easy to follow recipes as usual. So many you are going to have a tough time figuring out which to try first!Do you want to bake or cook?What I like most is the author's ability to someone sneak personality into all his books. Makes them exciting and informational to read.Well done Smith!

I have read so many Paleo books my brain is going to explode! What's great about this guide is you get the personal. The author uses this successful eating strategy to lose weight and tasty recipes to help motivate you to reach your weight loss goals.This book is sensible and not written with an iron fist! It's all about understanding healthy eating and making better food choices for you!Grab it. Read it. And let the author know what you loved!

This E-Books guide gives you info on publishing your book through an author's personal experience. I admire that. As an author of 60 books I can say if you are new to online publishing this guide will help get you started. Although I don't agree with all the tactics suggested, there are lots of helpful hints and tricks to help you make a name for yourself in e-book publishing!It's all about money and marketing-but that comes after you've published your book!I enjoyed reading this guide and think you should read through it before you start writing your books. Good Stuff!

Sleep Well is a lighthearted informational guide that gives you all the tools you need to identify sleep issues, understand sleep, and make sure you get adequate QUALITY sleep.I really enjoyed the way the author writes and feel this is one of those books everyone can gain from reading. Sleep is just so important in good health. My recommendation is you grab this book and let the author know what you learned. Well Done!

Or wherever you choose to get up close and personal with your partner.The author does a nice job staying focused and informational. Something in here for everyone to learn. Erotica is a wild and steamy sex sensation story that gets heated real fast. Roxy is one crazy gal that's for sure.So if you are looking to sweat a little I think this book will do the trick!

This Zen guide is chalk full of interesting take action information to help you transition into zen and use it positively in your life. The guide is well written and would be even stronger if there was sourcing to back up the authors thoughts. However this is a starting point and there's still plenty of practical useful information for you to learn and grow from.Personally I really enjoyed reading some of the details of this calming meditation or power of the mind practice.I think you should grab this book and get your zen on!

I'm a bit of a candle freak. Use them to make my house smell nice and was very interested to read this guide and learn more! I found myself chuckling away a little because the author talks about melting crayons down to make candles and my kids actually did that once - really cool!Lots for you to learn in this introductory guide. Grab it and let the author know what you learned!

This Yoga for Beginners guide is a practical take action book that explains what yoga is, the benefits, and simple poses to get you started. It flows nicely start to finish and I really enjoyed reading it.Some sourcing would have been nice but not essential for this beginner guide. If you are looking to get de-stressed and healthier, this yoga guide is a great place to start!

Sewing for Beginners is an introductory guide that takes you step by step through the sewing process. The author does a nice job keeping the explanations short and sweet and the diagrams are very helpful. Seeing is believing!If you are looking to get started learning simple sewing technique basics I suggest you grab this guide and get started.
