Then let the author know what you liked best about this self help guide. Good Stuff!

If you are interested in eating vegan, this guide is for you! It talks about why this healthy eating style came about. It also includes a step by step approach to test it out. From recipes to shopping lists it's all here.The author did a great job providing useful practical information that will help you eat vegan healthy to you choose. I recommend you grab this guide and let the author know your thoughts ~ Well Done!

Ketogenic Diet is a quality guide that takes you through the Ketogenic diet concept from beginning till now! The author does a nice job overviewing the benefits and disadvantages of this eating strategy.The sourcing throughout adds nice credibility and this only makes the information in this guide more valid. If that makes sense!Lots for you to learn from this guide about the Ketogenic diet. My recommendation is to grab this book and let the author know what you think!

This Labyrinthitis and Vestibular Neuritis is a great informational guide to help you understand and deal with these conditions. The author does a nice job making sure you first understand all the different conditions associated, and then explains possible symptoms, prevention, and treatment options. The exercises are what I really liked. Take action non-invasive pointers that help!Great guide I think you should read and reflect on!

I enjoyed reading this personal guide of the author's journey to recognizing and taking control of her eating. A motivational book that will hopefully inspire you to do whatever it takes to gain control of the food you eat, create a happy relationship with food, and find your healthy weight and stay there. We all know it's staying there that's most difficult!The author has lots of neat tips for you and my recommendation is you grab this book and reflect!

This erotica book gets straight to the point. There are some grammatical short sites but the storyline is clear and detailed enough to fit this short read.If you are looking to read out your fantasies this book will do it! It's descriptive and written to get you heated. Grab it and let the author know what you liked best!

Gardening for Dummies is a great practical little guide with take action pointers to grow flowers and veggies successfully. The author hammers home the fact that raised garden beds have lots of great advantages.Bottom line is there are lots of great tips in this guide to help you get successful with your garden. I recommend you download this guide and let the author know what you liked! Good Stuff!

This Stress and Panic Attacks guide is a great start to identifying and understanding what is healthy and what isn't. I particularly like the small part on phobias. For some reason that always fascinated me!In here you'll learn about symptoms and prevention and how to take positive action against anxiety and stress. Particularly when it interferes with living a healthy life! Good stuff!

This Candida Diet guide simplifies this nasty infection in an attempt to deliver practical useful information instead of overloading you with technical jargon. I like the fact the author is up front with this. So if you are already familiar with the basics this book may be too basic for you.Other than a few minor formatting issues this book flows start to finish, brief and to the point. I like how the author focuses on 'natural' preventative measures with food, talks about the floods to eat and stay away from, and follows up with a few good recipes to try. I was disappointed in the symptoms chapter a little. I feel more description is needed to help the reader recognize and relate. It does cover enough to get you started though!This is the first health and wellness guide I've reviewed by this author and with almost 2000 reviews under my belt I will say if you are looking to start taking control of your health and learn the basics of the Candida yeast infection with better eating tips for prevention, this is the guide to start with!Looking forward to reading more!

This 3D Printing guide is exactly what you need to get started understanding the importance of this technology. The author takes a rather complex process and breaks it down so you can understand it and take full advantage.It really is tough trying to keep up in this world! LolLots for you to learn in this guide and I recommend you read it and let the author know your thoughts!

How to Knit is a quality take action guide to help you learn the basics of knitting and beyond! I like the fact the author digs into the past first help you understand where knitting originated.The book is smooth start to finish with a simple step by step approach to get you knitting and know what you're doing! Lol I recommend you buy this book and let the author know what you gained!

Cats is a practical guide that gives you quality information to consider when raising your fluff ball. My daughter just got a cat so this book will be useful for her.The author writes in a personable tone with lots of good tips and tricks scattered throughout to help you raise your cat healthy and happy for the long run. I do feel some sourcing would have added more credibility to this book. However there's definitely lots for you to gain buying this book. Good Stuff!

This Gluten Free Life guide is a practical book that first talks a little about what gluten is and then jumps into delicious recipes for you to test out. The author writes in smooth informational tone stat to finish. I do wish there was some sourcing to add credibility.The recipes are creative and easy to follow. For me the nutritional information would have been a nice touch but not essential.Lots to learn in the introductory book and I recommend you buy it and let the author know what you liked best!

The Project Management guide is extremely well done! Chalk full of practical tools to help you organize and succeed in starting and finishing projects. The author does a Great job taking you step by step through the different stages that are manageable in length. Think of them as bite sized pieces!From prep to completion this guide covers it all!There is just so much to learn in this guide. Grab it and let the author know your thoughts. Well Done!

This Stress Relief Wisdom guide is going to make you think! What caught my attention was the author trying to open my mind to see more that what's right in front of me. Weirdly it makes sense. As a child I played many sports. Two of which were hockey and figure skating. When I slipped into my figure skates it wasn't about skating, like a hockey player might see it. For me it was an expression. Art and dancing across the ice. Some of which I took back onto the ice when I played hockey. And if you were just watching with no experience playing hockey it would just like like some rough and tough bumping, shooting a puck around and skating.I know I'm rambling but I'd like you to know is through well explained strategy the author shows you how to "see" and create your stress-free living. The power of the mind is a wonderful thing!I recommend you read this guide and de-stress! Great Job!

This 7 Key Ways to Become a Trusted Advisor book has lots of important take-action points that will help boost confidence and gain the respect you deserve.Micromanaging-A sign of distrust...so true!There are some formatting and syntax issues that steal a little from the flow of this guide. But I still recommend it because there is so much practical information throughout. Something in here for everyone to gain. I think you should read it and let the author know what you think. Good Job!

The 7 Secrets to Total Abundance is an interesting and very informative guide to help you capture complete health. The author does a nice job discussing 7 different factors toward good health and wellness. A positive spin with take action information.Lots to learn and I recommend you read this book and let the author know what you gained!

This Square Dance Saga book is a really entertaining read. The author teaches you all about square dancing through a sweet story.I remember doing a little bit of square dancing way back in school and was happy to remember some of it reading through this book.The book is light, inviting, and informational. Just really enjoyed it!

I really enjoyed reading this Japanese dating guide. The author makes it really comfortable by explaining his perspective through personal experience. He covers everything from the language barrier to different aspects of the Japanese culture that may make it easier or harder for you as a foreigner. But definitely not impossible.If you are looking to learn a little more about this dating scene I think you should start with this guide. Well Done!

I think I enjoyed reading this story to my kids and they did hearing. Perhaps it touched a soft spot because I also had a rabbit growing up! The author writes in an engaging manner from the perspective of a rabbit. Love that concept.This story will be relatable for just about everyone because it takes place in everyday life.Love all the family characters, even Dumb and Dumber, the dogs- lolBottom line is I recommend his book to you for plenty of smiles and laughs. Good Stuff!

This Domination and Submission Romance book is the first of its kind that I've read. I will say it was a pleasure! The author definitely grabs you by the collar with the first scene and it only goes way up from there.The storyline carries through start to finish. The book is naturally magnetic and I guaranteed you'll get heated.If you are looking for an erotic escape this book is it! Well done!

How to Stop Snoring is a quality guide that opens your mind the reasons you may be snoring. I can tell you firsthand snoring can ruin a relationship. My xboyfriend is overweight and suffers from severe sleep apnea. Uses a cpap machine and his snoring still made it impossible for anyone around to sleep. Sad but true.The author does. Nice job with this guide and I think you'll enjoy it too!

AMAZON Prime has great benefits for the buyer and the author discusses these throughout this guide. I like the fact they have been with AMAZON for quite some time. Gives me confidence they know what they are taking about! LolThere's plenty of great information for you to learn. And for me just be sure of the fine print before signing on. For instance if you are in Canada most of the "prime advantages" do not apply!Enjoyed reading this guide and learning and you will too!

The Full Cup of Murder is a light murder mystery. I say "light" because it's also humorous. The main character Allison or Ali is cute and funny, she draws you in with her nonchalant attitude and makes you want to learn more. I like how the author sets scene and jumps right in. Raised by her hardworking father, her mother died when Ali was 6, Ali spend most of her childhood helping her father in the bar, kinda like her home I guess.It's fitting that just a few pages in Jones smacks you in the face with a murder in the bar washroom, which initially looks like a chap that's had one too many.Not the case...poor Ray.From there the author continues to dip and dive you through a mish-mash of events after the unlikely murder in this sleep small town. So small there's only one other bar around. Of course there's panic and paranoia, as the author slowly starts unraveling the story bit by bit with a few unlikely twists and well thought out turns.I won't tell you the ending because I write reviews to intrigue you to read the book, not tell you the story! lol That's the author's job.I enjoyed reading this book and recommend it to you. Well Done!

There are some reviews here that make the claim that these are just as soft and comfortable as the OEM earpads.  This is not quite true.  I had made the purchase based on those reviews, but after trying them on, I've found that the foam is a bit denser and less well-padded.  So lets be honest: they're not quite the same as the OEM earpads.That said, I do not regret this purchase one bit.  While these Bluecell pads are not quite as good as the Bose replacements, they are 95% as good and the leading paragraph is me being particularly picky.  Installation was straightforward with no tools needed, and function is all there.  So for about 1/3 the price of the OEM pads, it's a no brainer.  Just buy these and skip over the overpriced Bose pads.  They're not quite as good, but they're perfectly good for the price.

I had put off buying a proper springbar tool for a long time, trying to make due with the cheap/free springbar tools such as the one I had from one of those 18 piece watch repair kits that you can buy for $6.  Those were rather frustrating times, especially because those tools often couldn't fit into solid endlinks to change bracelets.After trying the 6767, I immediately noticed the difference.  The tool feels very solid in hand as it should for a tool that costs about $25.  It is substantial in hand and feels like a real quality piece.  Then I tested the function.  The FINE fork fit into the gap in the end links of my Omega Speedmaster Pro bracelet and worked perfectly.  There was no hesitation, no squirming around to try to fit in forks that were too big, and I had the bracelet off in seconds.  The pusher on the other end also worked perfectly to adjust micro-adjust in the clasp.  I will never go back to a lesser tool and expect the Bergeon to last a lifetime based on the build quality.  Also, if I accidentally snap the fork, replacements are available for about $3.If you change straps somewhat often and don't currently use a proper tool (I'm looking at those guys who cut a notch in a fine screwdriver), just put down the money and buy one of these tools.  It'll make your life so much better.

If you own a dangler (Munroe, Tek, Gear-pull, pickpocket, etc), you should definitely own some of these Micro-Lock S Biners.  The lock definitely works; haven't had the S-biner come open in my pocket yet.  (Knock on wood.)  If you have fat fingers or particularly long nails, you might have a hard time unlocking the pivoting plastic lock, but I haven't had any issues with it.Right now, I'm using a micro S-biner to attach a Rexford RUT multitool to a Munroe DTS dangler.  And I also have a Peak Eiger Hi CRI flashlight and Victorinox Alox Cadet attached by 2 of these S-biners to a Munroe Mega dangler.  So yes, if you're into Every Day Carry, this is a great alternative to the harder-to-find McGizmo clips.  They're quite a bit larger than the McGizmo 20mm clips, but at the same time, still very reasonably sized for a keychain or dangler.

Shin Ryoku is easily my favorite green ink, and my favorite iroshizuku ink.  It's just dark enough to be taken seriously, but has that vibrant pop of color that makes your class notes or a handwritten letter stand out on the page.  The flow characteristics are awesome.  I have my TWSBI 580 (fine) dedicated to just this ink, and it writes fantastically--never skipping, never drying out even after taking numerous pages of notes.  Even though the TWSBI has a steel nib, this ink makes the pen write like a much more expensive pen; the flow really is just that good.  If you've been looking for a bottle of Mont Blanc British Racing Green, save your money.  This Japanese ink will probably make you even happier.

First things first, the wrist rest is soft, supportive, comfortable, and stays in place on your desk.  The faux leather looks nice, is relatively durable, and is easy to clean.  Those are the positives.However, one thing well worth pointing out is that the material is not breathable, and it may cause your hands/wrists to get hot and sweat.  I don't even have sweaty hands--no problems with shaking hands, and I barely use chalk when I rock-climb.  But sitting in a room at about 75 degrees, I find my palms getting moist and sticky against this wrist rest.  Sounds uncomfortable?  Believe me, it is.I had originally been using the plastic wrist rest built into the Logitech G710+ keyboard.  It wasn't particularly comfortable, and at first, I found this 3M product to be a huge upgrade in terms of comfort and support.  But after about 20 minutes of use, I saw the benefits of plastic over gel--I never sweat on the plastic.  And if you're at a computer for hours at a time, that's important.So if you were wondering why this product had to be antimicrobial, now you know.

Das Keyboard 4 presents a number of notable improvements over the last version, that easily make this keyboard well worth the $30 premium ($169 MSRP vs $139 MSRP).  In descending order of importance, these improvements are as follows:1. Dedicated media keys - This is by far the biggest upgrade because most people use media and volume keys frequently, and using an "Fn" key just didn't cut it on the old model.  The volume knob is attractive, proud, and has a tactile clicky turn to it, which feels better than the free-spinning volume wheel on the Logitech G710+ keyboard.2. USB 3.0 hubs moved to top right edge of keyboard - Now you can plug in your mouse or USB headset, or charge your phone, without the cable getting in your way; this is a very welcome improvement.  The speed of USB 3.0 is also great when you need to transfer large files--but more than that, the placement of the ports is a huge plus.3. Aluminum top panel- They have replaced the glossy plastic top panel, which attracted fingerprints, with a very sleek aluminum panel that gives the keyboard a high-end feel.  Now, this keyboard looks very premium, even to the non-techie passing by your desk.4. Thinner- Due in part to the aluminum, they managed to make this keyboard thinner without losing any of that well-built feel.5. Sleep Hotkey- Not sure how many people put their computer to sleep; I usually just lock it with Windows + L when I walk away, and let it hibernate automatically if I don't come back in time.  But I guess Das Keyboard is doing its part to help save the Earth.6. Magnetic footbar- Not as huge of a bonus as they claim, and quite doubtful that you'll ever actually take this off to use this as a ruler...it just isn't that practical.  But the option is there if it's an emergency.With these new features (primarily media keys and aluminum top panel), the Das Keyboard 4 has jumped to the top of the leaderboard for off-the-shelf mechanical keyboards.  For those uninitiated, mechanical keyboards really are that much better than membrane keyboards.  Believe the hype.  Your word-per-minute speed actually will increase with mechanical keyboards, and your keyboard enjoyment will likely be that much higher too.  The price is admittedly a bit high; but given that we interact with our computers through only two primary inputs (our mouse and keyboard), it is likely worth the price if you spend a lot of time in front of a computer.  With this model, you have four options:Professional MX Blue (traditional/clicky)Professional MX Brown (traditional/quiet)Ultimate MX Blue (blank/clicky)Ultimate MX Brown (blank/quiet)The "ultimate" version with all blank key caps is certainly less-practical than the "professional" version which has marked keys.  However, the coolness factor of the "ultimate" is simply unparalleled.  It is possibly the best-looking off-the-shelf mechanical keyboard available on the market.  This version utilizes the "clicky" Cherry MX Blue switches which are fantastic.  If you need something a bit more quiet, the version with MX Browns is also a good choice, with nearly as much tactility--but at the same time, nearly as much noise for those who are not acclimated to mechanical keyboards.The Ultimate Clicky is really targeted at typists who crave that particular typing experience.  In a professional setting, the "professional" model is likely more utilitarian because you can find keys like "delete," "F7", and "print screen" when you actually need them.  And the browns are probably better for most people because the blues are quite loud...I can hear them over Bose QC20s at moderate listening volumes.  The keyboard also lacks fancy features like macros and backlighting--which are certainly niceties in themselves (especially if you are a gamer), and are available in many competitor's keyboards in this price range.  But if you want to type quickly and accurately, and look like BOSS doing it, the Das Keyboard 4 Ultimate Clicky is the keyboard you have been waiting for.  It was certainly the one I had been waiting for.

When I got my nail clipper, I thought it was defective because it couldn't clip my nails.  And I realized it was because the clipper wasn't engaging all the way closed.  It'd go 3/4 of the way closed, without fully completing the clipping motion.  I thought I had gotten a dud, but after a bit of experimentation, I realized that I needed to go through an extra not-so-obvious motion of pulling back and pushing forward to properly engage the lever-arm of the nail clipper to allow it to fully engage.  It was not defective...just a bit less intuitively designed than expected.I am a male and had planned to carry this in my wallet.  However, if you have a nice leather wallet, I would NOT recommend carrying this in the wallet (unless perhaps you have a coin pouch in it) because it will wear through the leather.  So without a keychain attachment on the leather carrying slip or on the nail clipper itself, it has found itself relegated to my desk.  And in that case, there are many better nail clippers for the money.  I highly recommend the Seki Edge for less money, and less trouble.

The TWSBI pen shipped very quickly from TWSBI and was a pleasure to un-package: an external cardboard box with their logo opened up to an elegant clear plastic display that housed the pen.  It was impressive for a $55 pen.As for writing performance, the Fine nib writes well.  It isn't as smooth as some have claimed--but one cannot expect a steel nib to be quite as smooth as a gold nib.  Then again, I do enjoy the little bit of feedback that I get from the nib.  The piston filler holds a ton of ink, and the ink looks awesome twirling around in the pen body.  The build quality of the pen itself is consummate with the price of the pen, if not better.  In particular, the red TWSBI detail accent on the top of the cap is very high quality.However, my biggest gripe with this pen is that it was actually intended to be written with uncapped.  While it is possible to "post" the cap, it throws off the balance of the pen.  Also, the cap attaches to the twisting portion that manipulates the piston.  So you can imagine the danger if you attach or detach your cap carelessly and end up with ink all over your pants.  So I don't even bother capping this pen any more.  If you're prone to losing pen caps, this might not be the pen for you.But otherwise, for a very attractive, and well-performing, high-value fountain pen, this is probably one of the best choices on the market.  The closest competitor for the money to consider would probably be the Lamy Al Star.

I very much prefer to write with unlined notepads and this is the perfect size for short notes--consider it the Goldilocks size.  If you do need to write with lines, the paper is thin enough that you can put a sheet of guide-lines underneath to follow.  So really, blank paper is probably the best of all worlds--unconstrained but with that flexibility to accept structure.The paper works fantastically with fountain pens.  Nibs just glide along it, so if you like a bit of feedback, this probably isn't your paper.  But there is minimal bleed through and almost no feathering.  And this is in spite of the thinness of the paper.  It definitely doesn't feel like heavy-duty quality stationary, so it's not the most impressive paper if you're handing a note to someone written on it.  The thickness is similar to that of plain copy paper.  And really, that's my only gripe with it.  If it had heavier paper, (ex. 80 lb), I would probably enjoy it even more.  Then again, if it were thicker, you might not be able to use it with guide-lines underneath; so that might be an intended design compromise.

The Blue-Green Al Star is the limited edition color for 2014.  If  you were considering this pen, here are the top five things I think you should know:1. The Blue-Green color is much more green in person than the Tiffany blue that appears in the pictures.  It is nevertheless, very attractive, and has a metallic sheen underneath.2. I prefer 0.7 Gel Rollerballs, and the Lamy Fine point is a good approximation.  It writes like a steel nib (because it is a steel nib), but is adequately smooth.3. The grip section is triangular, so if you prefer round grip sections, this may feel a bit uncomfortable.4. Like the rest of the Al Star line, this pen's body is made of aluminum, which makes it feel like a quality everyday carry pen.  The clip also works well for that purpose, and clips nicely to any pocket.5. You will need to buy a converter if you want to use this pen with bottled inks.  The Lamy Z24 converter ($5-$6 depending on where you go) is the recommended converter, although it also works with the Z26.Hope that helps.  I personally think this is one of the most attractive limited-edition Al Stars ever released, and while you may be able to get it a few bucks cheaper at a few places, Amazon Prime shipping makes this a winner.

There's a reason the Lamy 2000 is on permanent display at the Museum of Modern Art.  It's a beautiful pen.  The design is over 40 years old and will likely remain a timeless design for decades to come.  From the moment you un-box the pen and hold it in your hand, you can tell that it is a fine writing instrument.  It fills the hand perfectly, has great balance wit the cap posted, and is just the perfect weight.The real reason I bought this pen, despite wanting the fountain pen was convenience.  If you want the Lamy 2000, but don't have a collection of bottled inks (as the FP does not take cartridge refills), the rollerball is the way to go.  You get the same great bauhaus lines as the fountain pen, but with all the convenience of regular rollerball and gel refills.It takes the Lamy M63 refill by default, but can also take many similar-sized refills if you use a spacer.  My preference for a good balance price and function is the Pilot G2 Blue 0.7.  But you've got a lot of options.This is certainly one of my favorite rollerball pens--and is probably the best option in a +/- $25 price range.

From the moment you pick up the fiberglass body, it's clear that this is a nice pencil.  The body has almost a synthetic woodgrain feel to it--like an air-dried piece of ebony and feels quite classy--while very different from the lacquer you'd typically see on other high end writing instruments. But then you try to advance the lead.  There is a tiny bit of slop in the movement--about one mm between starting to click and the actual engagement point where lead is advanced--so that's a bit unfortunate.  In fact, the clicking action is not the most pleasant.  Perhaps the pencil needs a longer break-in period, but the click is actually a bit scratchy (audibly so)--and the reason the travel-slop in the knock mechanism is made more evident because there is a very clear "break" for the actuation of the lead advancement mechanism.  So instead of feeling like a smooth paved highway, clicking the mechanism on this pencil feels more like grinding along a gravel road with a speed bump in the middle.  That's a bit dramatized, but gives you an idea of what the action feels like.Another iconic German pencil in the price range is the rOtring 800.  I like both.  The Lamy 2000 is lighter (easier to write with for an extended period of time), fills the hand better, and seems to have better balance.  The rOtring 800 feels more solid and durable, has a retracting tip which is both fun and practical, but feels slightly more difficult to write with for extended periods of time due to the heavier weight and slimmer body.  It's difficult to choose between the two, especially since both have minor flaws.  But if you like pencils, I think you'll learn to enjoy both of them.

This is by far my favorite pen holder.  I have it horizontally on my desk, with seven comfortably spaced pens neatly displayed in it.  It's certainly more elegant than a traditional pen cup--and much more so than having random pens strewn across your desktop.  The blue rubber fingers look very neat inside of the bamboo exterior and the block is a great conversation piece.I also own the Big Idea Design "PHX Organizer" ($70 retail) which is very similar in concept.  This item is superior in every way.  The quirky allows both horizontal and vertical placement.  The fingers are packed much more densely and hold the pens more vertical.  And subjectively, even though the PHX Organizer is a heavy block of aluminum that looks super sleek against a Mac setup on a clean modern desk, I think the Quirky block looks even nicer--and more unique.  Oh, and it's significantly cheaper than the PHX too.

At about $2 each, they are expensive.  But if you haven't tried a Palomino already, they're worth a try--and IMO, the Pearl is the best of the series.The Blackwing line In order from lightest to darkest is: 602, Pearl, Traditional.  And I've found that the Pearl is the best compromise.  It's the perfect mix of tip strength and dark lines.  If you've read the hype, you might have heard that you get darker lines with less pressure with Blackwing pencils.  Indeed, versus a regular $0.20 HB pencil, the writing experience is a night and day difference.  You can write faster and with much less effort--almost as if you were using a rollerball pen.  Is it worth 10x the price?  Probably not.  But if you've read this far, you're probably the kind of person who could appreciate the improvement in quality--irrespective of price.I replaced the erasers with Palomino's green replacements, which I think look great against the gold and white.  But the stock black ones look sleek too.  Unfortunately, neither is very good at actually erasing--you should get a dedicated eraser for that.  But the flat shape keeps the pencil from rolling (more-important than you'd expect) and also gives it that characteristic look that is always a conversation starter--especially in today's high-tech world.  (What's a pencil, anyway?)

This sharpener is identical to the Automatic Long Point sharpener manufactured by KUM.  I bought this specific model for its color and because it had Palomino on the side.  If you're spending $2/pencil for Palomino Blackwings, you might as well get the sharpener you really want even if it does cost a bit more.It does work fantastically and produces a very sharp and long tip.  This is similar to most electric sharpeners--but is a rare feature for manual sharpeners.  I only wish there was a way it could sharpen the wood and the lead in one shot rather in two stages.It also comes with two extra blades.  (If you can't find them, don't worry, you didn't accidentally throw them out with the box; they're stored in the body of the sharpener.)If you need a portable pencil sharpener, there are smaller ones, there are cheaper ones--but this is the best.

First the good: very cool orange cover, waterproof, dot-grid ruled.  Those are the key differentiators that set this special edition apart from the standard garden variety Field Notes.However, for me, this couldn't make it into the everyday carry because I never EDC a pencil--but rather a pen.  And my EDC pens, almost without fail, use gel or rollerball inks, because I prefer the way they flow and write.  That said, even my Fisher Space Pen cartridges would smear if I didn't leave enough time for the ink to dry on the page.And for that reason, the Pitch Black edition is probably the way to go if you are looking for a special cover and dot-grid ruling: you can write on it with any type of pen you may be carrying.  The Expedition edition is just for the person who REALLY needs that waterproofness in their notebook.

These are my second-favorite current-production Field Notes variety.  (My favorite is the standard Kraft Graph.)  The grey text on black cover looks even better in person than it does in pictures, and the dot grid is a great compromise between the somewhat more delineated graph rulings and a blank page.  So you get the structure to help line up your writing without all of the background clutter.I've been a long-time fan of the Rhodia dot-grid pattern, and finally, it comes to Field Notes without being on the plasticky pages of the Expedition edition.

As a male who likes to consider himself rather masculine, I can say that this is a great lip balm.  It smells nice, tastes good, keeps my lips permanently kissable, and doesn't go on like I'm applying lipstick--no dude wants to look like he is putting on lipstick.  This EOS lip balm was clearly designed for the purse, as it does not fit into trouser pockets particularly well, but the cool sphere looks great on a desk top.  Sure, unscrewing a pink egg and rubbing it on my lips raises some eyebrows at the office, but that just makes it a conversation piece...and makes me the coolest guy for a ten cubicle radius.From a non-statistical survey of beautiful women who used EOS lip balms, Strawberry Sorbet has been, by far, the favorite flavor.  (Honeydew and Sweet Mint were close seconds.)  Sure, the price per unit is a bit steeper than with the 5-pack at Costco, but this is the perfect place to get a three pack of the best flavor--and none of the undesirable ones.So manly men, and beautiful women, we have found the lip balm to end all lip balms.

Who needs a mousepad nowadays?  But if you're into handguns, this makes for a very cool conversation piece by your computer.  The texture isn't quite as technical as the SteelSeries QcK mousepads, but it works and the rubber bottom stops it from slipping.  And the huge surface means that you have a lot of room to work with for your mouse.Yes, it works great as a handgun cleaning mat too.  The surface helps to keep parts from moving around and helps to keep oils and grease off your tables.  It also rolls up nicely for storage.

I only wish I had discovered the Braun Series 7 earlier.  I had been using Gillette manual razors ever since I started shaving--Mach III, Fusion Proglide, etc.  They worked fantastically-well: simplicity combined with a close shave.  However, once I started to need to shave every day (guess those unkempt college days are over), I found myself loathing the 5+ minute routine every morning of lathering my face with shaving cream, washing the manual razor cartridge under the water every few strokes, and cleaning my face again thoroughly after shaving to avoid any residue shaving cream.  And that led me to the Braun Series 7.I can now complete the daily shave-routine in under 3 minutes.  That may not seem like much of a difference, but believe me, when you're trying to get out the door to catch public transportation into downtown in the morning, those few minutes help--any fan of the snooze button can certainly attest to that.  And sure, the shave isn't as close as the manual razor, but it's 80-90% as close and definitely gets the job done.  There's also no thinking about accidentally cutting yourself like you might with a manual razor.  For the ultimate time-saver, this razor even cleans itself.Love this gadget, and would recommend it to anyone.

I love this calculator.  I upgraded from the BAII Plus (non-professional).  Performance wise, they are roughly the same.  I have not noticed any speed increases in doing typical NPV or IRR calculations.  You get a few new features with the Professional version, but you will probably never use them.  Shallow positives include better tactility on the buttons and a more attractive calculator.  (The BAII Plus looks like something you might use in middle school algebra; the Professional version looks like something you might find on a hedge fund manager's desk.)But this calculator has huge benefits for the Chartered Financial Analyst exams if you plan to take them.1) Easily replaceable battery, no screwdriver needed.  You can rest easy if your calculator dies during the exam.2) Schweser Notes is based on the TI calculator keystrokes (good luck if you're trying with an HP).3) If you're upgrading from a BAII Plus, you can bring both calculators into the exam so you have a spare.  (Another fallback in case your battery dies AND you accidentally swallow your spare battery.)For those reasons alone, if you don't already own this calculator, and are looking to take the CFA, spend the $45 and just buy it.  It's the best financial calculator on the market to date.

I got this case for my Canon S95.  And it works fantastically.  It is a bit chunky, but works well if you're doing the tourist thing and aren't ashamed to have a camera on your belt.  Also, with the case, you can just throw it in your luggage and know that it is protected.  My only qualm is that the velcro closure would often catch on the OEM fabric lanyard that came with the S95 and eventually shredded it as if a dog had been chewing on the material.  So you'll want to upgrade to a leather lanyard or some other material for your wrist strap if you plan to use this case.

I use a Zoo Goo social iPhone5 case.  My OEM Apple lightning charger fits perfectly through the case.  But this Amazon charger does not because for some unknown reason, they decided to make the black plastic around the charging pin wider than on the OEM charger.  So now, I need to slip off half of my case before charging.  It is quite an annoyance just to save $2 over an original Apple cable.  So if your phone case has a narrow opening for the charger; AVOID this Amazon one.  It's not worth the headache.That said, this one hopefully will not break on me as quickly as the unlicensed Chinese clones.  (That lasted about a month before dying unexpectedly.)

I got this strap to make carrying my ukulele case more comfortable (tenor ukulele Ameritage case...so the case is built like a Hummer.)  The pad fit perfectly on the relatively thin Amertiage carrying shoulder strap.  But I immediately noticed that it added significant weight to the strap.  So when carrying the case by the handle, it not only makes the whole case heavier, but also turns the shoulder strap into an annoyance that can bump into your leg.  So if you plan to use this, plan to shoulder your bag/case the majority of the time.The pad had a nice contour to fit my shoulder, but simply was not that comfortable.  It is made of a denser foam which is on the firm side and can dig into your shoulder.  It just didn't work with me.  Another thing is that the area where the strap connects to the foam started to show separation from the first day.  I don't think it'll get any worse with use...but if it does, that'd be a big disappointment.I can understand why the USPS would use this strap: it's durable, does help to distribute weight, and postal carriers shoulder their bags the majority of the time.  But I don't think this is particularly well-suited for instrument cases.  Stick to using it for messenger bags.

This is the best mouse I have ever owned.  Coming from wireless mouses, I barely even notice the wire when I need to charge it, and it glides smoothly along the surface of my mousepad.  The sensitivity is also fantastic.  I've used this mouse to play Starcraft 2 and Guild Wars 2, but old habits with keyboard macros die hard.  So the mouse has had limited additional benefit there.However, I have found that this mouse and all of the button options are amazing for everyday tasks such as browsing the internet or flipping through long PDF documents.  Here are my key settings.G10 (top front): toggle to desktopG9 & G8 (top left): page up/page downG7 & G6: next tab / previous tabG5 & G4: Back / ForwardIf you are upgrading from a very basic mouse, just to get the page up and page down buttons alone, the mouse is well worth it.  It sounds trivial, but having all of those options with one click of your mouse makes browsing the web a whole new experience.  And with three profiles, swapping between game macros and regular work macros is easy as one click (G11).

I handled a Burnley custom Kwaiken at a knife show and fell in love with everything but the price.  So thankfully, Boker has manufactured one for the masses.  The knife looks great, but if you wanted to send your knife for some after-market modding, I removing the Boker Plus and AUS-8 markings on the blade make for a much cleaner look...because nobody is particularly proud to have paid $100 for AUS-8 steel.  (Note: I also have the "flipper" mod done to my Kwaiken and unfortunately it does not work particular well since the Boker version just was not designed as a flipper.)The detent on mine was on the strong side, so I took the knife apart and bent out the locking liner to loosen it a bit.  Much smoother action now, and just rockets open with solid lockup in all directions.  The major downside is this: YOU CAN SLICE YOUR FINGER EVEN WHEN THE KNIFE IS CLOSED!  If you run your finger along the bottom of the knife (which has a semi-open design) the blade comes close enough to the edge of the liner that it can catch the meaty part of your finger--especially in the areas close to the pivot.  So beware.  I cut myself once and will be more careful around that design flaw next time.

I finally upgraded from my Kindle keyboard 3G, no ads to the Kindle Paperwhite when I realized I be coming home later from work via public transportation and therefore, would be reading more in the dark.  I opted for the ad-supported version to save a few bucks, and that was a great decision.Pro tip: If you don't connect to the Internet for about a month (because you transfer books from your hard drive to the device), the Kindle stops showing you ads altogether...supposedly because it wants to show ads that are new and paid for by content sponsors.The battery life is great as promised, but the device ends up about the same weight and feel as the Kindle keyboard because of the larger battery that makes a device thicker and heavier than it otherwise would be.  So that was a bit of a let down there.  I keep my brightness setting relatively low and have never had a problem with running out of batteries.  The text is definitely crisp and easily readable.  I've enjoyed this Kindle for hours before bed, while on airplanes and in airports, and on the way  to and from work on the bus.  You don't notice the backlight when you're reading in well lit conditions and it's there when you need it in the dark.  If you're still thinking about upgrading from an older version of the Kindle, I would highly recommend the Kindle paperwhite.

When I realized I needed a new mousepad, I decided to upgrade to the best on the market. I saw that Steel Series, marketed itself as being the most used mousepad and gaming, so I was naturally intrigued.  I decided to buy the QCK+ because it promised to be an extraordinarily large mousepad and something different from what I would be used to.  Indeed, it was large as promised, but I still find myself only using a small portion of the pad due to the high mouse sensitivity settings that I prefer.  As for the surface it is smoother, and my mouse is able to glide along effortlessly.  I would say that the surface also helps to pick up more of the mouse's subtle movements.If you looking to buy mousepad and willing spend the money, this is probably the best there is out there.  Just make sure you have the appropriate amount of desk space because this thing is BIG!

I bought these to upgrade the plastic bridge pins on my Kanile'a custom ukuleles.  They were huge visual upgrade and the ebony with the abalone dot look beautiful.  It is especially nice if you have abalone fretboard inlays to match  or even abalone purfling or a rosette.  Tone wise, I don't hear much of a difference, but aesthetically, it was worth every penny.

I decided to try these glasses after hearing the hype for several years.  Long story short, these glasses do work.  I experienced less eyestrain after long gaming sessions.  They are very lightweight and almost feel cheaply made the frame is flexible and fits well.  The reduced coverage from the smaller lenses is not a problem because they are roughly equal to standard eyeglass lenses.  There is some slight magnification from the lens, which is a good feature.  The anti- reflect also helps and works as advertised.One comment, is that the packaging was one of the most difficult to open for a modern tech product.  That aside, the glasses do what they were advertised to do.  It's just up to you to decide whether you're willing to spend the money for yourself.  Personally, I don't think I would do it again.  But I will be using these during long computing sessions.

The At-A-Glance 2016 Weekly and Monthly Planner was just the thing I needed to keep track of doctor's appointments, social dates and meetings of my local civics group.  The cover is faux leather and quite rugged.  The planner has a full monthly calendar for each month spread over two pages, followed by spacious entry pages week by week (with room for notes).  The generous writing space is so large, the planner can double as a journal, or be used just for that purpose.  The back of the book has space for contacts and events, plus a list of holidays and even a time zone map of the US.  Altogether well planned and executed, I ordered two more for friends whose lives are as busy as mine.  Highly recommended.

This charming vintage Hummingbird feeder by Perky Pet is delightful and functional.  I ordered for a friend who has a weekend house in the Pocono Mountains; he already had several Hummingbird feeders, as who doesn't love hummers?  The base twists off to easily fill the feeder and the hobnail design is attractive and suits many a decor.  He was perfectly delighted with the feeder and you will be too!  Highly recommended.

My roommate insisted that I give this a good review.OK, I admit it  my stuff stinks.  Its not really my fault (is it ever anyones fault)  I have a multitude of chronic health problems and take many medications.  One of the side effects of the meds I take is a strong odor attached to my bathroom visits.  We previously tried everything; sprays (before it smelled like someone took a dump; now it smells like someone took a dump in a patchouli patch); candles (everything from scented vanilla to huge torch-like doubles), all to no avail.  When I saw the ads for Poo-Pourri I asked myself, Could this be the answer at long last?  So, when Amazon Vine offered me a sample I said OK, lets put it to the test.On the day the Poo-Pourri arrived, it coincided with a strong need on my part to use the john.  No candles were lit and no spray was used in order to maximize our assessment of the product.  The package suggest three-five spritzes directly on the water (I used five) before using the commode.  I held my breath and wondered aloud if my roommate would need to do the same (as usual) two rooms away.  The first thing I noticed about the Poo-pourri was that it had a strong citrus odor of its own (never mind that this was vanilla).  I finished my business and after I flushed and washed up, I invited my roomie to give the bathroom a sniff test.  I held my breath as he entered the john and pronounced Poo-pourri a winner!  For my part, all I could smell was the lingering citrus-like odor of the Poo-pourri!  What do you know, it actually works!Although the price is relatively high, we expect to purchase more and split the cost.  I, for my self-pride, and my roommate for his peace-of-nose.  Definitely recommended for the strong odor-maker in your household!

Just in time for the holidays, this set of everyday napkins is perfect for casual Thanksgiving and Christmas/Hanukah entertaining.  I presented the napkins to a dear friend who collects sets of linen napkins (he entertains a LOT) and he was perfectly delighted.  Just the thing for a gay holiday luncheon.  Very nice product.

I got the DII 100% Cotton Apron as a gift for my friend Clark, who entertains a lot and is a great cook.  He finds aprons are practical for keeping splashes off nice clothes when cooking for guests, and he owns several of them.  The DII 100% Cotton Apron is lightweight and is finished with a generous size pocket, which comes in handy when trying to do many things at once while preparing a large meal.  The apron is unisex, smart looking and a real value at the price listed.  Highly recommended.

The Tresemme Sea Salt Spray was not exactly what it promised.  While the spray did leave my hair in a tousled, unkempt casual appearance, it didn't seem to have much hold.  Isn't that what a hair spray should do?  Not recommended.

I use a lot of different conditioners.  As conditioners go, Dove Advanced Hair Series Conditioner performs at least as well as the next brand.  I found that it left my hair manageable and easy to work with.  It did not dry my hair out nor leave it too oily.  I would recommend it.

I got Dove Men + Care Fortyfying Styling Gel for my bathroom to share with my roommate.  Between the two of us, we use lots of styling gel.The product held nicely and did not feel overly greasy.  However, it did not stand up well to humidity.  We found that during periods of high humidity, the gel lost its oomph.  On the other hand, when it stopped holding due to humidity, we found that we needed only to run our fingers through it with some water to make it come alive again.  This didn't make much sense, but it is convenient.  On the whole, I feel I can definitely recommend it.

The HMDX Titanium Portable Speaker compares favorably with every similarly priced Blue Tooth speaker that Ive tried.  The highs are crisp and bright and the bass is impressive for such an affordable speaker.  In addition, the volume range is more than adequate for background music as well as entertaining.  I compared the sound to my upper-priced Jawbone Mini-Jambox and found it quite competitive indeed.  Set-up and pairing was quick and easy and overall I am quite impressed.  Highly recommended.

The Shoebox Assorted Birthday Card pack is handy to have around fore those occasions when you don't have time to shop for a birthday card and a friend or relatives birthday pops up unexpectedly.  The pack includes five cards, each with a different design or greeting.  The only drawback is that the price of the pack does not reflect any discount over purchasing the cards individually.  Still, they are great to keep in a drawer for use at a moments notice.  Recommended.

I gave this stainless steel manual coffee grinder to a friend, absolutely loved it.  The mini grinder is just big enough to grind the beans for a single cup of coffee, perfect for the person who lives alone and doesn't need to grind a lot of coffee at once.  The look is sleek and the grinder comes with a carrying case and cleaning brush.  Highly recommended.

The Chesapeake Bay New York Botanical Garden Peony  Bouquet Candle has an absolutely lovely fragrance, which is strong but not overpowering.  I like to light up the connecting hallway between the bedrooms in my apartment in the evenings.  Not phony or chep smelling, this candle is highly recommended.

Lovely design and striking color make for a very attractive linen napkin indeed.  I ordered these for a good friend who "collects" napkins and he was very happy with the design and finish.  Looked lovely on his dinner table, I must say.  Definitely recommended

The packaging for this item promised "no ride up" i.e. that the shirts would stay "tucked in".  I purposely wore all six tucked into my slacks or jeans and found this promise top be true.  The material is light, which I like in a white tee-shirt, especially in the summer.  The shirts are "tag-free" for extra comfort and, all in all, a bargain.  Recommended.

I gave this monthly planner to a friend with a bust schedule.  Sleek and nicely designed, the planner has plenty of room for appointments, notes or even keeping a daily journal.  The cover is sharp looking and the pages are nicely laid out.  All in all it made a nice gift that I was proud to give.  Definitely worth the money.

These are about the strongest trash bags I have ever used.  I used one to throw away about two dozen hardcover books I no longer wanted, fully expecting that the bag would break before I reached my apartment's trash room.  The biog not only held, it didn't even stretch!  I'm sold.  Definitely recommended.

It is difficult to review a battery that is supposed to last extra-long in the 30 days that Amazon Vine gives you to review a product.  I used the entire package on two clocks, two remote controls and a small radio the day I received the product.  When they have stopped  working, I promise to return here to let everybody know if they truly last extra-long.

I got the Rhodium Plated Sterling Silver I Am Lucky To Have You Clover Bracelet and Necklace Set for a friend of mine.  I was surprised at how lovely it was when it arrived.  My friend was absolutely thrilled with it; she kept the necklace and gave the matching piece to a friend of hers.  All in all, a very nice gift, and highly recommended.

I got this URBAN ARMY GEAR case for a friend of mine, who recently purchased the S6.  He absolutely loves it.  The case has a construction-themed design and a see-through back, that makes you feel confident that your S6 is being fully protected.  He especially liked the look and feel of the case.  The shell is strong and attractive.  Definitely recommended.

This scent reminded me of my last trip to the barber in my adolescence, not a great thing.  It has a strong, rather mundane odor, and made me think of those $5 bottles of after-shave we used to buy my father for Christmas.  I once read in the NY Times fashion section, that if you can still smell your cologne ten minutes after putting it on, you're wearing too much.  Well, I can smell this all day.  Not really recommended.

Scalisi Skin Care Advanced Wrinkle Cream promises a 45% reduction in wrinkles in eight weeks.  I believe them.  I have used this product nightly now for almost 30 days, and have already seen a dramatic reduction in under-eye wrinkles and sleep lines.  Two people who did not know I have been using this product remarked within the past few days that I am looking well-rested and thats proof enough for me.The dispenser is interesting, allowing just a small amount of the cream to come out of the jar at a time, so you can place it exactly where most needed.  I have found myself looking forward to applying it each night, as each application leaves the skin feeling noticeably tighter and yet more supple.  My one regret is that the cream is fairly expensive and when this is gone I dont think I can afford to buy more.But while it lasts, I expect to continue to enjoy it.  Recommended.

Please note that this review contains several spoilers concerning the initial hour of the film.  It does not contain any spoilers on the middle or climax of the movie.The first thing I feel compelled to say is that INTERSTELLAR is definitely not for everyone.  The film requires commitment in both time and thought, and therefore will not be to everyones liking, including some devoted fans of the science fiction genre.I will admit I have an affinity for films that require multiple viewings for the observer to digest.  Of course, I am no genius, but I was frankly amazed at how much of Christopher Nolans INTERSTELLAR I managed to understand on my first viewing.  When I saw it a second time, I was equally amazed at how much Id missed, and how beautifully it all came together.  I would not say that INTERSTELLAR requires a degree in quantum physics or an understanding of Einsteins theory of relativity, but they sure would be helpful.  Yet it turns out that the underlying theme of INTERSTELLAR is nothing more than an exploration of the power of love and what makes us human.  After my first viewing, I emerged from the theater with many questions, yet I had the feeling (and I still do) that INTERSTELLAR is perhaps the greatest science fiction film ever made and even possibly the best film I have ever seen of any genre.  I do not make these statements lightly.  I am a film buff who enjoys many different types of movies, but Sci-fi, drama and fantasy are perhaps my favorites.  INTERSTELLAR employs elements of each.The first portion of the film can be described thusly: Cooper (Mathew McConaughey) is a former NASA space pilot living in the near future, where a large-scale disaster (there are hints that it may have been climate change) has killed off much of the Earths population, and left the planet unable to sustain life beyond one more generation.  Dust storms blanket the planet and crops fail constantly.  One by one Earths crops have become history until corn is all that can be grown.Coopers daughter Murph and son Tom are above average students, but like other young people, they are encouraged to study farming to help sustain the dwindling food supply.  Murph complains of poltergeists in her room and is soon attempting to decode cryptic messages that appear in the dust near her bookcase.  When she and her dad discover that one of the messages contains geographic coordinates in binary numbers, they set out to discover what they may at that location.What they find is a secret NASA complex presided over by Professor Brand (Michael Caine) who is trying desperately to save the species by discovering a new, habitable planet while simultaneously exploring the possibility of launching a massive space station to evacuate Earths doomed people.  We soon learn that a crew of explorers has already been sent into a wormhole near Saturn.  The wormhole, which appeared suddenly 48 years prior, opens into another galaxy, where several potentially viable planets await.  Professor Brand convinces Cooper to leave his family and pilot a spacecraft into the wormhole, while he (Professor Brand) works on a problem concerning the space station.  Cooper is to be accompanied on this mission by Brands daughter (Anne Hathaway) and a crew of two more astronauts, plus two robots called Tars and Case.  Murph doesnt want her father to leave, because she understands that he will not be back for many years, if at all.  Believe it or not, this is only the beginning.  Be warned that the movie runs a hefty two hours and forty-nine minutes, all of which require sustained attention to absorb the films myriad details.With INTERSTELLAR, Christopher Nolan has fashioned nothing less than a modern classic, a film by which I believe future sci-fi films may be measured.  The music, by Hans Zimmer, is breathtaking, and so effective as to draw the viewer directly into the story.  The visual effects are stunning and the drama intense.  All together, they make for a highly potent and entertaining film.  During the final 45 minutes, I found myself in tears several times, particularly at the climax.I liked it so much that I did something I think Ive never done before  I went back to see it again the very next day.  The second viewing was even more rewarding and helped to answer many of the questions I had after my first screening.  While I did not understand it all the first time around (an understatement if ever there was one) I did understand enough to know that I was viewing something beyond extraordinary.For those who insist that this is Christopher Nolans worst effort, please note that up until now, I have not been a huge fan of his work.  But I believe he has more than come into his own with INTERSTELLAR, a film of amazing beauty, vision and heart.Interstellar is highly recommended.

The Mead Five Star Spiral Notebook sets a new standard in the otherwise common world of spiral notebooks.  The cover is made of durable plastic and resists spills and tears.  Each separator in the five-subject book has a reinforced pouch, that keeps and holds notes securely in the book.  The book contains a generous 200 pages and is thicker than other notebooks of the same type.  Each page is pre-punched with holes to fit a standard three-ring binder, so you can easily transfer notes directly into a permanent binder.  While the posted price may seem high, the overall quality is excellent and each of the notebooks should last for a long while.Recommended.

The Mead Five Star XPANX Pencil Pouch is a neat and practical idea.  The pouch offers three metal-enforced rings that fit into a standard three ring binder.  The pouch has a see-through window that discloses the contents and is easily large enough for all your pens and pencils.  A second zipper pocket can be used to store a small calculator or other supplies.  The pouch measure a generous 10 inches by 6  inches and expands to fit many writing instruments without being too bulky or obtrusive.  The pouch is constructed of sturdy material and is durable enough to last years without ripping or tearing.Based on my use of this great idea, I am awarding this product five stars.  Recommended.

Author Tommy Rosen holds advanced certification in Hatha and Kundalini Yoga.  In his new book, Recovery 2.0, he expounds upon his own recovery from alcohol and drug addiction and explains his own philosophy of combining traditional 12-Step recovery practices with yoga, meditation and holistic approaches to diet and exercise and their uses in treating advanced addiction to drugs, alcohol and gambling.The book is divided into three sections.  The first details his personal descent into the world of extreme addition to drugs and alcohol.  I found this portion of the book rather slow, but I was glad that I stuck with it.  The second section, Recovery 1.0 is a new-age overview of the 12 steps, which any recovering alcoholic or addict will find both familiar and refreshing.  In the third section, Recovery 2.0, he goes beyond the classic 12-Step approach to include spiritual practices such as yoga and diet to overcome all kinds of addiction.  It was this portion of the book that I found most fascinating and useful.  His modern explanation of the 12-Steps, combined with his very practical methods and advice, make a refreshing change in self-help books that I appreciated tremendously.As stated earlier, the initial portion of the book is rather slow, however, if the idea of a combination of the 12-Steps together with a holistic, new age approach to recover appeals to you, I believe you may enjoy this book very much.  Highly recommended.

The Unchartered Ultra-Lite Packing Cube is a wonderful idea whose time has come.  Every time I pack for a trip, I get tired of shoving all my items in a suitcase, only to find that I have poorly organized and forgotten my socks.The ultra-lite packing cube is exactly as its name implies; three separate pouches that you can use to compartmentalize items neatly arranged inside your bag.  The title ultra-lite does not begin to convey how lightweight the material is.  I have never felt such light material in my life.The three pouches measure 11.5 by 14.5 inches; 8.5 by 11.5 inches and 5.5 by 8.5 inches wide.  The two larger pouches are three inches deep and the small pouch is two inches deep.  My one criticism is that they could have made them a tad larger; nevertheless, by compartmentalizing my suitcase, they make it less likely that I will forget my socks underwear.  The 11 by 14 pouch is supposed to be for shirts, but I really wouldnt say that dress shirts would fit into it.  However, it does fit several rolled-up t-shirts and so certainly is useful.I like the look and practically weightless feel of the packing cubes and I am sure I will find all three useful when packing for my next trip.

Into the Woods debuted on Broadway in October 1987, where it was greeted with great enthusiasm by critics and audiences alike.  The narrative is based on four fairy tales, using versions by the Brothers Grimm (Cinderella, Jack and the Beanstalk, Little Red Riding Hood and Rapunzel).  The plot blends the familiar tales with an original story about a baker and his wife and their attempts to undo a witch's spell.  The musical boasts music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, the most respected theatre composer of the last 60 years, and a book by his frequent collaborator, James Lapine.Historically, fairy tales by the Grimm Brothers have been viewed as being darker and more realistic than versions of the same stories written by other authors.  Consequently, and because Mr. Sondheim is seen as one of the most (if not the most) challenging composers of modern theatre, it must be noted that Into the Woods is not a piece that was conceived with an audience of young children in mind.  Rather, it is a sophisticated adult experience, a fairy tale for grownups if you will.  While some of the darker and more provocative aspects of the story have been muted for the film version, the fact that the film has been produced by Disney has led many parents to assume that this is a film for small children.  It is not.  It is a moral fable for grownups; most children under the age of fifteen or so (unless they are very mature) will not be able to appreciate the story, and many parents of small children will find the material unsuitable.For the uninitiated, Mr. Sondheim has long been known for his extremely clever rhymes, and his intellectually provocative lyrics and scenarios.  Since 1957, he has written both music and lyrics for such heralded shows as A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Anyone Can Whistle, Company, Follies, A Little Night Music, Merrily We Roll Along, Sweeney Todd, Pacific Overtures, Sunday in the Park with George, Assassins, Passion, Bounce and, of course, Into the Woods.  He also wrote the lyrics only for West Side Story, Gypsy and Do I Hear a Waltz.  Whole revues have been assembled around his songs and even the songs he'd dropped from shows before they reached Broadway.  Nevertheless, aside from the lyrics to West Side Story and his most successful song, Send in the Clowns, he is largely unknown to all but regular Broadway audiences.  Yet many audiences are already familiar with the stage version of Into the Woods, either from Broadway, touring companies or the DVD of the complete show (with the original cast).  Like most of Sondheim's other works, Into the Woods has been praised for its witty and intelligent lyrics and its extremely humorous book.  It has also proved to be one of his most popular endeavors.Devotees of the stage work will find that, like Sweeney Todd before it, several cuts have been made in the story and music for the film version of Into the Woods.  Having purchased the soundtrack and now having seen the film twice, I would say that about one third of the story and one fifth of the music has been removed from the film version.  I was a bit more disappointed at the deletions of the choral portions of Sweeney Todd than I am in the music cut from Into The Woods.  The film works quite well, with a good deal of the music and humor intact.The following songs have been deleted from the score for the movie:I Guess This is Goodbye / Maybe They're MagicFirst MidnightAct II Prologue (So Happy)Agony (Act II Reprise)And the following songs have been replaced by instrumental versions:Ever After (Instrumental)No More (Instrumental)This is not surprising; what is surprising is that so much of the score has been retained for the film.  The original stage show ran over three hours, plus the intermission.  The film clocks in at just over two hours, which means that more than an hour of music and plot have been trimmed.  Many may disagree, but I believe this makes for a tighter, more structured story and score.  Considering the length of the stage work, some cuts simply had to be made.It is recommended that those previously unfamiliar with the score acquire the complete soundtrack (with the libretto included) and follow along with the words as the songs are sung.  The first thing you will realize is (as with any of Mr. Sondheim's works) how incredibly witty and sophisticated the lyrics are; on first listen you may miss most of his delicious wit.  His use of the language, his clever rhymes, and his intelligent, deft semantics will amaze anyone who takes the time to listen.  There are reasons why so many consider Sondheim the foremost composer of the theatre, and so many intelligent theatergoers hang on his every word.  Into the Woods is no exception, despite the cuts.The cast of the film, led by Meryl Streep, Anna Kendrick and James Corden are uniformly excellent.  I expected a faithful adaptation of Into the Woods as soon as I heard that the film was being directed by Rob Marshall, who brought the musical Chicago to the screen.  Mr. Marshall presented a faithful adaptation of Chicago, and once again he does not disappoint.All in all, Into the Woods is a towering achievement.  Few of Sondheim's musicals have been successfully transplanted to cinema.  Into the Woods may very well be the best of them.Highly recommended.

I absolutely love being a vine member, but its difficult to review a lightbulb.  Its particularly difficult to review a lightbulb that lasts 25,000 hours when you only have 30 days to review it.  Nevertheless, I am awarding the GE Energy Smart LED Lightbulb five stars, based on the fact that its easily as bright as a standard 100 watt bulb and it does deliver on its promise to provide uniform, soft light all around the bulb.  I am quite happy with this product.

I have been looking forward to this film since I learned it was being made.  Stephen Sondheim's INTO THE WOODS was one of the highlights of the 1980's Broadway scene.  With a book by James Lapine and Music and Lyrics by Mr. Sondheim, the witty, fast-paced and delightful story/score charmed audiences young and old when it debuted on Broadway on November 5, 1987.  At this writing I have not yet seen the film, but the Soundtrack arrived from Amazon today and I have listened carefully to it.Based on a combination of Grimm's Fairy Tales (Little Red Riding Hood, Jack and the Beanstalk, Cinderella, and Rapunzel) the classic stories are woven together and combined with an original story about a childless baker and his wife and their efforts to remove a witch's spell.The score is magnificent, and represents Stephen Sondheim at his very best, although those of us who are fans of Mr. Sondheim agree that - from West Side Story through Passion - every show he has touched has had its own magic.  Stephen Sondheim is known as much for his deliciously witty, complicated lyrics, as for his rich, rewarding melodies.  Judging from my initial listen to this soundtrack, the score is almost completely intact when compared to the stage version, unusual for a musical film.  As he did with his masterpiece, Sweeney Todd, Mr. Sondheim has made some minor lyrical changes for the film which enhance rather than detract from the score.Some will be upset at the omissions.  Based on the Soundtrack, the following songs appear to have been deleted from the score:I Guess This is Goodbye / Maybe They're MagicFirst MidnightAct II Prologue (So Happy)Agony (Act II Reprise)Witch's LamentPlus the following songs have been replaced by instrumental versions:Ever After (Instrumental)No More (Instrumental)I suppose if I had my preferences, I would restore the Act II reprise of Agony, just for my favorite laugh in the show ("Dwarves are very upsetting....").  The song "No More" never really clicked for me, but "Maybe They're Magic" proffered the witty line, "If the end is right, it justifies...the beans".  I do regret the deletion of "The Witch's Lament" from the second act.  Oh well, I would rather rejoice at what's been retained than bemoan the deletions.The CD includes a complete libretto.  The Soundtrack also includes a wealth of incidental music.  Fully half an hour of the ninety-minute soundtrack is instrumental.All in all, what remains of the score is extremely satisfactory.  If you are a fan of the show, or even if you are unfamiliar with this work at all, I promise that the Soundtrack to INTO THE WOODS will make you believe in movie musicals again.

I ordered this product mainly for my roommate, who had complained that his skin had been feeling extra dry lately.  I usually have problems with dry skin myself in the winter, owing to the harsh weather where we live.Nivea Body In-Shower Nourishing Body Lotion for Very Dry Skin more than lived up to its promise.  My roommate reported that after one application and rinse, the lotion made him feel noticeably less dry and considerably relieved the itching associated with dry skin.  As for me, my skin feels smooth and supple, with no more dryness or flaking.It's so nice when you find a product that does exactly what it says it will.  Nivea Body In-Shower Nourishing Body Lotion for Very Dry Skin is definitely recommended.

The OXO Goods Grips Professional Paring Knife is strong, sturdy and extra-sharp.  The handle balances nicely and feels good in the hand.  The handle is also appealing and looks quite spiffy.  Definitely recommended.

This Now Designs Apron is easily adjustable for tall, short, big or short people around both the neck and waist.  It has a handy large front pocket and is made of a very sturdy cotton.  I got this item for a friend of mine who entertains frequently.  He loved it.  I chose the color black, which hides kitchen stains.  Sleek and becoming, this apron will be cherished for a long time to come.  Easily worth the price and highly recommended.

When I ordered the Mead Pro Heavy Duty Binder I did not realize how packed with features the product is.  To begin with, the binder has a generous 1  inch D-ring three hole fixture, which is easily removed to carry your bound sheets independent of the rest of the binder.  Better still; the binder has an interior expanding file with four compartments and exterior pockets for notes and pens.  When they say that the binder is dependable and durable, they are not kidding; the binder is bound with high-quality, rugged fabric in an attractive bright blue color.Up until this afternoon, I had a large pile of junk papers and bills sitting on top of a bookcase in my dining room.  With the aid of a three-hole punch, I was able to fit it all into my new binder with plenty of room to spare.  One folder in the binder is now holding my financial statements, another my unpaid bills, and another has my health information and recent medical claims, etc.  Bye-bye pile, hello binder.  I expect to use this  item for a long time to come and I am very happy with it.  Recommended.

The Good Grips Interlocking Corn Holders from OXO are a bright addition to any casual dining experience that includes corn-on-the-cob.  The interlocking design makes it easy to make sure they don't get lost in the flatware drawer, unlike many other corn holders where you always have to search for one at the last minute.  Bright, colorful and sturdy.  I love 'em!

Warning: spoilers galore:Scarlet Marlow is on a quest to find the Philosopher's Stone, an ancient mythological treasure that can turn base metals into gold and grant eternal life to those who find it.  How original is that?  In a harrowing and well-directed sequence that opens the film, she manages to photograph the Rose Key, which contains the secret to finding the Philosopher's Stone.  As this was her father's life's work and the cause of his madness and suicide, she is determined to find the elusive prize.  After leaving Iraq she connects with her translator George in Paris and elicits his help in translating the Rose Key.  He promises to help her translate but refuses to provide her any further help; this caused me to deduce correctly that he would soon be joining Scarlet in her search.  After visiting an ancient church, she determines that that the Stone is hidden somewhere in the ancient Paris catacombs.  Scarlet then obtains the assistance of Papillion, a self-styled expert in the Paris catacombs and apparent graffiti artist, promising him the spoils of the search.  At this point, I thought that Steve McQueen must be rolling in his grave.  Together with Papillion's "team" they sneak into the catacombs and begin their journey.From here the plot goes from murky to ridiculous as the promising beginning is sacrificed to a story that degenerates into a tour through the catacombs beneath Paris in pursuit of the mythical Philosopher's Stone.  I found this part of the premise of the film to be intriguing, as publicity for the film boasted that the search was filmed in the actual Paris catacombs.  Unfortunately that promise did not come to fruition.The balance of the film treats us to a claustrophobia-inducing, endless tour of the catacombs, many of the tunnels being barely large enough to squeeze through.  As the group progresses through the catacombs, up into tunnels, down into water and back again, I kept wondering where this was heading, and glanced at my watch a lot.  There are endless clues and some frightening moments, but much of the action is ruined by an overwhelming sense on the part of the viewer that these tunnels are leading to nowhere.  As they continue to travel, sometimes seemingly moving in a circle, the plot makes less and less sense as our intrepid explorers penetrate deeper and deeper.  Admittedly there are a few spooky moments, which would have improved the film if they made any sense.  The end of this mess was one of the most pathetic non-events I have ever encountered in a motion picture, and I scratched my head as I experienced a "Huh?  That's it?" moment.  As I filed out of the theater with the other half-dozen moviegoers who sat through this atrocity, I was extremely grateful that I had made use of a free movie pass that a friend had given me.  Bottom line: extremely claustrophobic tour of the Paris catacombs combined with a nonsensical plot and too few scary moments made for one of the most disappointing trips to the movies I've had this year.  Avoid at all costs.

I ordered Febreze Air Effects Allergen Reducer Clean Splash because I really have a thing for Air Fresheners and can never keep enough of them on hand.  I like the idea that it also reduces allergens, but of course, it's difficult to judge the effectiveness of that particular feature.  However, I must say it has a clean, clean fragrance that left my home smelling scrubbed and sanitary.  The hefty weight of the container reassured me that the can would last a long while, something that I look for specifically in air fresheners.  I used it liberally around the apartment after cleaning today and my roommate commented on how nice the place smelled as soon as he got home from work.  Between our two noses, we judged this product a winner.  Recommended.

I got this necklace for a friend of mine who had been going through a rough time lately.  She mentioned to me that she was hoping to be able to find a new inexpensive necklace to wear to her nieces upcoming wedding.  As she is on a limited budget, she was not expecting to be able to afford much.  When I got this for her, it was just the trick to cheer her up and make her feel better.  I will not forget the look on her face when she saw it for the first time.  The necklace is positively elegant looking, definitely worth the price and quite lovely.  I was very pleased to be able to give it to her and she absolutely loved it.  The sterling silver chain and beautiful pendant makes for a far more expensive-looking piece than it really is.  Definitely recommended.

I got these napkins for a friend of mine who always uses linen napkins.
