For me, this is 'almost' Greek to me.  My step-father was Greek and he was in the restaurant business.  That included making all those wonderful Greek dishes many of us adore.  This product is close and just misses the tastes I grew up with; however, it tastes fantastic.  I add a little more lemon juice to give it that 'my' taste, but nothing else except saltines and Ouzo.  Luckily, there are producers of the soup and unluckily, they are few and far between.  It literally took years before I ran across a clam chowder soup that mirrored the real thing and it was just a few hundred miles away in Maryland.  Our local grocery stores do not carry slow selling products.  The store manager said soup that is over $3 - $4 a can is too expensive.  Not when it is so good, like It's Greek to Me Chicken Soup.

Take a few pieces of lightweight fabric and sew them together into an effective protector of passports and other potentially useful items for other unscrupulous folks to use and you have a Landing Gear Passport Holder that fits around the neck and either in front or on the side of the user.  If I know I will have to show my credentials, I will wear it under my suit coat so that I can retrieve it without a hassle on my part.  That's code for laziness on my part.  And worth it.  This item was a free sample based on my writing an unbiased review.  For me it is almost impossible to write a biased review.  It may not be written well nor exciting, but it represents my views.  Personally, this is a fine product and is extremely effective.

The picture does little to tell one what these are.  They are about the size of an oval quarter dollar or less than a half dollar.  I placed on on a bunion and relief was just a second away.  Each one is clear, clean flexible plastic that covers and provides relief of shoes pushing against the aggravated bunion or cut or some other problems.  Feet and shoes generally do not match one for one and a little push or pull may be necessary and this is where Gel Soft Pads work the best.  For me, they are a neutralizer for those mismatches.

2nd album from U.K. band delivers short, terse, angular post-punk minimalism that flashes vehement socio/political messages through addictively jagged dance rhythms on staccato guitar lines, punchy bass and conversational vocal interplay. Reminiscent of bands like The Raincoats, Au Pairs, ESG, Young Marble Giants, Gang of Four, Savages, Ludus, Delta 5, Prinzhorn Dance School.  Includes members from Covergirl, Trash Kit, Wetdog, Golden Grrrls.  Why Choose is a brilliant moment of charged-up rhythmic spazz for political post punks to indulge in retro-electrocution dance floor convulsions.  Excellent.

The 3rd album from this Nashville, Tennessee band is a keeper.  Dying Surfer Meets His Maker starts with some lope-along, bluesy guitar rock that has a slow-building thread of intensityand quickly escalates to the land of dark, blistering psychedelic metal.  Drums pound and struggle to explode with primal strength, while the guitars reach out to those strange, zoned-out dark holes of the universerealities only the bong-bowl rockers can find.  Acoustic guitars and electric acid-licks reside here in perfect harmony.  This is thoughtfully twisted rock n  roll with a semi-raw honesty that explores and prods the echo-whispers of classic rockers, blues masters and drug-land pioneersmixing it all into a chunky, soulful stew with a uniquely creative and primeval core of ROCK.  Recommended.

Debut release from Matt Berninger (The National) and Brent Knopf (Menomena, Ramona Falls)El Vy play memorable thumpy-bump indie pop songs with a quirky rhythmic flow of eccentricity thats balanced by Berningers incredibly affective and embraceable baritone.  Its a surprisingly congruous fit that pits the lightness of the music against the warmth and weight of an inviting vocal despair.  Honestly, if the National rocks your boat, youll want to sail on this one, too.  Knopfs musical contributions give the songs a slightly different twist, adding a strain of subtly playful overtones, but its still Berningers Leonard Cohen-esque voice that guides the ship and dips into the dark waters.  Overall, Return to the Moon is a huggable sliver-shiver of an album that will touch your heart with the authenticity of its beauty and subtly strange melodic turmoil.  Recommended.

2nd album from this Swedish triodroney-but-driving psychedelic rock with some blazing guitar rides to the outer edge of the hallucinogenic universe.  These are songs that caress your psyche with hippy-trippy love blasts; while packing a darkly compelling, melodic power in a heavy, hypnotic roar of rock music bliss.  There is not a weak moment or a wasted note here.  Similarities to New Candys, Psychic Ills, Wooden Shjips, The Warlocks, Asteroid No. 4, Singapore Sling, White Hills.  Futurecent is strong, zoned-out rock music for the beautifully slow roll of dissolving brain sparkle.  Recommended.

2nd full-length album from this Michigan band who play fluid-but-noisy psychedelic rock with a dominant reverberating surf/garage guitar twang.  The production is thick and purposely muddled, with a dreamy tin-can ethos pushing all the sounds to the center in an echoic blend of mid-fi  Americana rock drone.  Sometimes recalls bands like Coke Weed, The Warlocks, The Holydrug Couple, Ty Segall, Psychic Ills.  Holy Water Pool sounds like haunted desert cowboy ghosts on a narcotic binge to find the rock n roll soul of all the grinning sun-bleached skulls in the sands of time.

2nd album from Brazilian banddreamy, tripped-out psychedelic pop with some strangely explosive rock interludes and reverb-twanged guitar leads.  The songs often show an epic, almost prog-like, sense of melodic development.  Theres a blanket of sweet gentility thats regularly ripped apart by unexpected rhythm changes and beautifully odd, druggy surprises.  Fernando Almeidas sensually resonating vocals deliver the peculiar lyrics (sung in Portuguese with an English translation insert) through an ethnically tinged haze of mind-altering melodies and musical twists.  Reminiscent of bands like Os Mutantes & The Holydrug Couple, with references to White Fence, Foxygen & Santana.  Manual is a subtly potent slow-grower that promises new treats with every listen.  Nice.

3rd album from Virginia band who play earth-shakingly epic doom/sludge metal that incorporates threads of proggy noise, psychedelic lead riffing and some gargantuan-creepy melodic structure into the repetitious & sledgehammer-heavy vibration of this metal beast.  Recalls bands like Uncle Acid, King Woman, Conan, Sleep.  Griefs Infernal Flower is an album of gigantic proportions:  a bad-ass, bone-jarring rip in the mysteriously heavy spectrum of the hair-shaking doom universe.  Pretty cool.

3rd album from Swedish bandraw, rockin, bluesy guitar shredders with a heavy dose of classic 70s grit, some soulful songwriting bits and tastefully blistering lead work.  Innocence & Decadence is a genuine blast back to the days when rock n roll came from the gut and aimed for scrunch-faced air guitar hip gyrations in tight pants.  Recalls a lot of great bands:  Mount Carmel, Lonely Kamel, Ten Years After, Keef Hartley Band, Savoy Brown, Blues Pills, Taste, Firebird, Endless Boogie, Datura 4, etc.  When you need a break from everything labelled indiethis is the rock, the real stuff.

Debut album from Los Angeles band who play sophisticated sugar-harmony pop with a lovely & lazy summer retro twist.  The band adeptly mixes strains of girl-group pop and twee into an ear-pleasing sound that combines the comfort of memories with a contemporary production edge.  Like a mix of Girls, Camera Obscura and a slightly more weird Cowboy Junkies.

On their 9th album (and the first in ten years) these legendary U.K. synth-pop veterans of the dark-edged dance floor return with a worthy revitalization of their classic sound.  Sumners voice is as riveting as it ever was, the bass lines thump & drive with authority, and the synthesizers dominated the glitter-ball world of black leather boogie.  Core members have recorded with Electronic, Bad Lieutenant, Joy Division, Marion.  Includes guest appearances from Iggy Pop plus members of The Killers and La Roux.  Although it feels somewhat dated and registers as a bit of a guilty pleasure, there is an undeniably hypnotic allure to the repetitive electronic rhythms hereand the two or three songs that rock it up a bit lend a much needed edge to the album.  Music Complete may not be New Orders best moment, but its an enjoyable & admirable flashback to a legendary sound.

Baltimore band returns with their 6th album (and the 2nd one this year) featuring more dreamy shimmer ballads that radiate a mysterious beauty and a shadowy eloquence.  On Thank Your Lucky Stars the guitar is a bit more prominent, the tone is just slightly darker, the mood demands a deeper listener immersion, and Victoria LeGrands voice is haunted by an open-eyed maturity that rings less of innocence and more of celestial sensuality.  Though the songs are laced with a mystical secrecy and a spooky sort of charm, its still very much a Beach House albumwhich is a good thing.  Like their previous albums, the songs arent really memorable beyond the moment, but thats not important; tone and mood are the keys here.  Its the time you spend with them when its happening that matters.  Nice.

3rd album from British bandclassic guitar pop songs with gorgeous vocal harmonies leading dreamy, folk-tinged melodies.  Simple, unadorned, beautiful music that recalls artists like Fleet Foxes, Nick Drake, R.E.M., Sparklehorse, Tranquility, CSN&Y, the Beatles.

2nd album from British duo who play gorgeous, lilting psychedelic folk songs that capture a softly enlightened 60s vibe.  The songs are led by the sweet vocal harmonies and songwriting of Alison Cotton and Mark Nicholas, augmented by backing vocals, autoharp, mandolin & dulcimer.  Although most stay close to a traditional sound, they occasionally lean into a more rock side.  Recalls artists like Richard & Linda Thompson, Fairport Convention, Simon & Garfunkel, Syd Barrett.

4th album from Pennsylvania musiciangently stirred, lo-fi, yearning pop songs with a softly dark, gooey bedroom center of beauty & anguish floating in an atmospheric dream-state.  Some similarities to Elliott Smith, Mac DeMarco, Pinback.  Nice.  Odd.

This debut album from New Jersey singer Leslie Bear is a foggy, ethereal pop piece that mixes heavenly alien soundscape atmospheres with Bears angelic vocals.  Recalls artists like Grouper, Cocteau Twins, Beach House, Memoryhouse.  Softly strange music for the long narcotic sleep.

The 3rd album from the Swedish band absolutely nails the concept of psychedelic rock in a dirty-earth, organic way.  It is brilliantly, cohesively experimental; a fresh, original, incredibly creative rock album filled with desert ethnic shadow songs that buzz like a peyote vision and some serious flirtations with Middle Eastern meditative noise/metal.  Twisted and trippy electric acid-blues guitar licks explode from a mantra/drone raga-rock expansion of dynamic sound & the evolution of consciousness.  Shades of Goat, Bardo Pond, Telescopes, Spacemen 3, Dungen, Bong, Hawkwind, Voice of the Seven Thunders, Jimi Hendrix, Prson Sound.  Frid is an amazingly mesmerizing journey to new places where organic/industrial ethnic blues worms through an Alice in Wonderland psychedelic rock soundscape.  Highly Recommended.

3rd album from band out of Stockholm, Swedendark, rhythmically driving industrial/Goth rock with hard-edged, addictive melodies.  These are songs made for the manic dance of black leather boot heels in a dark, strobe-lit basement clubmarching, Germanic post-punk rock for the passionate release of harsh energy.  Then Comes Silence play a very specific style of music and, on this album, they do it better than almost anyone else in the game.  The punchy, repetitive core of rhythm over rigid monotone guitar leads, angry synthesizers and deep-creep whisper-throat vocals is a perfect formula for ritualistic bouncing off of the walls.  Their sound reflects bands like Red Lorry Yellow Lorry, D.A.F., Girls Against Boys, Skinny Puppy, Stagnant Pools.  Nyctophilian is a brilliantly predictable powerhouse of an album within its genre.  Recommended.

Debut album from this Australian bandstark and jagged-clean post-punk rock with rips of twisted angular guitar chords over dark, palpitating bass lines & some marching drum beats.  As powerful as the music is, with its lively, driving punk ethos wrapped in a minimalist throb; its Adam Curleys voice that gives the songs their unique intensity.  His distinctive vocal spacing and emotional resignation are punctuated with terse, passionate yelps of expulsive purging.  Recalls a bunch of great bands, such as The Comsat Angels, Gang of Four, Joy Division, Mission of Burma, Batfish Boys, Cold Pumas, Radio Birdman, Scumbag Philosopher.  Its You is packed with songs that carry the weight of the world and throw it back at you with a distinctly distant indifference that belies the gripping, angst-coated core of post-punk pathos.  Riveting and Recommended.

1st full-length album from band out of Venice, Italyfull-on psychedelic twang guitar rock that rips & roars with a passionate twist of trippy melodic reverberation and rainbow-colored, druggy drone-hooks.  Blasts of blistering feedback and chug-a-lug flower-power chords wind through narcotic & desperately dreamy vocals searching for the answer.  The guitars are engagingly thick and beautifully sinister, with a heavy rock thread that delivers an acid-dripped ticket to a streaking-star sonic immersion.  Recalls bands like Psychic Ills, Moon Duo, Baby Woodrose, Wand, Temples, The Black Angels, Asteroid No. 4.  New Candys As Medicine is the place where the mind squiggles in wonder to vibrations from a new rock n roll world.  Recommended.

New single from this mysterious Swedish band:  The A side (played here) is a bit of ethno-motorik, electro-psychedelic choral chant hypnotism.  Relax, the appropriately titled B side, is a more chilled-out slice of mesmerizing trippiness.

8th album from this Montreal, Canada band who return with big, epic, flowing indie rock ballads that lean toward expansive and unpredictable rhythmic structures, often building to a soaring crescendo.  Murray Lightburn is an exceptional singer, and many of the songs focus on the power of his voice.  The band projects a dramatic flair through opulent songwriting and full, complex arrangement.  The jurys still out on this one.

3rd album from this Belgian band is a sophisticated swirl of darkly accessible indie rock with big beat-driven, orchestral blasts of sensually epic intensity led by Maarten Devolderes sleazy-slurred, dramatic vocals.  The songs are deceptively entreating, with a mesmerizing core of club-groove smoothness thats balanced by a mysteriously compelling, embraceable energy riding on raw swells of open-hearted passion.  You might hear similarities to Black Strobe, dEUS, Arcade Fire, Grizzly Bearwith Leonard Cohens sense of romance and anguish.  With beautiful production and a warmif slightly tornheart, absorbing Thin Walls is like sitting in a lush & plush chair that surrounds you with a vaguely uneasy sense of comfort and fulfillment.  I like it here.  Recommended.

The 3rd release from this Norwegian bandinfectious 60s influenced rock n roll that mixes some kick-ass, soaring guitar leads with strong hooks & melody lines in a potpourri of hum-along psychedelic pop and addictive garage rock energy.  Great songs that will stick in your head and move your body, served with a side of fun and talent.  Recommended.

Buffalo, New Yorks iconic weirdos return with their 9th album, projecting an ultimate dreamy transcendence.  Listening to Jonathans soothing interplanetary voice  and floating around in Grasshoppers instrumental world is like the mellowest, most beautiful pure acid trip youve (n)ever taken.  Theres a lush orchestral feel to much of the album, spinning a colorful kaleidoscope of luminous sound.  The air is full of strings, bells, chimes, guitars, keyboards, horns, sitars, mandolins, moon glow and a magical sparkle.  Pop, jazz, choral, classical, prog, psychedelic, experimental and elegant rock all  take their turn pushing the current of the flow.  The sometimes melancholy lyrics reference bands from The Pretty Things to Dead Can Dance, from Popol Vuh to Elliott Smith, from Terry Riley to Talk Talkand remind us about the days when vinyl was king by default.  Celestial nymphs thread opulent strains of audio magnificence through the marshmallow clouds.  Reality takes a back seat, and your body is disconnected, gliding along on sumptuous soundwaves in an open-ended, luxuriant atmosphere.  Contributions come from members of The Posies, The Disciplines, Midlake and The Fugs.  The Light In You is a complex and beautiful album, with a rich sense of musicality and a touch of magic.

3rd album from Boise, Idahos Trevor Powers; his yearning, haunted high-register vocals guide songs that ebb & flow through a psychedelic wonderland of emerging pop sounds.  Synthesizers, horns, strings, piano & variophon flesh out the guitar/drums/bass core.  Many of the songs move sinuously through a fragile electronic web of sound.  The music often feels complex and orchestrated, with Powers voice straining to push some organic wave of emotion through the swirl of clutter.  Reminiscent of Tame Impala, Flaming Lips, Mercury Rev or Neil Young singing for the softly weird side of Wand.  Savage Hills Ballroom is a strange album that requires time and effort to dig out the reward, but it is there.

Debut album from Boston artist; Carpenter is a former member of Beat Circus & Ghost Train Orchestra and has played with The Swans, Colin Stetson & Marc Ribot.  Hes also a lyrically adept storyteller with a  hauntingly eerie baritone voiceone that calls to the listener with an emotional warmth & vulnerable, perceptive strength.  The music is generally low-key, with a complimentary sparseness that accents Carpenters vocals and can expand at a moments notice with the sound of reverb-soaked desert-twang guitars in a folk-tinged setting punctuated by the ebb & flow of female background vocals, strings and theremin.  Recalls artists like Leonard Cohen, Bill Callahan.  The Far End of the World is an album of subtle strength; the kind that will quietly crawl under your skin and finger-tickle all of the slow-festering, hidden secrets there.

6th release from this band out of Barcelona, Spain who play dark, rhythmically driving guitar-electro rock with a viciously jagged edge of punk-funk industrial tension and soaring, distorted riffs hanging in the air.  Still, theres a distinct emphasis on a tight & catchy, melodic center that effectively balances the noise and potential chaos.  Static, penetrating guitar notes and a solid thread of Gothic drone-rock mix into the compellingly hypnotic structure of the music.  Vocals in the native language (Cada Dia Es Asi translates to Every Day Is So) dont detract from the power at all.  Members have played in Linn Youki, Glissando, Anna & the Bananas, Mena.  Theres something very powerful and riveting about the nature of these five short songs that manifests itself in a potent immediacy.  I think youll be hearing more from them.  Recommended.

Debut album from duo out of Sydney, Australiaoscillating waves of atmosphere-driven synthesizer pop/rock with throbbing bass lines and rich, complex, darkly fluid melody lines.  The songs vacillate between a dreamy pop flow and mysterious washes of epic electronic transmissions. The production, although clean, feels purposefully muddled at timesmixing the instruments into a soup of undecipherable ingredients.  There is an intriguingly dark, post-Goth industrial edge that penetrates the murky drug-club aura with surprisingly melodic splashes of hypnotic & ghostly dance-floor angst.  Former members of Parades and Ghostwood.  Overall, Janes Lament offers an appealingly strange mix of beauty in  a mesmerizing rhythmic flow.

2nd album from Louisville, Kentucky band who play darkly sinuous, epic & creepy atmospheric rock with a desert drone-twang guitar edge of bluesy turmoil.  Thick chords hover and reverberate with the subtle roar of demonic authority, while desperately echoing vocals demand attention, and a motorik blues rhythm marches into post-rock oblivion.  Strains of psychedelic resignation fight for their place in the blood-splattered arena dust, driven by never-say-die drums and surrounded by the gritty, soul-deep twang & flow of sustained guitar notes searching the answer.  Some similarities to Gallon Drunk, Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds/Birthday Party, Crime & the City Solution, The Amazing Snakeheads, Blue Ruin.  Recommended.

New single from Los Angeles artist best known as the drummer for the Melvins (but he was also in Shrinebuilder, Fantomas, Tweak Bird, Altamont, Men of Porn, Nirvana and other bands).  Big Uns is a choppy axe-chord, metallic groove rocker with a  big guitar churn, some blistering & twisted lead riffs, creepy vocals and an overall classic rock feel thats mutated by some odd timing, manipulated voice & sounds, and some alien kazoo-like guitar notes.  The Qui side is equally strange, a bit less listenable.  Limited to 500 numbered copies on  red/ pale yellow vinyl.  Very cool!

2nd full-length album from duo out of Santiago, Chile who play deeply restorative, beautiful and warm psychedelic indie pop with sweeping, yearning melody lines that roll along in a mellifluous dream-state on big, friendly keyboards and fluid bass guitar thumps that sometimes double as lead notes.  Guitars lend a softly supportive rhythmic base, while exotic synthesizers wash over hypnotic songs that radiate a comfortable and druggy lounge-pop bliss.  Moonlust is music for slow eyes-closed head-nodding and a big, mesmerized smile.  Auditory relaxation therapy.

3rd album from Massachusetts artist Daryl Shepard, who plays mantra-like psychedelic desert-scapes interspersed with short samples of sci-fi space station voices.  Guitar notes evolve in hypnotic repetition as they move toward a just-out-of-reach finale.  Mechanistic percussion clicks behind guitar-hero ethnic ragas.  A deceptively simple sounding dramatic flair of stinging blues notes pierces its backing atmospheric drone.  And, finally, a snail-slow metal monster screams through the universe.  Sometimes recalls band artists like Black Sun Ensemble, Sandy Bull, early Dave Edmunds with Love Sculpture, Music Blues.

8th album out of New Jersey from this blistering, heavy stoner rock/metal trio with some mega-raging guitar riffs.  This is high energy, fast n hard guitar rock made for blasting comets back to their home planet; long-haired, mean-assed guitar hero rock n roll that has an explosive core, butexcept for the final trackfails to create anything thats memorable beyond the moment.  Includes members from Monster Magnet, Black NASA, Raging Slab, Godspeed, Core, Riotgod.

Debut album from California artist & former member of Catwalk.  Hessler plays big, ringing guitar pop with a clean & compelling sound that has a direct connection to the head-nodding, foot-tapping, humming center of the pop universe.  This is just beautiful & comfortable music with an addictive edge of pure pop bliss that cant be denied.  Recalls the best of bands like Teenage Fan Club, the Beatles, Tommy Keene, the Orange Peels, the Pains of Being Pure At Heart, the Small Square, Belle & Sebastian, the Field Mice.  Soft Connections is the sound of simple, warm, perfect indie pop.  Recommended.

Debut release from duo with roots in Champaign, Illinois plus Wisconsin & Japan who play warm, embracing pop melodies with mesmerizing, uplifting hooks and perfectly matched vocal harmonies.  These are the kind of quietly subtle & pure pop songs that you want to wallow in, cant get enough of.  The songwriting and production both shine with an effortless, natural glow.  Guitars are occasionally cranked up to provide a taste of power pop heaven.  Members have played with Velvet Crush, Tommy Keene, New Ruins, Matthew Sweet, Unbunny, others.  Guest contributors include members from Badfinger, Son Volt & Whiskeytown.  The music recalls bands like Teenage Fan Club, Nada Surf, the Beatles, Sloan, Tommy Keene, Nic Hessler.  The Small Square have opened a portal to a world where pop music reigns supreme.  Its a good place to be.  Recommended.

The 4th album from this New Jersey band, billed as a rock opera in five acts, is an ambitiously (29 songs) conceptual bit of storytelling thats filled out with half a dozen additional vocalists plus an expansive array of instruments.  Still, this mostly comes across as epic and rowdy blue-collar political roots punk mixed with classic, gritty-voiced rock n roll anthems for the peasant revolution.  Recalls artists like the Clash, Sham 69, Hold Steady, the Pogues, Sex Pistols, the Saints, Murder By Death.  The Most Lamentable Tragedy is intelligent rock for late-night pub drinking comradery.

Debut full length release from Chicago artist of strangely unpredictable indie pop/rock with eclectic twists of melody, peculiarly exotic instrumental sounds, dreamy pop bits, psychedelic side trips and mysterious journeys into angular, jazzy lounge-pop la-la lands.

Slim Twig is an anomaly.  His 4th album of manipulated musical collages is part of an alien world where the rules of production and musicality are twisted & molded to be consumed by open-eared listeners with alternative brain patterns.  The songs move through industrial noise-lounge soundscapes, experimental show tunes, orchestrated classical interludes, circus metal, psychedelic out-rock distortion and avant-pop melodies.  The press has compared him to Ariel Pink, Ty Segall, Royal Trux & Tame Impala.  Add a bit of Gary War and Peter Ivers and youre in the general area.  Its not an easy listen, but its not supposed to be.  As in life, there is a good amount of confusion and unexplainable occurrences.  Its a bit of a crap shoot, reallyand rolling the dice has always appealed to some of us.  if youre feeling brave, grab a pair and step up to the (turn)table.

5th album from band out of Nottingham, EnglandLorna plays stunningly gorgeous & sweet folky slow-core indie pop with breathy, angelic harmonies and gentle sing-along hooks embedded in a melodic & dreamy twee-pop heaven.  Sometimes recalls bands like Low, Prefab Sprout, American Analogue Set, Mojave 3, Belle & Sebastian, Camera Obscura, The Orange Peels.  Music with a sleepy-time beauty.

8th album, and the first in 15 years, from what appears to now be a one man band (aka Dave Pearce).  True to the title, these are ambient soundscape instrumentals that move from a fascination with minimalist dirge-dream mantras to exploratory psychedelic atmospherics.  Most of the songs glide & drone with the sort of subtle invasiveness that steers an opium dream (or nightmare).  All sounds originate from guitars.  Nice, not particularly memorable.

3rd album from Columbus, Ohio banddriving, hard-edged Stoner rock with classic heavy metal riffs, rock star vocals and a stadium-churning guitar chug.  This is high energy, head-blasting metal that rides a steed-snorting groove into hair-shaking headband Heaven.  Shades of Wo Fat, Fireball Ministry, Mangoo, The Cult, Sasquatch, Truckfighters, Baroness.  Find your saddle or nova-splode, Brothers & Sisters!

Debut album from Athens, Georgia bandquirky indie guitar/keyboard pop that moves from jagged power chords to rootsy synth ballads.  Some of the songs have a retro-melody guitar twang hanging in the air with sweet & subtle vocal harmonies.  Piano keys clang over rumbling drums, then strings and other bizarre sounds introduce manipulated vocals and whistling in a theatrical pop setting.  Sometimes recalls bands like Pavement, Jonathan Richman/Modern Lovers, Ween, Dead Milkmen.  Periscopes in the Air is a peculiarly appealing mix of indie pop with nostalgic influences and tongue-in-cheek experimentalism.

On his 3rd album, Australias Kevin Parker has removed the rock element, opting for a lush soundscape of bubbling, kaleidoscopic pop shimmer.  Its a brave and dangerous move that mostly works.  The albums title, Currents, is a perfect fit for the sound, which has the sort of unpredictable, wavy ebb & flow thats only found below the surface, deep down where few people venture.  In this dark, liquid environment, club tentacles writhe & dance to a beat of mysteriously skewed origin.  The warm, orchestral, multifarious production technique results in the kind of eyes-glazed relaxed absorption brought on by lying underneath a soft waterfall on ecstasy, while neon birds paint the sky with color-trail clouds.  Currents is a radiantly chilled-out psychedelic eruption, colored by subtle tweaks of gently twisted beauty.  Recommended.

Debut album from Swedish band who play gorgeous, effulgent pop songs set against thick, murky, distressed guitar chords that ring with a stunningly precious, distorted poignancy.  A celebratory melodic energy drives the white-noise scratch of pounding rhythms as songs move from the spirit of beautifully chiming guitars and cheery hum-along dream-pop to the roar of shoegaze power-bliss.  Includes members from Makthaverskan.  Sounds a bit like a combination of Ride, Eternal Summers, Slowdive, Veronica Falls, early My Bloody Valentine.  Last Forever is packed with the sort of aggressively happy, edgy indie pop that will put an acknowledging smile on your face and a dark-dreamy bounce in your step.

2nd full-length release from this musician collective with members in the U.S. & England who have also recorded three albums under the band name End Of A Yearplus tons of singles, cassettes, etc. under both names.  Self Defense Family play intelligent, atonal twang guitar punk with vehement socio-political lyrics delivered in a passionate talk/sing vocal frame.  The singer implores with a vein-bulging intensity while guitars spin an accessibly tension-mounting ambience.  Songs sometimes carry a subtle promise of impending pain that dwells as much on atmosphere as it does on anger.  Unexpected and angular psychedelic riffs crawl around behind the voice, painting a droney punk rock soundscape.  Beauty makes a surprise appearance on a dry, gray, cracked aural canvas.  Some similarity to Coliseum, Black Level Embassy, Poison Girlswith a touch of Television and The Fall.  This is music that requires & rewards a closer listen than you might first expect.  Heaven Is Earth holds songs of unusual depth that stretch the expected limits of the punk genre.  Strong.

On their 3rd album, this Norwegian band delivers a dreamy-sweet shoegaze barrage of deep-swirl, oscillating noise-pop.  Beautiful and manipulated voices ride waves of dark, throbbing soundscape rock; alien sounds pervade rhythmic threads in a kaleidoscopic audio invasion.  Creatures call through a psychedelic wash, bathed in the beauty of innovative celestial distortion.  Haunting layers of vocal harmonies lend light to the aural storm of heavenly feedback.  These are luxuriantly dense songs with an epic sense of beauty-as-noise in a universe of pulsating gauze-clouds.  Members have played in Low Frequency In Stereo, Casiokids, Electric Eye.  Reminiscent of bands like My Bloody Valentine, Loveliescrushing, Asobi Seksu, Ringo Deathstarr, Native Lights, Slowdive, Serena Maneesh.  Sun Stare Sound is the kind of pop album that sounds like floating elephants announcing war, resulting in the sort of dreamy, mellifluous cacophony that mesmerizes the ears with narcotic magic.

3rd album from French bandclassy & heavy power metal trio with a muscle-flexing psychedelic twist.  Massive bottom-end drums and behemoth bass guitar runs drive the engine.  The lead work is often subtle and always brilliant.  Atmospheric interludes and fluid rhythmic changes abound.  Trippy sounds are carefully pummeled into the earth hard enough to shake the planet core.  This is metal thats more fierce than brutal; rock music that draws on passion and creativity, molding it into the crunch-worthy strength of a giant warriors fist.  Johan Jaccobs guitar lines are spectacularly innovative with a hallucinatory intensity that weaves in and around the sledgehammer punch of the rhythm section.  Glowsun play intelligent metal rock with a clean & colossal production and a professional finesse that belies the incredible, ultimate heaviness of the album.  Recalls bands like Sungrazer, Colour Haze, The Machine, Helmet.  Beyond the Wall of Time is music to touch the metalhead deep in your elevated macho soul.  Recommended.

Debut release from Seattle band who deliver retro-rock swagger mixed with funky garage rock licks, a big splash of Southern roots rock and plenty of attitude to create an authentically nostalgic rock n roll sound experience.  Shades of The Rolling Stones, The Sweet, Lee Bains & the Glory Fires, Rival Sons, Black Keys.

Debut album from band out of Melbourne, Australiarhythmic, rootsy, drum-driven guitar rockers with a punk-infected pop energy riding on addictively distorted garage melodies.  Yelping cowboy-blues vocals and a throbbing bass line lay down a path for the explosive guitar crunch-riffs to blast the songs into the realm of bounce-around-the-room pulverizing fun.  Shades of Milk, Dead Moon, Bleach, or X (the Los Angeles one) meets Dylan with punk intentions.

5th album (first in nine years and the first one since 1998 with the original line-up) from this Chicago area band is packed with potent, classic female vocal led indie rock.  For me, Veruca Salt always fell in the same category as Smashing Pumpkins:  Everybody I know loved them and I thought they were just pretty good.  Well, either my taste has changed or theyre better than I remember.  Ghost Notes is built with addictively expressive voices, strong melody lines, and solid, ripping rock guitars spitting out some viciously hummable power pop tunes.  The songs sparkle and roar with confidence and the kind of fun-but-muscular melodic density that is so often lacking in indie rock today.  There are no weak tracks here!  Recalls bands like Throwing Muses, The Breeders, Sleater-Kinney, Hole, L7.  It may not be a world-changer, but there is a fresh & vital feel to Ghost Notes that gives it a power I want to experience again and again.  Recommended.

I am a big fan of the shirts this company makes. They are some of the most comfortable shirts I've worn and they pretty much get the message across of how I feel about the 2nd amendment and liberty. I buy these larger than I need because: 1) I conceal carry and I need to make sure it stays hidden and 2) these shirts do shrink over time. They don't shrink on the first wash but after a few times they do. I just need to make sure they stay big enough for me to continue to conceal my gun and knives.

*I was provided a free sample of the product in exchange for an honest review. My opinions are my own and I have not been compensated in any way.*This shower head is easy enough to install. I won't put any instructions here, there are plenty of places to find them if you need directions on how to put this in. You can probably figure it out by looking at it.Here's what you need to know. You get what you pay for. This works and works well but it is not heavy duty at all. I haven't had it long enough to test longevity but everything about it is cheap plastic and you can tell right out of the box that that's what it is. Understand that there is a good possibility that it probably won't last a super long time. If you live in an area with a lot of minerals in the water (like I do), that will probably make it worse. It's good if you just need to get a new shower head right now for whatever reason. If you're looking for a durable, long-term shower head, I would recommend in investing in something heavier duty.*UPDATED 10/25/2015*The company contacted me and asked me to change my review to a five star review. Of course, I'm not going to do that, it is unethical. They asked for an honest review and I gave it but apparently what they really wanted was just to get five star reviews. This is NOT a five star item. It is a three star item and I feel like I'm being generous. This may explain why it has so many five star reviews.

Corel Paintshop Pro X8 is a graphic editing software package that gives you some powerful tools but at a fraction of the cost of Photoshop. As a caveat, Photoshop is also far more robust but much of that power is not needed for the average user. The important thing here is that the "average user" does not necessarily mean a beginner. If you are not familiar with how graphical editing programs work, you're going to have a learning curve regardless of what you use. For me, Corel is easier simply because I don't need everything that Photoshop offers. If I was doing advanced editing for a photography company or magazine, then yes, Photoshop would be for me.The only reason I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 is the installation. I don't know about other users, but it was a pain. I'm not new to installing software. But when I went to set this up, it brought up an interface where I had to put in info to get a code only I didn't get a code. I had to jump through hoops. I finally got it figured out and installed but it was extremely annoying. Other than that, this is a good program.

*I received this item free of charge in exchange for an unbiased review.*The CopperJoint compression sleeve is a thin material that you slide over your arm to cover and compress around the elbow. To put it to the test, I had a friend of mine put it on because he has elbow issues and we trained in Krav Maga. The sleeve didn't roll up or shift which is good, considering we were training in ground based techniques which involve a lot of rolling and tumbling.The sleeve doesn't have any nasty odors or anything like that. No weird things fell out of it and there were no complaints of it being too tight or anything like that. The wearer reported that he really didn't feel much different in his elbow than normal but that could be because of the level of his old injury and it might be beyond the scope of this compression sleeve to offer relief. It's probably more effective for lesser pain and issues.

*I received this item free of charge for an unbiased review.*Tempered Glass screen protectors offer far more protection for your phone screen than the traditional, cheaper plastic ones. They can take an impact and save your actual screen. It may break the protector but if that keeps your screen from getting broken, it's done a good job.The LaoHe Tempered Glass screen protector includes a wet wipe to remove excess dirt, and then a dry wipe. There were still streaks after the use of the dry wipe (it's not microfiber, it's the same material as the wet wipe only it's dry). I used my T-Shirt to dry it. Once the screen was cleaned, I lined the protector up and laid it down on the phone. It sticks nicely and looks great. I didn't need to use anything to squeeze out the bubbles. It covers just above the ear speaker to just below the home button but it doesn't cover 100% of the face (it does cover the part that you'll touch). It might be designed this way purposefully to be compatible with cases, I really don't know.Once it's on, the feel of the screen protector feels like you are touching a phone screen. Some cheap plastic ones change the feel of the phone but this one keeps the original feel of it. Overall, it's a good screen protector.

I was excited to get a plate carrier relatively cheap. The problem is, the item that arrived had no area to put a plate. None. I'm not sure if it it was a mistake or not but I see by other reviews that I'm not the only one that this happened to. A plate carrier means it should have actual places to put armor plates. There was nothing. What I got would only be useful as a tactical vest for the MOLLE straps.

*This product was provided free of charge in exchange for an unbiased review.*These USB cables are made of strong nylon and feel nice and durable. The plugs themselves fee; solid and I haven't had a problem with them breaking. This is a three pack of different colored cables. This makes it easier to tell what's plugged into what, especially when you have a bunch of USB devices in the same area (which I do). The colors aren't exactly as pictured, but this type of coloration is difficult to duplicate on the computer (colors aren't nearly as bright in real life). Regardless, I don't have them to look pretty, I have them so I can easily follow which device is plugged in where so if I need to remove it, I don't have to fight with a bunch of other cables that are plugged into the HUB.

This book is an entertaining compilation of one liners and sayings that many of us are thinking but few every utter aloud. It's an amusing read while you're in a waiting room, chilling somewhere, etc. It's not something that's in depth but it's a good way to get a quick laugh or kill some time while you wait for something.

I purchased this magnifier to go with my EOTech XPS2-300 Whisper/Blackout red dot. The decision to go with the Vortex instead of an EOTech magnifier was based on previous reviews indicating that it's just as good for a fraction of the price. After testing the combination myself I concur with that assessment.To start, the Vortex magnifier is well built. It feels nice and solid. The hinges for flipping it to the side are well built. Mounting it was a snap. I didn't need any risers or anything like that. I just put it on and then put the EOTech on, sighted it in, and it works like a charm. Flipping the magnifier to the side is easy. I just reach up with my left hand, push the button with my thumb and roll the optic to the side with my fingers and then grab the forward pistol grip that I have mounted to the rifle. Same process to flip it back into place so it's easy to transition from close quarters to distance.This magnifier is definitely a gem and is one of those rare times where the cheaper item is just as good. I highly recommend this.

The Fobus paddle holster is a convenient, quick clip on holster. Simply take it and slide it onto your pants and you're ready to go. These are my impressions:1. The holster stays in place well. Drawing from it didn't dislodge it.2. It's easy to take off but does require two hands so if it's on right, it won't just slip off unless the material your clothes are made out of are very slick.3. The gun feels secure in the holster. I wouldn't recommend hanging upside down like a bat but you should be able to move around with no problem. If you have baggy or loose fitting gym shorts you may have a problem, simply due to the weight of the firearm.4. It does not have a locking mechanism or anything like that so if you were to wear this in an area that allows open carry, it would be easy for someone else to remove it. Always be aware of your surroundings.I got this holster mainly to attend training sessions and as a spare to lend so a range buddy who might not have one. I also use it as a "get ready quick" item. If something were to happen, I could slip this on and the Fobus mag pouch very quickly and be ready to confront whatever trouble pops up. Also, if I store a loaded Glock in a quick action safe, I store it in a holster so the trigger is sealed. This holster certainly has its uses. If you live in an open carry state and are going to go out in public (or if you do security and are appropriately licensed to do so), you should probably at minimum get a level 2 holster for that. Otherwise, it's a good holster to have handy.

I purchased this double mag paddle pouch to be able to quickly put it on and take it off when necessary. This includes trainings or if something happens and I need to get ready quickly. Here is my impression:1. I have a double mag pouch that attaches via belt loops. Though it is not easy to put on or take off quickly, it does keep the magazines close to my side so when I drop my shirt over it, it's concealed. The Fobus pouch doesn't do that. They stick out too far and imprint too much so I don't use it for concealed carry.2. It slips on nice and easily and stays on for me.3. I used 9mm and .40 caliber Glock magazines (Glock 17, 19, and 23) and it works great. The magazines stay seated as I move around and the holster doesn't get pulled up when I remove a magazine quickly for a combat reload.4. If I'm already wearing my regular pouch, this is great to quickly hand to someone else in a session at the range so we can work on drills (I always like to have spare gear).5. It is easy to take off but requires two hands as it does stay on securely.This is a good overall mag pouch. Though I don't use it for concealed carry, it's good in training sessions or to get ready quickly if trouble finds its way to where you are. It seems well made, nothing that strikes me as something that's going to break quickly.

*This is a review of a free product*The VicTsing is an adjustable, programmable, 9 button gaming mouse. The device itself seems to be sturdy yet lightweight. I haven't pounded on it the way a lot of people do, mainly because I just don't do that. The buttons feel crisp and resilient. it slides around on the desk nicely. The cord is strong. It even has LEDs on the inside so it lights up (and you can customize how it does that).In the pictures you can see the software on how to customize it. First of all, when you plug it in, it works as a basic mouse so you don't have to install drivers in order to get it running. The software it comes with (mini CD) is easy to use. On the basic settings, you can set up the DPI settings and customize the buttons (and you can have two pre-programmed modes in case you want to set up macros or button combinations for different games). Under the advanced settings, you can adjust mouse speed, scrolling speed, double click speed, and set up macros for customized button responses.In actual use the mouse feels natural to grasp. The buttons are all in easy to reach places and it shouldn't be difficult to get used to their locations. Overall, this is a good deal, especially if you're a gamer on a budget.

I bought these after I ran out of Dollar Store floss picks. I went by the Oral-B name and thought I was getting something good. I was wrong. These are literally the worst floss picks I've ever used, I go through five or six in one sitting because they break so easily. Matter of fact, I had two break in a row just a few minutes ago trying to get between the same two teeth! And they're not pushed close together either! I should've stuck with the dollar store ones.

Nerf does it again, this time with a bow and arrow set. I've gotten several of the Nerf blasters, so this is an interesting change. I decided to get this because the cheaper, non-Nerf bow and arrow were destroyed quite quickly. I decided to give this one a try.It has a cylindrical "cartridge", kind of like the revolver of bows and arrows. It holds six rounded tipped arrows (won't break windows or penetrate skin or anything like that but the tips are plastic, not foam so they might hurt if hit from up close). Someone can fire one arrow after the other, but after that, you'll have to reload (the set comes with six arrows total).Durability wise, this thing has been dropped on the concrete patio, tossed to the ground, thrown in a pile of toys, etc, and thus far nothing has broken. The "string" is thick and doesn't seem to be getting wrecked (only time will tell with this one). The only issue is that the arrows along the shaft are thin. Step on them, and they're through. Other than that, I haven't found any complaints at this point. It's overall a decent addition to the Nerf reputare.

I train in Krav Maga on a regular basis and I train with several people. We wear out equipment from beating the hell out of it. So when I was given the opportunity to evaluate these sparring gloves, I could not pass them up.First and foremost, these are boxing gloves. It means, either you're boxing or if you're sparring in a fighting style, you will be throwing basic strikes because the fancier stuff won't be possible. But sometimes that's just what you need. Learn to move and jab. In that case, these work well. They're padded well and have been holding up to sparring quite well. They stay on securely and haven't given a problem. The only test that I have yet to put them through is the test of time. I don't know what that will yield. If I have anything to note, I'll update the review at that point. Beyond that, it's a good pair of gloves.

The Seaside Knitters' series definitely offers a good deal of small town atmosphere, shared friendships, and strong family life.  I've followed the series since the beginning, mainly because I enjoy these connections, but the mystery itself is usually somewhat less important.  I would recommend this installment to readers who have read at least some of the previous books in the series.  There are about 50 characters (fortunately there's a list at the beginning, but it's still a lot!), and there's an interesting mystery, but in my opinion, it takes second place.I was surprised that one young member of the family (Gabby) was inexplicably missing this time.  She was prominent in the last book, so what happened to her?  That seems to be a mystery on its own.  Once again, there is a knitting pattern supplied without a picture, making it difficult to use.  A website is given too, but I looked, and apparently it has been moved.  It would be so simple to add a line drawing of the nice pattern at the end of each book for the knitters who follow the series.

The 5th in the Ashton Corners Book Club mysteries, this one is a strong addition to it.  I've followed the series since the beginning, mainly because I thought the first one (A Killer Read) showed a lot of promise.  This one for me ranks as highly as A Killer Read.  Its main strength comes from the individuality of the characters in the book club--men and women, old and young, with contrasting personalities.  The two cats, Edam and Brie, are more in evidence this time too, and I thought that was a nice plus.  Two small regrets are that there isn't really much sense of place in this series, other than the fact that we know it takes place in the South. Also, in this book, the "outside" characters are quite important, and I always think that makes it hard to keep readers' interest.  We care about the characters we know best, and I usually prefer to see them as central to the plot throughout.The lists of mysteries at the end that each character likes are quite fun, and there is also a preview of the author's new series, where she will be writing as Linda Wiken.  It is based on books too, but cookbooks this time, and a group of characters who arrange a meal based on a chosen cookbook.  No title was given for this new book, but I intend to watch for it.  The writing is consistently good in the present series, and I think the new one sounds promising too.

This new series that features six seniors who have decided to live together and share their strengths and good company has several strong features.  Who doesn't enjoy reading about characters each of whom has different abilities and a singular personality?  Sherry's niece, Nixy, visits the small community and adds her share of deduction and common sense, mixed with a bit of light romance.I found the pace a bit slow overall, owing mainly to a lot of dialogue (maybe this is inevitable when you have so many main characters), and not many suspects.  Also, the victim's death is described on the back cover, so we know it will take place, but it doesn't actually happen until the middle of the book.  To me, that slowed the pace considerably.Apart from these criticisms, the book and the series seem to show some promise, so I'll continue with it and see how it develops.  Readers who enjoy Southern hospitality and charm, around which many cozies are set nowadays, will find this one entertaining too.

This is the third book in the cozy "quilting mystery" series, and I think it's the best thus far.  It has an independent protagonist, Martha Rose, who is smart and capable; along with her quilting buddies, Lucy and Birdie, she manages to sort out clues in a plot that has some originality.  I enjoy the references to quilting in this series; they are more sophisticated than what one finds in some other quilting mysteries, and in this case, the involvement of a historically significant quilt was very interesting.  The cat Bumper and the dog Arthur are good additions too.What has held me back from enjoying this series completely is Martha's personality and especially her romantic relationship.  Both she and her boyfriend, Crusher, seem to rely on physical attraction and scarcely talk to each other about the commitments they would, or would not like to make.  I'm still on the borderline with this series, and I'm trying to convince myself that it isn't essential to like everything about the principal character.  I'll stick with the series, mainly because I found this one to be the strongest one yet in terms of plot development, deduction, and ongoing suspense.  Recommended then, especially to quilters, with small reservations on my part.

This is the second installment in the Lighthouse Library Mystery series, and I think it is a good contribution that will keep me interested in the series.  The lighthouse as a backdrop for the library adds some originality, and the writing is good.  Charles, the library cat, is also a fine addition. He doesn't really take part in the action, but his intuition about the library patrons is quite interesting, and he's clearly intelligent and popular.  Lucy, the protagonist, is smart and capable, and the mystery unfolds well.  There aren't really any deductive clues to be had, but the possible suspects are identified.  I agree with another reader that the ghost tales don't really add anything; some readers may enjoy a bit of diversion there, but I would be happy if they disappeared.  We could afford to have more capers with Charlie the cat instead, but then that's only my view.  It's a good series with some originality, and I look forward to the next one.

The fourth installment in this "book collector" series has the outward elements of a cozy, but it also has a great deal of originality in the makeup of the characters, the way the plot is carefully designed, and a slight quirkiness to the characters.  I am a devoted followed of the series now, but I admit that I wasn't always fully on board with the quirky side of Jordan, the main character, and her "outlaw" family, nor did I understand her employer, the elderly and very crotchety Vera Van Alst. I did like The Sayers Swindle (book #2) very much, and this one is also outstanding.  The series overall a very strong one, as long as readers don't expect every character to be entirely believable and rational all the time.  We learn more about the characters in each new book, and although it isn't essential to read them all, it will add to one's pleasure, for sure. In this book, I especially enjoyed the part that Jordan's friend Lance, the librarian, played in the investigation.  This series is a real winner, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys an unpredictable plot and many surprises.

I'm following this series, although this is only the third one I've read.  I think I may have missed one or more, but it really doesn't matter.  They can easily be read alone, so I wouldn't hesitate to recommend them on that basis.I do like this series, probably most for its interesting setting--a side-by-side caf and a weaver's shop.  Della, the protagonist, and her friend Jenny run the two shops, and there is also Matthew, Della's boyfriend, who is an ex-FBI man.  Della seems to me to be a bit insecure, or perhaps just immature, and she hasn't demonstrated any deductive skills as yet.  These traits made this mystery move a little too slowly in the second half of the book, and the person responsible for the crime was too easy for readers to identify.  However, I'll stick with the series for now; the reading about weaving is quite interesting--Navaho designs in this installment--and the writing is engaging enough to keep me coming back.

I thought the location (Vermont) and the Scottish charm of this series sounded promising.  The book isn't advertised as a ghost story, and it wasn't until I read the brief summary on the back cover that I saw a "spectre" mentioned.  It didn't sound as if the paranormal was going to take over the story, so I decided to give it a try.  The beginning, which took place in Scotland, was quite fascinating.  Then, back in Vermont, it became a ghost story, and the ghost became the main character--or at least the dominant one.  For me, that was a turn-off.Nevertheless, I did finish the book.  The author writes well, and the plot unfolded well too.  It was a little disjointed at times, I thought, and so much of the book revolved around the disparity between the ghost's 13th-century understanding and modern life that it got tiring.  The end was surprising in some ways, and I would say that if you love ghost stories, you might enjoy this one.  I might try one more book in the series, just to give it a chance, but so far it seems like the wrong choice for me.

This new series has several features that make it attractive: an interesting setting in a library that is in an old lighthouse, an exhibit of rare Jane Austen books, and a library cat named Charles.  The main character, Lucy, is tolerable, but I agree with some other reviewers that she doesn't use deduction and at times is a little flaky.  It's only the first book in the series, though, so I'm willing to give it another try with the next one, since the other features were intriguing, and the ending was also quite a surprise.  I always like that in a cozy mystery, since there are often similarities in the plots within this genre.  So, all in all, I enjoyed it and look forward to the next one.

I've read all but one of the 6 books in this cookie cutter shop mystery.  Somehow I missed "Cookies and Scream," but I think I'll wait a while before going back to that one.  It isn't that I don't enjoy the series; there are things I like about it, such as the good friendship between Olivia and Maddie, and their cookie cutter shop.  The little Yorky, Spunky, is a cute addition, and there are other characters who are also well-drawn.  My main objection is that there is a great deal of detail not only about cookie-making, but also about cookie-eating.  Everyone seems to eat cookies all day long, and it gets a bit tiring to read about it again and again.  The mystery itself is OK, without surprises but still fairly engaging.  It's just cookie overload that makes me want to pause before reading any more in the series.  I think the series would benefit from a trim--fewer cookies for everyone.

This is the 8th book in the Miniature Mystery series, and like the others, it is beautifully written, full of colorful atmosphere, and centered around retired English teacher, Gerry Porter, and her precocious 11-year-old grand daughter, Maddie.  Their usual home is Lincoln Point, CA, but for this installment, they visit New York City, and the mystery unfolds there.  I would recommend this series highly to readers who are interested in miniatures or crafting in general, and to readers who especially enjoy a plot in which family and relationships are of prime importance.  For me, it's the fine writing and the interesting detail about miniatures that keeps me coming back to this particular series.I am even more enthusiastic about the author's other two series--the Mathematical Mysteries (written as Ada Madison) and the older one, the Periodic Table Mysteries (written under her own name, Camille Minichino).  For my taste, there is more development and change in the characters in the latter two series.  Nevertheless, Manhattan in Miniature is a fine contribution to this series, and I highly recommend the other two series as well.

A new cozy mystery series is always fun to try out, and this one will be attractive especially to readers who are interested in needlework.  The members of the needlepoint group (both men and women) are diverse and well-portrayed.  The main character, Angie, is not a needlepointer herself, although she is sharp, capable, and caring.  The problem for me was the writing. There are many very short sentences that produce the sort of reading that one can do very quickly.  That may appeal to some readers, but it's not my personal taste.  I prefer to have good local atmosphere, vivid description, and more depth to the main characters.I did feel that the writing became stronger as the plot unfolded.  There was some suspense (although it's hard to establish much suspense in a 20-year-old cold case), and the outcome surprised me.  That's enough for me to try the next installment when it comes out.  I like to give a new series a chance, but even the cat Juno doesn't hang around much in this one.  I did like the historical side of needlepoint samplers and the quotes from them at the beginnings of chapters.  If that aspect is expanded upon in future books, it could be a promising series.

The mysteries in the China Bayles series are always complex and engaging from beginning to end.  I've read them all, and Bittersweet is a fine contribution.  Each time I read one though, I think it's the best, and then the next one comes along, and it seems equally good, but always different from the rest too.  There's no need to read them in order, but the more you read, the more you'll want to read them all.  The rugged beauty of the Texas countryside and issues around invasive plant and animal species are especially well-done this time around, and the characters have depth and interest.  Issues around women and their societal role also permeate the book, and China's multi-faceted personality is important to the resolution.One suggestion for readers who have not yet started this book: don't read the full advertising blurb on this website (or on the paper cover of the book) if you don't care for spoilers.  One of the events mentioned there happens only 50 pages from the end of the book, and for me it hung like a cloud as I was reading the book.  Some other events happen well into the plot too, so I'd say ignore that bit of advertising and just enjoy the way the plot unfolds.  There's plenty of suspense, and it's more enjoyable if you don't know what's coming.

I'm very pleased with this pie pan.  I've used it so far in a regular oven for making quiche for 2 people.  It works beautifully. The pan is not super-heavy, but it's heavy enough to allow the quiche to bake evenly, and the decorated lip on the top is very handy when forming the top of the crust.  It washes up well in the dishwasher, and it hasn't scratched from the utensils I used to cut the pie slices.  It is perhaps a little trickier to get the first piece out, as one reviewer mentioned, but I find if I use a smaller-than-normal spatula, it works fine.  I plan to buy another one--I love it!

I enjoyed this debut mystery in the Spice Shop series and would recommend it especially for readers who have visited Seattle or who enjoy plenty of atmosphere and sense of place in their mysteries.  I have only been to Seattle once, but the depth of experience and description in this book brought back many pleasant memories.  The author makes readers feel as if they are there, taking in the sights, smells, and sounds of the bustling market scene.  The main character, Pepper Reece, is clever, independent, and good at deduction.  There is a good deal of suspense, and despite the fact that there were many characters introduced in the book, there were only a few possible suspects, so I didn't find it difficult to keep them straight.  Also, the important characters are well-defined, so the plot unfolds nicely.  I look forward to the continuation of this series; it's off to a strong start.

This is the 11th book in the Martha's Vineyard mystery series, and like many other readers, I enjoy the character who is the sleuth, 92-year-old Victoria Trumbull.  For many of us, she is the main reason to pursue this series.  She is quick-witted, lively, writes prose and poetry, and knows the history of her island and its people very well.  I've read all the books in the series, and Jack in the Pulpit and Touch-Me-Not were my favorites, but all of them have a strong sense of place and lovely description of the seasons and rugged terrain around the island.  Every now and then, I find myself pausing to appreciate a particularly fine turn of phrase or an unusual sentence.  That doesn't happen very often in cozy mysteries, and it's one of the pleasures here.I would recommend this particular installment for readers who are boating enthusiasts, because a good deal of it takes place on the water in various types of boats.  The plot hinges around a university setting this time, where Victoria has been invited to teach a poetry course, and the various pieces of the plot unfold over the pros and cons of tenure for faculty.  The one part that didn't appeal to me this time was the way that the ending was not tied up for all characters.  In my opinion, there should have been another brief chapter to do that; it just doesn't feel resolved.  However, there was a good deal of suspense, and the ending surprised me, so those features are certainly praiseworthy.

As the second book in the fixer-upper mystery series, This Old Homicide was an improvement over the initial one (A High-End Finish), in my opinion.  The sense of how time passed was clearer in this one, and for the most part, the many threads of the plot were woven quite well into the mystery.  I thought that the men in the story were portrayed better and with more depth than the women were, which is a bit unusual for a cozy mystery.  Shannon, the protagonist, has an interesting job as a contractor, and the descriptions of the renovations she is involved in are well-done.Nevertheless, I prefer the other series that this author writes--the bibliophile mysteries--which is longstanding and carries quite a lot of suspense.  This one may continue to improve, but for now, it seems to have too many threads, too many characters, and not enough clever deduction.

I wasn't certain whether round shoelaces would stay tied, but they are wonderful.  No problem whatsoever with staying tied, and the 54" length is perfect for my New Balance ladies' walking shoes.  The NB shoes actually came with 56" laces, which were a tad long, so these are better. The tan color is just slightly darker than the ones that came with the shoes, but they are actually a better match.  I couldn't be happier and wouldn't hesitate to order these laces again in one of the awesome bright colors!

This is the third book in the Deadly Notions mystery series, which is named for the antiques/needlework shop that the protagonist, Daisy, runs called Sometimes a Great Notion. Daisy is in her 50s, a retired history teacher, and her interest in antiques and samplers is useful to her in this book.  There are several interesting characters too--both men and women--and there is a good deal of suspense.  The dog, Jasper, is a nice addition, and there are cats that belong to friends.  The cats stay pretty much in the background, but the whole small-town atmosphere is nicely portrayed, and the cheerful home life setting around Thanksgiving is well-done. Daisy's husband, Joe, who is a fine cook and woodworker, is also portrayed with depth and interest.I'm enjoying this author's writing. Although I read the 3 books out of order, it doesn't seem to matter in this particular case. The characters are all well-done, and the endings have been a surprise.  Daisy is a wise person, and she often states little words of philosophy that I find quite interesting and often uplifting.  The series is enjoyable, and I would recommend it to mystery readers.

Having enjoyed Indian food at restaurants for many years, I also wanted to learn to cook some dishes at home. That is the stated purpose of this book, so it sounded like a good start.  I also ordered Vij's Elegant and Inspired Indian Cuisine, which is a much more expensively-produced book with excellent recipes that are special and inspiring.  Both books are based on restaurant food, but in other ways they are miles apart.  I am not sorry that I purchased Curry Magic, but so far, I am not inspired by it.  I will use it mainly for condiment recipes--chutney and raitas--which are abundant and interesting.I have 2 reasons for not being inspired by most of the recipes in this book.  One is that many come directly from restaurants and are geared toward high-volume preparation.  Some call for "garam masala gravy," which is given as a separate recipe that includes 10 ingredients, 3 of which are separate purees of garlic, ginger, and onion.  Once made, this gravy is enough for 40 portions of curry, and one is supposed to put it in 10 molds and freeze it, then use it in other recipes in the book.  After doing all this, one is then prepared to make Chicken Dhansak (chicken cooked with lentils and vegetables), for example, which lists 8 ingredients in addition to the chicken and assorted vegetables.  One of the ingredients is "Akhni stock", which one would need to have on hand too (or use water).  One ingredient is "curry masala gravy" which one would have to have made previously too. The other reason is that there are a great many ingredients that one needs in the pantry but are only used infrequently.  Again, this is not inspiring to me.These steps complicated the recipes, in my view, at least for the home cook, who might prepare an Indian meal occasionally but not every night.  For restaurants, of course they can use the "gravy" constantly, but home cooks might not want to keep it on hand or make it and freeze it.  In comparison, Vij's Elegant and Inspired Indian Cuisine is much simpler, with only a few spices and mostly fresh ingredients.  My level of inspiration rises when I look through those recipes, but I find the ones in Curry Magic daunting.  This is of course merely a personal reaction.  Again, this book is reasonably priced (with only a few color photos), and for the cook who likes to spend plenty of time in the kitchen and who prepares Indian food often, it's probably worth pursuing.

Unlike many other reviewers, I have not had the pleasure of dining in the restaurant in Vancouver from which the recipes in this book come.  I do enjoy Indian food very much, and I would like to learn to cook some dishes at home as well as understand some of the methods used in Indian cooking.  This books satisfies those desires very well, and I would highly recommend it if you want to go beyond the basics but still want a relatively simple approach to authentic Indian cooking.  The explanations in this book are outstanding about why certain foods go together, which ingredients are better for certain types of dishes, and even which wines go best with each dish.Recipes that I have tried so far have all been excellent.  I agree with reviewers who have said that there is more salt and more water in some recipes, and I tend to reduce both of these ingredients as I cook. One can add more later, if they are needed.  Otherwise, even though some recipes read as if they might be highly spiced, they are not, in my opinion.  I follow them exactly the first time I make them (lessening the water and salt), and they are excellent.  For example, I've tried the chicken breast in coconut-chickpea flour curry, in which the chicken turned out moist and had a lovely tartness because of tamarind paste in the curry.  The cilantro-mint chicken curry is also very special and is one of the easiest recipes too.  I will make it often. The vegetable recipes are interesting too; for me, the cauliflower-rice pilaf was great, with its inclusion of cloves, cumin, turmeric, and cilantro.  Proportions for the ingredients in these recipes are often very important. Most of them serve 6 people, but I often make half the first time, and that has caused me no problem.The photos and commentary are both outstanding, and there are so many recipes that I intend to try.  I recommend this book highly for anyone who enjoys Indian cuisine.

I follow all three of Sheila Connolly's mystery series: the Orchard series, the Museum series, and this one, the County Cork series.  An Early Wake is the third in the Cork series.  My favorite was Scandal in Skibbereen, which was the second installment, and I was hoping for more in the present one. The best feature of Ms. Connolly's books is the depth of historical background, and in the case of this series, which is set in Ireland, there is tremendous possibility for description, beauty, folklore, and history, which could make a wonderful backdrop to a good mystery.  Unfortunately, it just isn't there in this installment.The protagonist, Maura, is a young American who has inherited a pub from a relative who died in Ireland.  In the first three books, she has been gradually adapting to life in a small town, new customs and vocabulary, and new people. All of these activities could add interest for readers, but I don't find Maura to be a very likable person.  She criticizes the two men who express interest in her for not being able to communicate, but she herself is a poor communicator too.  This does not make for pleasant reading while the three of them try to sort out what, if any, personal feelings they may have for each other. Also, nearly all the action takes place within the pub, so the Irish atmosphere arises mainly from the accents that appear in the dialogue.  Those too get tiring to read.I would recommend this installment if you follow the series and want to keep up with Maura's life.  Otherwise, I'd say skip this one and perhaps try one of Ms. Connolly's other series.  The Orchard series is a better bet, on the whole, than this one, in my opinion.

This series about Minnie Hamilton, assistant director of a library in a small town in Michigan, has been a strong one from the beginning.  She is dedicated to her job and to the idea of running a Bookmobile, and she has friends and an aunt who support her and provide assistance.  Her boss, the library's director, can be an obstacle to her progress, but she is resourceful and intelligent, and most of all she has a positive approach to life.  The cat, Eddie, is of course a real winner; his personality is special.  He began as a stowaway on the Bookmobile but now is a regular part of the routine, and library patrons (including 5-year-olds) love him.This installment has more detail about Minnie's life and quite a lot of description.  For me, that gave her character more depth and interest, but I can also understand that some readers may find that it's too much detail.  Eddie the cat is there throughout too, with many interactions that I found very engaging, but again, perhaps it's a lot for some readers who don't dote on cats.  In any case, if you're a follower of this series, I don't think you'll be disappointed; this one is every bit as good as the first two are.  Each one can stand alone, but the series is so interesting that I recommend reading them all.  Each one has unique features and characters that make the events believable.

I was prepared for a small toy, so I wasn't surprised by the size, but this little dog is only 6" from nose to tip of the tail and 4" tall.  The one I received stands up more than the picture shows and is in a very cute, playful pose.  The toy is well-made and very, very soft, but still sturdy.  It's just right for little hands, and I'm delighted to be able to give it as a gift.

The central idea for this new series is a familiar one in cozy mysteries: the protagonist is a young, clever woman who is not entirely happy with her life in a big city, and she inherits property (in this case, a fabric store) in a small town.  She must first decide whether to move to the new town or not, and inevitably of course, a murder happens to complicate the picture.  Happily, Diane Vallere has added a different spin to some of these events, and her new "material witness" mystery series shows promise.Some other reviewers have noted already that the protagonist's name, Polyester, seems like a poor choice.  I agree, but she does call herself Poly and encourages others to use that name. It's a small point. Poly is an independent risk-taker who cares about her family and family memories.  She doesn't seem to trust anyone at all, and that for me was a shortcoming. She accuses people she meets of some of the crimes that take place, and when it becomes clear that they couldn't have done it, she doesn't even apologize.  Her soft side is there though when she takes care of the two very cute kittens who were abandoned.I thought the characters were interesting, and the best part was that there was plenty of suspense.  The author often leaves an unsolved event or surprise at the end of a chapter, making one want to read on immediately.  I liked that.  I would recommend this series especially to readers who sew, or who like fabrics and design.  The author clearly has expertise in these areas, and the way she includes mention of them in the plot is quite fascinating.

I have followed this Library Lover's Series from Jenn McKinlay and enjoyed the previous installments, but I have to agree with some other reviewers who find the love triangle in this installment too prevalent.  The two men, both of whom want the affections of the librarian, Lindsey Norris, are now spending time with each other (when they're not busy chasing her), and they are trying to foil each other's attempts for attention.  It's amusing to a point, but the lack of any real change is tiring.There are a couple of action scenes, mainly on the water rather than in or around the library, and for readers who look for that in their cozy mysteries, this one delivers on that score.  However, the mystery is otherwise rather thin, and the love triangle is very prevalent, so all in all, it's a slow plot.  I'm winding down on this series, but I do like Ms. McKinlay's newer Hat Shop Mysteries.  If you're new to her books. I'd say give that series a try first.

This is the second in a new quilting series, and it has some strong features.  The author manages to create a protagonist, Martha Rose, who is gutsy and has an outgoing, caring personality.  There are several ways that Jewish customs and food come into the story, and that aspect helps to bring some of the characters closer together.  I enjoyed the setting near Los Angeles, and the three quilting friends--Martha, Lucy, and Birdie--have a close relationship.  For quilters, this series is fun, because the author actually appears to have a good knowledge of quilting, and her references to it add something to the background.On the other hand, Martha Rose's personality grated on me a bit, and I didn't like some of the decisions she made.  I'll stick with this series for the next book, because the first two books were satisfying in some ways, but unless Martha works out some of her problems in a more reasonable way, I don't think I'll be around for long.  I would recommend the series to quilters in particular, but a few reservations prevent me from giving it unqualified praise.
