This is the fifteenth book in the Dorothy Martin series, and readers who know the protagonists, Dorothy Martin and her husband Alan Nesbitt, will enjoy their close relationship and co-operative sleuthing.  I've read all the books in this series, and I find that I'm beginning to tire a bit of Dorothy's judgmental attitudes and snippy responses.  I suspect the author is trying to portray Dorothy as an aging but independent woman, but I find that her personality lacks warmth.  She claims to have friends, and she and Alan are (for once) at home in Sherebury in this book, but the aged Jane, her neighbor, is the only friend that seems to be there, and Jane is not very likeable either.  Alan seems like the sensible one, but we hear less from him, even though he is certainly highly regarded by the Sherebury residents and the police.  The mystery itself is not especially compelling this time; it mainly revolves around the very political atmosphere that grows up during the choice of a new bishop.There is some suspense, at least, but given that the victim dies on page 1, it's difficult for readers to gain a full picture of who he was and why Dorothy and Alan should investigate his death.  I would recommend this installment only to readers who follow the series, or perhaps to readers who might enjoy a mystery steeped in church politics.  There is a great deal of that in this mystery, perhaps a little too much for me.  I do enjoy this series in general, though, and I will look forward to the next one, hoping that Dorothy finds it possible to be more likeable.

This needlecraft mystery series has moved to the top of my favorites with this installment, the 18th in the series.  There is never a feeling of repetition in the plots in Ms. Ferris's books, and we always learn something new about familiar characters: Betsy (owner of Crewel World, a needlecraft store), her boyfriend Connor, and various friends and co-workers, including of course her important colleague, Godwin.  What is unique, as far as I know, about this series as compared with others that also deal with knitting, crocheting, or other needlecrafts, is that Ms. Ferris sometimes includes some societal issues in the plot and connects them in some way to a particular type of needle work, in this case crocheting.  The murder victim is an individual known for being a hoarder (or a "collector," as he described himself), and the plot treats that characteristic in a very sympathetic way, showing how it can affect other peoples' lives even when they may not know the hoarder.This deeper meaning of the plot is similar to what Ms. Ferris did in Threadbare, which dealt with homelessness and also stood out for me as a very special work in the series.  I would recommend Darned If You Do very highly to readers of cozy mysteries in general, but if you enjoy needle work, you will find it even more appealing.The writing is vivid and interesting, and there is a good amount of suspense.  The two cats, Sophie and Thai, each have distinctive personalities too, and their presence makes for enjoyable reading.  It's all very well-done, and the description is first-rate throughout.

I've been using this masher for a couple of months now, and I love it.  When it first arrived, I thought it was a bit large and heavy, but I was convinced immediately that it did mash potatoes to a nice fluffy consistency, very close to what a ricer would do.  I often use it for carrots too, and that works fine.  As long as the vegetables are cooked to a soft stage, they come out fluffy and evenly mashed.Today I was using it again, and I discovered that if you rock the masher slightly from side to side as you mash, it works much quicker and better!  The potatoes don't get pressed down too much either. They're even fluffier than usual.  Try it!  You might be as surprised as I was.The masher cleans up nicely in the dishwasher, but it's easy to clean by hand too.  No worries there, and the stainless steel is good quality.

Cozy mystery readers know that there's a certain risk in buying the first book in a new series. The idea of trying out a new series by an author whom you already know appeals to me more, because I am always hopeful that the features I already like in her books will transfer to this one. Unfortunately, it didn't work out that way for me this time.I follow Ms. Carlisle's "Bibliophile Mystery" series, where the protagonist is smart, creative, and a risk-taker.  The protagonist in this new series, Shannon Hammer, has potential--she's a general contractor and skilled at renovating Victorian homes.  That part works for me. However, I felt that most of the other women in the mystery were rather shallow.  Their interests and personalities just weren't cleverly portrayed.The mystery itself started off well too, I thought: an unusual murder, lots of suspects, good reasons to investigate further, and even a dog and cat that provided some diversion for Shannon. Unfortunately, these good points didn't hold throughout the book.  I found it hard to follow the time that had elapsed in the book, but as far as I could tell, the dog and cat disappeared from Shannon's life without explanation for a couple of weeks.  Then the cat made a brief appearance, but after that, nothing. No more animals. As far as the plot was concerned, again the timing seemed off, and the conclusion just seemed impossible.I don't like to judge the first book in a series too harshly--especially when the author's other series has worked well for me--but I won't buy a second book in this series.  Next time I'll borrow it from the library.  I doubt that this series is one I will be following for very long, but I'll give it one more chance before giving it up.

Of the three installments in this Amish Quilt Shop Mystery, this one has been my favorite.  Because I came to the series fairly recently and three had already come out, I read them all in close succession, but not in order. That didn't seem to matter; I thought they were all solid cozy mysteries with suspense, good character development, and a pleasant setting in Amish country in Ohio.This particular book, Murder, Simply Stitched, has more character development and contrast, in my opinion, than the other two books, and that is probably the main feature that gave me more pleasure in reading it.  Also, the three animals (a dog, a kitten, and a goat) each had a part in the story, and there was a little more about quilting in this particular installment.  The suspense was good, as usual, and there are a couple of twists, both of which surprised to me.I would recommend this book (and the series) to cozy mystery readers who enjoy character development, contrast of lifestyles between the Amish and the "English," and a bit of quilting on the side.  I would like to see more about Amish quilting, but that might not please everyone, and this series strikes a good balance.

This first book in a new series billed as a "Scottish Highlands Mystery" suggests that the protagonist, who is actually only visiting Scotland at this point, might stay there, thus making it possible for the whole series to use that setting.  There is no real hint yet of whether that is the case, but this installment does offer some very fine qualities: a good plot with twists, a clever protagonist who manages to assist the local detective, and a setting that is beautifully described.  There is so much atmosphere here around the colors, views, the sea and hills, the Scottish food and pub, and a diverse group of characters.I would recommend this new series for its depth of character portrayal and fine Scottish setting in particular. Although one can't expect everything to be revealed in a first book, I did feel that the ending was a bit rushed and perhaps needed reactions from a few more interested parties.  Nevertheless, it's a fine beginning and a series that I intend to follow.  There's plenty to enjoy here.

What I liked most about this first book in a new cozy mystery series was that it has some original elements to it.  As anyone who reads a lot in this genre knows, they can be formulaic: a young female protagonist loses her high-paying job (and/or her boyfriend) while living in a large city, and then moves back to a small town, usually to be with a relative, until she decides whether to stay there or not. Those circumstances are here, but there are some differences that contribute to a new angle on the familiar.  For one thing, Georgia works with stained glass, which is quite an unusual business or hobby for a cozy mystery.  I found her descriptions of the technique and the glass quite interesting.  I also thought the way the police were involved was unusual and made the plot move along nicely.  The police were neither too lax nor too overbearing, and their involvement and interactions with Georgia were believable.  Georgia herself is bright and capable, and her kitten is also a plus, even if only for cuteness.I think this series has potential, and I'll be staying with it to see how it develops.  I am hopeful that there will be more about stained glass in the next installment, but I think that for a first effort, it was certainly satisfying in all ways.

I have followed all three of Sheila Connolly's cozy mystery series (the other are the museum series and the newer County Cork series), and despite their very different settings, they all have a few things in common.  For example, there is a lot of historical detail; genealogy is given some prominence; and the mystery is not the most important part. All that is true here, and I would have to say that this one has less suspense than any of Ms. Connolly's mysteries that I have read.  That seems surprising in a way, since there were actually two cases being investigated, but the main one was especially lacking in a coherent development, and one large clue was entirely overlooked.  I didn't enjoy reading this installment, since I knew who committed the crime before the halfway point, and none of the characters caught on until near the end.  There were some lapses in logic too that were distressing.Ms. Connolly's series tend to start off very well and then gradually decline, in my opinion.  This one has reached its limit of pleasure for me, but I'll stick with the County Cork mysteries for now.  The setting in Ireland is a plus, and the characters are more lively.

Characters from the previous book, I've Got You Under My Skin, are here 3 years later: Leo, the grandfather; Timmy, now 9 years old; and Laurie, who is responsible for a television reality series featuring cold cases.  As is usual for Mary Higgins Clark, the characters are introduced in short chapters at the beginning.  We quickly come to understand their thinking, motivation, and possible weak spots, always with an interesting psychological factor woven into the description.  This is vintage Mary Higgins Clark: it's what we love about her writing, and no one does it better, in my opinion.The writing seems (to me anyway) to be Ms. Clark's, and I suspect the contribution of Alafair Burke is in parts of the plot, especially when technology is used and when legal issues are discussed.  Ms. Burke's background would contribute nicely there, but all else seems to be very much Mary Higgins Clark.  I've read all her books and absolutely loved at least half of them, and the rest were also very fine.  This one ranks with the very fine ones; in its way, it's even outstanding, and if it's the first in a series around cold cases and TV reality shows, I think it's an excellent idea that should suit the author's ability at storytelling very well.  Brava!  Excellent all the way.

I've stuck with this series thus far, largely because I enjoy the references to vintage cookware, the setting in a small town near the Canadian border, and two animals (a cat and a small dog) that provide some pleasant diversion.  The series came to a low point in one of the previous books, Freezer I'll Shoot, and I'm sorry to say that this one, No Mallets Intended, shared many similar qualities that for me didn't add up to a satisfying cozy mystery.The main issue with the protagonist, Jaymie, is that she has no particular reason for investigating the murders as she does, and she is not very skilled at it either.  There is a good deal of repetition too, as she asks over and over again, "who could have done it?"  She is quite likely to accuse suspects of murder outright, and she frequently goes out on her own, even though friends and family tell her that it's not safe.I think I've given this series a good try by reading all of the installments thus far, but two that don't measure up are enough to entice me to give it up.  There isn't really very much about vintage cookware anyway, and the timing of events seemed off to me in this particular installment.

I've enjoyed this series thus far, this being the third installment.  I thought the one prior to this one, The Sayers Swindle, was the best of the series; I would recommend that one unconditionally.  This one I would recommend especially to readers who are already familiar with Jordan and her employer, Vera Van Alst.  The bond between Vera and Jordan gathers some strength in this installment.  There is good character development too in Ms. Abbott's mysteries, and Jordan's family members and friends each have very distinctive personalities.The suspense builds nicely, and I found myself imagining the plot unfolding as a movie plot might, colorful and full of action.  Jordan is a smart, capable protagonist.  She doesn't trust people, and she doesn't assume that her first impressions are correct.  This gives her an edge in solving the crime, and even though she does allow herself to break the law to do it, readers can still see the good she is trying to do.  It's all a bit unusual for a cozy mystery, but for readers who like a mystery that is not straightforward, I would recommend this series, for sure.  Even Vera's two cats (Good Cat and Bad Cat) have distinct personalities, and there are also two dogs who play a part too.

It's always pleasant to find a new cozy mystery series that has plenty of suspense, a good cast of characters, and a setting that is unique.  This one certainly qualifies in all ways.  I'm not usually drawn to ghost stories or the paranormal, and I wasn't sure that a "dream club mystery" would be to my taste either, but I was mistaken.  The women who meet to discuss their dreams make a fascinating group: they are from different generations and have different interests, but they also are supportive and generally helpful to each other.The two sisters, Ali (owner of a retro candy shop in Savannah) and her sister, Taylor, are bright and independent.  Together with the ladies in the dream club and other friends, they use instinct and deduction to investigate the crime, and the plot unfolds well.Readers might find themselves thinking about their own dreams while reading about the interpretations the ladies put on the dreams they discuss.  There are two cats too, Barney and Scout, who are much-loved and have a bit of their own intuition.  I enjoyed that, and there was a good deal of suspense too right up to the end.  I'm looking forward eagerly to the next installment.  It's a fine beginning to this new series.

This is the third book in the League of Literary Ladies series and will probably appeal most to readers who follow the series, and to those who enjoy ghost stories.  It takes place during the lead-up to Halloween, and there are some very good scenes that involve the possibility of ghosts--or not, depending on what you are willing to believe.  Followers of the series will enjoy the personalities of the ladies who belong to this unusual reading group.  In fact, none of them seems to be very "literary," and in this installment the connection with a book for the club is quite tenuous.  The "bad" cat, Jerry Garcia, once again makes only one appearance, this time at the beginning of the book.  He is otherwise talked about a lot, but there is no real engagement with him and certainly no evidence that he will ever have any human friends.  It's the only series I know that has such a badly-behaved cat in it; cozies are much better known for having very cute pets in them.I didn't feel that this installment quite measured up to the previous two, and as some other readers have said, there were some inconsistencies in the story.  Nevertheless, the ghost story was a good one, so on that basis I can still recommend it.

This new cozy mystery series is labelled as a "fat cat mystery," but it will appeal to readers who enjoy sweets as well as to cat lovers.  These two features are probably the most original ones in this series, and I thought both were well-done.  The cat, Quincy, has a distinct personality and is part of the story throughout the book, and the food aspect is featured by virtue of the story taking place in Bar None, a shop co-owned by two of the main characters and where various types of delectable dessert bars are baked and sold.I think this series is a promising one, and I look forward to the next installment.  Nevertheless, there were a few features that didn't quite work, in my opinion.  One was the way that the two store owners, Chase and Anna, as well as their two employees, seemed ready to accuse each other of stealing, without making any serious attempt to solve the problem. Chase, the protagonist, was also impulsive in other ways and too-often boldly accused people of murdering someone without a shred of real evidence.The cat, Quincy, is a real charmer though.  There are a few paragraphs throughout the book (in a different font) that give a summary of his point of view, and they add a lot.  All in all, I would recommend this new series in particular for cat lovers.

This is the second book in the Blossom Valley mystery series, and I think this one is even better than the first one.  Here, once again, the protagonist Dana Lewis finds herself obligated to help the police solve the mystery.  The victim is her sister Ashlee's boyfriend, and Dana feels a strong sense of family obligation to help.There is suspense, deduction, and a group of possible suspects, but what sets this book apart, in my opinion, is its clever use of humor on several levels.  I usually find that humor tends to fall flat in a cozy mystery; often it's strained and just doesn't go with the otherwise serious nature of the plot. Here though, the contrast between the two sisters' personalities is often a cause for smiles, as are some of the little events around Dana's dislike for natural foods and spa life.  Since she works at a spa, she sometimes has a hard time coping with her own prejudices, and the result is worth quite a few laughs.  The farm animals even get involved in some of the humor.  It's all in good fun, and the suspense lasts right to the end.  I enjoyed this installment and look forward to the next one.

This is the fourth book in the Ashton Corners Book Club series, and it's still going strong.  My favorite was the first one, A Killer Read, but each one has strengths that center largely on the way the author is able to give an individual voice and personality to each member of the book club.  Ms. Chase does this in part by describing the mystery books that each of them picks for club meetings (and she gives a list of their favorites at the end).  For frequent readers of cozy mysteries, these hints and descriptions are quite fun to read.  Lizzie Turner is a leader within the group and the protagonist as the mystery unfolds.  She is smart, capable, and a good friend to the club members and to her policeman boyfriend, Mark.I enjoyed the plot and setting.  It moves at a good pace and keeps the reader (and Lizzie) guessing.  I did feel that the conclusion rolled out a bit too quickly and, for me, wasn't completely satisfying, but the series is still a solid one and very much worth reading.  The characters and their supportive and contrasting personalities make it work.  The two cats, Edam and Brie, are still in evidence, although they are docile companions who look pretty but don't say much (even in cat-speak).

Denise Swanson is a fluent writer.  I've enjoyed her Scumble River mystery series, and  I came to the Dime Store series with the hope that it would be another winner.  Instead, Ms. Swanson has given so much attention and focus to exploring a love triangle that the mystery takes second place.Love triangles are fairly common in cozy mysteries, and sometimes they work, especially if the characters are well-drawn.  Here, sad to say, the three main characters -- Dev (the Dime Store owner), and her 2 boyfriends, Noah and Jake-simply don't have much depth.  Their relationships don't mature beyond physical attraction, and the mixture of first and third person in the telling of the story becomes somewhat confusing.  The mystery is not engaging either.  Some of the other characters, such as Dev's grandmother, have potential, but there is not enough attention given to them to show depth there either.  So far, I've stuck with this series to see if it would develop into a thriving mystery series, but now I know I won't be following it any further.

This second book in the Bookmobile Cat series is every bit as good as the first one, which I thought stood out as original, engaging, and the beginning of a very promising series.  The strengths of both books lie in the main character, Minnie Hamilton, who is a dedicated librarian and who is passionate about reading and wants to be of assistance to library patrons of all ages.  In contrast to some other cozy mysteries that feature librarians, this one gives us a truer picture of the challenges and successes that librarians face in their work.  Minnie is far from being a stereotypical librarian though, and her interest in using a bookmobile in her work is quite special.  Eddie the cat is an engaging character too, and there is much fun around the way that he appears to understand his human friends, even though Minnie acknowledges that he couldn't possibly have human traits.The main feature that for me sets this series apart from quite a few other new cozy mystery series is the originality the author displays.  The plot, the characters, Eddie the cat, and the bookmobile are all unusual and handled in enough detail to be truly engaging for readers.  Minnie lives on a houseboat, which also adds some elements of interest, and her boyfriend, Tucker, is a pleasant addition too.  I think that the only way to be disappointed in the books in this series would be by reading them too quickly.  There are so many little things that are enjoyable along the way--plays on words, plot twists, and sometimes humorous episodes involving books and patrons--that some of the originality could be lost if they are skipped over.  This is a series in which the writing is clever, interesting, and certainly worth savoring.

The second in the Merry Muffin series from Victoria Hamilton, Muffin but Murder emphasizes the quirky characters in the town of Autumn Vale in upstate New York and centers around a costume party during which a murder is committed.  The mystery itself is certainly adequate, but I found the characters and circumstances this time to be a little too unbelievable.  I do enjoy the author's other books in the Vintage Kitchen Series, so for readers who like cozy mysteries and have not yet read Victoria Hamilton's books, I'd say the other series might be more fun as an introduction to her writing.  I will probably continue with this series too, but I'm hoping for a little less dialogue next time around and more lifelike characters.

This is the second book in a new series that features a protagonist named Stan (Kristan), who bakes and sells organic pet treats.  There are quite a few smiles about her habit of carrying a bag of treats everywhere she goes, ready to give one to any dog or cat she meets.  All the dogs and cats in the town love her!  In this installment, the victim is someone we haven't really had a chance to become acquainted with, and I always think this makes suspense more difficult to build.  Often the motives are less clear too.  Those features are true here, but it still works well,  especially since there's plenty of action in the second half of the book.Stan is likable, and she has now made some good friends in her new small town life in Frog Ledge, CT.  Her mother also comes to visit her this time, which adds some interest.  The author is good at showing contrasts in personalities, and I enjoyed the character of Stan's friend Char in particular.  The pets in Stan's life are also well-drawn and full of vigor, which adds a lot to the story line.  It's a series to follow in order, since each book features a few developments in Stan's life that are important.  There are some good-looking recipes included for pet treats too.

I bought this small slow cooker to replace a Betty Crocker one that was about 10 years old and was no longer keeping its high and low settings.  This one also has high, low, and warm settings; it's a little smaller than the Betty Crocker, and like most cookers, the advertised liquid amount can be misleading.  This one holds about 4 cups of liquid if there's nothing else in it, but if you add veggies or meat, count on using no more than 3 1/2 cups of liquid.  (A slow cooker is made to be filled between 1/2 and 2/3 full so that it won't leak or boil over.) There is no timer.  The handles on the lower part stay cool when it's cooking; this is nice, in case you need to move it while it's hot.  The insert washes up nicely in the dishwasher, and so does the lid.  There is not a tight seal between the lid and the insert when cooking, but for most dishes, that doesn't matter.I would recommend this little cooker as a second one for a household, especially if you like to make small batches of food occasionally.  I like to make applesauce, granola, and small meals in it, whereas for soups and stews I use my larger slow cooker.  For either one, I generally heat the food on HIGH for about an hour first, then turn it down to LOW and leave it while I go out. (This isn't essential, but I like to get the food up to cooking temperature relatively quickly.) Each slow cooker is slightly different, so one needs to experiment at first to see if the timing in a recipe is right for yours.  Timing is especially affected by the size of the cooker, so even recipes you know from a larger cooker may be different in a smaller one.As others have said, this cooker should cost you around $10 in a big box store.  For the price, it's certainly worthwhile to have as a second cooker, since it's small, easy to store, and will prepare small amounts of food.

There are certainly enjoyable features to this cozy mystery series: the theme of vintage kitchen equipment is nicely worked in; the little dog, Hoppy, is a cute and loyal companion to the protagonist, Jayme Leighton; and the island/mainland setting between Canada and the U.S. offers some good contrasts. Jayme's boyfriend, Daniel, and both sets of parents also offer a bit of interest to the plot.  What doesn't work for me in this installment is the considerable amount of repetition.  Jayme's interest in solving the murder doesn't really go beyond being nosy, and she clearly doesn't have much skill as an investigator.  Her main technique is to ask who could have done it over and over again.There is less detail about vintage kitchen supplies in this installment, I think, and that makes the repetition even more apparent.  I might try one more book in the series to see if the story line is a little tighter next time, but at the moment, I feel slightly disappointed in this one.

I had fallen a bit behind in this series that incorporates the craft of constructing miniature houses and interiors, and so I read the precursor to this one (Mix-up in Miniature) and Madness in Miniature one after the other.  For readers who know the series, it is very enjoyable, well-written, and has characters that have several dimensions.I thought Mix-up in Miniature was possibly the best in the series thus far, and for me, that view still stands after reading Madness in Miniature.  The latter one wasn't quite as intriguing as the others.  The mystery isn't as well sustained; there is less about the craft of miniatures (except in the early part of the book); and the ending isn't quite as thoroughly explained as usual.There is still a nice surprise at the end, and the series will no doubt keep going nicely.  The author is skilled at pacing the story line, and the main character, Gerry, is a thoughtful, kind, and resourceful person.  For readers who find her 11-year-old grand-daughter, Maddie, a little too "perfect," this installment may support that view, but I still find the entire setting a very attractive one and would recommend it highly, especially to readers who have already sampled the series.

I have been using this 7-cup processor for about 6 months, and my conclusion is that I like it a lot.  I have owned several food processors in the past 20 years, alternating between Cuisinart and Kitchen Aid.  Each time I buy one of these dependable brands, I always think "this is better," but then something happens, and I switch brands again.  Usually it has been a crack in the plastic feed bowl.  I have had some difficulty deciding which size was better for my needs too.  In the end, I hope this is the last food processor I will need; so far, it fits all my desires quite well, although there are some drawbacks that took some getting used to.First the good: the plastic in the work bowl is heavy-duty and does not cloud over from washing it in a dishwasher.  This is a major difference between this model and all other processors I have owned.  They all clouded over after one or two washings.  Also, the slicing disk has 6 different thicknesses that you can easily dial to choose one.  I can make coleslaw with just the right shreds on thickness "2," for example, which was something I could never do properly with the Cuisinart machine.  The shreds were too small and mushy.  There are also two choices on the shredding disk, which you can get by simply turning it upside down or not.  I love that.  The design with 2 holes in the disks is also amazing: you can pick it up easily without trying to slip your fingers between the disk and the bowl in order to get it out.  The difficulty of attaching the top is not a problem, once one gets used to it.  You just need to remember the steps.  Both the bottom and the top snap into place.  Every machine has its quirks in this regard, so one just needs to learn how each one works.Now the bad: The push-button system at the front is difficult to manage when you want short bursts and are trying to cut or chop in a particular way.  You need to press the "low" or "high," and then press "off" to stop the machine.  ("Pulse" does go off when you release the pressure.) Cuisinart machines are much easier to regulate, since they go off immediately when you let up the button.  Pulsing in short increments is also much easier with Cuisinart.  The pressure required to start the button on this machine is significant.  Maybe that's a safety feature, but I find it too stiff and hard to start.All in all, I am very happy with this Kitchen Aid processor.  The feed tube is large, and the work bowl is a good size for 2--4 servings.  It doesn't leak either--at least it hasn't yet--which is a difference from other processors I have owned.  I gave it 4 stars, because the buttons are too hard to press, in my opinion, which makes the chopping and shredding time hard to regulate, but otherwise it's a fine machine, and I recommend it highly.

As the eighth in the seaside knitters' mysteries, Murder in Merino has characters who are familiar to readers, a lovely seaside community, and lots of friendship and supportive relationships.  If you have liked other books in the series and haven't noticed the editing slips, and if you can overlook the over-emphasis on food and eating in restaurants, then I would still recommend this installment.  It is fun to get to know Izzy and her baby, Abby.  Birdie, the wise older lady in the group, is also unique.All that being said, I am winding down on this series, I think.  There was a group knitting project this time that did progress nicely, but in general there is not really very much about knitting in this series.  The plot gets covered in details that don't matter, and this time the mystery was quite easy to solve.  I kept wondering when the main characters were going to figure it out, since I had done so without much trouble.  The principal characters eat almost every meal at restaurants, which gets tiring, but it's their way of coming together to gossip, which they do a lot of too.The cat, Purl, who is pictured on the cover, made a cameo appearance near the beginning, as did Red, the retriever, and then they both were absent for the rest of the book.  A pity, I thought, but it's only one of the inconsistencies that one does notice unless you like to read very fast and don't pay much attention.

A new mystery by Carolyn Hart is always worth looking forward to, and this one is no exception.  Annie and Max Darling combine efforts at solving three murders that touch people they know, and the police chief Billy is also a fine collaborator.  The familiar trio of friends, Laurel (Maxs mother), Henny, and Emma also contribute in their own ways, and their personalities are well-drawn.  The plot moves along nicely with every detail in place, and Ms. Harts descriptive writing is colorful and beautifully written.I always enjoy the passages that feature Agatha, the black cat who lives in Annies mystery book store.  The second cat, Dorothy L., who is white, is a little more docile, but Agatha is in fine form here with her diversionary measures and some pleasant catitude.  My favorite of Ms. Harts recent mysteries is still What the Cat Saw, but every one of her books is outstanding, and this one is no exception.

I was not particularly taken with the first book in this series, but I decided to give the author another try.  I do like the setting in Snowflake, Vermont, and this book also takes place in the summer, which is a welcome change.  The Vermont atmosphere is very well-done, and the battle re-enactment around Bennington is nicely described. I did think this book was a little better in terms of character depth too, but I still felt that the pacing was a bit "off" somehow, especially in the more active second part of the book.  There were two important parts to the story at that stage, and we often spent too much time with one or the other, not knowing what was happening on the other side.  It made the plot drag a bit, I thought.I haven't given up on this series yet, because this one did seem stronger to me than the first book.  The recipes are usable and original too, so that's a plus.

I would have to call myself a fan of Mary Higgins Clark, in the sense that I know her style well and am always ready to read another of her books.  I have read them all, so I am happy when a new one comes out.  This book is no exception; I thought it was certainly up to her previous standard.  It's chilling in some ways, and she writes a well-plotted story with just the right amount of description, and with characters who are vividly portrayed.The one thing that held this book back from being outstanding, in my view, was that most of the characters had some "evil" in them, and their personalities remained much the same throughout.  The 3 main characters (one of whom is the boy, Timmy) aren't evil, but the "good" in them is not a focus either.  For me, that aspect made the storyline a little too dark for my taste, but nevertheless, Ms. Clark's style wins out in the end.  I recommend "I've Got You Under My Skin" to readers who know her style and reputation.  I don't think you will be disappointed.

After the first book in this series, Final Sentence, I thought it was worth trying one more book before deciding whether it's a series I want to follow.  Unfortunately, I know now it's not.  The characters are not well-developed, and the protagonist, Jenna, has very poor investigative and deductive skills.  She compares herself at one point to a pinball machine, and I would have to agree; for her, picking a murderer is like a shot in the dark.  Tigger the kitten is still as cute as ever, but he's not enough to make up for other drawbacks.I could only recommend this mystery as a very light, fast read, perhaps for vacation reading, and for readers who like plenty of dialogue.  There were a couple of twists to the plot eventually, and they did help me to stick with this mystery.

It's hard to believe that this mystery is the 22nd in the China Bayles series (and that the author has written several other series too!).  This series is my favorite of her works.  I love the combination of folklore and history about herbs and plants, Texas life and landscape, and a protagonist who is intelligent (a former lawyer) and able to use her deductive skills well. China's friend, Ruby, has a more emotional, intuitive personality, which is a good mix with China's "cool" exterior.  The police chief (nicknamed Smart Cookie) is also clever, as are the husbands, who have police training too.  Even with all this expertise, it's fascinating to see that law enforcement doesn't always work exactly as it should.Every book in the series has information about herbs, usually related in some way to specific events or the overall theme. This book will appeal in particular to readers who enjoy a lawyer's view (China uses her law training a good deal here), and an excursion into the history of Mexican art and artists. The writing is excellent, as always.  I did feel this time that readers could have used one more chapter at the end, to let us know how some of the other characters reacted to the conclusion.  It felt a little unresolved in that regard, but if that is an indication that we can anticipate another book in the series before too long, I can easily accept the story as far as it goes.  It's a fine mystery, and I would recommend Ms. Albert's series unconditionally.

This is the sixth in a series about Tori Sinclair, a librarian in the small town of Sweet Briar, SC.  She and her friends belong to a sewing circle, which is their excuse to meet, gossip, and snipe at each other (some do more of that than others, but after six books, we pretty much know all their views by heart).  The twins, Leona and Margaret Louise, have a prominent role in this particular book, and there is even a bit of growth in their personalities in the latter part of the book. I enjoyed that part.  There are good reasons for Tori to want to solve the murder, but as usual, she doesn't approach it in a very logical way.  Also, the sewing group doesn't do much real sewing, so readers who are looking for a crafty cozy are not likely to be fully satisfied. Paris, the bunny, is still fluffy and cute, if a little unconventional as a pet.I think that my interest in this series is waning; this book just doesn't have much suspense, and it's overladen with dialogue and repetition.  For readers who like to read quickly, it may be fine. I prefer to have more depth of description, character development, and a more complex mystery.

I ordered 3 of these penguins for gifts to children, and they are certainly very special and cute.  Seeing 3 of them side by side though, I noticed that 2 of them are 11" tall (not 12", as the ad says), and the other one is 10".  The difference is noticeable enough that I'm glad I'm not giving the 3 penguins to children in the same family, because they might not have been satisfied.  If you're ordering only one, it's worth knowing that the height will be less than 12".  They are about 6" in diameter, and the grey fleece is quite long, so it looks sort of feather-like.  The "wings" (if that's what they're called) lift up and have white beneath.  The beak is squishy, as are the feet, and the whole penguin is very light and soft.  It stands well too.I recently read a story about an oil spill in which penguins were injured, and they were given sweaters to wear so that they wouldn't preen until after workers had removed the oil.  I thought I would make a little sweater for each of these penguins and explain that operation to the kids who receive the gift.  It might enrich their play with the toys a little bit.These penguins are truly cute and just right for gifts.

The Outcast Dead is the sixth in this series, one that I have followed with great interest.  I think this installment is the best one thus far.  It's hard for me to say that though, because I already thought each previous book was worth five stars, so I can't really rate this one any higher.  The author makes each book in the series unique in some way.  This particular one shows a gentler side of Ruth, the forensic archeologist.  The two story lines about child abduction run parallel: a cold case from Victorian times, and modern child abduction that happens within Ruth's circle of friends.  We learn more this time about how the characters think, and especially about police work (Harry Nelson being the all-important chief investigator and long-time friend to Ruth), successes as well as failures, and perhaps most interesting of all, the emotional toll that investigative work takes on the staff.  There is a lot of suspense (as always in Ms. Griffiths' books), a sense of foreboding as we get to know the mothers and children better, and a resolution that is, for me at least, quite unpredictable.Would I recommend this book?  Yes, without reservation, but perhaps with some advice.  I know that a few readers have objected all along to Ms. Griffiths' use of present tense, and that feature continues here.  Although I found it unusual when I started reading her first book (The Crossing Places), I now accept it easily and even think it adds a certain immediacy to the storytelling.  Some readers haven't found it possible to understand Ruth's decisions either.  For that reason, I would say if you've not liked a previous book in this series, give Outcast Dead another try.  It's a more approachable book than some of the previous ones.  The cover makes mention of the author having received the Mary Higgins Clark award, and though Ms. Griffiths' work is much more atmospheric and unpredictable than that of Mary Higgins Clark, in some ways I was reminded when reading this book of some of Mary Higgins Clark's best mysteries.  They were sometimes chilling too, in the same way that this one is.  In other ways though, Ms. Griffiths moves mystery writing forward to a new level, one that I very much admire.  I was also glad to see Ruth back at home, with her daughter Kate and their cat, Flint, who has an endearing personality and who has been absent in some of the other books.  They are all reunited here with very positive results.

I just got finished reading Mary Elle, The Chosen One, and all I have to say is ahhh. Lynn Wood is an incredible author with a ton of talent which is evident just from reading this one novel. It literally contained everything that I look for in a good story, and everything tied up nicely towards the end. Plot line was engaging, characters were well written, and the overall tone of the story was incredible.Mary Elle is a story of love, destiny, and faith. Main character Mary Elle McGann is an inspiring artist who has been defeated. She's given up on her desire to paint, and doesn't believe she'll ever find it again. However one night, she hears voices in her head and those voices give her the answers in which she was seeking. She meets Luc Bordeaux, who is a wealthy Parisian collector. Everything will change for her from this point on.I was captivated by the story, and truly can't wait to read some of Lynn Wood's other works. Would highly recommend this one, especially if you are a fan of the romance genre.

Keeper of the Stone, by Lynn Wood, is Book 1 in the Norman Brides Series. I think for being a Book 1, it was good! I can understand why some others had some difficulty with it, but I just happened to enjoy it. I thought the writing was good, the plot was on par, and the characters were pretty interesting.Rhiann is a 16 year old girl, and pretty naive at that. But then again, aren't most 16 year old girls a little naive? She has an innocence about her which makes her beauty shine through even more. The Normans aren't well liked, but Rhiann likes them very much. They treat her kindly, and she appreciates that. She falls in love after a night in bed with a man, which is one of the biggest reasons why people around her call her naive. However, she is not naive, she is simply sweet. There are a lot of struggles she goes through, and there are a lot of characters in this book as well so it gets difficult to keep up with. However, I did enjoy it.I will definitely pick up Book 2 because this one really did have a lot of potential. Kudos to the author on a good try, I can definitely respect it!

Purple Hearts, by Paul Kelso, was an excellent read overall. It was well written, easy to follow, and highly enjoyable. From start to finish, I did not want to put it down until I reached the last page. The way that the author wrote the story, it almost felt like it was a non fiction instead of a fiction. Quite a few times I had to remind myself that this isn't based on a true story.Main character Carl Donner was fabulous, and definitely relatable. I found him to be very funny and well developed as the story went on.  Carl Donner is a 34 year old Vietnam Veteran, now living in America in 1982. He is a folk singer currently looking for gigs, even though he can't seem to get enough of good ones. On top of that, he is on the hunt to figure out what happened to his mother, who mysteriously died. In his search, secrets are revealed and the truth becomes more clear. One of the biggest pieces of dirt? Carl is actually the love child of President Ronald Reagan!Interesting read, couldnt put it down, five stars all the way! Definitely recommend.

Being an elementary school teacher, I am constantly in search of a good book for the classroom. I like things that are a bit out of the box; not to similar to the major authors on the market. Tess and the Giggle Pajamas, by Sheryll Raye, is probably one of the best ones I've read in a long time. Such a funny read, easy to understand, and really helps with their comprehension. The day that I brought this book to the classroom and read it, they couldn't get enough of it. I've had to read it about 5 times since purchase.This particular book is about a little girl named Tess who has a BIG personality. Her worst nightmare is getting dressed; how is she possibly going to manage that one? I can tell you one thing; it's going to end up being a big laugh! The kids couldn't stop giggling, and neither could I.Can't wait to see what other silly adventures Tess can get herself into!

PALLBEARERS AND GAMBLERS, by Michael Cruit, had everything in it to help me escape from my life for a little while. It was an exciting, heart pumping, edge of your seat kind of a read. It was extremely well written, quick paced, and the characters just sucked me right in. It was a bit different than what I usually read, but sometimes different is better, and that was the case with this one.Main character Michael Dibiso just returns back home from Vietnam. He is assigned to Honor Guard as a pallbearer for his fallen brethren. This is no easy position, however. Even the strongest man on earth would turn into the most bitter after dealing with this position. In the midst of all of this, his family has ties in the Chicago Mafia, which makes things a lot trickier than they already are. Seven million dollars now comes into question. With so much happening, it was extremely difficult to put this one down for even a second.I enjoyed it, and look forward to reading more by Michael Cruit.

Amarantox, by Tam Linsey, is the Prequel to the Botanicaust Series. Having read the series, I must say that I am very impressed by the writing of Linsey. She truly knows how to capture your attention, and leaves you pondering for long after you are finished reading the book. This was a very powerful type of a read, that affected me in a way. People have their own theories on how the world will end, but Linsey's vision is much darker than most could ever come up with.I don't want to give too much away in terms of plot, but the main idea of this story is about a womans fight against big businesses that threaten to negatively influence the planet in which we live. It's not an easy struggle for her, as she is only one person against a huge mission, but she is determined to get it done.There is so much more to the storyline than just that, but It's a definite must read. I would highly recommend.

Lady Grace & the War for a New World: A Paranormal Adventure, is Book 2 in the Earth's End series. Author Sandy Nathan has been doing an excellent job in this series, truly knowing how to keep readers on edge from start to finish. This is not your average "fantasy" type of read; there are so many more elements to it than that. It is filled with action and suspense that will get your heart pumping. The character development in this particular novel really did blow me away. The main question posed in this novel is, is there a way to recover a society that is violent and troubled? So much turmoil goes on, how do we possibly redeem it? Lady Grace shows us that it is possible, but it takes some effort and dedication. Overall this is a great read, and I truly can't wait for Book 3 to come out.

Triangle of Death, by Michael Levine, definitely takes you on a wild thrill ride. Even though Levine has pretty much lived this type of life, Triangle of Death is a fictional story based on what he's seen and been around during his career. However,he takes his experiences to create a spy saga unlike any other that I've read. At times, I wondered if this actually is a non fiction read because most of it sounds like it could really be happening, as unbelievable as that sound. There is so much action and suspense in here, you will have a very difficult time putting it down. It is a definite thought provoking read, which will probably keep you up at night. I would highly recommend it, as it is well written and highly engaging. Five stars all the way.

The Conversion Prophecy, by Michael Solomon, is an International Thriller that I had a lot of trouble putting down. It's action packed and really has a way of capturing your attention on every page. This was an extremely well written novel, that was very believable. It takes the current events of our times and makes a major conspiracy out of them. Right now were living in a scary type of the world, and Solomon poses a question: what if Islam was to take over the world? What kind of society would we be living in? By the end of reading it, I felt like the novel could be a real life, non fiction kind of a read - scary but true. Kudos to Solomon for writing such a believable book that is sure to keep you at the edge of your seat. Five stars all the way.

Michael Levine did an excellent job with Deep Cover. This is a true account of an international drug sting operation that went on. The operation ended up going very wrong, and deeply effected the lives and families of everyone involved, along with the US Government itself. I don't want to get too much more into it because I feel as if this is a book worth reading, but I do want to stress the fact that Levine did an excellent job with it overall. It is well written, extremely informative, and shares a lot of information about what goes on pertaining to the "War on Drugs". Maybe of us are still so clueless about it, but It's time that we open our eyes to it and understand. Something seriously needs to change in our Government, and Levine deserves a lot of kudos for having the courage to come out and write about what exactly is happening all around us. Five stars all the way, would definitely recommend.

I picked up the Go-Getter Guy Secrets To Successful Dates, by Titania Hudson, just for the entertainment value of it. However, I was really impressed by it, as it contains a lot of very useful tips on being that man that every woman wants to have. I feel as if most men are completely clueless when it comes to women; some outright have no idea how to even approach them. Others struggle with how to keep a woman for the long term, and are constantly wondering why their relationships don't work out. This book is broken down into different chapters, and goes into in depth detail on how to attract, and keep, the women that you want. It is well written, straight forward, and easy to follow. It's definitely recommended to any and all males, regardless of what you think about yourself in terms of relationships. Great read.

Wow, what an interesting read! The Apache Black Missile, by Joseph Groth, succeeded all of my expectations. I wasn't quite sure what I was getting into when I jumped into it, but I was pleasantly surprised with what I ended up with. This is a story about an international disaster that is just lurking in the shadows. Even though it is a fictitious read, I got so immersed into it that it felt like real life. It's written in such a believable way, you almost can't believe that it didn't really happen. Everything you could want in a good read is in this one; suspense, action, and a lot of thrill and mystery. There was also a lot of diversity taking place as well, which made it even more enjoyable. Kudos to Groth for writing such an enriching novel. I am definitely going to be keeping my eyes out for more by him. Five stars all the way.

Wow, what a thrill this story was! The Test, by B.A. Sherman, is Book 1 in The Greg Dorn Series. What a great way to start this series off. It was heart pumping, exciting, and thrilling from beginning to end. So many twists and turns that I did not see coming, and the ending left me yearning for more.In a small town in Kansas, 17 year old boy Greg has to deal with his fair share of tragedy. Both his mother and sister lose their lives in a car accident, that was caused by a mental patient. He doesn't know where to turn after this, but one thing remains: he is full of anger towards road rage drivers. This rage results in Greg turning to the police force, becoming a cop. Once he takes this step in his life, things start to look a bit brighter for him. He falls in love and marries his high school sweetheart. They move to Denver, where Greg finds a job as a cop there as well. However, something stirs up inside of him and his repressed anger comes out in the worst way possible. He now has a strong desire to kill. This causes him to lose everything; including his family. Rock bottom hits when he is shot by a fellow police officer.Loved every single second of this book, and would highly recommend it. Can't wait for Book 2!

An Imperfect Union is truly what this book is all about. Author Georgiann Baldino writes a story that could of actually happened in real life, during the American Civil War. She has a passion for History, and has written many novels pertaining to the subject, along with travel and suspense. I feel as if this particular novel represents all three of those categories, into one. I found the two main characters to riveting and exciting, and they had excellent chemistry together. Dr. Fred Dudley is a surgeon on the front line of the war. Cornelia Hancock is a nurse. The two of them come together through witnessing tragedy and many wounds. They learn to lean on each other through the hard times. What I liked best about this novel is that it truly does have elements of being historical non-fiction, even though the characters are fiction. Reading through, at times I felt as if these were real people and this was actually happening. I connected well with them, and found them to be extremely relatable. This was an excellent read, one that I would truly recommend to any and all historical fiction buffs. I will be checking out Georgiann Baldino's other reads ASAP.

Veil of Darkness is Book 1 in the Chalas Peruvas series, and what a way to kick it off! This is a Sci/fi / Fantasy novel combined into one, which made it double the amount of fun. I had very high hopes for this particular novel, and I'm pleased to say that Metivier did not disappoint even one bit. I could not get enough of the writing style, plot, or the main characters. All of it combined managed to just suck me right in.In a far away universe, a war is about to begin. The result of this could be the end of life. There is so much action and suspense that takes place throughout, in order to try and save destruction from taking place. I like how a lot was going on in this novel, but Metivier wrote it in such a way that it was easy to follow along with and understand; I didn't get lost at all. It's an extremely fast paced kind of read, and by the end, I was sad that it was over.I highly recommend this one, especially if you are a fan of Science Fiction. I can't wait for Book 2 to come out!

At The Sharp End of Lightning, by NR Bates, is a pretty interesting story that combines a lot of different things. It can be difficult to keep up if you don't follow along closely, but I found it to be pretty fascinating overall. A lot of research has been put into this by the author, which is extremely evident. I always appreciate it when an author takes the time to do their research before writing a novel like this.This is more than just an average science novel about the ocean. It's also science fiction with a bit of fantasy involved in it as well. Main character Yalara Narika is a sea sprite in desperate search for her lover in the never ending seas. Along with that storyline, there are other elements mixed in; sacrifice, losing a loved one, dealing with disabilities, and of course, climate change. All of these elements combined makes this a very well written novel. I enjoyed the characters as well, and found them all to be pretty fascinating.Five stars all the way, highly recommend.

Summertime, by Chuck Gould, is Book Two in this series. I did actually read Book One, and thoroughly enjoyed it. I couldn't wait for Book Two, because Chuck Gould is an amazing author who keeps you interested throughout. If you are interested in Fantasy type reads, then you definitely need to check this one out.Main character Wesley Perkins is just trying to figure out the world in which he lives in. If you read Book One, then you already know about all the struggles he had to go through. Book Two delves even deeper into this, showing the reader just how confused Wesley really is. His world is linked to a dead blues musician, Judah Jones. There are so many obstacles he has to overcome, and many dangers to try and avoid. Ironically, his closest friends are Jone's Granddaughters as they try to help him understand things more clearly.This book is filled with action and adventure, and will definitely take you on a ride. I highly recommend it.

I just got finished reading The Cries of the Butterfly and wow - I really have no words to describe this one. Rajeev Roy does an excellent job with the writing of this novel. This is a novel filled with a variety of different stories that end up combining into one. They are touching, and will throw you through a bunch of different emotions. I cried, I smiled, and I laughed throughout this entire novel. It takes a lot of talent to be able to evoke such strong emotions in a human being, but this one did the trick.Main character Wolf Butcher is the man who had everything. This all changes very suddenly one morning, when he loses his daughter. He has no idea where to turn after this tragedy, or how to cope with his life anymore. However, this all changes when two girls enter into his life. Savannah is a 29 year old girl who has been discarded by the world. Robin is an 8 year old girl who lives in an orphanage. These two girls are exactly what Wolf needs in his life, in order to survive and cope with his life. However, another tragic fate is thrown on him - he must choose between the two of them. Readers get to read about Wolf's story between him and Savannah, along with his story with Robin. There are also stories between him and his brother Al, along with stories between Wolf and his Dad. All of these combined into one make a strongly emotional tale that you won't forget about anytime soon.Excellent writing, and a definite must read. Would highly recommend.

I can't seem to get enough of Randall Reneau, and all of his great stories. Legend of War Creek is Book 4 of the Trace Brandon series, and just as fantastic as the previous 3. I love the authors writing style of these books, and the way that I am kept guessing throughout the book. The characters are amazing as well, and these books just find a way to suck me right in.Another search is about to begin. This time, geologist Trace Brandon and his crew are in search of a gold-bearing quartz vein, which was first discovered over one hundred years ago. This is a very dangerous task however, due to the fact that many who have tried searching for this particular quartz vein have vanished or turned up dead. However, Trace is ready to take on this task and willing to risk his life to do so. Very exciting journey, from start to finish.There's a lot going on on this novel, which will keep you interested from start to finish. I enjoy this entire series, and truly can't wait to see what Randall Reneau has in store for us next.

Sucker, by Mark Lingane, is Book 1 in the Para-noir-mal series, and what a great way to kick this one off! I have been dying for a good detective book for ages now, and finally got my full with this one. It was intense, had me on the edge of my seat, and was just fun overall. It was written in such a way that I felt as if I was watching a movie instead of reading a story. Great imagery, excellent characters, and overall wonderful plot line.Main character PI Van H. Avram has seen a lot during his career. However, something new and unexpected is about to happen to him; he discovers the body of a skinny blonde girl on his doorstep, and has no idea what to make of it. This opens a new world of paranormal activity, as he tries his best to figure this case out.What I enjoyed most about this book is that the paranormal aspect of it wasn't too far fetched or over the top, like you find in a lot of paranormal novels. Also, the twists in this book really had me shocked and surprised - I didn't see them coming. If you are in need of a great detective novel that fits into the current era and trend, I would highly recommend Sucker. I can't wait for book 2 to be released!

Having read Now What and And When (both by Wendy Proteau), I just couldn't wait for the third and last installment of this series to come out. Who Knew (And When), did not disappoint me in the least. It was everything I expected, and more. I am sad to see this series come to an end, but I am delighted that I had a chance to discover it. These are excellent stories filled with many twists and turns, with a main character who you won't be able to resist.Jade Prency is back yet again, with even more on her plate than ever before. If you read the other two installments of this series, you will know about all the hardships Jade has had to overcome to get to the point where she is now. She has become successful, which is something that she's always dreamed of being. She's finally at the top of the world, when it all comes crashing down on her, yet again. She has finally gained the confidence that she was always lacking, and feels at peace with her life - finally. However, she quickly comes to realize that not everything is as clear cut as it appeared to be. She will be disappointed, yet again. However, the ending of this one is slightly different than the other two - and that's all I'm going to say.I am so sad that this is the end of this wonderful series, but I am definitely going to keep me eyes out for more books by Proteau, because she has quickly become one of my favorite authors. I highly recommend this series.

A majority of people in the world have faced bullying at least once in their lives. Some of us are lucky enough to get away from it without any major scars, but some of us aren't so lucky. Bullying has become such a serious issue in today's world, and we need to become better aware of it so that we can help to make it stop. Some people view bullying as not a major big deal, but in reality, it causes a lot of psychological and emotional damage that stays with a person throughout their lifetime. A Ladder In The Dark, by Alan Eisenberg, is a first hand account of what the author had to go through in terms of bullying, and the after effects it had on him. He was faced with repeated childhood bullying, and this story is about his road from recovery. He makes us see that by telling his story, it is actually helping him to heal. When you keep traumatic events to yourself, they tend to eat you alive.This book is extremely relatable because most of us have been through similar situations as Eisenberg. Bullying comes in all forms, and doesn't only happen in childhood. There is workplace bullying that goes on, bullying among family members/friends, etc. This is an eye opening read that shows us what kind of damage is done by it, and how we can become more aware of what goes on around us to ensure that we never put anyone else in the situation that Eisenberg was in.I believe everyone needs to read this book, in order to gain a better understanding of a serious issue happening in our generation. Kudos to Eisenberg for being able to share his story with the world. Highly recommend.

Now What, by Wendiann, is the sequel to And When. I enjoyed And When SO much, I couldn't wait to pick this one up and read it. I am just as impressed with this one as I was with the first, which is a rarity. Wendiann has a lot of talent, and it really shows through in these two works. Such interesting story lines, believable characters, and great character development. I feel as if the main character is someone that I know personally.Jade Prency has been through a lot. She had to struggle through a discovery of a tumor, then her dad's diagnoses of a terminal illness, not to mention a dream relationship taking a turn for the worst. However, Jade is an extremely strong woman, and manages to pick herself up after each and every struggle. In this novel, Jade is a successful, best-selling Author, and the world seems to be on her fingertips. She is finally happy again, feeling as if the bad luck that she's been dealt with has finally come to an end. However, things are never quite that easy for Jade. The man who broke her heart reappears in her life, and she has no idea how to cope with it. It took her years to get over him, and just when she thought she finally had, there he is again. All of the memories came racing back to her, and she has no idea where to turn. The storyline just keeps getting better and better from there.Excellent writing overall! I am now a die hard fan of Wendiann, and can't wait for her next book to come out. These books just have a way of capturing my attention from start to finish. Five stars all the way, highly recommend.

And When, by Wendiann Proteau, really took me by surprise. As soon as I read the description I knew this would be a book that I was going to enjoy, but I didn't realize how invested in it I was going to get. Such a unique story line that feels almost too real, it drew me in and didn't let me go until the very last page. This is a story of how the real world and the online world collide and become one.Main character Jade Prency has to overcome many obstacles, and deals with too many hardships. My heart broke for her throughout this novel, as the character herself felt very real. The doctor informs her that she has a tumor, which quickly turns her life upside down. However, devastation strikes her yet again when she finds out that her father has been diagnosed with a terminal illness. She can't cope with reality any longer, which is when she turns to the internet, in order to escape. The online world becomes an alternate reality for many people, and this is exactly what Jade engrossed herself into. She is able to hide her appearance, and quickly becomes friends with an online support community. She tries to stay away from the men, but one Brady Gibbs captures her attention. He quickly becomes her hero, helping her every step of the way with all that she's going through. However, not everything is quite as it seems, and yet again, Jade is faced with more challenges. Is Brady really too good to be true, or is he the real deal?I thoroughly enjoyed this book, and it evoked a lot of emotions in me. I would definitely recommend this one to anyone who is a fan of reading in general, as I feel that it caters to most. Proteau is an excellent author, and I am truly excited to read more of her work.

The Monster Chase, by Marion A. Stahl, is a fascinating read that everyone should pick up. Even though it is a work of fiction, it focuses on our ailing health care system and the corruption that ensues behind the scenes. It's no secret that thing's aren't always as they appear, especially when it comes to our health care systems. I feel as if the struggles and hardships the main character in this book goes through are ones that real time physicians have to endure as well. This was a pretty dark read, but an important one as well.Main character Dr. Quaile is an excellent doctor, who takes her job seriously. She does everything right, treats her patients fairly, and somehow, gets the raw end of the deal. She makes sure she follows every rule and regulation set in place, in order to ensure that she will never be involved in a malpractice suit. However, she is ultimately forced to leave her practice due to health issues, and becomes the main target of a witch hunt. The powers to be will stop at nothing to make sure she loses her license to practice medicine. Due to the injustices that arise, Dr. Quaile's life quickly goes downhill, and she loses a lot. It's very sad, as well as eye opening because sadly, these things do happen in the real world.Once again, this is a work of fiction, but It's written in a way that Stahl probably has some first hand experience. We need to become better aware of what's happening around us, and the injustices that people are facing. Our health care system is failing, and if we don't have our facts, things will only get worse. I highly recommend this read.

Drachen: A Thriller, is Book 1 in A Matthys Rossouw Pursuit series, by Brendan le Grange. This book was almost like being on a wild ride, not knowing what was going to happen next. Grange has an amazing way of throwing readers into loop after loop, action after action. It just didn't stop until the end, which is something that I can definitely appreciate. This book was so complex, there was a lot going on in it which made me unable to put it down. Excellent writing.The book starts out on a high note, and ends on one as well. Brett Rivera's main goal is to outrun a group of assassins who are being run by Kalev. Brett is fortunate enough to find the wreckage of a looted treasure ship, Drachen. Everyone has been searching for Drachen, but up until Brett, no one has managed to find it. However, she discovers that the treasure has already been looted, by clues are left behind as to who took it first.There are a lot of characters involved in this book, and they all have one goal: find the lost treasure. I love that the main character is a woman, as she is portrayed as a strong lead. The only word of caution before starting this one is: don't start it at night! It will be the quickest way to lose your entire night's sleep. Five stars all the way for a brilliant story, and I truly can't wait for the next one to come out.

Deception's Sins, by Karen Truesdell Riehl, is the mystery story that I have been waiting for for quite some time. This one is extremely well written, and stumped me quite a few times. The plot line is extremely interesting, and definitely well thought out. This is a sequel to Freedom's Sins, but in my opinion, you don't need to read both in order to figure them out. This is a great stand alone novel as well, even though I would also recommend Freedom's Sins since It's just as exciting as this one was.Main character Roger Sundbee lands on Deception Island after failing his tell all book about the residents of Freedom, Indiana. He was in desperate new of a new start, and this small little Island off the coast of Washington appeared to be the perfect place for that. However, a twist is thrown in when the coroner's body is discovered dead, and no one knows who did it. Roger was the last person to be seen with him, which makes him prime suspect number 1. Roger now has to clear himself, and figure out what really happened to the coroner. Brilliant writing, and I loved the development of Roger as well.Overall, I would highly recommend this one. It will definitely leave you at the edge of your seat.

The Goddess of Fortune, by Andrew Blencowe, is one of the best books I've read in a long time. What makes it so interesting is, it poses the question of what would happen if certain things were changed during World War II? It's a very interesting take on a piece of history, and definitely left me wanting more.This is way more than just your typical war story. There is sex, politics, business, and strategy all involved as well. Some scenes were extremely erotic, which kept this so interesting. The people in power plot out strategies in order to positively boost their Country. There are secret alliances, a lot of lies and hidden secrets, along with betrayals. Louise was my favorite character in this book, due to the fact that she's only 24 years old and was smarter than most.If you are up for reading about a possible alternative to World War II, I would definitely give this one a chance. It was highly entertaining, and I am truly fascinated by Andrew Blencowe's writing style. Five stars all the way.

Before I begin my review, I just want to say something about the author, Firdevs Dede. I recently read another book by her, and was blown away by her writing style, and extensive knowledge. Her surrealist imagery is unlike any writing style that I've never seen done before. Her brilliance is astounding, and I do believe she will make it far in her writing career. I just finished reading DREAM Foundation, and was just as impressed as I was after reading the previous novel I read by her. DREAM Foundation is different, however. This one focuses on having a deep affection for art and human beings. It is about a woman who was about to give up on her dreams, due to difficult circumstances she had to overcome. Inspiration soon follows, and Nuala realizes just how important your passions are. The relationship between her and Patricia was very enduring, and truly helped Nuala along the way. This is a complex read but definitely a worthwhile one, and I would highly recommend it. I do plan on going back and reading some of Dede's earlier works, and I can't wait to see what she has in store for us next.

Ephiphany - THE GOLDING, by Sonya Deanna Terry, is a well written page turner. This is a unique kind of story, one that would be difficult to tell. Terry does an excellent job creating a story within a story, and it captured my attention almost from the beginning. I loved the plot, the characters, and the overall feel of the novel.Main character Rosetta Melki is a part time tarot card reader. She has a teenage daughter named Izzie, who also plays a big part in the story. Things get interesting when Rosetta joins a reading group and gets more sucked into the novel, (Our True Ancient History), than she ever imagined would be possible. This fictional story comes alive, and the two stories in Ephiphany play out together, which is a concept that I haven't seen done before. Our True Ancient History is filled with mystical creatures, such as dryads and fairy clans. Maleika an elf stars in this novel, and her and her son are able to travel into outer space. This is where it delves into the different realms and dream spheres. Rosetta is caught up in a mystery that needs to be solved.This was an easy to follow book that was fun to read and pretty fast paced. I enjoyed it thoroughly, and felt like I was in the novel with Rosetta. I would highly recommend this one to all reading fans.

Awakenings, by Mary D. Brooks, is book 4 in the Interwined Souls series. Having read the previous 3, I knew what to expect and couldnt wait to dive into this one. This has been an excellent series that has truly drawn me in and left me wanting more by the end. Brooks has so much talent, Its almost unbelievable. Historical fiction is definitely on the tops of my favorite genre, and this entire series is one that I will never forget.In book 4, we see Eva and Zoe yet again. I love how the author writes for these characters, the development is great and you almost feel as if you know them personally. Eva and Zoe are the stars of this series; they met during World War II, on different ends of conflict. They fell in love, but their love isnt easy. They have faced so many challenges that threatened to tear them apart, but they stayed strong through each and every one, and stayed together. They become world travelers, and have lived in quite a few different locations. Eva has some secrets that are about to be uncovered, and we get to see how the two of them deal with those.Another great book in this series. Yet again, I am left wanting more and cant wait for Book 5 to come out. Five stars all the way, highly recommend.

Songs of the Deliverer, by Elvo Bucci, is a pretty touching story that is wonderfully written. As a Catholic myself who knows the entire history of the bible, I found this story to be enlightening. It poses the question: what would the world be like if Jesus was walking amongst us today? I have asked myself this many times, so it was great to read a story about what things may be like if that was the case. This is a very different take on an old story, and I would recommend it to anyone who is a believer in Jesus.Even though this is a work of fiction, each story and chapter focuses on the Gospel stories of Jesus. You get a chance to see him in a new light, which is very refreshing. Instead of being Jesus, however, he reappears as Emmanue. Very inspirational overall.Bucci did an excellent job with this story, and I got a lot out of it. I felt touched, and did feel a closer sense to Christ by reading this one. I recommend it to anyone of the religious faith; you wont be sorry.

Illuminarium, by Truth Devour, is book 1 in the Soliloquys Labyrinth Series. I must say, this series is off to a great start! I wasnt quite sure what to expect when I jumped into this one, but I was pleasantly surprised. I am not usually one to read urban fantasy types of books, but I read the description to this one and was instantly intrigued by it. It was thrilling and fun to read, and I cant wait for book 2.Main character Harper is forensic psychologist who has seen a lot of bad, but still has hope for peace and harmony in her own life. One day she comes across an owl, and decides to follow it. She stumbles upon a mysterious book in the woods, and just like that, her life changes. All of a sudden, she is stuck between good and evil. Because of her current state, she has to live on the run and constantly hide out.
