Ahh tormenting ones pets with toys that squeak & squeal...  I don't have concrete or asphalt, just farmland, even so the ball  bounces rather well on the cut pasture grass & dirt much to the delight of my dogs.  They run around with it in their mouths, drop it, it bounces, they doggy pounce it, kick it, it rolls away, they chase after it.  On & on goes the fun.  Whenever they take an overly rambunctious bite, out comes a squeak that never fails to make them lift their ears in curious surprise.  Overall a lot of fun.  I just hope it holds up to all their play.
These are nice sized crunchy treats that the dogs actually have to chew to eat.  They all love them & it's a great way to give them a treat they don't swallow in one gulp.

I really enjoyed the first book in the series but the second book was a bit of a dud.  Despite this I gave this third book in the series a go & I have to say I'm glad I did!  Fatal Consequences has a lot of action & I desperately wanted to see the bad guys get their due.  Not only does Sam have a very serious case on her hands, where not only she, but her officers lives have been threatened, she is also planning to get married & dealing with her ex-husband possibly being released on a technicality.  Sam's challenges were much more real this time around & her relationship with Nick seemed a lot more realistic as well.  He is still unbearably perfect, but not so perfect that you want to throw the book out the window in disbelief (as in the second book).  If you enjoyed the first book in the series & were disappointed by the second, know that Marie Force makes up for it in Fatal Consequences.  Recommend.

This is a great little book for beginners or for those who simply want to add a full color herb book to their collection.  The bare basics are covered but I did find it annoying that the author introduced recipes utilizing herbs she doesn't discuss.  So if you want to learn about many of the herbs in her recipes, you will want to refer to another book.  What I like about the book is it's simplicity & full color photographs.  The book only covers 20 herbs so it is easy to do a quick search for a refresher on the basics.  Each section is very short so it really keeps things simple without adding too much information for a beginner to absorb.While I like this book & am glad to have it in my collection, I strongly recommend that if you are seriously interested in herbs, you get books that are a bit more informative than this one.  I highly recommend Rosemary Gladstar's Medicinal Herbs: A Beginner's Guide: 33 Healing Herbs to Know, Grow, and Use, Rosemary Gladstar's Herbal Recipes for Vibrant Health: 175 Teas, Tonics, Oils, Salves, Tinctures, and Other Natural Remedies for the Entire Family, & The Complete Herbal Tutor: The ideal companion for study and practice.  I own all three of these books as well as some others & I have to say they are worth every penny.Bottom line this is a lovely book suitable for anyone interesting in getting their toes wet in herbalism or anyone wanting to add another book to their growing collection.  As the author states, "I recommend finding one or two new plants each year.  Find them, sit with them, and observe them... Use them.  Make them into every kind of preparation....Cook with them, make them into salve, tincture, tea,... Once you know them, they will be a part of your herbal repertoire forever."

The cats are all nuts about this cat food.  I was able to try out all three flavors & have to say they were all received with gusto.  My crazy sauce loving cat licks up all the sauce she can, leaving the chunks for my other cat to gobble up.  I'm very happy to report that there is no guar gum or carrageenan in this food as it typically is in other canned foods.  This is in fact the first quality canned food I've come across that doesn't contain one or the other, including the certified organic brands.  What I don't like is the addition of caramel color.  If you are listening Hills, lets get the coloring out of the food too!Other grain free canned foods I've recently tried that the cats love are Nutro Breakfast Scrambles Tuna & Egg (be warned this stuff stinks! But it isn't saucy so my sauce head cat has to actually eat the food) & Purina Pro Plan True Nature (not as saucy as Crafted so, again the sauce head eats more food).  Note these two brand contain either guar gum or carrageenan.Overall I'm very happy with the Crafted canned foods.  The cans are super easy to rinse out & the cats lick their bowls spotlessly clean.

This is a really cute toy with an adorable little yellow faux fur chick with a yellow feather tail that reminds me of a Polish chick (the breed of chicken with the adorable top hat).  The plastic ball is much bigger than I had expected at about 4".  It is supposed to contain catnip, but it smelled like mint to me (by the next day, the smell was gone).  After pulling the tab to activate the bird, I put it on the floor for my cats.  My younger & more playful cat was both curious & slightly afraid, but she did start carefully poking her paw through the cage to tap at the little moving bird head.  The ball wasn't rolling.  I attributed that to the long materials tag sticking out of the birds bum.  I tugged on the tag but it wouldn't budge so I maneuvered scissors into the cage & cut it off.  As I was placing it back onto the floor a little plastic piece hit the floor.  It was part of the perch the bird is on.  Either I broke it or it was broken when it arrived.  I super glued it back together & let it dry overnight.After reintroducing it to the cats, it doesn't get the amount of play that it should.  They only found it interesting for a few minutes.  Because it makes noise (the mechanical noise is surprising loud plus it gives a few chirps) only when activated, I'll know if they are playing with it.  I haven't heard a thing for days.  I'm pretty disappointed the cats aren't interested in it as it seems like it should be a good time.*Update* 10-18-15Was 3 StarsWith new kittens in the house again, this toy became an instant hit.  All day & night I would hear this toy being played with whene the kittens were awake.  They absolutely love it.  The older cats still show no interest, but for kittens & young cats it is awesome!  I didn't update to 5 stars because of the broken bit I had to repair.  If you have a kitten or plan to get one, this toy is sure to be a hit.

Compared to the first book in the series, Fatal Justice was a little flat & not nearly as exciting.  The relationship between Sam & Nick didn't feel real.  Nick was too perfect & Sam was an unbearable bitch.  All I could think was how can any man put up with with a woman with such a bad attitude with a genuine smile on his face & somehow manage to say the perfect thing to make it all better?  It's fantasy land to the extreme.  Despite this, the story is entertaining in a beach read type of way.  It's not something I'd ever purchase, but it's worth checking out from the library for a mild diversion.  Hopefully Force manages to recapture what made the first book so good in her third book.  Fingers crossed.

This is a really fun way to send off a less than ho hum typical greeting card.  In order to use you need to pull of the thin film that has the saying "Live well.  Laugh Hard.  Love Big!"  Underneath the film is a blank chalkboard where you can write whatever you want.  It is easy to write on with included chalk pencil & equally as easy to erase after writing on it.Overall I was really impressed until I went to peel off the thin film & the mini chalkboard came right off the card & fell on my lap.  There are a mere two little thin strips of double sided tape that keep the board attached to the card.  I pressed the board back onto the card forcefully & it seems to be holding.  The board itself is made of wood so it could be removed & used for a kid or adult to play with without having to deal with the card if that's what you want to do or display it in some way.Note:  If you plan to mail this to someone, you will need to pack it in a padded envelope with extra postage.

I've had my eye on the kraft Avery shipping labels for a while now for my small family farm business.  Due to the much higher cost then just printing out on regular printer paper & taping the label to the pkg. I never ordered them.  When the opportunity came to try these white Avery labels, I jumped on it.  The box they come in is pretty big & rather heavy.  The labels are two to a sheet & take up the entire 8 x 10 space.  This is great if your printer is off or you want to make the label bigger, add your own business logo etc.  I must admit the end result is much more professional looking than my cut & tape method.  It is also much quicker, just peel & stick.  The labels are thin; similar to paper, so they don't block out images for when you chose to re-use a shipping box or envelope.  They perform exactly as advertised, they do not jam in any of my printers nor does the ink smudge.  Overall I'm very pleased with the results.

I run a organic farm & despite wearing a hat & tinted moisturizer with SPF 15, I still show signs of sun damage & of course aging (can't really escape that one).  I have been using this product for a little over a month & so far have experienced positive results.  I find one pump is more than enough product to lightly cover my entire face.  I apply eye cream first, then this serum, then my tinted moisturizer with SPF 15.  Normally I apply a bronzing powder & blush over the moisturizer because if I don't my face looks shiny.  Using this serum, even with over a week of highs in the upper 80's / lower 90's & working outdoors, my skin remains dry & smooth.  I have never experienced anything like it.  If this was the winter, I doubt I'd be able to use a serum such as this.In the evening after washing my face I again apply my eye cream, then this serum & then pure organic argan oil.  In the morning my skin is not greasy, it is smooth & dry.  Once I went to bed & forgot to apply the argan oil.  My skin burned a little & felt very tight.  When I woke up the next morning I applied a little argan oil.  Aside from that I have nothing negative to report.I was very concerned that it would cause my skin to burn & turn red (called blushing in the instructions).  This has not happened, nor has my skin flaked.  I think my skin looks a little brighter & even toned, but considering the short amount of time I've been using this, I could just be seeing what I want to see (sorry but I tend to be pretty skeptical of products like this).I anticipate this bottle will last a long time.  I'm very curious to see what the end results are after long time use.  I will return to post any relevant updates should they arise.  Overall, I think this is worth trying if you can afford it, but I'm not too sure this is something you would want to use in the winter unless you have excessively oily skin.UPDATE 7-15-15 (was 5 stars at time of original review):This lasted a little over 2 months.  I do not feel that the results are worth the price.  I think it improved very very minor marks but not the more noticeable marks.  I do think it improved my skin (hence not rating it any lower than 4 stars) but I don't feel it delivered the kind of results it promised.

JollyGear Waist Trimmer Belt is amazing. It goes on easily and is very comfortable to wear either while just doing things around your home or while working out. It really got me sweating out that excess water weight in my sides and stomach that working out alone hasn't. Wearing this waist trimmer belt is showing me the results I've been looking for for way too long.It stays in place and doesn't pop open. It's comfortable and helps with my posture too.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review.

Amir Patio Umbrella Light is so cool. It takes 3 AA batteries, not included, for a brilliant light for your patio umbrella or to use in your tent. I love having this light on my patio umbrella for after dark card games, patio parties, or just enjoying whatever while relaxing on the patio at night. It's a safe light to use inside your tent when camping and it provides a better light than many battery operated lanterns do and certainly more than a flashlight does.Just slide the switch to turn on the outer ring of lights and/or push a white button for the inner ring of lights. There's no need to move back inside just because the sun went down! Just turn on your own "mini sun" with an Amir Patio Umbrella Light.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my review.

Zensah Peek Running Socks is the most wonderful socks I've come across for workouts as well as hiking. When I go on a shorter hike during hot weather I like wearing low cut hiking shoes rather than boots. The socks wick moisture away from feet to keep them much more comfortable and cut down on blisters and rubbing. The seamless toe it a real plus because it's more comfortable and won't rub the edges of your toes.They keep your feet from sliding around in your shoes like some socks do when you're working out, jogging, or hiking. They keep my feet feeling good so I can be less focused on my feet and more focused on the activity I'm involved in at the time. The socks have good compression that feels good and helps cut down on swelling after long or brutal workouts.I wear a size 10 women's shoe and the Medium size socks fit perfectly.I received a free sample in exchange for my honest review.

"Becoming Ellen" by Shari Shattuck is a smashing follow up book to "Invisible Ellen." I loved the first book and loved this book too! The characters are great in this story that was very well conceived and executed. The characters are very easy to identify with and make the book a true joy to read.If you haven't read the first book then consider ordering both "invisible Ellen" and "Becoming Ellen" to you completely understand the starring character, her co-star character, and those characters in supporting roles. Besides, once you read the first book you'll definitely want to read the second one. I can't wait for book #3 in the series!This is chic lit for all you lovely ladies who love a good read to curl up with along with your favorite beverage.

"Heart Sisters: Be the Friend You Want to Have" by Natalie Chambers Snapp really was a disappointment to me. I wasn't aware that this was a book that would talk more about Jesus, scripture, and G-d than about the social and psychological issues about female relationships. G-d and spirituality as a part of this female to female dynamic I'm good with. Jesus and New Testament scripture, not at all.I'm not sure why this book's description doesn't spell out that it has a strong Christian focus.I suppose it's a great book for Christian women but not for those of us who are of other faiths.

"X: A Novel" by Ilyasah Shabazz and Kekla Magoon is a truly gripping story based on the early years in life of Malcolm X. It's a story that pulled me in from the beginning and left me captivated to the end. It's a hard story to stop reading and one that kept me up late into the night until I finished it. It's written with such a smooth, lyrical, flow that it simply carries you effortlessly from page to page.There's a lot to learn about the injustice he experienced, the trouble he found himself in, and the changes in him that catapulted him to be one of the most influential leaders in the Afro-American Community in the 1960's.For a YA book, it carries a powerful message. A must read for just about anyone, 16+, who is interested in US History.

Rhythm Superfoods Kale Chips, Kool Ranch, are so addictive! If you've never had kale chips before, they may seem a little strange tasting at first but they quickly become something I couldn't get enough of!  And they are such a healthy snack. Packed with protein, Vit. K, Vit. C, Vit. A, antioxidants, live enzymes, and more.These chips are Non-GMO Verified, Vegan, and gluten-free. Rhythm Superfoods Kale Chips fit just about any lifestyle or diet.

These Oliver and Jumpy stories are too precious! Each of the three stories is delightful and illustrated with amazing and brilliantly colored artwork. There are so many things to talk about in both the story and the illustrations. It's a book that can turn what could be an ordinary story time into an extraordinary one that allows fun conversation and bonding between parent and child.All of the stories are ones your child will ask you to read to them again and again.I received a free download of this book in exchange for my honest review.

These are so lovely and I really love how they look on me. Yes, they do pinch your upper ear but I remedied that by cutting a little moleskin and put it on the part that touches the back of your ear and cut a little strip to put over the part that touches the front of the ear placing it vertically. I think it's the thin front edge of the ear clip that digs into the ear. I'm a hiker so I've always got moleskin around for blisters on my feet, also good when new shoes give you blisters.These ear cuffs are a richer, yellow gold color than the photos on this page show. The little crystals add just the right amount of sparkly bling to each wing. You'll see that they do look MUCH nicer when you actually have them. They make me feel angelic as if I'm wearing angel wings; and would love it if they invited angels to come and whisper good things to me. Not sure they'll really be inviting angels to stop by but it's a nice thought.Wearing these ear cuffs with dressy casual works as well as with evening wear. If you've got the right kind of personality and accessories they work well with jeans and a t-shirt. Perfect for a night on the town, the opera, or a rock concert.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review.

This ear cuff is simply beautiful! When the light hits the clear crystals they shine and sparkle like your personality. Depending on the type of light and how it hits the crystals, you'll see brief little bits of yellow, green, blue, purple, pink, and bright white glitter as you move. I enjoyed holding it under an LED light and moving the ear cuff around just enjoying the beauty of it.I attend the opera and symphony quite a bit and will love wearing this ear cuff when I'm there as well as other events. It's a great addition to my evening accessories.Don't think this is something only for young women. I'm closing in on 60 and think I look beautiful wearing it.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review. You know it's honest because I just admitted my age!

"Woof (Bowser and Birdie)" by Spencer Quinn is such a fun book! It's a perfect mystery for kids with a lovable goofy dog. What's not to love?It's a book for kids but I won't tell if you or other grown-ups find yourselves with "Woof" in your hands!A great little read for the whole family.

"Pieces of My Mother: A Memoir" by Melissa Cistaro is an emotional read. It was really hard to read some portions of the book without taking a break and getting another box of tissues ready. There is so much sadness. And still, I loved the book.It's a very well done memoir.

"High Holiday Porn: A Memoir" by Eytan Bayme is a coming of age memoir of a young Orthodox Jew. It's mostly about the author masturbating and then being overwhelmed with guilt because he masturbated. I'm thinking this is a book geared to men who can probably related. Since I'm a woman, I'm lost on the humor.As a Jew, I was expecting maybe a little masturbation but more awkward first dates and kisses. Young love. At least young love where two people are involved rather than oneDefinitely a book for men more than it is for woman. I don't get it, I don't want to get it.

"Fishbowl: A Novel" by Bradley Somer is so utterly refreshing. It's creative, it's imaginative, it's great! The descriptions are vivid, the scenarios intriguing, the dialogue is engaging. It's an imaginary world that I completely buy.  What's not to love?It was such a pleasure reading this book that I can't wait to see what else I can find by Somer.

"Man in Profile: Joseph Mitchell of The New Yorker" by Thomas Kunkelf is a really good book. I didn't know who Joseph Mitchell was but decided to get this book. Now I now who he was and enjoyed learning all about his life. And what an amazing life this man had!Doesn't matter if you know who Joseph Mitchell is or you don't. This is a good book about a great man who lived an exciting life. I'm so glad got to read about him. Very enjoyable read BTW.

"Fueled By Failure: Using Detours and Defeats to Power Progress" by Jeremy Bloom is a book that should be handed out to college grads along with their diplomas. Too many young people are entering the job market almost as if they are expecting to make it to the top within their first year. This is the perfect book to let them know they need to slow down and get some experience under their belt. And part of that experience is learning what works and what doesn't.You have to make mistakes to learn what doesn't work so you can explore other options to  find what does. You can't be afraid to fail. There is no way to truly think outside the box and always be right. And if you always have to be right there is no innovation because things are done in a safe predictable winning way. There is no advancement. No change. You have to take risks to move on.This is a well written, fast read. A must have for any business office bookshelf.

"The Marriage of Opposites" by Alice Hoffman is a wonderful book. The author writes with such smooth flow making the reading of this book a true joy. I love Hoffman's descriptions and her elegant prose. The story and characters are well crafted and easy to connect with.This is great read that I really enjoyed.

"The Ghost in My Brain: How a Concussion Stole My Life and How the New Science of Brain Plasticity Helped Me Get it Back" by Clark Elliott is such a good book. I had a concussion several years ago when I was in a bus accident. Concussions are the weirdest thing; and scary to top it off. Fortunately I recovered from mine after a lengthy recovery but I know all too well what it is to live with diminished cognitive abilities. And the brain is such an individual creature in the body nobody can tell you whether or not you'll even recover from trauma to the brain. I found myself reliving my post accident healthcare scenarios in my head while reading about the author's.This book is full of so much important information. The author also does an excellent job of conveying to readers just what it's like to have a concussion. Most importantly, Elliott has let us know there is real hope for so many people who have experienced trauma to the brain.

"Enchanted August: A Novel" by Brenda Bowen is the perfect summer read. It even has August in the title! Grab some iced tea and this book and find yourself a spot by the fan, at the pool, or on the beach and you are set.This is some fun chic lit. It's a well crafted story with interesting characters who are easy to connect with. A book that offers a great escape from reality taking you to a completely different place, if only in your mind.I really enjoyed this one!

"Stir: My Broken Brain and the Meals That Brought Me Home" by Jessica Fechtor is just the type of inspirational book I need to have around. I have Secondary Progressive MS so I've always got something going wrong with my body and constantly need to improvise and adapt...again...and it does get tiring. Not a poor me scenario but an oh, the heck with it deal.As I read "Stir" I felt myself stirring and itching to get into my art supplies and cooking up some ideas on paper and canvas. It was the author's motivation for her own recovery is really catchy, like a song you can't get out of your head but better. Anything neurologically wrong with you can be a nightmare with endless frustrations. But, ya gotta do it again and again and again. And again.I love the recipes. My favorite is the Sesame Noodles. This dish is soooo good. I never thought of skipping the peanut butter either. I was out of crushed red pepper so I used chili paste instead.A well written book that motivated me to keep trying and try again. And again.

"The Silver Swan" by Elena Delbanco was a disappointment. This story could have been so much more. On one hand, much of the story is very well written with great characters. On the other hand, much of the dialogue and scenes are shallow and not up to the quality of the characters or the writing in other parts of the book.This is a book I wish I had passed on. The sad thing is, it holds so much promise and could have been better developed.

"A Deadly Affair at Bobtail Ridge" is the first thing I've read by Terry Shames and I LOVED it!!! I have to read more by this author. The way the story progresses with twists and turns, it kept throwing me off from what I thought was going to happen and had me starting over with my guesses. And isn't the the fun of mysteries?This is the kind of mystery I really enjoy.

"A Bad Character: A novel" by Deepti Kapoor is a story written in beautiful, lyrical prose. I lost track of time while reading this book. Kapoor's rich, vivid descriptions of Delhi and the various scenes throughout the book painted images in my mind. I love the smooth, easy flow and its rhythm.This is more than a story. It truly is a work of art.

"The Road to Character" by David Brooks provides important food for thought. I like his ideas on humility, something that we see less and less of. I see humility as a strength while I know others who view it as a weakness. Following this road to character is not an easy one and one that requires constant monitoring of yourself.With so much brashness and flaunting of self these days it's too easy to lose track of our inner self. Too easy to lose track of what it means to have character and poise and grace. This book gives us not only a reminder of the important aspects of who we are but a road to follow in order to discover or rediscover our character.

"Closed Doors" by Lisa O'Donnell is a haunting story of family secrets told in voice of Michael Murray who is only 11 years old. It's a well crafted story with intriguing characters and deep emotional turmoil. While struggling to find normalcy in his home life, Michael faces the regular things kids deal with and worry about in their lives.This is a powerful story that will tug at your heartstrings. I enjoyed this book immensely.

"The Fly Trap" by Fredrik Sjberg has got to be the most fascinating book that focuses on flies since "The Fly." There are so many different types of flies you know. But, this isn't a book just about the study of flies. It's about life, living in the woods, hunting in the woods, other insects, and flies. I found it surprisingly good.It's a pretty quick read. You might say the reader will simply fly through this one!

"Muse: A novel" by Jonathan Galassi is a book I really enjoyed. I love the rhythm and esoteric vibe the story's flow gives off. I had a hard time putting it down and found it to be a pretty fast read. Definitely a book for all those in the artsy, theater, music, literature, writer crowd! You know, the dreaded right brainers!

"Burning Bush 2.0: How Pop Culture Replaced the Prophet" by Paul Asay may have topics geared towards teens but the writing seems to be at the level parents would read. It's probably best used as a book for Christian families to use as a way to open discussions about G-d and His messages. There were things in the book that I found interesting but overall I wasn't impressed. I already got the message G-d speaks to us in all sorts of ways.

"Innocence; or, Murder on Steep Street" by Heda Margolius Kovly and translated by Alex Zucker is an utterly amazing novel. The power and force of this story left me wondering how a quiet woman could write with such a strong voice. Apparently she had it in her. Her words made me sit up and take heed and leaving me mesmerized and wanting more.I need to read more of her writing.

"Someone Is Watching: A Novel" by Joy Fielding is okay but not nearly as good as her other books I've read. It just wasn't one I felt grabbing at me or felt as if I couldn't put it down. I can't really put my finger on why, it just didn't do it for me.I'm still one of Fielding's fans and am looking forward to her next book.

"Ghost Fleet: A Novel of the Next World War" by P. W. Singer and August Cole sounded like a good read to me but, I wasn't that crazy about it. It is well written with great characters, it just wasn't my cup of tea. It seems more like a guy book than one targeted to gals like me. I know exactly which of my male friends would love this book just from talking to them about it. They'll most likely be ordering it for themselves.As far as I go, I just couldn't get into it. I do like a lot of books similar to this but, this one just didn't reach my female soul.

"Migratory Animals: A Novel" by Mary Helen Specht is an amazing book. The story and characters are well developed and executed with a smooth even flow. The dialogue is as engaging as the story itself and had me completely and utterly captivated  This book takes a look at characters who have reached a point in their lives where they need to make a decision on which direction their lives should go; stay on one road or take a turn and see where that road leads.It's a hard to put down book that pulled me in so deep the world outside this book didn't seem to exist. I lost track of time and found myself finishing the book at 4 am. I had know idea so much time had passed. It's been a while since a book consumed me like this one did.Definitely not a book to miss. And one I'll be re-reading again and again in the future.

"A Real Guide to Really Getting It Together Once and for All: (Really)" by Ashley Rickards is a great book for gals in their late teens to young adult. But, there is a little something in there for ladies of all ages. A great book to buy for a daughter, niece, or granddaughter that you can spend some time reading when she's not home! Or just buy one for yourself too, if you're the mother, aunt, or grandmother.There's a little bit of everything you need to know in order to be a completely together chic. Tips on hair, make-up, entertaining, decorating, relationships of all types, you name it. It's easy to read and easy to follow. No complicated examples with impossible directions for how to do nearly impossible things without a staff of beauticians, designers, decorators, blah blah blah.I really enjoy having this book and I'm of the older lady persuasion. Wish I had some of these ideas and hints when I was younger. It would have made life so much nicer!

"The Mapmaker's Children: A Novel" by Sarah McCoy took on an interesting approach alternating between women, one from the 1800's and the other from the present day. Historical fiction and present day fiction. It was well thought out and executed with engaging dialogue as well as interesting characters, descriptions, and scenes.It's a lovely story that is so easy to get pulled into. It's a book that I looked forward to getting back to anytime I had to put it down. A wonderful escape from my own life and a great summer read. It was the perfect book to take to the park and enjoy along with the sun and an icy beverage.

"The Man with the Compound Eyes: A Novel" by Wu Ming-Yi is a book that brings us a wonderful mix of the real and the unreal; the real, the magical, and the surreal.  It is beautifully written with smooth, even flow. The characters are people I cared about and could identify with.This is a terrrific read that is quite unique and executed with truly imaginative creativity. Wu Ming-Yi has woven together a very special book that should not be missed by those who love to dream and believe that fantasy can actually be an alternative reality.

"Eileen: A Novel" by Ottessa Moshfegh is a dark and oddly gratifying book. I actually enjoyed the bizarre, disparaging, creepiness this book offers.  It's a well written book with excellent flow that makes for a rather fast read. The story is a compelling one that I found to be a hard one to put down. There area few parts of the book that didn't read as well and were tough for me to get through, hence the 4 stars instead of 5.Overall, a wonderful, dark book that needs to be read.

I found "ZeroZeroZero" by Roberto Saviano to be a rather choppy read. The flow was so hesitant. An annoyance to read. Filled with commas and short sentences. Maybe it was, the translation. As I read, it felt jumpy, like I was reading Cocaine induced reading. Which, possibly was, the point. It just wasn't a pleasant reading experience for me.

"Denton Little's Deathdate" by Lance Rubin is an extremely humorous story about a world where people attend their funerals before they die. Everyone has a Deathdate. I'm not sure how to described how knowing when you are going to die and attending your own funeral makes for an amusing read but, trust me, it does.This utterly unique, and humorous, book is well conceived and executed. I loved the characters and everything in this black comedy about a teen whose deathdate is on the same day as his senior prom.Just the thought of knowing I'm going to die someday can bring on the anxiety but knowing where, exactly would definitely be a mind bender for me. And it should be for these characters too, right? And the plot thickens!This unique read is a must read and not miss. It's surprisingly good! A bit unsettling but, really good.

"The Woman Who Stole My Life: A Novel" by Marian Keyes is another winner written by this author! It's funny, well written with great characters and a difficult book to put down. It's the perfect summer read whether by the pool or at the beach. Actually it's a great read anywhere you can have your feet up and a cool drink at hand to help beat the summer heat.I really liked this book and hope to read more by Keyes.

"The Honest Truth" by Dan Gemeinhart is a wonderful book for the middle school, teen, and YA audiences as well as the old adult audience as well. It's a well developed story with engaging characters and dialogue. It has terrific flow and descriptions that paint a vivid picture of scenes and what's going on.This is a book that is a good one for parents to read before the younger range it's targeted for to allow for discussion of some of the more difficult topics within it. It makes for a way to not only open up discussion but helps start a way of beginning a new shared experience of books. A family book club so to speak. And this is a great book to start with since it's one everyone can and will enjoy reading!

"The Bone Tree (Penn Cage)" by Greg Iles didn't hold up for me. I found it tedious and a bit trendy with all the Civil Rights and JFK stuff. There seems to be a lot of those topics being tied into TV, movies, and books these days. So much it's almost as convenient taking sure fire emotional triggers from the 60's is the updated version of throwing in a couple Nazis in a WWII era film to get a rise out of the audience whether it fits into or is necessary to the story. Not to mention the JFK theory didn't fly with me in the least. Nor did the chat with Castro.I enjoyed "Natchez Burning" and "Spandau Phoenix" immensely. "The Bone Tree" just didn't hold up to those other books by Iles.If a book has as many pages as this book has I don't mind if the book is a good one. In fact, a good book is a great read no matter how long it is. But a book that isn't to my liking is seriously long no matter how short it is. It just wasn't the book for me.

"The Seven Good Years: A Memoir" byax Etgar Keret is one hilarious book! I've had some serious health issues and recovering has been taking so long. If I ever needed a book that cheered me up, it's now. And this one had me smiling and chuckling, working better than any prescription my doctor could write! I actually felt more upbeat and a little better while reading it. And I'm still feeling pretty good!One enjoyable, hard to put down book you won't regret getting. There's more joy in this book than you could find in 4 Disney Parks!

"Further Out Than You Thought: A Novel" by Michaela Carter was a terrific read. It's one of those books that pulled me in almost from the start. A real page turner that keeps you up past your bedtime, making it a great weekend or vacation read! It had me feeling so many emotions that had me embracing the characters and their engaging dialogue.It's life different from what I've known and seen through eyes so different from my own. A wonderful read I actually hated to see end.

"The Girls from Corona del Mar: A novel" by Rufi Thorpe started off okay and even then it was a sludge for me. This book was just too heavy and dark for me to fully enjoy it. I can see why some people would love it but it was too depressing for me. Some depressing books I can get into but this one was heavy handed depressing.I was tempted to stop reading before I was even a quarter of the way through but, kept hoping it would pick up for me. It didn't.

This is an exceptional mini tablet that really took me by surprise. I love how portable it is. It fits in my purse or backpack with no problem. There are several apps and widgets available for just about any need you may have.I downloaded the app for Netflix so I can watch movies wherever I go and for Facebook to connect with friends and family on the fly as well as others that I'll be using a lot. The sound is pretty good, much better through headphones or a speaker, and the quality of the video is extremely good. The camera can be set to take photos or video with the option to switch the screen and viewfinder around to take selfies. It loads quickly for high speed surfing and use.The battery charges up pretty quick, less than an hour for a completely empty battery, and keeps a charge all day long.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review.

Brightech's LightView PRO SuperBright Magnifier Floor Lamp with 60 LED's is the perfect lamp for reading when you have trouble with smaller print, for hobbies like stamp collecting or model building, or over a table for doing detailed artwork. The magnifying glass is clear with no distortion. I love it for working at my printmaking table while carving detailed lino and wood blocks as well as working on etching plates. And it's also great when I need to make out super fine print when my aging eyes just aren't seeing it like they used to.The light is a bright, full spectrum light that allows you to see true color. So the colors I see in my art in my studio is the same colors I see in my art when I take it outside and view it in sunlight.Whether you want to work on art or read the next best seller on your "To Read" list, closely examine the new stamps you've purchased at auction or actually read the fine print in that contract, this is the lamp you've got to have!And it saves on the amount of money it costs to have a light on. LED's give you bright light at a fraction of the cost spent on traditional and compact fluorescent bulbs.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review.

ROGGE DUO-Clean Screen Cleaner is really, really good stuff! It has no damaging alcohol or other ingredients that can ruin electronics while cleaning them. It worked wonders cleaning monitor, laptop screens, tablet, smartphone screen, and TV screens. Amazing, streak free results using this product and the enclosed cleaning cloth!I've been afraid to use anything on my TV screen to clean it. Rogge Duo-Clean took away that worry and allowed me to finally clean it, not just simply wipe it down with a glass cleaning cloth.All of my electronics viewing screens are looking good! I'm even using it to clean my glasses for streak free vision!I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review. And honestly, it's better than I had expected!

Syllable G600 Stereo Wireless Bluetooth 4.0 Headphones are really darned good headphones. They pair easily with my smartphone and computer. The sound is amazing with a deep rich bass. They feel comfortable on my ears and are a pleasure to wear for a long period of time.Listening to Heavy Metal and Rock sounds as good as Classical and the Blues.A great buy for such a great set of headphones.I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest review.

"My Paris Dream: An Education in Style, Slang, and Seduction in the Great City on the Seine" by Kate Betts is a terrific memoir about the authors escapades in Paris and its fashion industry. It gives great incite into an Australian doing her best to make a life in the City of Lights, international center of high fashion, art, culture, etc. etc. etc. She does a great job of translating the behavior, style, slang, and so forth.It's an eye opening book about the people of Paris as well as a very enjoyable read. I dream of going to Paris and eat up almost any book or movie from or about Paris. If I can't be there, I need everything I can get my hands on and brain into to feed the dream. This book did not disappoint.A perfect read for anyone who dreams of Paris whether you've been there or not.

"Flings: Stories" by Justin Taylor is an enjoyable collection of stories. These are stories geared more towards the under 40 audience, I still liked what I read. I am a fan of the short story and found the ones in this book to be well written in a unique, fresh voice.This is a great book for short story fans to add to their collection! Great summer reading for sure.

This is a beautiful product that is very well made.  Each section is made of a slightly different fabric and various pieces are crinkly (such as one leg, one ear, the antlers, etc.).  It's a good size too - big enough for a baby to roll around on but small enough to fold up and bring somewhere.As a mom of a ton of kids though, I'd be hesitant to give this as a gift because it's not terribly practical.  If you're using it for travel then it's really geared toward parents who don't mind schlepping a ton of stuff around.  I think a more seasoned parent would probably pack a blanket and taggie  (such as this one click here) instead.  This mat really is not quite a rug and not quite a blanket, so truly it's only purpose would be as a play mat.  If that's what you're looking for, this is a great choice.  As a mom of a bunch of kids though, personally I tend to gravitate towards the things that are more practical.Also as others have pointed out, it's very, very pink.

This book changed my life.  Her examples of idolatry as Christians currently experience it in our modern world were some of the deepest thoughts I've ever read.  She assumes you're a mature Christian struggling to live life with the passion you once had.  Her examples of idolatry include things like your to do list, your kids' accomplishments, your schedule and anything else that stresses you out.  The way that she encourages you to identify ways that God is not first are extremely helpful.  I can't praise this book enough.  I think I easily highlighted about 50% of it.  I have praised it so much my husband, who doesn't read, plans to read it.
This blanket it awesome - it's just the right weight, right size, right amount of stretch and very soft.  I have nothing negative to say about this blanket - great product!

I really enjoyed this study and got a ton out of it.  I did it alone and while I think a group would have been great, it was pretty awesome as a solo study as well.  I thought it was very well written, thought provoking, and looking at topics that aren't frequented in Christian circles.  I specifically thought that her exploration of idolatry went really well with another book I'm reading called Because He Loves Me.There were a few things she could have done differently that would have really set this book apart.  One is that she doesn't go very deep at all with her personal examples, and I would have loved to learn more about her personally.  I think that a Bible teacher does well to share their own struggles and she really doesn't.There were also a few times (thought not many) that she overextends an application.  For example, she talks about getting a group together and anointing each other.  Umm, what?Practically there were about 90% of the Bible references included in the text and you had to look up the rest.  I have little kids and I would have LOVED it if they were all included.  I know how to use my Bible and practically it's just easier when it's all right there.Those were all minor things though.  I feel so blessed to have done this study.  Her thoughts on focusing on the source of our provision, idolatry, self care and many other topics were dead on and thought provoking.

These are even better than I expected.  They are front lined, as others have mentioned, which is sort of unnecessary.  The bottom line is that kids can wear them alone.  My daughter is tall and thin and these fit her perfectly - they were a touch loose, longer than I expected, and easy to cinch around the waist.  I was glad that they weren't skin tight and that they were long.  They're actually pretty modest.  She's really pleased with them and finds them comfortable - which she's pretty picky about.  I would definitely order these again.

I read this aloud to my 9 and 6 year old and found it extremely confusing.  Maybe I'm slow on the uptake but it look me a while to figure out that the "furless" were humans and that "deathways" were roads, etc.  My kids kept asking me to explain the book and I wasn't sure what they were talking about.  The story is very dark and sad - Isla's family disappears almost immediately (with a lot of talk about fur and blood) and basically all she talks about the rest of the book is how depressed and upset she is about it.  I personally even found it a little disturbing.For kids into dark fantasy this will hit a sweet spot, but for kids used to lighter books I would avoid this one.

This book is clearly intended for early readers and not meant to be anything deep or meaningful.  I started out thinking the sisters would have a great relationship because the first part of the book doesn't elevate Beatrix (the one with magic) in any way.  I thought it would be interesting to explore that.  Instead, Beatrix ends up being pretty obnoxious and harassing Olive with her magic, which results in Olive retaliating with a prank which goes awry and they have to work together (without adults) to solve the problem.Again, there's no moral here and the witch part is not deep either, so easy to gloss over for those who may find it more objectionable.  She has magic because she was born at midnight on a full moon, not for any deep reason.  I actually appreciated that because I don't mind magic as a playful concept but prefer to avoid it otherwise.My kids found it entertaining but it's not something they revisit a lot.  Overall it's a cute story with no moral lesson and good for reading practice.  As long as that's what you're expecting it's worth the read.

This is a nice kit with liquid watercolors that are fun to mix, as opposed to the cheap kind you can't mix, but it didn't entertain my artistic 9 year old for very long.  She painted two of the pictures and never finished the third, and the results weren't very impressive.  I also didn't think she actually learned anything using the kit, which was my hope since she seems interested in watercolors.  The pamphlet it comes with is not very instructional.  Overall I think the price is way too high for what you end up getting.

This is an incredibly well designed game with excellent components and really good replay because the puzzle is constantly changing.  Every time you put out the six cards you have different rules to follow.  I love that it was time limited so that it can't drag on forever.  My kids, ages 9 and 6, were able to pick up on it pretty quickly and enjoyed playing it also.  So I would say definitely 4 stars for people looking for a logic game, especially because you can play it with more than one person (unlike other logic games we own).If you don't love logic games, like me, you may not really enjoy this.  Also if you're like me and are married to an engineer you may not win - ever.  That sort of ruins the experience for me personally.  It's not how I think and makes me feel stupid so I didn't enjoy this personally, but it is well designed and I'd recommend it for the genre.

I really enjoyed this game.  It's a nice placement game where you're trying to control islands by placing bridges (small rectangular pieces) between the islands.  If you have a majority of the bridges in place then you control that island and place a circle on it.  Whoever controls the most at the end wins.  The theme isn't strong so it's really more of an abstract.If you're glancing quickly then the cover is a little deceiving.  There's nothing hand related about the game and the board is literally a bunch of islands on it that look nothing like a hand.  I do wish that rather than going the magical route they would have gone the geographical route and maybe also made the game into a geography game.  It would have worked really well that way.Even so my husband and I enjoyed playing it together.  I don't think it has extensive replay abilities for adults since you're limited by the cards and therefore limited in strategy.  Once you've figured out the best strategy then it wouldn't be that interesting to play.  Even still, for kids and the non-serious gamer this is a well designed game that makes for a fun experience if you don't want to think too hard.

I was looking for something to wear while me and the kids go for long walks. I have a two year old so I always been my hands free. When I saw this money belt sold by VOCHIC I thought it would be perfect.This money belt was very light which was a huge plus. Its also adjustable so the kids could wear it as well. I was pleased with how much I was able to hold. I put my keys, cash, binki, and a few fruit snacks in it with no problem, The material is nice and durable as well.I included a few pictures so you can see for yourself what this money belt looks like in person. I hope that my picture and review helped to give you a better understanding of this product.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that this money belt worked great for long walks.

I love egg salad or eggs in my garden salad. When I saw this egg slicer made by Celebright it looked different then others I have used so I couldn't wait to give it a try.This egg slicer is designed to slice your eggs two different ways. When I made egg salad I used it on the end that thinly sliced the egg then I gently picked up the egg pieces keep them in place and turn it a 180 degree and re sliced it. This perfectly sliced the egg in to little pieces. I also used that same end when I make potato salad to slice the eggs. The other end slices the egg into bigger cubes like style that was perfect for my garden salads. I was extremely happy with this egg slicer.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that this egg slicer is perfect to use for so many different things!

I myself am not a smoker but every one around me is. I bought this black ash tray sold by Celebright to sit out side on the deck in hopes that people would smoke outside instead of inside.I loved that this ash tray was made out of plastic so it it fell I didn't have to worry about it breaking. Even though its plastic its not extremely light weight so it worked perfectly out on the deck. The middle part of the ashtray has holders so the cigarettes dont blow away of fall out. I now dont have to worry about every one throwing cigarette butts all over my yard and the plus side is they can all smoke on the deck now instead of in the house near me.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that this ash tray was a perfect outside ashtray!

I have been looking for ways to make small individual cakes for the kids. When I saw this food molds kit sold by Culinary Buddy I had to try it out in hopes it would work.This food molds kit worked perfect for my small cakes!! I was able to make layered cakes unique for each child. My son likes all chocolate so he was easy but My daughter wanted yellow and chocolate layered. The food molds kept my cake in a perfect circle. The best part was that I was so easy to remove the molds as well. My cake didn't break all a part and looked perfect!I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that this food molds kit will be my new way of making the children cakes!

My teen daughter is very obsessed with the color pink. When I saw this pink lightweight traveling backpack sold by C&G I knew I had to get it for her to try it out.This backpack isn't like normal back packs that you see, This backpack folds into a little carrying case that looks like a little purse. I was glad that this backpack was light weight since my daughter uses it for camping trips. It was comfortable to wear in the back as well. It is a thinner material but its strong for being thin. I myself liked that it was thin since it was for camping it it got wet it was able to dry out a lot easier.I included a few pictures so you can see for yourself what this backpack looks like in person. I hope that my picture and review helped to give you a better understanding of this product.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that this backpack worked great for camping.

My mother does tons of craft things but her eyes are not as good as they use to be. I saw this hands free LED magnifying glasses sold by Neon and had to get them for her to test out.These magnifying glasses have a LED light that helps you see the crafting items so much easier. The light wasn't bright were it would blind you but bright enough were you could see. Things they stay on you face so you dont have to hold a magnifying glass you have both hands free which was a huge plus. I did notice when I would hold my head down that they wanted to slid off so that is one thing I would change. Over all though they worked well.I received this product at a discounted promotional price in return for my honest and unbiased review. I can honestly say that these magnifying glasses are great if you need to be hands free.

We do not have many places to eat Koren food around here, Actually many people here dont even eat Koren food. I get bored with the same old stuff though so when I saw Seoul Food Koren Cookbook by Naomi Imatome-Yun I had to give it a try.This Koren Cookbook was filled with so many unique recipes for me to try out. I do however wish that some was a little more easy to make but over all it was still nice. With 135 recipes you are bound to find one that you will enjoy as well. I didn't realize how many ingredients it takes to make the Koren dishes so make sure you have your list ready to check off lol. Koren is not something I would eat every day or even every week but it is something I will be making at least every month.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I got this book SCRUM Basics by Tycho Press to help learn more about about management. I will be honest, I didn't know much about what SCRUM was but I was willing and hoping to learn more about it. However though I found this book extremely confusing and hard to follow. It didn't help me learn much at all but just because it didn't help me doesn't mean that it may not help you. Me and my teen daughter is always looking for jewelry to share. I'm a sucker for a good steam mop and am always looking for the perfect one with TONS of steam and a deep clean. This one was easy to assemble, just a moment or two. Theres one tank with two places to fill it. The solution is one spot and water in the other. I personally like cleaning with white vinegar, so once I've finished the solution I'll switch over to that. As for cleaning with it, I love the shape of the bottom and it has a nice swivel to it to reach corners. The big con I found is that it's verging on painful to hold down the steam trigger the entire time. I'm only 34 so it's nothing like old age making this aggravating.  I'd like it better if it had the options for bursts of steam or to lock it for continuous steam. I found the streamsteam button on the bottom, but then it switched it to steam only. I do like the idea of the grout brush, but I don't currently have any grout, only hardwood and vinyl tile. I suppose it could come in handy if I had a dried on spill though. Over all I do like this steamer but have found my favorite is still this black and decker one: http://www.amazon.com/Black-Decker-BDH1850SM-Steam-Mop/dp/B00B92CN5S/ref=cm_cr-mr-title

I eat well,except for my annoying sweet tooth, exercise every day(weather permitting) and hit the gym a few times a week. I mainly wanted a protein powder because I get too busy for breakfast or lunch most days and this is fast and easy for me. I've been through many different protein powders but can never find just what I want. A lot of the times I thought I could deal with certain aspects but over time just grew to hate them. The one that specifically comes to mind that I really didn't like was the sunwarrior warrior blend protein vanilla. Too gritty and too much of a weird aftertaste.I wasn't too hopeful when I decided to try this, but it fit what I always look for(specifically a lack of biotin) so I thought I'd give it a shot. I blended 20grams of this powder with 10 oz of Tazo pumpkin latte and maybe 3 oz of coconut milk in my ninja. Its surprisingly delicious! I think I might also try it warmed up, it's almost like a yummy regular pumpkin latte. It seems almost impossible to find a sugar free protein that doesn't taste like crap but this one is listed as no sugar added and just has some stevia. It doesn't taste overly sweet but was just the perfect sweet level for me. No gross aftertaste either. I'd definitely try the chocolate flavor of this protein.
