UPDATE July '15: After getting ignored a year or so ago with customer service I randomly got an email from a woman wanting to "improve" their customer service. This was at the same time my shine all of a sudden REFUSED to sync with the iphone app.  I was in talks with another customer service guy at the same time as this woman emailed me - he also stopped responding when he couldn't find a resolution. Anyway long story short, she sent me a new shine. She was really just trying to get me to say I liked this again on my amazon review, but it's still the same. Inaccurate tracking. I thought maybe having a newer one it would have improved? nope. I walk a very specific route most days and know the milage. No matter what I do or change on the app or where I wear the shine it's always wrong, but at least 3/4 of a mile if not more. I still wouldn't recommend anyone to buy a Misfit shineUPDATED review:First of all, as you may see in the comments of people who gave the shine a 1 or 2 star review, they said "contact us! we'll make it right!". I emailed the guy and he was quick to respond initially. He said he was forwarding to his tech team(or something along those lines) and they would get in touch with me soon. That was over a month ago. With that same email, he told me a bunch of things that should fix the problems I was having that I'd already tried. I told him I'd tried those and I never heard from him again. Then, the band broke. I emailed him a photo of the broken band and asked for a replacement. No response. They're pretending like they have great customer service, but unfortunately, they're all talk.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I go hiking with my dogs whenever the weather is nice and also hit the gym 2-3 times a week, so I thought this would be cool for motivation and to track my improvements. I also have a really hard time getting a good night's sleep, so I wanted to see what was happening there as well. A big update that deserves a mention: the shine app now syncs with the my fitness pal app and Lose it! app. I know that was a big con for many and I think its a very recent update.  The shine doesn't seem as accurate as I was hoping for. Just putting the battery in and syncing it to my iphone 5s, it told me I'd gone 56 steps when I hadn't even gotten up and crossed a room. Hopefully this is just because you tend to move it more as you get it set up, and isn't indicative of normal use/overtracking. I also had a really hard time putting the battery in. They include a tool for you to pop the back off, but that tool is also very good at scraping the shine. My 'jet' black shine now has little silver scrapes from where I struggled with getting the backing off. It was a pain in the neck and I'm not happy I already marked up my new toy. Now that I know how the paint scrapes, I would definitely have gotten the silver one instead of the black. Otherwise, I do like that it takes CR2 batteries instead of needing to be charged, big plus.Experience so far wearing it in different locations:Ankle: I started using it on my ankle in the wrist strap on my hikes and at the gym to see if that is what most accurately tracks movement. I've tested it against a pedometer I've worn that I know is very accurate(we actually spent a lot of time counting steps in the past and checking to see if the pedometer was correct). The shine tracked almost 400 more steps on a long hike then my bare bones pedometer did. A bit over ambitious in the count.In my pocket: I found this to be as effective as on my ankle for the most part. It does still overtrack when I'm hiking by a few hundred steps, and at the gym it tracks less than my treadmill useage. I would think a treadmill is pretty seriously accurate when it says you've done 2 miles but the shine says I only did 1.7Wrist: I tested it at the gym wearing it in the band doing a mile and 1/2 on the treadmill. The shine only tracked that I did about .6 of a mile which made me crazy, as I should have hit my daily goal with that 1.5. I think it tracks walking only when you're swinging your arms, the times I was holding onto the heart rate monitor on the treadmill it didn't count. Also, when sleeping I wake up and I've already tracked over 200-300 steps? This is not a fluke, it's every morning. I must be a crazy multi-tasker, walking in my sleep. I assume it's tracking my arm movement, but that shouldn't count as steps when it's also showing that's when I was asleep. Next I'm going to try keeping it in my pocket or attached to my waistband, but overall the experience at the gym and tracking steps in my sleep has me on the verge of returning it. I can understand a blip here and there of a few steps, but hundreds is not ok.It did track the time I went to sleep(wearing it on my wrist) and woke up to the minute, so that's on point. Sadly, within my 9 hour goal, it says I usually only have between 2 and 1/2 to 3 hrs and 45 minutes of restful sleep. Yikes!The app is ok, but it's not stellar, though it does seem to update pretty often. The sad thing is, even though I always do the update, I don't actually notice any differences in the app. I've found syncing to be temperamental, it usually take anywhere from 3-5 tries to get it to sync. Sometimes it recognizes the shine sitting in the circle on the screen, but most of the time it says "syncing failed". I would like more details in the sleep cycle part of the app as well, without buying that beddit thing. Honestly, this is just a fancy motivational tool because my 5 dollar dinky pedometer is more accurate than the shine. I'm going to keep using the shine and update my review as time goes on, but so far I'm a little underwhelmed.

These monitors are amazing! I usually lean towards using really good headphones to pick up every nuance and really LISTEN to music, but these gave a similar fun experience for me, I really heard all the instruments in some of my favorites. We have another set of very high end monitors and these are comparable, but for a lot less. They provide a deep low end with a lot of warmth to the overall sound, which I would think is attributed to the all wood cabinet. Easy to set up and I like that the headphone jack is in front to plug in my iphone. All the connecting cables needed get started immediately are in the box. They all had a good amount of length as well, I hate when wires are too short.These would be a welcome addition to any home and doesn't need to be reserved for audiophiles, since the price makes them great for anyone.

I've previously tried the Remington IPL6000USA I-Light Pro, Professional IPL Hair Removal Systemand didn't really get any results. When I saw this, I considered that there might be something a little more up-to-date technology wise that would make it work better, so I figured I'd give it a go.This one is a lot more compact, as the remington was attached to a larger piece via a cable. That made it harder to store, especially if you have limited space, so I really liked that bout the Philips model. This is just the body with a wire for power. I was impressed that it doesn't need any bulb replacements, as I've heard those can be very pricey. On the whole though, this one doesn't feel like it's really doing as much as the Remington did. On 5, the Remington would sting a bit, just like a rubberband snap. This one doesn't hurt at all. It seems to produce the same amount of light, but with less intensity. The Remington also felt like it had to gather juice in between, but this will just go one after the other if you hit the button. This one also has less bells and whistles. In order to start the Remington, you had to press your finger to to it to get it started, then it would beep before shooting at your skin. This one doesn't do any of those things. For the same price bracket, they're almost the same machine, though I really don't think either of these is worth more than 100 bucks. I suppose only time will tell.On top of that, you cannot use it on tanned skin(or any skin tone more than a fair-to-medium with dark hair). I'll have to wait for winter to get a more overall feel and review of this, since I can only use it on places right now that don't see the sun. I'll keep trying it and updating my review as time goes by.

This works well inside my cabinet under the sink. Only thing you have to consider is if you have a lot under there, it needs to go back farther to accommodate this basket. Otherwise, it works well and I like using it to hold spray cleaner and paper towels for easy access.

I had bought a fragrance sampler as a gift last year from a high end beauty store, which was awesome. It gave my boyfriend the opportunity to try out about 15 different men's fragrances, so that we could determine which one works with his body chemistry and was pleasing to both of our noses together. It actually turned out to be a pretty awesome gift and was a lot of fun. That particular gift set came with a voucher for a full size one of his choice, and in the end we had trouble deciding. This John Varvatos was our second choice, so I made sure to add it to my amazon list as a future gift.This not only smells amazing, the price buying for the 4.2 oz direct from amazon(I wouldn't buy from a 3rd party seller, personally) was unbeatable! It was the same bottle and box as I saw in the store. Buying this at Sephora or Ulta, it's about $75 bucks, so I was a huge fan of the price here. I would say this fragrance would span a variety of ages. We're in our early 30s, and it really suits him well. It's woodsy and rich, a bit mysterious. The notes are Ashwood, Tonka Beans, Santolina, Madras Wood, Quince Paste, Oak Moss, Silver Absinthe, White Lavender, Marine Fennel, Cubeb Peppers, Tobacco Leaf, Juniper Berries, Jasmine, Orris Root, Patchouli, Fir Balsam & Suede. A really delicious, masculine scent.  He alternates between this and a more aquatic fragrance depending on his mood. This is definitely my favorite of the two he uses. When he first started testing it out, I thought it might be too old for him, but after getting used to it, I really favor this scent. He sprays 1 spritz in the morning and when he comes home after work I can still smell it. I'd buy it again in a heartbeat!

For me this was more 50 shades of grey with a teeny splash of The Night Circus. All I kept thinking was "softcore circus".... It has some magical elements, but on the whole was a bit too much erotica. When I ordered it after reading the synopsis, I didn't realize this would fall under the erotica category at all and not only that, but it's book six in a series. I thought it was straight up fiction/romance, especially by the synopsis - which in the end I think was very misleading. If you're aware of what you're getting into and looking for some kink, you'll probably like this. Jackson is very adept at painting a rich, vivid picture of every scene with her words. The characters are interesting but overall it's very shallow. I didn't get any real passion or heart out of it. I wouldn't continue on with anything else in the series.

This is a nice, odorless hand cream but in all honestly, I could not tell a big difference from any other hand cream. My hands are in water on a daily basis and I use hand creams all the time. This cream feels nice, it is not sticky and does not leave a slippery feel on the hands, but after using it for a week, I could not tell a big difference on my cuticles and hands.

This beautiful book is a testament to one of the most iconic fashion photographers of the last century - Horst P. Horst (real name Horst Paul Albert Bohrmann). Horst's style, characterized by elegant poses and dramatic lighting, established him at the forefront of fashion photography as well as master portraitist.Chapters are arranged by the various types of photography he did with a brief introduction followed by luscious examples of his work, both in black-and-white and color. The first section covers his career in Paris where he photographed couture 30s fashion for French and British Vogue (his famous photograph "The Mainbocher Corset" is just one example).  "Stage and Screen" features portraits of Hollywood legends such as Bette Davis, Marlene Dietrich, Vivien Leigh and Gene Tierney. "Fashion in Colour" discusses his quick adaptation to the increasing popularity of color photography. "Male Nudes" shows how his dramatic use of lighting influenced later photographers like Robert Mapplethorpe and Bruce Weber. "Nature" explores his work with still lifes and flora. And finally, "Interiors" discusses his work as a photographer for "House and Garden" magazine. This chapter features an introduction by Valentine Lawson, Horst's longtime partner and includes photos of their popular home in the Hamptons.

This power strip/surge protector has 8 outlets that rotate (both horizontally and vertically), making it easier to position larger cords. Blue LED lights indicate power, usage and problems. It also features a resettable circuit breaker. The size is large (17" x 6") but is a slim design.This is a great value and is especially good for a home theater system. The lifetime warranty of $350,000 is also quite impressive.

I have used Reynolds Wrap Foil all my life and I can say without a doubt that it is superior to other brands. The heavy duty variety is especially stronger and holds up well to grilling, baking potatoes in the oven, etc. I also line baking sheets with this foil when heating something up in the oven. It helps prevents messes and protects the pans. I would not be without it!

This looks to be a sturdy and well-designed multi-tasking crock pot. (I have only used it once and will update my review as I experiment with it more). Unlike your traditional crock pot, for slow cooking purposes only, the Black & Decker Multi Cooker gives you the ability to sear meats and vegetables, saute and bake. The removable ceramic pot hold 6.5 quarts. The pot is a bit shallow which leads me to believe that a large chicken or pot roast might have trouble fitting. The pot is wide though (overall, the cooker is quite large and will take up a bit of real estate in your cabinet or counter). There are heating elements along the sides (for slow-cooking) of the pot as well as the bottom (for searing). I made chili and it was perfect (on the slow setting, it was ready within 4 hours). One point off for the absence of a timer and no auto shut-off. The instruction brochure that comes with it has good directions and advice. A few recipes (vegetable lasagna, lentil soup, etc.) are included.

Overall, this is an adequate biography of Stevie Nicks even though the author's sources all come from magazine articles, interviews, YouTube videos and other books. Still, the research level is impressive. The book does a good job of capturing her enigmatic persona, covering her turbulent on-again, off-again years with Fleetwood Mac, relationships with Lindsey, Joe Walsh, Rupert Hine (and others), and her songwriting process. Most interesting are insights into the inspiration behind some of her songs.The biggest complaint I have about the book is the author's writing style. Her parenthetical comments which attempt to bring the reader into her personal realm is annoying as is the bulleted lists at the beginning and ending of each chapter ("Things Stevie learns in this chapter", etc.). Die hard fans who have read everything on Nicks may not find anything new but for fans with average knowledge will finds lots of interesting tidbits here.

I do not doubt the fact that this drink is healthy. It is made of the juices from spinach, yellow carrots, pineapple and apple. 1 8 oz. serving is 60 calories. There is no sugar or artificial flavors added. That said, it tastes awful! I would much rather eat the vegetables themselves than drink this.

I loved Joan Rivers and I admire her daughter Melissa very much. This book though is brief and feels rushed with lots of filler (jokes, lists, letters, etc.). Melissa admits that she was approached by the editor after her mother's funeral (how tactless is that??) about getting a book out by Mother's Day. There are some interesting tidbits here for anyone curious about how the rich and famous live. The details of flying, living in hotels, room service and what Joan carried in her bag (as well as places she hid money!) were fascinating to me. I was also amused to know that she was a big fan of true-crime shows like "Forensic Files".  It is details like what she had on her DVR list at the time of her death that make the book a fun read. As juicy as these details are, there are also chapters are not really that interesting. It is obvious that Joan Rivers and her husband Edgar were great parents, with a great respect for education and good manners and instilling those values in their daughter.

Pros:Consistent heatPlenty of steamHeavyIrons wellCons:Hard to set temperatureDifficult to see water levelTemperature and steam amount have to be set separatelySteam button on wrong sideSteam amount the same no matter what settingClicking noise

The Belkin Air Sleeve offers good protection for your laptop computer. The stiff eggshell construction feels very sturdy. I am using it for my Asus 13" Zenbook (the sleeve is actually fitted for a 14" laptop). A few disadvantages - there is no storage area for a mouse or cords. The description states that it is easy to work with your computer right inside the case. There are a few problems with that however. While it is possible, since the laptop sits in a recessed area, if you have a flash drive inserted on the side of the computer, it will not rest in the case but stick out over the side (the same problem if you have cables attached). So, I think it is a good case for travel and protecting your laptop but not that great for working on your computer inside the case.

This is a very nice candle with a light, delicate scent. Upon opening it and smelling it, I was afraid that it was going to be overwhelming and sicky sweet. However, after burning it, it is quite mild, however a bit feminine. The jar is attractive with a nice botanical illustration of peonies. As the candle burns, the inside of the label becomes visible and is also illustrated. The candle has two wicks and is a light pink color. A bit pricey for a candle. It would make a wonderful gift.Specifics: Top Notes - Blackberry, raspberry, sweet orange. Middle Notes - peonies, iris, bay leaves. Base Notes: Cassis bud, rosewood, white patchouli. Essential Oils: Orange

These are pre-cut baking sheets that come folded. All you have to do is unfold and place them on your baking pan. I do a lot of baking and often use parchment paper that comes on the roll. The aggravating thing about the rolled paper is that it always wants to curl up. These sheets will lay flat. The only negative thing I can find about them is that they are a tad small for my large cookie sheets. I have to use several of them to cover the pan.

A Ruth Rendell Book Club group has been set up on Facebook and it is really interesting reading her books in chronological order. This is Rendell's third Inspector Wexford novel (following From Doon With Death and Sins of the Fathers). It is easy to see the evolution of her writing style and in this book, she really seems to be coming into her own and developing her signature style. The book is taut, vivid and full of surprises at the end. Rendell's attention to detail is very evident here - her descriptions of English streets, interiors, landscaping, etc. are top notch. She stills seems to favor Mike Burden - he does most of the work here - Inspector Wexford plays more of a secondary role, as he did in the previous books.

I would hesitate to call these "bolt" cutters as they are designed for small to medium jobs. I have used them to cut through thick wire and barbed wire. I like the size of them - they are easy to carry around in your pocket or toolbox. They have a nice grip and the plastic handles are comfortable to hold. A small plastic clasp locks the handles together - so far I have not had any problems with it. These cutters would also be nice to have for hobby work, sewing, picture hanging and other smaller jobs.

This body wash is designed for men (although women could use it too) and has a musky fragrance with hints of lavender. It is a dark purple color (a bit disconcerting at first) and is very refreshing. It can be used anytime you shower but is particularly good at night right before bed (lavender has soothing qualities that help you relax and get to sleep). The fragrance does not linger on my body.

When making pasta, the most time-consuming part is waiting for the water to boil. A large pot can take up to 10 minutes on our stove, then of course there is about 10 minutes more to cook the pasta. I was skeptical about this "no-boil" pasta but I confess it works and tastes the same. You make it in a skillet - just add 3 cups of water and cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally (we found that stirring more frequently towards the end gave better results).

I first heard about this book while watching a Dick Cavett interview with Bette Davis. He asked her which book she thought had the most accurate portrayal of Hollywood and she said it was this one. It is a portrayal of a narcissistic , ruthless heel named Sammy Glick, who rapidly rises from office boy to studio head, destroying careers, lives and backstabbing everyone he comes in contact with along the way. The story is told through the eyes of Manheim, a fellow co-worker, who witnesses Glick's callous determination as he goes up the ladder.The book was written in 1941 but holds up quite well and does not feel dated. (There are some derogatory terms used for gays, Jews and foreigners that you will have to overlook.) The writing is smart and witty and the novel moves along at a rapid pace. The narrator's snide thoughts and comments directed at Glick are, at times, quite humorous. It is an unforgettable portrait of the vicious nature of the Hollywood machine.

I really like the light illumination - it is perfect for reading. The magnifying glass is also excellent for detailed work or getting a splinter out of your finger. The quality, however, is questionable. I could not get the light head to stay up and ended up taking pliers to tighten the bolts that hold it in place. It is fine for now but I know that there are going to be problems in the future. If the light will not stay supported, then the lamp is practically unusable. The lamp can be used just sitting on a table or you can use the clamps to attach it to a board or other surface.

This set consists of 4 bags ("cubes") - the largest one measuring 17.5 x 12.75 x 3.25, a medium-sized case measuring 13.75 x 9.75 x 3 inches, a small one at 11 x 6.75 x 3 inches, and an oblong slim bag at 2.8 x 14 x 5 inches. They are very lightweight, made of mesh and nylon. The mesh panels on the front of the bags allow you to easily see what is inside. They are good for packing within larger suitcases. For short trips, I think these would be okay to use just by themselves. They are work fine as a bag to take to the gym, the pool or hiking. Although they are not that large, I have found that they will hold a lot of clothes, especially items such as socks, underwear, and shorts that can be rolled up. They seem to be durable and the zippers work nicely (there are 2 zippers on each bag and zip from the outside in).

I love these undershirts. They are soft, very comfortable and fit perfectly. I especially like the fact that they are not tight around the neck. The extra length at the bottom is an added bonus to help them stay tucked in your pants. The material (100% cotton) is thin and the shirts are not too hot. I have enjoyed wearing these both under my work shirts and as a comfortable shirt to wear just sitting around the house at night.

The latest novel by Elizabeth George is a dense doorstop of a book that follows Detective Inspector Thomas Lynley and his colleague Sergeant Barbara Havers as they investigate two separate but related murders. The case is essentially worked by Havers, who is trying to prove herself after being reprimanded because of events that happened in a previous novel. (Since I did not read that book, I wasnt sure what it involved but the issue isnt dwelled on that much.) Similarly, events regarding the death of Lynleys wife, is also alluded to from previous books.The case brings the participants into the orbit of a highly dysfunctional family with numerous skeletons in their closets.  Of course, each one could have a legitimate reason for committing the crimes and the end result is satisfying but somewhat anticlimactic.George is a good, and at times, compelling writer but she cant seem to focus on restraint. She is great at evoking the British atmosphere and for developing full-bodied characters. That said, at almost 600 pages, the novel is too long -  even with excellent character development, the book could have been a taut and pleasurable read at half this length.  About halfway through this, I was ready for it to end.

I am an avid gardener and unfortunately highly allergic to poison ivy. I have battled it all my life and have learned to identify it and try to stay away when I can. Ortho Max works to kill it as well as a number of nuisance vines and shrubs. Large and established plants sometimes need to be sprayed twice to make sure you have killed it entirely. This product should be used with care and caution because it is non-selective, meaning that it will kill anything else it comes in contact with. If you are spraying in a garden, try to spray on a windless day. If poison ivy is growing near desirable plants, I find it is best to not use the spray nozzle and just drip the solution over the plant to avoid having it come in contact with other plants. It usually takes a few days to kill the entire vine but you will immediately notice a wilting plant the following day. It is also important to apply this on a warm day (at least 60 degrees). I have used Ortho Max to kill poison ivy, Virginia creeper, briars and trumpet vine.

I always have difficulty getting to sleep at night and I have tried a variety of products. So far, the only thing that works 100% for me is prescription Ambien. I get to sleep within 30 minutes, do not wake up until 8 hours later and I don't have that groggy hung-over feeling all day. Melatonin, which this product contains, does help me sleep but I have the grogginess the next day which is not worth it.I had mixed results with this product. I have taken it for over a week and it has never helped me to go to sleep quickly. The first few nights, after I did manage to drift off to sleep, I woke back up several hours later. Finally, on the third night, I managed to sleep all night but felt bad the next day. Subsequent nights have been mixed, with some good nights of sleep and some mornings of no after-effects. It seems to be inconsistent for me.
Works fine, great value. I used this to connect my ASUS laptop to my Samsung TV. No problems at all.

So far, I really love the drill. It is much easier to use than my older B&D drill. I love the easy snap-in holder for the drill bit. The bit is easy to put in and out (just turn the dial), much faster and more efficient than the tool bit that has to be fitted in and turned. The power level is good with torque levels from 2 to 20. I used this for several hours placing hinges on four garage doors and have not had to recharge the battery yet.

I am pleased with this phone case. It is very attractive, looks to be high quality, and the coffee brown color is nice. It is slim and not bulky. There are 3 slots for card storage. So far, have not noticed any distractions to using the phone.

Update: After less than a year of use, the phone has an issue with rebooting (sometimes numerous times) and "optimizing apps" which takes a while. The phone will often go dead and the battery much be taken out and put back in to get power. At this point, it has become a daily issue. Very frustrating!  Also, the battery is exhausted much faster. I have found that disconnecting the data manager and wi-fi helps but for just texting and phone use, I would not pay this much.Original review:I have only been using this phone for a few weeks now (and for photos and Internet only, have not signed up for a phone plan yet) but so far, I really love it. It is comfortable to hold, quiet and light. The screen is bright and sharp. Battery power (3,000 mAh) lasts at least 3 days for me with light Internet use. It takes about 4 hours to totally recharge the battery. The battery is also removable. The phone feels pretty durable (the leather back is nice) but I did order a case for it as well as a screen protector.There are a few quirks that I haven't worked out yet but that is probably due to my lack of tehnical know-how. A few apps that I installed do not appear on any of the screens and the idle time-out feature is a bit annoying. The Instagram app does not work properly and freezes up (why I do not know). Aside from those few apps, all the others work fine.It has an impressive voice recognition feature. Composing e-mails or social media posts with the voice feature was surprisingly accurate and far better than my old phone.The thing I love the most is the camera which is the best I have seen on a smart phone. Resolution is impressive. Photos are vibrant, crisp and amazing in low light. I took a phote at night in my living room with only dim lamp light and the photo was outstanding. The rear camera, for regular picture-taking is 16MP while the front, for selfies, is 8MP. The Gallery features allow you to tweak your photos (similar to Instagram) and have a handy icon to share photos via various social media outlets.

Very tasty, very spicy ready-to-use plum sauce for either using in recipes or as a dipping sauce. It does have a strong Wasabi  and soy flavor. There is a handy brochure included which has a chart for making various sauces with adding just one ingredient (example - a cup of the sweet and spicy plum sauce + 3 TBS. ketchup). It also gives variations with using mayonnaise, mustard, BBQ sauce, sour cream, yogurt, peanut butter, etc.). This is a huge container!

These are unique cloths that work like a sponge. They are very thin and absorbent. They did an excellent job wiping down the sink after doing dishes. After using them, you can spread them out and they will dry out in a few hours. After many uses, they can be washed in a washing machine and allowed to air dry. They are much more efficient than paper towels.

Rendell's second novel (and her first non-Wexford) centers around the death (by wasp stings) of an unlikeable man in an upper-class English neighborhood. I had trouble keeping all the characters straight in this one and wish I had kept a score card. A lot of characters are introduced in the first chapters without much explanation as to who they are and what relationship they have with the others. Once over this hurdle, however, the book moves along at a brisk pace and is a quick, satisfying read.

I thoroughly enjoyed this biography of Rudolph Valentino. I have read hundreds of film-star biographies but I did not know much about Valentino. The author's research is quite detailed, with reference notes and a bibliography. The attention to detail is quite thorough, tracing Valentino's childhood, his early years in New York City working as a "taxi dancer", his short-lived first marriage and his second marriage to Natacha Rambova. His films, dealings with Famous-Players Lasky and the nation's reaction to him are well covered. The author's writing style is entertaining. The photos that are included (in 3 sections) are well-chosen and adequately represent the book's content (major people in his life can usually be found in a photo). I enjoyed every minute of it.

The was one of the last Valentino films and it is one of his best. The Amazon Streaming version is good in quality and I did not encounter any problems. The musical soundtrack features great music. However, there are a total of about 3 songs and they are played over and over again. Some of them do not quite match the mood of the scene. This became irritating about halfway through. Vilma Banky provides good chemistry and Louise Dresser is memorable as the Czarina.

I am currently reading a biography of Valentino and I am also watching his films for the first time. This was a pleasant surprise. For a very early silent film (1922), it is lengthy at 1:40 but it never drags and moves along at a brisk pace. Valentino is wonderful here (you will have to overlook the silly hairstyle). I actually thought his performance here was better than "The Sheik".) Nita Naldi is good as the man-killer Dona Sol, despite some hammy expressions in her first scene. A beautiful musical score enhances the film. Very good quality (not sure why it alternates between sepia and b&w), the image is sharp and well preserved.

So far we love this unit. Our kitchen gets very hot when we are cooking and instead of using a fan, we tried the portable air conditioner. First of all, there is not a window in our kitchen that can be raised so we had to position it in the adjacent dining room. It was be nice if the hose were longer but at about 5' in length, it reached to about one foot from the kitchen doorway. The setup was very easy - a panel fits inside the window ledge and a sliding portion of the panel has a hole where the hose is attached. The unit is heavy but rolls easily. It i did not take long before we could really tell a difference in the temperature in the kitchen. In fact, we had to turn it off when it got too cold. The unit seems to be powerful and it really puts out the cold air.

This cleaner is advertised for wood, concrete, and siding. I tried it on a variety of surfaces - a flagstone floored covered porch, brick steps and a set of concrete steps and aluminum siding. For the stone surfaces, it seemed to work best on the flagstone porch. This gets very dusty and the dust grime has reappeared rather quickly when using other products. The porch looked good after using this product. The concrete and brick steps were less impressive. They both had areas of algae growing on them and the cleaner did not remove it. The steps looked a bit better after cleaning but the concrete did not whiten up like the photo in the ad illustrates. I used the cleaner as the instructions stated - I allowed the solution to sit for 10 minutes and then scrubbed the surface with an old broom before rinsing it off. The aluminum siding cleaning was good although an entire bottle of this is not enough to clean a two-story house (500 square foot is the area it covers and that is not a lot).

A very impressive tool! These bolt cutters are powerful and comfortable to use. I tried these on some heavy duty welded wire mesh panels and they cut through them with ease. I then tried them on a 1/2 inch thick chain link and cut it with ease. Both handles can be folded back so that you can store them easier in a tool box, bag or wherever. I did not have problems with the latch that holds the handles in place as other reviewers did. I also love the bright yellow color as I am prone to loose tools. These are easy to spot.

The product does give a temporary tightening effect under the eyes. However, it also leaves a noticeable residue that cannot be covered up by concealer or make-up. It is very shiny so you can't just put it on and go out. And if you do try and cover it, the benefits are gone. It does have a very nice fragrance.

Overall, I was disappointed with this toothpaste. It is an opaque gel that is tasteless and does not foam in your mouth. It does not leave a fresh feeling in your mouth. In fact, after brushing, I could not tell that my teeth had been cleaned. There is no taste or after-effect, it is like brushing your teeth with water. I would suspect that the no-taste feeling remedies bad breath but it would be nice if the manufacturers included a foaming ingredient and flavor.

I have been putting a tablespoon of this in either tea or coffee (I do not care for the "oil slick" affect in coffee though). It is totally tasteless but I have found that too much (in my case, more than 1 tablespoon) upsets my stomach. I did not expect this to help me loose weight but I did loose a few pounds during the first two weeks of use. I am still accessing the product but so far, I think it is good. The cap on the bottle is terrible, however, it always drips no matter how careful I try to be.

This is a gorgeous book featuring 25 private estate gardens in England. The book begins with two famous ones, Hidcote and Sissinghurst, but the remainder were unfamiliar to me. Expansive lawns, walled gardens, stone archways, lush perennial and rose borders, they are all here, displayed in exquisite photographs. Truly a book to loose yourself in.

I have had success with Ortho gardening products in the past and this one is probably no exception. However, it does contain 2% Dinotefuran which is known to affect bee colonies. For that reason alone, I have decided not to use it. Dinotefuran has been banned in Oregon and New York (that should tell us something!)

This laptop is super thin and very light. It is also very, very quiet. It boots up within seconds and seems to very fast when surfing the Internet and watching video clips. The On/Off switch is located at the top right row on the keyboard, a bit odd at first, but I really like it. Battery life is very good. It takes about 3 hours to fully charge it and then it lasts for 8-9 hours. Wi-fi setup was very easy! In fact, the entire set-up was completed in less than 5 minutes with no headaches. The screen is very bright and vibrant right out of the box - I had to tweak the settings a bit to tone down the brightness.Just a few negative aspects - the touch pad is annoying, very sensitive and difficult to perform a right-click. I could not see a difference in using the left or right side and got so annoyed with it that I am using a mouse. The keyboard does NOT have a backlight. The case is attractive but easily shows fingerprints. Windows 8.1 is also a pain and takes some getting used to. Aside from that, this is a great laptop.

Rendell's second Wexford novel may appear a bit dated but it is easy to see the great writer that she was becoming. This book (released as "A New Lease of Death" in the U.S.) is taut, excellently plotted, fully characterized and full of descriptive settings. Wexford lovers may be surprised to find that he really plays a minor part in this book. A pastor by the name of Henry Archery wants to clear the name of the guilty party in Wexford's first case. Archery's daughter is engaged to his son and heaven forbid, there can't be any bad blood being introduced into the family. Archery second-guesses Wexford's work on the case and attempts to find out what really happened. Thus the bulk of the book follows the arrogant Archery and his equally smarmy son as they attempt to clear the name of the fiance. Inspector Burden also plays a significant part here, even more so than Wexford. Wexford is described as a bit gruff and uncouth in this novel, a few characterizations she toned down for him in subsequent books.

Art curator Justin Paton is the host of this 12-episode New Zealand based series that takes viewers to museums and artists studios to provide a fresh perspective on understanding art. Each episode explores a specific theme (landscapes, faces, etc.). A brief overview and history of the subject is discussed and then artists are profiled and interviewed about their motivations and how they get their artworks accomplished. A 60-minute documentary titled What is Beauty? discusses ten factors that make a work of art beautiful.The series is infused with techno-beat music and frenetic editing, probably an effort to appeal to younger students. This aspect isn't as annoying as the constant shots of the host walking around. It seems like 90% of the show has Paton walking down a street, walking into a museum, walking across a field, etc. etc. It became so amusing that every time a scene was finished, I would be thinking "Cue to host walking". With all the minutes devoted to footage of Paton walking about, a lot of art work could have been shown instead.

I have been using this on my iPad Air to navigate links (I have not used it for drawing) and it works fine. At first, it took me a while to get used it because it is so different from the larger, soft-tip stylus I have been using. This is much smaller, just slightly thicker than an average pencil, with a pin-point tip with a clear plastic disc attached to the tip. If you are used to the soft-tip, you will think this one is scratching or damaging your screen. That is not the case and I have found that it actually works better, especially for accessing small text and multiple links that are spaced close together.

An excellent documentary about historian and activist Vito Russo. Russo, who wrote the groundbreaking study of gays in cinema "The Celluloid Closet," also did tremendous work as a gay rights activist and AIDS activist. Colleagues, friends and family are interviewed about his life and career. Russo is also seen in interviews and television appearances. His childhood and experiences are discussed as well as his love of film and the long-range and exhausting research he did for "Celluloid Closet". The latter part of the film deals with the anguish and devastation of fighting for government assistance during the AIDS crisis and his untimely death from the disease in 1990.
The sheets are very soft and comfortable. The color is attractive (deep slate grey) and has an embroidery embellishment along the hems of the pillowcase. Very nice!

I am relieved that I received this as a product to review because I would have been very upset had I paid $190 for it.CONS:Assembly - Unless you are detail oriented and good at putting things together, I highly advise finding someone who is (you will need extra help anyway in order to hold together some of the pieces while the other attaches them). There are various screws, nails, etc., some of which are not easily identifiable when compared to the instructions. The instructions provide illustrations only. A friend who is better at this kind of thing than I am helped. It took us 3 hours total with several mishaps along the way. The bottom front panel is especially tricky. It took us 3 times to get it on correctly. You will need a hammer, Phillips-head screwdriver and flat-heat screwdriver. A tape measure is also recommended to check to make sure it is squared before the last step.Quality - not good. This is basically soft presswood that needs to be handled with extreme care to avoid damage. The "headless" screws that are to be hammered in are very soft. We broke two of them off by just lightly tapping with the hammer.Alignment of drawers - spotty. Despite being careful (and aside from the screaming and cursing), we followed the directions exactly and corrected errors along the way. Despite this, the drawers do not fit well. The ones in the middle must be slightly lifted to fit in properly (without hitting the drawer underneath it). (They do, however, move in and out rather smoothly).Strength is questionable. The instructions tell you to anchor the back of the dresser to the wall and even show you how to do it. This is the only step we skipped because we are only using it to hold light fabrics. (Anyway, having to put a bolt into your wall sounds extreme).PROS:Packaging was good - the pieces arrived in great condition with adequate protection.In looks, this dresser is pretty attractive. The sides and top are a dove gray and the drawers are white. We are using this in a sewing room to hold fabrics and materials.

Set during mid-late 1500s France during the violent Wars of Religion between the Catholics and Protestants, this biography details the volatile lives of Catherine de Medici and her daughter Maguerite de Valois. Elements of intrigue, sibling rivalries, backstabbing, infidelities, assassinations, religious fanaticism and more are all here in a readable and engrossing narrative.Catherine de Medici was a fascinating woman with motivations that are somewhat difficult to pinpoint. As the wife of King Henry II, she was pretty much cast aside by him and merely used as an heir producer (she bore him ten children). Henrys affections were directed toward his mistress, an older woman named Diane de Poitiers, another character that plays prominently in the book. Upon Henrys death however, Catherine changes from a sympathetic character to a more ruthless one, as she pursues an agenda to see all of her sons attain the throne.Catherines youngest daughter, Maurgerite, is thrust into a loveless marriage by her mother in a ploy to settle religious hostilities. The plan backfires, however, and days following the wedding, the bloody St. Bartholomews Day Massacre (more than likely instigated by Catherine) kills thousands.The author manages to detail the non-stop and confusing political machinations with ease (not an easy task when most of the men in the book are named Henry!). She takes care to explain her reasoning behind events that are not fully documented and compares her notes with other scholars on particular points. She does not practice the annoying habit of creating imaginary dialog between her subjects. The book has an extensive bibliography (for the most part, Marguerites story derives from her own memoirs).I must confess that I have not read many historical biographies but this one greatly peaked my interest and will motivate me to read more. Highly recommended!

I have only myself to blame. I am a huge fan of DotD. It is the movie that put me on the path to the career I am on currently (zombie author). It is easy to see the movie as you read or listen to the audio version of this adaptation. There are a couple of instances where a sliver of something is added to give you perhaps a new insight, but for the most part, this is the movie redone.Just about anybody could have sat in front of their DVD player and written this scene-for-scene adaptation and then threw in the possible thoughts of Steve, Roger, Fran and Peter. This did make Peter seem less likable than in the movie. Also, Steve comes across as a bit of a wimp and Fran sort of toughens up and adopts a hard shell. Not sure if I agree with those choices in the narrative. Anyway, if you are a mega-fan, you will probably add this just to have it, but don't expect much that you don;t already know from watching the movie all those times.It was still a nice gift from somebody who knew I love zombies, and this movie in particular.

I suggest a cup of your favorite warm beverage and a couch. If it is raining outside, so much the better. This book was given to me as a gift and it made for an excellent birthday present.

Doesn't work at all. Audio comes through but no video. I should've listened to the reviews. Tried this with a 5th gen video iPod and an iPad 2. Tried to connect this to a TV and our car. I purchased this item for an upcoming trip to NY. I have two kids, a 3 yr old, and one that will be 11 months when we will be in NYC. We didn't want to have strollers because it can be a headache navigating through the subway, stairs and just going through the city. The maximum weight is perfect for my 3 yr old because she's under 36 lbs. It's a lot higher than the Baby Bjorn and way more comfortable! With the Baby Bjorn I definitely feel the weight on my shoulders. It's not a big deal for me since I'm bigger and work out, but my wife is 5'2 and weighs 100 lbs. When she has/had our little ones in the carrier, it gave her back pains and forced me to give her back and shoulder rubs. But with the Mo+m, all the weight is distributed and nothing on the shoulders. Even with my 3 yr old on my back, I didn't feel anything. I was able to put my 3 yr old in the back and use my Baby Bjorn for forward facing. It can truly say that it's a much better feeling than the Baby Bjorn. I would definitely recommend this for any parent and suggest this over any other carrier. It is also much more affordable. Plus if you're like me, I love having the functionality of having pockets. You can throw some wipes and a couple of diapers in the front pocket for emergency purposes!

I've been using the Amazon Echo for a month now and I think it's a great product to have in the house. It has a certain wow factor when you are entertaining guests. Though it lacks in certain areas, there is such a huge room for improvement! I mean that in a good way. There are so many possibilities with the Echo. With the recent flooding in Texas, it was great to be able to get weather and traffic updates right before I leave to work. Checking the score on the Warriors vs Cavs game was handy. Sometimes I don't want to have to pull out my phone or iPad just to get information. This is what the future looks like. Being able to just use your voice to get information. Now I do wonder on how much the Echo listens in on.Even my kids enjoy the Echo. My 3 year old thinks she is my friend and she has a wealth of information. I love the playlist and song search feature. If entertaining guests, you no longer have to have the radio on or have the TV on to stream music. It was annoying to have your phone stream your music to a bluetooth speaker. The speaker on the Echo is amazing and clear. The sound quality is almost perfect.Setup was a breeze. Everything paired quickly and I had 0 wifi connectivity issues.Areas for improvement:I would like to be able to add additional locations for traffic information. Currently you are only able to have one location.A long shot but integration with Nest or Dropcam and MyQ garage door openers. Though they are owned by different companies, it would be nice to have the Echo control the Nest or Dropcam and MyQ. Actually anything that is automated and controlled by a smartphone or tablet you should be able to integrate.These are the few things I would like to see in the next update. At least the first one.

I've had plenty of projectors before but this by far is one of the most impressive. I've never heard of BenQ but after reading all the positive reviews I had to check it out. For less than $1000 you get an amazing 3D projector that can be installed pretty much anywhere. I put this in my media room projecting onto a 120" screen. It is approximately 7ft away from the screen and the picture quality is amazing! Extremely easy to setup and the eco functions are pretty good. I did not see any light or hear any loud noises. It's a definite must have if you want a quality projector at an amazing price. I do wish that this projector was more common so I can use a universal remote with it. But I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants an affordable setup. Message me if you have questions.

I first received this item last year before Xmas and I enjoyed it very much. During the time I've used it, I felt that it was giving me everything my dentist wanted. I like the UV Sanitizer and this is great for travel. The down fall of this product is really up in the air. Before I had this item for a year, it broke. I do a lot of traveling, and the item being damaged could be blamed on the careless acts of the TSA. Who knows, but when I arrived home that night I went to brush my teeth and noticed that the power on the toothbrush was very low. Being tired and not thinking, I figured that it was maybe because the battery was not charged. The next morning I still noticed that it was very weak. I let it charge again and that night I saw that it was fully charged. I ended up taking the toothbrush apart and noticed that the motor had been damaged. This could be just a flaw in this particular toothbrush, or it could be the TSA for smashing my bag and damaging the motor. Who knows at this point. I have a new toothbrush, same model, and I still love it. Give me that clean mouth feeling. I would recommend this item to anyone!

These have been a lifesaver for my daughter and me. I now am at the point where I put a few drops in every bottle. Here's how this works:Active Ingredient:- Simethicone is an anti-foaming agent. It prevents lots of little bubbles (foam) and instead causes the bubbles to join together in a larger bubble. Large bubbles are easier to burp out or pass- Simethicone acts in the stomach directly - it doesn't work by way of the bloodstream, making it much safer with respect to side effects, overdose, etcHow to Use- Feed the dose directly into baby's mouth after eating, or add a few drops to a bottle itself- IMORTANT: After administering, safely BOUNCE the baby to help the little air bubbles join together and rise to the top. I find this works MUCH BETTER than patting the back. After I administer these drops, a few good bounces gets the burp out without fail, and my daughter all in smiles. Get bounced not only works better, it's more enjoyable than getting pat on the back.Anyway - that's my advice. Offer liberally and then BOUNCE the baby. They really, really work.Taste wise, these are ok. Sweet. My daughter will take them contentedly.

I used mine for the first time tonight, and love it. I can't wait to use it all the time for cooking - and we cook a LOT. Slice the onion in half, lay the flat side down on the board, and insert the prongs into the onion, ideally right in the middle - slice either parallel or into the prongs for thin slices. It's especially handy for that last inch or so and you want your whole onion thinly sliced! If you insert the prongs into the middle, you can slice (parallel) first on one side then on the other, and you can have the slices paper-thin. If you want diced onions, this gadget is a huge help too. Again, cut in half, lay the onion flat side down, slice using the prongs as guides, keep the holder in place, then slice parallel to the prongs for thin diced onions. Simple. I received this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. All opinions expressed are my own

1. This product is NOT water-PROOF, nor does it ever claim to be. It is water RESISTANT. This means that if water gets into the tiny speaker holes on the back, into the tiny microphone hole on the front, or (God forbid) into the power port on the bottom, it will likely damage the electronics inside.Nearly all of the negative reviews of this product state that after one or two uses, they heard a loud screeching sound until the battery died and then they could never use it again. This is a direct result of their misuse of the product by either submersing the product in water or by allowing lots of water to flow over it. They are causing water to enter the holes in the product and thereby damaging the electronics inside.How do we avoid this? Place the speaker in a location where it is unlikely to have ANY water touch it. In the case of a shower, this will be under the shower head but on the same wall as the shower head. In a bath, it can be pretty much anywhere on the wall (not in the tub). Water should touch the speaker as infrequently as possible. In addition, run the fan or leave the door open to avoid large amounts of steam from collecting. Otherwise, condensation may form inside the speaker which would then collect into drops and damage the electronics. When touching the buttons on the speaker with wet hands, do NOT touch the microphone hole or any area directly above the hole, since water could collect on the speaker and then dribble into the hole. If you follow these simple, basic, seemingly obvious instructions, your speaker will not have this problem.2. The speaker has its own volume control, independent from the volume of the source. For example, if you are using a cell phone and your phone's media volume is set to 10%, the speaker will not get very loud even if you hold the >> button down and turn the speaker's volume up all the way. You need to set your phone's volume (or whatever your source is) to 100%, then use the volume controls on the speaker to adjust its volume.I received this item in exchange for a review.Overall, I really like the speaker. It has a great design, stays put in the shower, and is nice and loud while still being decent quality. Both my girlfriend (who I bought it for) and I really like it. I'm sure you will like it too as long as you avoid the pitfalls stated above.

This is the best LSAT book on the market. Period. I've never reviewed a book on Amazon before, but I felt strongly enough about this book, and the LSAT, to write a review here.Let me say a bit by way of background: I took the LSAT for the 2012/2013 application cycle. Like most people, I took a full-length practice LSAT, without any preparation, a few months before the scheduled exam to see how much studying I had to do to get into the 170+ range. My initial score was, to put it mildly, a disappointment.After coming to terms with the fact that I was going to have to really prepare for the exam, I evaluated my options. I didn't want to take an LSAT class. They're expensive, inconveniently located, and generally just regurgitate what's in the practice book they use. Still, since the LSAT is such an important factor in law school admissions, it seemed like skipping the class and studying on my own was too big of a risk, whatever the price. I ended up going with Manhattan LSAT, which had better reviews than Kaplan, Blueprint, and Testmasters (the other companies with courses in my area). By sheer luck, Mike Kim (the author of The LSAT Trainer) happened to be teaching my class.While ultimately I was right about the class--it was pricy, across town, and more or less a review of the material in the Manhattan LSAT books--Mike himself was phenomenal. I began going to class early and staying late so that I could pick his brain about the exam. While I was satisfied with the Manhattan materials (of which Mike was one of the main authors, I later learned), the most useful bits of information I collected came from Mike's uncanny understanding of the LSAT's structural aims. All of that information (and way more) is now beautifully organized in this book.As you'll see when you look at the Trainer, Mike understands the LSAT like a mechanic understands an engine. He has truly mastered it; and he has used that mastery to dissect the exam into its most fundamental parts. That's what this book is. It's an anatomy of the LSAT--a step-by-step tutorial that helps you see the LSAT in the way 170+ scorers do.There are a lot of LSAT materials out there. I've looked at many of them. Some are pretty good. Most are mediocre. A few are awful, and could cause you to develop habits that actually lower your LSAT score.Mike's approach in the Trainer is in a different league altogether. Here are just a few of the reasons why I say that:1. Simplicity. The Trainer simplifies the LSAT in a way that no other book I've seen does. For instance, one of the biggest problems I had when I was taking practice tests was deciding in the heat of the moment how to categorize the logic game I was facing. This is because I had learned to strictly categorize game types, as essentially all test-prep companies teach you to do. But, as the Trainer explains, this is the wrong way to look at the games section. All logic games are really just variations on a few basic conceptual ingredients. Once you identify those ingredients, and see how they interact with each other, you can go into just about any game feeling like you know how to handle it--because you do. Having this level of comfort and confidence on test day is priceless. And the point extends beyond logic games. The Trainer is consistently concerned with simplifying the exam. This is apparent, for instance, in the reading comp section, which teaches you to read for structure. I totally agree with this approach, and think that it's another nice illustration of the book's general theme, which is that you need to have a deep understanding of what LSAC is trying to test in each section if you want to consistently get high scores. (For you newbies out there, LSAC is the organization that writes the LSAT. You'll know them intimately soon.)2. Clarity. I have a few friends who are amazing test takers. (One of them got a 175 the first time he took the LSAT, after studying for only a couple of days. Naturally, I hate him.) However, it didn't really help me to talk to them about their approaches, because the ability to get a great score doesn't entail that you can explain (or even understand) how you're doing it. Mike can do both. Question types and conceptual approaches to them are explained in detail at the outset of the early chapters, and the writing that develops those ideas in later chapters is consistently clear and concise. Reading the Trainer is like being tutored privately by a top scorer who at the same time understands what it feels like to struggle with the exam. It predicts your questions and concerns, and addresses them in plain language as they arise.3. Comprehensiveness. Perhaps one of the best things about this book is that there's nothing that you need to know about the LSAT that's not in it. (But note: you DO have to purchase LSATs that aren't in it. However, this is a matter of practice, not strategy. And it's exactly what you ought to be doing anyway, as I explain in point 6, below.) From the most basic facts about the number of sections on the actual LSAT, to statistical information about how often each question type has appeared on past exams, to specific (but important) information about how you should time your sections--it's all there. I can't exaggerate how important it is to me not to worry that I'm missing something because my materials don't cover it. I want to buy one book and then turn all of my attention studying, without any nagging questions about what I'm not being told. That you can do that with the Trainer is unique and refreshing.4. Formatting/Length. This probably seems like a funny thing to list, but I think you'll see what I'm talking about when you see the book. The layout is exceptional. First, there is a TON of information on every page. This book does in 600 pages what other company's materials do in about 1200 pages, split across three (or more!) books (with a felonious price tag for each one). Second, despite the massive volume of information, the pages aren't cluttered. For anyone who's ever tried to typeset anything, you'll appreciate what a difficult task this is. This book was obviously designed with painstaking care. Third, the organization of the information is purposeful and effective. It has numerous charts and tables that help you catalog the information in your mind. (See, e.g., the table of common notations on p.206, and the constellation of questions on p.220.) Finally, just about every page is arranged differently, and the book and its contents are attractive. This might sound silly, but for me it's super important. If you use the book properly (as you should), then you'll be spending a lot of time with it. If the book isn't pleasant to look at, then it's going to take extra motivation to look at it after a long day of school or work. You don't want that.5. Intended Audience. One problem I had with many of the LSAT materials I looked at was that they seemed to target people looking to land in the 155 - 165 range. (Some companies, for instance, instruct test takers to try to complete only 3 of the 4 logic games.) For people who are aiming for a mid-160 score, maybe that's fine. But a sub-170 wasn't going to get me into the schools I was aiming for. Honestly, I don't know why these companies do this. Presumably they think that a large portion of the LSAT consumer market simply can't achieve a 170+, and believe that the methods 170+ test takers use aren't compatible with the optimal strategies for a mid-160 score. But this is wrong. As I think the Trainer brings out nicely, the way to master the LSAT is to come to see what the exam writers are really trying to test with each question--to deconstruct the LSAT into its most fundamental parts--and then to develop the skills necessary to meet the challenges each question poses. This book shows you how to do that, whatever your starting point. Will everyone be able to achieve a 170+? No. If they could, then LSAC wouldn't be doing a very good job of separating people out by their analytical abilities. But that doesn't mean that you should perform sub-optimally, given your abilities and work ethic, simply because your test prep materials think that you can't handle the real juice. You should try to get the very highest score you can. The tools that are best for 170+ scorers are also best for 160+ scorers. If you spend the time and do the work, you can meet your goals. This book agrees.6. Real LSATs. The Trainer is built around real LSATs. Whatever materials you end up using, DO NOT use materials that use fake LSAT questions. The Trainer explains why, and I totally agree. It's fine if a company illustrates a point with a non-LSAT question, but when you're practicing, you should always use real questions from old LSAT exams. To get a high score, you have to understand the subtleties of LSAC's questions. There's a common thread that runs between them, and seeing the thread is the key to success. Practicing with made-up LSAT questions is like learning to play basketball with a ball that's not quite the right size, or taking Spanish lessons from someone who speaks a slightly different dialect. It's a recipe for disaster. You shouldn't do it, and the Trainer gets that.7. Price. I regretted paying almost $1000 to take my LSAT course. (I also felt a little slimy about the fact that I was taking advantage of a resource that many people that I was competing against couldn't afford.) It all worked out in the end, but LSAT classes, at least from my experience, exist more to reassure students that they're not missing something than to provide useful information that's not in the study materials. I would have been better off skipping class and spending more time studying on my own. That said, there are likely some people who get a lot out of classes. But I think that this is probably limited to people who lack the time or discipline to study on their own. The Trainer's study schedules are smart and realistic. If you can stick to them, and you don't cut corners, then you'll be an LSAT machine by the time you finish this book. There is simply no reason to shell out for a class when you can pay $50 for this book, which is better than any of the other materials out there anyway--again, so long as you can stick to the regime on your own, and don't need someone to answer to.8. Inspiration. Maybe this sounds strange, but I was surprised by how impressed I became with the LSAT as I studied for it. I always hated standardized tests--I thought that they were all just collections of questions that were, at best, loosely related to certain analytical skills we all have. The Trainer changed my mind about that, at least for the LSAT. In the same way that a class on engineering will cause you to stare at the Golden Gate Bridge, in awe that a group of people actually built it, the Trainer highlights the LSAT's simple elegance. It really does test the skills you will use in law school, and it does that exceptionally well. The Trainer is always deeply respectful of the LSAT--of how hard it is and what it takes to meet its challenges. I admire that.If this review sounds like a total rave, that's because it is. I think that the Trainer is to LSAT prep what the Macbook Pro is to laptops. It's the best there is.

The cover of this book makes a bold promise: "Lose up to 20 pounds in 28 days - Eat More Food & Lose More Weight". This idea combined with the suggestion of a faster metabolism sounds like a dream come true.So, who is Haylie Pomroy and why should we listen to her?
