But I couldn't even tell if the heat was on, and seemed to be warm from the friction of the moving rollers alone.  I do like the rolling action much better on this Sharper Image than the other full-back massage cushions, especially compared to HoMedics.  And I rather liked the squeezing action of the air bags.  It was really nice that it would do the moving up and down for you instead of you moving the cushion anytime you want a change.  It also helps it roll past tender spots so if it does hurt, it hurts only for a second and moves on.  It isn't very tall, so it is unlikely to reach your shoulders unless you are 5'5" or less.  I am 5'10" and it didn't get quite high enough.  But it does get lower quite well, better than my fixed-location massage cushion for sure.The out of the box experience was very disappointing.  It had poor packaging internally and came with the bottom cushion carelessly mashed into the air bags when folded up and inserted into the box.  This left two defects, but weren't deal breakers.  It caused folds in the side air bags, which left the right one's inner bag creased and would not naturally stay to the side, so you have to hold it to the side as you sit.  And because the seat cushion was mashed against a harder structure, the foam was compressed and did not fully bounce back.  At first it was paper thin where it was in contact and only feels more normal after 2 weeks, but still hasn't fully bounced back so it is less even.  It was disappointing to find that they crammed it in and in such a way that it made it less nice.  It did not make a real functional difference.  But the first impression was lost.

9:16 MinsThese are great for cable management, such as around your computer or entertainment center.  They are much better than the alternatives, mainly twist ties and cable zip ties.  Twist ties are small, break after reusing a few times, and can pinch into your cable shielding if you crank them down.  Cable ties are nice and easy to zip on, but have to be cut off, and sometimes can be risky to use cutters so close to your wires.  These are much more flexible.  You can always open them and add another wire and are plenty long.  I was surprised that the entire length was Velcro, not just the ends, so it easily grips.  But it is not your usual Velcro (not like on shoes or bags), it thinner and a felt-like bottom side.  But it doesn't seem cheap or too flimsy.  They seem very appropriate for cable management.  They are plenty reusable, but are meant for occasional re-opening, not something you do daily.  It has a eye to slip a smaller end through, but it is entirely optional to use, as the Velcro alone holds well.  You can even cut them to any length if you prefer.There are 3 drawbacks. (1) If you have a pile of them, they stick together, unlike twist ties and cable ties.  So you have to prepare to use them by setting out some separately.  They also stick to themselves.  So if you are trying to use them one handed while handing onto wires with the other, it can be more difficult if they start to stick together or to themselves.  This will be noticeable, but I think acceptable.  (2) It takes sightly more work to remove them from the roll than peeling the next twist tie, but really isn't a problem.  (3) If you are using the optional eye hole, upon reuse the narrow strips around the eye hole are a weak point that will wear down faster, but you don't even have to use it and can cut it off.  Also it is Velcro around the eye hole so it sticks around the hole too so it doesn't easily slide if it catches.  You can't just pull to or loosen.Just picture thin felt-backed Velcro strips.  It is hard to expect any more from them if you understand they are just entire strips of a fine Velcro.  I like them, but they are not revolutionary.  When any cable management solution has some pros and cons, I think these do a great job.  The only thing that bothers me at all is that they stick together, but removing that would cause other drawbacks, which I believe is better as it is.

7:06 MinsThis is a perfect 270 degree right angle connector cable.  Unlike some other cables, and many angle adapters, this doesn't stick out too far in either direction, not too far past the head and not too tall.  This is critical because if it stands too tall, like some others that stick out an inch or more, then it still sticks out the side and is noticeable or speakers still cannot sit flush against the TV edge.  Also some TV ports don't have a lot of room beyond the port, and if the head of the cable sticks too far past the port, it doesn't fit, but this one fits well.  As shown in the video, this fits with room to spare.  If your TV is wall mounted, you will still have to pend the cable that sticks straight back and the amount of room might be tight depending on your TV.IMPORTANT: Pay close attention to which direction your port is facing, which will tell you which kind of right angle you need, 90 degree or 270 degree.  An HDMI port looks like a letter "D", and note which direction the rounded side of the "D" faces.  This cable works for ports where the rounded side faces forward where the cable runs in the opposite direction.  Some call this cable 270 degree.  There seem to be a lot more 90 degree cables out there where the rounded side is in the direction that the cable runs.  I needed one where the rounded side faced forward, and after searching I landed on this cable.  There are flexible adapters that can bend either way, but they usually stick out farther and tend to have poor reviews that report failure.  I really needed this direction that this cable supports, and am very happy that it solves my need.This is a standard Video+Audio v1.3 HDMI cable.  It only supports video+audio, which is standard for most people with cable boxes, DVRs, DVD or Blu-ray players, etc.  But if you need this cable to carry a wired internet signal to your TV passing it through from some other device, then you should look for a v1.4 cable or a v1.3 that says "with Ethernet".  This, being v1.3, also doesn't have what v1.4 adds -- 3D and audio-return.  If you don't need the TV to send audio back to something like a receiver through this same cable, and if you don't have 3D, then you should be vine with normal HD video & audio.  You can find more about HDMI specs on Wikipedia if you are unsure about differences.

9:51 MinsThis small flashlight is incredibly powerful for such a small size.  It is comfortable in your hand, well constructed, and easier than many to carry with you.  But it is not quite pocket size, so you can easily stick the nicely narrow shaft into your back pocket with the head sticking out.  It blows away any older incandescent light, and many other cheaper LED flashlights I have.  It beats out my other multi-LED flashlight in light quality, evenness, and convenience.  Compared to any flight light I've had in the past, any of the Coast lights offer such a great, bright, and even flood light that is so much nicer for lighting a general small area than those only with a focused beam.  I find it easier to work with.  The construction quality seems top notch.  The low beam mode seems pointless, which seems about 10-20% of normal brightness, and not very useful to me.  Just use the high light and carry some extra rechargeable batteries instead of trying to conserve.Coast has other smaller flashlights if an easier fit in your pocket is more important, such as the HP5 that is the exact same light but only one AA instead of the two AA that this takes.  This one is longer only by the length of the second AA, and the light is noticeably brighter for it.  Or one that is even easier to carry is the tiny HP2 that is my favorite, takes one AAA, and is amazingly powerful for the tiny size.  The HP6 is noticeably brighter than the HP5 (as shown in the video).In my house, I love this flashlight for its brightness & small size, but it is still my third choice, but only to the other two smaller Coast flashlights for pocket size convenience.  I still tend to grab the HP2 first because it is so tiny, then the HP5 when I feel I might need to focus the light, and then the HP6 when I think I might need even more light.  When needed, I just tote it around sticking up out of my pocket like a tool belt.  But when the power went out yesterday night, this was the best.  Coast make a large range of flashlights.  You need to pick the most ideal combination for you.  If I could have only two, I'd get the HP2 & HP6.

3:56 MinsThe best thing about this is it looks so much better than foam can coolers.  It is at least as good as the foam coolers.  Better yet it does seem to keep cans slightly cooler than in foam.  The foam can coolers (cozies) work fine, as I used one for years.  But foam can coolers are often quite ugly, display an advertisement, and often the advertised company doesn't even exist anymore.  This looks so much nicer.  It claims to keep cans cold for up to 3 hours.  I've never taken that long to drink a can, so I cannot say if it really holds for 3 hours.  But in normal drinking, I can see it seems as though it is slightly better, but not dramatically so.  It is at least as good, and maybe slightly better, but it was not a stunning difference.  Buy it for looks and at least as good performance, but probably better.The thermal-dynamics speak for themselves.  It should be the best possible solution for keeping a can cool without ice or refrigeration.  It is a genuine thermos, using a vacuum.  It simply has two walls separated by a vacuum that has no air to transmit heat.  It completely knocks out one kind of heat transfer.  The only place it should touch is at the very top where the metal comes together.  Without any molecules in-between, it cannot transfer heat.  There are still other ways heat transfers, but that is a major one.  A foam insulator instead works like insulation in your attic, with many tiny air spaces.  It slows the progress of heat transfer between air pockets by having many of them.  Heat will slowly work its way heating the air bubble by bubble in foam.  The effectiveness on slowing heat transfer is the R rating.  But this Thermos is a vacuum.  It should be superior.

9:27 MinsThis is an easy top choice for a very powerful small & convenient flashlight.  It easily fits in your pocket, takes only one AA battery and is sized only as wide along the shaft.  It blows away any older incandescent light, and many other cheaper LED flashlights I have.  It beats out my other multi-LED flashlight in light quality, evenness, and convenience.  It is very ideally shaped to throw in your pocket while working on odd jobs around the house that need more light.  Compared to any flight light I've had in the past, any of the Coast lights offer such a great, bright, and even flood light that is so much nicer for lighting a general small area than those only with a focused beam.  I find it easier to work with.  The construction quality seems top notch.  The low beam mode seems pointless, which seems about 10-20% of normal brightness, and not very useful to me.  Just use the high light and carry some extra rechargeable batteries instead of trying to conserve.In my house, it is second only to the even smaller and practically equally powerful Coast HP2.  This HP5 actually isn't noticeably brighter than the HP2, and has a wider head that is takes more room in your pocket than the HP2, which takes 1 AAA and the entire body is only as wide.  This HP5 has a focus-able head that can switch from an even flood to a focus light (or anywhere in-between), which can be useful.  Compared to the HP6, this HP5 is more ideally sized for just throwing in your pocket.  The HP6 is noticeably brighter than the HP5 (as shown in the video), but as it takes two AA batteries and is longer by one AA length.  But for the HP6 length alone, it doesn't fit in my pocket unless I just tote it around sticking up like a tool belt, which is only when I am focused on running around using it.  I still tend to grab the HP2 first because it is so tiny, then the HP5 when I feel I might need to focus the light, and then the HP6 when I think I might need even more light.The only negative is that with my HP5 unit, the head doesn't as easily move between flood and focus modes.  It takes more force than I expected.  My HP6 moves much more easily.  Neither can switch with just a finger, but at first I thought I was forcing it.  It really is perfectly fine and not a problem when you actually want to toggle the mode.  It really seems like the looseness of the head will likely vary between units as my HP5 and HP6 heads were very different in tightness.  The second thing to mention is that I thought the HP5 would be noticeably brighter than the 66 lumen HP2, but I really didn't notice a difference.  But it is still plenty powerful.

6:53 MinsThe best thing about this bulb is its shape.  It nearly perfectly fits in place of any incandescent, including any lamp shades that connect directly to the bulb.  In other aspects it is a very close match to the standard warm 60W incandescent and is a suitable replacement that should be perfectly fine.  The color temperature is quite good, and you might not even notice if someone didn't tell you it is a LED.  I've been a stickler for incandescent & halogen color bulbs that has slowed my use of LED & CFL in living spaces, but I can live with this one (which says a lot).  But you can still tell if you are looking for it.  In a world that is moving on from incandescent, I think this is an equitable replacement.  You can see in my video that it seems fine, but you can still tell a slight difference when I toggle between them.  I am thrilled with the shape, and satisfied with the color and evenness.The most noticeable difference is in the evenness of the light, which is still decent, but noticeably different.  The bottom half of the bulb is plastic, so light only outputs from the top.  So in a lamp shade that is evenly lit with incandescent, you will see the light skew from more at the top and less at the bottom.  I still think this is fine, just not perfect, as shown in the video.  The second most noticeable difference is the weight.  This weighs 6 times more than a normal incandescent bulb.  It weights in at 6.25oz (over a half pound) versus 1oz for an incandescent bulb.  However the weight doesn't really matter and is perfectly fine.  Only beware if you have some lightweight fixtures with flexible necks.The one thing that isn't equitable to any incandescent is the dimming.  This applies to all dimmable LED & CFL bulbs and is not unique to this one.  You cannot just swap just any incandescent bulb with this if it is in an incandescent dimmer.  You must use a dimmer that is compatible with LED and CFL, or you will shorten the lift of the LED or CFL, which takes away the cost savings in the long run.  If you don't know if yours is compatible, if yours slowly rises or dims to turn on & off, it probably is *not* compatible.  The slow rise & fall of light is easy on the eyes, but bad for LED & CFL circuitry.  Also some dimmers pump an initial burst to help incandescent bulbs turn on faster, which also hurts LED & CFL.  So my home is full of the old dimmers which will take me some time and more expense to replace.  But none of that is the fault of this LED specifically.  This is just FYI.

This Photo & Video suite is actually just a bundle of the independent photo and video suite, otherwise available separately.  You get 2 discs each with their own serial number.  These are powerful tools with lots of options that can do a really professional job.  For example, the video suite can help you make a really professional video with interesting titling affects & transitions, and somewhat easily.  It gives you templates to sample easily and just drag & drop in, with place holders to just edit the title text and right-click to replace a video or picture embedded within.  So your video starts with a nice titled introduction with embedded video (or picture) in a smaller bubble to introduce the segment.  There are lots of tools, filters / lenses, and options at your disposal.  Although with more options comes some amount of confusion and complexity at first.  More options and power doesn't make for quick editing.  The video conversions & combining might be optimized, but the time to actually work on your project will take some time.  This is not as intuitive or quick to do simple editing jobs as some simpler editors that just let you quickly trim/split/cut/combine/convert video.  It doesn't simply browser or organize your existing media library, but you can drag in anything to start working on it in a project.  But if you want to take the time to really work on something, then this offers the tools that help you do something really professional.The software starts with a getting started pop up with links to video tutorials to help you get started.  I strongly advise you to watch them if you are new (like me) to advanced editing tools, or you can be overwhelmed or confused about what to do and how to do it.  But it really isn't too bad.  But if you are expecting to just find your videos and start doing quick editing with them, this isn't the case.  For example, my Sony Camcorder comes with really good simple software that finds and browses all my videos easily, and can trim/cut/split/combine/convert videos as just the video files that they are.  But with this, you work within a project, and can drag/drop files into a story board, work on them from there, work on it to perfections, then produce the result.  But if you wanted to make a longer video like a wedding video with separately titled scenes, then this software can do far more than the simple camcorder software cannot.  So if you are looking only for an incremental step up from your existing editing tool, this one is just something suited for the larger picture than quick editing.  I wish it was a little easier to bridge the gap, and suit all needs.  For example, I do a lot of video reviews on Amazon, and it will take a lot less time to use the software that came with my camcorder to simply trim/cut/combine/convert to upload to Amazon more quickly.  But if I wanted to put together a DVD, I'd probably want to take more time to produce something that wasn't simply pure cut video that this suite can do.There is a lot to like, if you really want to spend the time to poke around and try tools.  For example, you can reverse videos, speed up or slow time video (think time lapse or slow to fill the time slot you want), separate video & audio tracks, overlay video & titles, overlay additional audio tracks, add music, etc.  It can read from lots of video formats, and has one of the most comprehensive video output format choices easily labeled for you that I have seen, much more than my camcorder software.  The video tutorials are helpful.The drawbacks are: (1) It doesn't have a simple mode to simply start with your existing video library like the usual camcorder software. (2) It takes more of your time for simple quick editing tasks (which is probably using the wrong tool for the job).  (3) There are so many choices that it can be overwhelming (but they have tutorials and you can ignore the stuff you don't want to look into yet).  (4) The free audio tracks are rather generic and make it sound like a little cheap (but they probably are royalty free and can use for the web) but for personal stuff you probably want your own music.

7:14 MinsThis DVD set package is quite nice, although not the standard shape for media cabinets.  From a packaging perspective, I had zero problems with mine, all discs were flawless.  I have a few comments about the ease of sliding in the lower discs, but it was in superb condition.  The DVD case that is in the form of the book of spells is quite nice.  I think they did a great job in the look and construction of the book.  The cover is textured nicely, the pages with a somewhat antique feel and thick.  Each season's section starts out with graphics and a nicely done table of contents for each disc.  Personally, I would have preferred if each disc's table of contents were mirrored on the back of the previous page to the actual disc slot so it lines up with the actual disc that I open the book to for added convenience to reference with the disc I am pulling.  But overall, I thought it was styled very well, and constructed well.Functionally speaking, I still prefer the normally sized DVD cases that fit on a media cabinet shelf along with all my other DVDs.  Being a completely different shape, it doesn't fit on a shelf that fits a usual DVD case.  I would prefer either a collection of slim-line case boxes for each season, or even better is a set of cases with the flip book style that even more compactly fits a complete season.  This is actually available, or if you purchase the seasons individually, but the older style that is out of production or individual seasons are more expensive.  So I still prefer the better value over function.There were reports of issues by other reviews, that was reports of glue particles on some discs.  What I can say is mine was flawless, which I show in the video, and was sold by Amazon.  I recommend checking your discs within the Amazon return/exchange window in case yours has any issue.  I've never had a problem exchanging defective items for free by Amazon.  They've been stellar in supporting things that were their fault, including defective or broken.

9:56 MinsThis is an excellent camera overall, packed with tons of features.  With so much going for it, I might say 5-star, if so much greatness outweighs a few drawbacks.  But having had the phenomenal Sony HDR-CX160 (m.blue)/(black) (2011 model at a lower price point & feature set) that I absolutely love everything about, there are a few drawbacks that matter to me.  The picture quality and image stabilization is superb at all light levels for me, including indoors in various lighting, and appears identical in picture quality to my CX160.  The audio quality is also equally superb.  Where the CX580 improves upon the CX160 is in other features, such as 32GB built in memory, 5.1 surround sound mic which shows you which direction sound is coming from in the LCD, built in light/flash, forward-facing recording indicator so others know when you are recording, comes with an HDMI cable to view on a TV without downloading, top-mount port for accessories like external lights, a few more configurable options (than the CX160) and both with lots of options.  This camera is highly configurable.  Btw, I really like smile detection that automatically takes photos.  They are fun to find later.AUTOMATIC SETTINGSIt does an excellent job with the automatic and default settings (same as my CX160) so that you don't have to tinker with it if you don't want to.  For example, if you are on vacation at Disney World, you want to just pull out the camera, snap a quick video, and not worry about adjusting anything.  This does a great job capturing moments.  I love a camcorder like this in place of a still camera.  It is so much more natural to take a short 30 second video, capture audio, and explain what is going on as it happens.  It used to take me longer to pause, wait for smiles, and take a static photo.  The key is to keep videos short to capture quick dynamic memories in place of still photos, but not take overall longer.  And beware, avoid recording everything like shows and attractions, because you will not really enjoy yourself live at the experience, and some would say your camera is going on vacation, not you.  This can take self control for some.  I pull it out before & after a show to capture our thoughts, and maybe once for a seconds in the middle to capture the essence for memory sake.  I took my CX160 to Las Vegas, it boy did it do a good job capturing the night time lighting indoors and out.  The CX580 is very similar in such quality.DRAWBACKSThe noticeable drawbacks to me are:1. The zoom is only 12X when my CX160 was 30X.  For video reviews and zooming in on attractions, I notice the difference right away, but you can easily live without it.  I've now done several reviews with the CX580 and have been happy, I just don't get quite as close up as I sometimes would.  You can turn on digital zoom, which goes up to 160X, but gets very grainy, but nobody says you have to zoom that much, so in-between it is okay.  The problem for me is that (like the CX160) zooming goes blurry out of focus at some point, and this CX580 goes blurry out of focus while zooming much earlier than my CX160, and takes longer than the CX160 to correct itself back into focus.2. The software for the CX580 is the new Play Memories Home (PMH), which has more functionality than the older Play Memories Browser (PMB) for my CX160.  The font size in PMH is noticeably smaller than in PMB, is not configurable, and doesn't follow the Windows setting to use large fonts.  With my eye sight, it gives me a headache when it is too small.  But this might be perfectly fine for you.  You can still trim, split, and combine videos.  But the new PMH software in an attempt to make it more intuitive also adds an extra step, so it takes more clicks.  In doing video reviews, I find it noticeable, but acceptable.  The PMB software can be upgraded to PMH, but I downgraded after.  You can still use this CX580 with PMB but only if you already have an older camera that activates PMB.  And from within PMB you can select to import, and pick the CX580 camera once attached, instead of it auto-launching.3. The CX580 is a little larger and taller than the CX160.  My CX160 was so small and fit so comfortably in my hand.  It felt so light and easy to control the zoom on top.  This CX580 isn't much larger, but it is a tad taller, and I can feel it.  It isn't quite as comfortable.  I was a little surprised that the higher end model (CX580) was larger.  Side by side it is noticeable, and noticeable to me only because I know what the CX160 felt like.  But apparently to get more functionality packed in, you have to let in a tiny bit more space.  However, after using the CX580 for a while, I really didn't notice and it is perfectly fine, especially if you don't remember a smaller one.  It still easily fits in one hand, just a bit tighter.OTHER TRICKSThe CX580 also sports a few other tricks.  One that I like is that you can more easily quickly delete videos.  It is subtle, but I like it.  Often enough I make a bad shot and just want to start over.  I wish you could click a button to delete the last video.  It can waste time to wade through later, by watching a partial one to see which ones finish or not, or have multiple takes.  With the CX580, the quickest way is click Menu, Edit, Delete, Movies and then start selecting, which is rather quick to do.  With the CX160, you have to enter play mode first by going into Event view, then can back out to Edit menu or else the delete action is disabled.  Both work in Event view mode directly to play and delete once playing, but that takes longer.  Btw, for me the CX580 cinema mode wasn't very useful.  I made things darker and less natural.  I prefer my vacation videos to look exactly as my eye saw them in real life, which is what these camera do a good job in under any lighting.EXAMPLESFor a low light example, see my Coast HP2 flashlight video review (http://www.amazon.com/review/R1EOZUUI0XZ2O8) taken with this camera (converted to SD).  For an indoor example, see my Harmony Touch video review (http://www.amazon.com/review/R1J5EF6N8ZEFLY) or Sony Multipod video review (http://www.amazon.com/review/R10LS2O9ODOP90) taken with this camera.SUMMARYSo for video & audio quality alone, Sony does have less expensive models that do as good of a job.  This CX580 packs more features than lesser models.  Feature sets and value to you is the main decision factor.  I don't think you can go very wrong with any decent Sony Handycam.  This just has more.RELATEDTravel Charger Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/RETABF9P6B42L/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permSony Multipod Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R10LS2O9ODOP90Case Logic MSEC-4 Case Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R29BOQMPQJ32S2/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permCase Logic EHC-103 Case Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R16IEENF18E370/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permSony HDR-CX160 Text Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R3JZXABW5J2HL7/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm

9:59 MinsThis is a very good, truly universal remote.  It can truly replace your existing remotes (minus few RF-only devices like a Wii or some uncommon DVRs).  It has a wide blaster that can usually hit all of your devices in the general direction (with line of sight open or glass).  This uses the newer MyHarmony software which is excellent, very polished, and easier to use, which would be great even for someone who isn't as tech savvy.  I really like the polished look of the software, intuitive use, speed, and drag-drop to buttons on the remote picture.  You can configure everything for any device in the activity. You can add, remove, or reorder soft buttons for any available action from any device in an activity.  You can configure any of the physical buttons to any device too.  Plus it can learn buttons from your existing remote if you need to teach it one that it doesn't know.  The MyHarmony version doesn't seem to know as many buttons as the older software, such as my TV ratio buttons to directly toggle to 16:9 or standard or zoom.  The harmony database often knows more buttons than your actual device remote had available, but the old software had even more, at least for my devices.  You can also make modifications directly on the remote, which will save back later if you synchronize to the website again so they are not overwritten.  The touch screen also offers gestures that you can map to anything, although fairly limited to 5 - tap, swipe up/down/right/left, such as to swipe right to fast forward.Why you want a truly universal remote like this is that you can get rid of 4-5 remotes laying all over your couch or end table, and make it easy to just "watch a DVD" without having to use 3-4 different remotes to turn each on and set all the inputs correctly.  This (like any Harmony remote) just takes care of it.  You press one thing and it starts and sets input, and does anything else you want it to do, including sequences you specify.But here is the bottom line compared to other Harmony remotes.  This remote is centered on its touch screen, and other harmony remotes like the One and 900 center on physical buttons optimally placed with tactile feel.  If (A) you love touch screens, you don't normally memorize where all the buttons are, you don't prefer to press buttons by feel, you don't often issue remote commands other than to turn on / play / and occasionally pause, and you are happy to look down and scroll through a screen when you do need to do something, then this is an excellent 5-star remote for you.  But if (B) you normally hold the remote in your hand without looking, you play / pause / fast forward / and jump back frequently, you prefer the tactile feel of physical buttons, then this remote is an okay 3-star remote for you.  It is still a Harmony remote regardless which is well built & configurable.  But basically think how often you fast forward.  I skip commercials constantly, so an optimally placed fast forward button and 8-second jump back button is critical, so I prefer the One & 900.  The gestures (tap to play/pause and swipe to fast forward or rewind) are supposed to help place these actions more optimally, but they still don't make it as easy as a button in the center.  The play/pause and fast forward buttons on this remote are at the top and are ackward to use by feel alone, but are perfectly fine if you look down and use two hands.Compared to the Harmony One and Harmony 900, the differences are many.  Aside from the touch screen & buttons primary difference, there are more differences.  The software is notably better on the Touch than the older desktop software for the Harmony One or 900.  The battery is built-in and cannot be removed.  My 900 and One very infrequently lock up, and pulling the battery lets me reset it.  The Touch has never yet locked up on me, but if it does, I don't know what the solution will be.  The charger uses a micro USB cable, which you can use with the charger or directly on the remote.  The charger orientation stands the remote up, which takes up more space if you tuck the charging station on a low shelf.  But this way you can use the remote while in the cradle and it is easier to notice standing tall if you prefer.  I still tuck my One & 900 into a low shelf only when the battery runs low.  The soft button layout is just a single column that you scroll by swiping, instead of the 2 column and 3 row pages you page between on the One/900.  The soft button icons are automatic and are more subtle in the same color on the right side of the text within the text bubble, instead of the more noticeable soft button icons on the One/900.  Lastly, the button database seems of the newer software seems to know fewer commands, at least for my devices, than the older desktop software on the One/900.  But still, the biggest thing still comes down to physical buttons or touch screen, which is a preference.UPDATE 2014: Logitech released a significant update to the firmware that may make it more usable.  For example, you can now do 2 actions per button depending on a short or long press.  I believe it is now closer to the newer Harmony Ultimate with the on-device usability.  It is still the same remote ergonomically speaking.  In the absence of the discontinued One and 900, it looks better.  I now just keep my DVR remote out for more intensive browsing.H.One Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/RH9NV6NMTOWVK/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm (discontinued)H.900 Video Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R2GPJD72HKV7HC/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm (discontinued)H.Ultimate Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R3GCRQA9JESHGQ/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permH.Simple Control Review: http://www.amazon.com/review/R3TDLD0ITMONOU/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm

9:57 MinsThis multipod is a great, compact way to carry all three (tripod, mono-pod, and mini-pod) all in one, and each very well built.  It is very versatile, easily configured and extended.  It feels well built, not cheap, but still lightweight, as it weighs 2lb 2oz on my kitchen scale.  The light metal, dense spongy grip, and rubber feet feel solid.  The extension points easily loosen, extend/collapse, and tighten (as long as you don't over-tighten).  The legs easily configure (surprisingly better than I expected) but take care not to step on them.  Mount point easily snaps securely into place and releases, and the hand nut to redirect it easily loosens & tightens.  I think it is a very nice, versatile tripod.  And in mini-pod form it is easily one of the best I had been looking at (as mini-pods tend to be cheaper and not have as many features).  The mini-pod is the exact same thing, just with the shaft removed.  The mono-pod is the same, just with a single foot and a bit lighter, but you might prefer to just keep the legs on while pushed together.Within each form, it is is very easily and quickly configurable.  The 3 standout features are: (1) The legs are so easy to configure.  There is a locking tab that easily clicks into 3 quick positions and the legs easily extend and retract. (2) The height adjusts very easily in 4 collapsing sections to quite a height (eye level for me, I'm 5'10"). (3) The mount on the top easily loosens and tightens to swivel in all directions *and* has a snap-in & release lever to attach/release your camera without having to spin your camera around a nut, just a little tiny platform that releases or snaps in.But to transition between the 3 forms, you will need to unscrew 2 things and reattach, such as remove the top & bottom (remove the middle shaft) to make a mini-pod, or remove the legs to make a mono-pod, etc.  It is very easy to unscrew and reattach (shown in video).  The case itself is very versatile and folds several different ways meant to store pieces when not used for each form.  But for a true professional who needs to instantly switch forms, it is too much to be unscrewing things.  But within each form, it is quickly configurable.  However you can almost instantly switch between tripod & mono-pod just by pushing together the legs or pulling back out as they easily configure.  But you must take care not to step on these legs, as they are lightweight hallow tubes, which might be a concern of someone running around crowds or stumbling around themselves in a rush.  I would think such a professional might choose an unbreakable piece of equipment, and perhaps the 3 pieces separately to suit the needs.The bag is surprisingly configurable, but is not perfect.  It transforms into several different shapes to store pieces and different modes, such as a mono-pod stuff into it supported by your shoulder instead of using the ground, such as to hold the camera high and steady.  The snaps and Velcro work well and quickly enough.  But it still take two hands to slide the tripod in due to the width and friction of the rubber feet.  But it is more about compact design and versatility.  The bag is not the highlight, but is a nice touch as opposed to a trivial bag or not having one.  The nylon strap detaches if you prefer to attach your own.

7:31 MinsI absolutely love this ultra bright tiny flashlight.  It easily bests all of my other, larger flashlights, puts old incandescent lights to shame, and still beats out my previous favorite that was my compact 6-LED flashlight.  But it doesn't quite beat my large 18V light from my cordless Ryobi cordless drill set, but oddly comes close in useful light.  It is very well built, seems rock solid and precise, and feels good in your hand.  Being able to turn the head to tune from flood to narrow beam makes a big difference in applying the light most usefully.  In the full flood mode, it is easily the brightest, most useful, even light for looking around.  In the narrowest mode it makes a very bright spot, which you might use in a lit room to light up something you are working on.  The ability to tune to flood mode is what makes this little thing throw more useful light that much larger ones I have.  It is so small, that you can easily toss it in a purse, bag, or pocket, and it only weights 1.3oz with AAA battery.  I really like that it has a clip too.  There may be bigger, brighter ones out there, including from Coast too, but this one you can just have on you when you might not have through to grab a larger light from your toolbox, trunk, or closet.  It is so convenient, you can always have a backup ready to go, and save going back to get the big light for when you really need to.The 66 lumen are well used.  It is far less than the 780 lumen of an ordinary 57 Watt light bulb.  So don't expect it to light a whole room like daylight.  But in the dark, and compared to other flashlights, it was ultra bright, was superb well use of the light, and extraordinary considering its size.The only drawback is that the battery life is only 2.5 hours, so you get a lot of light, but the battery is used quickly.  I am happy to optimize for more compact light than battery life.  So grab some good rechargeable AAA batteries and have some spares if you are going to be out a while with it.  Get the newer style rechargables the hold their charge for a long time when unused so it will always be ready (like Sanyo eneloop or other pre-charged kinds).  I hear NiMH last much better with a higher draw than Alkaline batteries based on other reviews.I was so impressed that I went right away to buy another as a gift for a relative.  But because it was temporarily out of stock, I bought the Coast PX25 (208 Lumen) instead from the same brand, which is a highly rated 208 lumen variation that is thicker by the 3 AAA batteries it uses (and no focus control).

8:40 MinsAs a ricer, this is well built, seems large enough, and works well.  Any firm items must be cooked first (such as potatoes or carrots), and then fairly easily presses through with two hands.  Obviously the smaller hole settings take more work than larger settings.  It easily rotates between the 3 size settings, and sticks there so it doesn't slip out of position.  The plunger that pushes food through makes a good seal (a good as I would expect), but not water tight, so a very small amount of potato ends up on the top rim over time, which you just brush off into the bowl.  It is large enough that you have plenty of leverage to squeeze the food through.  I can nearly do it one handed, but it is easy with two hands.  It starts out a little firm, then easily squeezes once it starts pushing through.  The hook to lay on the bowl edge works fine, except most of my pots are only just slightly deeper than this device, so you have to lift it up to squeeze so the food has somewhere to go as it piles up.  So I end up just setting it on top of the pile as I fill it, which works well.  Removing the outer plate when cleaning is easy enough, but takes a little wriggling back and forth.  The plates seem thick enough that I wouldn't worry about something like cooked potato.  Just remember you have to cook firm items first to make them sufficiently soft.  Cleaning takes some work just because it is a larger contraption, but would be no different than any other ricer.  As a ricer, I am happy with it.For mashed potatoes, it works well, but it is easier to make them with a good strong wire potato masher.  This makes creamy mashed potatoes of more consistent consistency, but depending on the hole size can still have enough chunkier tiny bits so that you know it isn't instant potato flakes.  You have to peel the skin from the potatoes to easily work with the grate.  But it does make quick work extruding the potato with ease, a few scoops at a time.  In my video, I actually made them with the middle size setting.  However, for mashed potatoes, I still prefer my good strong wire potato masher for several reasons. (1) The masher makes chunkier mashed potato of more irregularity (like many restaurants) depending simply on how much and how evenly you keep mashing. (2) The masher can doubly mash and mix flavorings (butter, milk, cheese or sour cream, salt, pepper) all at the same time as mashing instead of a separate mixing step. (3) The masher is much simpler to clean, just a small tool that is easy to clean compared to this whole contraption. (4) The masher can work with skin left on the potato (which I prefer).  But make sure you have a good sturdy wire masher (like my Kithenaid wire masher).  I have a plastic one that is terrible in comparison due to holes that clog, that bends, and takes more work.  So as a mashed potato maker only, I would rate this a 4/5, but I will use my wire masher due to combined steps, ease of cleaning, result consistency, and skins on.  But it is a preference, and many might prefer the ricer result.But a ricer has multiple applications, it isn't just for one kind of mashed potatoes.  I think it is a very good ricer overall.

8:01 MinsThis is a very nice cable, seems very well constructed, but is also very thick and heavy, so it has a few drawbacks.  With HDMI + ethernet + 3D + audio return, this cable is significantly thicker (and heavier) than a simple HDMI + ethernet cable.  For long runs, and combined capabilities, it is a very nice cable that I would recommend.  However, if you need only a basic HDMI cable, or just +ethernet, or shorter runs, a slimmer, less capable AmazonBasics HDMI cable is noticeably slimmer and lighter.  So there are pros - quality, all the combined capabilities, long runs, etc.  And the cons are the thickness & weight which could affect some uses, or for many be of no issue at all.  I have always been thrilled with all AmazonBasics cables that I own, as well as Monster cables and other premium cables I have bought over time.  I now look to the value priced AmazonBasics for quality digital cables.Directly compared to the AmazonBasics HDMI+ethernet cable (2 pack with optical cable), this cable is significantly thicker and heaver.  Of course this one has + 3D + audio return that the other does not.  But it does affect the cable's thickness & weight.  The connector construction seems top notch on both.  (1) A concern I have is that the weight of the cable alone, if left unsupported and dangling for some height to the television port, it will be pulling down with its weight.  So you will probably want to support the cable around a hook, clamp, or otherwise tac it up to take the weight off from the ports that it connects to.  Usually this will not be a problem, but the orientation of your HDMI connector and wire run could be a concern.  (2) The thickness will not bend as tightly, so if you had to make a tight turn, such as where you want to connect it to the TV, or wrap it around a hook.  However, I don't mean to imply it is inflexible, I just mean compared to a slimmer AmazonBasics HDMI cable.  (3) The thickness will make it harder (or impossible) to tuck along a carpet edge or in a cable conduit.  (4) The color, black, will be more noticeable if it cannot be hidden from sight or fit into a cable conduit.  Still, I would not hesitate to use this cable, provided I had a plan to run it appropriately.So this is a great quality cable for a value price.  I have always found AmazonBasics to be significantly better than the other cheap cables out there.  It is on par or exceeding moderate premium cables out there.  It might not have everything that the top tier from Monster offers, but I think it comes close enough for most.

9:59 MinsI love this router.  For home use of wireless access to your internet connection, it is excellent.  The signal was strong throughout my two-story house, and more importantly the internet throughput was nearly identical to the wired speed.  My upstairs bedroom (walls, ceilings in between) was especially problematic on my old router, which made my xbox internet connection spotty, slow to download, and extremely slow to start videos and frequently paused videos to buffer again.  With this router, I get a superb signal, and throughput to match, and my xbox works normally, and videos load quickly and with great quality to match my wired PC for internet streaming.  Upstairs, on DSL internet with 3 Mbps down / .75 Mbps up, my old router achieved 1.33 Mbps down / 0.66 up, and this achieved 2.90 Mbps down / 0.73 up, which was nearly the same as the wired speeds from my PC connected to the router.  For wired speeds it did not cause a slow down.  Before, directly with my DSL modem, my wired speeds were 2.89 down / 0.72 up, and now after it was 3.00-3.07 down / 0.66-0.72 up.  So the extra hop didn't seem noticeable, but overall there was always variance with the old or new router.  Oddly, the download speed tended to tick up a notch, and upload speed slightly down a notch, which is still just piggy backing on the old router that is the DSL modem.  Perhaps the QoS on this router prioritizes differently, or just real world variance.  It was just a different ratio overall on some tests.  So for a wireless internet connection, this router solved all of my problems.  I really couldn't be more thrilled.Internet access, downloads, and streaming is limited to your actual internet speed, such as 3 Mbps DSL, which uses only a small part of the states speeds of this router, making it effectively an N003 router.  Above your internet speed, the other 297 Mbps is only for within devices on your local network within your house, and limited by each specific device's card too, such as older wireless G, or N150 (single antenna), etc.  I think this N300 router does a fine job for the usual home user doing a casual amount of local network transfers, but I have not stressed it.  If you are really serious about tons of local network traffic and streaming between devices, you probably aren't looking at this N300 router, and instead looking at N600, N900, and the newest AC protocol routers.  So for the usual home router, I think this N300 is great for the average home user.  The back of the box clearly shows where this one sits among the current generation of technology this year.Setup was a breeze.  Connecting to it via the IP address given to you on a card was trivial, but just remember to connect directly to this router if using a wired connection to do it.  It walks you through optionally changing your router admin name, password, SSID, and security key.  You can also turn off the SSID broadcasting (which I recommend) for more security.  But the the changes to the SSID and disabling of SSID broadcasting did not take affect without rebooting the router (an option under the admin menu) which was not clear that I had to do that after saving.  For my xbox to work properly, I had to enable UPnP (QoS > UPnP menu, save, Admin menu > reboot).  They give you good quick start guides for Apple & Android portable devices & PCs (mac & windows), and a CD that you don't need to use (I never used it).  I had my network working in minutes.  Xbox took a few minutes to read up on the error about NAT issue, which xbox help pointed to enabling UPnP as I mentioned.  I had no problem at all using VPN for my work.  Both my mac and windows laptop easily connected to it too.

5:31 MinsSanDisk has never let me down with my HD Camcorder.  This card has never been the bottleneck to cause any quality loss or data loss.  For vacation video and pictures, I wanted the confidence that my recordings were not going to be lost, or reduced in quality due to card issues to be discovered when I return home.  You only have one chance to capture those memories.  SanDisk is a great brand.  Last year I bought two SanDisk Extreme SDHC 16GB 30 MB/s (the previous model), and this year I bought this SanDisk Extreme SDHC 32GB 45 MB/s (the next model).I recommend reading your camcorder or camera manual, and see what it states as the write speed at the quality setting you plan to use.  If it bothers to state it, I believe there is a reason.  If not stated, then don't worry, the minimum write speed by the minimum card spec should be fine.  For me, my manual (Sony HD Camcorder) clearly stated a write speed at about 23 MB/s for the mode I use, and up to 28 MB/s.  So I made sure I had a card that was internally capable of writing at the stated speed.  That way the card itself could not possibly be the bottleneck.  Now your manual should state the minimum card spec, like "class 6" or "class 10", or "UHS-I".  Class 10 refers to a 10 MB/s minimum sustained write speed, and makes indication that your camera or camcorder will actually take any advantage of using more than the minimum spec if it doesn't say otherwise.  Personally, I figure if the manual states write speeds separately, and only states a class 6 minimum, I am not taking any chances, as the math doesn't make sense.  A minimum spec class 6 could not possibly capture 28 MB/s of HD video over a long period of time without an equally sized internal buffer, or else it would have to degrade quality to keep up.  So I would see if you manual actually lists any numbers to see if it would matter in your case.This is a UHS-I rated card, and class 10, and backward compatible.  For UHS-I, I believe it is something that the hardware does have to specifically support to use the bus differently.  So you are likely to get somewhere less than that for devices supporting only beyond class 10 specifications.  I might guess that might mean somewhere near the 30 MB/s of the previous models claim before UHS-I.  For more on classifications, wikipedia is a good source.  Just do not expect to take full advantage of this card unless you have a UHS-I, or even beyond class 10, depending on device, which might not even be clearly documented.  In the end, I am happy with my choice with SanDisk.

4:57 MinsGlide is specifically for people with tight teeth, who shred floss, and have trouble getting it in and out.  Floss, like a tooth bush, is somewhat up to your liking and personal characteristics.  So Glide might not be for everyone, but I do believe it can be used by nearly anyone.  This packaging, the "Pro Health For Life" is stated for people 50 years or older for what it says "because it is Glide's softest floss".  So apparently compared to other Glide variations, this is softer.  But I personally really cannot tell any difference compared to Glide in the normal packaging that I have used for years, or compared to generic equivalents.  In fact, I thought it felt slightly less "soft" if I had to compare.  It is a tape style floss, very thin, but the tape width is wider than the normal packaging that I recall from before, or compared to the generic brand equivalent that I have been using.  The added tape width feels as though it might clean better (make up for not having brushing action of string floss), but feels to glide slightly less as there is more of it.This is a tape style, silky floss, that will feel and work differently than string floss (waxed or unwaxed).  I believe string floss can clean better because it can act as a brush and grab at grit slightly more.  But possibly thin tape floss might get deeper around your gums and teeth?  But if string floss doesn't work for you, tape floss is an excellent alternative, and loads better than not flossing.  You could always switch between them too if you can stand string floss.Overall, it really seems the same as any other Glide floss I've ever used, and I am equally happy with it.  The "50+" shouldn't matter.  I have used Glide floss for years now.  I am not a dentist and can only share my personal experience.  If you identify with tight teeth and do not like string floss, I would recommend Glide to anyone.  But perhaps if the tape is extremely bunched up, the very tightest teeth out there might feel it slightly more due to its width.

6:49 MinsWe love it.  It is an ideal size for small recipes for 1-2 people, with limited left overs depending on how much you eat, fill your plate or just 1/3 your plate with other sides like a veggie & potatoes or roll.  But it doesn't fit everything that you would want to make.  Realistically you will likely need both a 3.5 and 5 quart crock pots to select based on the size of the recipe.  We still use this 3.5qt most for 2 of us, but have on occasion found it filled too quickly and switched over to the 5qt.  Remember, any crock pot should only be filled to 2/3, not the top that is shown in all pictures on any box.  We had started with a lot of veggies and potatoes and found we were already at 2/3 on this 3.5qt before we could even add the meat, so we switched to the 5qt.  But then you do not want to always use a 5qt either, because you do not want too little in.  So we end up using this 3.5qt most for the 2 of us, but have to occasionally use 5qt.  The 3.5qt pot is easier to clean because it is smaller and weighs less than the 5qt.The construction and quality of this pot seem very good to us.  The lid is standard thickness for crock pots, and there doesn't seem to be any need for it to be heavier while it is cooking.  It does build up condensed water around the ring of the lid and bubbles out during cooking as it continually pushed out steam.  The 4 settings seem to give you plenty of flexibility, but we use low for most, and the automatic switch to warming mode is nice.  The recipe book was actually nice compared to a Crock Pot brand 5qt (that we also like) that claimed a recipe book, but really only added a few pages at the pack of its manual.  This one is a nice spiral bound book, but no pictures.We couldn't always just set it and forget it, or just follow the exact time on the recipe.  You really have to experiment to find the ideal cooking time for you.  We found our recipes are done earlier than the usual 8 hours stated in our recipes, and ended up getting overcooked.  So you make it once, realize it is dryer or veggies are overcooked, so you reduce the time next time.  So the meals weren't perfect the first time we did any recipe so far, but were better the second time around when we made cooking time adjustments.  For example, the first meal shown in the video was overdone, apples overcooked, and meat was a bit tough, which I think you can see in the video.  So next time, just cook it less.  For some meats, you really should test with a probe thermometer to ensure it is safely cooked, but hopefully only to confirm it is done, not to check frequently because you have to add cooking time every time you remove the lid.  For the second meal shown in the video (pulled pork), it too cooked longer than needed the first time, and was better the second time when we checked the temperature earlier and confirmed done earlier.  The best success we had with this was making pulled pork.  Btw, I skipped showing the steps testing the meat temperature, adding the BBQ sauce, and using a fork to shred the pork.

8:27 MinsThis is a competent drive that works, improves boot and load times (like any SSD), focuses on value, and is clear what you get.  I own 3 SSD drives now, an excellent Intel 510 Series 120 GB SSD that I love but is expensive, a SanDisk Extreme SSD 120 GB that was also competent but offers zero help to migrate from HDD despite its feature focus on upgrade, and now this Kensington 128GB SSD.  I have the version that is just the drive itself, which is clearly explained, but Kengington offers versions with a migration kit or sold separately if you do need to migrate from an existing HDD.  When your existing computer is in ridiculously bad shape, you need to re-install the operation system from scratch to clean up both software glitches as well, which was my case for this drive.  But if you do want to migrate from an existing HDD, I had a lot of trouble on my own with freeware, but then found great success and ease with Apricorn SATA Wire Upgrade Kit ASW-USB-25 which I highly recommend (see my separate video review).This drive successfully restored life to my older laptop (with a fresh reinstall of Windows 7), my Lenovo Thinkpad T60p with Intel Core 2 Duo processor.  Afterwards it boots to logon in 20 seconds.  Applications nearly (but not completely) instantly pop right open, or at least much faster than before without all the think time it had when I opened anything before.  Remember any security suite slows down boot time, run time, and shut down time.  There are sites dedicated to comparing them.  With any of my SSDs, it has rendered worrying about that needless as they all boot without feeling like I am waiting for them.  With no moving parts, any SSD should be able to boot and load faster because of their superior random read performance versus an HDD's seek time between non-contiguous data strips.  But some data like large files, video, and archiving stuff still works well on an HDD as a secondary drive.They key here is to consider it at its price point, where it focuses on value.  There are always more expensive top of the line things out there, so it is unfair to compare it to an SSD that is 2-3 times the price.  But with this, you get most of the benefits, is still much faster booting and loading than any HDD, and just works.  If you don't want to shell out the big bucks for a top of the line alternative, I think this is a competent way to go.  I am perfectly happy with mine.  Based on Windows Experience Index, this disk is rated 7.1, versus 7.6 for my SanDisk SSD, and 7.8 for my Intel SSD.

9:08 MinsThis makes migrating disk drives painless & simple.  It is especially great migrating between unequally sized drives like migrating from a larger HDD to smaller SSD.  And it successfully handles a bootable partition with a working operating system like Windows 7.  If you bought an SSD that didn't come with a migration kit, I highly recommend this solution.Migrating is actually a complicated process.  Especially when moving from larger to smaller, you have to move data to the front, then shrink the partition, then copy to new drive, make alignment changes if it is SSD, then expand to fit the new drive, and hope the operating system still works (mine didn't).  I encourage you to search the web for "migrate hard drive to SSD" and you will find a number of articles and freeware offering guidance, all fairly complicated and different.  I liked the SSD Freaks and lifehacker articles best.  I tried a long time and ultimately failed to migrate a working Windows 7 partition.  You might not realize that migrating to SSD requires different alignment, which isn't fixed by a straight copy.  This Apricorn software just does it all for you, painlessly and simply.In retrospect, the only freeware alternative I think would really work, is a Windows 7 backup & restore, which should reload properly onto the new drive.  But if you are like me, it takes 2-4 weeks to get all the programs reinstalled and reconfigured to the same level of productivity on my work laptop with engineering software.  But with this, within hours you can simply be up on your new drive, but with everything else the same as before.  But if you have a USB 3.0 port, I recommend the Apricorn SATA Wire 3.0 Upgrade Kit ASW-USB3-25 which should copy faster.  Otherwise this one using USB 2.0, it is perfectly fine for something you rarely do, and still works with USB 3.0 ports.One thing to note is that the first time you log onto Windows 7 on the new drive, it detects and fixes something, and then reboots.  Re-run your windows experience score too, which supposedly will help it re-detect it is SSD, enable optimization, and disable defrag.

8:08 MinsI was excited to try this, but the results were unacceptable, and the proof is in the video.  I believe success depends a lot on your microwave wattage and internal dynamics.  I have a very good top rated high wattage microwave (1200W cooking power) which yielded terrible results.  The instructions are clearly for a 1200W microwave like mine.  But based on experimenting I've done, I theorize that a lower wattage microwave and maybe without a turn table might turn out more even due to slower cooking.It always resulted in a ring of overcooked rubbery scrambled eggs with a paper thin or just a hole in the middle where your fillings would go.  Closing the clam shell just makes a double stack of these rubbery things with the paper thin center or holes in the middle.  It was rather unappealing and looked nothing like the pictures.  Waiting for the middle to become set took too long while the outer "ring" bubbled up and overcooked.  It didn't smell very good either, and tasted not so good.  It was "edible", but my wife refused to taste it from the look & smell.  You don't get browning in the microwave (which oddly is shown in one of the pictures in the manual), and without a little butter or oil in the pan, you miss some of the flavor you normally get on the outside of the omelet.It really isn't much easier than just making in a pan.  You still have to prepare beat & season the eggs and fillings.  You are really only saving washing a pan & spatula from the pan cooking phase and instead throwing this in the dishwasher.  You still have to wash any pans, boards, and bowls used for the filling and egg prep.  I sometimes struggle with using a pan because it cooks fast so you have move quickly because it cooks fast, and folding sometimes doesn't go well.  I had hoped this would make it perfectly & easily.  But it was far from it, just overcooked it in different ways that was unacceptable.  This isn't just a defective item, as it is just plastic.I'm really sorry, I tried very hard to make this work.  I spent a long time on this.  The video is made up of 63 clips to piece together the story, trimmed from 3 times that many recordings.

6:41 MinsThis is a small notebook mouse to be used to throw in your pocket when you go to meetings.  This is what a "notebook mouse" is expected to be, small, lightweight, portable, and be able to work on most or all surfaces, and have a good range in case you are presenting via a projector and not adjacent to your actual laptop.  It would be cramped (like any notebook mouse) to use every day as your actual mouse.  It is lightened by using a single AAA battery.  It has about the tiniest possible receiver, which is common among most mice now.  It can be stored under the mouse (like many mice), but more likely you just leave the tiny thing in your laptop port since it can be left in while toting even in most bags.  This is what a "notebook mouse" is, and it works well for what it is.  For anyone looking to use for hours on end, you probably should tote a full size mouse with a tiny receiver and optional single AA battery supported by many full size mice.The texture and feel of the mouse was quite good in my opinion, with the rubber sizes, detect click feel, and scroll wheel isn't free spinning but the soft clicking context feel to how far you scroll (that I prefer).  Mine came with a defect, a tiny bump where my right thumb rests on the side rubber which doesn't feel quite right.  But for infrequent use to run to meetings, I really don't mind.  But to use daily, I'd say it is just a defect and should be replaced by Amazon or by warranty as defective.The one uncertainty is how well iHome holds up for battery life and functional life compared to Logitech and Microsoft mice that set a very high bar for conserving batter life and lasting forever for me.  This uses a AAA battery, so to be fair, the battery will last only as long as a AAA could carry it, which will be no match for two AA batteries of a full size.  You have to trade off a little for convenience of a small mouse purely in battery size.  What you hope is that they optimize every ounce of the AAA it does have.  Time will tell.

2:30 MinsWe are extremely happy with ours.  You do not even know the pillow cover is there.  When I bought new pillows, I wanted to protect my pillow more, and protect me more from my pillow over time.  My nose doesn't seem a stuffy in the morning with the new combination.  The biggest benefit of these is that it makes no additional sound, especially no crinkly sound.  If you have looked at pillow covers, especially those designated for allergy control, all of the others I've looked at make a loud crinkly noise when you press on them (or someone moves or lays down while sleeping).  This one make no crinkly noise at all.  Beware some pillows have the crinkly noise in the pillow fabric itself, so make sure you buy a pillow that doesn't already make a sound.  But the point is, adding this does not seem any different than if you didn't use a pillow cover at all.That does not mean it is noise less on its own, but paired with a normal pillow case on top, then you wouldn't know the difference.  The fabric itself makes a noise if you slide your hand on it, compared to a cotton pillow case, but it makes less rubbing noise than the pillow itself, and is completely eliminated by a pillow case that you have to put on anyway and is the only surface you will actually rub against in use.  In, use, compression goes through all layers, so any layer that crinkles would be noticeable.I ordered two, one of mine came unmarked for size, but was actually the right size.  I am very happy with my purchase.

4:13 MinsThese are very good, not too sweet, not too crumbly, slightly dry, good raisins with low ratio, excellent texture, very natural tasting (nothing artificial), dense & filling enough.  For a store bought cookie, they are very good.  There is nothing artificial tasting to them, they stay soft, but have a good chewy texture that holds together well.  They taste a little dry, but are not dried out or too brittle.  Most home made cookies dry out and turn brittle on me in a few days.  These hold up well.  The raising ratio seems just right, not too many but a very good balance of sweetness & wetness in the right places.  They are moderately sized, smaller that I would have guessed from the large picture and size on the box, but seemed filling enough because they were sufficiently dense.  They are not perfection compared to actual home baking fresh out of the oven, but relative to store bought cookies, and other oatmeal cookies, I thought they were very good.One thing to remember is that these are not as healthy as implied by all the good things promoted about using Quaker oats and being a good source of fiber.  They do have 16% fiber and pack in other good things, but they do carry 9% of your daily value of fat too, per cookie.  Compared to other cookies or snacks which offer no positives, these pack in good things along with the bad.  Just don't think consider them as good as just eating an apple without any fat.  But if the alternative is to pick up potato chips or other cookies, these at least pack in health benefits if you are going to eat such a snack anyway.

7:39 MinsThe bottom line is that it works, but is far from great.  When you just need a means to get access to data on a 2.5" drive as cheap as possible, this can be an excellent value.  It is an adequate device to meet temporary needs.  The core components are just a bare aluminum case and SATA to USB connector.  There is no padding within the bay and your drive does not feel secure for toting around, but is perfectly adequate for making connections once in a while to get at data.  Surrounding the core component are very nice things, a USB Y-cable provided to draw extra power (although but you can use just one which I did only one), a plastic sheet to cover an exposed circuit board, screw driver, the tiniest screws you've seen aside from eye glasses, a pouch, instructions, and a little box to store it all in.  It is rather impressive that all this comes at at this value.My biggest problem with it was that the connector was bent a little, meaning my drive couldn't fit in perfectly, and I refused to stress the port on my drive, so I slid it in just enough to get one of the screws in and left the other askew a little.  It was perfectly adequate to get at my data during a computer outage that was down for repair.  But I handled it more gingerly and would not plan to use it to tote to work, throw in a drawer or backpack, etc.  The bottom line is the SATA & USB ports worked.  The second drawback is the drive is just by itself without padding of any kind in the aluminum tin.  It makes me a little uncomfortable, so I would handle it gingerly.  If you are going to tote it around a lot, or use it to build your own external drive, I would get a more durable one.  But for basic connections, it is fine.It worked perfectly fine with my Intel 510 SSD 120 GB SATA 3 (6 Gbps), but obviously ran more slowly like you would expect from USB 2.0.  Overall I give it 4 stars instead of 3 because it is so cheap, that for the price, you really can't be unhappy.  But it is definitely just "okay" otherwise.

7:27 MinsOverall I am very happy with this drive.  Just plug it in and it just works.  And it is 2-3X as fast as my USB 2.0 external drive (WD Password 500GB).  It runs warm, but not hot, and is quiet.  It isn't as fast as an internal SATA 3 (6 Gbps) drive, but for expanding storage, archiving stuff, or for backups it will work great.  I was growing tired of backups running long and having to check back to turn off my computer and am happy to cut that time in 1/2 or more from before.  It doesn't come with any software, but you really shouldn't need any anymore, as current operating systems have it built in.  This is more like Western Digital's Elements line of external HDs that are just a nice working drive that is quiet and fast.  It is a brick, but small enough to tote when you need to, but not so small as a WD Passport or other pocket drive.  It seems plenty durable.I will use the drive for backups and storing my video content, so in a realistic test of a 608MB file (from one of my reviews), I tested copying from my existing Seagate SATA3 2TB HDD to (1) USB 2.0 WD My Passport 500GB = 29s, (2) USB 3.0 Seagate 2TB (this one) = 8s (but varied), and (3) SATA 3 Intel 510 series SSD = 0s (instant).  Compared to USB 2.0 speeds, USB 3.0 was great.  Nobody expects it to beat internal SATA 3.  USB 3.0 bus speed should be fairly common among any drive supporting it, provided the drive holds up its end.  As far as this Seagate goes, it seems to hold up.  I got 8s at first, but it did vary.  As seen in the video, it actually took longer in that shot, so expect it to vary some.  In this kind of ad-hoc testing, other factors are involved, like drive power saving state, OS and other computer states, etc.I did have one problem, the drive arrived with a defect, but I was able to fix it.  It arrived with the USB 3.0 & ports not lined up with the holes on the back, making it impossible to plug the cables into the drive.  The drive inside was clearly not sitting right.  They were offset from the holes by more than 1/3, with the USB port virtually inaccessible.  Fortunately, I could use the more robust AC plug to pry it down as if it were on a spring, which pulled the USB port down, and then plugged in the USB cable and pulled down more, which then seemed to click and nearly stay in place.  Assuming defective drives can be replaced immediately by Amazon, my only concern was how this passed inspection.

5:45 MinsThe packaging is where this stands out, which is its major selling point.  It is a nice box holding 3 standard sized 500 reams.  You can just tuck it in a closet without worrying about the paper getting banged up.  The reams themselves are standard paper envelopes which are significantly better than plastic wrapped reams often found in consumer stores because they look better.  These don't tear to pieces like the plastic wraps once you open a ream.  You can actually reuse the box for reams you buy separately later.  Note that the top rests on the top ream, not the box edge, so that if you open the top ream and put it back and stack things on top, it will push down on that half open package until small enough to reach the box edge.The paper itself is just paper and conforms to the stated specs.  The brightness (92) is on par with other 92s, often labelled as bright white.  But side-by-side with my HP 92 it almost looked negligibly less white than the HP, perhaps due to surfaces reflecting differently in my lighting.  The weight (24lb) is more than your usual 20lb copy paper, but otherwise conforms to the state 24 lb that should be on par with any other paper stated at 24lb.  If you've never had 24lb before, it is only slightly thicker, nothing very stiff like cardboard or index cards.  Compared to 20lb, 24lb paper gives things a slightly better feel, better for two-sided (duplex) printing because the other side doesn't show through as much, inkjets will probably work better with in saturation, and the thicker, stiffer paper is probably slightly less likely to crinkle causing jam.  Honestly I haven't had a jam with 20lb paper in ages.  Jams are often due to rollers & grabber material in your printer needing replacement sooner than you realize they need servicing.It ships well, in a box with a few air pillows, but in general paper is pretty secure.  But rather than being a ream with only paper edges banging around a shipping box, this 3-ream box protects them well within the outer box while it ships.  The box itself would be safe enough to ship alone, but wouldn't look as nice or clean in your closet if banged up and full of stickers.

7:08 MinsIt really depends on many factors, so experiences will vary.  I think you will likely find varying degrees of success, not complete eradication.  If you have multiple pests, then you will probably deter some of them, in which you find 2-4 star reviews.  Or if you have one pest, whether or not it works on that one determines 1 or 5 star reviews.  I am happy with the products attempt to deter and isn't a gimmick, but the value will depend on your level of success.  Based on many reviews, clearly success varies.  At least this 5-lb shaker seems to last longer than the smaller cans at the local store.So it is really just a big can of pepper, mostly black pepper and cayenne pepper which are two of the 3 active ingredients.  Peppers smell and taste unpleasant to animals.  Whether this blend and processing are the perfect solution and cost effectiveness versus wholesale black and cayenne pepper depends.  It isn't a fence or barrier, just a deterrent to make it more unpleasant than the next alternative location for the animal which will hopefully move on and do its business elsewhere.  But you will be fighting against (1) habits that might take time to break, (2) areas previously marked by animals or other droppings that are more attractive that offset or overpower this, (3) if yours is still the least unpleasant alternative to limited or worse options, (4) the animal's sensitivity to taste and smell of this deterrent, and (5) how fast it gets washed away and perform at reduced levels.  You could have an old dog that has lost much of its sense of smell and has been using your lawn for ages and has marked the area that probably would be less deterred to change.  Or a cat's habit and previous droppings might overpower this product.This is similar to you going to the beach.  Suppose rocks litter one side of the beach along with a dead fish that washed up on shore and smells a little.  It doesn't stop you from walking through there, it is just unpleasant to setup your towel or walk around over there.  But you might walk through it to find better sands elsewhere.  But you would prefer to walk to the side of the beach that is sandy with a fresh air breeze.  Your yard is the beach to the pests.  You are just trying to make it less desirable.

9:38 MinsThe official genuine Lenovo part (P/N 0A65623), does exactly what it is designed to do, add a second SATA drive bay a Thinkpad with a 12.7mm slot, such as for a W520.  It seems as well constructed as I would expect.  You just lift the lever, flip the flap back, slide your drive in (with rubber rails), flip the flab down, lower the lever, remove existing optical drive, and pop this in its place.  It fits fairly tight, more than the optical drive due to rubber padding on the bottom.  I show the whole process in the video.  The BIOS will see it as an HD bay, and is likely by default after your existing drive in boot sequence order.  You can change the order and boot directly to this bay too.  More details are in the video.However, it does require the rubber drive rails, the same as any Thinkpad internal drive bay would, as it is just another bay to mimic the internal bay.  Rubber rails space it just right, and appear to offer both a vibration buffer and are a non-slip pressure point that the lever locks down to help hold it in place.  You can probably use it without rubber rails, but it really expects them.  Just remember it is no different than if you bought any hard drive to use in the existing built in drive bay which requires them.  However, it does not come with any rubber rails.  This is rather annoying because almost anyone buying a drive bay is buying a drive, and if bought anywhere other than from Lenovo they are not going to come with them.  I really think they should have thrown in the rails in the package.  You supposedly can order them from Lenovo as parts, but I had difficulty figuring out which part I really needed.  Your best bet is to hopefully have an old Thinkpad laying around with an old drive that you could take the rails from.
