I contacted my IT department at work, and they had some extra drive rails from old Thinkpads or bad drives.  They haven't changed in years for standard sized drives.  I used some old ones on my new SSD.I almost want to rate this 4-star because of the missing rails.  However, it really just emulates an internal drive bay, which doesn't come with them either, but probably on a drive that was pre-installed, so I relent.  Had there just been a second internal bay, it wouldn't have had the rails either.  It certainly isn't friendly to not include the cheap rubber.

7:40 MinsIt delivered as promised.  It was easy to affix to the wall and held very well.  I was surprised by how strongly it really held.  It takes 1 hour to set before you can use it, so be aware in case you were thinking of just sticking and using immediately.  Removal was easy (as shown in the end of the video), but took slightly more effort than I expected.  Get a good grip before you start pulling because it will take some small effort.  Also hold the clip itself from snapping like a rubber band once it releases, but do not hold it firm against the wall.  This might not be advised if you have arthritis.  It didn't leave any residue or damage behind on my wall.You must pull straight in the direction of the tab, not towards you or it risks breaking.  So take care when you place it to make sure you orient the tab in the right direction and position with enough room to pull 6 inches straight.  This might mean you cannot position it exactly in the middle between the socket and baseboard, or in a corner, so measure.  Figure out the orientation first before affixing the strip so that you put the tab on the correct side, and watch for accidentally flipping the direction comparing the clip face down vs affixing the strip when flipped over.  It is only large enough for one or two normal cables, not a bunch per clip, and is quite firm which makes it a little more difficult to fit the largest cable in.  The adhesive effectiveness might vary by material (based on some other reviews) but held very well for me.  Once you remove, you only have 1 extra strip to reuse one clip one time.This is so much better than taping cables up under a desk which leaves residue and falls down eventually.  This would be great for college dorms where you cannot leave tape on the wall.  But only time will tell if it will remove damage free after years in place.  I am still worried if it will really not fall victim to deterioration that other tapes get after years and heat through the seasons that affects other kinds of tape.  But in shorter periods, so far it has held up to its claims.

The drive alone is great.  For fresh new installs or as a secondary drive it works great.  It is easy to install, format, and it just works.  The speed improved boot time from 56s on HDD to 22s on this SSD, and after logon to being usable from 91s to 9s.  The drive has been reliable for me so far, visibly fast, and is being used daily on my work laptop with some heavy usage.  Applications open noticeably faster than my peers, but large applications are not exactly instant, but much improved.  I have used the drive heavily on an engineering laptop for a few months now and am very happy.  As a new fresh install, I give it very good marks, I'd say a 4/5.  I own 3 SSDs now, an Intel 510 Series 120GB SSD, a Kingston V200 128GB SSD, and this SanDisk Extreme 120GB SSD.  Performance-wise, this drive falls in the middle, but closer to the Intel than the Kensington.  Based on Windows Experience Index, the Intel rated 7.8, this SanDisk 7.6, and the Kensingon 7.1.INSTALLATIONAs a secondary drive, they give you no instructions, but you just pop it into any open SATA drive bay (or cable in PC), then in Windows 7 go to Control Panel > System & Security > Administrative Tools > Create and format hard disk partitions.  It should immediately recognize the new drive and offer to do something, say yes, select the drive, format, use defaults, and you can choose a different volume name like "SSD" if you want to.  You can always come back there to change the drive letter.  You can easily change the name later from Windows Explorer by accessing properties.PRIMARY DISK MIGRATIONBut for anyone looking to upgrading from an existing hard drive, and if it isn't convenient for you to reinstall everything, then you will not find any help built in here.  But it can work great, with some help.  My work laptop would take weeks to fully reload and reconfigure, which I cannot afford, so migration is by far a necessary way to go, and ideally should be fast and trivial (and believe me it can be).  But the upgrade experience packaged in this box is significantly lacking.  They leave you to your own devices to figure out how to migrate over from your existing HDD.  But you can buy an easy solution to help you easily migrate, as I did in two hours.  I find this lacking because the first bullet point on the front of the box is "Upgrade your PC...", but they really leave you hanging, as they give you no software, guidance, or cables.  Meanwhile competing brands do, such as Intel (Intel 510 Series 120 GB) provides free download software to migrate easily, and Crucial has a Youtube video showing migration using Apricorn EZ Upgrade (USB cable and software).  The instructions that come with this are useless, which just tell you to refer to your manufacturer manual.  SanDisk's own site doesn't offer any additional guidance, where they could have filled the gap.  So what to do?  I highly recommend buying Apricorn Hard Drive Upgrade Kit ASW-USB-25 (USB 2.0 cable & software), Apricorn ASW-USB3-25 (USB 3.0 cable & software), or Apricorn Hard Drive Upgrade Kit EZ-UP-UNIVERSAL (2.5" bay & software).  I bought the Apricorn ASW-USB-25 and successfully migrated in about 2 hours.  But before this, it was a mess.  I encourage you to search the web for "migrate hard drive to SSD" and you will find a number of articles and freeware offering guidance, all fairly complicated and different.  I liked the SSD Freaks and lifehacker articles best.  I tried and ultimately failed to migrate a working Windows 7 partition following these.  So if you just buy this with the Apricorn upgrade kit (if you need to upgrade), then the experience is pretty good, mostly attributed to the Apricorn solution.  For claims for upgrade and in retail packaging, it really is incomplete.  Compared to Intel's retail box, I think they should have labelled this OEM as this is nothing but the drive.HARDWARESo the drive itself is nice, no dud.  It has a 4-star drive, and a 1 or 2-star upgrade migration experience (considering its claims, competitors, and retail packaging) which only matters if you are going to migrate.  So I am averaging to 3-star.  I believe competitors have better upgrade experiences, but SanDisk prices seem significantly lower, and you can buy an upgrade kit and still save a lot.  Buy it for the price, buy a better upgrade solution if you need one and save yourself wasting time like I did or look elsewhere.  Btw, I also own an Intel 510 Series 120 GB that is great.

9:59 MinsIt is a great looking shaver, shaves very well for me (better than my Philips Norelco XL), trimmer works excellent for me, is easier to clean monthly, and has great charge level status lights.  But it is a little noisier, daily cleaning takes a little more work, and the bag is just okay.  Overall, I am very happy with it and am going to immediately stop using my Norelco XL and use this from now on.It is noticeably louder than I had expected (as seen in the video), but isn't too loud compared to some really cheap ones I've had in the past.  I really wish it were a bit more quiet, but is ignorable enough to only be a small negative in my mind.  But in shaving performance, it works really well for me.  In both shaving and trimming.  It is noticeably better for both than my Philips Norelco XL.  It also is a very comfortable feel in my hand.  I really like the battery status lights shows the level clearly.  They are nicely hidden under the shiny surface.  The daily cleaning is a little more work to pop off the head, shake and brush out, compared to flip open, dump, and rinse from my rotary.  But the monthly cleaning is much easier, still some work, but nowhere near the complicated work described for my rotary.  Of course a more expensive shaver with a cleaning system would be nice.  But this seems doable.Whether a rotary or foil shaver works best for you will vary.  I have found no rotary shaver can really pick up my hair without using a lot of force.  Foil shavers are just a different design and work better for me.  Now this foil shaver has a good foil design with various shaped holes that for me really do catch hair pretty well, better than my rotary XL.  It still doesn't mean only one pass, but it generally takes less pressure and work than my rotary.  It is better around my neck, chin line, and lip than my rotary, but still takes some time on my neck.  One thing to remember is that you still need to use circular motion with this foil shaver.  If you are shaving only in straight motions, it will not grab some stubborn hair.Replacement Parts: Remington SPF-73 Screen and Blades

9:57 MinsI have mixed feeling about 2 flaws, but overall there is a lot to like.  It has some unique aspects specifically for CFLs, the slider feels great, can adjust dimming, it has an easily interchangeable plate, button, and slider for white, ivory, and almond, & great instructions.  Only the button and minimum dim level give me some pause.  You can dim 600W incandescent or 150W CFL or LED, but less if you need 2 (500W) or 3 (400W) of these next to each other in the same box (which is standard for dimmers).  But you have to remember to toggle a switch beneath the plate between CFL or LED/INC depending on which you have.  It is easy enough to get to, but is something that wasn't clear by the instructions that you should just pop off the plate to access.PROS - Has a CFL mode (via toggle switch) that helps CFLs turn on better. - Slider feels great - Interchangeable plate, slider, and button in white, ivory, & almond. - Great instructions, good for a non-electrician, better than most I have seen.CONS - The button doesn't feel as solid as I would have preferred (probably due to interchangeable button cover) but seems fine. - The minimum dim level adjustment is a little complicated but you can figure it out.  I had to re-read the section several times, but it makes sense once you follow it.  I would have preferred a simple adjustment wheel.VERY MINOR - CFL versus LED/Incandescent toggle switch is under the cover and wasn't clear that you should just remove the cover to get to it. - Instructions font size is a little small (still better than some) but I did strain my eyes reading both sides end to end.  I would have preferred larger fonts or a link to larger instructions to print myself if they didn't want to print the paper.FYINote that some dimming ability still depends on your CFL bulbs.  If they aren't all the same brand or actually more limited in actual dimming ability than they advertize, it can affect how much range you really get, or whether all the bulbs turn on at the same level.  So you have to pick the lowest common denominator when all turn on adequately.  The CFL ability of this should help a little.  If you change bulbs or brands, you might have to revisit the minimum level setting again to fit the new bulbs best.

7:44 MinsThese are great to solve a problem that everyone has, fitting large AC adapters into power strips, and hugging a wall outlet.  I think these are nicer than the alternatives I've seen at the local stores.  They are a nice length that isn't too short to give you some room to work with, but not too long to become its own problem.  The combo bag is nice to get a sampling of the 3 styles from this brand.  But for real power strip organization, you might eventually want 5 of the same style.The 3 styles are suit unique purposes, two of which work well, and one seems to not function as well as I expected: (1.) Just an extension that has a small plug to put a buffer between your strip and the large plug.  The length is perfect to stand straight up in a U shape to connect to your AC adapter laying face up (like in the pictures).  It works best to simply liberate power strips, but only if you have the room to lay out AC adapters. I was surprised that I preferred this one over the rounded connector. (2.) A rounded plug that is both an extension and lets you stack more on top of it.  The wire extends to the side and at an angle so it can act more compact than #1 because it does not stand up.  However I had 2 problems with this one.  (A) It couldn't fit next to another in a compact power strip because the angled wire to the side was in the way (shown in the video).  (B) I couldn't actually use the stacking ability to plug anything into the top of the rounded plug (shown in the video).  It seems to be hitting something and I couldn't stack them. (3.) A wall outlet huger that lays flat against the outlet.  This is really great if you want to push something right up against the wall or don't want to see plug with a wire as prominently sticking out.  These aren't really a power strip liberator, and are more for a flat connection.  But you can use them too in a power strip, but they have a slightly larger head for a compact power strip.  I really like these, but for the right purpose, like behind a dresser, or TV entertainment center without room by the wall.The cables are 16 gauge (16 AWG) and rated for 13A, 1625W.  For 16 gauge is standard for extension cables.  Only more expensive cables for yard equipment and air conditioners offer 14 gauge.  Most power strips are 14 gauge for their own wire.  I wish these were 14 gauge, but realistically 16 gauges is normally the highest of most equipment you will be using these with.  I would not recommend pushing 1500W through a 16 gauge cable personally.  You home wiring is usually 14 gauge for a 15A circuit, or sometimes 12 gauge for higher amp circuits.  So 16 gauge for one device is standard.  But do watch out for space heaters, air conditioners, some coffee makers, or other things that draw high current that really should have a more expensive 14 gauge or 12 gauge extension.  But for liberating most things you plug into a power strip, 16 gauge should be fine.

6:51 MinsIt looks so much nicer than all the black covers out there.  Its functionality is great, does not have the imperfections or design issues of some cheaper alternatives, looks great, and makes reading the kindle easier in some ways.  It really does look nice.  It doesn't smell in the least bit (unlike reports for some other covers).  The charging and headphone ports are still accessible when closed.  There are virtually no flaws with it, except one that is a pro and a con.  My wife loves this cover.It has nice muted maroon color, nice brown leather binding, textured cover, stitching, and gold paint trim on the front and binding that is antiqued a bit with imperfections that are a nice touch.  The inside has a material that seems nice too that isn't just plastic.  Its weight is well balanced.  It isn't feather light, but isn't too heavy either.  The cover folds back easily, which offers 2 additional advantages.  If your hand cramps up holding the kindle alone because of how thin it is, with the cover folded back it adds some thickness that really helps make it more comfortable.  Also, it gives you a little bit of a shelf to slip your finger under or rest on something that makes it more comfortable to hold.It has a pocket that runs the whole length, unlike some corner pockets of some other covers that have a design flaw.  Other corner pockets can curl slightly at the corner in the middle of the cover, even if not putting anything into it, and come into contact with the screen, causing it to do things, like order books without your knowledge.  This one does *not* have that design flaw.  But if you cram stuff in there, you could still cause a problem, so I advise against using the pocket.The only possible drawback, however slight, is that the cover isn't held closed, which is a pro and a con.  In normal use, it isn't a problem at all.  But it could open on its own if loose in a bag, enough to let something slip between.  I still much prefer this over the alternatives.  I really don't want a snap curling around and being in the way, or making me press to snap closed which transfers force to the screen behind the snap.  You can just slip a rubber band or ribbon around for the times when it could be a concern.  I really prefer it this way.

8:41 MinsThis drive is whisper quiet, blazing fast, and has worked flawlessly.  Being SATA III (6G/s) I never feel like disk access is a bottleneck anymore.  Being SSD, it boots and loads applications and files with blazing speed.  The Windows 7 64-bit OEM install disc had no problem detecting and formatting the drive and installing Windows 7 to it in such a short time it didn't seem possible.  Windows 7 initially booted in about 3 seconds, before it could finish drawing the logo.  But once you install internet security software, boot time slowed to 13 seconds.  But I no longer put my computer to sleep, I just shut it off because it boots so fast.  I really love how IE, FireFox, MS Word, and Excel just immediately open without a lag.  Some programs still take a few seconds like TurboTax, but much less time than my old computer.  I have to say, this really delivered.PERFORMANCEI own 3 SSDs now, this Intel drive, a SanDisk Extreme 120GB SSD, and a Kingston V200 128GB SSD.  Of the 3, this is the clear stand out winner, but the SanDisk comes close and is much cheaper.  Based on Windows Experience Index, this Intel drive rates 7.8, the SanDisk 7.6, and Kensington 7.1.  I still think the Intel is the golden standard and worth the extra cost for your primary computer, and is more of a complete package.PRIMARY DRIVEMake this your primary drive with the operating system, application installations, and document files.  120GB should be be plenty for that.  But for photos, videos, and music, I recommend getting a secondary HDD, like the Seagate ST2000DM001 Barracuda 7200RPM 2TB SATA 6G/s, which has been blazing fast for me to store and edit all my video from my HD camcorder.  Use a large HDD for large files that are very optimal for large files stored as contiguous blocks that can be read easily in sequence.RETAIL BOXThe retail box for this drive comes with a SATA cable, molex power adapter for if you don't have a SATA power available from your power supply, and a mounting kit for a 3.5" bay if you don't have a 2.5" bay found on some newer cases like the Cooler Master Storm Enforcer Case.  Any SATA cable will do for SATA 6G (they really don't differ) but you should just use the one it comes with.  Do plug it into SATA III (6G/s) port, which is the point of the 510 series over the 320 Series.  It fit great with my Intel DZ68BC motherboard SATA 6G ports.SOFTWAREIt came with software, but instead go to the Intel support site and download the latest version of the tool box.  The software can detect for firmware upgrades, but only for firmware released as of the release date of that software.  It doesn't actually check the web for future versions of the firmware after the software version release, or detect software updates.  It is very easy to find and install.  Then you will need to run the optimizer once a week, either manually at the click of a button, or you can setup a schedule to run automatically.  Supposedly it improves the performance and should be run weekly.  Windows 7 already knows not to defrag the drive.  But if you use other freeware defrag tools, you should double check and make sure it doesn't try to defrag the drive because it will shorten the life span.SUMMARYI am sold on SSD after this drive, and it looks like Intel is the king of the best SSD out there with the 510 series at the moment.

7:08 MinsIt really depends on many factors, so experiences will vary.  I think you will likely find varying degrees of success, not complete eradication.  If you have multiple pests, then you will probably deter some of them, in which you find 2-4 star reviews.  Or if you have one pest, whether or not it works on that one determines 1 or 5 star reviews.  I am happy with the products attempt to deter and isn't a gimmick, but the value will depend on your level of success.  Based on many reviews, clearly success varies.  At least this 5-lb shaker seems to last longer than the smaller cans at the local store.So it is really just a big can of pepper, mostly black pepper and cayenne pepper which are two of the 3 active ingredients.  Peppers smell and taste unpleasant to animals.  Whether this blend and processing are the perfect solution and cost effectiveness versus wholesale black and cayenne pepper depends.  It isn't a fence or barrier, just a deterrent to make it more unpleasant than the next alternative location for the animal which will hopefully move on and do its business elsewhere.  But you will be fighting against (1) habits that might take time to break, (2) areas previously marked by animals or other droppings that are more attractive that offset or overpower this, (3) if yours is still the least unpleasant alternative to limited or worse options, (4) the animal's sensitivity to taste and smell of this deterrent, and (5) how fast it gets washed away and perform at reduced levels.  You could have an old dog that has lost much of its sense of smell and has been using your lawn for ages and has marked the area that probably would be less deterred to change.  Or a cat's habit and previous droppings might overpower this product.This is similar to you going to the beach.  Suppose rocks litter one side of the beach along with a dead fish that washed up on shore and smells a little.  It doesn't stop you from walking through there, it is just unpleasant to setup your towel or walk around over there.  But you might walk through it to find better sands elsewhere.  But you would prefer to walk to the side of the beach that is sandy with a fresh air breeze.  Your yard is the beach to the pests.  You are just trying to make it less desirable.

It is true that their canned dog food would be one of the better ones on the market if it contained the ingredients listed. This company would also get much credit for sourcing and manufacturing their food in the US. At first we thought we had done a good thing switching to Evangers for our little 8 lb Shorkie.However, not long after switching she started to have vomiting and seizures, even bleeding from the nose. So we did a quick Internet search on the food and found some very, very bad news.Aside from the customer reports of mold and rusty cans, we found this:Letters warning Evangers were sent by the FDA and are publicly available (read letters yourself online) about how they failed inspections by not having the ingredients listed on their cans, but something else in their food.----------------------------------"From December 2, 2010 through February 10, 2011, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) conducted an inspection of your low-acid canned food manufacturing facility located at 221 Wheeling Road, Wheeling, Illinois. In addition, on August 19, 2010, FDA received samples of (b)(4) Lamb and Rice Dog Food from the distributor, (b)(4). This letter notifies you of the violations of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act) that we found during our inspection and from the samples we received from the distributor. You can find the FD&C Act and its associated regulations on the Internet through links on FDAs web page at www.fda.gov1.""We found that you offered for sale (b)(4) Lamb and Rice Dog Food which was adulterated. Under Section 402(b)(2) of the FD&C Act, 21 U.S.C.  342(b)(2), a food is deemed to be adulterated if any substance has been substituted wholly or in part therefore. Our analytical sample results of this product revealed that a substance (lamb) was not detected in the product [...]"On December 14, 2010, FDA collected samples of your Evangers Grain-free Duck Pet Food during the inspection of your facility. We found that the Evangers Grain-free Duck Pet Food product was adulterated."-----------------------------------------Worse even than that was the fact that in 2009 the FDA had to order a SHUTDOWN of their production:"The U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced today it was suspending Evanger's Dog & Cat Food Co.'s emergency permit to ship pet food because the company's procedures could allow the bacterium that causes botulism to survive in some of its products.The FDA is stopping Evanger's ability to ship pet food in interstate commerce, said Dr. Bernadette Dunham."[Check that one out on Consumer Affairs web site]---------------------------------------------------------If all of THAT weren't bad enough, Evangers instituted a silent recall of their own food from their distributors because of the small, sharp pieces of metal found in their canned food:"Along with the peas, carrots, rice, and chicken, Ms.E**** found sharp metal tags floating in amongst the meat and veg When Ms. E**** asked what the tags were and what in the BLEEP they were they doing in her dog food, they assured her, that a similar incident happened a couple of years ago and were surprised to hear that there were still cans of it floating around.When Ms. E**** inquired about the extra ingredient, Evangers told her that the tags are used in the poultry industry as a means of identification and should have been removed from the chickens wings before they got used in pet food."---------------------------------------------------Well, now. If that were not bad enough, there's MORE. Are you ready for this?From Chicago News Center:"Prosecutors charged a Lincolnwood couple today [The owners of Evangers] with illegally diverting nearly $2 million in utilities to their dog and cat food company through an elaborate scheme where [Evangers] workers performed highly dangerous maneuvers.An employee was given a pair of rubber gloves and told to go up in a forklift to disconnect an illegal bypass attached to a high-voltage line shortly before ComEd inspectors arrived.Another time, prosecutors say, the worker was ordered to use a jackhammer to tear up concrete and asphalt so gas could be diverted to the plant in Wheeling. The smell of gas fumes wasnt unusual at Evangers Dog & Cat Food Co.The brazen nature of these thefts is exceeded only by the dangerous conditions that these individuals were willing to expose their employees to, said Cook County States Attorney Anita Alvarez.Joel Sher, 54, and his wife, Holly, 52, were arrested Tuesday [the owners of Evangers]. Each was charged with felony theft and money laundering in the scheme, which allegedly had gone on for several years. The company and couple once were featured on the Rachael Ray food show.Investigators seized $2.3 million from a Chicago bank account belonging to the Shers, as part of an ongoing money-laundering investigation related to the alleged diversion of gas and electricity, according to the states attorneys office."------------------------------------------------Tell you what, people, we are DONE with Evangers.

It is true that their canned dog food would be one of the better ones on the market if it contained the ingredients listed. This company would also get much credit for sourcing and manufacturing their food in the US. The smell of gas fumes wasnt unusual at Evangers Dog & Cat Food Co.The brazen nature of these thefts is exceeded only by the dangerous conditions that these individuals were willing to expose their employees to, said Cook County States Attorney Anita Alvarez.Joel Sher, 54, and his wife, Holly, 52, were arrested Tuesday [the owners of Evangers]. Each was charged with felony theft and money laundering in the scheme, which allegedly had gone on for several years. The company and couple once were featured on the Rachael Ray food show.Investigators seized $2.3 million from a Chicago bank account belonging to the Shers, as part of an ongoing money-laundering investigation related to the alleged diversion of gas and electricity, according to the states attorneys office."------------------------------------------------Tell you what, people, we are DONE with Evangers.

It is true that their canned dog food would be one of the better ones on the market if it contained the ingredients listed.  This company would also get much credit for sourcing and manufacturing their food in the US.  At first we thought we had done a good thing switching to Evangers for our little 8 lb Shorkie.However, not long after switching she started to have vomiting and seizures, even bleeding from the nose.  So we did a quick Internet search on the food and found some very, very bad news.Aside from the customer reports of mold and rusty cans, we found this:Letters warning Evangers were sent by the FDA and are publicly available (read letters yourself online) about how they failed inspections by not having the ingredients listed on their cans, but something else in their food.----------------------------------"From December 2, 2010 through February 10, 2011, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) conducted an inspection of your low-acid canned food manufacturing facility located at 221 Wheeling Road, Wheeling, Illinois. In addition, on August 19, 2010, FDA received samples of (b)(4) Lamb and Rice Dog Food from the distributor, (b)(4). This letter notifies you of the violations of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act) that we found during our inspection and from the samples we received from the distributor. You can find the FD&C Act and its associated regulations on the Internet through links on FDAs web page at www.fda.gov1.""We found that you offered for sale (b)(4) Lamb and Rice Dog Food which was adulterated. Under Section 402(b)(2) of the FD&C Act, 21 U.S.C.  342(b)(2), a food is deemed to be adulterated if any substance has been substituted wholly or in part therefore.  Our analytical sample results of this product revealed that a substance (lamb) was not detected in the product [...]"On December 14, 2010, FDA collected samples of your Evangers Grain-free Duck Pet Food during the inspection of your facility. We found that the Evangers Grain-free Duck Pet Food product was adulterated."-----------------------------------------Worse even than that was the fact that in 2009 the FDA had to order a SHUTDOWN of their production:"The U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced today it was suspending Evanger's Dog & Cat Food Co.'s emergency permit to ship pet food because the company's procedures could allow the bacterium that causes botulism to survive in some of its products.The FDA is stopping Evanger's ability to ship pet food in interstate commerce, said Dr. Bernadette Dunham."[Check that one out on Consumer Affairs web site]---------------------------------------------------------If all of THAT weren't bad enough, Evangers instituted a silent recall of their own food from their distributors because of the small, sharp pieces of metal found in their canned food:"Along with the peas, carrots, rice, and chicken, Ms.E**** found sharp metal tags floating in amongst the meat and veg When Ms. E**** asked what the tags were and what in the BLEEP they were they doing in her dog food, they assured her, that a similar incident happened a couple of years ago and were surprised to hear that there were still cans of it floating around.When Ms. E**** inquired about the extra ingredient, Evangers told her that the tags are used in the poultry industry as a means of identification and should have been removed from the chickens wings before they got used in pet food."---------------------------------------------------Well, now.  If that were not bad enough, there's MORE.  Are you ready for this?From Chicago News Center:"Prosecutors charged a Lincolnwood couple today [The owners of Evangers] with illegally diverting nearly $2 million in utilities to their dog and cat food company through an elaborate scheme where [Evangers] workers performed highly dangerous maneuvers.An employee was given a pair of rubber gloves and told to go up in a forklift to disconnect an illegal bypass attached to a high-voltage line shortly before ComEd inspectors arrived.Another time, prosecutors say, the worker was ordered to use a jackhammer to tear up concrete and asphalt so gas could be diverted to the plant in Wheeling. The smell of gas fumes wasnt unusual at Evangers Dog & Cat Food Co.The brazen nature of these thefts is exceeded only by the dangerous conditions that these individuals were willing to expose their employees to, said Cook County States Attorney Anita Alvarez.Joel Sher, 54, and his wife, Holly, 52, were arrested Tuesday [the owners of Evangers]. Each was charged with felony theft and money laundering in the scheme, which allegedly had gone on for several years. The company and couple once were featured on the Rachael Ray food show.Investigators seized $2.3 million from a Chicago bank account belonging to the Shers, as part of an ongoing money-laundering investigation related to the alleged diversion of gas and electricity, according to the states attorneys office."------------------------------------------------Tell you what, people, we are DONE with Evangers.

The problems with 3G/4G network connectivity are well-documented for this device.  We are only a few months out of warranty and Amazon will not support their device.First Amazon told us to get a new SIM card from Verizon, which we did.  It did not fix the problem.  When we called for help again, the supervisor at Amazon told us that they had never heard of anyone else with this problem before.  (What utter b******* !)  This problem is known all over the Internet.  The second supervisor we spoke to did seem to recognize the problem, but since we are out of warranty they have no solution or assistance for us.And they do not repair their own devices, so even if we wanted to pay for a repair it is not available through the very company selling the devices.Go figure.

This is the best tasting oat bran cereal we have found, bar none.  And we've tried A LOT of them.The instructions on the box are wrong.  It says microwave 1-2 mins.  That is patently wrong, unless you like undercooked, crunchy hot cereal.  Also, the amount of liquid seems too much to us, but that is dependent on how firm you like your cereal.  We use about 1 and 3/4 cups of water to a slightly rounded half cup of cereal.  We cook it for more like 6-7 minutes on high (stir before cooking and once after 5 minutes).The consistency then is rich and smooth and moderately firm.We add raisins, cinnamon and walnuts and a touch of brown sugar and either milk or vanilla coconut milk.Very good tasting cereal.

Excellent gloves.  I wanted some gloves that were thicker and with a longer cuff than the ones you find at regular stores like Home Depot or Target.  These gloves are a thicker mil and they hold up to a lot of harsh chemicals with no breakage.There is no comparison to the cheap, thin gloves with short cuffs.  The longer cuffs of these gloves will help prevent liquid from coming in.  The cheap ones break all the time, as well.They do cost more, but are well worth it to protect your skin and hands.I got these medium sized gloves since the smalls were just a bit too tight for my hands.  I am a female with medium sized hands and the mediums fit me better.  My hand measures just shy of 7 inches long from the base of the palm to the tip of the longest finger (like 6 and 7/8ths inches). and 3 and 1/8th inches across the palm.  Fingers about 3/4 inch thick at the base of the forefinger.

Excellent gloves.  I wanted some gloves that were thicker and with a longer cuff than the ones you find at regular stores like Home Depot or Target.  These gloves are a thicker mil and they hold up to a lot of harsh chemicals with no breakage.There is no comparison to the cheap, thin gloves with short cuffs.  The longer cuffs of these gloves will help prevent liquid from coming in.  The cheap ones break all the time, as well.They do cost more, but are well worth it to protect your skin and hands.The small are just a bit too tight for my hands.  I am a female with medium sized hands and the mediums fit me better.  My hand measures just shy of 7 inches long from the base of the palm to the tip of the longest finger (like 6 and 7/8ths inches). and 3 and 1/8th inches across the palm.  Fingers about 3/4 inch thick at the base of the forefinger.

It is very sturdy and will last a long time.That said, the grating itself is not at all what we prefer.  The largest/coarse grater makes oddly shaped, stubby shreds.  When we grate carrots, the pieces are short and stubby, not long and thin the way other graters work.The opposite side is ok - more of a fine shredder.  The narrow side is for things like hard cheeses but is too fine for parmesan cheese or most things we want on a fine grate.  It takes an eternity to grate on that side, and the results are disappointing.We are dispensing with this grater.

It has not harmed our fabric couch and presumably disinfected it well.  We are glad to find something that was safe for the upholstery, but it most certainly does not have a scent that in any way resembles eucalyptus.The smell is more like baby powder or something similar.  Not bad but we don't really like scented things much anyway.  Would have preferred a genuine eucalyptus smell, but this one is at least not offensive.

It is nice that it has no scent and is biodegradable/non toxic.But the bottom line is - it does not work as a degreaser.  AT ALL.  We tried in in several applications.  At one point we gave up and tried glass cleaner on a greasy spot in the kitchen, and that worked much better than this.  This product seems about as effective as plain water on grease.

It is nice that it has no scent and is biodegradable/non toxic.But the bottom line is - it does not work as a degreaser.  AT ALL.  We tried in in several applications.  At one point we gave up and tried glass cleaner on a greasy spot in the kitchen, and that worked much better than this.  This product seems about as effective as plain water on grease.

I have a half a dozen ice cream/gelato books, and I will not be using this one.I have an issue with the ingredients.  They call for flour and corn syrup and corn starch, evaporated milk, among other odd additives.  I been making ice cream/gelato for a while, and scoured my books and recipes online and have NEVER seen wacky stuff like flour in ice cream.  WT****?!!!I have, however, seen corn syrup added, and avoid books that use it.I am sorry - I will NEVER put flour and corn syrup in my ice cream.  No how, no way.

Thankfully, someone has finally said what we really needed to hear.  We are going through the final stages of life with a family member.If only the rest of the medical profession would begin to comprehend what this amazing person has shared with us all.

We really liked this summer bedspread.  It was the right weight and seemed well-made.  However, after washing it, we discovered it shrank a quite a bit - mostly in the width, and somewhat in the length.It no longer fits the bed, sad to say.It also faded in color quite a bit, even on the first washing.  We really liked this item before washing it.  Since it lost so much color on the first wash (navy), it probably would continue to lose more with repeated washings.  We are returning it anyway, since it shrunk to no longer fit our Eastern King bed.

It works fine for autos, but we originally got it for another reason. We tried everything under the sun to get rid of soap scum on our glass shower doors and tile walls.  We finally found a very easy solution.While at Costco we saw a vendor selling a package of EZ Detailer all in one Carnauba Wax.  He described all the things it could do besides the obvious (car wax) and one thing he said was that it would remove soap scum from glass and tile showers.  We looked at him like he had lost his mind.  He insisted it would work:  just leave it on for 10 mins and scrub it off.Well, we relented and bought it and tried it at home.  Yes, it did indeed work - the scum came off pretty easily.  Glass and tile completely clear and rid of the soap scum that had plagued us for years.

It is hard to rate this since it has varied so much over the years.  At first it was the best tasting almond butter we'd ever tried.  I mean, like phenomenally delicious.Then it started tasting bitter.  We called the company and found they were forced to use Italian almonds during the California drought (I think that is what wrecked the crops that year).  We are not sure if they are still sourcing their almonds for the organic butters from Italy, but we stopped buying it because of that.If they ever go back to CA organic almonds, we will buy it again in a heartbeat.

This is a fantastic set of garden shears.  We had bought a pair from a high-end local garden store and they were not very good, so we wanted to get some really good ones that would last.They are not too heavy, very sharp and well made.It actually was able to cut tree branches up to sizes between a quarter and half an inch thick just using the blades (we did not understand about the limb notch at the bottom of the blade at the time), but I don't think that it was very good for the blade so we aren't going to do that again.  :0)Although the picture shows green colored handles, we got burgundy, which was just as nice.

These seem well made and comfortable.  The sizing is a bit unexpected -- the small is actually pretty large for my hands (about 6 and 3/4 inches long from base of palm to tip of middle finger)I guess I should order extra small.  I would order the same gloves again, just in a different size.

Most of the oils we got from Now Foods are great.  Grapefruit is wonderful, pine oil is very nice, sweet orange is wonderful.  This one, however, is either rancid or contaminated.It does not seem possible to create such a foul smelling substance from something as nice as ginger.
This is one of the better oils this company makes.  Their lemon is also good.  We've gotten some oils from them that were disappointing, but this one was very good.

We bought the Fir Needle, Spruce and Pine from Edens Garden. They were fairly accurate in terms of their scent.  We have yet to find one that smells like  freshly broken needles from an evergreen, but still the smell does remind us of the tree itself.

We bought the Fir Needle, Spruce and Pine from Edens Garden. They were fairly accurate in terms of their scent.  We have yet to find one that smells like  freshly broken needles from an evergreen, but still the smell does remind us of the tree itself.  Now Foods makes a very nice pine essential oil, as well.

We bought the Fir Needle, Spruce and Pine from Edens Garden. They were fairly accurate in terms of their scent.  We have yet to find one that smells like  freshly broken needles from an evergreen, but still the smell does remind us of the tree itself.

We've been buying tons of essential oils from different vendors, and the ones from Now foods are some of the better ones we tried.  This one smells just like a real grapefruit, and is very, very nice.  Love it.

We've been buying oils from a variety of sellers, and Now Foods has consistently sent us oils that smell just like the item advertised and they are quite fresh.It is amazing how many of the oils from other vendors have odd, off-putting odors and how many don't smell that much like the thing they are claiming to be.This oil smells just like a real orange, and is very nice.

This brand of oil has some scents that are good, but we don't care for this one.  It smells like artificial limeaide - sort of like lime jello.It is not repulsive, but not really like real lime, either.

This is one of the better pine oils we've tried.  The ones from Edens Garden were ok, but not as fresh smelling as this one.  I would not mind if it were a bit more potent, but the aroma is quite nice and piney.

This is not an essential oil that smells very good - it smells somewhat like ginger, but has an off-odor that is unpleasant smelling.  I am not sure why it smells bad -- maybe not a pure batch.In general, I find the oils from Now Foods and Everyone EO  to be purer and fresher smelling that those from Edens Garden.

This is the nastiest smelling essential oil I have EVER smelled.  I have purchased oils from many companies and this by far the worst.  It does not smell much like peppermint, and, in fact, smells like a cross between hospital disinfectant and cow manure.  (Seriously.)  We can only conclude it has been contaminated in some way, because there is no way they are shipping this substance as is to anyone else and remaining in business.They indicate it is an insect repellent; well, it is a people repellent, too.  My guess is it would repel anything possessing the capacity for escape.
Super thin padding, the material that goes around the edge of the mattress is flimsy and way too large for our 10 -11 inch mattress.  Even at the low price we decided to send it back.

These are beautiful hoops that are a cut above regular plain hoops.  The workmanship is quite nice and the design is very attractive.  They are a medium size which is what we wanted.Recommended product.

High quality mattress cover that fits our bed.  Our mattress is not very deep so it was hard to find a more shallow one.  (Our mattress is about 10-11 inches deep).Very high quality item - durable and well made.
Excellent cd.  We love this artist and the music is relaxing and still interesting.  Great purchase for music lovers.

This case worked for us after trying the regular non-grip case.  The regular CandyShell  case  (that is, the non-grippy version) is almost as slippery as the phone (which is saying a lot -- the phone is so slippery we don't dare use it without a case).We sent the regular CandyShell case back to get the grippy one and are very happy with the new one.  It still comes out of the pocket fine and is a well-made, easy to hold case.  It is only slightly ribbed so it acts as a protector and is easy to grasp without being too obtrusive.  It is somewhat flexible, but not too thick so that the form factor is not increased by much.  It fits the phone (HTC one m8) exactly right - cutouts are perfect and the built-in volume buttons work great.If you have one of these slippery phones (a design flaw if there ever was one), this case is an excellent protection for your phone.

It seemed like a reasonable printer at first, then it started having issues with the software.  A whole variety of errors, finally resulting in our taking it back to the store for a refund when it was less than a year old.It seems to be common to have color printers these days refuse to print black and white if their color inks are seen as empty.  It is also common for these vendors to say the ink containers are empty when they are not.Amazingly, they also won't allow refills and reuse of the same cartridges successively.So the ink ends up costing far more than the printer did really quickly.  In spite of this, out of laziness or inertia, we were going to keep the thing in spite of its frequent paper jams, errors, and wasteful use of ink.  Then it failed completely.We had bought a Brother B&W laser printer that operated cheaply and flawlessly, so we decided to replace this one with a Brother MFC J5720DW.We have been very happy with the replacement printer.  Plus, it can do automatic duplex copying, scanning and printing.  (We don't have to flip pages over or anything.)It is a shame that HP has gone so far downhill.  Used to be a good company.

Excellent timer.  Finally, a timer I can turn the beep off!  I am in an office and loud beeping is not appreciated.  The timer can flash or vibrate.  It also has a neat feature in that when the timer has gone off it continues to count in the other direction to tell you how far you went past the set time.Also, it can count up or down and act as a clock when not actively timing something.I also love the memory function, since I can set minutes and seconds without having to redo the counter (especially with setting the seconds).We use it as a tea timer - and for our purposes, it blows all the others we tried away, including Teavana's, all of which broke within months of purchase.Very worthwhile purchase.

It is a very nice coat hook.  It is rounded and does not poke holes in sweaters as some do.  It is, not, however, very wide.  Most partitions now are about 3" wide, as mine is.  I had to stretch it apart to get it to fit, but it works and does not seem to be experiencing metal fatigue from the modification.It is working and I am glad to have a metal, sturdy hook for the office.

If I have to work all day on a dessert it is not easy.  If after working all day on a dessert from a cookbook I discover the recipe is a complete and total scr3w up -- disaster -- misprinted, mistaken, erroneous recipe, then I am REALLY ANGRY.  I wasted a ton of ingredients because NO ONE edited and reviewed the recipes in this book.Check out pg 32 - Tarte au citron.  Total botch job.  The amount of lemon juice is total guesswork because she says 5 lemons, but the amount of juice from lemons can vary greatly.  The amount of sugar is pretty normal, the amount of eggs is a bit lower than some recipes, but still within reason.  Then look at the amount of heavy cream she asks for.  1 cup plus 1/4 cup of sour cream.  REALLY?  Are you ****** kidding me?????!!!!  It made a bowl of lemon juice soup that was 200% of the amount of fluid needed to fill the tart pan.Compare to any other recipe for lemon tarts and you will see more like 3 tablespoons of cream!!!!!  Look at CooksIllustrated, for example.Throw this book away.  Otherwise, you can never be sure the recipe is not totally botched up.

Not very good at all.  We are experienced cooks and the recipes are at best mediocre and at worst, horrible.  As in, repulsive, like the Vegetables with Minty Lamb stuffing.  Followed the recipe EXACTLY - rice was not fully cooked after over an hour, and the flavor was indescribably bad.We gave it one star extra for very nice photography.(Gee - I wonder if we can get the author to refund the $$$$ we spent on the food we are throwing into the garbage....)

We had been trying to find a good dishwasher detergent.  We are sensitive to odors so we tried the Seventh Generation liquid, but it did not get the dishes clean and created a dark film buildup on glasses.Then we tried Cascade.  It did indeed get the dishes clean and removed all film, but it left a soapy smell on the glasses.Research online led us to try this one.SCORE!Not only are our dishes super clean, but NO SMELL!

Nothing small about this watch.  The face is massive and the wrist band is huge.  This looks like a man's watch, not a women's.The description says 'small' but this is misleading.  It costs about 20.00 to return it in that the shipping out and back is not refunded.Returning it anyway.

These are very nice pillow covers.  We purchased them in both sage and brown and have been very happy with them.  The sage on my computer is fairly close to the actual color (everyone's computer is different in this regard), and the actual color was slightly lighter and more of a sage green than greyish, but again this could be different on different computer screens.The brown was very close, also, to what we saw on the screen.  It is fairly dark.The feel of the material is very nice, smooth and soft.  Stitching seems sturdy, as well.

Unlike the Go Walk version 2's we bought, these are too small.  They do not run true to size and are shorter in length than the standard.  Neither set of shoes fit either of us, but the Go Walk version 2 pairs did.  The quality of this shoe seems a bit less than the version 2s, but they seem relatively well made for the price.  We probably would have kept them if they had fit.

We ordered these instead of the capsules one time and found that these tablets are unusable.  They are large and are rough -- as though coated with sandpaper.  They literally tore our throats trying to swallow them.  (Had a sore throat for some time after taking them.)Can't they put some sort of smooth coating on them?If you are pulverizing them you may be able to use them, but otherwise they are painful to swallow.The product does work if you can find a way to actually consume these things.

It has a nice cover and seems to be reasonably well-made.  The stuffing is not insubstantial, but is quite bouncy and not very firm.  If you are wanting a pillow that gives quite a bit then this may be just right for you.  We were hoping for something firmer, however.

Mrs Meyer's various soaps are very nice, but our favorite by far is the lavender.  We compared the scent to some more expensive brands like EOS, etc., and this one is just as nice or nicer.The soap is rather thick, so if your dispenser is made for a thinner soap just a bit of water will help.  It has a reasonable amount of cleaning power and removes grease pretty well, although probably would be insufficient for serious amounts of oil or grease.Recommended.

The leather is nice and fits the kindle quite well.  It turns the power on and off as it opens and closes.  We really had hoped it would stand up the way the picture shows, but the crease in the list that acts as a stand collapses and there is no way to get it to stand up on the table.
There are a number of other types of plastic toothpicks out there, but these are the originals and are still the best by far.

We have been enjoying the use of our new cameras.  One lets us see if we really did shut the garage doors and the other is pointed to our little dog who stays in the kitchen while we are gone.The clarity is excellent both day and night and the wide viewing angle is great.Customer service is also excellent when we call for answers to questions or concerns.The installation was ridiculously simple.  Pretty much the solution for anyone not wanting to work to install an internet-capable video surveillance system.
The pad is a great protector for our granite countertops.  It is easy to clean and seems quite durable.  It is not washable on the bottom side, but other than that it is perfect.

I have never been able to find tights that are actually opaque.  Many claim that they are, but they never are!  These tights, however, are actually opaque, which means I can get away with a somewhat inappropriate hemline at work.  They also have some control top in them, which is good (they could stand having a little more, but since they're so opaque, I can't complain too much).  I highly recommend these and will be buying them again--however, they show no signs of wear, so it will likely be a while before I have to buy another pair.

I found it after researching dry shampoos and their reviews for a couple of hours on Amazon, and this one has lived up to its reviews.  I didn't think it was possible for a dry shampoo to work on my fairly oily hair, but I am delighted to say that this product is awesome.  *I used to have to wash my hair every day, or else risk massive oiliness--no joke.*  Now if I oversleep for work or an airplane flight, I can use this product and my hair looks soft and shiny.  It doesn't look as thick as it would if I had washed and blowdried it, but at least it looks presentable.  I couldn't be happier.Some observations:1) You really do have to work it through all sections of your hair (for me I do this by spraying through sections around the crown of my head and my ears, AND doing the same by flipping my hair upside down and going section by section before brushing everything out).2) This bottle goes by fast!  I have only used it a dozen times and it's pretty much toast by now.  My hair is average length and thickness.  However, given how it has saved me about a dozen times with early morning meetings with clients and flights, I have happily purchased it again and I'm sure I'll continue to purchase it.(Review written by Woody's wife; Woody does not have to worry about washing, drying, and styling his locks.)

This book is beautifully illustrated, and so sweet--it's the story of the toys on a child's shelf, with each of the toys waiting for something.  For one it's the moon, for another it's the rain.  It reinforces vocabulary without being over the top.  It keeps my toddler's interest.  Best of all: there is no subtle (or not so subtle) pressure for bedtime.  I think it's the only book we own where the main character isn't going to sleep at the end of the book!  How refreshing.  I will be buying this book as gifts for other parents--that's how much I like it.

Why we bought the Ring:We live smack in the middle of a place where home invasions arent uncommon and wouldnt even make news.  As a matter of practice, we dont answer the door if were not expecting somebody.  But we also have lots of people ringing our doorbell: politicians who come by for meet-and-greets, our neighbors who want to pop in at unexpected times, and people peddling goods.  We decided that because we dont typically answer the door, we wanted to do two things: (1) see who is at the door without being obvious that were looking, and, depending on who is there, (2) let them know that were home whether we are or are not home (especially for the peddlerswe never know if theyre just in our neighborhood to see whos home).In theory, the Ring doorbell is supposed to do these two things: if somebody rings your doorbell, a pop-up alert sounds on your iphone, ipad, i-whatever, which allows you to see a real-time feed of who is there.  You can then have a conversation with the person through the microphone on the Ring.  The entire interchange is recorded through Rings optional cloud service (free for 30 days then $3/month thereafter or $30/year).  All of these features recently drove me to my local big box store to buy and install the Ring.Unfortunately, the Ring turned out to be much better in theory than in reality, so Ive had to return it.  Below, Ill lay out what I think is great about the Ring and then why I returned it.What is great about the Ring:(1) The concept is awesome.  For a geek like me living in a moderately-high crime area, I cant think of anything cooler than being able to see who is at my door, being able to talk to that person, and being able to record our interchange.(2) The Ring is also supposed to send you a pop-up alert when motion detection is triggered.  You can change the settings on your iphone or ipad or other devices to narrow this range and even to limit it to certain areas.  Picture a half-circle  this represents the Rings 180-degree visibility due to its fish-eye lens.  There are six zones in this half-circle: one smaller half-circle for the 5-foot area right in front of your door, and five more zones beyond that, extending out to 30 feet.  So, if you want to shut off the motion detection for the left area of your yard/street because thats a busy intersection, the Ring app allows you to do that.  Again, very smart and very cool in theory.(3) Ring has done a good job of making the sound clear through the two-way noise reduction  even when Ive been in my car, at work, or anywhere but home, it sounds remarkably clear and thus believable that Im actually home.  (This is according to my wife, who performed several tests of the Ring with me to see how it was working.)(4) You have two installation options.  You can install it without connecting it to your existing wiring, but if you go this route, you will only hear the app alert and not your doorbell.  However, Ring does have an add-on device called the Chime to solve this problem  for $30, the Chime plugs into a regular socket and makes a noise similar to what your doorbell would make.  Alternatively, you can do what we did and install it straight into your existing doorbell system.  Installation was a beastly, 3-hour task, but once finished, the Ring worked flawlessly with our existing doorbell system.  Not only does installing the Ring this way allow you to hear your actual doorbell plus the alert on your Ring app, but there is an added benefit of conneting the Ring to your existing wiring: the wires will deliver a small trickle charge to the Ring so that you dont have to take it down to recharge the battery through the provided USB cord (which Ring says has to happen about once a year, unless you live on a very busy street, in which case the battery will drain faster).(5) Intuitive, easy-to-use software.  Multiple people in your household can download the free Ring app for their own devices and thus get alerts when somebody is at the door.  The app is quite simple to use.  Also, in case you were wondering (I certainly was), the alert on your iphone or other device will sound if you have your volume on, but will vibrate if you have silent mode + vibrate on your phone, or will make no sound if you have silent mode without vibration on.  In other words, you will not have an embarassing moment during your work conference because your Ring app sounds.(6) Great customer service.  I availed myself of several of Rings how-to videos during the installation process, and I felt (and still feel) connected to the brand.  I believe in what theyre doing and I like their philosophies and promises (such as replacing the Ring if its ever stolen).Why we returned the Ring:(1) The motion detection did not work.  It simply did not work.  We tried multiple sensitivity settings (bringing it farther away, bringing it closer, restricting zones), but it never picked up any activity unless the person rang the doorbell.  On various occasions, I even stood one foot from the Ring for several minutes, waving my arms, dancing around  and nothing.  The importance of this cannot be overstated.  While its quite useful to see who is there once that person rings the doorbell, I also wanted what Ring promised: seeing who was there when the person did not ring the doorbell.  We have plenty of people who knock, and we have plenty of package-theft incidents.  These are the types of things I was hoping to be able to record with the Ring.  Its simply not worth it to be to have the Ring alert triggered only if somebody rings the doorbell; for $199 (actually, for about half that price), I could put up a decent camera and get a companion app for my phone.(2) Along these same lines, the Ring had some lag in recording when somebody did ring the doorbell.  So, when our friendly UPS man delivered a package recently, he rang the doorbell (as he always does), but then promply got back into his truck without waiting for a response (as he always does).  The video feed, however, shows nothing  not even his truck driving away.  Others have reported a similar lag time; Im hoping that this is something Ring will fix in the future.(3) The Ring does not allow you to see whats going on unless the Ring is triggered by motion or by the doorbell being rung (in our case, only by the doorbell being rung).  Given that the Ring has a pretty big camera connected to your iphone or other device, it seems odd that this feature is not available.  In perusing the internet about the Ring before I purchased it, I saw from several other peoples thoughts on the Ring that this was something people wanted.  Im hopeful that this will be available in future versions of or software updates to the Ring.(4) The picture quality is pretty grainy  720 pixels.  When we had a suspicious person come to our door during broad daylight and ring the doorbell, his face in the video was somewhat clear, but not enough that Id be sure it was him if I saw him in person.Additional cons/things to be aware of (but not deal-breakers):(1) Before you buy this, know that this product is huge!  Its about as wide as a cigarette box and a little bit taller.  Unless your existing doorbell is on a large slab of siding, there will be installation issues.  You can remedy this by buying or creating a small slab of wood that sits behind the Ring and on top of your siding or next to your siding (i.e., you would drill that small slab of wood into the siding so that you now have a bigger face plate to install the Ring on).  Or, you can do what we did and install the Ring with just two of the screws on (there are four screws  one in each corner).  Surprinsingly, the Ring was still quite secure this way, but its an issue you should be aware of.(2) The mollies that come with the Ring are smaller than the drill bit that is provided with the Ring  so, you will be creating gaping holes in your siding with mollies that arent the right size.  We ended up using our own mollies (which I highly recommend), but not without creating some serious holes in our siding.(3) The cloud feature is great, but several people out there have lamented that it should be able to be stored in ones own cloud storage (like your Box or DropBox account) rather than in Rings proprietary cloud.  I dont so much have a problem with the fact that the videos are stored in Rings cloud  rather, I would just like more transparency with what security measures they take for their cloud.  I wouldnt just want anyone to be able to hack in and see the house.  Also, given that you do have to pay $30 a year for the cloud service, youve now essentially identified your home address by linking up your credit card (billing address) with images of your house.  For people who are in the market for this kind of doorbell (i.e., security-conscious people), this might be a sticking point.  (The Ring does ask for your home address when you set up the app, but this is not required for the camera to work and was certainly not something I provided.)Overall, while the Ring has some great concepts, it didnt deliver for us.  Im so disappointed that it didnt work out for us  I had such high hopes.  In sum, I believe theres no reason that this product cant be awesome with some tweaking.  I think its just too early for the technology to be all there, so to speak, or there arent enough competitors to make this product as exceptional as I know it can be.  Down the road, I will definitely be keeping my eyes open for later-offered doorbell cameras by Ring.

I was looking for (1) pillow shams and (2) those oversized, square shams (24x24 or thereabouts) in plain white for a bedroom that's being redecorated.  Although I never could find the oversized, square shams, I finally found these pillow shams after many hours browsing and I am very happy with this purchase.Why I am very happy with this purchase:1) This is a very thick, very nice sham.  It has some texture to it--a quilted look, almost--which is nice because everything else I saw (and I trolled the Amazon site for hours looking for shams) was either faux velvet or faux suede.  There may have been a few that were just 100% cotton, but the reviews mentioned how thin they were.  So, this was the best I could find, and I'm very happy with it.  The room I'm using it in does not have any quilts in it, and is fairly modern, but this surprisingly fits in just great.2) My exhaustive Amazon search also led me to discover that it's nearly impossible to find plain white shams!  As mentioned above, what I found was generally either faux velvet or faux suede.  Those just wouldn't have fit into the overall decorating scheme of the room I bought these for.  So, if you're looking for something plain but with some interesting details (the quilting, as mentioned above, and the scalloped borders), I suspect these shams would work for you, too.3) Good price - $20 for two shams is a great deal, as far as what I could tell from comparison shopping.Something to note:1) They really mean it when they say this is a KING-sized sham.  These shams are very long and don't work with just a regular pillow in them.  I didn't take note of the king-size in the description, so I stuffed two regular pillows in there, and that is working pretty well (though a bit lumpy) until my new king-sized pillows arrive from Amazon.In sum, great product, especially given what else it out there.

We were very pleasantly surprised when this came in the mail. The material is so soft and it's not see-through at all, and has held up well after washings. For what appears to be a high quality shirt, the price is also pretty great. (I haven't been able to find many kids' t-shirts for this price.)  I also love that although there's a tiny logo, it's really tiny and is just a darker gray color instead of something "louder."There's only one flaw we can find: it's on the short side. The picture doesn't really show it, but it's a little bit boxy. All of our other 3T shirts are much longer. So that was a disappointment but, with all of the good things about this shirt, we are happy with our purchase and will probably buy another one in another color.

After losing too many socks to the floor and to our household pets, and after seeing my son with cuff-marks from socks that last for days, I've become quite picky about kids' socks.  Once our young'un unfortunately finally outgrew our tried-and-true Fruit of the Loom Little Boys' Low Cut socks, it was time to find new socks.Not so easy!  I looked at a ton of different brands of socks and read a ton of reviews.  Falls off too easily?  Next.  May cause farmers' tan?  No thanks.  Causes red marks from digging into the ankle?  Been there, done that.  We finally landed on these socks and they looked great.  One small problem, though--other people had major sizing issues with them.  I, too, was confused.  What is a 9-2.5?  My young'un, age two, wears a size 9.5, but I don't know when the shoe sizes transition to 1, 2, etc., so I wasn't sure what the sizing meant or what to expect.I am happy to say that these socks are great!  I would say that they are half a size too big for him right now, so they may run one size too big.  Even though they're a little long in the toe area, they still fit great into his shoes. They also stay on his feet, which is upsetting to the family pets but very exciting for the rest of us.  We also really like the material--it's soft yet substantial. In other words, they aren't thin, they appear quite durable, but they're not scratchy at all.We will definitely be buying these again in the next size up when that time comes. Great find and great socks.

Our family has been very pleased with these drawer liners, and we plan to buy more to cover more of our clothing storage areas.Why these are 1000% better than moth balls:1) Pleasant smell. Moth balls will leave your clothes smelling like your great-Grandma's house used to smell. Case in point: we recently returned from a B&B that had the stench of moth balls everywhere because the proprietors kept moth balls in all of the drawers and cabinets for the entire winter and spring and only just removed the moth balls before our stay. The clothes we brought on the trip and haven't yet laundered--like our rain jackets and other jackets--still reek of moth balls. That trip made me realize that we didn't have anything in our house to keep moths away, but we needed it--I had two nice-looking and expensive sweaters that got destroyed within 6 months, and my wife had a similar experience with one of her wool cardigans. When we wised up and got these cedar planks, I worried that they would leave a strong cedar smell on my clothes, but they haven't.2) Non-toxic. Moth balls are said to be toxic. Not only is the vapor harmful, but children and pets can mistake them for food, especially due to their sweet odor and taste. I certainly don't expect my two-year-old or dog to be gnashing on this large cedar plank.What else we like about these cedar planks:1) Great fit in our drawers. Each plank has grooves on the bottom so that it doesn't slide around as much when you open your drawers. The grooves are also great to fit onto a wire rack. But note that if you're using it on a wire rack, such as in a closet, they might not be as effective (more on that below). These planks take up much less space than a cedar block or a bag of cedar chips, and you can line them up to cover the whole bottom of a drawer, or you can use just one per drawer. (We just use one per drawer, which seems to be sufficient because you can smell the cedar each time you open the drawer.)2) They'll last forever. All you have to do is sand them every so often--once they don't smell anymore--to get them working again.From what we can tell, this is the safest and most pleasant way to keep moths away, but they're not 100% fool-proof:1) As mentioned above, they need to be sanded every so often to keep them effective. Time will tell if and when I or my wife will get around to doing that.2) As I understand it, cedar needs to be in a small, enclosed environment for maximum effectiveness. This means a container or drawer, not a regular closet. A closet means that there is potentially too much airflow for the cedar, and too much airflow means that it will not kill moth larvae (though it may be effective for adult moths). The reason behind this is that cedar is thought to mask the smell of the wool that attracts moths; it doesn't kill the moths or larvae like moth balls do. So, that's why you should keep the planks in a small, enclosed environment where the smell will be present. This means that you may have to rethink/reorganize where you keep your sweaters; that's what we had to do after we bought these planks and researched cedar.

The title of my review pretty much sums it up.  We love, love, love this book.  It's a story about a little boy, Henry, and his teddy bear, who play together and learn to use the potty.  Despite the fact that the story is fairly long, our son actually pays attention throughout the whole story (not a typical thing--he usually gets through a few pages of any book!).  He also brings the book to us quite frequently to have us read it to him.Most importantly, this book really seems to have made things "click" for him.  We went shopping for "big boy" underwear shortly after reading this book to him for the first time, and he seemed to make the connection.  He also discusses Henry's diaper and his accidents while we're reading the book.  He engages with the story in a way unlike any other story.I agree with the reviewer who commented on the unforgivable grammar.  There is one portion of the book where it says "Teddy and me . . ."!  I honestly think I'm going to take a sharpie to the book and fix it, because changing it to "I" doesn't mess up the rhyme or the rhythm.  It's very odd.  However, it doesn't affect my star rating and I suppose when my son is older, it would be a good way to teach him about grammar.  (On the other hand, I hope that we won't be reading this book at the same time that he's learning about grammar, because that would probably mean that we'd be potty training at age 5!)

I'm a tall and lean guy, and so it's not easy to find shirts that fit.  Shirts that are long enough tend to be too wide.  It's also a bit of trouble (and expensive) to go to specialty big and tall stores, so I don't get around to it too often.  So, I'm thrilled to have found this product online.Pros (in ascending order of importance):--It's made of a thick (but not too thick) material.  Very comfortable even in the hot summer weather.--It's a decent price compared to what I've seen at local big and tall stores.--It has held up well in several washings--I haven't seen any fading yet and I tend to wash my clothes maybe a little too often.--NO MORE "PLUMBER'S CRACK"!  This makes me, my wife, our neighbors, my coworkers, and the general public VERY happy.Cons: None that I can think of.  This is a great product and I will be ordering again.  I like it so much that I've donated my "regular" polos.

I am very pleased with this product.  I had my doubts when it arrived because it's a tiny thing, but it quickly started growing and has been consistently growing since then.  Interestingly, I bought and planted this hydrangea exactly at the same time as several other hydrangeas from a local store.  The local store hydrangeas have not grown at all.  So, needless to say, I will be ordering this brand of hydrangea again when next spring comes around.

I saw Jessica Alba reading this book to her daughters on Instagram and I bought it.  Who am I?  I don't speak a lick of French, and I have no idea what goes on in this book except that I think this vole-type creature goes hunting around accusing all of these other animals of pooping on his head.  Isn't that terrible when you can't figure out how a big poop got on your head?  I'm not sure if he ever figures out who pooped on his head. My son doesn't let us get to the end of the book.It's a weird book.  It's even weirder to try to pretend to pronounce the words.  I think my son's onto me, and he's a mere 2-year-old.  However, the book makes him laugh a lot--at least, until the midway point of the book, when, for unknown reasons, he decides we are finished--so I give it four stars; I like it and my son seems to like it.(Written by Woody's wife; Woody does not "follow" Jessica Alba on Instagram.)

Guests were coming to our new lake home and we realized there was no trash can in the guest room they were staying in.  We didn't want to put any old trash can in there, but we also didn't want to spend a fortune.  This ended up being the perfect trash can for the room.  It's sturdy and quite attractive and looks more expensive than it actually was.Do note that this trashcan is small (it's not even a foot high).  However, as my wife has said, this trashcan might be the PERFECT way to subtly convey that houseguests and fish start to smell after three days.

I loved this vacuum for the 10 or so times I used it.  I even bought it as a gift for someone else because it was such a great little vacuum, the way that it sucked up dog fur on the steps and dust in the kitchen.  But the last time I used it, approximately 90 seconds into vacuuming, a large flame (the size of a fist) sprung from the innards of the vacuum.  Surprisingly, no fire started, so the Woody Family is safe and sound.  However, as for how I'm going to vacuum my intact house, I suppose I'm stuck with two options, neither of which is appealing: (1) buy another vacuum, now that I'm just two or three months out of the warranty period; or (2) attempt to use this vacuum again, and possibly burn off my face or hands.So, if you are still tempted to buy this vacuum, even after the tort that it committed against me, let my story be a lesson to you: if you buy this vacuum, use it for a minute or less at a time so that it doesn't overheat.  Apparently, this vacuum is not meant for long vacuum sessions (even if those sessions are under two minutes!).

We are so glad we found this product.  We spent one weekend shopping in the stores for a longsleeved rash guard for a boy that did not contain slogans (e.g. "lobster trap!" or similar).  We finally gave up and turned to Amazon.We weren't sure what size to buy with this product, because our young'un is usually around a 2T, and the 2T rash guards we did see in the stores seemed like they were drowning on him.  We decided to go with a 3T from City Threads, hoping that it wouldn't be too big and that possibly--possibly?--he could also wear it through some of next year.  Turns out the 3T is great.  It's definitely a little bit big on him, but nothing that prevents him from doing beach things.
