(We did roll up the sleeves once.)Also, the product itself is a nice thickness--not too thin and not too thick.We are so glad that we found this, particularly with how hard it was to find longsleeved rash guards without slogans.

We didn't buy the first one of these until I recently got a new car, so we wanted to protect the leather as much as possible.  I thought it might be overkill or a little unnecessary until we took out my wife's Radian for use on the airplane last week, and we saw a couple of long scratches on her leather that hadn't been there before (her car is also new and we know they weren't there before).  So, as a result, we immediately ordered her a seat protector to nip any additional leather damage in the bud.  We're at the point of being really sick of purchasing baby products, especially now that our young'un is a toddler--we thought the "must purchase everything" phase was over!  However, after seeing the damage that can be done to leather, we consider $20 a great trade-off.

I don't know what I would do without these armpit shields.  I discovered these about a year ago, but at the time, I was purchasing Kleinert's armpit shields for short sleeves.  Those work fine, but require a LOT of adjusting, especially if you are wearing a tighter fitting jacket.  These long-sleeve shields do the trick, however.  I can go through an entire day and not have to adjust them at all (or at most, maybe once or twice, but only to position it a little bit better).I do not wear a suit jacket without these anymore, period.  I do this because even though I don't have a B.O. problem and I don't perspire (I use Certain Dri and so I don't sweat!), there's still a funky smell that occurs from wearing a suit jacket up against a bare armpit, or even a short-sleeved armpit.  At least, that has been my experience.  I've ruined too many suit jackets, but not anymore.  Somewhat expensive, but best clothing product ever.

We purchased these straps to clip onto our child's Diono Radian car seat (the manufacturer sells its own straps, but those seem to break quickly for most people).  We've just done a test run on a whirlwind trip through four airports in the past 24 hours and these straps have been fantastic.  The fabric is sturdy and stiff, and so are the clips.  They fit our car seat perfectly, which allowed us to carry a VERY heavy car seat as a backpack (this is key when trying to herd a toddler through an airport).  The only thing I would change is the padding on the straps--there is some, but not much.

I purchased this TV (KDL-40R450A) from Costco a little less than 2 years ago (Summer 2013).  The TV itself is very attractive and thin, and is very lightweight (I easily mounted it to my wall).  The display was also great, but within the past two months the TV has developed a thin horizontal line running across the entire screen, about 4-5 inches from the top of the screen.  The line exists regardless of which HDMI input source I use, and also shows up in TV settings menus.  It's not terribly annoying but it is distracting and obviously not something I'd expect from a Sony product.  I have another Sony TV that I purchased in 2002 that is still working flawlessly, so the appearance of this line is disappointing, to say the least.

This is one of the better cell phone covers I've owned.1)  S-View functionalityThe "S-View" screen is the small screen visible when you close the cover.  It provides extra functionality.  The added functions I've used most are answering phone calls without opening the cover and turning on the "Flashlight" function which turns on the LED light on the back of the phone (much easier than unlocking the phone and searching for the app).  The S-View display also lets you know the temperature and the number of steps you've taken if you're using the S Health app.The S-View screen is another screen and it does require additional cleaning, however.2)  Wireless chargingIf you own a wireless charging pad, you can use this case to drop the phone down on the pad and start charging the phone.  This prevents having to find a charging cord.  Not a life-changing convenience, but it is nice not having to look around for the charging cord and plug it in properly.  If you're buying a charging pad, make sure you get the larger pad so you don't have to balance the phone (as you do on the "mini" charging pads).3)  Protection from dropsI've dropped the phone a few times and it has seemed to protect the phone well.  There's a small crack in the glass of my phone after a drop that happened before I got this cover, but the crack hasn't got worse since I've used this cover, and the few times I've dropped the phone after getting the cover have not resulted in new cracks.  The leather edges of the case protrude slightly from the phone and seem to provide a decent bit of shock absorption, although this is certainly no Otterbox Defender.4)  Style/comfortThis is a somewhat subjective area but I feel like the cover adds a bit to style and comfort.  I like how this case doesn't add much to the bulk of the phone.  You have to replace the back battery cover with this cover and this removes a lot of the bulk you would have with other cases.  I do wonder if I'll be able to find the original phone cover when it comes time to sell or trade this phone in, so I would put the old cover in a place you can easily remember.The case feels like real leather.  Although the seams to the leather seem to have gotten a little dirty after months of use (my wife has used the term "grody"), the cover itself has stayed a rather solid white.  Buying the darker cover would have avoided this.  I imagine I could clean the cover with some type of leather cleaning agent, but I haven't felt the need to do so yet.5)  CameraPictures taken with this cover on are saved in a different default folder in your photos.  The S-View pictures/videos are sized differently from pictures/videos taken without the cover on because the S-View screen is square and the regular phone screen is a rectangle.  I've taken to not using the S-View camera feature because I like the larger view and resolution of pictures when you use the phone's full screen.Overall, a great case and I highly recommend it.

UPDATED JULY 2015 (3 stars):I'm sad to say that after just two uses of this book while traveling, and maybe three uses of this book at home, most all of the pages have ripped from their seams. This had already happened as of the time of my review below, and as I said there, I can't place all the blame with the book because it is a book that little kids are playing with (and we know they're not the gentlest of creatures). However, it's a bummer that after just a handful of uses, this book is now pretty much unusable (we bought it mostly for travel and didn't want to have miscellaneous loose sheets flying everywhere in a car or especially in an airplane).Also, another issue we have encountered after taking it on our second trip: it's just too big and cumbersome for any real, practical use on a trip.  It's so big that it doesn't even fit into a very large carry-on.  If it does fit, it sticks out of the top of the carry-on, is stiff, and takes up so much space in a bag.  So, the bulky size of the book, combined with the weak seams issue, means that we no longer travel with it, unfortunately.  It still gets three stars because I consider it an okay product--and I still love the concept of reusable, non-sticky stickers--but because our son doesn't really like to play with it at home and because we bought it primarily for traveling, it just doesn't suit our purposes. This has just been our experience--others may have a great experience with this book for their young'uns, especially if they're planning to use it at home.AUGUST 2014 REVIEW (5 stars):Before we had children, one of my top 15 fears as a parent was having stickers stuck to every surface of my house (I had seen too many of my wife's nieces and nephews going wild with stickers). So when my wife suggested a "sticker book" for our young'un, I immediately vetoed it until I found out these stickers are reusable.I'm so glad that I didn't veto this purchase. Not only are these stickers reusable (i.e., no mess), but they kept our young'un entertained for at least 25 minutes of a recent airplane flight. In airplane time and in one-year-old time, that's almost equivalent to a four-hour-movie. He loved peeling off the dinosaurs and re-peeling them off, over and over; for those 25 minutes or so, he truly was transfixed (and not bothering the flight attendants or other passengers!). The same has held true at home: he actually sits on the floor quietly and flips the pages of his book back and forth and peels and re-peels the stickers. It's unclear what he's actually doing, but he's around one, so he gets a hall pass, and the book seems to keep his attention and keep him happy, so that makes us happy.At the front of the book, there are several sheets of animals that are grouped into like categories--farm, aquatic, jungle, etc. Later in the book, there are "scenes" with illustrations depicting farm life, aquatic life, jungle life, and so on, so that the animals you saw earlier would "fit" into those scenes. (For instance, the jungle scene has a long tree rope that the monkeys can swing from, and the monkey stickers, I was pleased to see, are positioned so that their arms are up, not down, so that it looks like they're actually swinging from the tree when you put them next to the tree.) However, do note one thing about the sheets of animals at the front of the book: the stickers can be hard to peel off if you have a younger child. Like many young'uns, our young'un is probably too little to take the stickers off of the backing for the first time, and he got frustrated at first trying to peel them out to play with them. So, here's what we did: we peeled off the white background sheet that keeps all of the stickers in place, and then stuck the stickers back onto the background (not the "scene" backgrounds, but the plain white backgrounds in the beginning of the book). He could then easily peel them off when he wanted to play with them.We've just found one small downside to this book, and that's the seams to this book: they're not very sturdy. The very first time that our son played with this book, two of the sheets fell from their seams within minutes. There's no way to put them back into the book, so now the book has missing pages. I can't completely place blame with the book, when our young'un is a rambunctious, no-holds-barred young'un, but I was surprised that this happened after just a few minutes of play. Still, this doesn't affect my star rating of five stars.I am hopeful that as our young'un gets older, this book will become even more useful and entertaining to him. If he's occupied now around one year of age by just peeling and re-peeling stickers without an awareness of what they're doing or the fact that dinosaurs don't usually like farmland, then I think this book will last for at least several more years. It's also meant to be for 3+ years, so that's another reason I'm hoping it will keep its usefulness (note also that this means you have to watch your young'un to make sure he or she doesn't swallow any of the small stickers--there are some giant stickers in the book, like dolphins and dinosaurs, and then some tiny ones, like birds and flowers). In sum, we are beyond happy with this sticker book.

It only feels weird the first time you strap your baby into a three-point harness to change his diaper, until you come to two, key realizations: (a) your baby is not crawling or rolling around, naked and covered in unmentionables, all over a dirty bathroom floor, to "explore"; and (b) because your baby is not doing (a), you are free to wash your hands and fix your hair in the mirror for three seconds.  It's a strange and liberating feeling.In all seriousness, our son is at the age--and has been at the age for months--where he likes to do gymnastics during diaper changes.  With several trips we took this summer, we knew that public changings were going to be disastrous.  I was sort of half joking when I googled three-point harnesses for portable changing pads and came across this pad.  My wife said it wouldn't work because the pad would roll up (because there would be nothing to weigh the harnesses down).  Well, this portable pad works beautifully because it does have a little bit of heft to it.  It has a dark blue thick plastic base that folds in three sections into what looks like a folio.  It is covered with a dark blue pad that also folds along with the plastic base.  Both the plastic base and the blue pad are washable.  There are then three adjustable yellow harnesses for the baby's chest and shoulders, plus a fourth strap that can go around a sink faucet (we've never tried this, but the instruction booklet explains it and shows pictures).We were worried that the changing pad, overall, would be too bulky to carry around on our various trips.  Now, it didn't fit in our regular (teeny) diaper bag, but that's because we had a teeny diaper bag when we first bought this (it would have fit a two-inch binder in the main compartment at most). We've since upgraded to a larger diaper bag and the pad fits just fine.  It's also not very heavy--it's a couple of pounds.  But honestly, the pad's slightly larger size and weight (as compared to the standard, flimsy portable changing pad that typically comes with a diaper bag) is WELL worth it.  I can't tell you how many times on our trips this summer my wife would return from the bathroom with our son and say "I am SO glad we have this pad," and how many times I did the same.  True story.To sum it up, the only reason you shouldn't buy this pad is if you are blessed with a very calm child who sits still for diaper changes.  If not, and if you plan to travel anywhere (restaurants, out of town, etc.), I highly recommend that you get this product: it's the coolest thing ever and has my and my wife's highest recommendation because it has made our lives so much easier. I want to buy one of these for every new parent I know--that's how great I think this product is.

After quickly going through five pairs of shoes that never stayed on our son's feet (if we could even get them on his feet), we've finally found a shoe that goes on easily and stays on and we couldn't be happier.Here's a breakdown about these shoes:Sizing:As suggested by other reviewers, we ordered a larger size.  In fact, we ordered TWO sizes larger, and got the wide width, and the shoes still stay put.  (Never mind that our son looks like Ronald McDonald with his clown feet, but we keep telling ourselves that at least he'll have room to grow into the shoes....)Fit:I'm not sure if it's because we bought the wide version, or because we bought two sizes too large, or because you can loosen the shoes with the laces, or just the way the shoes are constructed, or all of the above, but these shoes go on quite easily (even over our son's high arches and beefy baby feet).  You can then get a pretty tight fit with the laces.  It's worth noting that even though we bought two sizes too big, the shoes still fit great.  We don't even need to put socks with them; the only place where they are big is in the toe (hence the clown shoe look).Comfort:As a general principle, our son HATES shoes.  Because he's a young'un of few words, I can't say definitively that he's smitten with these shoes.  However--and this is a big however--he doesn't try to pull these shoes off every chance he gets, unlike every other pair of shoes that he has had (I doubt he'd be able to, anyway, with how well they fit on the ankle and with the laces).  Also, after a full day of wearing them, even without socks, he has no blisters.Price:My wife and I had--and are still experiencing--some sticker shock when it comes to toddler shoe prices.  So, a little part of me hurts for saying that $20 is a reasonable price, but for what we've seen so far, this is a pretty reasonable price.Looks:Due to the aforementioned sticker shock we're experiencing, my wife and I wanted to get the most use we could out of these shoes, so we purposefully ordered a couple of sizes up (hoping he could wear these shoes into puberty, or at least into kindergarten).  So, not surprisingly, as mentioned, the shoes look a little clown-like because they're quite large in the toe area, though they fit very well everywhere else.  Because our son's feet are so small for the shoes, the laces are also quite long, further exacerbating the clown problem.  Otherwise, the shoes are cute.  The navy goes well with lots of outfits.  (Do note that the color in the pictures looks like a denim or chambray, but the actual shoes are a true navy.)Overall:We are so happy to have found these shoes. They're (relatively) affordable; they fit our son well, even with tons of room to grow; we don't have to struggle to put them on his feet; they appear comfortable; they are cute; and, above all, they stay on his feet.  Although this is our first Keds purchase, this certainly will not be our last.

Let me start by saying that any moderately attractive pair of shoes for a young'un is bound to fall off. It's like there's an inverse relationship between beauty and functionality, and the more contraptions and straps there are, the uglier the shoes are (but you know they'll stay put). So, with these Tom's, which are sleek, they don't stay on for very long at all. That's why I feel it's not fair to take away more than one star for these Tom's because it's likely that any itty-bitty shoe without a bunch of straps or laces isn't going to work out very well.And that's the huge downside to these shoes: they stay on for a few seconds, maybe a minute if we're lucky. However, these Tom's also have their own inherent flaw: they have pretty thin, shallow walls, which makes it quite easy for our son's feet to slide out of them. Just like adult Tom's, the shoes have a minimalist look. The only difference is that there's a small flap of Velcro over the top of the child's arch. We had hoped this would make the fit snugger--and it does, but only ever so marginally, and it's really the thinness and shallowness of the shoes' walls that cause them to fall off so much, and the lack of straps.With all the smack-talk above, what's to like about these shoes?1) For one, I like that they're closed-toed--good for keeping our son's feet clean as a whistle during trips to the city.2) They're cute in their simplicity. As mentioned, the shoes don't have a ton of straps every which way. They're just a basic looking pair of shoes that go with everything (my wife and I wanted to buy one pair of shoes, not a bunch of pairs, especially at this price). In my opinion, they're versatile because they're so simple--they look cute in pictures but they don't stand out, and they're neither too dressy nor too casual.3) For a slip-on pair of shoes, they're quite easy to put on because of the Velcro strap, which opens up to offer a little more room (great for those beefy baby arches).Would I buy these again?Probably not. Although the shoes were cute for some outings and photographs, and proved to some well-meaning family members that our son actually does go out in public in shoes (sometimes), the shoes didn't ever stay on for more than 60 seconds when my son was walking around. When my son was sitting down, he often pulled the shoes off due to the Velcro straps. We believe we had him in the correct size, and we in fact bought the shoes in two different sizes (it was recommended by many to size down and we found that one size down from our son's true shoe size indeed offered a much better fit in the Tom's). So, for all of the above reasons, we remain on the hunt for a pair of shoes that are simple-looking yet stay on the feet.

Six years ago, I was checking out at a store and they were offering "sweater stones" to remove pills for something like $10.  At the time, I thought "nah--I'll be fine, and if I ever end up needing one, I can find another one elsewhere."Flash forward to every six months since then.  I've cursed the day that I didn't buy the sweater stone.  I've never seen a sweater stone sold in stores, and when I've asked people about them, they look at me like I'm crazy. For some reason, I didn't consider the internet until recently when a shirt (brand new) got so bad that I realized that these items must exist on the web!  Sure enough, I came across The Laundress Sweater Comb and I'm very happy with this purchase.The sweater comb is sleek--approximately 4L x 2W x .25H (all in inches)--kind of close to the size of a thicker, elongated credit card.  The design is attractive, with cedar covering most of the mesh.The product actually works, too.  I've used it on four of my shirts and a couple of sweaters where I was becoming "that girl" (you know, the one who won't lift up her arms because underneath it's so pilled?).One thing to note, and the instructions will mention this: this product is not the best for looser, yarn-like fabrics. If you're going on a hot date TONIGHT and the only option you have is your favorite pilled, yarn-like shirt, then what you need to do is test an "inconspicuous" section of the shirt so that you don't show up to your date with the fabric looking "teased." The only thing that should look "teased" is your hair, amirite, ladies? (I kid... do not tease either your shirt or your hair, dear reader.)Finally, though we can't always get what we want, I wish this cute little sweater comb came in a cute little sack or case so that I could travel with it and de-pill things on the road, on the plane, in all the hotels of my life. I travel a lot for work and I also create a whole lotta pills. That's the only flaw I can think of. Otherwise, this is an awesome product. Don't let this be the "sweater stone" that got away six years ago...(Written by Woody's wife; Woody doesn't know why a sweater would need to be combed or, heaven forbid, teased)

Let me start off by saying that there's going to be some bathroom TMI in here, but if you're reading reviews for Metamucil, I'm going to assume that you're kind of okay with some TMI.  In any case, I will tone down the gross factor as much as I can.First, here are the positives of this product:(1) It's smooth and not gritty at all, and has no taste that I can detect.  I can't taste it when I've mixed it into even a thin beverage like water or apple juice.(2) It dissolves fairly easily. Usually it dissolves really easily, though occasionally, little intractable clumps get left behind on the spoon or in the bottom of the glass.(3) It hasn't made me any more constipated. Not that I would expect fiber to do that, but I'm trying to be as positive as I can about this product before I launch into the section below on "why I'm already searching for a new fiber product."Next, here's why I'm already searching for a new fiber product (this is in ascending order of importance to me):(1) It honestly doesn't do as much as I thought it would. I am taking the recommended daily amount (3 teaspoons, or 15 grams), and despite having stuck with it for a while, I haven't seen a noticeable change in my stool habits. I've gone from 4-5 bowel movements a week to... 4-5 bowel movements a week.(2) Here's the real kicker. The only real change I've noticed in my stool habits with this product is that everyone around me is mortified, including me. Because the product is made with inulin (which is derived from chicory root), it gives me gas like you wouldn't believe. (Maybe chicory root won't give you gas, but it has always given me terrible gas--e.g. Fiber One bars, which are made with chicory root, tear my stomach apart.) I know that some people have gas regularly; I'm not one of those people--or, at least, I wasn't until I started using this product. I went from an average of 0.5 farts per day (confirmed by my wife) to an unbelievable, unacceptable level of farts per hour (which I will abbreviate as FPH). I estimate the FPH at a whopping 15. At first, I was taking the bulk of the dose before bed, which caused an estimated 120 farts per night (15 FPH x 8 hours of sleep). My wife was horrified. She convinced me to switch the bulk of my dose to the morning, which has caused me to go the bathroom at work to have gas multiple times per hour. This has had a three-fold effect of (a) decreasing my work productivity; (b) raising coworkers' eyebrows; and (c) forcing me to be creative in finding new routes to the bathrooms and new bathrooms (on a positive note, I have discovered new bathrooms throughout my place of work). Of note, the gas is not productive in the least--in other words, as I mentioned above, I'm not making any more stools; rather, my stomach is just being torn up (even when I just take one or two teaspoons per day instead of three). It's highly uncomfortable and highly embarassing personally (if I take most of the dose before bed) and professionally (if I take most of the dose before work). Further, no matter when I've taken the dose, the FPH last all 24 hours of the day (though they are strongest in the 8-10 hours or so after I've taken a dose).Although brevity may be the soul of wit, I certainly haven't been able to keep my wits about me with all of the FPH going on with this product. So, to sum it up, you may have a different experience with it, but (1) chicory root has never sat well with me, and it's no different with this product; and, most importantly, (2) it's not helping my bowel issues at all. I remain on the hunt for a fiber product.

Our young'un could not get the hang of regular sippy cups (the kind with the no-leak valves).  We just kept buying different brands and offering them to him as if that would make a difference.  My wife and I tried sucking on them to make sure nothing was stuck or that they weren't too hard to suck on, but that wasn't the problem: they were pretty easy to get liquid out of if you have a moderate ability to suck.  But, for some reason, our son couldn't get the liquid out.  We realize that part of the issue may be that our little one isn't adept at tilting while sipping, and maybe that's what you have to do with a regular sippy cup (but don't quote me on that).In any case, while exchanging dad war stories at work one day (his involved something cool; mine involved sippy cup woes), a coworker nonchalantly said "you need a straw sippy," as if it was the most obvious thing.  When I got home, I read that straw sippies often work better for the young'uns because the straw resembles a nipple.  Well, wouldn't you know, when we ordered these straw sippies, our son chewed on the straw instead of sucking on it.  This persisted for a couple of days until it finally just clicked.  He now sips his young'un beverages all by himself!  It's a miracle (for us, at least). What I've now learned is that it's maybe not an actual miracle but the fact that these straw sippies have a different mechanism to prevent spills--a lock mechanism instead of a no-leak valve.  For us, that has made all the difference. Also, with the straw sippy, he doesn't have to tilt the cup; he can hold it below him just like you would with any straw-containing beverage and the liquid comes out fine.One caveat: do make sure that you twist the straw sippy lid on perfectly (even if you hear it click), or else the cup is prone to leaking.So, to sum it up, if your child is deficient at the whole regular sippy cup thing, don't throw in the towel just yet!  And if you order these straw sippies and they don't work out right away, give it a little time.  For us, it took a couple of days until our young'un finally "got it."

We usually exhaustively research baby socks, perhaps because our family pet likes to carry them away if he finds a stray sock, so we like to make sure any socks will stay on our son's feet.  This time, however, we bought these on a whim and couldn't be more happy with this purchase.  Here's why:(1) The socks pretty much stay on!  That's always the million dollar question with baby socks.  We've lost an average of two socks per week, which we consider much better than the typical baby sock (which, for us, averages a lost sock every ten minutes or so).(2) The band around the ankle isn't too restrictive.  We've found so many baby socks that cut off circulation around the ankle, leaving marks on our son's ankles.  This isn't the case with these socks.  The tradeoff is that, as mentioned, we have lost an average of two socks per week.  We are okay with that tradeoff.(3) The thickness is perfect--not too thick and not too thin.  It's obviously the summertime right now, so we wanted a material that would give him some protection and warmth but not too much.(4) We also like how low they are on the ankle.  With all of the other awkwardness in our lives, at least we don't have to worry about the awkwardness of a farmer's tan on our son's legs.

We have a mostly love and a little bit of hate relationship with our Dionos.  We're not the most patient people, but we've finally put a little muscle into these seats and we've come to love them.  If you can stick with these seats, I think you'll find, like we do, that they're a great investment.  But, I'll also tell you why they will make you cry at times. If you can bear with this lengthy review, I will let you in on the secrets of the awe-inspiring and tear-inducing Radian.Why we love these seats (we own two, one for each car):(1) The Radian is a tank. To my knowledge, it is one of only two seats on the market that is fully steel-framed. The Clek Foonf is the other one, which is unpronounceable, more expensive, and doesn't last as long: your child has to be able to sit upright before using it and it only lasts until the child is 65 pounds. At the rate my child eats, he will be 65 pounds by a year-and-a-half, which would be not long after he started sitting up. Now, with the Radian, although all car seats have to meet government safety standards (quite easy to forget in the guilt/hype advertising of buying baby products), we feel a great sense of peace and security when going on long car trips with it.(2) The Radian is narrow and therefore still lets you have some of your backseat. When my wife and I were young and nave (approximately 1 1/2 years ago, while expecting our aforementioned first child), we thought we would have three children, or we at least didn't want to have to re-buy car seats because of that possibility.  So, we initially gravitated toward the Radian because it's a super narrow seat and allegedly fits three across the backseat of cars. Well, now that the shock of having a toddler is with us, I can assure you that my wife and I have not measured or tested whether three Radians can fit across our backseats, nor do we plan on testing that out. But, if you are blessed with more baby-patience than we are and plan to have lots of young'uns, then you will probably like this feature of the Radian. In any case, the narrowness of the seat is nice when I'm schlepping my coworkers to Denny's for lunch and two of them can fit in the back of my tiny sedan with no problem.(3) The Radian's dimensions are compact, but if they don't make sense for your car, buy an angle adjuster. Speaking of my tiny sedan, the Radian probably will fit in your car. Before we bought our Radians, we read about people fitting these in Honda Accords and Honda Fits all day long. So unless you're driving a Pinto, I would think you'd be able to get the Radian installed. But, with that being said, the fit isn't necessarily going to be perfect (especially because the seat is so tall). Although the Radian fits perfectly into my small, older sedan, it was a mess at first in my wife's larger sedan. So, we researched and bought the $10 "angle adjuster" on Amazon that Radian makes, and that solved the problem. Just that inch of foam somehow made a huge difference, such that without the angle adjuster she couldn't see out the rearview mirror, and with the angle adjuster she can barely see that the Radian is even there. Her cousin also had fit problems (even with a mid-sized SUV) until she bought the angle adjuster, though her cousin had to end up installing the seat behind the passenger side instead of in the middle. So, to make a long story short, the fit of the Radian may not be perfect for your car, but you can likely rig it with the angle adjuster to make it work. In any case, I would definitely recommend choosing the shipping option that also offers free returns. I remember seeing that some colors would ship with free returns (I'm not sure if that's a Prime-specific thing or a seller-specific thing or what).(4) The Radian has high weight limits for rear-facing (45 pounds), which is important to us, so we can have our young'un rear-facing for as long as possible. This is higher than some other seats we were considering.Why we used to curse these seats (but we're over it now, we promise):(1) We bought these seats with the idea that this would be the only seat we'd have to buy for our young'un, because it's supposed to go from newborn in rear-facing mode to 120 pounds in booster mode. He was born a hearty size, not preemie but not humongous, yet the angle was so steep that he would have probably been taken away by CPS right then and there at the hospital if we had tried to drive him away like that--seriously, it was more like a 75 degree angle, not the desired 45 degree angle; he would have looked like Hannibal Lecter strapped to the almost-upright gurney in Silence of the Lambs. Maybe it was the slope of our sedans' back seats, and maybe you'll have better luck in your car, but we had to buy a Graco bucket seat (with two bases) that we used for the first several months. So, we weren't happy about spending the extra money on another seat, but in the long run, it didn't turn out to be too much money and it was convenient to be able to carry our infant in a bucket seat.(2) It took an act of Congress and many test runs with a very upset little boy for us to figure out how to tighten the straps properly. We find this to be a major downside to this seat, or at least a major frustration. The instructions are complicated and the seat is not intuitive at all. You can google it, and terms like "ratchet" and "tug tug tug" will pop up, and to us, that didn't help at all. Basically, what we learned is that there's a little metal bar at the bottom middle of the seat (almost at the base of the seat, in the front). It's a metal clip that resembles an airplane seat belt clip. To tighten the straps, you have to pull up on the metal bar/clip with one hand and pull on that section of the strap, while at the same time putting your other hand behind the car seat where the "slack" in the straps is and using that hand to pull the straps as tight as you need them. Some people say it helps to do this while having only the chest clip strapped; we found this to be true. Two things to note about this: you usually have to adjust the straps every time you get in the car, and the metal clip, at least in our cars, is wedged between the car seat and the backseat. So although we have figured out how to tighten the straps, the Radian is not known for being the most user-friendly car seat.(3) Finally, we won't talk about the long nights that my wife made me install the seats. We just won't. My only advice on that is to watch the video instructions that come with the instruction booklet (through the QR reader on your smartphone), google, google, google, and beer, beer, beer. Then, once you think you have it installed, definitely don't forget to have a local fireman (or two or three) check your work.Basically, the Radian makes you feel like it's possible to get close to being Parent of the Year for buying a steel-framed car seat, until you realize that you have no idea to use it. And then slowly, you learn how to use it, and then you feel kind of awesome again.********************************UPDATED JUNE 2015 after traveling with the Radian on six airplane legs with one rambunctious toddler:I recently traveled on six flights with the Radian and wanted to update my review to offer some observations and tips about flying with it. For starters, I had no idea what to expect and the whole idea of hauling the carseat around the airport and installing it in the plane was previously daunting, but it was actually a relative breeze. This section is lengthy, so read this only if youre planning on using the Radian for an airplane trip; otherwise, youll gouge your eyes out from boredom.PRE-TRIP:1) I highly, highly recommend buying two straps to attach to the back of the seat so that you can carry it through the airport like a backpack. On the back of the Radian, there are three hooks at the top and two at the bottom, so you'll want to choose the inner two hooks on the top so that the straps are symmetrical; ignore the random hook on the left outer side. The hooks from top to bottom are 19 inches apart so you'll need straps that are at least a little bit longer than that. We had much success with a set of Nylon Backpack Straps (abrasion resistant 400D diamond grid ripstop nylon straps) from Amazon (under $10 for a set of two straps). After researching straps for about an hour,  including Dionos straps, and realizing that we were not about to carry the 400-pound Radian and our sizable toddler through several airports if the straps broke, we decided to go with the Nylon Backpack Straps because of what we read about some peoples Diono brand straps breaking unexpectedly.2) Once you get the straps, plan your other luggage accordingly. The womans smile on the Radian brochure must be photoshopped, because it's not a fun experience to carry the Radian, but with two straps, its bearable. My wife, who is fairly tall and strong, carried the seat like a backpack for just one of our legs, and her shoulders were mildly sore, but nothing too bad. Mine were not sore after carrying the carseat for the other legs of our trip. But its still a heavy and unwieldy carseat, even as a backpack, so I would recommend as little carry-on luggage as possible, and for what you must carry on, wheels and/or backpack straps are a good idea. (This was especially true for my wife, who now can only carry my son on her hip because he's now about 1/3 of her weight and half her height. Side-hip toddler carrying is an impossibility when carrying the Radian as a backpack.) For our first trip (4 legs), we had two very large tote bags as our carry-ons and that did not make things easy. For our second trip (2 legs), we checked everything but the kitchen sink/my wife's purse, so that made things much easier.3) Find your Radian manual and read about how to fold the carseat. Its extremely easy after youve done it once, so that's why a practice run is a good idea. We have two Radians, so we just took one out of the car we werent driving to the airport, and folded up this one. If you can't practice on your Radian beforehand, know these things:(a) You'll need to get on your knees on the ground to fold up this sucker, so plan your outfit accordingly. (I did not do this. To the skycaps who got a show, I apologize.)(b) The most important thing is to fish out the little red strap with white Velcro. This is located between the chest straps and is accessible through the little slots of fabric. This red strap is what folds over onto itself to keep your Radian folded up while your carry it. Once you fold the Radian (also a bit trickyyou have to push down on two small red levers located on the bottom, back side of the seat), thread the red Velcro strap through the bar underneath the seat, and attach the red Velcro strap back onto itself. This is explained in the manual except the red Velcro strap part was very hard to see on the manual's picture. The first photo I have attached shows the red Velcro strap undone, and the second photo shows the red Velcro strap holding the Radian folded into place (and the third photo is the same as the second but with the entire folded Radian in view).(c) Consider bringing a few rubber bands to tie together all the random straps that are in the back of the seat. No big deal if you don't bring them, but you'll have lots of straps hitting you and possibly dragging on the ground and generally causing mayhem.BOARDING THE PLANE:1) Of course, if you can and want to, board during "pre-board."  This is for passengers who need additional assistance or who are traveling with small children--usually additional assistance comes first and then small children, but some airlines lump them together.  In any case, this occurs before even the million milers can board, so you'll have plenty of needed time to get situated and get the carseat installed.2) As soon as you get on the plane, find the first friendly looking flight attendant and ask for a seatbelt extender. You'll need this whether you're installing forward-facing or rear-facing.  Also: clarify with the flight attendant that its for the carseat, unless you want him or her to stare you up and down to decide whether you need a seatbelt extender.A note on traveling with the Radian but doing infant-in-arms: if you did not purchase an airplane seat for your child but are traveling with the Radian, it DOES fit in the overhead bins and would even have enough room on the top of the seat for any small luggage. I read online that in order for this to work--being allowed to put the Radian in the overhead bin instead of gate-checking it--you need to follow the high school locker room rule: keep your eyes down. Quickly and calmly heave the Radian into the overhead bin and then sit down in your seat and keep your mouth shut. I did this on one leg of our second trip with the young'un and there were no problems. I felt okay with using the overhead bin space because that was my only "carry on" item and it's about the size of a big rollerboard; my wife had only a small under-seat carry-on--her purse. Also, I've read that gate-checking is probably fine, but I personally don't like that you can't see if the luggage handlers throw (or accidentally drop) the carseat; if that were to happen, I always worry that this could cause damage or render the seat unsafe or unusable. Finally, and importantly, bringing the carseat as a "carry on" instead of gate-checking it also creates the possibility that for those of you flying with an under-2-year-old, you can use the seat if there ends up being an open seat. Now, we know this almost never happens on oversold airplanes these days, so if you want to have even a remote chance of this happening (it happened to us on one of our legs!), book the window and aisle seats of a three-across section as close to the back of the plane as possible.  This is because the middle seats in the back of the plane tend to fill up last. Then, when you're at the airport, kindly ask a gate agent if the middle seat can be "blocked" out for you--it will be filled if needed, but it will be the LAST seat to be filled.REAR-FACING OR FORWARD-FACING?We did both. We really liked with forward-facing that the seat had a good angle relative to the bottom seat cushion, and that our youngun had lots of room for his legs. He had plenty of room in economy comfort on two of the legs of our first trip (which we splurged on because we wanted to be sure we had enough room for the seat). On the downside, on the trip legs that were NOT economy comfort, forward-facing allowed our youngun to kick the seat in front of him, and he's too young to understand the "golden rule," so we flipped him to rear-facing for those segments.With rear-facing, the obvious disadvantage is that the carseat is bracing up against the seat in front of it--see fourth photo. This was the case on our first trip, but oddly on our second trip (same airline and same aircraft), the carseat just grazed the seat in front of it but didn't press against it. In either case, however, the close distance between the Radian and the seat in front of the Radian means that the person's movement will move the carseat, and possibly wake your child during a nap. It also means the person cant recline the seat. We have read online some horror stories about people being angry that they cant recline their seat, and we decided that if the person in front of us said anything pre-flight, we would offer to turn the seat to forward-facing but mention that there might be some kicking that we arent able to control well. Fortunately, we got kids in front of our son those times, and they never even tried to recline their seat. The rear-facing angle is also very upright. (The fourth photo also shows the angle of the Radian in rear-facing mode.) Therefore, I'm not sure how well a very young infant would fare in a Radian in coach (whether rear-facing or forward-facing), due to the fairly steep upright angle of the seat.INSTALLATION:1) IT FIT. The Radian easily fit both forward-facing and rear-facing, and we were even able to have the armrest down. I feared we would have to gate-check it, but thanks to the Radians narrow frame, we had no problems there.2) Installation (both forward-facing and rear-facing) was surprisingly simple and quick. After you have the seat belt extender attached, thread the seat belt through while your knee is on the seat (in order to get the most leverage and tightest fit possible). If you have another adult with you, that person can wrangle your youngun in the aisle seat while you are working on the window seat with the carseat.3) We were never able to get a super tight fit, meaning the seat would move around a little if we pushed on it, but we felt that this was less important in an airplane than in a car.4) Un-installing the seat is equally easy. Lest we had to wait for the entire plane to deplane before we got off, we just used the time waiting at the gate before deplaning began to take our youngun out of the seat and into one parents arms while the other one of us undid the airplane seatbelt and folded up the carseat while the carseat rested in our lap.  Very quick and simple.  One time we didnt have enough time to fold up the carseat before we had to deplane, so I just carried it off the jetway and folded it on the floor of the terminal. It was heavy but definitely manageable for a short distance.One final tip: If your child is old enough to grip food and bring it to his mouth, I also highly recommend bringing along a Munchkin Click LockDeluxe Snack Catcher filled with your childs favorite snack, and then looping it around the harness with the Baby Buddy Secure-A-Toy. This way, you wont be worried about a snack rolling down several rows while your child screams for his food.All in all, air travel with the Radian was pretty much a breeze. If you do nothing else, buy two shoulder straps to carry it and bring your Diono manual in case you need to refer to it while traveling (whether to fold the seat or install it into a rental car or an unfamiliar car). Safe travels!

I love this mascara.  I've been using it for years with great results.Here's why I like it:-***I don't get puffy eyelids anymore, which used to be a consistent problem (!)***-It doesn't irritate my eyes or underneath my eyelids (which is where most mascaras used to irritate), which I attribute to its natural status, but who knows-It doesn't make my lashes clump-It makes my lashes look longer (they need all the help they can get), and if I apply it slowly and apply a couple of layers back to back after curling my lashes, this really helps my lashes look longer-It makes my lashes look thicker and darker (I always order the black color)-I always get a consistent application with itThe only downside is that it seems that the mascara doesn't last super long (I estimate 4-5 months of daily use). It seemed like all of my previous mascaras, without fail, lasted for almost a year.(Written by Woody's wife; Woody does not wear mascara)

Now that I am the proud parent of a small child who requires a packhorse to travel with him for an hour-long outing, I knew that our planned trips to the beach and abroad would be nightmares.  Why?  Because I would have to do the thing I dread the most in life: check a bag.Once I accepted that the most efficient way for our family to travel would be to pack all of our family's clothes into one large, checked bag, I knew we would have to get the largest suitcase available while still keeping some ground rules.  Here's what we looked for, and what we found, in this Samsonite set:(1) The large suitcase is VERY spacious but is not ridiculously big.  Although I wish the large suitcase were more like 29", the 27" suitcase is still really spacious.  This is the only one we used for our beach trip, and we were easily able to fit all of our family's clothes for the beach into the suitcase (as well as souvenirs on the way home).  You don't want the large suitcase to be anything more than 29" or 30" or so, because then you get dangerously close to the oversized bag charges, and those sure are fun!(2) The large suitcase is light.  It's easy for my wife to carry.  My under-one child can't carry it yet, but he can push it across the floor with ease (when it's empty).  There are handles everywhere--on every single side of the suitcase, including a little portal on the bottom of the suitcase.(3) The small suitcase is 21", which is well within any carry-on size limit I've ever seen on any airplane, but let me tell you: it is HUGE looking for a 21" suitcase.  Pre-child, I regularly carried on a 25" rollerboard (yes, I was that guy), but it fit every time and I would laugh at my wife's tiny looking 20" or 21" rollerboard.  Well, this 21" is spacious.  Should I get the chance to fly solo again, literally and figuratively, I will be taking this little 21" suitcase and it will be amazing how much I can fit into it.(4) Both suitcases, in addition to being spacious, are well laid out.  There are compartments galore: multiple pockets in the front, pockets on the inside rim, and pockets and dividers on the inside liner section.(5) Both suitcases are spinners!  I remember when Up in the Air came out in 2009 and George Clooney bragged about his perfect 22" spinner suitcase and how it allowed him to speed through the security line.  Well, since that movie, it seems like everybody has a spinner.  I didn't get them, until I got these suitcases.  They are fantastic!  It makes such a huge difference in the maneuverability.  If you have a choice between a spinner and a non-spinner, get a spinner.(6) The suitcases are nice looking.  I have had what I consider some nice suitcases in my life, but never a giant suitcase, and so with so many suitcases in my house, I simply wasn't willing to spend a fortune on yet another suitcase.  These suitcases are good looking suitcases that probably any reasonable person would feel comfortable bringing on a business trip or anywhere else.  They don't stand out one way or the other.The only downside I can think of is that EVERYBODY at baggage claim had a black Samsonite, so that's something to consider.  My wife tugged at me to grab "our bag" about seven times before our actual bag actually came out.Finally, note that you may be able to find cheaper options elsewhere: I was *this close* to buying these on Amazon when I was in Costco and saw these on sale for $70 less--the exact same set.  Obviously, I chose to go the Costco route.

We were pleasantly surprised to receive this juicer as a gift.  We've never juiced before, but we've been curious to "juice" due to too many of those tempting late-night infomercials about the "bullet" and other juicers or blenders.  We had fantasies of quickly whipping up healthful and tasty vegetable cocktails to sip on while our toddler quietly plays with his Legos in the other room and takes Lego breaks to sip up his own baby vegetable juice from a mini straw (I am not making this up).I can't blame the Big Boss Juicer for crushing our dreams, but things didn't go exactly as planned.  For starters, I didn't place the juice pitcher beneath the spout where the juice comes out, so that made a big mess.  Next, our son, who is not bipedal and does not yet speak English, did not understand what a straw was and therefore did not drink from the straw.  (He did, however, love the carrot-apple-spinach juice.)  Angered by the straw incident, he did not quietly play with his Legos in the other room and therefore my wife and I did not peacefully sip on our juice.  It was more like we shotgunned the glasses of juice.  Please learn from our failures.How the Big Boss made things easier in our time of tragedy:(1) It's powerful and massive.  It gets the job done.  I chucked some whole carrots in there and wham! bam! - those suckers were pulverized in just a few seconds. I didn't have to cut anything except for one apple that was a little too big to fit down the hatch.(2) It's compartmentalized into a helpful way: dry pulp on one size and juice on the other.  I hear that the dry pulp is tasty in sweet breads and other recipes, and the Big Boss handily sorts this out for you into a big, black container.(3) The food pusher (the tubular, black piece pictured at the top of the Big Boss) is instrumental in pushing stubborn food down into the juicer to meet its certain death.(4) From my limited knowledge of juicers, this price point ($99) is very good for such a powerful machine.Where the Big Boss made a grown man (me) cry a little bit inside:(1) It's gigantic.  Either we let this be another item on our precious counter space by pretending we are going to juice a lot, or we store this in the pantry and schlep it out when we want to use it; either way, it's annoying.(2) The cleaning is no joke.  I might be the laziest S.O.B. around when it comes to cleaning, but when one reviewer on here said "clean or else you'll get ants (trust me)," I listened up and scrubbed my Big Boss.  But do you know how long it took?  Seven minutes to wash all of the parts and pre-soak two of the parts that needed pre-soaking, then five more minutes to come back and scrub the two parts after they had been adequately soaked.  I did actually time it.  That's twelve (12) minutes of my life that I'll never get back, and I'm not sure how I feel about that.When you combine the time it takes the clean the Big Boss with the fail that was our first juicing experience, I can't say how often we'll be using this machine.  Don't get me wrong: it's a powerful machine and does a great job, producing delicious juices.  I just think that you need to evaluate what you are buying it for.  Do you have juicing fantasies brought on by late-night infomercials and a not-yet-bipedal child who is destined to splash carrot juice everywhere?  Or do you actually know what juicing is (unlike me) and would use this machine more than once per week?  If you answered yes to the latter, then, by all means, juice away!  I don't think you'll be disappointed.

1:01 MinsWe are loving these Waxman gripper pads.  We bought these once we discovered little pock marks all over our wood floors from the bottom of our chairs and couch.  We had once had cheap felt pads on the chairs and couch, but it didn't take long for those to fall off and we never got around to replacing them... until now!  We LOVE these pads. Yes, they are pricier, but they are SOLID and get the job done.  Most importantly, they keep our furniture in its place and keep our floors protected.

So, I foolishly didn't have a case on my Note 3 for the longest time, because I guess I didn't think that any case would work (the phone is already SO darn big, which you know if you own one or are considering owning one).  I kept the phone in my back pocket or wherever I thought the screen wouldn't get scratched.  Thankfully, before purchasing a case, the screen didn't get scratched, but my under-one-year-old son thought it would be a good idea to smash one of our household tablets to pieces (!).  We thanked him for picking our least favorite tablet, and considered it a wake-up call to baby-proof ALL of our electronics, including this massive Note 3.Enter the OtterBox Commuter Series.  I used to be an OtterBox Defender guy, back when I had an iPhone, but I just couldn't justify that larger size with the already huge Note 3 (how would I even be able to fit it into my pocket?).  Plus, the reviews of the Commuter were pretty great, so I bit the bullet.  Once the Commuter arrived, I was a bit disappointed that the instructions were a bit like Ikea furniture instructions (seriously--it took me a while to figure it out, but I'm also not that savvy with putting things together).  But 10 minutes later, the case was on.9/10 for looks and functionality of the case.  The case does not add much bulk at all to the Note 3 but it seems really sturdy.  The Commuter really seems to strike the balance of size and protection.  I also love that the rim of the case sits up about 1/3 centimeter from the top of the screen, so that I can put the phone face down and not worry about scratching the screen.  My only complaint, and it's minor, is that the back of the phone is quite slippery.  I wish there were a little more rubber on the back so that it would stay put on slippery surfaces (plane tray tables, car middle consoles).But, 3/10 for the screen protector that's included with this case.  Although it hasn't interfered with the functionality of the touch screen, it's quite flimsy, and mine has pockets of bubbles in it and bumps from my application of it.  Perhaps somebody else with a surgeon's steady hands could get it right the first time, but I couldn't.  They do include what looks like a small credit card in the package to smooth out the kinks, but not only did this not get rid of the bubbles, but it left little streaks on the screen protector.  Now when I look at my phone, you can't see any of the marks unless the screen is white, gray, or black (or off), but it looks pretty pock-marked and bad, so off shopping for a nicer screen protector I go.  So, this is something to keep in mind if you order this case.  I'm usually not picky about things like this, but the bubbles and marks on the screen really don't look so great on an otherwise great looking phone (plus, again, it's bumpy in parts when I scroll through pages).Despite the screen protector issue, I'd recommend this case in a heartbeat--as I said above, it's a great mix of size and protection for the Note 3.  Just be forewarned about the flimsy screen protector that comes included in the box.

After our son threw down one of our unprotected tablets in a fit of curiosity and shattered the entire screen, we realized, once again, that we apparently are terrible at the whole concept of "babyproofing."So I went off to research protectors for our other, unscathed tablets and our phones.  I initially was going to go with the otterbox for my ipad mini because that's the brand I knew of, and years ago when I had an iphone, that's the brand of case I had for my iphone, and it was built like a rock.  I also liked the stand that came with the case, for watching movies.  I was this close to buying that when I happened to read articles about tablet cases that are specifically built to protect tablets from young'uns' fierce ways.  Trident was one of the recommended brands.  I read lots of great reviews here for the Trident case, and was sold.Now that I've had the Trident for a while, I'm ready to say that I'm quite satisfied.  Once I had my ipad mini properly encased in the Trident, my son came over to inspect.  He whacked the corners of the ipad onto the carpet a couple of times (just a couple!), and I cried a little bit inside, but I knew that it would be okay based on the military tests from six feet with this product (as well as the other reviews here of what little hands have done to ipads protected in Trident cases).  I'm happy to say that the screen is not cracked, though I won't be letting my son perform that scientific field test again....Some other nice features are: (1) the side grippers (though these could be moved toward the front just a little more, or maybe that's just the way I hold my ipad); (2) the size (the case is STURDY but really doesn't seem to add too much bulk or weight to the mini); and (3) the price (a little less than what I felt were comparable cases).To sum it up: I'm really glad I found this brand.  It's a solid case and I'm now confident that a second household tablet won't also end up in tablet heaven.

My wife and I haven't been feeding our under-one-year-old gluten (due to my wife's gluten issues): we want to have a baseline first to see what his reactions to different foods are.  The problem is that this makes his practice of his self-feeding and fine-motor skills quite difficult, as most finger foods contain wheat or are slippery (like fruit).We were on the fence about buying this product.  It's organic, which is great, and gluten free, which is obviously great for our situation, and it contains less sugar than other comparable brands.  But as we all know, this product really is just glorified rice puffs.Well, glorified rice puffs be darned, the boy loves them.  And they give him a much-needed opportunity to practice his self-feeding and fine-motor skills PLUS the huge added benefit of less mess.  Prior to this, pieces of banana were what he practiced on, but of course those stuck everywhere--to his face, to his clothes, to the high chair, to the floor, to the dog's fur, you name it.  We love that we don't have to monitor for choking hazards as carefully with these puffs as we would with something like Cheerios, because these puffs melt in the mouth (my wife and I may have sampled one or two of these...).  Also, these puffs have given us parents a nice break from spoon-feeding for a few moments while he learns to feed himself.  Just this evening when company dropped by, he entertained himself by picking at a dozen of these puffs.  (Sure, it took him approximately 22 minutes to eat the 12 puffs, and our friends wondered what was taking him so long, but it bought us some much needed catch-up socializing time with our friends.)Although we don't plan to give him these puffs often--we bought them primarily for road trips and social outings--we think he'll survive, despite the debatable nutritional content.  Plus, everybody in the household stays sane, which is important, too.  In sum, the whole family is happy with this purchase.

These are beautiful blocks: they are colorful, with interesting detail.  Each six-sided block has four letters (two of which are embossed, two of which are flat), one number, and one animal (with a picture of the animal and a description underneath the animal stating what the animal is).Our son has immensely enjoyed playing with these blocks.  He enjoys stacking them up, knocking them down, and clacking them together.  The blocks make a fantastic sound when clacked together.  We've also successfully been able to get his attention or turn his sour mood into a good mood by clacking the blocks together a few times.The fact that our son enjoys playing with these blocks is really just a bonus: in reality, we initially bought these blocks only to take "documentary" photos of him every month (e.g. stacking up the blocks to say "THREE MONTHS").  These blocks have been a cornerstone to these monthly photographs--in particular, the embossed letters really add a lot to the pictures and make everything look great.  We wanted to do something more than just writing his age on paper, but we aren't crafty enough to do some of the really cool ways people do monthly photos that you can find on Pinterest or other craft sites.  We've seen the cool pictures of the "age blocks" (the three blocks--one giant block that says MONTHS and sits on the bottom of two smaller blocks that have the different numbers you can rotate for the months), but those are more expensive and single-purpose, whereas these blocks have allowed our son countless hours of playtime outside of his monthly photos.We've discovered only a small downside to these blocks.  As our son is fond of gnawing on most everything, I wasn't surprised to find him gnawing on one of these blocks a few weeks ago.  However, I was surprised to find that after just 15-20 seconds of his gnawing on the block, the embossed border on the side of the block was already splintered off.  In other words, the wood is pretty soft.  I don't feel that it's fair to remove stars for this, because this product is intended for ages two and up, so just be aware of this if your child is "orally fixated" like ours is.  Now that we know this about these blocks, our son's chewing experience with the block was his first and last time.In sum, these are beautiful blocks that have added much joy to our son's play time and have added a lot to our monthly photos of our son.  We are really happy with our purchase of these, even if they require additional supervision.

We love these pajamas.  First, they are incredibly soft.  The back of the truck design would be rough, but they've put in a soft patch to cover it up.Second, the PJs themselves have a really cute design.  We often have a hard time finding clothes that aren't overrun with slogans on them and tons of busy patterns, so we really like that these PJs are a little more subdued than what we can usually find in the stores.This is our second Leveret pajama order.  Our other order was the turtle PJ set.  That set is really cute, too, but definitely not as soft, and the material is thinner on that.  However, we're so happy with this set that we'll definitely be ordering another Leveret set soon.

In my opinion, this book is greatly improved over the original book, and heres why:(1) Keirsey provides a helpful framework to understand potential sources of friction in relationships: he proposes that NTs and SJs are opposites, and SPs and NFs are opposites (he calls them "mirror images," and he has tweaked these mirror opposite combinations since the original Please Understand Me).  This was incredibly helpful to me, because I bought to book to help beef up my understanding of MBTI types.  Even though I already had the original Please Understand Me, I was having trouble with a person who was like oil to my water; I couldnt figure him out but I knew that some others didnt have problems clicking with him.Armed with all of my mirror images possible temperaments (there were only a couple), I read through the descriptions until I settled on a description of a person that was as if it was written by Keirsey describing the person I was  having trouble with.  I was so pleasantly shocked that I have now figured out this guy, which I had not been able to do with the original Please Understand Me, and not even with the first book's description of that same temperament because that description wasn't nearly as detailed or helpful. It almost skimmed the surface. This updated book has cleaner, fresher examples, and they resonated with me so much more.How does it help me to use this book to find out other people's MBTI profiles? Well, before I read this book, I thought the guy I didnt click with seriously could be just plain out of his mind, but now that I see how he thinks and what makes him tick, I TOTALLY understand why he acts in certain ways. So, now that I'm armed with this information, I have already been able to build bridges instead of, every day, wonder "dude, WTF is wrong with you?" Because that latter approach previously hadnt been working for me...(2) Theres much more meat to the analysis of each type, which is great.  The analysis goes into more depth about work and home, and provides illustrations to show how the type compares to other types.  I do wish, however, that there was a bit more constructive criticism (when warranted)for instance, how a persons personality traits come off at times in a not-so-positive way and how a person could consider tweaking these behaviors from time to time.  I noticed Keirsey does this in some places for some types but not as much (or at all) for other types.(3) On the Keirsey Temperament Sorter II, as with the Keirsey Temperament Sorter I (this is where you determine your type preference), there are still 70 questions (10 for introvert/extravert (I/E), 20 for sensing/intuition (S/N), 20 for thinking/feeling (T/F), and 10 for judging/perceiving (J/P)).  However, for the S/N, T/F, and J/P questions, I found the questions on the Sorter II to be more nuanced than the Sorter I.  Not only were they more nuanced, but in many cases I couldnt even figure out which category the question was going for, which I think is great (you never want to be able to game the test).However, and this is a big however, the I/E questions on the Sorter II seem to have been revised to more simplicity.  For instance: several of the 10 I/E questions ask things like waiting in line, do you often chat with others or stick to business? and are you the kind of person who is rather talkative or doesnt miss much? and at work do you tend to be sociable with your colleagues or keep more to yourself? The Sorter I questions, on the other hand, have more questions that get at whether one derives his energy from others or is sapped by others.  An example of an I/E question on the Sorter I: At a party, do you stay late with increased energy or leave early with decreased energy?  In fact, I got a completely different result from the Sorter II for Introvert/Extravert, then retook the test with the Sorter I, and got the opposite result (7 points v. 3 points both times, but in opposite directions).To sum it up:(1) If you already have the original Please Understand Me, theres no need to buy this one unless you have some curiosities (like I did), in which case you will be very pleasantly surprised.(2) If you do not already have either of the Please Understand Me books, buy Please Understand Me II, but just know that the Keirsey Temperament Sorter may not pin you down for extraversion v. introversion.  You may want to take the official test for that or just keep in mind the differences in some of the questions, some of which I discussed above (that the first test focuses more on the energy felt from others by extroverts).Why buy this book at all?  Because until everybody is forced to wear his or her MBTI preference on a little nametag, this book is the next best thing to trying to figure out how to make peace with the very different people in your lives.

Listen up, guys, I thought I knew it all about underarm products.  I was and still am a Certain Dri devotee.  Because of Certain Dri P.M., which I put on almost every night, I haven't sweat under my pits since Britney's Toxic album was big.  So I thought I was doing great in that department.BUT, and this is a big but, I try to be very careful about suit jackets (and any nice shirts, like silk shirts)--especially suit jackets--when I am wearing them close-fitted for all-day on the job or an all-day event, and then turning around the next day for another all-day event with no time in between for dry cleaning.  I find that even doing this once--even with the protection of Certain Dri and my men's strength Arm and Hammer deodorant--will leave a funky smell on the suit armpits.  It's not a BO smell, but more like a musty smell.  And I find that the smell NEVER GOES AWAY, no matter how many times you dry clean the suit.Enter these "ready shields" from Kleinert's.  So, at first I had my doubts.  The average review was 3 stars when I decided to buy these.  I decided to take the plunge because I just bought a couple of new suits and I really did not want to ruin yet another couple of suit jackets.  I am SO glad that I got these.  I wore them two days in a row, all day, and both suits, my silk shirt, and a cotton shirt smell just like they did after I picked them up from the dry cleaner.  I could not be happier.  I then laundered the pads just to make sure to keep them clean (and for another suit-wearing experience tomorrow), and they laundered well.Now, these things don't change my star rating, because this product is awesome, but there are a few things I think you should know about:1 - The product packaging was designed by Don Draper.  Seriously, it's from the '60s and consequently hasn't been updated to have any sort of useful information to me.  It simply tells you to "place shield in armhole with cotton ply against the body" (the shield has two sides, one of which is more of a matted material; one of which is more of a shiny material, and I still have no idea which is the cotton ply side).  I googled and googled and watched a bunch of Kleinert's videos with some very nice ladies in them, but it still didn't tell me which side is cotton ply.  I'm guessing it's the matted side, so this is the side I've been putting closest to my body.  The packaging also just discusses how to sew in the product to your clothes and states that Kleinert's also has a snap product available (though this product is a snap product) - so, it's all a little confusing, but once you take it out of the package, it's really a snap (pun intended!) to put on: you just put the pad in your armpit, tuck your arm down to hold it into place, then loop both of the snaps around your bra (one snap around the front bra strap, and the other snap around the top bra snap).  You can even leave the pad and snaps in place when you take your bra off to save time getting dressed.2 - Wearing the product can take a little getting used to.  First, I feel like a bird flapping with wings when I wear them (though you can't see them under long-sleeved shirts).  Sometimes you have to tug at the top strap a little bit because sometimes the top strap will fall down your arm a little bit.  This doesn't really bother me because I have this product for use under suits.  However, I could see this being more of a problem if you were going to use this product for short-sleeves, though perhaps it's easily fixable by affixing the strap to your bra strap with a safety pin.I'm so happy I found these little suckers, even if I feel odd wearing them.(Woody's wife wrote the following review; Woody does not wear bras)

Initially, these sheets worked okay.  I liked that I could wear them in the shower and that they offered great protection for my scar.  I also liked that they stayed on for a few days.  My scar started to look smoother and softer after just a few uses.However, the instructions say that you can wash the sheets and reuse them (this also gives your skin much needed time to air out each day).  I did this carefully several times, but I was never able to reuse them successfully: the sheets would curl up and look dirty from things sticking to the adhesive.  And even when I decided not to take off a sheet for a couple of days, the sheet would start to curl up and fall off anyway.When I finally got frustrated with how often these sheets were falling off, I happened upon Neosporin Scar Solution.  These are great.  They stay on for 6-7 days at a time and I only take them off because the edges start to look a little dirty.  My scar looks smoother and softer (though it did with ScarAway).  I haven't tried to wash them and reuse them because every time I look into the package, there's another sheet.  It says it's a 12 week supply, but I've been using it since mid-January and I still have several left in the box.  I couldn't be happier with these, and I believe they are the same or less money than ScarAway.

This board has run pretty flawlessly for five months or so with the auto-overclock feature enabled (via pushing a physical button on the board).  This board auto-overclocked a 4770k to 4.2ghz using 1.3v and set the XMP profile on DDR3 RAM to 1600mhz. Both the i7 and RAM could probably be manually overclocked higher but I see no need given the more than adequate performance.Make sure you download the latest firmware for the onboard Killer LAN ethernet connection; the original firmware had some issues.All in all, this is an excellent product that I highly recommend.

My wife and I big Mineral Fusion fans, and this product is no exception.Here's why we love this product:(1) It's the BEST product that we've been able to find for our skin.  We play a lot of tennis, which means we need to put on sunblock on our faces all the time, or else we'll get scorched.  If we put on regular sunblock, or even oil free sunblock, it wreaks havoc on our skin.(2) Related to point #1 above, this product is gluten free.  Though there is a debate in the gluten-free community as to whether this matters, my wife cannot eat gluten and therefore prefers not to put gluten-containing products on her skin (and notices that her skin is less itchy and bumpy when she avoids gluten-containing products).(3) Because the product is a mineral powder that is applied with a brush, you don't have to touch any sticky sunblock.  Enough said on this point.(4) Because this is a specialty item, it's not something we can find at our destination when we're traveling, so I'm always happy when a product can fit into our carry-on luggage.  I love that this is a sunblock but isn't subject to TSA's 3-ounce liquid rule.  Along these same lines, it's also a really easy product to carry in your purse, bag, etc.Here are some things you should know, though:(1) The product is not meant for heavy coverage.  You'll want to reapply very often.  Even when reapplying very often, you'll still get some sun (though not a burn, in my experience, and I have somewhat fair skin).(2) If you plan on using this product a fair amount, it doesn't last very long.  When I'm playing a competitive tennis season, plus practices (~20 uses), the bottle is nearly gone, and I only use it on my face and shoulders.  This is always a little frustrating because the product is relatively expensive.  However, given the benefits of the product, and how it doesn't mess up my skin, I can live with this (I just wish it lasted longer and/or were cheaper).(3) The brush is not the best quality.  Not only is it rough and feels scratchy when you apply it to your face, but it often leaves bristles behind on your face and body.(4) The product is a little drying.  This is absolutely not a problem for us, and it's one of the reasons we love it, but something to note if your skin is on the dry side to begin with.(5) Using the product can be hard to get the hang of at first.  You have to turn the bottle over and shake it vigorously and even tap it on a surface if necessary, and then apply it.  If you don't see beige powder emerging through the bristles, then nothing is coming out.(6) People will look at you like you're crazy when you apply this product.  At tennis matches, my wife always feels like she has to make the disclaimer: "this isn't powder! I'm not putting on makeup!"In sum, if your skin is at all finicky or sensitive, or if you must avoid gluten products, or if you just want to try a great mineral sunblock, I highly recommend this product.

My wife loves these pants, says that they make her butt look a lot better than other workout clothes--like "spanx" for her walking, pilates, and yoga workouts.  She also loves that you can't see through the pants like every other type of spandex pants she has.  The material is thick and the compression is good.She far prefers using these in her walking workouts compared to her pilates and yoga workouts because they are a little stiff/constricting when she bends and the fabric is a little slick, making her moves uncoordinated.She says she's still on the hunt for a pant that will make her butt look even better, and one whose fabric won't be so slick and stiff so that she can use it for all workouts.  As it is now, the fabric's just not very breathable.
