(And while I'm at it, his character's crush on his cousin Haley [Sarah Hyland] is creepier than it is comical; and although it's a relatively minor [no pun intended] recurring subplot, it represents a major miscalculation by the writers.)The development of the Dunphy children is a main focus this season: Haley still lives at home but lands a low-level job in a field rife with humorous possibilities - and her sudden awakening to something resembling romantic love creates an intriguing final-episode cliffhanger.  Middle child Alex (Ariel Winter) is finally emerging as her own person (more than just the family brainiac suffering from middle-child syndrome) as she approaches high school graduation and a promising college future.  And formerly little Luke (Nolan Gould) undergoes an astonishing growth and maturity spurt that causes mixed reactions in his father.Jay and Gloria (Sofia Vergara) have a fine acting moment together in an episode subplot about an anniversary gift; and Ed O'Neill as Jay has a comedic acting field day in the episode that finds him competing on Cam's team in a gay bowling league.The Claire (Julie Bowen)-on-her-computer episode ("Connection Lost") is extremely ambitious and well executed, if a bit disorienting.  Modern technology gets another comical workout in the "American Skyper" [clever title] episode featuring a robotic camera and Phil Dunphy (Ty Burrell) who is literally not all there.A hilarious dual addition to the cast this season is the appearance of Steve Zahn and Andrea Anders as the Dunphy's new next-door neighbors, Ronnie and Amber LaFontaine, ex-trailer trash who made a ton of money overnight in California's newly legalized medical marijuana business and took a significant residential upgrade.Looking forward to the next season on DVD.

When Bear Family (of Germany) did its earlier three-part series "And the Answer Is," it juxtaposed the original hit record with its sequel that attempted to cash in on the predecessor's success.  "Second Helpings" is Ace Records' (of London, England) second collection of such follow-up records; and like the first, it consists of nothing but the sequels.  So if you are not familiar with the originals, all of which go back to the 1950s and '60s (the latest being from 1966), your enjoyment of this disc will be considerably lessened.  You may deduce from this then that this compilation is almost completely geared toward knowledgeable fans of the oldies from approximately fifty to sixty years ago.Since this CD comes to us from Ace, which represents the paragon of consistent quality in this field, you can expect a five-star package with sparkling sound mastering (these may be moldy oldies but they sound like they could have been recorded last week) and a 20-page booklet that is impressive-looking even for Ace (which is really saying something!).  It's loaded with photos and colorful record realia (label, record jacket, album cover, trade magazine ad and poster repros), and holes in our knowledge are plugged by compiler Sam Szczepanski's (whom I'm nicknaming "Eyechart") superbly limned, ultra-informative liner notes.There are actually a few sizable hits here, although nothing that rivals their predecessors: Sam the Sham & the Pharaohs' "The Hair on My Chinny Chin Chin" (inspired by their #1 hit "L'il Red Riding Hood") made it to #14 on one national pop chart in 1966; The Marvelettes' "Twistin' Postman" (the de rigueur 1962 twist-based follow-up to their #1 pop and R&B smash "Please Mr. Postman") went Top 40 pop and got to #13 R&B; Jimmy Dean's "The Cajun Queen" (#22 pop and #16 country in 1962) exhumes "Big Bad John," the #1 pop and country hit that preceded it; and Paul Anka reached Top 40 pop by asking us in 1963 to "Remember Diana," his self-penned dbut chart-topper from six years earlier when he was 15-16 years old (it rode the charts for more than half a year).  The only other charter is Jan & Dean's mouthful, "The Anaheim, Azusa & Cucamonga Sewing Circle, Book Review and Timing Association," their 1964 follow-up to their memorable #3 smash "The Little Old Lady from Pasadena."  "The Anaheim, Azusa..." [I'm not going to write it again!] peaked at #50 in Record World.Best sequel title:  The Crests' "You Blew Out the Candles" as the sequel to "Sixteen Candles."One case in which the sequel is arguably better than the predecessor: soulful, powerhouse singer Lenny Miles' "Donna's Gone" (1962), the answer to "Don't Believe Him, Donna."By far the worst sequel here is Marty Robbins' "Feleena (from El Paso)," an LP track that slogs on to the same repetitive "El Paso" tune for an interminable 8:17.The most indispensable sequel record: Buddy Holly's "Peggy Sue Got Married," the demo of which was completed after his death and inspired the 1986 Francis Ford Coppola film of the same title.  We are fortunate this even saw the light of day.Personal favorites of mine include Wanda Jackson's rockin' "Man, We Had a Party" (1961), which sums up her equally raucous "Let's Have a Party"; George Jones's tongue-in-cheek "Root Beer" (1962), which followed up on "White Lightnin'"; Slim Harpo's "Little Queen Bee" (1964), the answer to "I'm a King Bee" from seven years earlier; and Booker T & the MGs' "Mo' Onions (1962), based on "Green Onions" and even mo' (I mean "more") of a showcase for Steve Cropper's stinging guitar licks.Grab "Second Helpings" before they're all gone!

This is a veritable treasure trove for fans of this too-often forgotten era of pop and pop-rock (1959-1963) between the first wave of rock & roll and the British "invasion" that followed the Beatles in early 1964.  Here are 90 of the most forgotten records from this period [total running time: 3 hours, 35 minutes] - ones that NEVER get played on oldies radio because they not only missed reaching the pop Top 40, they missed the entire Billboard Hot 100!  (Most oldies radio avoids anything that wasn't at least Top 20.)  The case with many of these records is that they were quite popular in some markets, but for some reason were unable to get the radio airplay elsewhere needed to generate broader demand.A real advantage of a collection like this is that there should be very little duplication with any other CD collection you own.  I especially enjoyed the fact that I knew so few of these records, even though by around the mid-point of this time frame I was starting to becomebe aware of everything that was being played on the radio.  This is a trip back in time that one can hear with fresh ears.  And that reminds me of another advantage: the sound is astonishingly good given the age and relative rarity of these records.  Two more advantages: 1) a 16-page booklet with an informative paragraph devoted to each and every artist and record (that's 90 records by 90 different artists); and 2) every record is presented chronologically, giving one a greater sense of the musical flavors of each year.For anyone who might think that such lesser hits as these must have been throwaways, let me point out that 13 of the 90 recordings were by future Rock & Roll Hall of Famers.  Here's the list: Johnny Cash, Ray Charles, Sam Cooke, The Crickets, Duane Eddy, The "5" Royales, The Flamingos, The 4 Seasons, Barry Mann (in the R&R HOF as a songwriter), Del Shannon, The Temptations, Ike and Tina Turner, and Stevie Wonder (13-year-old Little Stevie Wonder in 1963).  Johnny Cash is also in the Country & Western Hall of Fame, as are Glen Campbell, Sonny James, Webb Pierce, Hank Snow and Conway Twitty.  And Sarah Vaughan is a Grammy Lifetime Achievement honoree.Other artists of note appearing in this collection include Arthur Alexander, The Angels, Paul Anka, Bobby Bare, Gary (U.S.) Bonds, Johnny Burnette, Vikki Carr (her competing version of The Crystals' "He's a Rebel" from 1962 is on the unconvincing and borderline shrill side), The Chantels, The Del Vikings, Jackie DeShannon, Ral Donner, Shelley Fabares, Barbara George, Clarence Henry, Brian Hyland, Jay & the Americans, Hank Locklin, Aaron Neville, Tony Orlando, The Robins, Tommy Roe, Neil Sedaka, Bobby Vee  and Baby Washington.There are 14 Billboard "Bubbling Under" one-timers who never appeared on any other national chart with this or any other record.  Ever heard of the Kenjolairs, Aki Aleong, Vicki Tasso, Doug Warren & the Rays, or Jan Burgens & His New Orleans Syncopators...?  I didn't think so.My Top 20 from this collection (the highest positions most of these records have ever seen!)1) Nolan Strong & The Diablos -  "Mind Over Matter" (1962) - Detroit proto-soul classic (penned by Devora Brown) with a phenomenal lead vocal by the ethereally high-voiced "Daddy Rockin'" Strong and the stellar electric blues-rock guitar of [sounds like it could be Lonnie Mack/Jimi Hendrix icon Robert Ward!(?)]  It broke through on WLS (50,000-watt Top 40 radio) in Chicago, reaching #16, but surprisingly went no further.  Definitely for fans of Nathaniel Mayer & The Fabulous Twilights' "Village of Love" (on the same Fortune label) - and definitely (IMO) one of the best records of 1962.2) Little Stevie Wonder  "I Call It Pretty Music But the Old People Call It the Blues Pt. 1)" (1963) - dynamic and propulsive, and by an unmatched talent, but it got lost in the immediate wake of Stevie's phenomenal dbut single, the #1 pop and R&B smash "Fingertips, Pt. 2"3) Robert Parker  "All Nite Long (Pt. 1)" (1959) - cookin' and jivin' sax instro that should never have stalled at #113 in its only week on the chart.  This was Robert Parker five and half years before his Top Ten hit "Barefootin'."4) Johnny Cash  "Johnny Yuma, the Rebel" (1961) - one of the best vocal TV theme songs of all time (from the Western series "The Rebel" starring Nick Adams)5) Big Al Downing  "The Story of My Life" (1962) - harmonica-powered Southern-style R&B take on Marty Robbins' 1958 country and pop hit (an early Burt Bacharach-Hal David composition).  Like "Mind Over Matter," it was a hit on WLS in Chicago [#15] but failed to break nationally.6) Googie Ren  "The Slide" (1960) - sizzling and grooving organ-&-sax-propelled R&B dance-call tune7) The Temptations  "Paradise" (1962) - This Temptations chart dbut record was obviously inspired by The 4 Seasons, with Eddie Kendricks taking the high-voiced lead vocal (in other words, the Frankie Valli part, but in his natural voice, as opposed to Valli's falsetto)8) Ray Charles  "No Letter Today" (1963) - Ray in his brilliant country-soul period doing credit to the 1944 Ted Daffan country ballad hit.  This one got buried on the flipside of "Take These Chains from My Heart."9) Conway Twitty  "What a Dream" (1960) - This otherwise rather ordinary ballad serves as a showcase for seemingly all of the Twitty bird's trademark vocal tricks, especially his guttural croaks.10) Baby Washington  "Handful of Memories" (1962) - #16 R&B hit by one of the all-time great voices of the genre11) Aaron Neville  "Over You" (1960) - cool, relentlessly rhythmic New Orleans R&B with a neat horn chart. Living legend Allen Toussaint produced and co-wrote it.  It was Neville's first chart record (preceding "Tell It Like It Is" by six years) and a significant national R&B hit (reaching #21).12) Sam Fletcher  "Time Has a Way" (1959) - big ballad by the big-voiced Roy Hamilton sound-alike called "The Man with the Golden Voice" (which later became Paul Carrack's sobriquet)13) Jack B. Nimble & the Quicks  "Nut Rocker" (1962) - original recording of the classic instro by an alternate incarnation of B. Bumble & the Stingers14) Del Shannon  "I Won't Be There" (1962) - a good, if not particularly memorable one penned and performed by the talented Shannon, who followed his big chart dbut year ("Runaway" was a breakout #1 smash in '61) with a major chart slump in '6215) Tony Orlando  "Chills" (1962) - That''s right, Tony Orlando!  The 18-year-old New Yorker had an appealing soulful-pop style, and this is a solid Gerry Goffin-Jack Keller-composed song.16) Duane Eddy  "The Battle" (1962) - This twangy-guitar version of "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" was likely intended as Eddy's answer to his signature instro smash "Rebel-'Rouser from 1958.17) The Chantels  "Here It Comes Again" (1962) - graceful girl-group harmony18) Eddie Quinteros  "Come Dance with Me" (1960) - an all-out rockin' tribute to Ritchie Valens who had been gone one year19) Hank Snow  "Miller's Cave" (1960) - not a wasted syllable in the telling of this blood-curdling tale set in a forbidding Southern Georgia locale - a #9 country song by one of the greats20) Bobby Vee  "One Last Kiss" (1960) - 17-year-old Robert Velline from Fargo was on the cusp of a major breakthrough (with "Devil Or Angel"), but only the most comprehensive Bobby Vee collections on CD have ever included this appealing cover of a number from "Bye Bye Birdie."The only ones I loathed upon first listen:1) Gus Backus  "Wooden Heart" (1961) - truly terrible Teutonic twaddle (inexplicably, Joe Dowell's version got to #1)2) The Swe-Danes  "Scandinavian Shuffle" (1960) - entirely sung in idiotic vocalese (which is redundant) [Beware of the ear-splitting final note - if you are able to make it that far]3) Robie Lester  "The Miracle of Life" (1960) - insipid [Beware of bloated song titles that promise more than they can deliver]

Diana Krall "Wallflower - The Complete Sessions" chronology of covers [orig=original artist / wr=writer]- "Yeh Yeh"  orig-Mongo Santamaria '63 [instrumental/wr-Rodgers Grant/Pat Patrick /later lyrics by Jon Hendricks]  [1st released vocal version: Georgie Fame with the Blue Flames '64-65]- "In My Life"  orig-Beatles '65-66 [wr-John Lennon/Paul McCartney]- "California Dreamin'"  orig-Mamas & Papas '66 [wr-John & Michelle Phillips]- "Everybody's Talkin'"  orig-Fred Neil '66 [as the theme song from the film "Midnight Cowboy" it became a #6 pop hit for Nilsson in '69]- "Superstar"  orig-Rita Coolidge '70 [wr-Bonnie Bramlett/Leon Russell]- "If You Could Read My Mind"  orig/wr: Gordon Lightfoot '70-71- "A Case of You"  orig/wr: Joni Mitchell'71- "Wallflower"  orig/wr: Bob Dylan '70- "Heart of Gold"  orig/wr: Neil Young '72- "Alone Again (Naturally)"  orig/wr: Gilbert O'Sullivan '72- "Operator (That's Not the Way It Feels)"  orig/wr: Jim Croce '72- "Desperado"  orig-Eagles '73 [wr-Don Henley/Glenn Frey]- "I'm Not in Love"  orig-10cc '75 [wr-Graham Gouldman/Eric Stewart]- "Sorry Seems to Be the Hardest Word"  orig-Elton John '76 [wr-Elton John/Bernie Taupin]- "I Can't Tell You Why"  orig-Eagles '80 [wr-Timothy B. Schmit/Don Henley/Glenn Frey]- ""Don't Dream It's Over"  orig-Crowded House '87 [wr-Neil Finn]- "Feels Like Home"  orig-Linda Ronstadt '95 [wr-Randy Newman]- "If I Take You Home Tonight"  wr-Paul McCartney [unissued]Very torchy, chanteuse-y, lovely, calming late-night cover version orchestral pop (not jazz) fare -warmly and beautifully rendered - with credit done to every song, original artist and composer (and with barely a melody or chord change), although it could hardly be more ballad-heavy if it tried.  In fact, it is only on Trk 14 (one of the earlier "bonus" tracks), a rousing duet with Georgie Fame on "Yeh Yeh," the disc's sole song with any kind of a link to jazz (the Latin soul-jazz of Mongo Santamaria - and the oldest covered song here), that this album really ever ventures forth from its cocoon.  (Incidentally, Fame and his group had a #1 UK hit with it in January '65, and it subsequently got as high as #13 in the U.S.  He remains a superb organist and has always "owned" this tune.)  Still, I am very pleased with every one of these ballad renditions whose originals date from the mid-1960s on.  And frankly, I've just about had my fill of 1930s and 1940s standards.  (One more version of "How Deep Is the Ocean" [from 1932] and I'll jump into the ocean!)  Before getting to "The Complete Sessions" additions (Trks 17-20), I would say that my favorites (other than "Yeh Yeh") are probably "I'm Not in Love" (she absolutely nails it!), "I Can't Tell You Why" (best new arrangement - and Eagle/co-writer Timothy B. Schmit does the background vocals on it)," "Don't Dream It's Over" (fine song that hasn't been overcovered), and two that were contemporaries of each other in early 1966, "In My Life" (from "Rubber Soul") and "California Dreamin'."  Her vocals on "Sorry Seems to Be the Hardest Word" and the McCartney dbut song "If I Take You Home Tonight" are admirably affecting as well.Clearly, the intention here was to do a purely pop album of high-quality songs from the second decade of the rock era on, nearly all by writer-performers.  I have no doubt it was a labor of love for the artist, Diana Krall, and it's a highly successful one reflecting her integrity and commitment.  I'm just saying that a little more variety would not have hurt the cause.Now for the four tracks appearing exclusively on this CD (bringing the total running time to 74:30):- "A Case of You":  Her gorgeous piano accompanies her most mesmerizing, duskiest, jazz-inflected vocal.  I suspect Joni Mitchell would heartily approve of this stellar interpretation.- "If You Could Read My Mind":  Hauntingly beautiful duet with Sarah McLachlan.  Heavenly harmonizing.- "Everybody's Talkin'":  Luminescent duet with Vince Gill, featuring more lovely harmonies backed by an intriguing orchestral pop and country-tinged arrangement.- "Heart of Gold":  Stunning take on the Neil Young classic.  Diana's voice sounds genuinely weary from the title quest, and the country violin backing follows up perfectly on "Everybody's Talkin'."These final four tracks on the "Complete Sessions" are as strong as anything that precedes them (on average, even stronger), making it hard to fathom how they could have been held out until this edition.  Because they are all so good, I raised my earlier (pre-"Complete Sessions") rating from four and a half stars to five stars.  Diana Krall is just too fine a star to be denied her full due!

chronology of the original hits covered here:"A Change Is Gonna Come" (Sam Cooke / 1964 - posthumous release)"My Girl" (The Temptations / 1965)"I've Been Loving You Too Long (to Stop Now)" (Otis Redding /1965)"The Chokin' Kind" (Waylon Jennings / 1967 // soul and pop hit version: Joe Simon / 1969)"Ain't No Way" (Aretha Franklin / 1968 [written by Carolyn Franklin])"Who's Making Love" (Johnnie Taylor / 1968)"Clean Up Woman" (Betty Wright / 1971) - changed to "Clean Up Man" here"Woman's Gotta Have It" (Bobby Womack / 1972)"You'll Never Find Another Love Like Mine" (Lou Rawls / 1976)"Tonight's the Night" (Rod Stewart / 1976)"Purple Rain" (Prince / 1984)"(No Matter How High I Get) I'll Still Be Lookin' Up to You" (Wilton Felder w/Bobby Womack / 1985)"As We Lay" (Shirley Murdock / 1986-87 // notable Kelly Price cover version in 2000)There is also one Urban Mystic co-penned original: the pulsating "Feel Good" (Trk 14, at the end)If you have a vocal GPS system, you'll find Urban Mystic's superbly raspy soul voice at the intersection of David Ruffin Avenue and Bobby Womack Boulevard (and only about a block and a half from Teddy Pendergrass Lane).  He is really that good that he can be mentioned in this company.  I actually prefer his vocal on "You'll Never Find Another Love Like Mine" to the original, as it lends a truer, more emotive David Ruffin-esque feel to the Gamble-Huff Philly-soul song that flirted with easy listening back in the '70s.  It is neat [no pun intended] to hear the gender flip in "Clean Up MAN" from the Betty Wright 1971 soul and pop smash original.  The backing vocals are very well done, and on a few tracks, particularly those ballads originally featuring a woman (Aretha's "Ain't No Way" and Shirley Murdock's "As We Lay"), the female duet vocalist (uncredited) is excellent.Obviously it would be impossible to top the originals (other than possibly in the one case I mentioned), given all the great artists (many immortal) and producers involved with those, but this is an exceptionally solid album of classic soul covers (with the one very good original "Feel Good" in the final position).

Dr. John's chronology of Billboard pop chart hits in this collection:"Wash Mama Wash" (1970)  #108"Iko Iko" (1972)  #71 (#50 in Record World)"RIGHT PLACE, WRONG TIME" (1973)  #9"Such a Night" (1973)  #42"(Everybody Wanna Get Rich) Rite Away" (1974)  #92 (#72 in Cash Box)Tasty gumbo, as only Dr. John could deliver it, of New Orleans R&B, jazz, blues and soul, rock 'n' roll, menacing and mysterious Creole/Cajun swamp voodoo, and a soupon of psychedelia (the last two influences appear early in this collection when he was still in his "Dr. John the Night Tripper" persona).  I have always enjoyed the way he growls in his heavy urban N'Awlins accent, which is a unique mlange of Southern and Brooklynese ("toin" for "turn," for example).Malcolm "Mac" Rebennack (before he became "Dr. John") was a teenage prodigy local piano wizard, session player, songwriter and R&B record producer going back to the late 1950s,  but these are the key songs that really put him on the American popular music map.  As I suppose many did, I first became aware of him through his strikingly soulful pop-rock smash "Right Place Wrong Time" from 1973, which continues to be a staple of oldies radio.  (I turn it up loud every time.)  "Such a Night" (his original and not the same as the much earlier Elvis Presley record) was a delightfully cool follow-up that should have been a bigger hit.  Both of these were produced and arranged by his friend, the great New Orleans creator of immortal music, Allen Toussaint.  These two tracks stand out, but everything in this collection is entertaining.Three particularly pleasant surprises for me here are: 1) the opening track, the U.S. promo-only single version of the brilliantly ironic "The Patriotic Flag Waver" (1969), which skewers political and social hypocrisy; 2) his very credible 1972 version of Willie Dixon's "Wang Dang Doodle" (also a U.S.-only promo single); and 3) an outstanding 1972 collaboration with Buddy Guy and Eric Clapton on Guy's "A Man of Many Words," which was clearly intended as a tribute to the late Otis Redding.The package includes a colorful ten-page booklet with five pages of informative new liner notes by Gene Sculatti, and the sound mastering is top-notch.If you're a Dr. John fan, you can't go wrong with this CD.  (And if you're not, you may become one after listening to this.)

Lindi Ortega's "Faded Gloryville" is up there sharing the same rarefied Americana air as Eilen Jewell's stellar "Sundown Over Ghost Town," and we can only hope that these two artistically extraordinary albums will be duking it out for the Best Americana Album Grammy.  (When asked to offer a definition of Americana music, I usually respond that it's country music for people with measurable IQs.)These songs are realistic depictions of life and love in working-class America where emotional and day-to-day survival can no longer be taken for granted.  One can get trapped in a "Run-Down Neighborhood" and a woman can find that her man has "Run Amuck" amid the "bars and dirty alleys...whiskey and tequila...uppers, downers, coffee and cocaine."  "Faded Gloryville" is the trickle-down American dream now come crashing down - a place of disillusion where "nobody wears a crown."  But she holds out hope that "Someday Soon" there will be "somethin' better [...] waitin' for me...a thousand miles from yesterday."In addition to the previously cited pair of ballads, the album begins and ends with a pair of strikingly poetic and poignant beauties, "Ashes" and "Half Moon," respectively.  And by way of contrast, besides the aforementioned "Run" songs, there are some other potent rockers as well: the appealingly New Orleans-y "When You Ain't Home"; the bouncy, coolly melodic and emphatic "Tell It Like It Is"; and her breezy "I Ain't the Girl," which is thematically somewhat reminiscent of Bob Dylan's "It Ain't Be Babe" (but from the distaff side five decades later).The only song not written or co-written by Lindi Ortega is her splendid Memphis-soul-style cover of an all-time favorite of mine, the Bee Gees' "To Love Somebody" from 1967, which they originally intended to be an Otis Redding Memphis soul record.  This is one of three tracks not recorded in Nashville but in that other Mecca of Southern sixties soul, Muscle Shoals, Alabama.Excellent production, songwriting, musicianship, vocals...the works.

I don't view myself as a fan of new age music, yet I enjoy everything by this remarkably gifted composer and master of the guitar and other instruments.  How he comes up with gorgeous melody after gorgeous melody, so often lilting, intriguing and exotic, tropically breezy and refreshing (and with Latin motifs) is a secret for the ages, new or otherwise.  Phenomenal blend of guitars, acoustic and electric (and sitar on two tracks) and enjoyable percussion that is almost always strangely soothing.The opening track "Passage to Paradise" (so many of his titles are beautiful, inviting and exotic in and of themselves) is a paragon of this formula of musical loveliness; while the closer "Peruvian Joy" is sheer acoustic perfection - and will leave you joyful.  In-between, we get a few more tracks than usual of the electric variety that brush up against pop-rock and are not all that distant from some of Carlos Santana's purely instrumental work.  His uncharacteristic title for one of these, "Strat Your Stuff," reveals his affinity with some of the slightly edgier guitar guys.It may appear to be a contradiction in terms, but this is an intensely pleasant 52 minutes of music.

If I didn't know better and you told me this album was from 1972, I would believe it - and that's a compliment to the timeless, vintage nature of what 79-year-old R&B/soul-blues harp (harmonica) master Billy Boy Arnold and producer/guitarist Duke Robillard have put together here (13 years after their excellent collaboration "Boogie 'n' Shuffle").Arnold's wailing Sonny Boy Williamson [I]-influenced blues harp is always a highlight, but it's his astounding versatility that really carries the day here: everything from 1940s Louis Jordan jump blues to electric blues, to 1950s and '60s R&B, to early-'60s soul jazz, to late-'60s/early-'70s soul.  And he can really deliver the goods vocally in every one of these genres with his uniquely compelling, soulful and emotive, been-through-it-all singing.With 14 songs (including eleven covers of other artists) the highlights abound, but special mentions must go to the deeply emotive seven-and-a-half-minute gem of a performance on B.B. King's "Worried Dream" from 1967 (featuring standout electric blues guitar work by Robillard) and the 1960 soul-jazz classic "Work Song."  The latter receives its best vocal version since lyricist (and fellow Chicagoan) Oscar Brown, Jr.'s original interpretation.  Arnold's warm, sincere and confessional tone offers a different take on it and is so convincing that if I had the power I would see that he (the narrator of the tale) is immediately released from hard labor on the chain gang!Being a big fan of '60s and early-'70s soul, I am particularly pleased with his enthusiastic cover of Ray Charles's 1962 hit "Don't Set Me Free" (with searing saxes and trumpet, as well as Raelettes-style backing vocals), Mack Rice's undervalued "Coal Man" from 1969, the propulsive 1971 Ann Peebles B-side "99 Lbs.," and Joe Tex's brilliant 1972 social message song "A Mother's Prayer" (which unfortunately was largely overlooked as the flipside of his funky mega-hit "I Gotcha").The only misstep is that Arnold's repetitious, one-joke, double-entendre novelty-song closer "Keep On Rubbing," at six-minutes duration, goes on three times too long for sober ears (just a minor blip after thirteen very solid-to-superb tracks).This is the work of a true Chicago living legend and should not be missed.

"Reach Out: Chess Records at Fame Studios" chronology of hits (peak positions in Billboard listed):Laura Lee  "Wanted: Lover, No Experience Necessary" (1967)  #84 popIrma Thomas  "Good to Me" (1968)  #42 soulETTA JAMES  "SECURITY" (1968)*  #11 soul / #35 popLaura Lee "Hang It Up" (1969)  #48 soul* The Etta James hit "Security" and the two other included tracks from her hit LP "Tell Mama" appear for the first time in their original mono mixes (before they were "stereo-ized" back at Chess).  ("Security" was originally a lesser R&B hit in 1964 for Otis Redding, who wrote it.)Note that other big hits that resulted from this North-South collaboration (Bobby Moore & the Rhythm Ace's "Searching for My Love," Etta James's "Tell Mama," etc.) have been included in prior Fame compilations by Kent Soul.If you are expecting something special from a 24-track, 65-minute Kent Soul collection of late-1960s Chicago Chess Records artists recording with the phenomenal Muscle Shoals, Alabama musicians at Fame Studios under the supervision of Rick Hall, you are not going to be disappointed.Three of the four female Chess artists who were sent down there came out with hits, especially native Chicagoan Laura Lee and Etta James, the latter whose stalling R&B/soul-superstar career was resuscitated by the new Southern surroundings and tightly focused atmosphere.  New Orleans soul queen Irma Thomas's Chess output merited much greater success than what you see above, as the three tracks appearing here amply demonstrate.  The fourth outstanding female Chess artist, Mitty "I Had a Talk with My Man" Collier (originally from Birmingham, Alabama) is heard in a pair of previously unissued performances, including a particularly poignant take on the Don Gibson country ballad chestnut "Too Soon to Know."  The unusually deep rasp in her voice was due to vocal cord problems that led to a temporary cessation of her singing career.On the male side, we get three excellent tracks by the deep southern (Montgomery, Alabama-based) soul combo Bobby Moore & the Rhythm Aces, who had landed the very first Chess hit recorded at Fame (in '66), the national soul top ten and pop top 30 crossover smash "Searching for My Love" with their stellar vocalist Chico Jenkins.  How their powerhouse plaintive ballad "I Wanna Be Your Man," with its majestic soul horns, went nowhere is a bit of a mystery.None of the other male artists who went down to Fame scored hits.  Maurice and Mac, who split from The Radiants (of "Voice Your Choice" fame), sought to emulate Sam & Dave to no avail despite their fairly solid songs and very solid performances.  Singer-songwriter Lee Webber is positively Wilson Pickett-esque in his soul stylings, especially on his ultra-funky reading of the Beatles' "Good Day Sunshine."  This one is guaranteed to grab multiple spins.A real find here is the Fame tenor sax man Charles ("Charlie") Chalmers whom Chess recruited to record a soul-jazz instrumental LP (which was given the tacky title "Sax and the Single Girl," a play on a popular book and movie of the era).  Three undeniably cool tracks are included and are among my favorites.This set is full of rarities, and the overall quality never wanes.Kudos once again to compiler and sleeve notes author Tony Rounce for his peerless work.  As ever with Ace/Kent Soul, the sound mastering is impeccable, and the 16-page booklet - in addition to being so informative - is attractively adorned with photos and record realia.For anyone into this exhaustive Fame compilation series, there should be absolutely no hesitation about this one.

Caprice Records chronology of chart hits from 1961-62 (highest position on a national chart listed):Janie Grant  "Triangle" (1961)  #23Gerry Granahan  "Unchained Melody" (1961)  #109THE ANGELS  "'TIL" (1961)  #14Janie Grant  "Romeo" (1961)  #75JAMES RAY  "IF YOU GOTTA MAKE A FOOL OF SOMEBODY" (1962)  #10 R&B / #18 popThe Angels  "Cry Baby Cry" (1962)  #35Janie Grant  "Oh Johnny" (1962)  #89James Ray  "Itty Bitty Pieces"  (1962)  #41Janie Grant  "That Greasy Kid Stuff" (1962)  #701962 James Ray LP track covered by George Harrison in 1987:  "(I've) Got My Mind Set on You" [#1 in U.S. in January 1988]Vibrant and very appealing music on the independent American record label Caprice founded by then 21-year-old Gerry Granahan, already an experienced recording artist and record producer at that tender age.  All of the label's charting tracks (listed above) are included, plus all of its 12 other A-sides, for a total of 21 tracks, plus two previously unissued acetate duets with Granahan and Janie Grant (not that these are of any real interest beyond historical, I suppose.)The standout talents are clearly the ones who performed on the label's two biggest hits:  1) The New Jersey girl trio the Angels, who did a gloriously harmonized take on the 1957 easy listening standard "'Til."  Their more age-appropriate early-'62 follow-up "Cry Baby Cry" was even more affecting, IMO, even if it didn't burn up the charts to same extent as its predecessor.  Unluckily for Granahan and the label, the girls bolted for the Mercury subsidiary Smash; and true to that label's moniker they quickly broke through with one of the biggest hits of 1963, My Boyfriend's Back," a much tougher-sounding record and an oldies classic.  2) James Ray, a diminutive 20-year-old homeless Harlem kid with a powerful and soulful voice, was brought aboard by songwriter Rudy Clark to be a demo singer; but he proved ideal for the hybrid pop/R&B Clark song "If You Gotta Make a Fool of Somebody," which became a sizable crossover hit.  The excellent Clark-penned follow-up "Itty Bitty Pieces" was more raucous and narrowly missed the top 40 (while inexplicably being passed over by R&B radio).  Unsurprisingly, these were the two recording acts who got to record the label's only two LPs.  A brilliant extra is the inclusion here of the James Ray LP track "I've Got My Mind Set on You," which I'll take any day over the George Harrison remake 25 years later.  Sadly, Ray reverted to his drug habit (only this time presumably with a bit more cash on hand) and didn't live beyond his early twenties.  (The liner notes have him not making it to his 22nd birthday.)Also on the label, 15-year-old Janie Grant (real name: Rose Marie Casilli) came up with her own first two charting A-sides reflecting her young romantic experiences, "Triangle" and "Romeo."  The former went top 30 in both Billboard and Cashbox. (Incidentally, "Triangle," whose original session tape is missing, gets a superb DCS [Digital Constructed Stereo] makeover.)  Her next top side, "Unhappy Birthday," was penned by future '60s superstar songwriter Jeff Barry ("Da Doo Ron Ron," "Then He Kissed Me,"  "Be My Baby," "Baby I Love You," "Sugar Sugar," etc.) but went nowhere.  The song is excessively self-pitying, yet it's clearly a thematic forerunner of Lesley Gore's "It's My Party" without the Judy and Johnny name-drops.  She got back on the charts twice more: with an actual "Johnny" tune, "Oh Johnny," which dates back to 1917 (!); and the gimmicky, of-the-moment song "That Greasy Kid Stuff," which referred to a TV commercial for Vitalis hair tonic.  That was the label's final charting record.Granahan's own '61 records were cool ones: an uptempo version of "Unchained Melody" and a high-flyin' "Dance Girl Dance."  And for the epitome of obscure 1961 Caprice vocal cool, we have one-non-hit-wonder Jesse Dean's vocal version of the classic Jerry Lordan instrumental "Apache," a #1 monster hit for the Shadows in the UK and a #2 U.S. hit by Jorgen Ingmann.A fine 12-page accompanying booklet, containing photos, informative liner notes and the label's singles discography, is included.For anyone who disparages this era of youth-oriented American pop (1960-63) preceding the British Invasion, you might wish to reconsider somewhat after listening to this CD.

The only surprise here is that the actual song "Time and the River" (known best for the original 1960 Nat King Cole hit version) does not appear.  What is completely unsurprising is that David Sanborn - in his 25th LP and 40th year as a lead recording artist - comes through again with a terrific effort and another dazzling display of alto sax virtuosity.  I would also expect no less from a Marcus Miller production, as bassist Miller and saxophonist Sanborn have a collaboration on record going back 35 years.Sanborn's alto playing is as expressive, emotive, impassioned and soulful as ever, and the participation of the exceptional Afro-Cuban percussionist Javier Diaz makes this record even more refreshing and rhythmically exciting.  A spectacular choice for a cover, especially given Diaz's involvement, is D'Angelo's collaboration with Roy Hargrove, "Spanish Joint," from D'Angelo's 2000 album "Voodoo."  It's a funky Latin sizzler all the way.  Marcus Miller's original song contribution, "Seven Days Seven Nights," is strongly melodic and creates the impression of a kind of Latin-jazz "Take Five."  "A La Verticale" is a stunning opener with a brilliant arrangement featuring eleven instruments, including blistering electric guitar work by Yotam Silberstein in the second half when this track really takes flight.  By way of contrast, the closer is a short, simple, languid and lovely instrumental duet between Sanborn and pianist Roy Assaf on David Amram's theme from the 2004 version of the film "The Manchurian Candidate."  I admire all of these tracks immensely but I'll give the edge to his original, "Ordinary People," with its deep Latin-soul groove and Ricky Peterson on Hammond organ.Sanborn is a master at working with vocalists, especially soulful ones, and we get a pair of fine guest vocal performances here: Larry Briggs on "Can't Get Next to You," the 1969 and 1970 soul smash by the Temptations and Al Green, respectively (this version hews much closer to the funky Memphis groove of Green and his producer Willie Mitchell); and the sublimely soulful Randy Crawford doing her compelling best on "Windmills of Your Mind," the swirling Oscar-winning ballad from 1968 (the film "The Thomas Crown Affair") by Michel Legrand and Alan & Marilyn Bergman.  This is the finest version of it, IMO, since Dusty Springfield's in 1969.  (For music trivia fans: the original version was sung by the late Noel Harrison, son of Rex.)42:21 passes very quickly and enjoyably when listening to this outstanding music.

Considered the companion compilation to the previously well-received "Finders Keepers: Motown Girls 1961-1967" (which I reviewed 7/27/13 and also gave 4 stars to), this one is not quite up to it in quality - but only because it contains nothing that was issued in its day - whereas its distaff predecessor contained nine released recordings, including one by the Supremes, as well as one of Mary Wells's greatest hits.  So, not a completely level playing field.Motown did not bring in untalented performers or producers, so there is nothing here that is not competently rendered.  The problem in many cases was a logjam of releases causing tracks to get lost in the shuffle.  In some other cases, the songs themselves are undistinguished and not nearly up to the talent level of the performer(s).  A blatant example of this is Detroit's fantastic Fantastic Four (with their fantastic lead singer, James Epps) wasting their talent on a nothing of a song titled "I Wanna Say I Love You."  Another would be the phenomenal Edwin Starr getting stuck with the astoundingly trite "The Sound of Love."  One wonders who could do such a thing to this dynamo who recorded "Twenty-Five Miles," "War" and its terrific sequel "Stop the War Now."  There's a bit too much of this sort of thing going on here to allow me to enthusiastically endorse this collection.  (But wait, there is justification for a four-star recommendation on the way.)In another case, we have a track that was left in an unfinished state - and it's one of my favorite things here: Jimmy Ruffin doing "(Loneliness Made Me Realize) It's You That I Need" nearly a year before the Temptations had the big hit on it with Jimmy's brother David Ruffin doing the lead vocal.  With no background voices or extra musical "sweetening" (beyond the basic instrumental track) and Jimmy's voice dominating the track, it is fascinating to listen to such a high-risk/high-reward soul singer pre-"What Becomes of the Brokenhearted."  He is pure soul perfection deep into the song until he stays too long in his high register and breaks off key momentarily  (something that would have been easily fixed in a second take).  As compiler Keith Hughes says about this in his liner notes (excellent ones that cover each track in depth over 12 pages): "[A]n unfinished [Jimmy Ruffin track] is better than none at all" (and nothing else of his remains in the Motown vaults).In my estimation, the three completed most "must-have" tracks here are Marvin Gaye's January 1963 studio recording (as opposed to his issued "live" one) of the rousing "Mojo Hannah," which would have been an obvious R&B-chart smash single (but probably one with too little pop crossover potential for Motown's liking); Frank Wilson's drop-dead gorgeous self-penned ballad "Together 'Til the End of Time" (which only made it to #125 pop as a 1966 Brenda Holloway release); and veteran soul star Chuck Jackson's powerhouse take (in late 1967) on Holland-Dozier-Holland's "Where Did You Go," a 1965 Four Tops B-side.Overall, I found half of the 24 tracks to be enjoyable and a number of others to be listenable and/or of historical interest.

If this newly recorded and released CD sounds like one of the best Memphis soul albums from 1967 or 1968 that you have never heard until now, it might have something to do with the fact that this Minneapolis-based septuagenarian soul singer par excellence Willie Walker recorded three singles at Goldwax in Memphis in those years (two of which were leased to Chess for distribution) and sounds just as fresh and strong in 2015.  I would situate his expressive soul voice somewhere between Johnnie Taylor and Syl Johnson, both of whom put in time recording in Memphis, for the Stax and Hi labels, respectively.  Great work creating a completely convincing and compelling traditional sixties-sounding southern-soul album (with some blues and country influences) by producers Rick Estrin and Kid Anderson for Jim Pugh's (who plays organ and piano here) Little Village Foundation label.There are too many stellar tracks (of the twelve total) to enumerate here, but I have to start with the track that joins five others as my favorite all-time soul adaptations of Beatles songs.  As previously constituted, my list included Ray Charles's covers of "Yesterday" (1967) and "Eleanor Rigby" (1968); Joe Cocker's versions of "With a Little Help from My Friends" (1968) and "She Came in Through the Bathroom Window" (1969) and Esther Phillips' "And I Love Him" (1965).  Joining these now five decades later is the version of "Help!" heard here, a duet with Curtis Salgado that is hard to hear any other way than as an authentic deep southern soul ballad of desperation interpreted with intense feeling.  There are a few others that stun as old-school southern-soul ballads as well, including Willie Walker's own heart-wrenching "Not That I Care," Rick Estrin's touching original, "What Love Can Do," and an emotionally devastating take on John Conlee's top ten hit country ballad from 1982, "I Don't Remember You."  And I certainly can't leave out the other big ballad here, "If Nothing Ever Changes" (the title song, no less), a majestic soul blues with a social conscience, penned by local Minneapolis pianist Bruce Pedalty.  This one also features a powerful blues guitar solo by co-producer Kid Anderson.It's not all ballads as the relentlessly propulsive Willie Walker version of Eddie Hinton's "Everybody Meets Mr. Blue" definitively establishes.  It's one of a pair of Eddie Hinton ("the white Otis Redding") covers - the other being the closing mid-tempo consoler "Hymn for the Lonely Hearts."  The disc's opener "Read Between the Lines" (penned by Clarence Reid and Willie Clarke) is a hot Miami soul groover that also graced the late Michael Burks' final album "Show of Strength."  Rick Estrin finally unleashes his blues harp on Calvin Arnold's "Funky Way" (a 1967 song).  I mentioned Estrin's songwriting skill with the ballad "What Love Can Do," but he also contributed "Is That It?" with its Johnnie Taylor "Cheaper to Keep Her" vibe; while both producers collaborated on the old-school-R&B-sounding "Hands of Time" with its lesson that boils down to time wounds all heels ("payback is a...drag").  We also get a dose of mid-'70s funk/R&B with a version of Southside Movement's chilling and semi-creepy "I've Been Watching You." a Bobby Rush co-write.Did I say earlier I wasn't going to enumerate all twelve tracks?  I lied.Get this album if you're a '60s soul fan.  I hope they'll make more like this.  It may be 47-48 years later, but Wee Willie is still in his prime - possibly more so than ever!

With this, her fifth studio album, it is pretty much indisputable that Jessy J is the queen of Latin-tinged contemporary jazz saxophone (and she is excellent when she picks up the flute as well).  She is an impeccable player, and this is her best piece of work from start to finish.Seven songs here are originals - all of these co-written by Jessy J, who was involved in nearly all of the album's arrangements and some of the production.  Guitarist Paul Brown produced, recorded and mixed a number of tracks and plays on five.  Keyboardist Gregg Karukas also guest stars on four of the Paul Brown-produced tracks.Lead single "The Tango Boy" is endlessly catchy, with its relentlessly pulsating beat, and features Jessy J's most uninhibited playing.  Let's just call it the contemporary jazz original lead single of the year.  The Cuban-flavored "Paraso Mgico" (which I reference in my title here) is a joyous Caribbean delight with Jessy J on flute and leading the colorful Spanish-language chorus.  Catch the cool and clever, perfect ending of the song.  "Back to the Basics" is melodic (as is everything she composes) but has a cool, funky Latin beat and a particularly fine piano solo by Norman Jackson.  Opening original "Una Mas" combines gracefulness and soulfulness and is followed by the sultry and dreamy title ballad ("My One and Only One").  "Cuba" (we're back in the Caribbean!) has a swirling melody and features excellent drumming by Iajhi Hampden and a Wes Montgomery-esque guitar solo by Michael Angel.  "Siempre" features the sultry solo voice of Jessy J, as well as her flute stylings, and a very fine Rusian Sirota piano solo.Her three well-chosen cover versions, it seems to me, take her out of her usual bag and are the proof that she is the equal of anyone in this contemporary jazz (sometimes called "smooth jazz") genre.  Her take on The Cure's "Love Song" (or "Lovesong") is exquisite, possessing a beautiful, rich tenor tone.  The percussion, as well as Paul Brown's superb guitar backing and solo, all contribute to a stunning ballad track.  (IMO, this is one of the most gorgeous melodies to emerge from pop music in the last 20 years of the 20th century; and it's not hard to see why Adele would make it the only cover version on her second, incredibly successful LP, "21.")  Then there's the Jessy J version of Toni Braxton's #1 R&B and pop smash from 1996, "You're Makin' Me High."  It's melodic, soulful and grooving - and 6:22 seldom goes by this quickly.  Paul Brown outdoes himself on this one with his tasty guitar licks and red-hot blues-jazz solo.And finally (and it is in the closing [Trk 10] position) there's my favorite of all, an absolutely loaded-to-the-brim (Jessy J is heard on three instruments; and there is some rare programming here, but it all works in building an astounding wall of sound) instrumental cover of the phenomenal song "Strawberry Letter 23," composed by teenage genius Shuggie Otis in 1971, off his magnificent "Freedom Flight" LP, which I was lucky (or perceptive) enough to purchase at the time.  There is nothing more to say after this.Warning: This album is not recommended for jazz snobs and avant-gardists who prefer incoherent, out-of-tune saxophone screeching and fourteen-minute solos.

At 6'5" and 300 pounds (according to his blazingly brilliant autobiographical song "Texas Bluesman" - which also serves as a tribute to his Lone Star State musical heroes), Sugaray Rayford is one big bluesman possessing a full-throated baritone soul-blues voice that can really deliver the goods with compelling clarity and passion.  He executive-produced this CD and wrote or co-wrote every song (eight of the nine tracks on this 44-minute disc co-written with bassist Ralph Carter, who also co-produced), all of which are well-constructed and sound completely distinct from one another.The band, in addition to Carter, is first-rate and includes sax and trumpet (plus a guest appearance on the CD's one live track by blues harp virtuoso Bob Corritore), with guitarist Gino Matteo in stellar form throughout.I mentioned "Texas Bluesman" and should also give props to the paragon of Sugaray's impassioned singing, "Take Away These Blues," as well as the socially committed pro-peace-and-brotherhood-and-the-environment "Call Off the Mission"; the sincere and personal "Live to Love Again" ("if I live to love again, I'll be a better man next time"); the funky and hot "Miss Thang"; and the enthusiastic invitation for fun on the "Southside of Town."  Only the nearly-seven-minute bedroom-seducer closer "Slow Motion" threatens to wear out its welcome (although I realize it's more for "doing" than listening - in which case seven minutes isn't long enough!).This is one of the year's best in the soul-blues arena.

Chronology of Isley Brothers chart hits (1966-69) at Motown [soul / U.S. pop (highest position on a national chart listed) / U.K.]:"THIS OLD HEART OF MINE (IS WEAK FOR YOU)" (1966)  [#2 soul / #12 pop / #3 UK (in '68)]"Take Some Time Out for Love" (1966)  [#66 pop]"I Guess I'll Always Love You" (1966)  [#31 soul / #52 pop / #11 UK (in '69)]"Got to Have You Back" (1967)  [#47 soul / #93 pop]"That's the Way Love Is" (1967)  [#105 pop]"Take Me in Your Arms (Rock Me a Little While)"  [#22 soul / #97 pop]"Behind a Painted Smile" (1968)  [#5 UK (in '69)]LP: "This Old Heart of Mine" (1966)  [#15 soul / #140 pop]The question is whether or not the Isleys should have stayed with their own new T-Neck label in '65 instead of joining Motown, where as you can see they only had one top 20 U.S. hit during these prime years of the 1960s.  After they left Motown and resumed on T-Neck in '69, all their first record "It's Your Thing" did was go to #1 soul (spending four weeks at the top) and #2 pop, en route to taking home the best R&B vocal group Grammy.  I for one am glad they went to Motown, if for no other reason than they got to work with Holland-Dozier-Holland in their prime, which resulted in their classic hit "This Old Heart of Mine (Is Weak for You)," one that graced my collection at the time.  Had they not been there, some other group or artist would certainly have had a hit with it (it may actually be my favorite H-D-H song, which is really saying something!), but no one could have done it better.  That song and Ronald Isley's voice were made for each other.  Its follow-up, "Take Some Time Out for Love," by its title sounds like a relaxed ballad, but instead it's rockin' R&B more like their earlier more raucous and raw pre-Motown stuff.Next best for me, after "This Old Heart of Mine," is the intriguing and dramatic "Behind a Painted Smile," from two years later, which inexplicably went nowhere in the U.S. yet climbed all the way to #5 in the UK in '69.  The following year something similar happened when Jimmy Ruffin's "It's Wonderful," a non-charting Motown record in the U.S., rose to #6 in the U.K.  And speaking of Jimmy Ruffin, Disc 2, Trk 3 of this collection contains the unissued original version of "What Becomes of the Brokenhearted," which bore the incongruous title of "Smile."  We hear the same basic backing track as on the immortal Jimmy Ruffin ballad, but with completely different lyrics, which are threadbare and don't come close to matching the majestic melody.  The song was altered to "Crying in the Night" and then finally "What Becomes of the Brokenhearted."The Isleys' version of "Take Me in Your Arms (Rock Me a Little While)" is relentlessly pulsating, and it's clear why it became a hit again just three years after Motown's Kim Weston had a #4 soul hit with it.  "I Guess I'll Always Love You" was a bouncy 1966 semi-hit (and another one that saw far greater success a few years later in Britain), but so often in this collection it's the Isleys' recordings of material done first by other Motown artists that we encounter.  This kind of recycling was par for the course at Motown but was ultimately not going to allow the group to get many breakout hits of their own.  Besides the competent covers of Marvin Gaye's "Baby, Don't You Do It" and "How Sweet It Is (To Be Loved by You)" (there's a large area of overlap between Ronald Isley's and Marvin Gaye's voices), there are entirely too many tracks here that sound like they could be Marvin Gaye B-sides or LP tracks.  Not that I particularly mind that, as I liked those songs, and both Gaye and the Isleys gave their full commitment to everything they did during this period.  But for the Isleys' advancement, it was not a good thing that so much of the material they were given was not standing out from the pack.Other particularly strong cover versions are H-D-H's "I Hear a Symphony," which would have been a huge hit for them had they gotten to Motown earlier and arm-wrestled the Supremes for it; "Greetings (This Is Uncle Sam)," which distinguishes itself from the Monitors' semi-hit version by specifically referring to the war in Vietnam (certainly Motown's first reference to it in song); the Four Tops' B-side "Sad Souvenirs"; and an admirably rough take on Paul Revere & the Raiders' "Good Thing."  I would include "Whispers (Gettin' Louder)" in this list, but Jackie Wilson's soaring vocals on the original hit version just can't be matched.The emotive ballad "Nevermore" probably features the best vocal performance here among the unissued tracks  Two other notable ones are the Smokey Robinson-penned "It's Out of the Question" and "Little Miss Sweetness."There are unquestionably a few too many tracks that don't make much of an impression, but I can't penalize this collection for being TOO inclusive when there is so much of value here.  (Total running time for the 52 tracks/two discs: 2 hours, 25 minutes plus.)  The sound is excellent (the final eight tracks feature stereo or alternate mono versions ["I Guess I'll Always Love You" is heard three ways]) and the booklet is attractive, although nowhere near as comprehensive or informative as what Ace compilations offer.

One of a series of superb Ace/Kent Soul anthologies, this one may be the most fun due to the fact that the Monitors were so undeservedly obscure.  Sometimes referred to as a "second-tier" Motown act, with only five singles and one LP in a six-year period, "third-tier" might be more like it.  If it hadn't been for a regular local (Detroit) lounge gig, they couldn't have afforded to remain with Motown as long as they did.  More than for any particular recording, the group is undoubtedly most well known for its outstanding lead singer Richard Street, who subsequently became a Temptation for 24 years after being brought in as Paul Williams' replacement in 1971.  Street was also employed as a member of Motown's famous Quality Control Department and got to witness up close for a time all the label's great material winding up with other acts.This collection manages to cobble together the Monitors' sole LP (from 1968, which also happened to be their final release for the label), their five singles (all of whose A-sides were on the LP), their two non-LP B-sides, and twelve previously unreleased recordings, for a total of 26 tracks and a 70-minute running time.The fine title song of this collection ("Say You") showed the Monitors at their mid-tempo smoothest.  It was the first of their four singles, but despite breaking big in their home town of Detroit, it only went to #36 soul nationally and did not cross over to pop at all.  Their second 1966 release, "Greetings (This Is Uncle Sam)," was their only semblance of a significant hit, reaching #21 soul in Billboard while barely squeezing into the top 100 of all three national pop charts at the time.  Originally a 1961 semi-novelty R&B harmony song by the early (integrated) Motown group The Valadiers, this lightweight take on being drafted into the military took on an entirely different, ironic tone in 1966 with the war in Vietnam then raging.  Suddenly, the line, "Please don't take me, Uncle Sam" could be heard as a genuine plea of protestation.One can easily make a case for the Monitors' two 1967 single A-sides being their best: "Since I Lost You Girl," is a sizzler with an impassioned lead vocal by Richard Street, who co--wrote the song with co-Monitor Warren Harris and producers Harvey Fuqua and Johnny Bristol.  Chart-wise, It appeared only as "bubbling under" the Billboard pop Hot 100 [at #117].  Even better (and really sounding like a can't miss hit IMO, although it didn't chart nationally at all) is the William Weatherspoon/James Dean (of "What Becomes of the Brokenhearted" fame) produced and co-penned "Bring Back the Love."  It's intense and insistent and really pleads its case, while the Motown Funk Brothers go to town on it.  Street, the record expert, thought it "was the closest one [to being a big hit for the Monitors] out of all them; that if they'd played it, it should have been a hit."1968 brought their last single, both sides of which were written and produced by Weatherspoon and Dean.  Top side "Step by Step (Hand in Hand)" cheerleads catchily for uniting in positive social action.  Not that much of an attention-grabber, but any social engagement in a Motown record was relatively rare prior to 1970.  The B-side "Time Is Passin' By" is yet another intense and compelling Weatherspoon/Dean composition right up there with "Bring Back the Love."On the1968 "Greetings (We're the Monitors)" LP, by far the best of the songs not already mentioned is their very deft cover of Jay & the Techniques' easily melodic "Baby Make Your Own Sweet Music."Nearly half of this collection is made up of previously unreleased tracks, and there is hardly a difference in quality between most of these and the released material.  For me, the most essential track of this whole collection is the one that Weatherspoon/Dean and "What Becomes of the Brokenhearted" fans can't do without: "Crying in the Night" is the sped-up sibling of "What Becomes..."  The history is a bit convoluted but suffice to say that "What Becomes..." and this one sprang up from the same source.  While on the subject of Motown classics, here also is an early version of "Too Busy Thinking About My Baby," which morphed into a Marvin Gaye smash two years later.  Johnny Rivers twice paid homage to Motown with his hit covers of the Four Tops' "Baby I Need Your Loving" and Smokey & the Miracles "Tracks of My Tears"; so why not (?) a reverse tribute with the Monitors taking on Johnny Rivers' own #1 record from 1966, "Poor Side of Town," which Rivers wrote with producer Lou Adler.  It's a good one, heard here for the first time.  Also of note is the Monitors' first crack at the Smokey Robinson co-penned-and-produced "The Letter."  It's melodically coherent and insistent (as one expects from a Smokey song), with moving lyrics (another Smokey trait), and it has a cool arrangement with horns.  Alas, it too got shelved (and a new version appeared the following year as a David Ruffin LP track).Richard Street describes the Monitors' fate at Motown best when he states that the group got "lost in the shuffle" at Motown.Ace/Kent Soul does it again with its stellar sound mastering and deluxe 20-page accompanying booklet full of photos and color (featuring the de rigueur record jacket and label repros)...and especially 17 pages of comprehensive and informative liner notes (and detailed credits with each song's recording history) by co-compiler (with Tony Rounce) and Motown historian Keith Hughes.  And obviously, it really helps to have Richard Street's lucid commentary woven so seamlessly into the notes.

I can hardly believe that there is yet another outstanding Johnnie Taylor LP (this one from 1977) that I'm first hearing now all these years later.  It is essentially a Detroit album (produced by Don Davis) recorded in Muscle Shoals, Alabama - making it quite an unbeatable combination (the best of two soul worlds), one that reflects back to JT's real persona as a soul artist (without a trace of anything synthetic or disco: think JT at Stax) and presages his final stop as a recording artist way down south in Jackson, Mississippi at Malaco Records, where he would again consistently excel with his patented mix of soul, blues and occasional scooch of pop done soulfully.  This obscure, one-off effort for RCA came between charting albums for Columbia but charted nowhere itself (nor did the one single off it top-sided by the LP's leadoff track "I Want You Back Again").  Unfortunately, the previous few (post-Stax) years had found JT having to compromise for commercial success, which meant dropping the blues altogether and watering down the soul in favor of dance-oriented pop-funk.  This project got his soul-blues juices flowing again, and he delivered 32 minutes (eight tracks) of completely committed performances in the service of very good to excellent material.Up to now, when I have thought of the finest soul covers of 1960s pop and rock, the records that would spring to mind were Otis Redding doing the Rolling Stones' "Satisfaction"; Ray Charles's takes on both of the Paul McCartney/Beatles' songs "Yesterday" and "Eleanor Rigby," as well as Wilson Pickett doing "Hey Jude"; and Bobby Womack's version of "California Dreamin'."  From this trouvaille of an LP, and joining their ranks, is JT's knockout reading of the Association's "Never My Love."  Call him "Johnnie Taylor the all-out soul wailer" on this rousing, emotive soul triumph that just keeps building all the way.  It's a powerhouse track featuring a terrific Wade Marcus arrangement with dramatic backing vocals.In addition to "Never My Love," I recognized the mature and compassionate soul ballad "I Worry About You" from a 1968 Joe Simon single.  The rest are originals that all impress in their own way: "Forgive and Forget" is the closer and it takes us out with some heartfelt and authentic JT blues wailing.  "Stop Half Lovin' These Women" delivers a message the guys had better heed.  It features some down-home soul rapping, not unlike what Bobby Womack was becoming known for in the '70s while recording in Muscle Shoals (a style which can be traced back to Joe Tex in the mid-'60s).  His ode to frustration, "Wanting What You Can't Have," begins with some unearthly JT screams as it moves into the territory of those relentless '70s "blaxploitation"-type movie themes.  "Heaven Bless This Home" gets down to some serious prayerful pleading as JT calls out for his woman to come home for the sake of their children.  He doles out more advice to the guys on "If You Really Love Your Girl (Show It)," a sweet and sincere southern-soul-style ballad.I'm grateful to finally be able to hear this superbly recorded and performed Southern soul LP (that I didn't even know existed!) on a high-quality Fever Dream CD.

At 79, Buddy Guy may be the last surviving still actively recording link to both the blues of the Deep South and the 1960s Chicago electric blues scene.  I was wondering what he would do next (in 2015) now that we are definitively in the post-B.B. King era.  What I wasn't really expecting was this, one of his greatest albums ever.For the first six tracks of this 14-track, 59-minute disc, I was thinking this is very entertaining, very upbeat, sounds great, is well produced (by drummer Tom Hambridge, who wrote or co-wrote all twelve of the original songs here - five with Buddy); and although "five-star"-worthy for sure, not necessarily one of his all-time best.  Then came Trk 7 and the stellar soul blues of "Crying Out of One Eye" (featuring the Muscle Shoals Horns) and a whole parade of fantastic tracks all the way through the closing pair of heart-felt tributes: to B.B. King (the stunning gospel-soul-blues duet "Flesh & Bone" with Van Morrison), and the other to his great mentor and friend Muddy Waters (the poignant and brilliantly played - on dual acoustic guitars [with Doyle Bramhall II] - "Come Back Muddy").Although the opening title track seeks to explain Buddy's lifelong (or at least since the age of two!) obsession with the guitar, it's Trk 8, "Turn Me Wild," which contains his single best encapsulating refrain: "The blues done turn me wild, dug deep down in my soul."  "Thick Like Mississippi Mud" (Trk 12) is the real, deep southern stuff again with the Muscle Shoals Horns (who jumped on over to Nashville where this LP was recorded) and Buddy's plaintive and scorching 1957 Stratocaster guitar licks.Besides the moving B.B. King homage with Van Morrison, Trk 8 takes the cover version duet cake with a terrific R&B (accent on the "B") remake of Brook Benton & Dinah Washington's all-time classic from 1960, "(Baby) You've Got What It Takes" [the #1 R&B record of the year; and it even got to #2 pop in Cash Box], with Joss Stone doing an astoundingly effective job with the Dinah Washington part.  Both of them sound genuinely inspired.  Not to slight the other guest stars,  Billy Gibbons of Z.Z. Top provides a throaty vocal and blistering guitar alongside Buddy on the raucous, pounding  Texas shuffle "Wear You Out" (one of those early tracks I found so entertaining); and Kim Wilson of Fabulous Thunderbirds fame guests on harmonica (reminiscent of Junior Wells with Buddy) on Little Walter's "Too Late" (a Willie Dixon co-write from 1953), as well as on the spunky original, "Kiss Me Quick."Lastly, something has to be said about Trk 10, another masterpiece (penned by Guy, Hambridge and Gary Nicholson), called "Crazy World."  If you have always wanted to hear Buddy Guy express his deepest thoughts about the state of our beleaguered planet - socially, economically, ecologically; crying out against the injustices (as he backs himself with startlingly emotive "wah-wah" guitar riffs) - this is it.  Very powerful, without trying to be overpowering - and an original-song-of-the-year candidate with "Crying Out of One Eye" (if I have anything to say about it...which of course I don't). I have nothing else to say at this time, as I need to listen to this phenomenal album again (for the I've-lost-count-of-how-many-eth-time in these past few days).

Bobby Womack "Across 110th Street"/"Facts of Life"/"Lookin' for a Love Again" Charly [UK] hit chronology (peak positions on national soul [Billboard] and pop [Billboard or Cash Box] singles charts):"Across 110th Street" (1973)  #19 soul / #49 pop"Nobody Wants You When You're Down and Out" (1973)  #2 soul / #29 pop"I'm Through Trying to Prove My Love to You" (1973) * #80 soul / #101 pop* B-side of "Nobody Wants You...""Lookin' for a Love" (1974)  #1 soul (for 3 wks) / #8 pop"You're Welcome, Stop On By" (1974)  #5 soul / #53 popOn the Billboard LP chart:"Across 110th Street" (1973)  #6 soul / #50 pop"Facts of Life" (1973)  #6 soul / #37 pop"Lookin' for a Love Again" (1974)  #5 soul / #85 pop"Across 110th Street":  Isaac Hayes's "Theme from Shaft" won the 1971 Academy Award for best original song, and that seemed to assuage the Hollywood establishment's guilt over ignoring black singer-songwriters; so much so that the following year they completely bypassed the greatest film soundtrack/song combination ever (IMO) in Curtis Mayfield's "Superfly" original score and song "Freddie's Dead."  To this I would add the third greatest "blaxploitation" film theme (in three consecutive years), Bobby Womack's "Across 110th Street," which he wrote with his soundtrack collaborator J.J. Johnson.  Again, no nominations, but it's a keenly observed, dynamic recording that was worthy of greater recognition.  The LP is almost equally divided between Womack vocals and J.J. Johnson & His Orchestra instrumentals; and it's all cool stuff, although not nearly at the level of the title song (which also appears in instrumental form with powerful, emphatic horns and a hot organ solo at the end).  Two other fine Womack songs here are the relaxed and resigned, mid-tempo "If You Don't Want My Love" and the relentless soul-blues-funk of "Do It Right," punctuated by Bobby's James Brown-esque (or Wilson Pickett-esque) soul screams."Facts of Life" is most notable for the strength and variety of its cover versions, starting with what I think is his Womack's all-time best in this category: his take on the brilliant 1920s blues song "Nobody Wants You When You're Down and Out," made famous by Bessie Smith's immortal 1929 rendition.  His mentor Sam Cooke also recorded it in 1961. which certainly would have inspired him, but remarkably he perfectly adapts the song to his own voice and style, rendering it virtually unrecognizable as anything other than a Bobby Womack record.  His cover of Sam Cooke and the Soul Stirrers' "That's Heaven to Me" is a direct and beautiful tribute to Cooke.  "I'm Through Trying to Prove My Love to You" is sheer Bobby Womack in its testifying style straight out of the mold of his earlier hit "That's the Way I Feel About Cha."  The last three tracks are all late-'60s ('67-68) covers:  Burt Bacharach-Hal David's "The Look of Love," originally recorded by Dusty Springfield as the theme from the James Bond film "Casino Royale," "A Natural Man," which is his gender-reversed take on Carole King/Gerry Goffin's song for Aretha Franklin - one of her great signature recordings at Atlantic; and Bob Dylan's "All Along the Watchtower," which Jimi Hendrix made his own with his transcendent electric guitar-powered psychedelic-blues-rock version.  "Look of Love" is done in the manner of his gritty-cool '60s covers of the pop hits "Fly Me to the Moon" and "California Dreamin'"; "A Natural Man" is subdued and poignantly soulful; and the closing "All Along the Watchtower" gets an emphatic soul reading with searing guitar backing, but it's no match for Hendrix.The "Lookin' for a Love Again" LP is dominated by the fantastically propulsive title song, which was Bobby Womack's biggest hit single ever, both soul (the #3 soul hit of 1974) and pop (his only ten pop-chart record ever).  Of historical note, it was a remake of the biggest hit The Valentinos (a.k.a. the five Womack Brothers) ever had: the gospel-influenced soul rocker (featuring an 18-year-old Bobby) on Sam Cooke's SAR label reached #8 R&B and was clearly ahead of its time.  Also here is the 1974 follow-up hit soul single with an easy-going, conversational style, "You're Welcome, Stop On By," as well as the smoothly delivered slice of Southern soul, "You're Messing Up a Good Thing."This is an excellent collection solidly housed in great-looking hard-cover book form (featuring a scene from "Across 110th Street" on the cover) with secure, smooth-plastic disc holders on both sides of a 16-page booklet replete with full-color cover art (and additional photos), three pages of song listings and writing credits, and seven pages of informative liner notes by Roger Dopson.  In tandem with the 2015 Charly box set "Preacher" (which I reviewed 7/24/15), all of Bobby Womack's first eight LPs are included in two neat packages with first-rate sound mastering.

This is the second Real Gone CD in just over three months to unearth a "lost" Dusty Springfield (unissued) LP from the turn of the 1970s.  First came "Faithful" (which I reviewed 5/5/15), intended for U.S. release on Atlantic in 1971; and now this one for Philips recorded in London in '70 and '71.  Some of these tracks did come out on a "hodgepodge" (meant disparagingly by critics) British LP in 1972, as did others on much later CD anthologies.  But now, as with "Faithful," we get a coherent and complete collection of what could have been had Philips originally included all of this material on a single LP, along with concurrent non-LP singles.  (A major problem in both cases was that Dusty prematurely bolted for ABC/Dunhill.  The story is beyond convoluted, but it receives full explication in Joe Marchese's six pages of comprehensive, highly informative liner notes.)What matters at this time is the quality of the music and Dusty's work - and there are no problems at all on that score.  There are absolutely gorgeous, beautifully orchestrated ballad covers (Michel Legrand/Alan & Marilyn Bergman's "What Are You Doing the Rest of Your Life?"; Charles Aznavour's "Yesterday When I Was Young"; the Rascals' "How Can I Be Sure"; Leon Russell's "A Song for You"); more ace songwiter material (Carole King/Gerry Goffin's "I Wasn't Born to Follow"; Jimmy Webb's "Mixed Up Girl"); soft and sensual bossa nova songs (A.C. Jobim's "Come for a Dream" [title tune of this collection]; the enigmatic "See All Her Faces" [title song of the 1972 "hodgepodge" LP]; "Goodbye," composed specifically for her by Spike Milligan); pure pop ("Let Me Down Easy" and the Roger Cook/Roger Greenaway/Tony Burrows hit-factory-sounding "Sweet Inspiration"); as well as recent U.S. girl soul (Betty Wright's "Girls Can't Do What the Guys Do"; The Honey Cone's "Girls It Ain't Easy"; and The Glass House's "Crumbs Off the Table").I happen to appreciate Dusty's mastery of all these genres and have no objections to their being mixed together.  The "hodgepodge" charge seems too facile for me, since you know that if there were nothing but soft ballads and pop, it could just as easily be dismissed by naysayers as "unadventurous," "monotonous,"or the lazybones' favorite, "boring."As with the earlier "Faithful, I can't recommend this collection highly enough for Dusty Springfield fans.

In 1963, as a kid in my second year of collecting 45 rpm records, the very first time I heard the Cascades' "Rhythm of the Rain" on the radio I knew where my next dollar was going.  It came between Del Shannon's "Little Town Flirt" and Skeeter Davis's "The End of the World," and I bought it at the same time as The Rockin' Rebels' instrumental "Wild Weekend."  (Somehow I had managed to scrape two dollars together!)  This was late January outside Chicago, but the elements were not going to hold me back.  In my world at the time, "Rhythm of the Rain" was a masterpiece pop record, and I have never wavered from that view.  It got to #2 in Chicago on WLS radio (890 AM), #2 nationally in Cash Box, #3 nationally in both Billboard and Music Vendor, and even crossed the pond reaching #5 in the UK.  Especially cool was the fact that "Rhythm" was able to cross over onto the R&B charts and place as high as #7.The follow-up 45 came along in April.  In Chicago, only the moving and gorgeous ballad "The Last Leaf" got played, and it rose to #14 on the WLS Silver Dollar Survey.  However, nationally the other excellent side "Shy Girl" received more initial airplay until "The Last Leaf" took over.  This radio exposure split was a setback for "Leaf," the higher charting side, which only got to #42 in Cash Box and #60 on the Billboard Hot 100.  (Due to being tapped out from my prior purchases I couldn't get this fine double-sided hit 45.)The big selling points to this Teensville collection from Sydney, Australia are:1) its thoroughness: this is by far the most comprehensive disc covering the Cascades era with John Claude Gummoe (founding member, lead singer and writer of "Rhythm of the Rain"), as it contains all of the group's recordings on Valiant and RCA (and four unreleased tracks), plus significant material from three other labels.2) its 33 tracks and total running time of 80:14 (not a misprint; it exceeds 79:59 by 15 seconds)3) its flawless all-stereo sound4)  the neat 12-page booklet with an introduction by John Claude Gummoe, Mr. "Rhythm of the Rain" himself; seven pages of concise, informative liner notes; color label scans; photos of the group, as well as of Gummoe alone from 1960 (pre-Cascades) and 1995.5) the music itself, obviously; but of special note are four of the last five tracks:- Trk 29: "I Bet You Won't Stay" (Liberty/1965) - written for the Cascades by a British fan of the group, none other than Ray Davies of the Kinks!  It has a cool jangly mid-'60s British beat sound, with emphatic vocals, and is one of the group's finest records.  How it could have been largely ignored is anyone's guess.  (I suppose it's possible that no one was expecting this type of record from this group.  Too bad - but at least we can hear it now!)-Trks 30 & 31:  "Truly Julie's Blues" and "Cheryl's Goin' Home" (Arwin [label]/1966) - a pair of top-notch Bob "Elusive Butterfly" Lind covers, the latter of which "bubbled under" all three national top 100 singles charts at the time.- "bonus" track 33: "Rhythm of the Rain (Millennium Version)" [2005 recording] - John Claude Gummoe's beautifully produced home-studio-recorded (with storm and rain effects) updated version of his classic.  It's dreamier and more reflective (hence slower) than the original, and his voice had matured and mellowed into magnificence, maintaining an easy and natural high register.Overall, this is an outstanding collection.  For Cascades/"Rhythm of the Rain" fans it is an essential one.  By dint of its very thoroughness though, a number of rather instantly forgettable lesser tracks - trite, saccharine romantic (young love) ballads - tend to weigh it down a bit in the middle; however, the Cascades' commitment and sheer harmonic talent are always there, making even these tracks listenable.  The numerous musical high points - especially the two towering versions of "Rhythm of the Rain" - along with the superb production and presentation, make this an exceptional single-group sixties compilation.

No question, this is largely diatribe with a lot of repetitive overkill and heavy-handedness; and attempting to listen to the entire 51 minutes in a single sitting will become ponderous, for sure.  Yet, one can admire Neil's single-minded focus and be grateful for a singer-songwriter (backed by an outstanding group of musicians) who is not preoccupied with self and who is willing to take on what he considers to be a broader global danger.  I find it impossible to doubt the sincerity of his belief that hypercorporatist greed is destroying our way of life and our freedom - and ultimately poses an existential threat to our planet.Two of his songs talk about love but not in a mundane way.  "People Want to Hear About Love" is an engagingly tuneful rocker that deals with the subject ironically, while "A New Day for Love" offers a heartfelt message of hope for the future.The country-tinged rocker "Workin' Man" pulls no punches in describing the plight of small farmers, whom mega-agribusiness is out to crush (if they resist being wholly exploited) using its high-priced corporate attorneys (U.S. Supreme Court justice Clarence Thomas - who was once one of these Monsanto "men with briefcases" - gets called out for his hypocrisy in this matter)."A Rock Star Bucks a Coffee Shop," with its punny title and jaunty melody (featuring happy-go-lucky whistling, no less!) is all in-your-face irony, as its lyrics just continue to pile on the outrage to this upbeat tune.  The title track piles it on thick as well, only it's heavy, plodding, repetitious, long and drawn out.By the way, for anyone who thinks Neil Young sings off key, have you ever heard him before?
