He has always sung in his OWN key!  There is nothing new to say on this score.  Q magazine's Mark Blake describes the "grizzled and angry" Young's voice as one that "creaks like an un-oiled silo door."  At least he said nothing new in a new way!  No doubt that the more layered the sound of a track is behind him, the better he sounds.What really makes this album a winner is the presence of a near masterpiece: the song "Big Box" (which calls out Walmart by name in one verse) gets everything right musically and lyrically.  It is an epic, superbly constructed track that really hits the bull's-eye.  Even with its 8:16 running time it doesn't seem too long.  I would almost go so far as to call it a "Layla" for this century, only political.From "Big Box": "[Plundering, law-breaking] corporations [are getting] too big to fail, too rich for jail...some way, somehow we will prevail."Write on, Neil!The DVD includes complete versions of every song as they are being recorded.  Superb sound and cinematography.

The Fantastic Four were the rare case of a group that was hot until they joined Motown, hot again after they left Motown, but who had nearly nothing to show for their time there.  In fact, these native Detroiters' one hit record at Motown, "I Love You Madly" (not in this collection) originally came out on their previous label and was then transferred to Motown's Soul imprint (the label home of Jr. Walker & the All Stars, Gladys Knight & the Pips, and Jimmy Ruffin).  At Motown they did not receive consistent support and were relegated to second-tier (arguably third-tier) status.  (One of their members called it being "put on the shelf.")  However, they themselves were as consistent as could be, as one can hear across the 25 tracks found here: 12 which were for a projected LP that never materialized, and 13 additional tracks.  Both sides of their three issued 1969-1970 singles (the only ones recorded at Motown) are here.  I knew of this Detroit group when they were with their previous label (Ric Tic) and had their 1968 soul-chart single "I've Got to Have You," but I never heard these three before.The Fantastic Four were blessed with an outstanding, powerhouse lead singer in the portly form of "Sweet" James Epps, whom I would situate voice-wise between Darrell "Open the Door to Your Heart" Banks and Motown's David Ruffin.  Since the projected LP was going to be called "How Sweet He Is," there was no doubt that the plan was to spin James off as a solo act.For me, the two most outstanding tracks by a mile from "How Sweet He Is," which should have been A-side singles in my estimation, are their fantastic (hey, it's the right adjective for these!), exquisitely rendered cover versions of Marvin Gaye & Tammi Terrell's beautiful duet ballad "If This World Were Mine" (written by Marvin) and Jerry Butler's cleverly tuneful "Just Can't Forget About You."  Both of these in their original releases had been B-sides and thus way undervalued. - meaning, there could have been huge hit potential to exploit.  "If This World Were Mine" was the flip side of "If I Could Build My Whole World Around You" and did not receive anywhere near the kind of attention it deserved: only #27 soul nationally and #68 pop.  Butler's "Just Can't Forget About You," as the flip side of the #1 soul (and #16 pop) smash "Hey, Western Union Man," was completely ignored.  The singles that were put out on the Fantastic Four were solid but just wouldn't have stood out from the crowd enough to have had much impact (that and the lack of promotion).The bonus tracks feature a killer version of Johnny Bristol's "I'm Still a Struggling Man," which went on to become Edwin Starr's follow-up hit to "Twenty-Five Miles."  Three Bobby Taylor-produced tracks - "Loving You (Is Hurting Me), "I Hate Myself for Loving You" and "Fan the Flame" - are excellent, emotive (as the titles suggest) midtempo ballads.  ("Fan the Flame," co-written by Smokey Robinson, originally appeared on a Temptations LP.)  The uptempo, very catchy and well-constructed "In a Bad Way" would have been another fine choice for a Fantastic Four single - it had originally been a 1964 Freddie Gorman single on Ric Tic and was worthy of a second chance.This is a typically outstanding Ace/Kent Soul compilation.  The sound mastering is flawless - and included is the obligatory Ace booklet with photos that never fails.  Co-compiler Tony Rounce's six pages of liner notes tell the Fantastic Four's story about as well as it can be told in this format.  Sadly, as we learn in the final paragraph, none of the original Fantastic Four survived to see this "long-overdue retrospective of their time at Motown..."  But Fantastic Four fans now have this pleasure.

"Here Today! The Songs of Brian Wilson" Hit Parade (peak national pop chart positions indicated):Jan & Dean  "New Girl in School" (1964)  #26The Hondells  "My Buddy Seat" ('64-65)  #61The Tokens  "Don't Worry Baby" (1970)  #71Hugo Montenegro  "Good Vibrations" (1969)  #87Bobby Vee  "Here Today" (1966)  #122My top 13 (out of 25 total tracks), which includes "New Girl in School," "Don't Worry Baby" and "Here Today" (listed above) -[chronological order]:The Surfaris  "Don't Hurt My Little Sister" (1965)Keith Green  "Girl Don't Tell Me" (1965)Bruce & Terry (Bruce Johnston & Terry Melcher)  "Help Me Rhonda" (1965/unissued until 1998)Johnny Wells  "Guess I'm Dumb" (UK/1967)Carmen McRae  "Don't Talk (Put Your Head on My Shoulder)" (1967)Nick DeCaro  "Caroline, No" (1968)Little Peggy March  "Aren't You Glad?" (1968)Betty Everett  "God Only Knows" (1975)Kirsty MacColl  "You Still Believe in Me" (1981)Darian Sahanaja  "Do You Have Any Regrets?" (1994)Of the above ten, a trio of women (Carmen McRae, Betty Everett and Kirsty MacColl) rule.  Jazz chanteuse Carmen McRae's recording - produced in London by Johnny Keating, replete with theremin - is a near masterpiece among Brian Wilson/Beach Boys cover versions.  Betty Everett's Gene-and-Billy-Page-produced "God Only Knows" is an emphatically soulful mid-'70s take on the classic tune.  And Kirsty MacColl's "You Still Believe in Me" qualifies as an outright masterpiece, taking into account all aspects of the multi-layered production supporting her magnificent, deeply connected reading of the poignant "Pet Sounds" ballad from fifteen years earlier.The problem with this compilation, though, involves the other twelve tracks which do not make my cut.  Most of them are concentrated in the middle of the disc, creating kind of a doughnut effect.  Tracks 11 through 17 take the inconsequentiality cake, with Jay & the Americans' "Things Are Changing" (a Bob Dylan rip-off title) hitting rock bottom (in more ways than one).  It's actually a bizarre piece of Phil Spector-produced propaganda (in the form of an extended public service announcement) urging poor minority kids to go out and get jobs which were supposedly so plentiful.  This is an even preachier and more dumbed-down quasi sequel to Jay & the Americans' jingoistic 1963 hit that proclaimed, "Only in America, land of opportunity..."  This feels like the longest 2:50 ever captured on vinyl and would appear to be here only as a sop to completists.(Incidentally, a suddenly distracted Homer Simpson stopped reading this review following my "doughnut" and "cake" references.)As usual, one can trust Ace Records to provide the best sound mastering possible, along with a deluxe 20-page full-color booklet chock-full of eye-popping realia and comprehensive liner notes covering each track and artist.The effort is here - and there is very little I had ever heard before - but getting through a dozen of the lesser tracks (just about half) felt like a bit of a slog.

Leon Bridges in his recording dbut takes us back further than most retro-soul artists who concentrate on the 1965-1975 time frame.  Clearly inspired by Sam Cooke, he ushers us back to the R&B and early gospel-tinged soul sounds I would situate more in the vicinity of 1957-1964, paralleling Cooke's heyday.  Bridges, who is from Fort Worth, puts an unmistakable Southern spin on these tracks, evoking New Orleans and a bit of Memphis.  Remarkably, there are no covers - only brand new, very authentic-sounding originals co-written by the artist.  He possesses a sterling, smoky-textured soul voice that is all his own, even if it does at times contain distant echoes of Cooke.  He can bend notes with the best of them and occasionally displays melismatic skills recalling Aaron Neville but in moderation and without the falsetto register.Within the somewhat narrow format he has chosen for this outing, each song seems distinctive to me (successive listens bear this out):  "Smooth Sailin'" is a cool and classy groover with organ, a pulsating beat and emphatic backing vocals by Brittni Jessie; "Pull Away" is an R&B ballad reminiscent of Sam Cooke at the turn of the '60s; while the closer "River" is the most overtly Cookian song, seemingly derived from the opening line of "A Change Is Gonna Come" ("I was born by the river...").  "Twistin' and Groovin'" may suggest Cooke's "Twistin' the Night Away" by its title, but the inspiration here is clearly Wilbert Harrison's 1959 crossover smash "Kansas City" - this is bouncy, old-school blues-rockin' R&B with blues guitar and Lee Allen-style New Orleans sax.  The three songs at the top - the title track "Coming Home," "Better Man," and "Brown Skin Girl" - will completely draw you into this intriguing alternate retro-soul world of his; the aforementioned "Smooth Sailin'" in the four-spot will refresh; but then prepare to be bowled over by the phenomenal gospel-soul melodic beauty of "Shine" with its irresistibly churchy female backing voices; and possibly even more so by the tender, haunting quality of the ode to his mom (from New Orleans) "LIsa Sawyer," replete with dreamy sax and hypnotic backing vocals.The album's running time is a little over 34 minutes but that would have been typical of LPs from the period being reflected here.  I was left wondering what this outstanding young talent is going to do for an encore.

This is definitely not up to five-star level of its 2014 predecessor ("Dor L.A. Soul Sides 1"), but it has enough worthwhile moments to recommend it: certainly Johnny Braff's "This Girl Is a Good Girl," a 1970s Trinidadian import that sounds a bit like deep southern '60s soul  la Percy Sledge with unusual lyrics; "Nitty Gritty City" by the girl-group The Swans (1966) which suggests second-tier Motown (but the beloved kind!); the solid soul ballad "I Look in the Mirror" from 1968 by one Eddie Kool (unsurprisingly, not his real last name!); and "I Only Cry Once a Day Now" by The Puffs (talk about obscure girl groups!), which is transformed from maudlin to quirky-good by Gene Page's new (1966) arrangement of it.  A few too many of these records sound a bit out-of-date even for their time, though; and some of the attempts to update the label's sound (by trying to increase the social relevance or funk quotients) feel a bit awkward and/or imitative.This being an Ace/Kent Soul compilation, one can trust the sound remastering to be as good as it can be; and as usual, the accompanying booklet (16 pages) with compiler Ady Croasdell's liner notes (telling the well-researched stories behind each act and each track) and superlative color graphics is a real treat.

Bobby Womack "The Preacher" / 1968-1972 5-CD Charly [UK] box set hit chronology(peak positions on national soul (Billboard) and pop (Billboard or Cash Box) singles charts:"What Is This" (1968)  #33 soul / #138 pop (in Record World only)"Fly Me to the Moon" (1968)  #16 soul / #52 pop"California Dreamin'" ('68-69)  #20 soul / #43 pop"I Left My Heart in San Francisco" (1969)  #48 soul / # 104 pop"It's Gonna Rain" (1969)  #43 soul / #121 pop"How I Miss You Baby" (1969)  #14 soul / #80 pop"More Than I Can Stand" (1970)  #23 soul / #90 pop"Arkansas State Prison" (1970)  - soul (did not chart) / #135 pop"I'm Gonna Forget About You" (1970)  #34 soul / - pop (did not chart)"The Preacher (Pt. 2)" / "More Than I Can Stand" [live] (1971)  #30 soul / # 111 pop"Communication" (1971)  #40 / - pop"THAT'S THE WAY I FEEL ABOUT CHA" ('71-72)  #2 soul / #22 pop"WOMAN'S GOTTA HAVE IT" (1972)  #1 soul / #32 pop (Cash Box) & #60 pop (Billboard)"Sweet Caroline" (1972)  #16 soul / #42 pop"HARRY HIPPIE" ('72-73)  #8 soul / #25 popon the Billboard LP chart:"Fly Me to the Moon" (1969)  #34 soul / #174 pop"My Prescription" (1970)  #44 soul /  - pop"The Womack 'Live'" (1971)  #13 soul / #188 pop"COMMUNICATION" ('71-72)  #7 soul / #83 pop"UNDERSTANDING" (1972) #7 soul / #43 popMentored by Sam Cooke (starting with his time in The Valentinos on Cooke's SAR label) and Wilson Pickett, you could tell from Bobby Womack's dbut solo LP at the age of 24 ("Fly Me to the Moon") that he had absorbed the best of both and had emerged as a fully formed soul star in his own right.  One listen to his amazingly soulful spin on the Mamas & the Papas' pop-folk smash from three years earlier, "California Dreamin'," attests to this.  When he wasn't doing likewise with the previous-generation oldies "Fly Me to the Moon" and "Moonlight in Vermont," he was exhibiting his remarkable composing talent as a writer on seven of the twelve tracks.  No doubt the two best of these were his versions of his recent collaborations with Wilson Pickett, "I'm in Love" and "I'm a Midnight Mover."  His B-side of "California Dreamin'" titled "Baby! You Oughta Thimk It Over," provides a preview for a number of his future compositions in the 1970s.  "Love, the Time Is Now" is a Memphis-style ballad clearly inspired by Sam Cooke and Otis Redding.Speaking of Memphis, all of these LPs were recorded in Memphis or in Muscle Shoals, Alabama, as he had learned from working with Wilson Pickett that that was where the best soul musicians (of the non-Motown stripe) were currently working.  Womack himself, of course, was a guitarist of note, which is why Ray Charles had hired him for his band a few years earlier (pre-Pickett)."My Prescription" may top the list for most undervalued soul LP of 1970.  All it contained were seven (!) chart songs (counting a reprise of "Fly Me to the Moon," his dbut album's title song).  The first single from it, following the earlier "Fly Me to the Moon" / "Moonlight in Vermont" chestnut/soul-revival template, was a funky-soul reading of "I Left My Heart in San Francisco."  It went nowhere (barely even Top 50 soul), but fortunately he had a supply of self-(co-)penned originals that made for better singles, especially "How I Miss You Baby" and "More Than I Can Stand," both of which did well on the soul charts (the former was actually his biggest solo soul hit until 1972).  One more "Moon" song appeared on this LP, a stunningly soulful cover of the British pop hit from 1965, Jonathan King's "Everyone's Gone to the Moon.""The Womack 'Live'" LP (1971) was his breakthrough soul album, and it featured the track (with its extended soul "rap") titled "The Preacher," which provided him his nickname (as well as this box set's title).  Edited and combined in a medley with "More Than I Can Stand," it became the memorable sole single (A-side) from the live album.  Other highlights abound, including another smokin' hot take on "I'm a Midnight Mover"; but above all I'll go with his bluesy Sam Cooke/Percy Mayfield medley "Laughing and Clowning"/"To Live the Past" and the surprise guest appearance by the great Percy Mayfield himself.  Not to be missed either are his superb back-to-back covers of the iconic '60s pop ballads "Everybody's Talkin'" (by Fred Neil - and a huge Nilsson hit from "Midnight Cowboy") and George Harrison's "Something" with the Beatles."Communication" ('71-72) and "Understanding" (1972) gave Womack a pair of consecutive #7 smash soul albums, plus his two biggest hit solo soul singles to date: the gentle, testifyin', electric-guitar-punctuated "That's the Way I Feel About Cha" and the understanding and sympathetic "Woman's Gotta Have It" (from "Understanding") - #2 and #1 soul-chart smashes, respectively.  Both LPs included a classic pop ballad for Womack to feast on, as he took both James Taylor's very personal story "Fire and Rain" and the Beatles' "And I Love Her" to the church of soul.  "Understanding"'s opener "I Can Understand It" became a sizable soul-radio LP-track hit, while the LP's second single yielded hits on both sides: the initial A-side was yet another "soul-icized" pop cover, this time of Neil Diamond's "Sweet Caroline"; and then came the touching, easy-flowing B-side "Harry Hippie," written by Jim Ford about one of Bobby's brothers.  As a result of the single's remarkable longevity (on the charts from late August of '72 to early March '73 [a 28-week span]), it became his first solo million-seller.Each of the five discs is housed in its own replica original record jacket (easy-to-handle, non-abrasive cardboard).  These are contained inside a single attractive, easy-opening box.  The 16-page accompanying booklet is a treat: jam-packed with photos, colorful record-jacket repros, label scans and a trade-publication poster ad.  There are seven pages of comprehensive and informative liner notes; and the sound has been newly remastered from the original analog master tapes.This is absolutely essential 1968-1972 soul by one of the immortal masters of the genre.

Be prepared for 79 absolutely astonishing minutes of blues magic, with a couple of ultra-soulful R&B ballad oldies and a late-'50s soul-jazz instrumental classic.For Chicago West Side blues fans, we get four excellent covers of classics by two of the best of all time, Otis Rush and Magic Sam.  A couple of Rush's "time" songs, "Right Place, Wrong Time" and "It Takes Time" receive high-intensity makeovers with Earl's blazing guitar and Michael Ledbetter's powerful, soul-drenched vocals.  "All Your Love," my favorite magic Sam tune, is explored for seven-plus minutes, with another outstanding Ledbetter vocal and plenty of room for Earl to dazzle with his stinging Magic Sam-esque guitar fills and for Dave Limina to delve deep on piano and Hammond B-3 organ.  Diane Blue does the vocal honors on Sam's probing, soul-searching "What Have I Done Wrong."Limina is especially luminescent (on B-3) with Earl on B.B. King's "I Need You So Bad" (KIng's recent death really raising the stakes for this track as a tribute).  There is also a top-notch bit of New Orleans blues here with a fiery remake of Fats Domino's "Every Night About This Time."Of Ronnie Earl's three originals, two are impressive soul-blues duets ("Follow Your Heart" and "Higher Love") with the aforementioned guest vocalists (who appear on twelve of the thirteen tracks), Michael Ledbetter and Diane Blue.  The third is the title song "Father's Day" by Earl and Ledbetter - very movingly sung by the latter - which deals with the very difficult personal issue of repairing rifts in the family and coming together in peace, understanding and forgiveness while there is still time.Earl et al (Limina, Jim Mouradian on bass, Lorne Entree on drums) transform themselves into a stellar electric guitar, organ and sax (Mario Perett on tenor, Scott Shetler on baritone) soul-jazz combo with their brilliant rendition of Bobby Timmons' classic "Moanin'," first recorded by Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers in 1958.The variety keeps on going right to the end with the closing gospel tune "Precious Lord" sung to a fare-thee-well by Diane Blue.But I was most taken aback by the 15 minutes devoted to a pair of early '60s R&B songs:  Gladys Knight & the Pips' 1964 hit ballad [#4 R&B / # 38 pop] "Giving Up" (written by Van McCoy) is taken to the church of the blues.  Just the deepest soul and blues together in a magnificent instrumental arrangement and with a vocal by Michael Ledbetter that will overwhelm you with its soulfulness.  Fine song, but I can't imagine what could have inspired such a masterpiece to emerge from it five decades later.  Four tracks down, the deep exploration of Bobby Bland's #2 R&B hit ballad from 1960, "I'll Take Care of You" (written by Brook Benton and Clyde Otis), stretches out to nine minutes - all instrumental for the second half - with stunningly gorgeous solos by Earl and Limina.There is so much intense, smoldering, passionate, high-powered playing and singing on this one CD that it's hard to imagine anything that could ever top it - yet if anyone can, Ronnie Earl will find a way.

Tad Robinson is the most exquisitely mellow soul and soul-blues crooner since the late Bobby Bland (leaving aside Mr. Bland's occasionally injected guttural growl which no one could ever duplicate), and this latest album "Day Into Night" affords him ample opportunity to excel for 53 minutes, most of this time spent luxuriating in his sweet spot, that being relaxed retro-1970s-sounding soul and blues with a lot of soul.Of the 12 tracks, ten of them are originals co-penned by Robinson or members of his band (particularly keyboardist Kevin Anker and bassist Steve Gomes), one of them is a cover, and the other is an alternate take (using a different instrumental arrangement) on one of the originals.  And wouldn't you know it, this one remake is of Bobby Bland's great "Lead Me On," a #9 R&B hit on the Duke label from 1960.  This more '70s-style funk-infused remake is unquestionably the finest recorded version of this song in the 55 years since. The one we hear twice is "Call Me" (not Al Green's or Blondie's, etc, - as I said, original), a terrific mid-tempo groover (personally, I prefer the Trk 12 second version with the soul horns in the mix, but Trk 2 has the strong guest organ part by Benjie Porecki in its favor).Not only is there the fine aforementioned tribute to Bobby Bland, but on my favorite of all my favorite tracks here, Syl Johnson and Hi Records/ Willie Mitchell-as-producer receive a fantastic doff of the old chapeau on the impossibly funky and grooving Gomes-Robinson-penned "While You Were Gone."  As if this isn't over-the-top great enough Tad also treats us to his only harmonica solo on the album, and it's a sizzling Slim Harpo/Louisiana-swamp--style one.  Speaking of Hi Records '70s male soul artists (other than Al Green), "Lonely Talking" is a lovely Otis Clay-type soul-blues ballad featuring more soulful organ sound as well as an astonishing guest appearance by Anson Funderburgh on blues guitar.  The other top soul-blues ballad here (and one which I'm guessing inspired the album's title) is the powerful and haunting "Nightwatch," with another magnificent blues-guitar guest appearance, this time by Alex Schultz.  The other Memphis soul giant Stax Records gets its shout-out with "Need Some Better," which is pure Johnnie Taylor.There is not weak moment anywhere on this album, nor is any track undeserving of praise, but I would be remiss if I didn't mention the moving tribute to Bobby Womack, whom we lost a year ago, bearing the title "He's Moved On."  Kevin Anker created a right-on-the-money Womack-esque tune, replete with horns and stirring backing vocals, while Tad Robinson almost seems to be channeling his spirit with his emotive, pleading vocal (and soul-rapping, as Womack would do so effectively before the definition of "rapping" changed).For those who appreciate this genre and wish to hear one classic and ten new original songs that do honor to it, I don't think there will be many (if any) better than this in 2015.

This is an attempt by the RPM International Retro series to capture the origins of French rock 'n' roll (a major cultural import from the U.S,) when it was raw, vital and untamed -- before much of it became watered-down y-y (teeny-bopper) pop music.The rock 'n' roll explosion in France really occurred with the emergence of Johnny Hallyday in 1960.  However,  that particular chapter was covered on a prior CD in this series, so what we get here are 1) the sparse 1956-1959 period when "rock and roll" seemed to be more of a music-hall novelty-act item featuring sped-up orchestral arrangements with accordions (!) and clarinets, and very little connection to the contemporaneous American youth phenomenon; and 2) the male groups and female solo rock 'n' roll artists who came along in Johnny's wake.The male groups include Les Chaussettes Noires ("the Black Socks") fronted by future solo star Eddy Mitchell (they do an Elvis and a Gene Vincent cover in French); Les Chats Sauvages ("the Wild Cats"), with lead singer Dick Rivers, who are also heard twice, including on the classic, disc-opening Twist  Saint-Tropez; and the menacing and rowdy, bad-boy, black-leather-clad Vince Taylor et ses Play-Boys (who were actually a British group) with their wild English-language covers of Elvis's "Baby Let's Play House" and Chuck Berry's "Sweet Little Sixteen."  They clearly possessed more attitude than musical ability - which depending on one's point of view, now make them either seem all the greater or all the worse for it.  Incidentally, like Johnny Hallyday, none of these native French lead artists used their real names, as the idea was to adopt an American rock 'n' roller identity.  Eddy Mitchell and Dick Rivers were U.S.-inspired names (the latter's was derived from the Elvis film character Deke Rivers: "Dick" is pronounced like "Deke" in French); and Brit Brian Holden took the more supposedly American-sounding name of Vince Taylor.Johnny Hallyday is in fact featured on this CD, on the last two tracks, as a 15-year-old on home-made French-language recordings of "Heartbreak Hotel" and "Tutti Frutti" from 1958.  Unsurprisingly the audio quality is on the muddy side, but these tracks are here to preserve a bit of history and only appear at the very end.  Still, the Johnny vocal talent is already in evidence.  He clearly has the best natural feel for this music, as well as the most rock and R&B-ready voice.Also of note is the group El Toro et les Cyclones (a name which must have sounded absolutely wild in 1962 France), heard here on their French "Long Tall Sally" cover (Oncle John), featuring future French recording star Jacques Dutronc on guitar.  Danyel Grard, in an early recording, gets wild (and borderline scary) with his hyped-up Gallic take on the Ike Turner-penned Gong-Gong (I'm Blue) an R&B hit by the Ikettes.  On the distaff side - but staying sauvage - there's Nicole Paquin's Mon mari, c'est Frankenstein (originally, "You Can Get Him, Frankenstein" by the Castle Kings).  And another transplanted Brit, Gillian Hills, turns in a credible French-language version of the Shirelles' "Mama Said," tying it to the unstoppable dance craze as En dansant le twist.  Jackie Seven's (definitely not the young Frenchwoman's real name!) Le Rhythme du rock is one of my least favorites from this post-Johnny wave: just too mindless and repetitious, although in its day it might have seemed admirably anthemic.By far the best of the pre-Johnny era is the French-language cover of Little Willie John's "Fever" by Gabriel Dalar, which mostly uses the 1958 pop-hit arrangement for Peggy Lee.  For my two favorites overall, I have to go with les Daltons, the guitar instrumental group heavily influenced by the Shadows of the U.K.  With Long Chris (a future close musical associate of Johnny Hallyday's) providing the vocal they do an astoundingly hot and rocking French version of Fats Domino's "Hello Josephine," as well as the twangy, reverbed, Shadows-like instrumental with a Western U.S. motif titled Dalton City.All twenty of the studio-recorded tracks sound tremendous; and the twelve-page accompanying full-color booklet is to be treasured - as besides the indispensable seven pages of informative Kieron Tyler liner notes, we also get repros of the 17 record jackets that once held all of the featured records here issued between 1956 and 1962.  The presentation is five-star all the way, which leaves the overall quality of the music as the tricky issue.  There is about one-third of this disc that I would not want to hear again anytime soon and a slightly lesser percentage than that which I am really enthusiastic about.

Ace [UK] "California Nights" hit parade (highest U.S. national pop chart positions):"My Town, My Guy and Me" (1965)  #32 Billboard"I Won't Love You Anymore (Sorry)" (1965)  #61 Cash Box"We Know We're in Love" (1966)  #58 Record World"Off and Running" (1966)  #94 Record World (only "bubbled under" in Billboard at #108)"Treat Me Like a Lady" (1966)  "bubbled under" at #115 in Billboard"California Nights" (1967)  #11 Cash Box"California Nights" turned out to be '60s pop princess Lesley Gore's last major hit and she was only just turning 21; yet her run which began at age 16 in '63 with her recording of "It's My Party" was impressive and memorable, as well as being more enduring than any of her teen girl-pop counterparts'.  At least she held her own rather well against the British invasion, although her best record "You Don't Own Me" was prevented from becoming a national number one record when the Beatles suddenly crashed the U.S. pop charts with "I Want to Hold Your Hand" in early '64.  What she couldn't weather as the late sixties approached was the onslaught of more heavyweight, relevant and personal material being generated by her rock and singer-songwriter contemporaries.In any event, what is clear now is that whenever Lesley Gore had a distinctive song to work with she did very well with it.  All of her hits attest to this; and it should be noted that she co-wrote the first three hits listed chronologically above (all contained in the bonus tracks) - two of them with brother Michael (in 1980 they were Grammy and Oscar nominated for their songwriting on the ballad "Out Here on My Own" from the movie "Fame.").  "California Nights" is a beautifully composed tune by the late Marvin Hamlisch (just a couple years older than Lesley - both are gone now, sadly), who went on to great heights in the business. [For trivia buffs: Hamlisch is the only person to win all of the following awards: Academy Award (3), Grammy (4), Emmy (4), Tony (1), Golden Globe (2) and Pulitzer Prize (1, shared).]The Bob Crewe co-writes on the "California Nights" album, other than the catchy, undervalued single "Treat Me Like a Lady" just sort of blend together with several others, but there are two more that make a strong impression: the single "Off and Running" (written by Carole Bayer and Toni Wine/produced by Quincy Jones, who produced "It's My Party") is a British beat-influenced rocker with a hot Jack Nitzsche arrangement.  It barely cracked one of three national top 100s, yet in retrospect it seems like one of her better efforts.  My guess is that it was just too unexpected from her, and neither radio programmers nor her fans would go for it.  "Cry Like a Baby" is not the subsequent Box Tops hit but a genuine soul record (a fairly minor R&B hit for Aretha Franklin while still at Columbia) penned by Jo Armstead, Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson.  These two fine tracks took Lesley out of her pure pop bag and allowed her to shine in very different ways.This being an Ace package we get the 16-page deluxe-booklet treatment loaded with colorful photographic realia; while the liner notes by Malcolm Baumgart briefly tell the story behind every one of the 25 recordings.I just wish there were more songs here that really stood out and would have been fully up to Lesley's Gore level of talent.

There's about a 36-minute masterpiece of an album lurking inside this 56-minute Brian Wilson CD produced by BW and Joe Thomas.  Toss out six tracks that are sappy ("Our Special Love," "Somewhere Quiet" and "One Kind of Love"), overly self-absorbed ("I'm Feeling Sad"), inconsequential ("Saturday Night"), and a major misfire in the key number two track position ("Runaway Dancer," with its trite, outmoded Sebu Simonian programmed beats and Brian sounding ridiculously out of his element), and this is one eminently enjoyable 12-track album (deluxe version).The stand-out of my dozen recommended songs here is without a doubt "Whatever Happened," featuring Al Jardine and David Marks.  The lyrics express longing nostalgia in a strikingly authentic and convincing way, and the Beach Boys harmonies are magnificently recreated.  An original song-of-the-year candidate in my view.  The same combo returns four tracks later with more lush harmonies on "The Right Time," while Brian and Al duet (and Al is truly outstanding here) on the exquisitely harmonious and tuneful "Tell Me Why."  For bouncy, poppy and irresistible, you can't do much better than "Guess You Had to Be There," a duet with Kacey Musgraves, who also co-wrote it."On the Island" is a short and breezily refreshing number with She & Him, on which She (Zooey Deschanel) sounds more like this generation's Doris Day than ever (which is a huge compliment in my book).  Brian's backing vocal is absolutely priceless on this track.  "Half Moon Bay" is a drop-dead gorgeous instrumental featuring the solo trumpet of Mark Isham; and continuing the theme of enjoyment and appreciation of the water and/or tropical island life is "Sail Away," which brings back Blondie Chaplin and Al Jardine for yet more golden Beach Boys sounds - and this one cleverly and delightfully adds musical cues (especially toward the end) reminiscent of Brian's brilliant 1966 Beach Boys adaptation of "Sloop John B" from "Pet Sounds.""Don't Worry," despite the similarity of titles, is unrelated to "Don't Worry Baby."  I might have written it off as featherweight but for the completely winning and unexpected turn-of-the-'70s midtempo soul arrangement.  The first 14 non-"deluxe" tracks are bookended by the brief but gorgeous disc opener "This Beautiful Day" and the beautifully orchestrated four-and-a-half minute closer "The Last Song."That leaves the two "deluxe" edition bonus tracks: a reprise of "Love and Mercy" coinciding with the new biographical film of Brian Wilson by that title; and his heart-felt home recording (just Brian and his piano) of "In the Back of My Mind."  After becoming completely accustomed to his meticulous production techniques for so long, it is startling to hear anything this raw from him.  It is stark and soul-baring...and a whole different type of proof of his genius.

It has been five months now since Lesley Gore has been gone, so it felt like time to go back and listen to the last album she made (and the only one after 1982).  In short, it is even better than I remembered, and I am now more sold than ever on the original songs that were written for it.These original songs from 2005 are nearly all ballads of an reflective, introspective nature, as they weave an almost hypnotic late-night-jazz-tinged web of sheer fascination.  Speaking of "web," one of the best here is the entrancing "Cool Web" (written by John Fischer), which is about a romance fraught with peril.  Once you get over the shock that her voice and her approach to singing are a thousand miles removed from the teenage Lesley Gore, you will develop a real appreciation for the highly skilled, mature chanteuse that she became.  Sensitive producer and pianist Blake Morgan penned a pair of the most lovely original ballads on the album: "It's Gone" (about the end of a love affair) and the especially beautiful "Better Angels," which is now even more compelling (and beyond spooky) as she sings, "And though my case looks fatal, I'm still hoping better angels come to me."  The title song, written by guitarist Mike Errico, is about longing, and like "Better Angels" stuns with the line, "We picked up where we left off in another life."  Lesley, along with Errico and Morgan (and Tanya Leah and Lorraine Ferro), composed the wistful and delicate "Words We Don't Say," while Lesley and Ellen Weston collaborated on her final track "We Went So High," which looks back at love and life, making it the ideal last word on all of it.Lesley was the sole writer on the clever and bouncy (thus, quite a change of pace) "Not the First," with the line, "You're not the first to think you'll be the last."And then there are two of her great older hits from two very successful periods, both of which impressed me the most ten years ago and do not disappoint in any way now:  The Academy Award-nominated "Out Here on My Own," which Lesley wrote with her brother Michael, was a huge Irene Cara hit ballad [#4 in Billboard, with a 26-week chart run] from the smash 1980 movie "Fame."  (She was also nominated for a Grammy for her work on the original score of the film.)  This can now be viewed as the definitive version.  And then there's her immortal "You Don't Own Me," the proto-women's liberation song penned by two of the writers of Danny & the Juniors' "At the Hop" (Dave White and John Madara), which earned the distinction of being the first record that was blocked from the #1 position by the Beatles' "I Want to Hold Your Hand" when the British Invasion struck in February of 1964.  (In Chicago, it was knocked out of the #1 spot.)  Here, Lesley takes "You Don't Own Me" at a languid pace, making her point with every syllable, while making us realize once again what a brilliantly constructed and written song this is.For a final album (sadly, as it turned out), recorded some forty years after one's height of fame [no play on words with the film title intended], this is about as solid an effort as one could hope for.

Gregor Hilden from Mnster, Germany, employing eight different classic guitar models (by Gibson, Fender and Gretsch) over the course of 13 tracks and 59 and a half minutes, takes us on an astounding sonic adventure that in some ways feels like a direct line back to the mid-1970s when artists at his level of talent and musical knowledge could break the barriers of blues and soul and funk and jazz and fuse them all in the most appealing ways.  That he begins with a cover of Grover Washington Jr.'s "Mr. Magic" (composed by Ralph MacDonald) from 1975 (you can't get any more mid-'70s than that!), the biggest and most memorable soul-jazz hit of the decade, seems completely appropriate.  The song's transition from sax to electric guitar could not have been handled more deftly than it is here.  This is scintillating soul-jazz that truly stands the test of time - that being 40 years now.  The other soul-jazz (with Latin and blues flavors) standard Hilden and his combo cover is Kenny Burrell's immortal "Chitlins Con Carne" from his 1963 LP "Midnight Blues."  Thomas Hufschmidt's electric keyboard, also featured in a superb solo on "Mr. Magic," is key [no pun intended] in lending this version an updated '70s-fusion vibe.  Horst Bergmeyer's B-3 organ solo infuses it with some late-'60s soul.Classic '60s heavy blues-rock receives a dose of jazz flair in a tribute to Peter Green's Fleetwood Mac, while the remaining ten tracks are all original Hilden compositions, all of which are impressive in their mastery of each of these genres in a greater jazz context.  Since "Mr. Magic" is my favorite overall, my second favorite would have to be Hilden's own "Mr. Magic" equivalent, titled "Desert Song."  It's exciting but gorgeous and soulful at the same time, with that seemingly inevitable, natural groove that "Mr. Magic" possesses in spades, while being totally original.  "On Flow" is a sizzling, pulsating blues-rock, R&B and soul-jazz hybrid (really, it's all there!), which is lacking just one thing: a good title!  "Springtime" is tuneful and upbeat and features a majorly soulful Bergmeyer B-3 solo.  On "Naylor's Blues," what can I say? He nails the blues; and I would be surprised if B.B. King were not a prime inspiration.  "Rock-Zabern is oxymoronic relaxed funk; Greg's Funk" is funky blues; "Blues from the Other Side" is easy-going blues jazz; and the title song ("In Phase") has a lilting melody and is also taken at an easy pace.Fans of the late, great Jeff Golub should really like this album.

This 1989-90 season of "The Wonder Years" resulted in its highest ratings ever: the 8th most popular show on TV.  At a time of sitcom dominance (seven of the top nine shows) "The Wonder Years" was the second highest-rated on ABC, behind only "Roseanne."  This represented a significant bounce-back after its Season 2 ratings slump when it wound up in a tie for 22nd place.  I enjoyed Season 2, but as I pointed out in my five-star review of the DVD, there were a couple of problems which I think were reflected in the ratings.  Season 3 is right in the pocket all the way, and we can see why it was the most successful full season of the series.Season 3 tells the story of Kevin Arnold's (Fred Savage) year in eighth grade (1969-70).  It has its quirky moments, but nothing that goes out too far on a limb - and that includes the brilliantly quirky "Tree House" episode, which (shall I say) branched off in a delightfully unpredictable direction.Older brother Wayne's (Jason Hervey) tormenting is toned down this season (I wrote that excessive bullying and weirdness was a problem in Season 2), and the result is both the best comic pay-off (the lurching car scene) and the best character pay-off thus far in the series for Wayne, as we come to understand some of his very believable middle-child frustrations.  Beneath all the derision directed toward Kevin, it begins to become clear that he really cares about his brother.  Juliette Lewis guest-appears memorably in a few episodes as Wayne's gum-chomping bimbo girlfriend Delores (definitely not the same as the Delores from a notorious "Seinfeld" episode"!).Hippie-ish older sister Karen (Olivia D'Abo), as a high school senior with leaving her "bourgeois" home for college on her mind, continues to assert her independence, leading to unavoidable conflict with her hard-working, minimally-communicative Korean War-vet father (Dan Lauria, as Jack Arnold), as well as to an emotional resolution of their generation-gap issues in the "Daddy's Little Girl" episode.  Alley Mills (as Norma Arnold/Mom) is stellar in the "Faith" episode, in which her losing the year's tax receipts reveals the true extent to which she is the glue that holds the family together.But mostly it's about Kevin and best friends Paul Pfeiffer (Josh Saviano) and Winnie Cooper (Danica McKellar) as they navigate their way through junior high school and the mounting pressures (particularly social) of eighth grade.  The back-to-back episodes "She, My Friend and I" and "The St. Valentine's Day Massacre," are pivotal in the inevitably changing nature of Kevin and Winnie's relationship.In a bonus-feature interview Jason Hervey talks about the music being an absolutely essential element in the telling of the "Wonder Years" story.  Now with nearly all (96%) of the licensing rights to the originally-featured music obtained, the series feels complete on DVD.  There is almost an embarrassment of musical riches, but from this season I'll just mention three particularly effective uses of 1960s recordings: 1) The Beach Boys' "Good Vibrations" and "Wouldn't It Be Nice" in the opening "Summer Song" family-vacation-at-the-seashore episode; 2) the comedic use of James Brown's "Papa's Got a Brand New Bag" and Jewel Akens' "The Birds and the Bees" in the aforementioned "Tree House" episode; and especially 3) the powerfully affecting appearances of the Motown ballads "What Becomes of the Brokenhearted" (Jimmy Ruffin) and "You're All I Need to Get By" (Marvin Gaye & Tammi Terrell) in the most emotionally charged moments between Kevin and Winnie in the unforgettable "St. Valentine's Day Massacre" episode.The bonus features are extensive and illuminating (with no shortage of intelligent, in-depth observations) AND we get the answer (from one of the producers) as to how in the world Wayne's repeatedly addressing his brother as "Scrote" was able to get past the network censors.  The only drawback with this extra material is that it covers the entire series, so there are spoilers all over the place.  And alas, there is no episode commentary.Saving the best for last, I will mention that this is the season that includes what is possibly the greatest three-episode story arc in network half-hour-series TV history: Episodes 2, 9 and 20 ("Math Class," "Math Class Squared" and "Good-Bye").  The third of this trilogy earned Emmy awards for writing (Bob Brush) and directing (Michael Dinner), while the late Steven Gilborn was robbed of one for his acting portrayal of Mr. Collins, the no-nonsense, uncompromised-standards-upholding, "old-school" algebra teacher who believed that "every problem contains its own solution."  Kevin would be changed forever (for the better) by having been his student.  (Gilborn in real life held a Ph.D. in literature and had been a college professor before becoming an actor.)This is a season to cherish in one of American television's finest series

This is 59 minutes of reverbed guitar and wailing sax heaven; some of the greatest Southern California surf music (from 1963-64) never heard on record prior to this present stellar Thom Starr and the Galaxies collection.Fender Jazzmaster master Starr, heavily influenced by Dick Dale, Duane Eddy, and especially by Paul Johnson of the Belairs (of "Mr. Moto" fame) from the local South Bay area, just a year out of high school was composing his own superb surf-style tunes, and he and his band did record a ten-track all-instro LP in 1963 with the brilliant title "Sons of the Beach."  Only problem: it fell through the cracks and never got issued by any label.  Terrific tracks with titles like "Strange Fever (Just Before Dawn)," Woodie Welcome Wagon Part 2," "Surfer's Bubble," "No. 1 Son," "Launching Pad," "Cherry Wipe Out," "Sand Blast" and "Jellyfish Kiss" stayed in the can for the rest of Starr's lifetime.  These songs were right in the pocket (or should I say "pipeline") of the best surf music out there at the time.  The problem I had where I was (in the Midwest) was that we got none of this phenomenal instro-surf-combo stuff except for the Chantays' "Pipeline" and the Surfaris' "Wipe Out."  For some dumb reason the radio programmers here wouldn't touch this stuff (besides those two that somehow managed to made it through); and when it came to instrumentals we would only get "safe" easy-listening ones.  (I guess "safe" was their reason, and it was indeed a dumb one!)The 1964 tracks, a mix of covers of Paul Johnson ("Mr. Moto," "Bedlam" "Squad Car" and "Vmonos") and Dick Dale ("Shake & Stomp") songs and his own originals, are even stronger that the '63 stuff - and Starr's original compositions show just how phenomenally gifted he was.  "The Nomad" is definitely intriguing and "Renegade" rocks out, while his only down-tempo one, "Enchanted Island," is a thrillingly (and chillingly) gorgeous masterpiece that needs to be discovered.  It is easily one of the best melodic compositions this genre ever produced.Fine, concise and informative liner notes by John Blair (author of "The Illustrated Discography of Surf Music, 1961-1965") are contained in the accompanying fold-out card, which adds color photos and track info.  The mono sound mastering is excellent throughout.  Sundazed, in assembling this whole package, has done what it does best.

"Been all around this world just to come back to you...; it's a long and lonesome highway, it's a bitter shade of blue..."  - from Trk 1, "Worried Mind" by Eilen JewellThis album, which has so much to do about returning home as part of her search for peace of mind, is pensive, poetic and deeply personal.  It is also bittersweet, as there is still much to be disillusioned about - such as the discovery that a cherished place of one's youth (in Idaho) is now abandoned and desolate (and officially designated as a "ghost town").  She sings of "empty silos on state highways" and about "this whole place...going under."  Yet, the closing track, "Songbird," which almost certainly is inspired by her young daughter ("My whole world rests on those tiny wings") is a gentle song of belief in a beautiful future, full of comfort and hope.Each of these twelve songs (averaging just over three minutes in duration) stands on its own; but put together they add up to a thoughtful, thought-provoking and ultimately haunting whole, demanding repeated listens.  Metaphors abound in the form of trains and rivers and roads, a "half-broke horse," and even an "old guitar with broken strings...played by the unseen hand...in the 'hallelujah band.'"  The latter song's eerie vibe is enhanced by the reverbed electric surf guitar of Jerry Miller.  (I had to check the credits to see if maybe Los Straitjackets had made a guest appearance!)  The layering of guitars throughout (Eilen Jewell's acoustic, Miller's electric [plus mandolin on one track], and Jake Hoffman's pedal steel) is brilliant.  The effect of all three together is particularly shattering on "Some Things Weren't Meant to Be," with Miller supplying the tender twang as Eilen laments, "My best was less than you wanted from me."  The twang (with its distinctly western sound) adds punctuation again on the introspective "Pages" ("...I search for words to make things right") and the melancholy song of longing, "[If You Were] Here with Me."  Her harmonica solo, which she saves for the aforementioned closer "Songbird" is as poignant as it gets.  And in the most striking change of pace, Trk 3, "Rio Grande," begins with a blast of Jack Gardner's south-of-the-border trumpet and features more snaky surf guitar, plus a pulsating beat kept by Eilen Jewell's husband, Jason Beek.Superb songs, beautifully languid lead vocals, excellent musicianship with completely on-point arrangements all combine to create what I believe will stand as one of this year's best (maybe THE best - we'll have to see) albums of all-original singer-songwriter material.

The Catacombs U.S. hit parade - peak national chart positions:Gene Chandler  "Nothing Can Stop Me" (1965)  #3 R&B / #18 popThe C.O.D.'s  "Michael [The Lover]" ('65-66)  #5 R&B / #41 popFred Hughes  "You Can't Take It Away" (1965)  #12 R&B / #89 popThere are not many hits here out of 28 tracks, but then that was precisely the point of the working-class underground dance-club scene in a number of UK cities north of London that began in the '60s: finding the rarest highly danceable, uptempo U.S. R&B/soul imports on 45, which in turn would help define the local club's unique ambiance.  Nothing from the British pop charts allowed.  The Catacombs (popularly abbreviated to the "Cats"), located in the West Midlands city of Wolverhampton, was an influential Northern Soul (as the scene came to be called) venue established in a 107-year-old building that was originally a convent, and in the intervening years had multiple uses such as a lead smelting works and a warehouse.  This collection contains 72 minutes of music that was featured there during its six years of operation.  It all sounds sensational and is in true hardcover CD album format, with a colorful 24-page booklet loaded with label scans of these obscure 45s, photos, brief background info on each recording artist, and a ten-page history of the Catacombs.These records date from 1962-1970 - the golden age of U.S. soul, one might say - with a large majority from the sweet-spot years 1965-67.  Listening to WVON in Chicago in '65-66, I certainly remember the Chicago soul hits featured here: Gene Chandler's "Nothing Can Stop Me" (Chandler was a favorite of mine since "Duke of Earl" in 1962, the first 45 I ever bought; and this present record got a lot of Top 40 pop airplay as well) and The C.O.D."s ultra-catchy "Michael," which is one I may not have heard since.  It's unlikely I had ever heard more than a handful of these selections before.  Other examples of Chicago soul here include the good ones "That's My Girl" by Dee "Raindrops" Clark (1964), "Every Beat of My Heart" by the Du-Ettes (1965/Mar-V-Lus label), and the Five Stairsteps' "Change of Pace" (1967/Windy C label).The third of the above-listed national chart hits is Fred Hughes' melodic and rhythmic, sweet-spirited "You Can't Take It Away."  In addition to this one, I would especially recommend Johnny & Lilly's hard-soul Huey P. Meaux/Crazy Cajun production "Suffering City" (Johnny & Lilly were Texas soul and blues man Johnny Copeland and his wife Lavelle White); the great Bobby Womack's 1966 original (and superior) version of his debut solo single two years later, "What Is This?"; the Fi-Dels' Motownish "Try a Little Harder"; and the driving uptown soul of Jerry Williams (before he morphed into his Swamp Dogg soul innovator persona) on "If You Ask Me" (1967).  And then there's the one that is credited as being the most influential of all early Northern Soul discs, Leon "I-Wanna-Do-Something-Freaky-to-You" Haywood's Four Tops-inspired "Baby, Reconsider" from 1966 (on the Fat Fish [!] label).You can't go wrong with anything involving this collection - unless you're looking for ballads, that is!

Nine syllables instantly vaulted David Ruffin to stardom in 1965: "I've got sunshine on a cloudy day."  The song "My Girl" went to #1 R&B and pop; and for the next three years - until his expulsion from the group - he was the principal lead singer of the Temptations at their 1960s peak.  He joined Smokey Robinson (co-writer/producer of "My Girl" and others for the Tempts) of the Miracles and Levi Stubbs of the Four Tops as the top three lead vocalists of male Motown groups of the era.Cut to 1971.  Despite some prior solo success, Ruffin ceased to be a priority at Motown.  Not being first-tier there was an iffy situation at best for an artist, and consistent backing of the company went out the window.  Seven different producers or combinations of producers were involved with the dozen tracks originally scheduled for release as the LP "David" in mid-1971 (that many producers being a sign in and of itself of a non-priority project), but it is a matter of speculation why the album got shelved (and was only first released here by Hip-O Select decades later).  Certainly, a complete lack of volatility swirling around Ruffin since his ouster from the Tempts was NOT among the possible explanations.Not helping matters was that the four songs from the unissued LP that did see release at the time as single sides made virtually no impact in the marketplace.  The first single was doubly strong and included both the opening and closing tracks of the projected LP, respectively: the Henry Cosby co-written-and-produced "Each Day Is a Lifetime" and the Dale Browner penned-and-produced "Don't Stop Lovin' Me."  The latter was the only one to register at all - barely, at a peak of #103 in Cash Box.  Obviously, with both singles tanking, the chances of the LP going anywhere would not have been good at all.I find it to be about two-thirds of a very good album, but even on the weaker songs Ruffin's commitment to them is remarkable.  He always remained in fine form as a vocalist, possessing the strongest combination of a deep soul rasp, impressive vocal flexibility and range, and a unique ability to emphasize his emotions (so often hurt and anguish) with a whole assortment of chilling whoops and wails - and do so naturally, without a hint of artifice.  And ever since "Ain't Too Proud to Beg" in '66 with the Tempts, he was the undisputed king of imploration in soul music.Besides the aforementioned "Each Day Is a Lifetime" and "Don't Stop Lovin' Me," "Anything That You Ask For," "Out in the Country" [not the same as the recent Three Dog Night hit], "I Can't Be Hurt Anymore," and "Let Somebody Love Me" are solid tracks.  But special mentions need to go to his covers of the big crossover soul and pop hits "Rainy Night in Georgia" and "I Want You Back."  Nobody but Jerry Butler perhaps could have been as mellow as Brook Benton on "Rainy Night in Georgia," but Ruffin gets down to his best Benton-esque baritone, as well as adding flavors of his own to the gorgeous 4:40 track.  Taking on Michael and his four Jackson brothers on "I Want You Back" might seem like an odd choice, but Ruffin's version offers convincing evidence that the song has a more mature message than can be gleaned from the pre-adolescent/adolescent Jackson 5's original.Of the seven "bonus" tracks - ones that did not make the cut for the unissued "David" LP - the stand-out is Ron Miller's "Heaven Help Us All," which went on to glory in the latter part of 1970 as a Stevie Wonder single.  It's a moving song with a touching and heart-felt Ruffin reading of it, although Stevie's was clearly the more dynamic version.  On the inexplicable side, how did they completely miss the powerhouse Johnny Bristol co-written-and-produced "Get Away Heartache (Keep Moving On)," the most obvious ready-made potential hit of this entire collection?  The heartache he expresses so convincingly and deeply might have had something to do with the then understood-to-be-hopeless health situation of Tammi Terrell with whom he had had a love affair.  (She was in a coma and gone within weeks.)Excellent work by Hip-O Select in compiling this 76 minute CD, applying impeccable digital mastering to the superlative stereo (plus, the four mono single mixes), and providing a colorful (even featuring the original LP artwork that no one got to see at the time), informative 16-page booklet with remarkably thorough credits and recording-session details.  My holding out on the highest rating (by one-half of a star) comes from there being nine or ten tracks out of the 23 total that I think are beneath David Ruffin's talent to the point that they can be a bit of a chore to sit through.  Still, the presence of 13 or 14 really good ones is easily enough for me to highly recommend this collection.

Bettye LaVette is better than ever in 2015 at the age of 69 (a 53-year span as a recording artist) as her current LP "Worthy" - one of the best of the year so far - will attest.  This CD "Take Another Little Piece of My Heart" takes us back to late '69/early '70 when Bettye ("Betty" then, without the final "e" she later added) was still 23 and already on her sixth (!) different record label.  This time she found herself on the short-lived Nashville-based Silver Fox imprint, so named not for Charlie Rich but for the guy who had the nickname earlier, Kenny Rogers' brother Lelan Rogers, who ran this SSS International subsidiary and produced these 13 tracks.  No LP (like Dusty Springfield's "Dusty in Memphis" earlier that year) emerged from these Bettye LaVette Memphis sessions, but four singles (eight sides) were issued at the time.Bettye's from-deep-in-the-gut, guttural singing style (so unusual for her age) was already well established by this time, and the sounds of Memphis Studio, with the backing of its Dixie Flyers rhythm section, was made to order for this young woman from Detroit who sounded so much more like a Southern R&B/blues singer than she did Motown.The four issued singles:1) "He Made a Woman Out of Me" (1969-70) - typically Bettye in that it held nothing back.  It rode the soul charts in December '69/January '70, peaking at #25.  This was the only one that appeared on a national pop chart, although barely: only making #118 in Cash Box.  A few months later, Bobbie Gentry, in her country-soul style, had a version out that got to #71 on the pop Hot 100.2) "Do Your Duty" (1970) - Yikes!  Talk about not holding back!  This was a real soul sister's women's liberation song demanding that certain needs, shall we say, be met by her man.  This goes well beyond Aretha Franklin's version of Otis Redding's "Respect" -- and ironically, its writer, Ronnie Shannon, wrote two of Aretha's other early hits at Atlantic ("I Never Loved a Man the Way I Loved You" and "Baby I Love You.").  It climbed to #38 soul in early spring.3) "Games People Play" (1970) - No national chart action at all but a phenomenal soul rendition of the recent Joe South Grammy winner for 1969 Song of the Year.  Maybe too recent and the public was "Games People Played"-out at the time, although it sounds completely fresh today.  The B-side "My Train's Comin' In" is a hot one that sounds like another shoulda-been hit.4) "Piece of My Heart" (1970) - Yes, that ("Take Another Little) Piece of My Heart" by Jerry Ragovoy and Bert Berns - originally by Erma Franklin (1967) and immortalized by Janis Joplin with Big Brother and the Holding Company the following year.  Make the total three stellar versions in three years.  The B-side "At the Mercy of a Man" - the CD opener - is funky, bluesy, horn-driven, gutbucket soul that could probably only be sung by her or Tina Turner or Janis Joplin, or possibly Etta James then.  Bettye could still sing it now in the same way, but with even more maturity.  Alas, no chart action on this single either, so Bettye was off to label number seven.Most notable of the unissued tracks were the two she sang with Hank Ballard, the former R&B giant who came up with "The Twist" and also happened to be a Silver Fox artist at the time:  "Hello Sunshine" is a solid soul ballad previously recorded by both Aretha Franklin and Wilson Pickett at Atlantic; and "Let's Go, Let's Go, Let's Go" is a fun recreation of Ballard's own #1 R&B/ #6 pop smash from ten years earlier.  But my favorite of all is what could have been one of her signature records had it been released (up there [almost] with "Let Me Down Easy" which I bought midway through high school in June 1965): the magnificent southern soul ballad "Easier to Say (Than Do)" which has everything working for it: a superlative instrumental track featuring mighty Memphis soul horns and a right-on-the-money background vocal chorus - and above all, a beautifully deep, warm, heartfelt and commanding vocal by Bettye.  It was withheld from release most likely due to an another Lelan Rogers-produced version (with the same backing tracks) being out at the time as a Charles Hodges B-side -- ironically on the Calla label, on which Bettye had had her aforementioned biggest hit "Let Me Down Easy" four and a half years earlier.I gleaned the previous nugget of information, as well as a few others, from the five pages of accompanying booklet liner notes by author Bill Dahl.  (The best little informational gem is how Bettye got to Lelan Rogers and Silver Fox: it was at the suggestion of the latter's brother Kenny Rogers who thought Bettye's 1968 version of Mickey Newbury's "What Condition My Condition Is In" on the obscure Karen label in Detroit was "the greatest thing [he'd] ever heard" and "much better" than his own breakthrough hit version with the First Edition.)This is an excellent Varse Sarabande CD I'm glad I finally got to hear - in yet another great year in the amazing career of Bettye LaVette.

Her contemporaries Aretha Franklin and Gladys Knight both heaped praise upon her, and Linda Jones was only 22 when she had her signature hit record, the entrancing soul ballad "Hypnotized" in the summer of 1967 (a.k.a. "the summer of love").  The record had been rejected by a number of labels, until the brilliant soul songwriter and producer, Jerry Ragovoy, who was running Warner Brothers' soul imprint Loma at the time, instantly recognized its potential and put it out - the first of five chart records Ms. Jones was to have with the label in '67 and '68.  "Hypnotized' went to #4 on the Billboard R&B chart while crossing over to #21 on its pop Hot 100.  She would double that number, making it an even ten on her two subsequent labels (Neptune and Turbo) before her shocking death resulting from diabetes at the age of 27.A true vocal dynamo, Linda Jones can be situated on the '60s/early-'70s soul-sister powerhouse-vocalist continuum between Aretha Franklin and Dee Dee Warwick, her "neighbor" from Northern New Jersey.  All three came from family gospel-singling groups and thus could instinctively belt out the secular soul as well.  Jones actually beat Aretha to Atlantic Records by two years, but she moved on after her dbut single on their Atco imprint, the hard-charging dancer, "Take the Boy Out of the Country" (b/w the mid-paced, organ-propelled beauty "Taking Back My Love," which has her singing with passion in her highest register), surprisingly didn't catch on.  Jones was especially known for her intensely emotive, dramatic performances on ballads such as "Hypnotized" and its hit follow-up single "What've I Done (To Make You Mad)" [#8 R&B / #61 pop]; but besides her earlier Atco single, there are multiple examples here of her excelling at Motownesque uptempo material as well.  Her final single at Warner Brothers/Loma, "I Just Can't Live My Life (Without You Babe)" [one of five making its dbut on CD], even sounds like a Supremes title, but when it failed to chart, she and her excellent producer George Kerr moved on to Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff's Neptune label.  It was preceded by the classic big soul ballad "I (Who Have Nothing)," previously recorded by Ben E. King (who had the original U.S. hit with it) and the aforementioned Dee Dee Warwick.  This was just the type of song -tailor-made for Linda Jones.  The other slow-ballad cover version here [also making its CD dbut] is the one almost everyone was covering back then, Paul McCartney's "Yesterday."  Besides being ultra-soulful in her hands, this is her only song performance with a low-key ending, rendering it all the more dramatic.  Two other original ballads (co-written by Kerr) stand out for their rather spectacular, uncompromising expressions of heartbreak and torment: "Seeing Is Believing" and "Fugitive from Love."  Favorites of mine also include the southern-soul-style ballads "The Things I've Been Through (Loving You)" and "What Can I Do (Without You)."As one would expect from a Real Gone Music/Rhino release, the digital remastering from the original sources is impeccable; plus this being a David Nathan/SoulMusic production, we benefit from his extensive knowledge of the subject of American soul from this era in the form of four pages of liner notes (contained in the eight-page accompanying booklet).  Thanks to him as well, we finally get the definitive clarification 48 years later on the "hyp - NO - tized" / "hyp - MO -tized" mini- (extermely mini-) controversy.

For admirers of this utterly amazing and unique, modern-era (recording as a lead artist from 1957 to 1970, the year of his premature death at age 45) Louisiana delta blues harmonica master, songwriter and brilliantly expressive vocal interpreter of downhome, often country- and rock-tinged blues and R&B, this "complete" (and it is, for all practical purposes, just that) collection (5 discs, 410 minutes [=6 hours, 50 minutes], which averages to 82 minutes [!] per disc) is going to be incredibly difficult to pass up.The first two discs contain all his Excello-label issued material, which has all been available on high-quality CDs.  The harder question concerns the value of the other three discs: two containing all of the existing alternate takes and material that was unissued in his lifetime, plus the first-time-ever appearance of the last song he ever wrote and recorded (presumably, a home-made demo) during the last month of his life - January, 1970), and one (Disc 5) containing 87 and a half minutes of his live sets (including previously unissued material) from 1961.  I will admit that as a major fan of his since his biggest hit, "Baby Scratch My Back" from 1966 (talk about unique!) [#1 R&B / #13 pop in Cash Box], the first blues record I ever got - and I subsequently picked up his incredibly cool cover of Charlie Rich's "Mohair Sam" from 1968 (recorded at Fame Studios in Muscle Shoals) [#113 pop in Cash Box], as well as his 1969 "The Best of Slim Harpo" LP - I was a bit hesitant about this purchase.  The clincher for me was the 12 in. X 12 in., 104-page book, available nowhere else but as part of this package.  It is colorful and comprehensive and of the highest quality.  62 pages of extremely well-written and detailed notes by Martin Hawkins on Slim's life (and death) and entire career - including each recording session - make it totally indispensable for Harpo-ites. (I would estimate that on its own it would be a $60 item.)  And having listened to Discs 2 through 5, I am fully convinced they are worth it as well.  Some of the alternate takes are significantly different from the released versions and are arguably even more enjoyable in their own way.  The live tracks from '61 are a bit iffy, given that the sub-par amateur sound recording rendered Slim's vocals somewhat muddy.  However, his harp and his band's instrumental work come through tolerably well; and the extended live versions of their instrumentals "Buzzin'" and "Moody Blues" are outstanding - especially the nine-minute latter song which thankfully was mic-ed much better.Ultimately, you can never really go wrong with Bear Family box sets of your favorite musical artists.

1964 was undoubtedly a watershed year for the American pop-music scene due to the breakthrough of Liverpool, England's Beatles (whose three U.S.-issued 1963 singles, including future U.S. #1 "She Loves You," all tanked stateside that prior year) and the resulting so-called "British invasion" of groups and vocalists who followed them to the upper reaches of the U.S. pop charts.  There had been a mini-pre-"invasion" of sorts in 1962, but that was mostly by British instrumentalists such as Kenny Ball with "Midnight in Moscow" [#2]; Acker Bilk and his "Stranger on the Shore" [#1];and the first #1 record in the U.S. by a British group, "Telstar" by the Tornadoes (produced by the legendary and notorious Joe Meek), which held the #1 spot on the America's national pop charts for three weeks, just 13 months before the Beatles got there.  The other big breakthrough in 1964 was the Supremes becoming Motown's first act to cross over onto the pop charts with multiple #1 records (both pop and R&B) - three in a row in '64.  In fact, the Supremes actually spent more time at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 in the second half of 1964 than the Beatles did.This present collection contains no Beatles or Supremes - who would hardly qualify as "hard to find" - but it does feature other British Invasion acts; some girl and girl-group pop (a genre which, apart from the emerging Supremes, peaked in '63); a pair of surf-style instrumentals; a five-song R&B hunk (including blues man B.B. King's biggest crossover-to-pop hit up to that point, "Rock Me Baby" [so sad to hear of his death this very morning]); a couple of cool remakes (Johnny Rivers' "Mountain of Love" and veteran crooner Dean Martin's "Everybody Loves Somebody Sometime," which plowed right through to #1 in August); a car song ("G.T.O." by Ronny & the Daytonas); a novelty (Shirley Ellis's "The Name Game"); and a Top 40 hit by an unknown group, the Chartbusters, who were the first American group to credibly recreate the British beat-group sound with their "She's the One."Speaking of the British Invasion, in addition to the Kinks, Dusty Springfield, Herman's Hermits, Chad & Jeremy, and Matt Monro, THE highlight of this disc has to be the dbut in sensational digitally-enhanced stereo (DES) of the Animals' "The House of the Rising Sun" in its original unedited four-and-a-half minute British single form.  Five others that receive the first-time DES treatment and have never sounded better are Diane Renay's "Navy Blue"; the surf instro "Penetration" by the Pyramids; rockabilly Gene Simmons' "Haunted House"; Alvin Cash & the Crawlers' R&B dancer "Twine Time"; and saving the next most impressive for last: Terry Stafford's "Suspicion," the record that WOULD HAVE spent three weeks at #1 in the U.S. (instead of none nationally) if it weren't for the Beatles.The other U.S. solo act blocked by the Beatles (in this case, by their first and biggest of the year, "I Want to Hold Your Hand") for what also would have been three weeks at the top was Lesley Gore with her powerfully-delivered proto-women's-liberation anthem "You Don't Own Me."  It's the closer (Trk 29) and is especially moving in the wake of her recent passing.  [For the sake of pure trivia, since the record in question doesn't appear here, the U.S. act that got screwed the worst by the Moptops (twice as badly as either Lesley Gore or Terry Stafford) was the Four Seasons, whose "Dawn (Go Away)" was deprived of six (!) weeks at the top of the Billboard Hot 100.]The Diane Renay "twin spin" of "Navy Blue" and "Kiss Me Sailor" breaks format a bit, but forgotten follow-ups that flagrantly tried to ride their big-hit predecessors' coattails were a favorite phenomenon of mine from that era.  I'm also glad to get to hear a few records from the old days for the first time ever (51 years later!).  For me, there are three in this category for sure: French-Canadian chanteuse Lucille Starr's Edith Piaf-influenced ballad "The French Song (Quand le soleil dit bonjour aux montagnes), Scott English (an American from Brooklyn, as opposed to being yet another British invader) and his "High on a Hill" (not a drug song!), and the Gene Pitney-penned "Across the Street (Is a Million Miles Away)" by Ray Peterson, which barely squeezed into the Cash Box top 100 at #99.Please keep going with these superb compilations, producer Bill Buster (with sound producers Mark Mathews and Walt Weiskopf) and Hit Parade/Eric Records.

This "Complete 60s" pop instrumental series hit a licensing snag along the way (after Volume 3/1962) and has since had to double back to the 1950s, producing a brilliant set dedicated to 1959 and now this one, with 78 sparkling minutes of superbly sound-engineered nationally-charting instrumentals from 1950 to 1958.With a few exceptions from 1958, when the rock-inflected instrumental was becoming a bit more mainstream, what appears here for the most part is what came to be known as "easy listening," a very popular format on the radio with adult audiences of the era and well into the sixties.  In its instrumental form it tended to be highly orchestrated and would often feature one dominant lead instrument that would carry a catchy melody and have a "radio-friendly" running time of under three minutes.  More than being anti-rock-and-roll, this music was really anti-jazz, which in the '50s turned considerably more be-bop and diverged fairly dramatically from the pop mainstream.  As far as I can determine, only "Night Train" from 1952 (here in Buddy Morrow's orchestral version) came directly out of jazz.I'll confess that I like much of this time period's "easy listening" material somewhat less than its rock-era counterpart but am glad that it is being preserved by Bill Buster and company (sound production by Mark Mathews and Walt Weiskopf) and presented with superior sound to anything it has ever previously known.Why is this collection absolutely "essential"?  Answer: the magnificent "digitally-extracted stereo" (DES) CD dbuts of Les Baxter's "The Poor People of Paris" [the #1 instrumental hit of 1956 and sixth biggest pop hit overall in the breakthrough year of Elvis Presley]; Hugo Winterhalter and Eddie Heywood's "Canadian Sunset" [the fifth biggest instrumental hit of that same year, 1956 (and 21st biggest overall)]; and the rock instrumental classic "Tequila" by the Champs [the #1 instrumental and fifth biggest pop hit overall of 1958 (and the first-ever Grammy winner in the Rhythm & Blues category)].The accompanying booklet includes Greg Adams' six pages of concise but informative paragraphs covering each of the songs and artists featured in this collection.  The CD's back cover includes each song's national chart peak position (along with the year and month it dbuted on the chart), its running time, and if it appears here in regular stereo or in DES.Let's hope this valuable series can resume with its deep exploration of the rest of the 1960s; but in the meantime Bill Buster et al have done a phenomenal job with the fifties.

Gene Chandler's Brunswick singles national hit parade (peak positions on the Billboard soul chart listed as well as the peak pop-chart positions reached in either Billboard, Cash Box or Record World -- chronological song listing, which matches the CD track order):"The Girl Don't Care" (1967)  #16 soul / #50 pop"There Goes the Lover" (1967)  #46 soul / #96 pop"Show Me the Way to Go" [with Barbara Acklin] (1968)  #30 soul / - pop (did not chart)"There Was a Time" (1968)  #22 soul / #63 pop"From the Teacher to the Preacher" [with Barbara Acklin] (1968)  #16 soul / #40 pop"Little Green Apples" [with Barbara Acklin] (1969)  - soul (did not chart) / #123 popGene Chandler's national chart-hitting career spanned 24 years (1962-1986), and during this period of time he holds the record for hitting the R&B/soul charts on more different labels (9) than any other solo act.  I'm not sure what the significance of this "record" is, but it would seem to indicate that he was unstoppable.  At Vee Jay in 1962 he told us, "Nothing can stop the Duke of Earl" [#1 R&B and pop for multiple weeks on each chart]; and at his next stop at Constellation he proclaimed (in its title line), "Nothing Can Stop Me" [#3 R&B / #18 pop].  This present disc includes all nine of his singles (both A and B sides) at his fourth Chicago stop (immediately after the Checker division of Chess Records), Brunswick, from 1967 to 1969.  While at Brunswick he was the label's #2 male star after its longtime mainstay, the great Jackie Wilson.  Three of his nine single releases were duets with Barbara "Love Makes a Woman" Acklin, a terrific pairing clearly inspired by Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell at Motown.As you can see from the above "hit parade," there were no "Duke of Earl" massive-hit equivalents among his nine Brunswick singles, nor anything to rival "Groovy Situation," his first release at his next Chicago-based label Mercury in 1970 [#8 soul / #10 pop].  Yet all these Brunswick records are solidly soulful, mature and creative.  Chandler co-wrote nine of the 18 sides, all of which were superbly produced by Carl Davis.This whole Brunswick reissue series on Japan's Solid/Ultra-Vybe imprint boasts masterly stereo remastering and sounds astonishingly vibrant and bright (even on the disc closer "Suicide" [!], one of Chandler's greatest little-known records).  Included in the twelve-page accompanying booklet are six pages of clearly legible English lyrics to all 18 songs, plus two pages of new liner notes (in Japanese, which I don't read).Chandler's tenor soul balladry is intense from start ("The Girl Don't Care") to finish ("Suicide").  "Familiar Footsteps" is an absolutely exquisite ballad that is kind of a throwback to his earlier post-doo-wop/early-soul style.  Shame on all the radio stations that didn't play this back in 1969!  "Suicide" is shatteringly dramatic and beautifully orchestrated; but even in an era when a melodramatic death ballad like Bobby Goldsboro's version of "Honey" could reach the top spot on the pop charts, "Suicide" was taking things a step too far for radio programmers.  Note that Chandler's next release (and first at Mercury) was the irresistibly upbeat and sunny "Groovy Situation," which returned him to the Top Ten, both soul and pop.The big one with Barbara Acklin is the catchy, very Marvin-and-Tammi-like "From the Teacher to the Preacher"; but the surprise here is the best cover version (the sexiest, anyway) of "Little Green Apples," featuring a swirling orchestral backing.  Chandler's "Eleanor Rigby" cover is a cool mid-tempo one that borrows heavily from Ray Charles's hit remake.And for anyone convinced that Gene Chandler was merely a master of the soul ballad or occasional mid-tempo fare, listen to his sizzling take on James Brown's "There Was a Time."  He completely lets loose on this one, even tossing in his notorious post-"Duke of Earl" nickname "The Woman Handler" as he dances "the Gene Chandler."This is a fantastic 49 minutes of Chicago soul.
