Volume One of this series, covering the One-Derful! label, began with Otis Clay's "Got to Find a Way," his tribute to his mentor and great Chicago West side R&B/soul man Harold Burrage who suddenly departed this world in 1966 while at the height of his powers.  In fact, just the year before, Burrage had his biggest hit ever - as well as the M-Pac! label's [#7 on Cash Box's national R&B chart] - with his immortal original version of that hard-charging, relentlessly pulsating soul record.  But we don't just get this amazing record as it was issued in the summer of '65, as Secret Stash has unearthed and provided for the first time ever the entire record with its opening verse and chorus intact.  (These had been excised prior to release supposedly so that the radio of the day would have a snappier version to play.)  Thus we have one of the finest Chicago soul records of all time finally heard here as originally intended.  Say no more, I'm there!  [On the subject of the fantastic soul man Otis Clay, who is still very much with us, do not miss his outstanding 2013 and 2014 CD albums "Truth Is" and "Soul Brothers," respectively (the latter with Johnny Rawls).]  Burrage is also impossibly soulful on the insistent, regretful "Things Ain't What they Used to Be (Since You've Been Gone)."  And then there are two of his unissued tracks making their dbuts here: "Bad Situation," which has him in Otis Redding mode, and "Mountain of Soul," which is as catchy as its title.  How could these two have been left in the can?This is also the collection that features the company's answer to Aretha Franklin, the phenomenal Dorothy Prince.  Her "Hey Mister" (late '63/early '64) features churchy organ and majestic horns; but then in the final minute all hell breaks loose, with a sudden time shift (for the faster) and some no-notes-barred soul belting and wailing by Ms. Prince - who like Aretha and so many others from this era, transitioned from gospel singing to secular soul.  The B-side "Every Night," which closes the disc, is a powerhouse bluesy ballad with an after-midnight feel.It is so enjoyable to hear the Accents ever-so-upbeat "New Girl" from the summer of '64 again after so long - and the whistling bit remains a real attention-grabber.  It wasn't a nation-wide hit (unless you call a one-week "Bubbling Under the Hot 100" appearance at #128 in Billboard a hit), but it was huge in Chicago, reaching the top five on R&B station WVON and the top 30 on Chicago's pop giant WLS at a time when the British invasion was dominating their play list.  Just a carefree summer record from a youthful time.Maurice Dollison & the Turnkeys may not have succeeded in their attempt to launch a dance craze in 1963 with "The Earthworm, Part 1," but they did leave us with a cool, funky workout featuring Dollison's slithery guitar licks and a girl chorus's priceless backing vocal chants of "ah ooh wiggle wiggle" and "wiggle wiggle baby."  Also from the early days (late '62) comes Bobby Davis's one-off frenetic rocker "Damper Down," with sizzling guitar by Mighty Joe Young and a hot sax solo by Monk Higgins..  Also from '62 we get from Bobby Turner (the still actively recording younger half-brother of Blues and Rock & Roll hall of Famer Freddie King) and his fine self-penned ballad "Come Back Home," which melds his mellow vocal with Phil Upchurch's blues guitar and an early urban-soul-emerging-out-of-doo-wop sound.1966 brought the excellent southern-soul-style single "Don't Try to Fool Me" b/w "I Stand Alone" by raspy-voiced Stacy Johnson; while the even raspier voice of Willie Parker in 1967 inhabited three (two previously unissued) hard-driving tunes which sound eerily like Motown productions with the Funk Brothers.  And in this disc's most pleasant surprise, I'll take the closest thing M-Pac! had to Motown's Miracles, the Ringleaders (from Saginaw, Michigan) and their pleading, sweet-soul (a contrast with all the "hard soul" around it) 1966 ballad "Let's Start Over" reminiscent of "Ooo Baby Baby" with its soaring high-tenor (Smokey-esque) lead vocal.  It became a Chicago soul hit, but the other side ("Baby, What Happened to Our Love") also garnered some attention, as well it should have: it's a super-slinky, harmony-laden uptempo groover that refuses to let up.As with its predecessors, the sound work on this relatively - ranging to extremely - obscure material is sensational.  Again, there's a 36-page accompanying booklet with incredibly detailed liner notes profiling all the featured artists by "Chicago Soul" author Robert Pruter.  There is also an opening essay introducing this M-Pac! imprint, as well as a three-page essay on the history of the British Northern Soul dance-club phenomenon and how the One-Derful! / Mar-V-Lus / M-Pac! family of labels became so integral to its development.  Without the interest generated by Northern Soul, it is unlikely we would ever get to hear all this great old R&B/soul music prized for its obscurity as much as for its danceability.

With a voice that could just about have had her passing as the fourth singing Franklin sister (after Aretha, Erma and Carolyn) and a warm, honest and passionate delivery 100% on target on every one of these well-crafted Southern soul songs, the late Sandra Wright should have gotten more opportunities to record and become a big name in soul.Her only two real chances for a breakthrough came first with a pair of Coral-label singles recorded in Nashville in 1968 when she was twenty (they elicited no action) and then six years later for Stax Records in her native Memphis.  Both sides of her two singles for Stax (issued on the company's subsidiary Truth label in '74 and early '75 are here on this disc: the title track "Wounded Woman" b/w "Midnight Affair" and "Lovin' You Lovin' Me" b/w  "Please Don't Say Goodbye."  Again, no action, despite these being such strong soul tracks superbly produced and engineered by David Johnson at Broadway Sound in Sheffield, Alabama using a group of outstanding musicians mostly from Muscle Shoals (including a stellar horn section).  Still, five more tracks were recorded with the intention of an LP being released in '75.  Following Shirley Brown's huge soul/pop crossover success in late '74 on this same Truth label with her single "Woman to Woman" [#1 soul / #22 pop], things still looked promising for this type of down-home Southern soul.  But by '75 Stax was struggling financially (en route to bankruptcy the following year), and there was no way at that point for them to be able to promote and work a distribution deal for a virtually unknown artist with zero hits to her credit.  Thus, the LP was shelved and only first came out on the UK's Demon label in 1989.  And now it returns in 2015 on Soul Brother Records (thanks to the continuing British interest in traditional soul music), digitally remastered and sounding better than ever.  The nine tracks total just 28 and a half minutes, but this is solid Southern soul that sounds fresh and won't wear out its welcome.I would estimate that I have seven or eight favorites out of the nine, so I'll just mention a handful: "Wounded Woman," with its infectious mid-tempo groove makes it in my mind a cousin to Barbara Acklin's "Love Makes a Woman" and "Clean Up Woman" by Betty Wright [no relation]; "Lovin' You Lovin' Me" adds some sensuality of the sort Millie Jackson was selling with at the time (albeit without any of the raunch occasionally associated with Ms. Jackson); "I Come Running Back" is an Aretha-style mid-tempo ballad fueled by the fantastic horn section; "I'm Not Strong Enough to Love You Again" (the briefer "Not Strong Enough" might have been a better title) is in the warm and confessional style of labelmate Shirley Brown; while "The Sha-La Bandit" is the one that fascinates me the most.  It has somewhat of a soft and slinky Memphis Hi Records style that makes me think this had to be inspired by Al Green's "Sha-La-La (Make Me Happy)," which was just taking off around the time this was recorded.  It almost seems like an "answer" record about having her "sha-la" (happiness) stolen from her.  I could be way off here, but I'm enjoying it anyway, as I am this entire disc.This is classic, traditional Southern soul with a 1968-1974 flavor - with no funk or synthetic elements.  Thanks again, Soul Brother, for giving us the real thing.

Recorded in 1971, "Faithful" was intended to be Dusty Springfield's third LP at Atlantic, after "Dusty in Memphis" (1969) and "A Brand New Me" (1970), and was expected to be released early in 1972.  Yet only now (a mere 43 years later!), thanks to Real Gone Music (UK), it is seeing its first release in its complete original album form.White-hot producer at the time, Jeff Barry, was brought over to Atlantic to helm this project (he also arranged, as well as contributing three new songs); and while I'm not going to say this LP, as now thoroughly reconstituted, is as strong overall as its two predecessors, it is definitely playing in the same league.  Dusty is as passionate and emotional, sultry and soulful as ever -- and I would contend that at least a couple of her finest performances on record can be found here.Two singles from this set did in fact get issued in 1971, but despite their high quality, neither charted nationally.  The first single A-side, "Haunted," (written by Barry and Bobby "Montego Bay" Bloom) has Dusty in hard-charging Motown mode on a song that reminds me a lot of two by Marvin Gaye that I really liked from 1968 (preceding "I Heard it Through the Grapevine"): "You" and "Chained" (both about love obsessions, as is "Haunted").  The Barry-Bloom B-side "Nothing is Forever" (a bonus track here, as it was not intended for the "Faithful" LP) is a big ballad, Dusty's other specialty besides soulful pop.  The second issued single was Jeff Barry's "I Believe in You," which sounds as though it could have been the deepest southern-soul recording ever attempted by a white British artist up to that point.  It's one of her greatest moments, but it may have been too specialized for the marketplace at the time, which was mostly driven by radio airplay.  The B-side was the dramatic pop ballad with strings, "Someone Who Cares," a 1970 movie theme done first by Kenny Rogers & the First Edition.In any event, with these two singles going nowhere; and given Dusty's "dissatisfaction" with Atlantic (according to Joe Marchese's informative liner notes), she flew the coop (moving to ABC/Dunhill) before the LP could be released, pretty much assuring its extinction.But at least we have it now!  And in addition to "Haunted" and "I Believe in You," it contains some other truly fine ones.  The original, "Love Shine Down," is one of several gospel-tinged numbers (there is also the opener "I'll Be Faithful," whence the LP's title, and its closer, "I Found My Way Through the Darkness"), and her performance on it is clearly Aretha-inspired.  Interestingly, Dusty does a catchy, uptempo original titled "All the King's Horses," which would appear to have inspired labelmate Aretha's own self-penned 1972 ballad by this exact title.Besides the aforementioned "Someone Who Cares," the two other cover versions here are of some note [no pun intended]: Carole King's "You've Got a Friend" (from "Tapestry") has to be one of the most covered songs of the '70s, but Dusty's version was actually one of the very earliest, recorded before "Tapestry" even got to the #1 spot.  It should be noted that Dusty had regularly been covering Carole's songs for eight years when she recorded this one.  But taking the remake cake is a magnificent, heavenly reading (with a gorgeous Barry arrangement) of David Gates/Bread's #1 pop ballad from the previous year, "Make It with You."  It could very well be Dusty's most sensual vocal performance ever.  She almost seems to be caressing the words as much as singing them; and it doesn't take long before she's floating on air into her highest register.  I'll repeat: magnificent!And only four tracks later (with the excellent "Love Shine Down," "I Believe in You" and "Have a Good Life" in between), she is rocking out southern-style (very credibly, I might add) on the pounding, insistent, electric-guitar-laden "Natchez Trace."This is definitely the frontrunner so far in 2015 for finest album reissue of the year.

I belatedly realized I could not consider myself a true connoisseur of '60s/70s pop music without owning at least one full CD of the best of Serge Gainsbourg.  Given the task of putting together 70 minutes of his best work, I don't think it's possible to do much better than this "best-of" set consisting of 23 songs spanning 1958-1980.  I really can't quibble with any of the selections here; and I'm grateful that some songs I find irritating, such as Marabout, Jeunes femmes at vieux messieurs and Nazi Rock are NOT present.  (I realize Nazi Rock is a spoof, but having heard it once is sufficient.)Most indispensable of course is the inclusion of the sexually provocative Trk 12, Je t'aime moi non plus with Jane Birkin from 1969, the notorious international sensation that was banned from the airwaves all over the place (even in France, where it was not allowed to be broadcast until after 11 p.m.).  Despite being banned by the BBC (or possibly because of it), it got to #1 in the UK.  In the U.S., where it was disallowed by most outlets, it got to #58 nationally on the Billboard Hot 100 (make that the very hot 100!); and Record World had its fun by allowing it to rise to #69 on its chart.  I heard it on the air in Urbana, Illinois, but that was on college radio.  (Chicago's two 50,000-watts Top 40 stations were busy playing the Archies and the Cuff Links at the time.)  And yes, Gainsbourg did purposely plan this record's release for '69, which he labeled l'anne rotique.  Trk 14, in fact, is none other than the companion Jane Birkin duet titled 69 Anne rotique.  Both Bonnie and Clyde (Trk 8) and Je t'aime moi non plus were recorded as duets with Brigitte Bardot, but BB requested her original version of the latter be withdrawn before release (so to speak).  Gainsbourg, after offering the song to a few others who turned it down, finally landed on (so to speak) a willing Jane Birkin.  Trk 10, Initials BB, has a moping Serge in London trying to drink away the vivid, haunting memories of his steamy, whirlwind affair with Bardot.  It too is essential listening.From the turn of the '70s, La Ballade de Melody Nelson is here, as is La Dcadanse (such a clever wordplay coinage for dirty dancing) with Birkin.  From mid-decade is the terrific pop song Je suis venu te dire que je m'en vais ("I Came to Tell You I'm Going"), an eloquent expression of profound regret about a romantic affair run its course.  From the end of the decade is Gainsbourg's most highly-charged political song ever: his reggae-style, defiantly satirical and anti-establishment take-off on the French national anthem La Marseillaise titled Aux armes et caetera.  France's virulently anti-Semitic right-wing went nuts and his life was seriously threatened.  Gainsbourg, in his own iconoclastic way, wound up reminding the country that La Marseillaise was itself a hated, feared - and banned! - song by the establishment of its time, which is how it emerged to become the anthem of the Revolution in the first place.The disc closes with a duet featuring yet another all-time lovely, Catherine Deneuve, on the only slightly blasphemous song Dieu fumeur de Havanes about God being an appreciator of fine Cuban cigars.Besides Je t'aime moi non plus I'll choose as three favorites: 1) the disc-opening Le Poinoinneur de Lilas, which was also the opening track of Gainsbourg's dbut LP from 1958 -- it's really a brilliant short story in the form of a mesmerizing up-tempo song about a Paris Mtro ticket puncher who faces an existential dilemma; 2) Qui est in qui est out? (1966), a breezy freakbeat commentary on the disposable pop culture of the time (including the pop music scene that he himself was part of); and 3) last but not least, the insanely catchy (and just plain insane - like a fox) Chez les Y-Y (1963), in which he recreates what would roughly be the equivalent of a Taylor Swift pop hit for its time appealing to young girls (of course, the music was much better then!) and...let's just say, he adopts a subversive, highly socially inappropriate attitude that turns it inside out.  Hilarious, as is the must-see(-to-believe!) YouTube dancing man video of the song.Poet, satirist, sensualist, iconoclast, provocateur, playboy, pervert, eccentric genius with a solid grasp of popular music and the power of the pop lyric, Serge Gainsbourg was not afraid of flying too close to the sun.

This is truly exceptional: over two and a half hours of instrumental music from Motown Records 1964-1970.  The Motown hit factory in the Detroit years (until the move to LA starting in '72) was not exactly known for its instrumentals.  In fact, only five Motown instrumental single sides from this era ever charted nationally: four by Jr. Walker & the All Stars and one by Stevie Wonder using the pseudonym Eivets Rednow (his name spelled backwards).  And none of these cracked the Top 30 on any of the national pop charts.However, the company in its Detroit heyday was known for its fantastic, extremely consistent and influential session musicians. They were the ones who developed what became identified as "the Motown sound" and were its backbone and unsung heroes.  Chief among them were bassist James Jamerson and the Detroit jazz organist/pianist Earl Van Dyke whom Jamerson persuaded to give up life on the road and come to work at Motown.  Van Dyke was such a powerful and unique player Motown went ahead and released six singles and two LPs under his name.  They are all here on these two filled-to-the-brim discs by Hip-O/Select/UMG/Motown - plus ample bonus material, including three ultra-rare (two previously unissued) tracks under Jamerson's name.  There is nothing here that is short of smoking hot, despite the fact that none of the issued material ever rang up enough sales to chart nation-wide.The first LP, "That Motown Sound" (1965) by Earl Van Dyke and the Soul Brothers (Motown felt that the name Soul Brothers had more class than the rhythm section's real name, the Funk Brothers), consists of 12 tracks whose vocals were replaced by EVD's Hammond B3.  Most of these tracks are so familiar ("My Girl," "Nowhere to Run," "Come See About Me," "How Sweet It Is (To Be Loved by You)," etc., that at first it seems strange to hear EVD's organ chime in at the exact point, for example, you're expecting to hear David Ruffin intone "I've got sunshine on a cloudy day...".  Each track on its own really cooks, no doubt about it, but you really have to like the soul organ sound to stay with this for 12 straight tracks.  Four (!) tracks of Marvin Gaye tunes is excessive (more variety is needed) and will make you miss Marvin's voice.The Disc 1 bonus tracks really help out with this variety "problem," as they include both sides of EVD's 1964 dbut single "Soul Stomp" and "Hot 'N' Tot" (on which those titles tell the whole story), as well as his cool 1966 single "6 By 6" with The Motown Brass (Motown's stellar horn section).  "The Flick" (composed by EVD, Jamerson and guitarist Robert White) is not in its two-part 1966 single form but appears instead in a previously unissued, uncut alternate version, which at 12 minutes long becomes rather tedious (too much of a good thing perhaps).  There are also a couple of tracks recorded live in Paris: sizzling, somewhat jazzier reprises of singles heard earlier, "Soul Stomp" and from the "That Motown Sound" LP, the Marvelettes' "Too Many Fish in the Sea."Disc 2 is anchored by Van Dyke's second, final and even rarer live LP, "The Earl of Funk," from 1970.  Since it is not tied to any previously laid-down tracks, it has the distinct advantage of being freer and looser (although the funk is tight and intense on a number of the dozen tunes here), allowing these superb musicians (George Benson, sax; Uriel Jones, drums; Eddie "Bongo" Brown, congas and percussion; in addition to EVD, Jamerson and White) to really shine (and jam [!] on the funk numbers).  It's a cool mix of mid-tempo to slow pop and pop-soul ballads of the era ("Someday We'll Be Together," "My Cherie Amour," "Rainy Night in Georgia," "Wichita Lineman," and one from the early '60s, "Stand by Me"), one pop-rocker that gets s soul workout ("Na Na Hey Hey Kiss Him Goodbye"), a bunch that get majorly funked up (The Meters' "Cissy Strut," Sly Stone's "Thank You Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin," EVD's previous single "The Flick" and two originals: EVD's "The Stingray" and the EVD-Henry Cosby-Stevie Wonder co-write "The Whip-A-Rang," as well as a throwback to an earlier era (think Duke Ellington in the '40s), saxophonist George Benson's "Fuschia [sic] Moods."  Speaking of this George Benson (as opposed to the singer-guitarist of the same name), he is also amazingly mellow and compelling at the same time on "My Cherie Amour" and "Rainy Night in Georgia."  Electric guitarist Robert White glows on "My Cherie Amour" and is utterly fine on my favorite here, the bluesiest version ever of Ben E. King's "Stand by Me."The Disc Two bonus tracks, besides the three James Jamerson features (Wow, does "Fever in the Funkhouse" ever live up to its title!), include the moving closer "Ode to Benny B." (dedicated to the recently deceased Funk Brothers drummer Benny Benjamin), on which Stevie Wonder contributes the harmonica part; EVD's final single, "Runaway Child, Running Wild"; and two of my other favorites in this collection, which have EVD playing piano:  Jimmy Ruffin's "Gonna Give Her All the Love I've Got" (very slinky and cool) and a previously unissued version of the ever-tuneful "Too Busy Thinking About My Baby."  (I know, yet another Marvin Gaye song over a a pre-recorded track; but this is from a different time, and we get to hear EVD on a different instrument.)This is an outstanding compilation, with sparkling digitally remastered sound and a colorful, photo-filled 28-page booklet that includes detailed track credits and well-written, informative notes by "Standing in the Shadows of Motown" author (and film co-producer) Allan Slutsky,  It's a bit too rich for even a couple of sittings; but listened to a bit at a time it's a breath of fresh air for fans of Motown, instrumentals, and sixties soul and funk.

One would most likely need to be a dedicated fan of the genre to even know the name of the late songwriter/singer George Jackson (who passed away two years ago), let alone be interested in this third volume of his "rare and unreleased recordings from the Fame [Records in Muscle Shoals, Alabama] vaults" from the late '60s/early '70s. Jackson was a staff songwriter at Fame during this time, so what we have here are mostly unsold demos sung by him.  Only the anomalous title song of this collection, the "tear-in-his-beer" country ballad "Old Friend" (co-written with O.B. McClinton, who went on to become one of the most successful black country recording artists of the '70s and '80s), sounds fully fleshed out.  It had previously been recorded at Goldwax in Memphis by soul artist Spencer Wiggins, and it seems as if it were at some point intended for release in this George Jackson Fame-recorded version.As far as pure lyrical phrasing is concerned, Jackson was close to unbeatable, as no one grasped the nuances of his songs as well as he.  But vocally, in terms of his sound, while pleasing and competent enough, his singing did not possess the excitement or uniqueness (the memorability or recognition factor) necessary to stoke major record sales - certainly not in a league with, say, Clarence Carter or Wilson Pickett, the two most prominent male recording artists who recorded his Fame songs.One song here in demo form that did make it onto a Fame recording was the swaggering "My Own Style of Lovin'," which was tailor-made for Wilson Pickett on whose 1969 "Hey Jude" LP it would appear.  Both the Jackson demo and the Pickett recording feature the stinging electric guitar licks of the immortal Duane Allman.  Another good one that got picked up was "Heart on a String," which came out as the 1970 B-side of Candi Staton's soul/pop crossover hit (also a Jackson co-write), "I'm Just a Prisoner (Of Your Good Lovin')."  (Staton was by far Fame's all-time leading female artist.)  "Break Away from Me" was no doubt intended for Clarence Carter but was obviously too much of a sound-alike with his big hit "Too Weak to Fight," also co-penned by Jackson.  And speaking of unsellable sound-alikes, Jackson's "I'm in the Middle of a Good Thing" comes perilously close to infringing on Eddie Floyd/Steve Cropper's "Knock on Wood" copyright.These demo recordings have the major advantage of being backed by Fame's stellar Southern-soul session musicians; and the more layers that were applied to each one the better.  The lead-off track "It's Up to His Woman" has impressive soul horns on it, while the consecutive rocking tracks, "Switch Tracks" and "Two Legs and a Red" (the latter again penned by O.B. McClinton), feature cool (non-Duane Allman) guitar.  "Just Another Day" is a sweet soul ballad [no kinship with the Paul McCartney song] with gorgeous piano, organ and guitar.  The bouncy, organ-driven duet "Gotta Have Soul" with co-writer Marjorie Ingram (sounding a bit like Carla Thomas) could have had minor hit potential with a full production.Frankly though, a few too many of these songs and recordings don't really amount to much and would seem to be here solely to be put on the historical record, so to speak - and can be considered completist fare only.  Hence, my four-star rating.  As CDs of demos go, this is no Carole King's "The Legendary Demos" (2012); but it still contains enough good tracks to recommend it.One track I am definitely not recommending is the closing one, which is just a curiosity piece: the 1963 crude home demo recording of an 18-year-old Jackson doing his own "Won't Nobody Cha-Cha with Me."  It's as bad as its title would indicate (and it's a rough two and a half minutes to get through for the listener).Finally, this being a Tony Rounce Ace/Kent Soul compilation, we get the benefit of his four pages of insightful, meticulously researched liner notes.Oddity: The penultimate track, an attempt at a Percy Sledge-style ballad, is twice listed and once referred to in Rounce's notes as "That from the Heart," which is not even English.  It should be "That Comes from the Heart."

This is easily one of the best soul jazz recordings of its decade (the 1970s), made for what had been the genre's leading label, Cadet, the jazz division of the legendary Chess Records of Chicago.  "Superstition" (1973) was the third of organist Shirley Scott's three LPs for Cadet from '71 to '73, but the label was then owned by GRT out of New York and wouldn't be for much longer.  But whereas the business situation was in decline (as it had been since Leonard Chess's death in 1969), artistically it had no effect on the excellence on display here: superb production by Esmond Edwards and a fantastic lineup of personnel backing Shirley Scott who was still at her '60s peak.This is forty minutes of "sizzling hot, funky '70s soul jazz" [quoting my review title] that never lets up.  Shirley's 7:44 original "Hanky's Panky" (I assure you, nothing to do with Tommy James & the Shondells!) is rip-roaring and sets the whole tone for this LP, allowing her whole crew of soloists to let loose: Jimmy Ponder (electric guitar), Jimmy Owens (trumpet), and a real star turn throughout by Ramon Morris on tenor sax.  In the penultimate position (Trk 6) comes her other original here, the equally hot (but shorter and with a higher Shirley solo quotient) "Liberation Song."  Not receiving solo time but deserving of major credit is the rhythm section of drummer Grady Tate and bassists Ron Carter and Richard Evans, the latter of whom provided all the stellar horn arrangements.That leaves the five cover versions, all of which receive the funkiest blasts of soul they have ever known: the Carpenters' "Rainy Days and Mondays" for darn sure!  The Beatles' "Lady Madonna" is the first of these.  We knew from Fats Domino it had R&B/soul potential, but nothing like this.  It positively smokes!  The title song, Stevie Wonder's "Superstition" is the least surprising choice, but it's definitely a cool one to hear on soulful organ.  For me, two peak high points (as opposed to all the other nothing but high points) are her takes on the Stylistics' touching and beautiful "People Make the World Go Round" and Gato Barbieri's brilliant jazz theme from "Last Tango in Paris."  The former is framed in all its melodic gorgeousness, but Shirley and company are undeterred from exploring its inner grooviness and jamming with it for a while.  The latter builds on Barbieri's sweet, swirling melody and takes it to the stratosphere - and saxophonist Ramon Morris does seem to be somewhere in outer space on his intro and outro solos.  But then, when you see that the closer is the languid Paul Williams/Roger Nichols ballad "Rainy Days and Mondays (Always Get Me Down)," immortalized by the soothing but sad-sounding voice of Karen Carpenter, it looks like Shirley is set to take us home with a sweet, slow one.  Not on your life!  She turns it into a jaunty romp that will have you thinking maybe rainy days and Mondays aren't so bad after all.This is the sort of seventies soul jazz I like the best: all organic (excuse the pun).  Thank you, Soul Brothers Records (UK).

This is entirely synthed and programmed electro-pop music, which I don't care for in most contexts - but it works very well on "Maneater," "I Can't Go for That," "Kiss on My List," and surprisingly, "Sara Smile."  On some of the other tracks, though, it's a bit off, even creating sort of a sour sound (which nearly sinks "She's Gone," for example, and detracts from what otherwise could have been an excellent "One on One.")  At least, the mechanics of this music are understated and simple enough that it doesn't become unlistenable at any point.  However, it's Inara George's cool, detached, yet pleasingly retro-soulful, note-perfect vocals on every one of these Hall & Oates covers which make this album something special and worth listening to on repeated occasions.The disc's opener is the one original here by the duo (Greg Kurstin and Inara George), and it's a real attention-grabber: "Heard It on the Radio" is by far the "busiest," most thoroughly contemporary production here, but it fulfills its mission of setting you up for the tuneful Hall & Oates music (we heard on the radio) to follow.These H & O songs are solidly constructed pop gems that don't need much alteration; and fortunately, the melodies are all left intact.  But it's kind of a mixed bag for me overall.  I really like the aforementioned four (from my opening sentence) a lot but cannot completely endorse the rest.  Organic musicianship with some of the same cleverness exhibited here could have made this an all-around indispensable covers album.  [Total time of album is 30:14.]

Little Milton (Campbell) may not have been the greatest R&B artist or the greatest blues artist or the greatest soul artist of all time (although I would rank him high in each category), but he and Bobby Bland were easily the two best ever at incorporating all three genres into all their work for many decades (both of them breaking big in the 1960s).  Little Milton could also play a downright dazzling electric blues guitar when the song at hand called for it.Growing up in the '60s, I had three Little Milton 45s on the Checker (division of Chicago's Chess Records) label: the magnificent message song "We're Gonna Make It" from 1965 [his biggest hit ever: #1 R&B / #18 pop]; "More and More" (famously covered by Blood, Sweat & Tears" later in 1968); and in 1969, the title song of this present stellar LP which sounds sensational on this super-high-quality stereo Japanese-import reissue."Grits Ain't Groceries" is sheer late-'60s R&B greatness - an exciting, rollicking remake of the Titus Turner tune that turned out to be Little Willie John's dbut hit [#5 R&B] in 1955 (then titled "All Around the World").  Little Milton scored a #13 soul / # 73 pop hit with it.  I thought its passionately powerful and smoldering Chicago blues B-side "I Can't Quit You Baby" (co-written by Milton, and with that dazzling guitar I mentioned) made it an unbeatable combination, worthy of of #1 - at least on the soul charts.  "I Can't Quit You Baby" (all 6:42 of it) appears here as Trk 3, right after "Grits," which is as it should be.  In any case, it was Chess Records' biggest R&B/soul hit of the year, which is significant considering that they were up against the Motown machine, James Brown and Aretha Franklin who combined to spend 36 (out of 52) weeks at the top of the Billboard soul chart in '69.Both sides of the follow-up 45 to "Grits Ain't Groceries"/"I Can't Quit You Baby" are here: "Just a Little Bit" b/w "Spring."  "Just a Little Bit" (originally recorded by Tiny Topsy in 1959) is another rousing and gritty energy generator that coincidentally also peaked at #13 soul - but could only manage to crawl to the #97 position on the Hot 100 pop chart.  (Neither Bobby Bland nor Little Milton were artists Top 40 stations of the era were interested in programming consistently: too soul-bluesy, as opposed to toned-down and smoothed-out Motown-y pop-soul which dominated the black-music quotient on white-run stations across the country),  "Spring" is a mid-tempo groover with a hot horns, sax and organ accompaniment that won't just won't quit (truly - it goes on for an extra minute or so with Milton just joyfully ad-libbing and soul-wailing behind it.There is an excellent cover of Jimmy Hughes' Muscle Shoals/Fame studio original "Steal Away," while "You're the One" has Little Milton in full-on, smoky-voiced Bobby Bland R&B crooner mode.  The LP closer takes him deep into B.B. King territory (guitar and all): a stunning remake of B.B.'s "Did You Ever Really Love a Woman" from 1956.  For anyone looking for a shorthand way of describing Little Milton's music, you could just say he was kind of a musical cross between B.B. King and Bobby Bland, and you wouldn't be far off.What a year 1969 was for these three: B.B. King's "Why I Sing the Blues," Bobby Bland's "Chains of Love" and Little Milton's "Grits Ain't Groceries"!  I'm so glad to finally have this outstanding LP 46 years later on an exceptionally high-quality CD.

Ace/Kent Soul and compiler/liner-notes author Tony Rounce have done it again!  For the first time ever we get every one of Garnet Mimms's 14 singles (both A & B sides) during his hit-making years (1963-66) at United Artists working with the great Jerry Ragovoy and Bert Berns as his producers and co-writers (Jerry Ragovoy produced on all 29 tracks).  And to bring the total CD running time to 77 minutes, Kent Soul included as the catchy closer the 1964 LP title track (and should-have-been single) "As Long As I Have You."  Incidentally, the Veep label was United Artists' R&B subsidiary on which Mimms's final three 45s for the company were placed.Because we are dealing with Ace Records, all the deluxe CD-package amenities are in place: impeccable sound mastering (nearly all tracks are in stereo), making the 1960s sound as good as they ever have since...well, the '60s and the original 45s (until we wore them down); and exquisite graphic and photographic art, featuring all the colorful realia you could want in a 16-page booklet, and which serve to illustrate Tony Rounce's telling of the complete Garnet Mimms musical story: from his gospel, pre-R&B/soul roots and finally back to gospel and the church again.In 1963 Garnet Mimms accomplished something that Hall of Famers James Brown, Ray Charles, Sam Cooke, Marvin Gaye, Otis Redding and Jackie Wilson did not: Mimms had two U.S. Top Ten R&B records, including a #1 song that also made the pop top four.  The only other recording act that year to do this was Martha & the Vandellas.  And by the way, the aforementioned Sam Cooke and Jackie Wilson were - as we learn in the liner notes - the two biggest influences on the big-voiced Mimms's singing.  The fact is that Mimms was so vocally versatile he could sing comfortably in several different registers and styles.  (Just for fun, see if he doesn't sound almost exactly like Ben E. King on his revival of the Jarmels' "A Little Bit of Soap," as well as getting eerily close to Sam Cooke's sound on "That Goes to Show You" and "Keep On Smilin'.")Garnet Mimms's great #1 R&B smash [three weeks at #1; also, #4 pop on all three principal U.S. charts at the time] was Ragovoy's and Berns's "Cry Baby," his dbut United Artists record with his backing group the Enchanters.  The verses are sincerely and warmly voiced, measured and melodic; but then the chorus erupts into emotive secularized gospel fervor in a strikingly original way that caught people's attention and may have advanced the development of soul music in the '60s (as a separate branch of R&B) more than any other single record - particularly given its huge and unexpected crossover success.  The song was still as compelling as ever eight years later when Janis Joplin had a posthumous Top 20 pop hit with it.I will just mention my favorite Garnet Mimms records from the following two years: "A Quiet Place" (1964), with its realistic depiction of close-quarters urban living (euphemism for tenements/slums), had diminished chart success [#25 R&B / #73 pop] due to its having been a B-side originally; and the emphatic and sophisticated "It Was Easier to Hurt Her" (1965), which only "bubbled under" the Billboard Hot 100 at #124.

The Valentinos on the charts: peak positions noted - national R&B and pop:-"Lookin' for a Love" (1962)  #8 R&B / #63 pop-"I'll Make It Alright" (1963)  #97 pop-"It's All Over Now" (1964)  #21 R&B / #63 pop**[big pop chart discrepancies: #63 Cash Box / #94 Billboard / #112 Record World]-"Everybody Wants to Fall in Love" (1964)  #142 pop (Cash Box)cover versions:-The Rolling Stones: "It's All Over Now" (1964)  #25 pop / #1 UK****[The Stones' first British #1 (one week in July between The Animals' "House of the Rising Sun" and the Beatles' "A Hard Day's Night")]-Wilson Pickett: "She's So Good to Me" (1966) [track on LP "The Exciting Wilson Pickett" (#3 R&B / #21 pop)]-J.Geils Band: "Looking for a Love" ('71-'72)  #30 pop (their first chart single)-Bobby Womack: "Lookin' for a Love" (1974)  #1 R&B (3 wks) / #8 popThe Valentinos (1962-64) are primarily known for having launched the career of the late soul great and Rock & Roll Hall of Famer Bobby Womack and for their two biggest hits ("Lookin' for a Love" and "It's All Over Now"), which became even bigger hits later on.  In the case of the Rolling Stones and "It's All Over Now," which came out just a month after the Valentinos' original, the original's progress on the pop charts was significantly impaired  as the latter came to dominate Top 40 radio airplay.  (However, an initially disappointed Bobby Womack would receive ample consolation in the form of songwriter royalties.)The new early-sixties term "soul music," as opposed to the existing term "rhythm & blues," originally referred to the secularized adaptations of gospel songs that were becoming hits. The clearest example of this is offered by the juxtaposition on this present CD of Trks 2 and 3, the gospel single "Couldn't Hear Nobody Pray" by the Womack Brothers and their dbut secular single "Lookin' for a Love" as the Valentinos, a direct adaptation of the former.  Sam Cooke, who co-founded and was heavily involved with running SAR, was a major proponent of this new development in black popular music and was only too glad to have his young protgs (the Womack brothers, a.k.a. the Valentinos) become the breakthrough group in this field.This is exciting, very raw and emotive, organic-sounding music - all the more so on the tracks featuring Bobby Womack's raspy, gritty, compelling and commanding lead vocals.  Some of the others (ironically, on those most influenced by Sam Cooke's smoother sound) make a much lesser impression.Stellar sound engineering by ABKCO Records and a very fine booklet with comprehensive, highly informative liner notes by author Bill Dahl; and also possibly the most thorough individual track and session credits you will see this year for recordings that go back 54 years.  Just a superlatively produced compilation by Teri Landi.  This is a superb follow-up to last year's L.C. Cooke's "Complete SAR Recordings."

This LP was the very obvious follow-up to the moderately commercially successful "The Look of Love."  Both took their titles from their opening Burt Bacharach tunes; and both included other contemporary pop hits, including by the Beatles.  This one added a second Paul McCartney Beatles song, with the last two tracks being "Hey Jude" and "Fool on the Hill."The arranger on both "The Look of Love" and "Always Something There" was the great Thad Jones, who contributed one excellent original blues-jazz composition for each - here, one called "Home Town," which outstrips everything else due to its creative jazz content.  For this outing, Jones - who strictly stuck to his arranger-composer duties on "The Look of Love" - played trumpet on half of the ten tracks.  However, only add to the orchestral pop side while detracting from the soul-jazz side.I would have to say that much of this particular "Always Something There" advantage is offset by the dubbed-in strings on all tracks which There is quite a roster of notable sidemen here, including Kenny Burrell on guitar (for eight tracks); Jerome Richardson on flute, clarinet and duet tenor sax; and Herbie Hancock and Hank Jones splitting the piano assignments (with Hancock appearing on eight tracks).The two slow, romantic ballads, Leslie Bricusse's "When I Look in Your Eyes" (from "Doctor Dolittle") and "Song for Bonnie" (an original by brother Tommy Turrentine) are beautifully rendered - and I'll cut them some slack for their use of the dubbed-in strings.That leaves the seven pop covers, which are generally taken at a midtempo pace (which means "Hey Jude" moves along faster normal, actually making for an appealing change) and don't stray too far from their principal melodies.  Frankly, not much can be done with "Little Green Apples" or "Those Were the Days," but Turrentine and company sizzle and sometimes even soar on the others due to the cool, brilliant melodies, changes and sequences they have to work with.  In addition to "Hey Jude" and a graceful, waltz-time "Fool on the Hill," we're talking the Doors' "Light My Fire" (definitely an incendiary bluesy-soulful take on this one!) and Laura Nyro's groovy "Stoned Soul Picnic."  And the title song, "Always Something There," originally recorded as a soul record by Lou Johnson, is given a prime soul-jazz take here to get things started.  Blue Note artists as formidable as the ones I've named cannot possibly miss targets this well constructed - and they don't.  The good time they are having bounces right back on us, the listeners.  Special kudos to Stanley on "Stoned Soul Picnic" for becoming so enthralled that he can't hold back from launching into some far-out improvisation toward the end.  Too bad it gets faded out so quickly, as this LP was not really going for that.This Japanese-import Blue Note reissue is the first high-quality one for this LP (avoid the earlier Liberty-label cheapo knockoff reissue at all costs!) - with impeccable stereo sound, all the original artwork, plus the original liner notes by the renowned musician and jazz writer Leonard Feather.Granted, this is not for jazz purists who view with utter contempt anything associated with sixties pop songs.  In my opinion, just a couple of the song choices are not the best, and the strings should have been limited to the ballads only.  However, if you just want to hear some delightfully melodic '60s music played unpretentiously and enthusiastically by an all-time great who delivers the goods with his trademark soulful tone and effortlessly attractive phrasing, this is a worthwhile CD to have.

Gerry Goffin/Carole King "Hung on You" hit parade -- highest national chart placements:Bobby Vee  "Sharing You" (1962)  #12 (Music Vendor) / UK #10The Drifters  "When My Little Girl Is Smiling" (1962)  #18 (Cash Box) / UK #31Earl-Jean  "Randy" (1964)  #147 (Cash Box)Dion  "This Little Girl" (1963)  #19 (Cash Box)The Shirelles  "What a Sweet Thing That Was" (1961)  #30 (Cash Box)Freddie Scott  "Where Does Love Go" (1964)  #30 (Billboard R&B) / #82 (Billboard pop)The Righteous Brothers  "Hung On You" (1965)  #43 (Cash Box)Tony Orlando  "Am I the Guy" (1961)  #124 (Music Vendor)This is the fourth of Ace's Goffin-King songbook CDs; and besides the top six songs listed above - which saw some chart success and were by major artists of the day - I am almost certain that I had only heard two others of these records before: Dusty Springfield's excellent (superbly produced at Atlantic) version of "That Old Sweet Roll (Hi-De-Ho)" and the Phil Spector-produced "No One Ever Tells You" by the Crystals - both from prior collections that went deep into the artists' material.That left 18 recordings for me to discover here for the first time, including some complete chart missers (and two that barely "bubbled under"), B-sides, tracks from obscure LPs, one that went unissued at the time, and a pair of UK-only singles.There are a couple of oddball songs here: a novelty by the Clovers called "The Sheik" and "Please Hurt Me" by Little Eva, which is in the same repulsive lyrical vein as Goffin's notorious (and quickly withdrawn) "He Hit Me (And It Felt Like a Kiss)" by the Crystals.  While not really "oddball," "Road to Nowhere" by the obscure (there's that word again!) folk-rock-y harmony group The Hearts & Flowers from 1967 (it would almost have to be from '67 with a name like that!) contains desolate lyrics which (at least subconsciously) may have presaged the impending dissolution of the Goffin-King marriage and professional collaboration.For the newly discovered (by me, anyway) gem of gems here, of which I knew neither the singer nor the song, I would have to go with Henry Alston and his soaring and heart-rending vocal on the Drifters-esque "So Many Lonely People" (1964), featuring some of Gerry Goffin's most poignant and empathic lyrics.  Ace Records compiler Mick Patrick's informative liner notes, which provide a thumbnail of all the songs and artists, tell us that Alston had been in a mid-'50s R&B vocal group and was essaying a comeback as a solo act.  Unfortunately this fine record, produced by Goffin and arranged by Carole, went nowhere and Alston was never heard from again.  But a big thank-you to Ace is in order for enabling us to hear this 51 years later.I could go on about the attractive 16-page accompanying booklet with all the photos and realia (in addition to Mick Patrick's liners), but this is a given with any Ace collection.  For those who must know, ten of the 26 tracks are in stereo.  I think the title song/CD opener "Hung On You" by the Righteous Brothers was defectively mixed by Phil Spector (rather muddled -- but note, nothing to do with Ace's highly professional remastering process), which might explain why it got flipped by radio stations all over the country and the B-side oldie "Unchained Melody" (sung by Bobby Hatfield) became the much bigger hit.

This third and final Gene Chandler LP on Brunswick from 1969 (preceding "Groovy Situation" and his subsequent stint at Mercury), like its two predecessors, laid a commercial egg, failing to chart at all; and the pair of high-quality singles it produced also missed the national charts, both R&B and pop.  At that point Chandler was thought of as a singles artist - and pre-"Groovy Situation" was still somewhat in the shadow of his Vee Jay days and his gigantic crossover pop and R&B smash "Duke of Earl" [#1 on both charts for multiple weeks] from seven years earlier.The "two sides" referred to in the title are not exactly in balance.  Chandler delivers a trio of original soul ballads (that's one side), while his cover versions of mostly recent records (the other side) number seven.  Three of these latter seven are direct lifts from the 1968 Ray Charles songbook, using close to the same arrangements and emulating Ray's vocal style: the upbeat, semi-funky take on "Eleanor Rigby" and two ballads from the LP "A Portrait of Ray" - the recent French hit by Nicoletta ("The Sun Died" / Il est mort le soleil) and the 1933 Jerome Kern-Otto Harbach show tune "Yesterdays" (also recorded by Sinatra).  The other covers include his credible closing take on Dinah Washington's "This Bitter Earth"; Bobby Goldsboro's maudlin #1 pop song "Honey" (Ouch! Hard to turn this one into soul); the cool opener, Tyrone Davis's "Can I Change My Mind" (essentially a twin version); and an excellent reading of Herb Alpert's #1 pop version of Burt Bacharach-Hal David's "This Guy's in Love with You" (which Gene sings much better than Herb).It's the three original soul ballads that really stand out, though.  Producers Eugene Record (of Chi-Lites fame) and Carl Davis contributed the majestic, pleading "If You Would Love Me," while Chandler co-wrote "Familiar Footsteps" (which has a warm doo-woppy melody and vocal to match, reminding us a bit of his "Duke of Earl" glory) and the shatteringly dramatic, exquisitely orchestrated "Suicide."  "Footsteps" sounds like a shoulda-been hit, but it was out of step with the late '60s; and while the death song "Honey" was huge in '68, "Suicide" was just too much for a single, despite being a superb record.This Japanese-import series of Brunswick LP reissues on CD features top-of-the-line sound mastering and sumptuous stereo.  This is a well-produced, very well-performed album, with the only problem (besides the inclusion of "Honey") being that the remakes don't really bring anything new to the table other than a better lead vocal on "This Guy's in Love with You."

This is the first time that the twelve singles by the great Southern soul ballad pioneer Johnny Adams recorded for the Ric and Ron labels (same company) have been assembled on one disc with both the A and B sides and all from the original masters.  Add a couple of demo takes unearthed in 2013, and you have the 26 tracks that comprise this superb hour-long CD compiled by Tony Rounce who also wrote seven pages of informative liner notes contained within the colorful 12-page accompanying booklet.  And then there is the usual stellar sound-mastering work that Ace provides.Johnny Adams was a New Orleans gospel singer who by happenstance at the age of 27 in 1959 suddenly found himself embarking on a secular "soul" music (before it had that generic designation) career with a string of big local and Gulf Coast hits on the Ric label.  Only one of these broke through to the national R&B charts in 1962, that being "A Losing Battle," a mature Ray Charles-esque ballad co-written by a certain young Malcolm Rebennack (who had been working with him since '59), which climbed to #27.  Malcolm "Mac" Rebennack later became known as Dr. John.  Later in the '60s for SSS International, Adams, more in the guise of a country-soul crooner (foreshadowed by his 1964 recording of Hank Williams' "Cold, Cold Heart," found here), had his only major national crossover [soul Top Ten and pop Top 30] hit with "Reconsider Me."  From 1984 until 1998 (the year of his death) he had a distinguished run of nine albums for Rounder Records in a mixed soul and blues mode, peaking with the stone masterpiece "Room with a View of the Blues" in 1987.From his first secular ballad and original signature song "I Won't Cry," and including his entire 1959-64 run at Ric/Ron, it is abundantly clear that this is one of the finest vocalists of all time, Southern soul or otherwise.  Normally a smoky baritone, he could seamlessly shift into smooth mid-range tenor; and then, as intense emotion warranted, he would go into a bone-chilling high tenor, or even a blood-curdling falsetto soul wail when the feeling so moved him.  His astounding vocal range was used judiciously and never exploited as a gimmick, as Adams remained ever committed to the integrity of each song he sang.

This is the once great and soulful Ramsey Lewis lost in bland, mediocre and outdated electro-pop-disco-funk land playing mostly disposable musical fare.  The first album ("Routes") has him drowning in synths, while the second ("Three Piece Suite") is awash in overprominent electric bass and percussion (and in a few cases, pointless dubbed-in strings).His shining (Ramsey-of-old) moment is the tender, reflective ballad "Looking Glass" from "Routes" - and wouldn't you know it, this is the only song where he was involved in the writing...and it's a Steinway Concert Grand solo performance.  One can only wonder what it is doing here; or else, why couldn't he have committed himself to a whole album of such worthwhile creative artistry?  (Obviously, we know the answer was a cash-grab attempt by his Columbia-label overlords.)"Routes" also has the slight advantage of New Orleans legend Allen Toussaint producing and composing four tracks: "Crystals 'N' Sequence" is a short-but-sweet pop-soul effort, while unfortunately the melodically gorgeous "You Are the Reason," which could have been prime Ramsey, is instead sabotaged by an annoyingly repetitive, way-too-prominent electric bass line.  (The other two Toussaint productions are of the generally forgettable funk sort that do nothing to enhance his legacy.)From the second LP's title "Three Piece Suite" and the cover photo of Ramsey in a black tux, you would expect a classic-jazz result, but what you actually get are songs so forgettable that you'll be forgetting them while still listening to them.  It's Ramsey just going through the motions, half-heartedly, and succumbing to the whole overproduced mess.These two 1980/1981 LPs were pathetic attempts to milk the last ounces of commercial profit out of the pop-funk and disco crazes which had exceeded their 1978-79 expiration dates.  "Routes" and "Three Piece Suite" limped into the '80s with precious little actual jazz content.  What a waste of talent!  Ramsey Lewis did do some fine work during his Columbia years, but at least a few of his LPs were treated as not much more than mere commercial product, and the artistic bar was appreciably lowered.  Clearly, that is what happened here, and only one outstanding track got through: the solo "Looking Glass"; plus the very good Allen-Toussaint-penned pop-soul (not jazz) instrumental "Crystals 'N' Sequence," both from "Routes."

Actually, the 2014 Grammys got two right, both in American roots album categories, a million miles removed from all the commercial junk that dominates the proceedings.  Rosanne Cash richly deserved her recognition for "The River and the Thread" for Best Americana Album.  ("Americana" is country that is not instantly disposable, which is why Sturgill Simpson also wound up in that category); and this present album, Jo-El Sonnier's brilliant labor of love, "The Legacy," which took top prize for Regional Roots Music Album.Specifically, the region (in "Regional") is South Louisiana's Acadiana, the heart of French-American Acadian (Cajun) culture (a.k.a. "bayou country").  The music is traditional French Cajun, so the accordion (of which Sonnier is a master) and fiddles are prominent, but the sound in this modern era is also filled out by other compatible country instruments, including pedal steel guitar; and the singing is in the region's traditional native language, which is French.  In reality, it's a colorful, tasty (like crawfish and gumbo) independent dialect of French going back hundreds of years.  In the modern-communications era, a bit more of the surrounding American Southern influence has crept in (case in point: Trk 9, titled "J'ai Gone Fou" for "I'm Goin' Crazy"), yet despite much vocabulary borrowing, its grammar and usage remain remarkably intact.  The central question is whether or not the French language at the root of Acadian culture can survive.Jo-El Sonnier's "The Legacy" is certainly a mighty contribution to this effort to preserve tradition and language.  Twelve of the thirteen  (one is an instrumental) have entirely Cajun French lyrics (translations available at his website).  In his hands the accordion may be the most emotive instrument on the planet, capable of turning on a dime from joyful to mournful and then back again (since the Cajun spirit is optimistic - which it has always had to be in order to be able to survive through incredibly adverse circumstances).  Cajun music has never been accused of holding back its emotions.Sonnier can also be heard on harmonica; co-producer Shane Theriot plays acoustic and electric guitars and percussion; Kevin Hare is on bass guitar (and he is also responsible for the superb sound engineering on the record); Beau Thomas and the matchless Michael Doucet handle the fiddles; Joe Rogers and Laine Thibodeaux provide steel guitar [it's hard to go anywhere in Cajun country without encountering a Thibodeaux or a Theriot!]; Doug Belote and Brian Brignac are on drums.  Called "The Legacy Musicians" on this project, they put up quite the Cajun wall of sound!Jo-El Sonnier was a country-chart hitmaker from 1975 to 1990, with 1988 being his peak commercial year: two Top Ten singles, 55 weeks on the Billboard country chart (he had overlapping hits), and the Top 20 LP "Come On Joe."  When commercial country became largely a southern pop-rock hybrid, Sonnier returned exclusively to his Cajun roots; and his talent and integrity have been recognized with multiple Grammy nominations.  This breakthrough winner "The Legacy" (which he states "has been a lifetime in the making") represents yet another artistic game-raiser for him.  It is absolutely sparkling, intensely immediate and affecting - and is 100% organic and authentic (and made in Cajun country!)

This album amply demonstrates the degree of diversity that is possible in the blues-rock hybrid genre.  And it certainly doesn't hurt that it features two lead vocalists: guitar wizard/leader Nick Moss who is more of a gruff-voiced rockin' blues guy, and rhythm guitarist Michael Ledbetter who is a convincing and compelling soul singer.  They also combine for the bulk of the songwriting duties - in fact, all but a pair of exceptional covers: a haunting rendition of Son House's "Death Letter Blues" (lead vocal by Moss) and a tough-as-nails take on Faces' "Bad 'N' Ruin" (from 1971), with Ledbetter assuming the original Rod Stewart lead.There are a generous 14 tracks here and a running time of 77 minutes.  Of the dozen originals we have what I would deem a Nick Moss Band seven-minute magnum opus, nearly a Derek & the Dominos "Layla" moment, if you will, in the Ledbetter (lyrics)/Moss (music) co-write "Fare Thee Well" (sung by Ledbetter, with superb background vocals by Tina J. Crawley and Lara Jenkins), propelled as much by Bryan Rogers' piano and Patrick Seals' drumming as by Moss's stellar guitar.  But ultimately it's the perfect construction of the song mated with Michael Ledbetter's searing and soulful, spot-on delivery of  his moving words (about trying to hold on to love against the odds), which match the equally soulful melody to  a T, that make this a magnificent track.While "Fare Thee Well" is a cut above, there are no slouches here.  "I Want the World to Know" has Ledbetter testifying soulfully, and he's again in his tougher "Bad 'N' Ruin" mode on "Tell You Somethin' 'Bout Yourself."  The intriguing "Walking on a Ledge" balances on the edge of rock and soul, while Moss nails the heavy blues-rocker "No Reason" and the easy, breezy, Southern-soul-sounding "EZ Bree Zee."  There's even a delicious closing jazz-funk instrumental (with Bryan Rogers on organ this time) called "(Big Mike's) Potato Pie," on which Moss executes his fieriest extended guitar solo as he takes us home.There's more, but I'm risking carpal tunnel syndrome as it is.  Best work yet by Moss & Co.  A good "Time" was had by all.

Great-sounding Japanese import CD of a 1970 Brunswick soul-jazz instrumental LP (recorded in 1967) by the high-energy organ/tenor sax-led combo the Wildare Express, featuring organist Reuben Wilson before he was signed as a leader by Blue Note.Seven of the ten tracks are covers of pop and/or soul hits from 1963 to 1967 (in fact, five are from that latter year and thus were extremely fresh when this LP was recorded).  The three originals are all very cool (and since it was 1967, I'll say it, "groovy") jams of the jazzy R&B or blues sort, with "Cruising" being particularly tight (it appears to have been issued as a promo single).  The others, having been recent hits, resonate particularly well for fans of this era's music due to the strong recognition factor, while also offering the fascination of how deftly they were able to be transformed into sparkling soul jazz by young, enthusiastic, and undoubtedly expert musicians.  As it turned out, these songs could not have been better chosen; and the proof is that they all have endured over the intervening 47 years.  One might initially wonder how the Bob Crewe Generation's "Music to Watch Girls By" could possibly be transformed into soulful jazz.  The answer is quite groovily, thank you very much.  (This one has to be grabbed for the next "Austin Powers" movie!)  It is one of the highlights here.  The Express's "Walk On By" (the Burt-Bacharach-Hal David song made famous by Dionne Warwick in 1964 - and the CD's title song) is given an ultra-appealing midtempo Latin-beat treatment.  And speaking of "treatment," the Sweet Inspirations' "Why (Am I Treated So Bad)?" is a funky sizzler that I believe surpasses in sheer gusto the Cannonball Adderley hit instrumental cover from that same year ('67).  Two rather serious songs, Percy Mayfield's "A River's Invitation" and Lou Rawls's recent "Dead End Street" get lively, swinging, carefree workouts.  ("Dead End Street" was officially issued as a single in '67 b/w "Why Am I Treated So Bad" [Brunswick 55343].)  "Alfie" is the second Bacharach-David number here, and the Wildares make it this set's most dramatic ballad -- in fact, it is the only song taken at a slow pace.  Stunningly lyrical sax.  And here is something you don't encounter too often in a jazz context: a Motown girl-group song.  In this case it's Martha & the Vandellas' "Jimmy Mack."  The sax traces the melody line quite literally, but when Wilson's Hammond B3 comes in, a minute of hip, funky jamming ensues until it closes with a brief recap of that same familiar bouncy and joyful melody.If one could acquire this item in an actual record store, I would recommend you walk on in and buy "Walk On By, " the one and only LP by the fabulous Wildare Express.  Express yourself the Wildare way!

Mary Love has to be one of the most obscure artists in a popular music genre (i.e., soul) to have ever received the full-disc anthology treatment.  She only managed to dent the Billboard R&B/soul Top 50 twice (in 1966 and in 1968) and placed no higher than #46.  This is no reflection, however, on the quality of her work during this period, since that #46 record, "The Hurt Is Just Beginning," written by Mary Love herself, is an absolute beauty of a compelling, mature, smooth and exquisitely melodic soul ballad, which based on merit should have received major airplay on all the soul and Top 40 radio stations.  It was one of the great records of a great year (1968) for soul music -- and to think I only heard it here for the first time 46+ years later!  (It was easily better than 80% of the Top 25 Hot 100 songs of the moment, which included "Little Arrows" by Leapy Lee; "Bang-Shang-a-Lang" by the Archies; "Chewy Chewy" by Ohio Express; "Cinnamon" by Derek; "Quick Joey Small" by the Kasenetz-Katz Singing Orchestra; and I'll toss in Bobby Vinton's "I Love How You Love Me."  I'm making myself sick!)  I will go so far as to say that there was no better singer-songwriter record in the entire Hot 100 during the weeks of November 30 and December 7, 1968 (the two-week period when it was riding the bottom of the soul chart).There are a solid half-dozen other soul gems here, including consecutive 1966 releases on the Modern label that feature her bluesier side, "Move a Little Closer" (her other national R&B chart placer) and "Think It Over Baby"; the hard-charging title song of this CD ("Lay Your Burden Down"), which showcases her astonishing soul-wailing ability during the latter part of the record; the funky but emotive "Born to Live with Heartache"; the yearning ballad "There Is Someone for Me" (the latter two shared the same 1971 45); and "Loving You" (from a 1977 blaxploitation film soundtrack, no less), a deeply-felt, dramatic ballad with a Millie Jackson-like country-soul vibe.  These last three songs were penned by the singer.So far so good, but I cannot endorse the final fifteen minutes comprising her later religious recordings.  Besides being utterly inorganic, low-rent productions, they are full of simple-minded, repetitious, proselytizing propaganda I never want to hear again.This being a Kent Soul/Ace Records release, the 1960s/1970s music sounds as fine as anyone could reasonably expect.  (Six tracks are mono, nineteen are stereo, and the 1965-67 Modern label material was meticulously re-mastered.)  The 20-page accompanying booklet is among the most colorful, photo-and-realia-packed of its kind you'll ever see (near the top end, even for Ace), with detailed liner notes that recount the artist's life story (not an easy one; Mary Love passed away in 2013 at the age of 66) by the disc's compiler Ady Croasdell.

Conductor Anatole Fistoulari was something of a ballet specialist, and over the years I have managed to pick up several of his titles, all enjoyable, on a variety of labels -- Gayne Ballet Suite, Adam - Giselle  (complete ballet) ~ Offenbach - Gat Parisienne ~ Strauss Graduation Ball / Fistoulari, Dorati and Tchaikovsky: Swan Lake [Highlights].  A few years ago the Australian arm of Decca reissued this two-fer in their Eloquence line, and I knew from the moment I saw it on Amazon that it was going to be worth owning.  I suppose the best part of this collection is the variety.  Unlike the aforementioned titles that focus on the work of a single composer, here we get selections from numerous composers -- Verdi, Mussorgsky, Saint-Saens, Rossini, Weber, Walton and more.  As the liner notes relate, "The music on this pair of CDs falls in to one of two categories: ballet music from an opera, or ballet music that was not originally intended for dancing at all, but that was subsequently adapted for that purpose."  (The exception is Minkus' "Don Quixote".)  Three recordings are in mono from the mid 1950s (J. Strauss II, Weber & Minkus), but the rest of the titles are in stereo from the early 1970s.  Interestingly enough, the highlights here for me are the four "dance" numbers -- Verdi's "Moorish Slaves," Mussorgsky's "Persian Slaves," Weber's "Invitation" and Rossini's "Soldier's Dance" from William Tell (not knowing the opera, a nice companion to that famous Overture). Overall, Fistoulari's feel for ballet music is impressive but I am also consistently impressed by the quality of performances that Eloquence Australia continues to unearth from the vaults.  "World of Ballet" is a welcome addition to both the conductor's and label's catalog.

A few years back, I spent a great deal of time (and money) tracking down OJC discs before they went out of print, and then critiquing them here on Amazon when no one had yet to offer their comments. While the "Birdlanders" volumes did not elude me as a purchase, somehow I forgot to review this title at the time -- well, let me remedy that. These 1954 recordings, originally issued as three Period label LPs then re-sequenced by date as two CDs, were the brain child of pianist Henri Renaud, a visiting French amateur who assembled these groups out of jazz musicians that frequented the club Birdland. As a result, we get a first rate jam sessions from some of the great NYC players of the time. Volume 2 is divided up into two groups -- a March 13th sextet session featuring Renaud, Al Cohn, Kai Winding, Tal Farlow, Oscar Pettiford and Max Roach, and a March 5th quartet date with Renaud, Cohn, Gene Ramey and Denzil Best. I didn't know much about Renaud before this so it is educational and enjoyable to hear his original compositions, "Marcel the Furrier" and "Burt's Pad," along with solid renditions of standards like "Stardust" and "You Stepped Out of a Dream." This isn't essential material by any means, but a worthwhile collection for both the music and the window into the world of Birdland that it provides.

The other day I was having fun searching around on Amazon and came across this title from EMI's old "Artist Profile" series, and it got me reminiscing.  Years ago when I first got into classical music, these were the two-fers -- most of them found in a cut-out bin at Tower Records -- that got me focused on the great conductors and performers of the genre, instead of just the composers.  Granted the Cluytens set isn't as valuable all these later as it was for me then, but along with Andr Cluytens accompagnateur (as accompanist) (see my review), it sent me down a path of discovery for one of my favorite conductors.  While much of the music here appears on a plethora of different reissues, some of it still remains unavailable in any other form save this CD (to the best of my knowledge anyway) -- Pierne's Concertstuck for Harp and Orchestra and Berlioz's L'Enfance du Christ Overture for instance.  That is significant for serious collectors, and for novices, you get one of the best ever renditions of Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony plus a terrific Debussy "Jeux" and a whole lot more.  I would not recommend paying ridiculous collector prices for this dual disc, but more than 15 years since its initial release, there probably aren't a lot of discounted options remaining for truly interested parties.

In the past couple of years, I have really enjoyed exploring the recordings of conductor Karl Munchinger.  You can imagine my delight then, when the newest batch of Australian Eloquence reissues featured five volumes of Romantic Overtures, one of which was dedicated to performances by Munchinger.  "Volume 3" is a two-disc set -- the first CD showcases works by Weber, Schumann, Schubert, Cherubini and Mendelssohn, while the second focuses mostly on Beethoven, but also concludes with two mid 50s mono tracks, Schumann's "Manfred" and Gluck's "Alceste," both with L'Orchestre de la Suisse Romande. (The other selections are all in stereo with the Vienna Philharmonic.)  For the serious collectors out there, please be aware that the 1975 account of Schubert's "Die Zauberharfe" Overture is the very same one contained on Schubert: Rosamunde (see my review), but as that was the title that introduced me to Munchinger, I can't complain too much about duplication.  The real treat here for me are the Beethoven performances -- it is so refreshing to hear Munchinger's light and airy treatments of the "Leonore" and "Egmont" Overtures, and fascinating to compare the same orchestra on the same pieces under the baton of Karl Bohm or Hans Schmidt-Isserstedt.  One final nerdy note, usually the album art for these Eloquence reissues has nothing to do with the old LP jackets, but here they have used the same painting that graced the Decca original -- nice touch.

In the mid 1970s, Leonard Bernstein had some major personal life changes, the least of which was growing a beard and making a few recordings with the Orchestre National de France for EMI, including a rather eccentric account of Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique, which I enjoy but others have absolutely crushed.  The great cellist Rostropovich didn't seem like the type to tolerate too much tom-foolery, so this rendition of Schumann's Cello Concerto doesn't present too many surprises, though the seemingly average pulse could also stem from the fact that it's a B+ Concerto to the A's that are the Dvorak & Elgar.  (As an aside, it really gets the little brother treatment when paired with the Rostropovich/Karajan "Don Quixote" on the Great Recordings of the Century reissue -- now that's a performance!)  On the other hand, this is one of the very best performances of Bloch's "Schelomo," most likely why it comes first in the track listing even though it receives second billing on the jacket cover.  An altogether tougher nut to crack, once the listener gets passed the dissonance, it is one of the most expressive pieces in the repertoire.  It too has been reissued, paired with a Haydn Concerto in the most unlikely fashion, but at least available in a newer form than this title.  However, owning the aforementioned Strauss and Haydn on separate discs, was my reason for purchasing this long out of print, LP length, 1987 produced CD.  Though with prices currently skyrocketting for it used in the Marketplace, you may want to settle on the other editions to hear this fine music.

My introduction to this music came via the old budget EMI Seraphim title Handel: Water Music Suites for Orchestra No 1-3/ Music for the Royal Fireworks, so it is only natural that I have an affinity for Yehudi Menuhin conducting these works.  These recordings have been widely available over the years and are currently available through a variety of CD collections, including the box set Handel: Water Music / Fireworks Music / Concerti Grossi.  I settled on the Double Forte editions as they were very inexpensive a decade ago on the old HMV Canada website, when the dollar was way up.  Many period instrument purists may object to these performances, but some of them are 45 years old and the stereo still sounds impeccably clean and crisp today.  I love these accounts, however I must say that Simon Preston's organ sound always struck me as a bit carnivalesque.  If you can find this two-fer as cheaply as I did (there are some really great used CD prices currently), then it would be too hot for you not to Handel.

My introduction to this music came via the old budget EMI Seraphim title Handel: Water Music Suites for Orchestra No 1-3/ Music for the Royal Fireworks, so it is only natural that I have an affinity for Yehudi Menuhin conducting these works.  These recordings have been widely available over the years and are currently available through a variety of CD collections, including the box set Handel: Water Music / Fireworks Music / Concerti Grossi.  I settled on the Double Forte editions as they were very inexpensive a decade ago on the old HMV Canada website, when the dollar was way up.  Many period instrument purists may object to these performances, but some of them are going on 50 years old and the stereo still sounds impeccably clean and crisp today.  I love these accounts, and if you can find them as cheaply as I did, then it would be too hot for you not to Handel.

If you were on a jazz game show, and the question was name the pianist who recorded a trio album with Charles Mingus and Max Roach as his rhythm duo, you would most likely answer Duke Ellington ("Money Jungle").  However, if for some crazy reason you said John Dennis, the host would probably have to check with the panel of judges to discover you were also correct!  To my knowledge, the only other album Dennis played on is "The Fabulous Thad Jones" so how he was able to get Mingus and Roach into RVG's studio in 1955 may seem like a small miracle.  But after just one listen to "New Piano Expressions" it is abundantly clear that this pianist more than holds his own in that elite company.  And as good as the five trio tracks are (plus three alternate takes), it is the four solo selections at the end of the disc which show Dennis' true genius -- an amazing ability to play with both hands a la Erroll Garner, Art Tatum, Oscar Peterson or some classical master.  So after listening to this disc, the next question our jazz host could pose is "Why did John Dennis not make it big?" and unfortunately that answer doesn't come so easily.

Albert Ayler's "Spiritual Unity" and Pharoah Sanders' Pharoah's First (see my review) launched ESP Disk in 1964.  Eight years later when "Revolutionary Ensemble" was released, both the company and the free jazz movement were drifting into obscurity.  Despite this, I have always found this trio date to be one of the most exciting things ever produced by the label, or in the entire musical genre for that matter.  During the 47 minute epic "Vietnam," violinist Leroy Jenkins, bassist/cellist Sirone and percussionist Jerome Cooper cover an incredible musical palette -- they are a warped classical chamber group, a rockin' Mahavishnu-like power trio, the ghost of a Paganini Caprice, wild avant-swingers, a horror movie soundtrack, fireworks and explosions, wounded animal noises, everything but the kitchen sink.  It is an amazing tour de force, and rather improbable that there aren't more contemporaneous recordings of this group (or that anyone had ever bothered to review this disc here).  Sometimes this style of music and its subject matter are a product of their period and environment, but when it's on, like it is here, it can transport you across space and time.  Truly Revolutionary!

"Meet the Jazztet" is the classic Jazztet offering, but of all the other albums collected on the Art Farmer/Benny Golson Mosaic set, "Here And Now" is the most impressive in my opinion. These 1962 sessions (February 28 & March 2) find trombonist Grachan Moncur III joining the frontline, along with a rhythm section of Harold Mabern, Herbie Lewis and Roy McCurdy.  There are terrific versions of Golson's now standard "Whisper Not" and Monk's "Ruby, My Dear," plus some impressive originals by Farmer, Moncur, Mabern and pianist Ray Bryant ("Tonk").  Inexpensive copies of this out-of-print CD with mini-LP cover are still available in the Marketplace, so interested parties get a copy of this disc while it is still in the "Here & Now."

...this Kodaly reissue is really unnecessary.  The best thing about this arm of Decca is that they find unreleased and rare recordings from their vast vaults, and make them available to the public when seemingly no one else will.  Well, this Kertesz Kodaly material has been readily available for years, AND even Decca Australia has reissued most of this material before on Kodaly: Hary Janos Suite/Dances of Galanta/Peacock (see my review).  Surely, there are still some deserving performances that could be dusted off for us classical connoisseurs rather than just repackaging of another staple.

Some jazz fans think Pharoah Sanders' Karma is the tenor saxophonist's best album and an unqualified jazz masterpiece.  I on the other hand, don't really care for all that chanting and singing, so my favorite Pharoah album is Tauhid.  Of course, before Sanders was snatched up by a major jazz label, along with other Coltrane disciples, to cut those aforementioned classic sides, he made this record for ESP -- 49 years ago yesterday in fact -- on September 10, 1964.  While "First" isn't as fully developed as his later Impulses, and Pharoah works better without a pianist in my opinion (though Jane Getz plays admirably), it also doesn't have all of the dated hippie trappings of his more "mature" efforts either.  An excellent place to start then, to hear an early avant-garde squawker who would go on to become a master.
