The title of this CD, "After Hours," is misleading -- it makes you think it is a sultry, late night saxophone ballad compilation when it is simply the name of what is the longest and possibly best track on the disc. In fact, this is another in a series of two albums on one CD reissues of Willis "Gator Tail" Jackson's 1960s Prestige albums. While other collections have been a fun discovery (see my reviews of Please Mr Jackson, Legends of Acid Jazz, and Nuther'n Like Thuther'n), unfortunately this one is a bit of a mixed bag. The March 26, 1963 session that produced the original LP "Loose..." is solid and features some terrific up-tempo jams, along with the aforementioned, quieter CD title track, performed by trumpeter Frank Robinson, organist Carl Wilson, guitarist Bill Jones and drummer Joe Hadrick. It is the second part that disappoints -- the original LP "Soul Grabber" recorded over two days in October 1967. To me this just sounds like instrumental R&B, like Sam & Dave without the singing. The tunes have good beats but there is nothing original here, and the short, jukebox length of the songs leaves no room for improvisation. Overall four stars is being kind, but with "After Hours" current price under a buck in the Marketplace, I'll be generous and round up a little.

I purchased this CD because when checking my collection against the track listing of the new DG Karajan 1960s Box, I realized this was one of a handful of performances I did not already own.  So instead of plunking down hundreds on the set and trading in all of my old discs, I opted to order this CD for under a dollar plus shipping from a Marketplace vendor.  Rossini's String Sonatas were written during the composer's youth, so they are more ear-candy than the orchestral showpieces that are the Overtures.  With that in mind, one could argue that a chamber group may be more appropriate than the Berlin Philharmonic to showcase this music, but my feeling is why not hear one of the world's greatest orchestras, even if it is only their string section, when given the chance for any and all of the repertoire.  A respectable Rossini disc then, if not earth-shattering like Karajan's "William Tell" Overture -- see my review of Rossini and Suppe: Ouverturen.

It's hard to believe that five years after first discovering OJC CDs were being remaindered, and then after hundreds of purchases, there would still be a few titles for me to unearth during a trip to Boston two weeks ago. Sure enough, this Art Pepper title was one of five discs I found at the Newbury Street Newbury Comics, though in fairness I did have it on my Amazon Wish List for some time.  While I love classic jazz of the 50s & 60s and own more than 3000 albums from that era, I probably own only a few hundred jazz albums made after 1980.  Art Pepper is a perfect example of why -- I adore his recordings for Pacific and Art Pepper Meets the Rhythm Section, but for the longest time I didn't bother with anything past 1960's Smack Up and Intensity.  All that changed a few years ago when I found a used copy of Complete Village Vanguard for less than a buck a disc.  I simply couldn't pass up a bargain like that regardless of how good the music was, but upon listening to it I was not only blown away by Art's playing (and of course Elvin's drumming), but also by a pianist I had never heard of previously -- George Cables.  Pepper said that Cables was his favorite pianist, and considering Art recorded with the likes of Hampton Hawes, Russ Freeman, Carl Perkins and Wynton Kelly, that was some compliment.  It's easy to see why after listening to this disc, and its companion Tete-A-Tete, as the duo have a telepathic connection.  "Goin' Home" is also special in the Pepper discography because he plays clarinet on half of the eight tracks.  This would prove to be Art's last album as he died a month after its recording.  While many jazz fans, myself included, can be a bit snobbish and dismissive when it comes to jazz players whose careers span decades, being especially (and often unfairly) critical of the later years, Art Pepper was someone who had something to say musically from the beginning all the way up to the very end.

It's hard to believe that five years after first discovering OJC CDs were being remaindered, and then after hundreds of purchases, there would still be a few titles for me to unearth during a trip to Boston two weeks ago.  Sure enough, this Willis Jackson title was one of five discs I found at the Newbury Street Newbury Comics, though in fairness I had seen it previously on Amazon, but thought it was only a compilation.  In actuality, "Gentle Gator" is much more than a mere comp.  I like to think of it as a companion of sorts to At Large -- the latter collecting the more upbeat numbers from original LPs "Shuckin," "In My Solitude," "Neapolitan Nights," and "Really Groovin," while "Gentle," you guessed it, showcases the ballads from the same albums.  While I prefer the honkin' soulful Gator to the sultry soulful one, there are some real gems on "Gentle," especially mid-tempo numbers like "Girl of My Dreams," "Careless Love," "Amor" and "They Didn't Believe Me."  I don't know if I would pay full price for this CD, but if you can find one marked down as I did, then you can say hello instead of see you later, to this Gator.

Tchaikovsky Ballet highlights discs are a dime a dozen, but I've enjoyed learning more about the tendencies and subtleties of a variety of conductors by listening to their performances of such well-known, popular fare.  One such CD is Sleeping Beauty (see my review) -- I hadn't even heard George Weldon prior to puchasing this, but I knew the Philharmonia, and I was impressed by how much the conductor extracted from this orchestra, compared to the likes of Kurtz, Sawallisch and even Karajan in similar material.  Unfortunately, there aren't many other Weldon discs around -- a great Grieg Piano Concerto with soloist Gina Bachauer (see my review on Music of Edvard Grieg) was all I could ever come up with, until I saw this CD advertised in the liner notes to another recent purchase, Symphonie Fantastique (again, see my review).  These IMG reissues don't have extravagant packaging compared to some historical labels, and it would be nice for them to print something (anything) about the recording specifics, but the sound quality is good enough considering they are late mono recordings.  Weldon's Elgar readings fall short of Boult or Barbirolli's, but they are impressive enough, with the Enigma Variations particularly insightful.  This release doesn't do complete justice in showcasing George Weldon's talents, but I suppose with only a handful of titles to choose from, beggars can't be too choosy.

Leroy Vinnegar's Leroy Walks! is one of my all-time favorite OJC CDs -- see my review.  On the strength of that disc, I decided to take a chance on this trio album, "Jazz's Great Walker," originally issued on the Vee Jay label, but rescued from the vaults by Collectables/Rhino.  Pianist Mike Melvoin, who also played with Vinnegar on Leroy Walks Again!! (again, see my review), didn't impress me then, but steals the show here as he is MUCH better.  Don't worry though, Leroy's walkin' bass still features prominently.  The sound on this 1964 recording is terrific, but the material is mostly standards and none too adventurous.  In all, walk but don't run to get "Jazz's Great Walker."

Not being a huge fan of opera, I bought this CD for a version of the amazing, but rarely recorded (compared to other Wagner orchestral music) Das Rheingold Prelude.  I first heard this music in the movie "The New World" and was captivated by its mesmerizing, interweaving strings, brass and winds.  It was unlike anything I had ever heard from the composer, and light years ahead of its time with its 20th Century sound.  I'm sure seeing Karl Bohm perform the Ring Cycle at Bayreuth was an equally thrilling experience, but I cannot get passed all the coughing and distracting noises littered throughout this two-fer of highlights.  I bought the Solti highlights disc instead, and that studio account is just so much better at allowing me to completely immerse myself in that very special Prelude, and the other brilliant selections as well.

I don't collect a lot of chamber music, but I will buy pretty much anything that the folks at Australian Decca see fit to reissue in their Eloquence line, especially when I can find one used for just pennies in the Marketplace.  I have other versions of the Brahms and Mozart Clarinet Quintets (the Philips Duo two-fers are terrific), and these mid 50s recordings by members of the Vienna Octet are equally impressive accounts, despite the mono sound.  The brief Baermann Adagio, formerly attributed to Wagner, was a new piece for me, but it fits nicely between the more recognized works.  This disc is one in a series of ten Wiener Oktett releases in the Legacy series, and I might have to keep an eye out for some of the others, now that I've heard and enjoyed this one so much.

What is punk rock? Its a rock music genre that started in the mid-seventies in the United States, United Kingdom, and Australia. Its roots were garage rock. Punk rock is short or fast-paced songs, with hard-edged melodies and singing styles, minimal instrumentation, and offbeat lyrics.L. A. Punk Rocker is a beautifully written depiction of punk rock. Through their short stories, Ms. Brenda Perlin and her friends capture a vibrant time, from the perspective of teens. Ms. Perlin also brings her own particular viewpoint. She was a girl who didnt follow the crowd. Rather, she set her own tone and style, despite the bullies who tried to make her life miserable.The pictures bring their own value to the work. The snapshots and photos show action, sometimes frantic and sometimes poignant, of a time that seems long ago and faraway.Check out L. A. Punk Rocker. Even if you missed it, youll live through itvicariously, through the thoughts, feelings, and eyes of those who did.

Twelve-year-old Kristina has a difficult time at school. The other kids tease and bully her. The only bright spots are Raymond, her pet rat, and her favorite teacher. When Ms. Hensley gives Kristina a Christmas present the last day before the holiday break, Kristinas adventures begin.The lovely story is great for kids. If your child hasnt already delved into the world of fantasy, The Warble by Victoria Simcox is a great introduction.

In Origins of the Never, friends Olum and Tenybris seemed like two mischievous, fun-loving boys. Appearances were deceiving. Olum manipulated magic, while Tenybris grew more skilled at using magic to get what he wants.Now, in Souls of the Never, the boundaries between dreams and reality merge and blur. In a world filled with fantasy, scifi, romance, and time travel, with dragons, elves and faeries, the characters grapple with issues like bullying, friendship, and deciding whats wrong and right.C. J. Rutherford's Souls of the Never is a wonderful book. In the story geared toward young adults and teens but suitable for all ages, Mr. Rutherford deftly moves the reader back and forth through time. The chapter graphics are lovely.Origins of the Never: A prequel to Souls of the Never serves as short introduction to Souls of the Never. The tale weaves complexities of emotions, surrounding them with magic.

Hot Air is a fresh take on terrorism. Denise Kahn brings a new setting to an all-too-common plota hot air balloon.The gritty details add to the story. The characters are rich and believable, and make the reader care about them.The story moves along at a brisk pace, keeping the reader engrossed in the ride.

Jeffrey Miller paints a vibrant picture, with brushstrokes of exquisite detail. He captures the political climate of the day. Mr. Miller also shows a deft hand and true eye for social issues, such as drug use and trafficking, and poverty.The fast-paced thriller will draw you into the story, holding your attention through the action and the surprises.

Logan is as rich as he is handsome. He swoops into the diner.Waitress Jenny is shocked when Logan chooses her to whisk away in his expensive car. She wonders if shes making a fatal mistake, but she cant resist Logans animal magnetism.Logan has a mysterious past. His enemies are stalking him, waiting for their chance to move in for the kill. Can he prevail against the odds, as well as save the beautiful Jenny?Jess Hayek weaves a wonderful spell with her paranormal adventure. Ms. Hayek is the mistress of the erotic story, and hold us in her grip until shes ready to let us go.

With Alex the Mutt, the whole is greater than the sum of the parts. It is a great story a dog, but its much more than that.It also chronicles a journey. The author starts as a non-dog owner, and ends up a dog owner. Through that journey, the reader is given a unique insight into the authors life. Her childhood, her relationships with her dad, and even her awkward teen years are part of that journey. Along the way, we also meet people who should never be allowed to own dogs. Grrr! And we live through the poignancy of dogs who never have the chance for a life with a loving family.Brenda Perlin's Alex the Mutt is a lovely, heartwarming story. The beautiful illustrations bring the story alive, adding depth and breadth. If youre in the mood for some great fiction, Ms. Perlin is also the author of Fractured Vows (Brooklyn and Bo Chronicles: Book Three). Its is a wonderfully written story.

Thomas Jerome Baker's How To Self-Publish Your Book For Free on CreateSpace & Amazon Kindle: Make Your Dream Come True! is the definitive resources for self-published authors.The book is written in a friendly, chatty style. The author could be seated in your living room with you, sharing his wisdom. Hes the army of one, helping you publish your hard work.In my opinion, the section on publishing your book on Createspace is the best part of the work. Mr. Bakers wonderful step-by-step instructions and helpful hints turn a painful and tedious process into an easy procedure for you.And now, its time for a break. If youre in the mood for wonderfully written fiction, Mr. Baker's masterpiece Story Tellers: In Pursuit of Happiness is an excellent choice. It offers both entertaining stories and an intellectual exercise in the nature of man, the real and surreal, light and dark, good and evil, winning and losing, and the past, present, and future.

In the first book Chaysing Dreams, Tessnia Sanoby seemed to have it all. She was beautiful, athletic, and intelligent. After suffering a shattering epiphany and profound loss, Tess read a mysterious letter which changed her perspective on her entire life. She learned what Chayse really meant. And her life took an unexpected turn.In the second book Chaysing Memories, Tess had a hole in her brain and in her heart. Three weeks of memories were lost. Tess managed to move on, and became a scarily proficient special forces agent.Now, in the third and final book Chaysing Destiny, Tess continues to make her mark in special forces. In a dangerous undercover assignment, she's sent to Iraq.The wonderfully talented Ms. Williby presents the ultimate paranormal thriller. The reading for me was bittersweet. Making my last visit to Ms. Williby's wonderful world, with its memorable characters and exciting situations, was a great experience. Yet, I hated to see the end of the series.

In Bee's Knees, a mother and son meet for a few desperate breaths. In the waiting room, the husband/father adds whiskey to his bilge-water coffee.In George, a little boy hides in a small closet, surrounded by tiny military figures and battle cards. Is it sanctuary or a prison?Constance, The Lady Jewel, discusses her crimes against her stepdaughter Cinderella in this excerpt from Heel Toe:At this Dr. Brothers did look up. Pausing from his doodle, he inquired, You see no problem with asking your daughter to cut off her toe?You are an insipid little man. Why would she need a toe if she is married to the prince?In Octopus, a Korean woman's reflections upon her unhappy childhood cross and mirror her own children's miserable childhoods.George returns in Super Friends, enjoying his interactions with his own brand of friends.In Spilt Milk, the milk could be Strawberry Quick, light on the milk, heavy on the strawberry. Spilt, running everywhere, it makes a huge mess. Caleb is not going to clean it up this time.Naiad was shot by stranger. In Fish Tale, she explores her wish to be a mermaid. One day, the little minnow is transported to her seaside castle by a new driver.In Decaf or Regular?, apprentice Jared learns the coffee experience.Caleb waits for his eighteenth birthday in Birthday Boy. "Calebs left leg resumed its metronome beat."In Tooth Fairy, George finds a new focus for his passion for collecting.In Invisible Joy, a shallow and conceited woman becomes visible.Pria is the consummate Plucker.D. K. Cassidy's Spilt Milk: A Collection of Stories explores life from different, chilling perspectives. The finely drawn illustrations add depth to the stories. Ms. Cassidy brings the dark elements together seamlessly, keeping the reader's attention while she weaves the story, pushing the pedal on her Singer sewing machine.Ms. Cassidy is also the author of Curious Reality.  It's a well-written book, with characters from Spilt Milk making reappearances and new stories.

The extinction protocol was triggered to save mankind.Lauren is a soldier. She's a pregnant solider, on the run with Anise, an orphaned child. After a strange encounter in the frozen wilderness, Lauren realizes they are not alone.Is the hidden watcher a friend or an enemy?C. J. Anderson brought us Enter Ruinland, Survive Ruinland, Fate of Chiron, and Assault Ruinland. Beyond Ruinland is the latest offering in the series.

For the first in many years, Miller's Island is the epicenter of Mari's trials and tribulations. Miller, Mari's fourteen-year-old daughter named for the island, was the outcome of a long-ago tryst. Mari wonders if her daughter's father will resurface. Teresa, angry and materialistic, shows up unexpectedly with her family in tow. Aunt Frankie arrives for her visit, along with her cat Simba.Secrets are everywhere. As the vacation continues, odd events "haunt" the group.Leona Bryant's Miller's Island is an excellent exploration of family feelings and values. Mari and Teresa work through a lifetime of misunderstandings and skewed perceptions. It's a great story of empathy, forgiveness, and letting go.

Owen! The college football player is a sucker for a pretty damsel in distress. When the marketing assistant talks about her deceased brother and sheds tears, Owen is determined to get past her defenses.Ember's life hasn't been easy. She is shocked when the handsome and popular Owen explodes into her life like a football player in the fourth quarter, lobbing a Hail Mary pass.Zander is supposedly Ember's friend. But he has enough hidden agendas to fill a football stadium. He's got his eye on the game, and he'll cheat to win, implementing his own de-flate-gate.Jillian Jacobs' Ember's Center (The O-Line Series Book 1) is an excellent story for readers of all ages. Ember burrowed her way into my heart, and lodged there. She is a heroine who needs all the cheers we can give her.

Three women struggle within the confines of less-than-happy marriages. Heather is bored with her attorney husband Lance and her job, and sick of her critical mother-in-law. Victoria is married to Ed, a construction worker. He's handy around the house, but not with her. Catherine's husband Peter is never home because he spends his evenings having fun in the city...without his wife.Christine Ardigo's Cheating to Survive (Fix It or Get Out Book 1) captures the daily trials and tribulations of working women who try to balance work and tyrannical boss, home, children, and marriages. The story follows their unhappiness and depression, and their approaches to spice up their lives.I love the series title, Fix It or Get Out. That's exactly how I feel.

Jarvis Mann is a Denver private detective. When he gets a call from a prospective client, he's thrilled. Hey, it's a client. And her voice sends a frisson of something else down hisspine.Emily will never get a gig as a centerfold, but she's attractive. She tells Jarvis she's being stalked, and asks for his help. Her stalker is a shadow in the background.R. Weir's Tracking A Shadow is a fresh, fun detective story. Jarvis is a wise-cracking PI. His chatty inner thoughts keep the reader engaged, smiling, and on their toes. The pop culture references add an extra dimension to the story. Mr. Weir does an excellent job with giving the reader the pieces of the puzzle. It's up to the reader to put them together.

Sharon Delarose's firsthand account of her experiences is an interesting work. Her words are compelling and thought-provoking:"I do not possess a single "waking memory" of an alien abduction. What I remember are incredibly vivid UFO dreams and the terror that those "dreams" left me with. While I refer to them as dreams, it may be more appropriate to call them screen memories of repeated UFO abductions, which is what I now believe them to be."Screen memories are false memories that overwrite actual events which, if remembered, would be highly traumatic. Some UFO researchers refer to screen memories as 'merciful amnesia.'"Screen memories make it possible to have a lifetime of alien abduction experiences and not be aware that you were ever abducted. All you are left with is a jumble of bizarre memories, vivid dreams, and seemingly irrational fears. You may remember seeing or dreaming about bright lights, UFOs, monsters, floating in the air, or being paralyzed. My dreams took me far beyond that into another world which was sometimes beautiful and other times terrifying."Ms. Delarose is a brave person. Her book Alien Nightmares: Screen Memories of UFO Alien Abductions is living proof of her courage.

John James Audubon's life story is interesting. He went to great lengths to follow his dream, in spite of setbacks. Those lengths will seem extreme and foreign to those of us in this day and age.Sharon Delarose's Audubon: The Dream That Wouldn't Die is a fascinating account of the artist and naturalist.

The gritty thriller has some realistic depictions and adult themes. The pivotal event in the story is an explosion at the Royal Ordnance Factory.Reg, Dr. Simmons tried. There are secretaries a short way off. Keep calm.I am calm. Bowden sat down heavily. Im as  calm as a man listening to a time bomb ticking, with his b@lls chained to it!The book toggles back and forth between two main time periods: 1951 and 1979-1980.Neil Grimmett's The Hoard reflects the author's keen sense of building suspense. Mr. Grimmett deftly handles the changes between the time periods, while keeping the action true to its own point in time.

Alora is an Anmortal. As hundreds of years pass, she stays sixteen.Her life changes when she crosses paths with a human in her forest.With an enemy willing to use trickery and deceit to defeat her, Alora has to make difficult choices.Megan Linski's Alora is a great YA fantasy for readers of all ages.

The characters and the action in this book will pull you in from the first page. When you've turned the last page, you're disappointed to find "the end".Blood Money, by Anthony Hulse, is a well-crafted mystery/thriller. The ending is not what you expect.

In the first book of the series, Turtan was introduced. He is an Inspector of the Cross, doing his part to fight a war that's lasted five thousand years. He travels through space, his life suspended in stasis, while his A. I. Dr. Glitch handles operations on board the starship Argo.In Kingdom of the Jax, Turtan's adventures continued. He faced a no-win situation, forced to confront an emperor with a terrible secret.In Defender of the Flame, Turtan's focus changes. He's going to use his thousands of years of experience to train recruits at the First Cross Academy.John Rosenman's Defender of the Flame is as beautiful and compelling as the previous two volumes in the series. Mr. Rosenman is a master storyteller, his talent and his imagination bringing the words on the page to life.

The hardcover book is filled with awe-inspiring black-and-white photographs, framed in tastefully contrasting red borders.The photographs are always thought provoking and sometimes poignant.In the introduction, Ryan Pyle writes of his role as a humble photographer. I think his photographs serve as a visual depiction of many of the social, economic, political, and ethnic challenges facing of the land.

Arryn is a Fire Child. Formed from the elements, his race was created by elves to be their "servants and playthings". They found independence, and created their own city.As a younger grandchild of the king, Arryn is content with his brother Deraen's destiny as king.When a powerful enemy gathers her forces to conquer the kingdom, Arryn's family and his life are completely change.Mary Fonvielle's Children of Fire sets the stage for the later works. Ms. Fonvielle introduces a well-imagined world, and fills it with interesting characters.

The story begins in 2008. Charlotte is under a restraining order. She's forbidden from interactions with Des, a celebrity. Unfortunately, she violates the terms of the order.With the help of Taylor, her best friend and roommate, Charlotte puts a mad plan into place to avoid jail and losing her job.The story is full of fun, laughter, and zany characters running to and fro. Celia Kennedy did an excellent job. Charlotte's Restrained is a great book to while away a cold evening, snuggled in by the fire.

Troubled eighteen-year-old Ash and his mother Lily move in with Jude."Sometimes Ash believed Jude felt his difference, a complicated expression would cross his face, or his words would be clipped instead of their usual lightness. There were occasions where he would catch Jude watching him. It always made Ash wonder whether his dad had given him similar contemplating looks. Other times, like now, Jude treated him as casually as his mum, Mr. Danton, and Chicken George."Some people didnt react at all. They didnt seem to sense anything emanating from him. Mr. Danton and Chicken George were examples. His mum knew something wasnt right, it hadnt been for a long time, but she couldnt trade a psychological problem for a psychic one."There were no such things as ghosts."Gemma Farrow's Copperheart (The Disenchantment Trilogy Book 1) is full of spine-tingling secrets. Ms. Farrow gives the reader clues, using her unique brand of excellent foreshadowing. Ms. Farrow is also the author of the short work "Beneath the Willows," a horror story.

Seventeen-year-old Moira wants to disappear. She's experienced more grief and loss during her life than most people. Her sisters and her parents died in horrific accidents. She doesn't know why she alone was saved.When mysterious young man attacks Moira when she's home alone during a storm, she's afraid her luck has finally run out. She's teetering at the abyss of death when unexpected rescuers swoop in and carry her to safety."Dying."The word sinks like a stone in my chest and I choke on a ragged exhale. Belamars hands gently trail across my face, brushing my heavy hair aside. Unveiled, I feel exposed, naked, as if there is nothing between me, and the hole in my heart. Aching sorrow punches me in the chest, and everything tilts."Death and I are never apart, even here across the universe."Cheryl Mackey's The Unknown Sun (The Destiny Series Book 1) is classified as Young Adult. However, the excellent writing, well-defined characters, and wonderful story is appealing to all ages.

Square, Episode 1, introduces Tony. He served four years in prison for a murder. He learned a lesson in prison and he wants to make a difference.Square (the complete seasons 1 - 4), by Perrin Briar, is a psychology thriller as well as a mystery. It's full of twists and turns. It's difficult to give the story justice without spoiling it for the reader. Take a chance on Square.
The KONA French Press is easy to use. It works well, and it gets the job done. It's also a pretty addition to the kitchen counter.

Teresa has to relearn everything after an accident leaves her blind and with both visible and invisible scars. Two men vie for her affections. Which one will win?There's also a bonus. The book includes the Team Red novella, "In Love with Teresa March". It was previously released with the 2013 version of the Shades of Pink anthology.T. Hammond presents Blind Seduction: Team Red, Book 1. I love the main characters, who are gutsy and determined. I adore Red, who is extra special and even more so as a service dog.Thank you to Ms. Hammond for offering TWO versions of her stories. In her own words:'At reader request, there are two concurrent Team Red series versions: Blind for adult readers preferring a spicier, adult-themed story, and Red series more suitable for New Adult readers.'

If you get into a car accident or are involved in any other incident, it may be hard to recall the details of how exactly everything happened. This makes it easy, the camera catches everything. Never be the victim of a hit and run again, now you can always catch the license plate number of the person as they drive away. This dash cam comes with the mount and the charger. You will NOT need to purchase your own SD card because it comes with a 16GB card. The mount was easy to put on and it says it is heat resistant so when the windshield heats up on those hot summer days, the mount will not fall. The instructions were included in the box and dash cam is easy to set up and use. The instructions are clearly written so that a child would be able to figure out how to use it. The extra night vision feature is great for nighttime driving and the headlights of your car will also add to the visibility of the picture. If the camera gets full, it will automatically delete the oldest file so you dont have to worry about emptying the SD card everyday. You can set the loop feature to rewrite the data every so many minutes or not at all. However when you have a video that you want to save, it is easy to take the SD card out and retrieve the file on the computer. The screen on this dash cam is larger than most cameras. It is easy to see. The picture quality is very good and clear but you can change the resolution depending on how much space you want the files to take up on the SD card. Another feature I like about this camera is that it has a built in sensor that will detect that you have been in an accident and it will automatically record and save the file. This file will not be deleted if the memory card should become full. I really like this product and I do think it is necessary for anyone who lives in the city or anywhere that traffic accidents are very common. I love the piece of mind that comes with having a dash cam, no worries about hit and runs and people will be less likely to rob you at a red light if they see that you have a camera on your dash. Its very easy to use and install somewhere. These are super cute lights and I am going to purchase another set. I just wish they did not tangle so easily. This is the cutest Air Humidifier night light that I have seen. I needed something small but efficient for our camper when we go for the weekends. Since the camper is not used all the time it tends to get a musty smell to it. I set this night light humidifier up in there and in no time the musty smell seemed to have diapered. Its small and sits out of the way, yet it helps us see in the dark if we turn it on at night. The best thing is that it will shut it self off after three hours.  It works perfectly, in fact I have never seen one this small work so well. Full Disclosure: I received a free sample of this item in exchange for testing, inspecting and reviewing purposes. This stroller isn't for everyone - there are a few downsides that I'll get in to in a bit. But for someone looking for a well-built travel stroller that is very light and very comfortable, this is the one to get.The most important feature of this stroller is the weight, and it really does make a difference. We initially purchased a different Maclaren stroller that was listed at about 11lbs, and the difference was dramatic - what seemed like a small difference in weight turned out to be a huge difference on a daily basis - not only was it notably heavier it was also bulkier. The Mark II in contrast is both light and compact. The folding mechanism also means it's compact when standing or thrown over a shoulder, so it's great for getting around in tight spaces like a subway, elevator or airport.When unfolded, the unit has a very small footprint, making bit easy to maneuver in stores. The wheels have independant suspension which makes a difference on rough pavement, though it would not be the greatest stroller for dirt or gravel trails. The frame is incredibly well built with a hexagonal tubing, which is very rigid. The handles are surprisingly tall. Which makes for a much better position for the person pushing the stroller - no bent back syndrome for parents. Both me and my wife found this to be true, and she is 5'6" and I'm 6'0", and I imagine it'd be true for taller people as well. The small footprint does mean that for people with long strides, it's necessary to take a little care not to step on the back wheels, but that's something you get used to pretty quick. The folding mechanism works very well for a one-handed fold and unfold (with a little practice) and the locking mechanism is easy with one click of the pedal (though for some reason you have to push both of the unit is folded). While it doesn't stand freely like some other mfrs, it does lean nicely out of the way against a wall.The material of the unit is a lighter fabric, perhaps best suited for summer though with the addition of a universal padded seat or one of those zip-up blankets it works well in winter too. The seat doesn't recline but the angle isn't so steep that a toddler can't fall asleep a it might not be the most comfortable for a long nap, but at least for my toddler that doesn't seem to matter much. The seat back is very high, as is the canopy. This means that it will fit a pretty tall toddler, giving you years of service, but at the same time it means that the canopy doesn't provide as much side coverage for smaller kids. There is a caopy extension built in, but again for smaller kids it's not going to do very much. My biggest problem with the design is actually something very small - the buckle is a really strange design that requires holding the two upper part of the buckle together while clipping it in to the lower receiver. It's frustratingly awkward, especially with a squirming kid.The downsides are pretty well described above, but to summarize; there is no recline, it is a lightweight (but durable) fabric best suited to summer, and the canopy is too tall. The seat is somewhat short and unpadded. The buckle is poorly designed. It's not going to fill every need, and we still keep a "Sunday stroller" around for longer walks and trips. But overall as a short-trip stroller this is a very good one - easy to throw over the shoulder and whip out when needed.

It's only been a couple of days, but already I'm loving this vacuum sealer, and can't imagine living without it. Orignally I bought this for the sous vide cooking I planned to do, for which it's great; the bags are large enough to fit at least a three or four pound roast in, and are thick and durable so they are reusable - which is good for the environment as well as the pocket book. The lot comes with a dozen gallon and a dozen quart, all of which are even a little larger than something like a ziplock of similar capacity. The bags are cook and freezer safe, and BPA free (at least the parts that touch food). The vacuum process is straight forward, and easy to get the hang of; after sealing the bag with the little plastic tool (it's not necessary, but it does help), just put the nozzle of the handle over the red ring, press firmly and pull the trigger - that's it. It's best when done on a firm surface and with nothing under the valve, since this gives a better seal. Any liquid that's in the bag will get sucked up a little in to the unit, but it's collected in a removable trap that is easy to clean.Aside from sous vide I found an immediate use for his device when on the same day it arrived, I also got a random smoked, spiral cut ham from a relative (this happens to everyone, right?). Knowing I wasn't going to eat a 10 pound ham in a day, I made quick work of it, and split it up between a few single-serving quart bags and a gallon bag for the bone and some bits that will eventually become soup. I was impressed at how quick it was to do all this, and how much the vacuum bags saved space in the fridge by compressing everything down. Now I look at just about everything in my fridge and freezer and wonder if it really should be in a vacuum bag. Probably it should.

I've had this unit for just a few days so I can't speak to thre long-term durability of it, but so far I've found it to be an exceptional "consumer grade" espresso machine.First, the build quality and appearance are quite nice - the all-stainless look fits well in the modern kitchen, and the very compact footprint makes it perfect for people with little counterspace, or those who just want a very sleek look. The thin dimension does mean that it's a little deeper than other units, especailly with the handle in the unit it projects about 17" from the wall. But still, very compact. That compact shape does have a small downside though - the top cup warmer area can really only fit espresso cups, not larger coffee cups. Not a big deal, but it is always nice to have a warm cup to pour in to.The functionality of this unit also shines. It's incredibly easy to use, with one-touch brewing of either one shot or two. this is great, especially if you are doing other things while brewing your morning cuppa - turn the unit on, pack the handle with some espresso, nd by the time you're done packing the machine is probably ready to brew (it's very quick!). All you have to do then is press the button and you're done. Espresso brews in about 30 seconds, and becasue it shuts itself off, you can use those 30 seconds to get the milk ready for your cappucino, which is also pretty easy to make. To heat the milk, just press the steam button and wait until it stops blinking, and then turn the steam wand on (a little purge of the pre-steam water is a good idea). .The steam wand is really nice - most home units I've owned haven't really had a steam wand that could move around a lot, or give enough clearance between the unit and the pitcher to get a good angle for frothing. Not so with this unit - the wand is fully articulated, moving side to side and back and forth. The steam is powerful enough to get pot of milk hot or frothed quickly, with no signs of petering out at the end. The other thing I really like about the frother is the fact that the covering can be easily removed and rinsed. Most wands I've used end up with a lot of gunk on them after time because they generally don't get well cleaned each and every time. Since it's so easy to clean, I don't see that happening with this wand.The unit has some programmable aspects as well; the brew temp can be adjusted between three different levels, and the unit can be programmed to work with harder or softer than normal water (which affects the time between descalings, which you get a notification about). One thing that is NOT programmable is the length of the shot. This actually surprised and disappointed me a bit - I find the shots are a little on the long side. whereas I like to pull a double a little short (less watery). That does not seem to be an option with this unit, and I wish it were. [EDIT: it's actually possible to interrupt the brew - just tap the brew button again and the unit stops. But it's not programmable, which would have been nice.] The shots are of normal size though, so it's not a huge deal - again, this is a consumer grade machine not a pro machine, so in exchange for convenience you give up some control. You still end up with a very nice espresso.Unlike other reviewers, I did not have a problem getting good espresso - it's full and rich, with nice (not exceptional) crema. It's about what I'd expect from any decent home machine with a 15 bar pump, maybe even a little better since this unit automatically pre-wets the grounds which has the effect of releasing more flavor. Espresso quality varies with a lot of factors, including grind, coffee type and roast, as well as freshness. If you're not getting very good espresso out of this machine, it's probably the coffee you're putting in, or if you're using the absolute freshest coffee ground correctly, it's possible the brew temp is high and you need to adjust it down.Another thing that I am a little disappointed with is the "basket handle" aka the "group" - the one included with the system is a little long and a little light, which ends up feeling a little cheap in the hand. Also, it's designed around a "pressurized" basket which means that while it is more forgiving of vagaries in the grind or the tamp, it doesn't brew as nicely as an unpressurized system and it's more likely to get clogged at some point. Again, it's a convenience/control trade-off. Luckily I happen to have an unpressurized group that works with the system, so I just use that. I believe there are other third-party groups available to buy if you're not satisfied with the one that's included.Overall I'd say this is a great home unit for a person who is just looking for a delicious espresso or latte in the morning. It heats up quickly, it brews quickly and quietly, and it offers a number of consumer-friendly features that make it super easy to produce very good coffee. Those who are obsessed with pulling the absolute perfect shot and having a lot of control over every aspect of the process should probably look elsewhere.

There is much to love about the Fire Stick - it's small, and brings Amazon streaming to any TV for a very low price. And Amazons selection for streaming are amazing - I love that I can watch a lot of things for free with Amazon Prime, and get Amazon's own shows too, and also that if its not available on Prime I can rent it easily from the same device and service - no jumping back and forth between different apps just to find something. The remote on this device is basic but straightforward and easy to use, though it would be nice if the buttons had better markings or colors, just to make it easier to use. My issues with the stick come down to two; first, the wifi receiver isn't as strong as it could be, and in my case that lead to some connectivity issues. Nothing that couldn't be fixed with some rearranging of the router, but if your wifi isn't strong where you have your TV this could be a problem. Second, the fact that this requires the use of a wall plug is a little frustrating - it would be nice to have it plugged in to one of my TVs USB ports to draw power, but apparently that's not possible. At least that's what the instructions say. Ymmv. Overall it's an excellent product for people looking to "smarten up" their TV at a low price. And for Existing Prime members who have only been able to access video on the computer until now. It's a no-brainer. People who have wifi issues should opt for the speedier and more capable Fire TV unit, which not only has better wifi reception, but also supports more gaming options.

This mount is actually incredibly useful. I got it because I often use my iPad (mini) while cooking and wanted something that could hold it upright on the counter and it works great for that - the suction is super tight, and the neck bends at just about any angle. I like that I could use it in the car as well, but I actually think it's so useful in the home, sitting next to my desk, or mounted under a cabinet, that I'm going to buy a second for use in the car. Heck, I might even buy a few of the button-style ones and put them all over the house!My only concern is the strength of the magnet, which holds the iPad mini in place well enough, but it's not so strong that it can't be tipped off with minor bump. I'm not so worried about my mini, but certainly people with the larger iPads or other devices might want something with a sturdier grip. If I were using his in the car, I expect it might slip off if I hit a good sized pothole. Again, this is for the iPad mini, not a phone. Phones are held very firmly and I'd have no issue using this in the car with a phone. This device does come with one large and one small metal plate to put on the back of a tablet or phone, so you get a twofer if you have both phone and tablet.

Surprisingly good earbuds at a reasonable price. I mean, we're not talking Shure level here, but they have a good sound, great volume and the construction quality is good. If you're planning on using these with a bluetooth dongle or a small "clip style" mp3 player they should work nicely with the short length.

Solid, handsome stairs. Stain ends up looking a little more black than in the picture, but I'm fine with that. I particularly like the locking mechanism that keeps the stairs in the open-and-locked position - our previous stairs didn't have that and I was concerned that at some point they might fold up on their own.

I used these stencils for a craft project and taped them in place very carefully. Despite that, it was hard to get a clean line on the letters because the material is very flimsy. It just means having to be a little more careful when painting, I suppose. Otherwise it's a good set that should last through multiple projects. Contains a full alphabet as well as numbers and some random, if not terribly useful, patterns like stars.

This is a perfectly decent hat for the price - a nice wool, comfortable fit (for a "medium" size head I ended up with the smaller size and it fits just fine). It's not too retro looking, and I appreciate that. My only complaint with it is that the picture does not include the fact that this comes with a small metal logo at the left temple that says "Pamoa" and has a small turtle on it. The logo does not seem to be easily removable, though I'll probably give it a go with some needle-nose pliers, at the risk of damaging the cap.

Great for craft projects. Easy to work with, if a bit on the fragile side. Sure, some of the letters are not in the quantity that some folks would like, but the box is cheap enough that you can always buy more. We used these to create 3 children's height rulers, with the letters spelling out the names. We had plenty of letters and tons left over. So for about $2 per ruler, not a bad deal. Certainly less expensive than buying each individual letter on its own.It's worth noting that the exact numbers of each letter are printed on the back of the box. It would be nice if Amazon had a picture of that included with that product description so that people could tell in advance if the needed letters were included.

I had been buying coffee ground at the store, since my theory is that a better grinder there makes up for a lack of freshness, provided the coffee is never more than a week old. But I finally decided to invest in a decent grinder and I'm glad I did; this grinder elevated the quality of my espresso instantly. Fresh grounds make a big difference in the quality, and his grinder puts out a very consistent grind. It's plenty fine for espresso too, which some of the other, less expensive models, seemed to have a problem with. I like the fact that the grind is pretty adjustable, and that there is a time to grind just as much as you need for your daily dose, if that's how you want to do things. It's not a quiet machine exactly but it's certainly less bothersome than a chopper.There are a few things I don't like, however. First, there are no numbers on the fineness dial - just hash marks that don't match up with the settings exactly. So if you change your grind from time to time (ie do drip coffee one day, espresso the next) you migh find it hard to get the same setting. Second, the container for the grounds is just plain messy. Taking it out of the machine inevitably gets some grounds on the counter, and removing the lid (which isn't hinged) does so even more. By the time I'm done with my second espresso of the morning, there are grounds everywhere. The only solution I can come up with for this is pouring that grounds in a separate container and storing a couple days worth at a time. That's fine, but defeats the purpose of a home grinder somewhat.Overall I'm pretty happy when the grinder and it's definitely a keeper, but I'm going to have to make some adjustments to my mourning routine to make sure I have time to clean up a bit, or get some supplemental storage/scooping equipment.

This is easy to attach and use, but ultimately I felt that it interfered with putting the knife in my pocket more than I was benefitting from a one-handed open. Also, it could be designed to look a little more sleek and not so much like a industrial screw. That's just personal preference though - it definitely works as advertised.

Overall very high quality piece, though I wish the tail and the prop were wood instead of plastic. I love the rubber wheels though. Seems very durable, which is probably why the prop and tail are plastic.
Needs to be really well mixed, or clumps will form and dye will not be uniform. I recommend the liquid version.

At first these speakers weren't delivering much volume, but I think it was my PC because once I muddled around with the volume settings I was really suprised that these speakers can really pump it out - sitting maybe two feet from my PC, the average video (Amazon Prime Instant Video, of course) is plenty loud between 30% and 35%, and more than that gets uncomfortable. The speakers are a bit muddled, perhaps a little basey. This may favor games and big action movies over more dialog-heavy movies. Anyway, I think with the right EQ settings that can be corrected.The fact that these are USB powered is both an advantage and a deficit; they're easy to plug in to a PC, especially if you've got an extra USB port. But if you've got a hub, you have to split the speaker plug from the USB plug, which makes for bit of a mess of wires. Not worse than with an extra power wart though, so overall I guess it's a plus. Especially if you're hooking these up to a TV with a USB, since it means it's easy to hide the cables.My biggest gripe is the blue lights - they kinda look cool, but they are distractingly bright, especially when the lights are off. There's no way to turn them off, and covering them up is not easy either. It'd be great if there were a way to turn them off. Otherwise these are great speakers, especially for the price.

Very high quality toy in almost every respect - all wood constrction, great paint job, charming design. But the magnets that hold the parts together are so weak, it makes it very hard for a toddler to play with as a plane - instead it easily falls into its component parts. It's more of a puzzle and model than a toy. Probably more appropriate for 2-3 yo, though at that age they may find the puzzle too simplistic.

So slim, light and elegant - looks like something between a stiletto and a straight razor. This is a fantastic pocket knife for everyday carry. The blade is a little on the long side at 3.75" but it's not unwieldy. The blade was not well sharpened when it arrived, but a little time with a whetstone fixed it just fine. Note that this is pretty much just for right-handers, since the opening mechanism really favors that side, and holding it in the right hand leaves the thumb nicely positioned on the hinge for grip, while holding in the left hand wouldn't be nearly as comfortable or secure.

My older Garmin GPS was stolen from a rental car, and I can honestly say that I'm at least a little happy that it was. Replacing it with this 2597 has really made a big difference in my driving. First, the old GPS I had promised traffic, but I was never really able to use it effectively. This unit integrates traffic very well in to the whole navigation experience, and it can really improve driving times. The way it works is that it indicates a traffic jam ahead and estimates the delay. If it determines that the delay is longer than taking an alternate route, it automatically offers up that alternative and shows how much time you might save by going a different way. On a recent trip, this meant avoiding a jam of about 20 minutes by diverting to a different road, and I'm pretty sure I saved at least half an hour. I really like being able to see traffic delays ahead (and the distance to them) because it also helps me plan for breaks, fueling up and better knowing the accurate time of arrival.Other than the traffic, this unit also has a significantly improved touchscreen from my previous unit, making it easier to use gestures to scroll or move the map, and less laggy, more accurate typing. The sat recepters and processors are better too - much quicker to fix on location, and reroute in case of a missed turn or detour. The screen is nice and wide, and though there's a lot of information displayed, once you get the hang of it, it's easy to read. The Bluetooth speakerphone is slightly better than previous units, making it easier to hear on the road.On the downside I would say that the menus are slightly more confusing - it's nice not to have to type in city and state every time you enter an address, but the auto-search doesn't always pick the right locations to be searching. The "lane assist" is nice to have most of the time, but between that, the traffic and other data displayed, it can be distracting sometimes, and that's not good for a GPS. Better than missing a turn because you were in the wrong lane though, I guess.Overall i"m very happy with this, and would recommend it highly - another great GPS by Garmin made even better by bluetooth, traffic, and most importantly, lifetime map upgrades. Worth the money... just don't leave it in a rental car.
Great swim/su suit, and super cute. Great customer service.

Very solid construction and a great gate for both kids and dogs. Sometimes it's a little hard to get just the right tightness for absolute security, but with a little force it all works out in the end. My only complaint is adjusting it can be frustrating sometimes, since the peg doesn't stay in the slot very well when it's not completely closed. One note to make setting it right easier; if you are usually putting it in the same place, use a marker to color in front of and behind where the peg goes - this will make finding the right tightness much easier.

I wish this would work with my pre-2013 LG smart tv - it's much more comfortable in the hand than the original wedge-shaped remote I have. I don't know why it won't work (error msg says "unsupported device"), since the buttons are essentially the same but for the voice control. Oh well, I guess I will just have to track down a replacement for the other remote since mine broke.

A little long initially, but easily trimmed - just had to remove the end cap with pliers and cut extra length off, seal with a lighter and then pop the cap back on (again, with pliers to clamp tight). The buckle can be a bit difficult to open, but better that than too loose.
Did not fit he iPad mini retina

I was looking for a case for my iPad mini retina that would be slim like the Apple cover, but also provide back protection, all for a reasonable price. The Khomo cover satisfies all my needs; the case is thin, it's comfortable with an almost rubberized feel, and the magnets hold the cover firmly in place when closed. Overall it's a great case for the money.

There are a few reviews that suggest these devices fail relatively quickly, but for the time being I have to say I'm pretty ratified with this purchase. I needed extra IR lighting because I moved a baby monitor far enough away that the video was basically impossible to see. This fixed the problem and how; so bright now, it casts IR shadows from 10 ft away. At first I was annoyed that I had to order tha pore supply speeratly, but after investigating power supplies I realize there is a reason for this - lots of folks get multiple units and hook them up to a four-in-one power supply so buying without power supply saves money. Plus if it ever fails it's cheaper to replace. I'll report back of there are problems in the future but for now, and for the money, this is just the right solution.

Like a fitbit for your garden, the Parrot Flower Power gives you basic information about the health of your plants. The data that's collected is sunlight, water, fertilizer and temperature, and it records the data continuously. To check in on the plant though, you have to sync the device via bluetooth with your phone, and when the data is synced it is also uploaded to the Parrot (?) servers for analysis, and then notifications are sent. This is overall a pretty good system if you like to check in on your garden on a daily basis, but there are some limitations. Since the device isn't connected to the Internet directly, it can't be checked remotely, and it can't be used with services like IFTTT to trigger other actions or alerts. Having something that is directly connected to the Internet would make for a lot more flexibility with the system, but would probably be more expensive and complicated.As for the data it collects, it's nice to generally know the state of your garden. And because it is set to monitor a particular kind of plant, it is monitoring the health of that plant and doing the analysis for you. I found this very useful to know when I was overwatering or underwating, or when I needed to add fertilizer. One limitation though is that it doesn't seem to corrolate data with things like weather patterns - if it's cloudy one day, it'll tell you to move the plant, instead of realizing that it's just a cloudy day. Also those kinds of alerts seem to be specific to that day, not the overall trend - my tomatoes, for instance, are exposed to all-day sun, but on one cloudy day I got a notice when it should have just realized that the plant is in a good position.Overall I'd say this is very useful, but could be more useful with a few improvements. I'll definitely be buying one or two more to monitor other plants in the garden.

I had to oil these when I first got them because the release mechanism was a bit tight, but after that they've worked like a charm. Very easy and quick to get a good snug fit. I use these for a tensioned sunshade application and they do a great job of getting the tension just right, and they're quick to set up and take down. My only gripe is that for my application I wish that the hooks weren't so far away from the ratchet, and I'm a little concerned that the webbing may fray (already showing some signs of wear). Otherwise, definitely a nice little piece of gear to have for strapping something in to the bed of a pickup, on to the roof of a car or any other time something needs to be tied down securely. A great value for a four-pack too.

There weren't many options when it came to finding a walk-through gate that could fit a large opening (in my case, between a wall and a kitchen island) so I pinned my hopes to this Regalo. So far, I can say I'm pretty happy with it, though there is some room for improvement.First, the design is very flexible, with the base unit covering 27" (just under a standard door width) and three additional extenders provided, each of a different length to reach up to (I think) 54". I didn't use all the extenders, but with the right two I was able to get a really perfect fit in my space. That will not be true for everyone - some might find that there ends up being a pretty large gap between the gate and the wall. If you're lucky enough to get the right sizing, it's a snug fit. If it's not a snug fit however, you may be left cranking the threaded bolts all the way to the max, which leads to some floppy instability at the top. This is really the biggest design problem, as these bolts are somewhat loose in the sockets, especially if extended the full length. They would be better if they were threaded sockets and the bolts were thicker.The biggest advantage of this system is the fact that it uses friction and pressure to hold it in place, rather than screwing in to a wall. In my case, that would have meant screwing in to the side of a cabinet which was unacceptable. I appreciate the design of this system, though it is inherently less strong than systems that screw in to place. There are "cups" that the ends of the bolts can fit in to reduce the risk that bumping or pushing on the top of the gate will make the pads slide, but these must be screwed in to the wall to work properly. I may try to fix these in place using something like a Command strip removable adhesive, but I can't say whether that will work well or not just yet.For around $50, it's a great deal and the construction is very good. I only wish it were available in wood, or perhaps in another color.

This works very well on our counter top - it's easy to put in place and is very secure when attached properly. The fact that it folds up makes it perfect for taking with you when you're going someplace that might not have a high chair, or even when you just want to throw it in the pantry at home. Overall safety and quality are top-notch, my only complaint is that it's hard to clean.

I was excited at the prospect of getting a waffle maker and sandwich press in one unit, and this unit does a decent job at both. The heavy plates used as the griddle surface are good, and the nonstick coating makes cleanup easy. The way the plates connect to the unit, however, isn't all that well designed, and they tend to rattle around a bit. Construction quality is lower than expected on this unit, and the price seems high as a result.

I've been on the hunt for a good pair of bluetooth earbuds for a long time, and I've tried a lot of the other options. This is by far the best set I've had in just about every way. But there are a few problems, most of them minor, to consider before purchasing.I'll start this review with the packaging. I rarely care about packaging but in the case of these headphones, the packaging was so irritating, I have to say something. The packaging looks like it was designed to be high-end, which one would expect for a product that cost above $150. The cardboard is thick and imprinted with rich graphics, and even has a book-like cover that is held in place with magnets and opens with a cloth tab. But inside the cardboard box is a plastic box which is difficult to open, and then inside that is a piece of foam that holds the headphones in place. Despite all of this packaging, the headphones are taped in place with many layers of cheap scotch tape, which has to be cut with scissors - carefully though, so as not to cut the headphone cords. Finally, the headphone holder is a somewhat cheap plastic box, again held shut with magnets. It's difficult to open, but does seem to hold the headphones securely in place. Overall the "unboxing" of these headphones was a bit of a pain and not the quality experience one might expect from the outside packaging. Not that I really need a "high-quality unboxing experience" but heck, I'm sure the packaging alone added $20 to the retail price, so it might as well add something.Now to the good part; the headphones. As far as design goes, these things are fine. They're a little big outside the ear, but generally they just look like a pair of oversized earbuds not much different than the $20 ones you get from Sony. I would have appreciated a better finish on the outside - something like the brushed aluminum of say a Vibe Moda would be nice. But looks aren't why I bought these headphones so it's not something I'm concerned much about. The cable is kinda flat - not thick and flat like say the Beats earbuds, but thin and flat in a way that does reduce tangling while still retaining some flexibility. The control unit, which powers the headphones on and off and allows adjustments to volume, and skipping tracks, is again decent but made out of plastic. Nothing great as far as design, but nothing too bad.The fact that they charge via micro-USB is really important for me, since it reduces the number of chargers and cables I have to carry around. Included with the headphones is a very short (9") flat charging cable which fits easily in the clamshell headphone holder and can be used with a laptop when on the road. It's too short for use with a desktop in most situations, I imagine, but you can always get a longer cord or a separate charger.The fit of the earbuds is where I'm a little conflicted. Generally I like earbuds because they block out ambient noise and until a decent set of noise-cancelling bluetooth earbuds come along, this is probably the next best thing. They do block out a lot of outside noise, which is good for travelling via subway, plane, and other noisy modes. The buds themselves are quite thick though, and even though I'm a big guy, I guess I have tiny ear holes because even using the smallest rubber bud (three are included) they are a little hard to get in the ear properly. The external silicon "wings" do hold the buds in place though, so even if they slip out a little they don't fall completely off. Overall I'd say they work well in most situations, including for working out/running, which is the main reason I bought them. I'd like to see improvements to the design including a better wing attachment system so they stay in place better, and a smaller bud offered, but for now I'm pretty happy with the fit.Pairing the headphones couldn't be easier, and is much better than previous headphones I've used. I appreciate the actual voice notification saying the headphones are connected too, which eliminates the problems of having to constantly check the phone to see if the connection has been made. The battery life seems very good - I haven't once run out of juice during a normal day of use which includes an hour and a half commute, a gym workout and some time in between when I just want to escape the noise at work. What helps a lot is the fact that there is a battery monitor for the headphones on my iPhone - no software to install, it just shows up there and I can monitor my use that way.As for the actual sound, I'd say it's exceptional. Clear and crisp, nice and loud (though not skill cracking). I haven't had any dropped "packets" as I have with other BT headphones, and there isn't any crackle coming from the headphones. I did notice a few pops when doing things like using Siri, but never during a phone call or during audio playback, so I think this is something that is probably more on the phone side than the headphones. The only real problem I have with the sound is related to the fit; because the earbuds are so tight in the ear, they act as a sort of a "drum" and any impact on the cord transmits a sound to the ear. This means when moving (walking, running) there tends to be a constant thumping that results from the cord bouncing up and down. This happens with all in-the-ear buds, but it seems more pronounced with these than others that I've used.I do have a couple other minor problems - there's no indicator LED for when the phones are on, so you have to hold them up to your ear and press the power button to know if they are. The rubberized cord, while durable yet flexible, does have a tendency to grip a bit on the back of the neck, which sometimes means it gets hung up when turning my head. I suppose using the included cord-shortener might help, as would wearing the buds in an over-the-ear fashion, but that's not my preference. I'd prefer to see the cord coated in a fabric wrap of some sort which would be more stylish and more comfortable. But other than these minor problems I'm overall pretty happy with these earbuds. Yes, they're expensive (more than I've paid for any headphones ever, actually) but for me the convenience of going cordless is worth it.* NOTE: this review is based on using these earbuds with the iPhone 5, which has the newer Bluetooth 4 chip. I imagine that some of the features described, such as the battery life, the battery indicator, and the clear connection are the result of this BT4 connection, so these headphones might not be as good when paired with older devices on the BT2-3 standards.

Lots of candles that burn a long time. I use these decoratively for dinner parties, but the main reason I have them on hand is in case of blackout or emergency. A month's worth of light is a nice thing to have as a backup.
Install worked like a charm, and it's quite a handsome shelf. It's a little small - especially the depth, but it holds a few small items well enough.

Nice looking, stainless construction. The digital readout is a bit enigmatic, and the toastiness knob doesn't seem to be consistent, leading to easy burning. Most importantly, the toasting of the bread is uneven, spotty in parts. Ultimately it's a decent toaster, but it looks better than it cooks.

This was a very easy unit to install and works pretty well to hold up four mops/brooms/etc as well as offering a number of hooks for things like dustpans. My only complaint is that the sliding mechanism is a little tricky.

Finally got around to upgrading an old heater and I'm pretty happy that I bought this one - it's got a nice small footprint for a small room, but because of the tower design it can really put out the heat. The design is slick looking and high quality. The remote does feek a little cheap, but it's nice to have at least. The one problem I have with it is that the temp sensor doesn't seem very accurate. That's pretty common though, so it's a minor complaint.

This is a very nice, compact device that does quite a lot of things; radio, flashlight, and charger for external electronics, all of which can be powered by solar or hand crank. While this isn't what you'd use to power up your phone on a daily basis, it'll do in a pinch. The size of the unit is smaller than I expected and quite easy to handle, and the light is quite bright. My only complaint about it is that the USB charger is a mini USB port instead of a full size USB, which means that in order to charge anything you have to keep a collection of adapters around. And while there are a number of adapters included, it seems it would have been easier to just have a full-size USB instead.

I recently decided to move to a multi-monitor setup and upgrade to this over an older Dell 2409 (I thinnk that's the model number). Sitting side-by-side with that older monitor, it's a world of difference. This Acer is so sharp and so bright, it makes me think I need glasses just to look over at the old one. While the bezel isn't quite as thin as one might have hoped (about .5" all around, except at the bottom where the "chin" is a little thicker) the overall design is sleek and handsome. And while the screen is glossy, it isn't noticible because the brightness of this monitor is so exceptional. Using this at home in a room with a skylight, I don't notice any reflections whatsoever. Colors are great, and the viewing angle is fantastic. While I'm not a monitor connoisseur by any means, it's certainly an improvement over my old one.This monitor comes incredibly well packaged and it's easy to set up. The monitor stand is two pieces - a flat part that's made of a really nice looking brushed black metal (or maybe it's metallic looking plastic) and a glossy plastic column. The column screws in to the base without tools, and snaps in to the monitor quite easily. It has a decent range of motion - maybe +10 degrees up and -5 down. The unit comes packaged with a full array of cables - DVI, VGA and HDMI, which was unexpected.Overall, a very good monitor for the price.

As much of a fan as I am of the genre, I hesitate to even call this "science fiction" because it really is a very different kind of movie than one usually thinks of using that term. It's more like The Time Traveler's Wife than Star Wars, though even that comparison fails because Another Earth is far less "sci-fi" than even Time Traveler's Wife. In the end, Another Earth is simply a thoughtful, insightful, compelling story of loss and redemption that is based on a premise of the existence of another planet, though for much of the movie the reality of that is somewhat irrelevant. Well worth watching.

Not the most protective case, but if you're looking for something to protect the back and sides of your phone from getting scratched, this will do the trick. My only complaint is that the edges are a little sharp and it isn't completely squared off, so you can't balance the phone the way you could without the case on.

Dark painful literary masterpiece.  I frankly found the experience of reading this like being in a nightmare.  But it was exquisitely done, a grim, elaborate, grudgingly moral and profoundly pessimistic piece of fiction designed to make the reader suffer.  It is in its own way powerfully romantic, in that it renders the world in such extreme joyless and dismal terms, and ends with such bold strokes of cruelty. There is nothing of pedestrian realism in it.  In this regard it made me think of "Last Exit to Brooklyn" by Hubert Selby.  Both novels seem merciless and despairing indictments of a world that has convinced itself it is morally bankrupt. .  I'm glad I read it, but would not want ever to be in it again.  As I'm 74, I do remember the world of the 1960's and I can understand why this novel is considered "emblematic" of the times.  There was a deep exhaustion still hanging over the West then, due to the two great wars, due to the Cold War, and it seems our collective culture needed time to regain unapologetic  faith in itself  and in its capacity for joy.  But this novel makes a metaphysical statement about life that is bigger than its story or its time, or its particular circumstances.  I admire Le Carre very much. I recommend this as I do Selby's novel, and Remarque's novel, "All Quiet on the Western Front" about an earlier time.  Such dark gems.

This is the sixth Gabriel Allon novel that I've read.  I read two recents ones and was so impressed that I went back to the beginning and I'm now reading Allon's adventures in order.  Well, I didn't think Silva could top "The Confessor," but "A Death in Vienna" does indeed top it.  This novel takes on an immense theme --- the horrors of the Holocaust, and the immense debt owed to ALL its victim by ALL of us --- if we are ever to recover from the inhumanity and cruelty of the Second World War, and move on  to a world in which such ghastly horrors can never again happen.  And the author treats this immense theme with dignity, feeling, restraint, and wisdom.  The book is beautifully written.  Yes, it's "a spy novel" and there are inevitable touches of the romance and artificiality inevitable in good page turning spy stories....and this is indeed a page turner!....but this book is infinitely more.  It way transcends the limitations of a genre.  I recommend it heartily to anyone who enjoys fine writing, a thrilling plot, and who craves a deep vitally important  theme as well as terrific storytelling.  I love Silva's characters, particularly Ari Shamron, and Gabriel Allon, the enigmatic and every human hero.  I love his vocabulary, his phrasing,  his use of adverbs,  his subtle way of revealing the thoughts and feelings of his people.  I love the way he describes the cities and towns and rooms through which his people move.  But I think I love more than anything else the unfolding tale of these Israeli spies and the great historical and religious  legacy that informs their particular struggle.  Just a great book.  Loved it.

Enthralling throughout.  This is perhaps the finest of the Silva novels I've read so far, and I am going right into another.  Loved the richness of his vocabulary, the stylistic flourishes, the finely drawn characters, and the remarkable chase and action scenes.  Suspenseful to the last page.  Superbly crafted throughout.  This is one fine writer on every level.  ---  His plots are complex and filled with marvelous surprises, and his style is always enjoyable in itself.  I love being with his heroes.  I love being in his world.  I love the great international scope of his novels, and the strong moral overview at the core.

Another superbly entertaining novel from Silva, and a pleasure to recommend on all levels.  Fine writing, lean, often beautiful ---  and appealing characters  always exquisitely drawn and as interesting as they are sympathetic.  There is the deep romance here of many  spy novels or films ---in that  the heroes are presented as noble but deadly,  expert executioners with a profound moral vision.  I like their deep sensitivity to personal loss, and they strong blood and tribal ties.  As in "The English Girl," the locales are glamorous, exciting,  expertly rendered whether we're talking Lisbon and other European capitals,  or the bleak coast of Ireland.  And the Author's Note is compelling and persuasive.  Silva must surely be known as "the thinking person's thriller writer."  I don't know of any novelist whose done better in this genre.  And the book transcends genre enough for me to care about it deeply and want to read more of this author's work.  A pleasure to recommend.

I bought this on a whim, and discovered what may be for me, THE ultimate thriller writer.  Loved it.  Loved the substance, the intelligence, the international political scope ---- combined with a truly fluid and beautiful writing style.  Loved the hero, Gabriel Allon.  Loved the vividly described locales.  And of course the storytelling, the pace, the suspense ---- all marvelous.  Going right into "The English Spy."  What we enjoy is always a personal decision, and very likely we're all always seeking just the right mix of elements ---  to entertain, absorb, carry us away yet give us more than simple distraction.  For me, I don't think it can get any better than this.

Maybe the best Jack Reacher novel I've ever read.  And I may have read them all. Not sure.  But this was just terrific.  Loved the descriptive touches, the precise details, the pace, the sense of place, and the surprises.  Never guessed the ending.  Never saw it coming.  Just superb.  Jack Reacher at his finest.

Superbly done historic series about the great British lawyer, William Garrow, at the Old Bailey, and his role in the developing of criminal trial law.  Just loved it.  As so often with these British series, the actors and actresses were perfect, and I fell in love with Alun Armstrong as John Southouse before the third season finished. Also fell in love with Michael Culkin as Judge Buller. Rupert Graves made for a pathetically human yet somehow charming  villain. Lyndsey Marshal gave a very credible performance as an intelligent woman wrestling with matters of honesty, honor and the love of her child.  Aiden McArdle was just marvelous as the prosecuting attorney so often pitted against Garrow.  And Andrew Buchan was very sympathetic and convincing as the lead.  The writing was superb.  I only discovered this series a week or two ago, and I am so sad that it was not continued.  If only it could be revived...  I thought it captured the spirit and ambience of the 18th century (and potentially the early 19th century) beautifully.
