But the book also contains a wealth of information about the use of light earlier ---  how well to do people only used candles up to 1800, for example, and how oil lamps developed afterwards,etc.  The descriptions of early shopping streets starting  in the 1700's and how they used light, mirrors and eventually (by 1850)plate glass to display their wares were enthralling.  ---- The in depth discussions of the psychology of light also fascinated me --- how people respond to flickering flames, how an oil lamp became the focal point of a family gathering much as the primitive hearth had once been the focal point; how people clung to candles and oil lamps in drawing rooms even when they had gaslight in other parts of the house, etc.  ---- But I cannot do justice to the richness of this book by listing these things here.  This is a brilliant study of people and light on many different levels, and beautifully written and engaging from start to finish.  Highly recommended.  (Historical novelists will love this book; it will tell them all kinds of things about the world of the last two centuries; it's full of priceless details.)

This book arrived today and I spent several hours with it, reading, underlining, making notes.  It's well written, well reasoned and very well documented. I'll be studying it for quite some time.  ------  I will be purchasing copies of this book for some Catholic friends.  ------  This is exactly the kind of deep exploration of Catholic beliefs that I welcome with all my heart.  I welcome the effort here of a scholar to go back to the biblical passages upon which a seemingly crucial belief is supposedly based, and examine those passages carefully, moving on then to the Didache, and to the work of the Church Fathers who supposedly influenced the evolution of the belief.  (I myself in my own unscholarly and amateur way feel drawn to do this.  And long ago, I searched my New Testament diligently to try to find a justification for an anointed all male Catholic priesthood and I could find none. )  ---  This book goes much deeper than I could ever go into the concept  of the Eucharist and the concept of Transubstantiation, and into Atonement theory,  and into many other related vitally important theological matters as well.  The scope is immense.  The implications of Wills' questions are immense.  I found the discussion and the documentation to be a great gift.  ---  I wish I were able to describe in greater theological detail why I find this so valuable.  For me this is fresh air.  This is bright light.  The 2,000 year old complex and multi-layered Catholic Belief System needs this.  This is an honest and timely and illuminating pursuit of truth.

I stumbled on this book several days back after watching Ann Todd in the marvelous black and white classic film, "The Seventh Veil."  This powerful romantic film had had a strong influence on me when I was young.  I was inspired by the world it revealed (of European art and refinement)  in which the heroine, a concert pianist, is dominated and cherished by her mysterious and sometimes cruel Cousin Nicholas (played by James Mason) who trains her to be a great musician while at the same time denying her evidence of his love.  ----  I expected this book to be of passing interest, but found myself reading it page by page right through to the end.  It is a simply marvelous story, unfolding with restraint and elegance the story of a remarkable life in the arts.  Ann Todd acted not only in films, but with the Old Vic in England, and in many many plays.  She met and made friends with many fascinating people --- second husband David Lean, and actress Ingrid Bergman to name but two- and she went on to become a maker of documentary films, traveling the world in search of beautiful and exotic subject matter and inspiration.  I was sad when the book came to a close, but deeply touched by the writing, by the author's humble reflections on the meaning of life, on her many spiritual experiences as well as her travels.  Just a beautiful book really.  I'm thankful there are many used copies out there, and I hope somehow this book is taken up again, reprinted as an attractive paperback and made available to a new audience.  There is much here to interest many.  Now I must go in search of Miss Todd's documentary films.

This is a very readable and excellent study of the Gospel of John in relationship to the Gospel of Mark and also in relationship to Matthew and Luke.  Just about an believer and any biblical scholar might benefit from reading this book. It's not surprising that some find the book deeply disturbing.  I suspect the book is going to upset "born again" Christians in particular, especially the sort who post so often in the Amazon Christianity Forum arguing for the "born again" approach while they insist they are not religious and not Protestant, and that their "born again" approach to Jesus is the only valid one.  But a book like this might shed considerable light on the development of their particular brand of belief, and a brand it is. ---- I welcome more studies of the gospels like this one, studies which delve into the distinct possibility that gospels writers might have been  responding to one another when they wrote their individual gospels.( I've always thought that the authors of Luke and John were in active dialogue and argument with one another; but I am not a biblical scholar and cannot write a book long treatment on the subject. )  The writing here is careful and clear and the research is excellent.  A good work of biblical scholarship, and a highly accessible one.  And like any good book of biblical scholarship, the book draws you deeply into the biblical texts and you come away with new insights, whether you agree with the author or not.  Highly recommended.

To say that this book is important is an understatement.  Sadly, too many today don't know that there are in fact thousands and thousands of gay Christians, and many churches in which gays are welcomed, and where gay clergy are welcomed, and where same sex marriage can be celebrated.  In spite of tremendous hostility and prejudice on the part of some Christians, gay Christians are not about to give up on their faith in their God or their faith in their churches.  Gene Robinson made history when he became the first gay bishop appointed by the Episcopal Church in America, and in this gentle, and beautifully written book he makes the case for the Christian acceptance of Same Sex Marriage, in the name of love.  Very well worth reading.  This is an excellent book to give as a gift to gay Christians who may be struggling in hostile communities,  and to Christian parents of gay children who are not finding support in their churches.  ---- It is my opinion that gays are winning the battle for acceptance in America on all levels,  and soon the persecution they are suffering now will be a thing of the past.  Highly recommended.

Books like this have to be beautifully written. If they weren't, I doubt anyone would read them.  What the book offers is an interpretative overview of history that is well documented and makes for compelling reading.  There is a wealth of material here and great bibliography.  A book like this prompts us to put in coherent form what we know about thousands and thousands of years of history.  And I think our minds long for this coherence, long to make sense of the tons of data we have accumulated in modern times about our past,  and the wilderness of specialized studies published every day that are too numerous for any one reader to ever fully examine. ---  I found this highly readable and entertaining, an excellent book for the scholar and a delight for the mainstream reader who loves history and has wondered about many mysterious cultural developments and whether they are at all related.  Quite an achievement. Quite a find.  Highly recommended.

I recommend this book highly.It's true that no one can prove whether or not Paul was a Pharisee, and onecannot prove which parts of the gospels were written early and which added later,and which parts are honest reportage and which passages might have been added laterto make a point.  But a lot of skeptical and speculative biblical scholarship involves these sameproblems, yet brilliant contributions are made by such scholars.And really none of the author's speculation or conclusions in speculative matters undercut his basic theories: that Paul is the inventor of Christianity, and that he did it by fusing three different kinds of belief: gnosticism, Jewish belief, and pagan mystery religion belief.Frankly, I think Maccoby's explanation of Paul --- his explanation for the absurdities and contradictionsin Paul, and for the sum of Paul's assertions --- is best I've ever read.I admit for me the Christian belief system does not work.  I pursued it for 12 earnest years (I also grew upCatholic)during which time I devoted myself to faith based biblical scholarship, devouring the works of many great scholars.But in the end it all fell apart for me; and no small part of it was that I could not make sense of the O.T. and N.T. together.  The assertions by Paul in the N.T. simply were not supported by the O.T. --- and the supercessionist theology,  and supercessionist cliches I confronted from Christians,, apparently built up on the basis of Paul, were not supported at all by the O.T.I left the belief system confused, disappointed and disillusioned. And for quite some time I've ponderedquestions like "How could Paul just throw out God's law from Sinai?"  or "How can anyone say that the O.T.and the N.T. together are inerrant when Paul throws out the law of God Himself?"  Well, this book by Maccobyaddresses this issues in the best and most complete way I've seen to date.  --- It confirms me in my conclusions thatthe Christian Belief System is founded on falsehoods, contradictions, and absurdities.  But it goes much further than Icould on my own in explaining how this might have come about.I recommend this book highly --- very highly.  I hope that it is not out of print now, and that if it is, that it willvery soon be reprinted.  The scholarship here is excellent; the writing is clear; and the book is profoundly illuminating.I do not agree with every single assertion or conclusion of Maccoby, but the book overall is a mighty achievement.  It is tremendous in scope as it addresses the birth of a religion and the problems inherent in that religion. It's concluding chapter alone is worth the price of a copy.

This is a solid, substantive, and beautifully written book on the topic, which seeks to separate out what we can reliably infer about ancient times from archaeological evidence, as opposed to what we might learn from fanciful and speculative material written about ancient times.  We are also asked to take a hard look at early literary source material about ancient religions, with a view to understanding the complex context in which many such sources developed, and the inevitable pressure of social bias on the writers or historians.  ---  Frankly, after years, of reading Sir James Fraser with great relish and drawing tremendous inspiration from The Golden Bough, I welcome this solid study that discusses what has and has not been "proved" about ancient religion and customs by solid archaeological findings.  I welcome the careful critical evaluation of  early Christian writings about pagan beliefs and customs.  ---- This book doesn't diminish the value of The Golden Bough or speculative and intuitive writings about mythology and what mythology can teach us about ourselves.  It underscores a different emphasis.  I really want to know what can be known about ancient religion.  And so for me this is a breath of fresh air.  Will I throw out Robert Graves' The White Goddess or Frazer's The Golden Bough? Certainly not.  I will continue to value them for the genius connections that can be made by the intuitive mind, and I will continue to weigh their conclusions and insights against meticulous scholarship like that of Ronald Hutton.  -----  Lastly, I want to the praise the writing skills of this author.  His text is organized, well reasoned and beautifully laid out, which makes this a scholarly approach that can be accessed and enjoyed by readers of all levels.  And make no mistake, the book is enjoyable.  Highly recommended.

Yes, we all know him and love him for Sherlock Holmes.  But Doyle published a great deal of other fiction, including brilliant historical novels, and tales of the supernatural which have inspired film and fiction since his day.  This collection aptly titled Tales of Unease provides an excellent introduction to Doyle's speculative short stories and will reward any lover of Victorian fictional prose with treasures a plenty.  "The Ring of Thoth" is a marvelous tale and so is "Lot No. 249" and both inspired me personally in the writing of my own novel, The Mummy or Ramses the Damned.  I find in all Doyle's  work the same rich vocabulary and vivid descriptions I savor in so many 19th Century English writers, but what distinguishes Doyle's work is his great love of action, of pounding narrative full of high incident as well as unforgettable characters and images --- which is why, undoubtedly, Doyle's work has inspired so many films.  Again, this little volume functions as an introduction.  There is a great deal more, much more, of Doyle to be re-discovered, studied, enjoyed.  And speaking of introductions, the essay here on Doyle by David Stuart Davies is excellent.

The prose of Amelia Edwards is often on a level with Charles Dickens, so much so in fact, that for years many of her supernatural stories, published anonymously in Victorian periodicals were thought to be his work.  She writes with such sensitivity, such vision, and such an immediacy that she ranks as one of the finest writers of the period.  Loving ghost stories as I do, I put her in company with the great Sheridan La Fanu, M.R. James and Algernon Blackwood.  Her descriptions are breathtaking, the moods she creates are engulfing, and her voice convinces you that she is the man so often telling the story in her tales.  Highly recommended.  I wish all this woman's writings was available in hardcover. She deserve a renaissance.  Don't overlook her enormous contribution to the study of Ancient Egypt.  It is one of her main claims to enduring fame.

I've just begun my experience with this author.  Finding a quote from him in an old book on my shelf, I ordered this book with great enthusiasm.  But nothing prepared me for the beauty, the purity and the profound truth of every word I have read so far.  This man understands the pain, indeed the agony of those of us who have left traditional belief systems we once passionately loved.  He understands the search for meaning in this world that obsesses so many of us; he understands the loneliness from which we reach out to the Maker of the Universe in spite of our fears that there is no one to hear our prayers.  I've ordered several other books by this brilliant and profoundly gifted author.  Highly recommended.

The more I read about the abuse of teenagers in the "troubled teen industry," the more worried I become.  This book strikes me as solidly researched and solidly written; and I look forward to new books on this topic.  Clearly many abusive corrective schools, both religious and secular, still exist in this country, and in others.  And teens sent to some of these places continue to be at risk for cruelty and deep psychological damage.  It is frightening to think that young people can be subjected to isolation, starvation, unproven and destructive psychological techniques, and even physical beatings and torture in these institutions.  It is frightening to see that well meaning parents may be deceived into sending their kids to these hellish institutions by deceptive advertising, staff and supportive authority figures; and that often money is involved, the parents paying huge sums for a corrective "education" that may not be an education at all.  My heart goes out to the teenage victims.  What can we do, other than  spread the word,and encourage more and more scrutiny by the media and the public? I don't know.  But if you know nothing about this subject, buy this book. Read and weep.

I found this show to be much better than most cop shows offered on television, and I am a fan of cop shows, without doubt.  Poppy Montgomery was terrific as the "star," a detective who can remember almost everything that has ever happened to her. For me, she showed greater range in her acting than she had on Without A Trace where she'd never been given the opportunities that she had here.  She was certainly strong enough to carry the show. The scenes in which she travels back mentally to review a scene, tapping into her infallible memory for detail, were always enthralling.  However the  supporting cast was exceptionally good as well; and the writing was fresh and unusual.  I couldn't predict where the stories were going and I found the resolutions satisfying.  I became more and more interested in the supporting cast, as well as the star.  I was very disappointed when CBS cancelled this show.  I don't think networks gives new series enough of a chance to find their audience.  Maybe some one on cable will pick up this show.  Hope so.  I recommend what we have of it here -- one interesting and entertaining season.

The new golden age of television continues with this absolutely spectacular HBO series, based on the brilliant writing of George R.R. Martin.  You cannot help but be drawn into the bleak, yet richly colorful world of these fantasy/medieval style characters when the writing is this good and the actors so unforgettable.  The sets are often exquisitely beautiful, and the costumes dazzling.  At times the whole looks like pre-Raphaelite painting. ----  Having not read the books, I was now and then  confused as to who is who.  But I came to realize that the series would eventually give me all the information I needed to remain fully engaged and fully delighted.  --- There isn't a false note in the cast, nor a false line in the dialogue.  And one has the feeling, no matter how fantastic the kingdoms and their warring monarchs, that one is delving into our history and our evolution as a moral species.  Speculative fiction at its best --- which this most certainly is ---  is always about us and always about us now as well as "long ago."  Games of Thrones is setting a whole new standard for daring, complexity, and sumptuous execution of the vision.  Highly recommended.

We are in a new golden age of television today, a time rich in historical, science fiction, speculative and fantasy drama.  And this series, Pillars of the Earth, is a perfect example of the fine fare being offered to us now regularly. Right up there in production values with The Tudors,  this is a fast paced and suspenseful and thoroughly entertaining drama. It is leagues beyond the older slow moving and often poorly conceived historical dramas of yesterday's television.  Beautifully written by John Pielmeier, and lavishly filmed with excellent cinematography and art direction, this series carries one back to the great age of cathedral building --- inviting us to surrender to  a brutal yet fascinating world where good fights against evil in spite of endless defeat.  Matthew MacFadyen is superb in this, as is Rufus Sewell, Donald Sutherland and Ian MaShane and just about every other member of the large cast.  This is dark, yet always fun, and the glimpse we get into the making of cathedrals is tantalizing and enthralling.  Highly  recommended.  If you've given up on historical series in the past because of the poor quality, by all means give this a try.  As I said above, we are in a new golden age of television now.  I have bought the Ken Follett novel on which this is based.  Enjoy as we await the sequel.

When confronted with this beautiful and brilliantly conceived  series, one has to confess that neither historical accuracy or the limitations of television much matter.  The brilliant Neil Jordan who created, wrote and directed these episodes has made this his own rich and meaningful and unforgettable material.  You don't go to Shakespeare's Hamlet or his Macbeth or his King Lear  to learn history;  you go to them to be with Shakespeare in his world and see how he uses history to construct his universe.  Well, that is what is happening here.  Jordan has made The Borgias his own mad universe in which he can talk about good and evil, humanity and cruelty as he wants to do it, and his dialogue and staging and vision is what matters.  I find the series (I have now seen all of season two which will soon be released on DVD if it isn't already) horrifying and mesmerizing. I cannot look away from it though it drags me to places I don't want to go.  And I sense without even thinking about it that this is like no other programming on television at this time.  It is so extreme, so fully realized, so uncompromising, and so intelligent  that it is in a class by itself.  Of course the actors and actresses are superb.  The cinematography and art direction surpass anything I've seen on the small screen; and the entire look of the series is Renaissance in its colors and proportions.  It is entertaining?  I honestly don't know. When something is this riveting and contains this much cruelty I don't know if it's entertaining.  I know that I recommend it to everyone.(Disclaimer: Neil Jordan directed the film, Interview with the Vampire, made from my first novel.)

If any film comes close to topping The Innocents with Deborah Kerr, as the ultimate haunted house film, it is this mastery film with its fascinating and original "take" on the haunted house genre.  Nicole Kidman gives a genius performance as the woman at the center of the mystery here, and her two children, a boy and a girl, are perfectly cast.  The other cast members are remarkable;  and every single person in this film looks extraordinary, and their behavior is carefully choreographed to be tantalizing and ultimately frightening.  The old house itself is magnificent, both inside and out.  But the true genius of the film is the original twists and revelations it brings to the genre. The ending is profoundly satisfying, making sense of the many chilling scenes throughout.  And make no mistake, there are chilling scenes here of such subtle horror that they take your breath away.  If you have not seen this, I would say most definitely see it.  it is my opinion that this film did not get the accolades it should have gotten when it was released.  But surely its fame is growing among those of us out here who treasure this kind of beautiful work in the genre.  This has to be on its way to classic status.

I studied Henry James' "Turn of the Screw" in college, and I saw this superb and unforgettable film when it was made, and have watched it many times since.  It is brilliantly faithful to James' novella.  It has never been topped at the ultimate haunted house film in which the horror is beautifully sustained with masterly cinematography  and flawless responses on the part of the governess who sees the ghosts and is terrified for the fate of the two children in her charge.  It just doesn't get much better than this.  The old dark house is engulfing and beautiful; its spaces are perfect backdrops for its four lonely and vulnerable occupants; the grounds are as haunted and forlorn as the structure itself.  And two of the scariest ghost scenes take place outdoors in broad daylight.  What drives the film of course is the governness, and her extraordinary bravery (if that is what it is) as she confront the horrors she is seeing and their threat to the boy and girl in her charge.  Is she mad? Or are there two powerful spirits seeking to commune with each other through the hapless children?  ---- James himself would never reveal whether this was a story about psychological breakdown or an actual haunting.  One dead give away, that it is about madness, for me, is that there is no good reason for the ghosts --- if they are ghosts --- to be revealing themselves to the governess.  But then again, perhaps they cannot help it or have an agenda involving her that I have not understood.  ----- But for me, this film and the novella itself work best as classic ghost material.  ----  There is not only terror here --- which is so common today in such movies --- but true horror.  And I recommend this to anyone who wants to be royally entertained by all the classic elements we expect from English ghost stories.  Deborah Kerr gave a magnificent performance in this; the supporting cast is perfect; and the children exceptional.  This will be around as long as movies are around.  It is indeed a masterpiece.

It's difficult to believe this film was made in 1996 as it seems absolutely contemporary and, I suppose, timeless.  --- The cast is exceptional, the script flawless and the pacing something of a miracle.  Essentially it is about death and illness being an integral and inescapable part of life, and what love can achieve for us when we approach tragedy and loss with love.  Meryl Streep is a marvel at the unloving sister who has chosen selfishness rather than love; and Leonardo de Caprio gives his usual top quality performance as a child who has learned to trust no one.  Diane Keaton, for my money, does the heavy lifting as the one who knows how to love, but is fully human at the same time, vulnerable to fear, vulnerable to panic, vulnerable to emotional and physical exhaustion.  ---- The humor in the film works wonderfully, and I wonder if the film wouldn't have been unbearable without the humor, because it so accurately depicts the horrific burdens life can put upon us, and the crippling effects that illness can have on anyone of us at any time.  Ultimately the film uplifts, reassures and essentially shows the wisdom of love and that altruism isn't just a virtue that some enjoy when they can afford to enjoy it, but rather a very valuable coping mechanism for everyone.  Life is better, this film says, for those who know how to love, and for that reason it is a practical virtue as well as a beautiful one.  The film looks beautiful, the camera never being cynical about the small house in which the drama takes place, but revealing instead the coziness of the dwelling and the vibrant personalities in it.  Highly recommended.

This book is well researched and well written, and frankly I wish there were more like it on this topic.  There is a lot of talk today from the Religious Right about "protecting the unborn" but there is not enough talk about protecting the children we already have from abuse.  --- This book alerts one to the various ways in which children can be abused and are being abused under the umbrella of religion, and I think it's important for Americans to be informed on this matter.  Our children are our future.  And our children are our moral responsibility.

I find this a very compelling book.  From the beginning Colette Livermore's tone is humble, charitable and honest.  She gives us an invaluable story here, and she writes beautifully.  I hope we get more books like this from members of Sister Teresa's order.  And well written stories of the personal spiritual quest, whether from nuns or lay persons, Protestants or Catholics, atheists or agnostics, often teach us a great deal.  This book is about some extremely large and crucial questions.  Those questions have to do with Christianity, what it is, what it attempts, and what it achieves in the world today.  I like the simplicity of the writing here, the clarity, and the sincerity.  ---  I was very moved by Ms. Livermore's conclusions.  I recommend the book.  It's quite an achievement.

When I was new to Amazon several years ago, I reviewed this book (below) anonymously.  Well, I no longer have the means to edit that review, but I can copy the contents here:  This is a startling book, and well worth a detailed read. If Trobisch is right in his conclusions about an early edition of the New and Old Testament, we have much to investigate in this new light. I was persuaded by his carefully reasoned and extremely well documented arguments. And I find the material intensely exciting. What more can Trobisch point out to us, using only the text of scripture itself as he has done here? I can't wait to see response from the academic community to this excellent and compelling work. Anne Rice, New Orleans, La.Let me add now, years later, that this book had an incredible impact on me.  I tend to think that Trobisch's idea: that theNew Testament as we have it was an "edition", carefully edited and compiled and distributed with the thought of unitingthe early Christians makes an enormous amount of sense.  His scholarship is simply excellent. He's using internal evidence andexternal evidence. He's consulted the manuscript evidence; he's knowledgeable about the nomina sacra and other stylistic elements,and his thoughts on N.T. identifies its own authors are very thought provoking. I'm mightily impressed with this book.  I'm surprised that it did not get a great deal more attention in biblical studies.Maybe it will yet be re-discovered.  Or maybe it's better known than I think.  Anyway, I think it's a power book with powerful insights.It might be unsettling to some to have to see the N.T. in this light; but this author has laid out the reasons for his conclusions herein persuasive and responsible terms.

This author was recommended to me by some one in one of the Amazon Christianity Discussion threads in which I participate. And I am so thankful for that recommendation.  I'm in the midst of reading this book  and looking over and reading the author's other two books.  I'm amazed at how eloquent, accessible and insightful this author is.  And he puts forth his priceless observations in a gentle manner, which really shouldn't offend religious sensibilities at all.  Just about anyone might benefit enormously from reading this book.  It seems to me that it is vitally important for people to study and come to understand something of the evolution of religion, something of the evolution of religious and theological ideas.  No matter what you believe or don't believe, it can help to know something of how religious history developed.  --- Right now, religion is a divisive issue in American politics.  We need to be informed about it, at the very least.  And of course for many of us religion involves a lifelong personal quest.  This book has so much to offer to readers of all backgrounds.

These roaster bags make almost anything taste good...well, with the right seasoning. Seriously though, even cheaper cuts of meat will be succulent and tender when cooked in a roaster bag. Also, the overall cooking time is less when cooked in the bag. The way I work my magic, there's less clean-up. These are win-win at every angle.The up-to-8# size is great for larger chickens or small turkeys (turkey breast). While I've not cooked meals-ready-to-eat all in one bag, I'm pretty sure that I can pull that off to with these smaller roasters (recipes with smaller cuts of meat, potatoes, carrots, etc.). Reynolds is a leader in these kitchen line of products. Buy with confidence.

I was a little hesitant with ordering this Sport-Fit Armband for my Galaxy S6. I have my S6 in a battery case and wasn't to keen on the idea of having to remove my phone from its case every time I might use the Sport-Fit. First, I might state that I actually use two battery cases; one is the Mophie Juice Pack and the other is the Skiva Energy Skin. The Mophie DOES NOT FIT, but the Skiva, while snug, fits without any problem. This is a real winner for me and sells me on the onthe Sport-Fit.The plastic window over the touchscreen works fine and I'm able to navigate my phone without any frustration whatsoever.  I have read some reviewers complaints over excessive sweat being a problem, but I've not experienced this to be true for me... although I've not used the armband while jogging or other activities that would cause heavy sweat. I used my armband almost exclusively for indoors workouts weight training and elliptical cardio and had no issues.

This SwissGear TSA Backpack is a really great little bag... maybe I shouldn't say "little." While it might not be a full size pack, it's not small by any stretch and is capable of fitting most gear you could imagine taking on a flight. I'm easily able to pack my 13" Chromebook, my Kindle, a couple books, water bottle, snacks, my RX meds, and quite a few sundry items (hygiene stuffs) and I still have room for more. Best of all, the back is really, really well made. Heavy duty reinforced seams all around with strong zippers and serious rivet action for the plastic handle. Additionally, there are quite a few hooks and loops to hang stuff off of, if that is your thing. It also has plenty of inside compartments for keys, pens, and other items you might want to keep separate for easy access (wallet, passport, keys...). I love SwissGear quality and I love this backpack!

Viva Labs supplement products are a trusted brand, at least in my household. Glucosamine, Chondroitin and MSM are a fairly standard combination in today's market, so there's not a lot "new" that can be said about this. My experience taking GCM for over 7 yrs now is that GSM works for me. I know I experience definitive difference in my mobility with joint aches and pains when it is not featured in my supplement regimen. I am 50+ male and do suffer from a family history (maternal and paternal) of arthritis. What I might speak to in particular about he Viva Labs line of supplements is constancy, economy, and they are easy to administer (swallow) being a coated caplet. This is definitely a good choice for any of your supplement needs.

I've been testing this battery case from Skiva for a few weeks now. I've run it through the ringer and I am convince that it is a winner. I bought the Mophie juicepak for my Galaxy S6 before (preordered) before it was even released, so I have a good comparison. While the Mophie has a little bit larger capacity, I think the Skiva is a better product. The rubberized feel of the Skiva EnergySkin is good for grip, where my gold Mophie is far to smooth and slippery. The slimmer profile of the Skiva is easy in the pocket and more manageable in the hand than the Mophie as well. Also, the Mophie requires a special adapter for the earpiece where the Skiva does not. Hands down, in my opinion, the Skiva is a better product. Oh, and as a killer bonus??? The Skiva EnergySkin is about 1/4 the price of the Mophie Juicepak. Now, you tell me, who's the winner?

I appreciate the environmentally conscious efforts of Hollender with these products. From a practical standpoint they are functionally perfect and do what they are intended to do. Sensitivity remains high as far as condom sensitivity goes, but where these condoms excel is the confidence inspired through the use of chemical free lubricants and/or spermicides. As some reviewers have noted, the condoms fit a bit snugly, but I have no issues with the fit and actually prefer a snug fit for both, comfort and sensitivity. This is the first time I've tried this brand and will likely make my prefered choice going forward.

Sturdy, clean edges, and easy assembly/disassembly. What more could you ask for in a frame or bedding platform?There is not a lot I can add to what has already been reviewed for this frame. Everything arrived complete, although the packaging was pretty gnarled from travel and handling. This caused me to be skeptical for the condition of the bed frame before opening, but alas, all was okay. I suppose it is understandable considering travel and contents are only a heavy (70lbs) metal frame.Assembly was a snap and very intuitive. No deep meditation or engineering degree required to put this baby together. I like that! Also, while didn't disassemble the unit, it holds promise that it will deconstruct as easily as it constructed if and when I move. (I am an apt dweller).I like the heavy gauge metal the frame is made of and expect it will last my lifetime without any bending or warping. Great frame. I only wish the price was a little more consumer friendly.

The commentaries published by the Kregel Exegetical Library continue to impress me. The Commentary on Exodus by Duane A. Garrett is another strong volume in the Old Testament Series.One of the many things that I particularly like about this series is there are no compromises where scholastic excellence is involved. The volumes in this commentary series are the pinnacle of academic excellence in my opinion. This can be an intimidating attribute for some, but I would say there is no reason for intimidation. In addition to academic excellence, the commentary is among the most readable that I have experienced. I am not a language or textual criticism expert and I still find the writing conversational and understandable. The marriage of readability and scholasticism is what moves me to rank this series so highly.Duane Garrett has done an exceptional job with research and exposition of the Exodus narrative. Beginning with an incredibly comprehensive introduction addressing geography, archeology, Egyptian dynasties, socio-political circumstance, textual criticism and so much more, Garrett lays a solid foundation from which he works the major themes in his Commentary on Exodus.No matter what commentary or commentaries you may have in your  library for this key book from the Old Testament Scriptures, Kregels Commentary on Exodus by Duane Garrett is a worthy addition and compliment to your collection.

I have appreciated the communication skills of Andy Stanley for years. Personally, I think he is one of the great communicators and teachers of our day. I have often marveled at his ability to repackage timeless teaching and contemporize it for the present audience. Enemies of the Heart is another sterling example of this gift that Stanley has.While Enemies of the heart touts Four Emotions That Control You, the primary teachings that it draws from seems to come from Evagrius and Pope Gregorys teaching on the Eight/Seven deadly sins. Stanley addresses four major challenges to the Christian life (five if you count lust from the final chapters in part four), guilt, anger, greed, and jealousy. The original Deadly Sins codified by Evagrius and Gregory the Great follows: Lust, Gluttony or waste and over indulgence, Avarice or Greed, Sloth or Apathy, Wrath or Anger, Envy or Jealousy, and Pride or vanity and narcissism. The teachings of the ancient fathers of the church stated that guilt was the result of culpability to these major sins. I think you can see the parallel of Stanleys premise from Enemies of the Heart and this ancient treatise on the sins of man.In part three, Stanley addresses the sins by offering counter disciplines and attitudes to change the behavior of the persons plagued by guilt, anger, greed, jealousy, and lust.  This is not unlike the disciplines introduced by the church fathers to similarly deal with the issues of these core sins. They offered the following pursuits to eradicate the deadly sins: chastity to overcome lust, moderation to control gluttony, charity to counter greed, diligence to abate sloth, patience to smother anger, kindness to temper envy, and humility to sate pride.I am thankful for people like Andy Stanley who can repackage classic teaching and help to expand the audience of such. This is a great introduction to the issues of sin and classic spiritual formation. Those who would like to delve deeper might consider the writings of the Philokalia.

These are solid headphones, most definitely not in the realm of the better ranking for sound and comfort, but they are good.The first thing to remember, at least I told myself to remain objective, is that these are gaming headphones. This means they should not be judged by the most discriminating audiophile for top sound quality against the most sensitive and dynamic of headphones. I had to remind myself of this on several occasions...these are gaming headphones and they are designed for different purposes.Next, with consideration to form and function, these are a bit cumbersome. They feel clunky, heavy, and bit awkward on my head and around my ears. Having had a taste for better fitting and more comfortable headsets, these have been difficult for me to get used to. They do have some nice features, the inline volume adjustment is nice and I love the detachable mic.Finally, my thoughts on the sound quality, are a mixed bag. I've not tested the full dynamic range of these headphones and I'm not sure I've gotten an accurate depiction of 5.1 or 7.1 sound just yet, but what I've experienced is promising. With a flat EQ, I think the headphones are slightly heavy in the mids and bass response. There also seems to be a bit of chorus or delay effect built into the sound reproduction...not too much, but a little. I think this is helpful for music listening, but with voice reproduction, it sounds a little echoey...All in, these are a decent consideration as gaming headsets go. If music is your primary reason for searching headsets and you landed here, I would move along. If you think your headphones should pull double duty, then these are a cost effective option and worthy consideration.

I really like this Flash Drive. I like and trust Samsung products and 64GB is a nice chunk of storage...add in USB 3.0 for fast file transfer and you have a winner. These things can be said for many other Flash Drives, well, except for the Samsung part, so what really sets this drive apart for me are a couple of things.First, I really like the styling of the drive case. It's sleek and feels like steel or chrome or some other high quality metal. It is waterproof, shockproof, magnet proof, and x-ray proof... I like all of that. Also, the size is good for me. I've had Flash drives that are bigger and I've had them much, much smaller and this truly feels like the best size between the chapstick size drives and the micro drives. This drive is about the size of a stick of trident or dentyne gum. The little keyring fob is a bonus, but I likely will not be using this feature. All in all, this is a great package and is setup to be a trusted drive I'll use for a long time.

This product is about expectations and delivery, real-world solutions and cost-effective products, and practicality. Objectively speaking, I think this device meets the bottom line in all these categories. Keeping in mind all these parameters, the iluminage Precise Touch hair removal / reduction system does what it says it will do.It is important to follow the directions and it is important to realize there will be a treatment plan involving a number of sessions. The amount of sessions will be determined, of course, by skin type, hair color, and density of hair. I conducted a couple small tests, and even with very fair skin and light hair density, it took several treatments for the hair reduction to be noticed, but the results were satisfactory.As a previous commentor/reviewer stated, it is important to shave down the existing hair for the most pleasant results and best experience. Personally, there was no pain in my experiments, but my tests did not include the unit at full power. I also have not had the opportunity to experience long term metrics with my tests. As I have more time and experience, I will plan to update my review accordingly. For the time being, I believe a slow approach and reasonable expectations will bring the best user experience... it has for me.

I don't get these strictly for the "health bar" or "protein supplement" category they live in. I get them for my sweet tooth and to ease my conscience that I'm not eating a snickers or a reese cup. With that disclaimer, I love these! they're tasty and I can have a relatively clear conscience when I eat them...and they sort of tie me over between meals, which keeps me from making a fast food run or other unhealthy choices. I've tried other protein bars and come away with a "mealy" aftertaste in my mouth. These don't do leave me with a yucky aftertaste. Clear conscience and sweet tooth sated equals a 5-star win!

I've been taking Curcumin supplements for awhile now and these are a smaller dosage than what I am used to taking (former 1000 mg vs 500mg). Like my last supply, I have not found these irritating to my stomach or causing me any IBS issues. I do take them after a breakfast meal. While I  take them in conjunction with a Glucosamine Chondroitin supplement, it is difficult to determine if my minimal joint pain (I suffer from gouty arthritis) is related to one or the other products...or if it might be a combination of the two.I have only been taking this brand for a few days now and I feel no difference in the results from my last brand. I can say the 500mg capsules are easier to swallow, but the increase in dosage makes this product pale in comparison for value with the last supplement that was packaged in the same quantity, but in 1000mg dosage. For that reason, I give the ranking for 3-stars due to cost.

Beautiful screen and plenty of Ooomph with the Intel i3 chip and 4GB of RAM. All this for a "Cloud"book is more than enough and then some. The actual footprint and profile of the "book" is solid, lightweight, and thin...almost the size of an ultrabook. There is nothing to complain about or nowhere the hardware and/or system itself falls short. If this is your only use for a machine, it does it all and it has it all. What it may lack in storage or optical drive (should you need either), there are input jacks for USB 2, USB 3, and SD CF storage. It's a complete win.Now, if you're looking for all this and more??? The onboard 16GB SSD is a tiny bit lacking. I do wish it came with more built-in storage. I'm a push-it-to-limit kinda guy and I want to put an install of Linux Ubuntu for a dual boot system. I've not had to time to fully investigate the best way to approach this challenge, but I have a couple options I wish to explore. Option one is to replace the current SSD with a larger drive. Option two, involves a less permanent solution of utilizing the USB 3 and external SSD or the SD CF option for a boot partition. We shall see how this experiment works. Since this exceeds the actual function of my chromebook's design, my pushing the limit wishes are in no way reflected in my review.

Corel Painter is an outstanding software program. Truly, the capacity of this "painting" software is only limited to the skillset and creativity of the person using it. I have used various iterations and versions of Painter through the years and continue to be impressed with the advancements and capabilities the new developments bring.Do not be deceived or misled, this is very powerful software and the learning curve can be steep. Yes, basic applications and functionality can be realized with a few clicks and drags, but tutorials and use exercises will be the path to full enjoyment of Painter. Likewise, while a mouse can be used, the best use will be a stylus and pad like the Wacom line of tools. In this new 2016 version there are a number of new features and brushes. At this juncture of my introduction to them, I cannot honestly describe a real world application for them, but I'm sure this is where creativity of application reigns. I will look forward to seeing some of the work produced with these new brush sets and have my own creativity inspired.The usage of this software and the art work that can be produced is limitless with Corel's Painter. If you don't believe my words, check out some of the online galleries and see for yourself. I hope I can realize even a tenth of the potential of this software and I'll be creating gallery quality work. Why then only four stars??? I rank it four because I really think using a mouse to interface with the software is a significant limitation. A stylus and pressure pad is the way to go and those are an additional cost to the user.

This is truly an all-in-one body (hair) groomer. I've owned a few sets of clippers, trimmers, and "groomers," but this setup by Panasonic is in an entirely different league. I think one thing that really appeals to me is the approach to the comb attachment. Each comb attachment is designed for a specific application and the depth of the cut is facilitated with a micro-adjustment wheel (up to 39 settings) on the groomer itself. No more fumbling through my bag of "blade guards" to find the right guard for the depth of cut I desire!Another great feature is the detachable blade (for a good deep clean). It simply snaps off and snaps right back on. No more screws to remove for blade cleaning or replacement! Oh, and it is also able to be cleaned under running water.The groomer comes with three specific grooming attachments (body hair, beard, and head). A charger, cloth carry case, and smaller container of lubricating oil make up the kit. This is, my new favorite.

Pretty sweet little setup with the starter kit...and you'll have "fun, fun, fun till grandpa takes the Groundshock away." I grew up with slot cars and the problems inherent with that design (cars slipping out of the slots, flying off the tracks in turns, bad electric connections in the tracks...). NO MORE! This is one cool setup! And setup is a breeze with capability of building multiple (8) tracks with the initial startup kit.Controllers are your smartphone. I did not check iPhone compatibility, but Android smartphones were no problem. A quick download of the Anki OVERDRIVE app from the Play store and you can be up and running.One thing I have noticed in the short time of play and research for the gaming system is the great support from Anki. These folks seem to be on a continuous mission to upgrade and enhance the play experience. Each email and comment appears to be individually and personally answered. This is a very good sign in my estimation.One drawback is that this might be crazy addictive. The starter kit is exactly that...a starter kit, and it seems the additional track pieces will be something to seriously consider in the future. There are also a total of six cars in the Anki line-up, so this adds another four exciting elements to the Groundshock and Skull cars that come with the startup kit.Lots of fun to be had here ...and if you're a young grandpa like me, you can also become super cool to your grandkids by breaking out this toy this next time the kids come over.

There is much to commend in this Bible, and still...there is much that does not answer my own needs, requirements, and hopes in a study Bible.First, a few things to commend... It has colorful maps, graphs, and tables. I'm not being cheeky here, I really do like the addition of color and the maps are great. Most of them are in context, so you are not required to turn to the end of the book to look at the map and turn back to your reading when you're done with the map exploration. The book introductions are adequate in most cases, sometimes better for some books and sometimes not so better...adequate. Book outlines, text references, and most of the "study notes" are fairly standard and what you'd expect from most study Bibles. While the concordance is not exhaustive, it is substantial having almost 5,000 word entries.Where I felt the Bible was lacking is strictly subjective and should not be a reflection of the Bible specifically. I am part of an evangelical denomination, but I don't want a strictly evangelical study Bible. I would like an ecumenical and objective study Bible. I don't care for Scripture being notated and indexed according to an evangelical perspective. I would prefer objectivity and inclusiveness where it relates to the Christian faith. I am capable of making my own judgments based on the information, but this is or can be difficult where the information has been skewed or completely omitted.

This one works! No drips or leaks and Aladdin is a trusted name in the insulated container business, but there's more.Dishwasher safe? Check! and there's not a lot of hidden sealer rings and plastic moving parts that need to be disassembled or removed before going in the dishwasher. This is important because all those little parts can become places for "unclean" things to happen. Trust me here, it happens. This mug removes those problems and it's an easy cleanup on the top rack of the Dishwasher. Done.Stainless steel means it's got longevity of life. This mug should ride shotgun with me a long time.Here's my one of my favorite things... many insulated travel/coffee mugs I've had have been "leakproof," but they've also created vacuum when I start to drink. You know what I'm talking about, you go to get a sip and only a trickle comes out because there is no breather hole. Yep, that's a bigtime drag. The design of this mug is ingenious in that the lever latch covering the drink spout is also a plunger hinge that prevents both leakage and opens the spout for liquid pass-through. This is wonderful because the plunger latch is low enough allow air passage that prevents the formation of vacuum. I drink freely and still no leaks!This is my new favorite mug, and I really do hope it lasts me a forever longtime!

This is a nice planner/appt. book. It's larger than versions I've used in past years, but I chose this specifically for the additional writing space and the wider At-A-Glance perspective the larger size offers me. The hard cover provides plenty protection for me in my messenger bag ensuring that it will last me all through the year.A few extra features often included in yearly planners are also included here: Holidays through years 2016-2018, Event planning section, Quick Reference section for phone no.s and contacts or other important info, and a folder pouch for collecting business cards and such.Nice planner. It will serve me well in the coming year.

My two stars express it best, "I don't like it."In my opinion, the book is rife with problematic posits. I should begin with the disclosure that my tradition holds an egalitarian view for women and ministry. I also agree that the male and female relationships, when most healthy and God honoring, are practiced with a spirit and attitude of mutuality. Having said that, I do believe there is a divine sense of order that is bent in the direction of patriarchy by God's design and not exclusively by nature of the Fall of Humanity.The opening chapters of James' Malestrom begin with tired stereotypes of male masculinity; men are brutes, violent, "impregnator-providers," aggressive, and more...it got exhausting for me very quickly. Then, there was this statement that I believe is a false premise; "If men must rule--whether in government, on the streets, or in private homes--then anything that threatens a man's place of authority also jeopardizes his manhood." This is what James calls the "Malestrom," which is the foundation of her thesis...if I understand correctly. The strawman was building. Even with this disheartening early build-up, I tried to keep my reservations and bias neutralized, trying to read with some modicum of objectivity.Following the thesis statement, she goes on to exaggerate her premise with this statement; "The malestrom poses one of the most serious historic challenges to the gospel..." Then in the same paragraph of this statement she drops in a comparison with ISIS; "This is not simply an internal church issue. We have ISIS to consider." Oh. My. Jesus. Have Mercy.James has offered (in my opinion) hyperbole and excessive drama to hook her reader and build her premise, so she sets her stance to begin the journey of building the case for her thesis and unleashes this bomb; "...Two major problems confront us before we even begin: first, that a chapter is missing from the Bible that is most pertinent to our quest, and second, that the men in the Bible best equipped to help us have gone missing too." I kid you not... (see pg 33). I heard the words in my head, "Are you serious???" After delivering such thesis defining rhetoric in her opening salvos, she now suggests her case is going to be built on "missing chapters and missing men" from the Bible she is using to define and prove her case. I think this is more aptly called personal opinion and conjecture.Personal opinion and subjective interpretation of the texts cited by James continue to spiral in a direction of her own choosing, by the end of chapter one, the reader is completely caught up in the swirling whirlpool of James' feminist theology...and it never stops. Rest assured, if is smells like an agenda, looks like an agenda, and talks like an agenda...there is likely an agenda.I will say again, I think the right alignment of men and women is mutuality. Regardless of how James wills to present her case, we all have roles to fill within the context of society, civilization, and relationships. There is no way, at least functional way, everyone can play the same role or be the same character. However, we can coexist with mutual love and respect for one another and place equal value on the place and role that each individual will assume as we live out our lives with one another. I don't know if I agree with a defined-in-stone hierarchy in anything, but I do believe there is a place for leadership and authority and that should be assumed by the best person, male or female, for a given time and duty.I think overusing and resurrecting tired metaphors, even if they were born in some measure of truth, is unhelpful if we are to move forward, so I'm left unconvinced by James' thesis and her conclusions...and it seems, that she is unconvinced as well. She writes beginning pg. 202:"The final chapter of a book is supposed to bring the subject to a conclusion. But any sense of closure to the subjects raised in this book evades me." She continues; "As I reach the end of this literary journey, I must admit I have more questions than answers, and those questions deeply trouble me..." I think the reason for this unsettledness hearkens back to my earlier comment that much of the case built by James is conjecture and personal opinion rather than real exegesis of the text. To her credit, I believe she ends the book on a very positive note. She writes; "The way forward is challenging. The problems are complex, and we have only begun to grasp the remedies God provides. But we are not walking into the darkness, for Jesus knows the ways and is still saying, 'Follow me!'" In my opinion, these are the best sentences of the book and found on the last page.

This is a very handsome watch. It's also a very heavy watch.I stopped wearing a watch several years ago when it seemed a little redundant with carrying a smartphone with me all the time. Personally, I don't wear a watch as a fashion accessory, so functionality and practicality are the determining factors for wearing one. When I was offered the opportunity to review this Invicta 17313 model, I figured sure "it's been awhile."Out-of-the-box the watched seemed much more expensive than its MFRP. It's sturdy, stainless steel, and has quite a bit of heft (did I mention its heavy?). Mine is the speedway chronograph and I find the function mostly useless for my world, but its there if anyone needs it. I tried to play around a bit with the stopwatch and chrono and wasn't very impressed with the action of the buttons. The buttons all have screw-down water-tight fittings that must be "unscrewed" to gain access to the function...kind of  hassle, but understandable I suppose to stay true to the water-resistance side of the build. Other than this particular chrono feature the watch is pretty straight-forward in its design. There is a day counter to keep track of what day it is...The bezel has markings set for time splits when using the chronograph, but my aging eyes had a tough time distinguishing the markers, also the nice looking black finish contributes to the difficulty of making out the hash marks on the bezel...at least it does for my eyes (I do wear progressive bifocals).I wrestled a bit with what ranking I would give this watch. Based purely on my impressions, I rank it a 3-star, but I'm thinking I might be a little harsh and were it not for my poor vision and the fact that I'm not used to having what feels like 2lbs of metal dangling on my wrist, I might rank it a 4-star watch. It is truly built well and it is a very nice looking watch. That alone counts for something.

I've had the printer installed and networked to my LAN for a few days. Installation out-of-the-box was relatively trouble free and took less than 30-minutes from unboxing to software installation to final setup and ready state. I had no problems connecting the printer to my wireless network and all my networked devices found and connected to the XP-830 with no headaches.Print Quality: For regular text documents, printing is fast and the font readability is very crisp. A+ or 5-stars grade. I had a couple of minor details to work through for the photo printing as my first couple photos delivered issues relating to print head alignment. During my initial setup, I accepted the default maintenance settings and allowed the installation setup software as my benchmark. I printed a photo and had lines across the image. I went back to the printer's maintenance mode and performed a nozzle cleaning and print head alignment. A couple of passes through this maintenance app and I am now printing premium quality images. So, recap, for photo images BE SURE to run the nozzle cleaning app and the printer head alignment function.The software interface is a little clunky for me and I've not figured out the desktop app or if there is one. Also, the Epson App for smartphone (I'm using Android) is pretty good and fairly intuitive. I did successfully print wirelessly with no hangups from my Galaxy S6 immediately after downloading and installing the app from the Android App Store. Be aware that images d/l from the web or Facebook might print out pixelated due to a lower image quality.Other than the normal learning curve frustrations for new hardware/software, I have one little complaint. I wish there was a second tray that I could use fullsize paper. This would allow me to have one tray for text documents and one tray for photo images. It is for these reasons I'm going with an overall 4-star.

This little prayer book has become my new favorite. I've used a number of prayer books over the years, but the simplicity and purity of this little missal is something special to me. The binding and quality of the pages paper is very, very good. I expect the book will fair well in my daily carry gear and this important to me as I've worn out several paperback prayer books in the past and ruined the binding edge of some leather covers as well.

I've owned a number of HDD external drive housings in the past, this one is AWESOME! Out of the box, slide in SATA drive, plug in and power up. My Windows 7 and Windows 10 machines recognized it in an instant with drivers loaded almost instantaneously, I was ready to transfer files in under a minute. Seriously.Quality of the drive is very good and I expect a number of years of service. I bought this drive after visiting a Best Buy and noting their comparable product was 3 times the price. This one is a winner!

It's hard to tell when reviewing vitamins and supplements how much benefit your body is receiving. Without very controlled circumstances, most interpretations are highly subjective. I don't know yet how my body is receiving and processing the Curcumin supplements, but there are some observations I can share.These are large capsules, but I do not find them difficult to swallow. They are a one capsule, once a day dosage recommendation. I have not found them irritating to my stomach or causing me any IBS issues. I do take them after a breakfast meal. I also take them in conjunction with a Glucosamine Chondroitin supplement, so I'm not sure if my minimal joint pain (I suffer from gouty arthritis) is related to one or the other products...or if it might be a combination of the two.I plan to update my review with pertinent information as it surfaces.

I am a longtime supporter and user of Paintshop Pro, dating back to the days it was coded by JASC. While there have been some "clunky" updates and bloated packages through the years of its development, the last few versions have been pretty good. I note that  some of my problems with slow processing and system crashes with previous versions may have been related to older computer hardware, inadequate system memory and failure to perform clean installations (removing previous versions of Paintshop Pro). This is to qualify my complaints of other earlier versions, so with adequate system requirements, I say, version 18 is another step in the improvement direction in my opinion.The package is a quick installation (i'm using Windows Version 7). The interface has a few changes (I was currently using Paintshop Pro 15), but those changes are intuitive and easily learned. The program operates smoothly on my computer, but I think it should considering I have 12GB of RAM. I appreciate the many presets and these will be handy for first-time users or newbies to the world of digital image manipulation, I like to have a closer hands on approach, so the manual controls are my preferred method.There is no shortage of features in this package and one should not limit their creativity to photos alone. I use Paintshop Pro for many desktop publishing projects. It has been my swiss army knife for digital publishing/printing for almost twenty years and I don't see that changing in the near future...as long as these updates and the support for the product continue.

I like this bag, but there are a few things that I would like to see that could have made me love it.It is adequate from my tests down to 40+/- degrees, but I've not had the opportunity to test it below those temps. I also found there is ample room for me in the bag. The price for the bag is also very good for its quality. Finally, the bag is lightweight (3lbs) and compresses nicely to fit into an included stuff sack that packs easily into my backpack.Now, what I wish it also the bag featured. I wish it had a water resistant or moisture proof gortex bottom. It would be even nicer  if it had full gortex or moisture resistant outer shell. I think these would add quite a bit to the cost of the bag, but they would move me from like to love.

These around-ear headphones are super comfortable, like almost wearing nothing at all. Bose has made a very nice-fitting and extra lightweight set of gear that I can wear for hours at a time (I use them when I telecommute for my work in the evenings) without the slightest discomfort.Sound reproduction is well above average, but I have used other headphones that are slightly better in this area than the SoundTrue II. Those headphones are also more expensive. These are NOT noise canceling, but thee around-ear design does help a bit in muffling ambient noise.Although I do not use the inline controls (Apple iProducts), they are a nice perk and do work well when paired with an iPhone, iPod, or iPad.One thing I've learned about Bose, one can appreciate their attention to detail and product integrity. The SoundTrue II headphones are another great and very affordable addition to this lineup of favorite audio accessories.

I've been a Linksys product user and supporter for well over a decade now and I've come to depend on the consistency and durability of devices in their home networking product line. The WRT AC1200 is a continuation of current technology and proudly joins a lineage of dependable networking devices.Like previous devices, this router is very user friendly with ease of setup for the LAN neophyte and equally sophisticated configuration choices for the network Guru. With a click-through wizard the newbie can literally have their network up and running in a scant few minutes; likewise, for the network admin types, there are manual options to vary the levels of security, create QOS standards, and various options to allow port pass-throughs (VPN tunneling, gaming, server technology, and etc.). This is truly a very capable router. Additionally, the latest technology for radio broadcast is incorporated for very fast data transfer. If you are a "super tinkerer," this device provides open source technology for those inclined to write your own firmware scripts. (This is way over my head, so I cannot speak to this feature).I live in a smaller apartment, so my signal strength out-of-the-box is full power anywhere in my apartment.All in all, I am very satisfied with performance and support of another fine product from Linksys.

Excellent Bed! Very comfortable and solid support.Comfort and expectations thereof are certainly subjective, but coming from a superior innerspring mattress (Serta's top of the line), I was very surprised to experience the firm, but plush support of this memory foam mattress. It is, in every sense, as good a mattress as my Serta innerspring was. It is certainly too early to speak about long term support and stability of firmness, but I remain hopeful.Set up is easy. Simply and carefully remove packaging and unroll the mattress allowing time for it to recover from it's vacuum sealing. This happened for me in less than a few hours (between 2-4 and it was relaxed enough to sleep on). Full recovery can take up to 24 hours. There is also a bit of "new car" smell to the mattress, but that gasses out after a couple-few days. I do not notice anything unpleasant to my senses anymore.At present, I have no immediate concerns. The mattress sleeps well, and the Cool Gel Ventilation does what it is intended, at least to my experience...I do not sweat or toss and turn during the night due to reflected body heat. I do wonder about edge support, but that doesn't seem to be a problem at this juncture. Sheets fit well over the 10.5 inch thickness and I've added a protective topper/cover for my own peace of mind.Great mattress and perfect alternative to the "big brand" memory foam mattresses. Buy with confidence!

I absolutely loved this book!I've been a Christian for a long time and I've participated in "Seder" meals from an Evangelical perspective and interpretation... On those occasions I been left with a feeling of incompleteness, confusion, and a sense of possible devaluation of the intent and purpose of the Seder because of missing context. I understand my feelings now after having read What Every Christian Needs to Know about Passover.Rabbi Moffic has brilliantly and eloquently laid out the background and the ritual of the Passover for people challenged by the culture and the history of this ancient meal (like myself). While no expert by any means, I most definitely feel more equipped to participate with respect in the service of this yearly ritual.The book is masterfully written and very easy to understand. Beginning with a sufficient background of the history of the Seder and Passover, the Rabbi proceeds with detailed steps through every aspect of the Passover meal complete with attention to every dish, every ritual, every question, song, and response. As I said earlier, "Brilliant."It was even more fortuitous that I was able to obtain this book during the Lenten Season as my curiosity was piqued because of my personal engagement with this very holy time of the Church calendar. I look forward to continued study of the book and accompanying ritual with hopes of possible participation of a Seder among my own family and closest friends. I'm sure this book will be a great asset to me in the coming years.

No, monitor calibration is not only for professionals.Who needs it? That depends, but if you want your photos to reflect the accuracy of what you see, then monitor calibration is important. Digital photography has radically changed the photo imaging game. While many folks may only display their images through social media and digital displays or slideshows, some people still get prints done. Whether you print your photos at home or you outsource through an online service or local big box outlet store, calibrating your monitor for accurate color reproduction will help ensure what you see and photograph is what you get. This is where monitor calibration is important and the Spyder5Pro makes it easy-peasy.The S5P100 is a quick setup. Downloading the software from the online link and activation is just a few minute task and you're up and running. A quick calibration for ambient light and you're calibrating your monitor for accurate color representation. There is nothing close to rocket science with this task. The software wizard makes the calibrating process as easy as a few mouse clicks. Depending on your monitor (desktop or laptop), the start to finish time is 5-10 minutes at most.If you take your photography seriously, even if you're not a professional, you might consider this an invaluable tool. Datacolor is a leader in the monitor calibration field. Buy with confidence.

So far, so good!This air fryer has  a lot of good things going for it. It is quick, it is efficient, and it is easy to clean up and we haven't even gotten into the talking points about how it cooks. About that...I haven't run this unit through all the paces yet, but for what I've experimented with it performs very,very well. I'd likely give it an excellent if I were being completely fair, but I've pushed it pretty hard on a couple of occasions to find its limits. I've "fried" frozen precooked wings on three occasions now and the fryer has done great with them considering overall performance. There has been some experimentation with cooking time duration as I came close to overcooking one batch and undercooking another, but those are user issues and no fault of the fryer. Now, after a few batches, I feel I have a fairly good handle on amount of wings to cook time ratio and things have been fairly consistent with excellent food quality results.I have also experimented with uncooked chicken breasts and a light coating of seasoned flour (no oil). Results weren't as good as I expected, although the chicken was evenly cooked and tasted exquisite, the appearance wasn't uniformly golden brown and appearance is important. I believe I was in error here again and not the fryer. I may have overfilled the basket and not allowed for good convection flow around the chicken pieces. I think my results will be better on the next go around.I look forward to sampling more recipes and feel that this will be an oft-used appliance in my kitchen. It's fast, easy, and it really does a great job of cooking delicious food with a little trial and error investment.

Pilgrims Progress is likely one of the greatest works of literary allegory that exists. I realize how bold that statement might be, but one only read the book to find the truth steeped in that boldness.While Pilgrims Progress charts the arc of the Christian journey, I dont think it is limited to the Christian experience. Truly the brilliance of John Bunyan is realized in his astute understanding and the following portrayal of the human journey as seen through Pilgrims (Christian) eyes.Originally written almost three hundred fifty years ago, the version I review has been updated to include both the actual Holy Bible Scripture verses and the Scripture references in line with the text of the story. This is a great benefit to the reader who may want to understand the theological reference from whence Bunyan develops his story (an example follows).What does this mean? Christian asked.The Interpreter answered, This is Christ who continually maintains the work already begun with the oil of his grace in the heart. By this grace, in spite of what the Devil can do, the souls of his people still prove to be gracious. (My grace is sufficient for thee; for my strength is made perfect in weakness. Most gladly, therefore, I will rather glory in my weaknesses that the power of Christ may dwell in me. -2 Cor. 12:9)Other than the Scripture helps and modernized language, the book remains faithful to the original writing published in 1638. Although  some of the concepts may be a bit complex for very young children, I wouldnt hesitate to read it to those even as young as second grade. In fact, I read the story to my children when they were between the ages of seven and twelve years old. Even if some of the ideas and situations found in the story or big, it can serve as conversations starters and discussions about the nature of lifes journey. This work should be on everyones must read list perhaps to revisit and read again and again.I received a complimentary copy of  this book with no obligation to post a favorable review.

Very nice! I ordered this because I have an expensive quilted mattress cover with memory foam and I wanted something to protect it, since it is not so easy to wash. This cover is PERFECT for my use. There is a waterproof liner, which is important to me, but the liner isn't "crinkly" and is only on the one side... the side of the cover that is closest to my sheets almost has a flannel feel to it - soft and not stiff or "crunchy" the way most waterproof covers can be.As mentioned, I have a thick quilted cover over my mattress already and it too is quilted and rather thick. The overall thickness of my mattress and existing cover is around 13-14 inches. The Perlux mattress cover has deep fitted corners that easily fit over my mattress and memory foam pad with room to spare. The fitted edges are stretchy so there's not a jumble of loose material around the mattress once the cover is in place. Another plus for me and my OCD self.Most importantly, this cover is easily maintained in house. It is machine washable, but there are specific cleaning care instructions to follow, so there is no damage done. (Do not dry on med. or high heat, no ironing, no bleach, and no dry cleaning) Following the instructions should ensure a long and satisfying life.

Extremely nice sink, very nice to look at with its clean and modern look, but also very nice functionality. How Kohler has managed to incorporate such a high level of scratch resistance to this finish is beyond my technical understanding (check out the videos!), but it seems almost impervious to scratching. Note that I have not attempted this same level of testing, but under normal use conditions I think expectations can be realized that the finish will remain in close to pristine condition for a long, long time.The undermount design adds to the clean and modern look and the deep oversized capacity of the sink provides plenty room for cleaning large pots and pans. This is a huge plus for me when it comes to washing baking pans and roaster inserts that aren't dishwasher safe or are oversized for placing in my dishwasher.If there is any negative critique from me, it is solely directed to the price of the product. I don't know what the scratch-resistant coating costs, but other sinks of comparable size and features (sans scratch-resistance feature) cost considerably less. I think I could swallow the disappointment of a scratch or few to save a few hundred dollars. Cost aside though, this is an excellent sink.

Oh, how I wish all partially assembled or assembly-required products went together as easily as this Thule Sport Stroller. Out of the box and ready to jog-N-roll in about 15-20 minutes. Seriously. Most of the unit is already assembled and collapsed in folded storage mode.
