This means assembly is restricted to popping on the tires...and that is, literally, a snap.The stroller has a number of very cool features: a hand brake, a foot brake, a lockable front wheel, cushioned shock-absorbing rear wheels, a reversible canopy hood and ample storage for baby bottles, water bottles, toys, books, change of clothes... a high quality and very thoughtfully designed product for sure. These points and the fact that this is almost a single-handed operation for collapsible storage and preparation for use, as well as compact storage (easily fits into the rear storage of your minivan or hatchback SUV/CUV) make it a perfect choice.While ideally designed for jogging, it should not be restricted to only those considerations. The lightweight design, ample storage, and comfort ride of the Glide Stroller makes it great choice for almost any use. Quality construction and premium features put this on your short list, if you're in the market for almost any stroller.

This Skiva Cloud Wifi Router offers a lot of features for the invested bucks. The price of $25 is very fair for a basic N300 router, add the features offered with the Skiva RT001 and you have a winning combination. Initial setup is a breeze, almost plug and go for your wireless devices to connect. Personalized configurations are relatively easy too with the setup app or direct config via the web interface.The USB port provides a connection point for NAS storage by USB thumbdrive or any HDD equipped with USB connection point. I've not tested or attempted connection with the cloud storage feature, so cannot comment. The router does work as an access point or network extender. As I stated at the beginning of this review, you get a lot of router for $25 bucks. There are competing devices on the market with more features and more bandwidth, but you'll pay upward of 4X the price. The old saying, you get what you pay for can be true, but in this case, you get a LOT more than what you pay for.(I was provided with a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review)

I've tried quite a few car chargers and most of the dual port designs were not adequate for my needs. The Skiva PowerFlow Duo 4.2 Amp charger has proved to me that it is a capable challenger to the chargers I've tried before. The problems I've experience with the other designs is the ports have not equally distributed the power output. The Skiva design does not follow that architecture and each port output is 2.1 Amp. This allows my Android S3 or my Nexus 10 to be in use and continue to charge. This meets my needs! Naturally, without the  devices in use (a lot of power consumption with the display screens on), the recharge time is much faster. This purchase is a no-brainer, definitely a great buy for the price.(I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review)

What's not to like? This is a basic network router with better than average coverage and functionality for its price point. Truthfully, I wonder if it can be beat for function-to-cost ratio.Netgear is a leader in home networking and can be trusted for producing quality gear and this N300 Wi-Fi Router is no exception. Setup is a button click away as are connections to all your networked devices. The GUI and software wizard are as intuitive as it gets and you can have your network setup and running in mere minutes.Understand this is not a multi-feature unit with loads of bells and whistles, but if you're looking for a basic connection device to serve as a Wi-Fi router or repeater on a small budget, this might be what you're in the market for.

I'm loving  this shower caddy! I must admit it was a little bit awkward with the first steps to assembly, but it all came together after a few moments of laying out all the pieces and thinking through the process. Not to worry, but the assembly instructions are a bit on the minimalist side of things. Granted, it's a fairly simple design, but I still had some questions about what piece went where ...and the compression spring tensioning section was giving me a fit. While this is a newer component in the Grayline lineup, I was still able to find a YouTube video that was helpful to me in figuring out how the sections went together. Once assembled, installation in the shower was a snap. It was literally a 2-minute job.Functionality so far has been good. I have some concerns over the strength of the shelves themselves and what the maximum weight load is, but I've not found any problems yet. I've got a 12oz bottle of liquid soap and a 16oz bottle of shampoo on one shelf and there's no sag. We'll see if the unit holds up long term, but no complaints for the moment.The corner placement is not overly obtrusive nor is it a space hog in the shower. The overall footprint is small enough to not be bothersome and the number and size of shelves creates storage for even the most cluttered of showers. I'm really happy with my caddy.

This is a dandy little utility pouch! Don't be fooled by the "stroller" designation either, it can be used for many purposes other than merely attaching to a stroller. It's attachment velcro straps are ideally suited to a handlebars of a stroller, but similarly can be attached to bicycles, shopping carts, and backpacks...or carried as an insulated pack inside a backpack. The ways this little pouch can be used are only limited by your imagination. The inside pouch is moisture proof and has some insulation for keeping items hot or cold...if the thought is to "keep cold" a small freezer back is advisable. The saddlebag/pouch is a decent size very capable of carrying a couple of 16oz plastic bottles and a few snacks or other sundry items. I have nothing I can think of that is lacking for this pack, I do think I might be able to add or affix a shoulder strap that might enhance its use even more.

This is one very, very sturdy folding table. Heavy gauge steel construction and solid enough to support up to 500 pounds of (evenly distributed) weight, this is not your cardboard stock folding tea table. This table is beast class.There's not a lot I can say about it other than it is quality constructed with every element of its design and assembly. Honestly, this is the most well-made folding table I've ever encountered. I should qualify my reasoning by saying, I serve in a church that has lots of folding tables of varying ages, construction, and design function... this one ranks at the very top for its design. I have not doubt that it will last a very long time under heavy use. In fact, I won't hesitate to mention this mfg for consideration when we purchase new orders for folding tables in the future.This has multiple uses, your needs and imagination are your limitations. One last comment: best folding table ever, in my experience.

This is a very nice bedframe for its price. As other reviewers have noted, it comes disassembled and there are quite a few parts, but don't let that deter you. The package comes with all its parts including a small hex wrench and nut wrench; no other tools are required. While the assembly instructions are on the minimalist side of things, the actual work of putting the frame together is very intuitive. All time counted, from unboxing to complete assembly to disposal of the packaging materials was one hour exactly for me.The frame is very sturdy and has ample room for storage underneath. I did not have a mattress for this frame, but was looking to add a bed for a guest room, so ordered the Classic Brands Mercer 12 Inch Hybrid Cool Gel Memory Foam and Innerspring Mattress, Queen Size to be paired with it. I will have a separate review for that mattress, but let me say the pairing of these two items is a match made in mattress heaven. The mattress really adds another layer of stability to the foundation/frame, tying the whole together for a rock-solid and restful experience.My "con" list isn't very long, but there is no point of attachment for a headboard. This isn't a game killer, but it should be noted. Also, I have concerns over the longevity of the plastic sleeves the wood slats fit into. At present, everything is good, but time will be the determining factor on this question and that will need...well, time.All things considered, this is a good deal and a comfortable frame for a big mattress. Don't let the assembly scare you off, buy with confidence.

This book is mesmerizing, fascinating, and absolutely brilliant.Allow me to say from the outset, the work presented in this volume far exceeds relevance to insight toward child development. It is not only a window into the mind, psyche, and soul of a child... No, it is a portal peering into the great mystery of each of us.Be advised, this book is not a book about religion nor does it purpose an agenda. This is likely, in my opinion, one of the most object treatments of the concepts relating to human spirituality that I have encountered. I have appreciated the science behind Lisa Miller's (author) observations as much as I have appreciated her "real-life" observations and anecdotes. As I have read through The Spiritual Child, I have been aware of my own thoughts getting carried away with considerations and critical reasoning of the thoughts presented to me. In other words, I am being fully engaged by this book. I am engrossed and invested...I'm considering my own upbringing as well as the raising of my own children and I'm considering the implications of my involvement as I prepare for the welcoming of my first grandchild in the coming months. This, to me, is the sign of a well-written, well-researched, and well-presented book. Honestly, I was hooked even from the introduction.It is evident from dialectical flow of this book that Lisa Miller is a scientist (Clinical Psychologist and Director of Clinical Psychology at Columbia University). Do not let this revelation lead you to consider the book is written in academic speak; it is not. Dr Miller writes as a parent as much as a scientist and presents her thesis and findings in a conversational tone. As I mentioned earlier, I was drawn in to the discussion as early as the introduction. I appreciated the hard data from biological studies that helps to move this subject from nebulous subjectivity to observable, tangible, objectivity. Chapter two, "The Science of the Spiritual Brain," was a helpful introduction and foundational piece for the remainder of the book.Chapter seven, "The Six Spiritual Strengths," is exceedingly thought provoking. This chapter continues to stir thoughts about my own childhood and moves me to consider how I will engage my grandchildren relative to their developing spirituality. The results of avoiding the relevance of these findings and information is revealed in the following chapter eight, "Window of Awakening," where Dr Miller presents some disturbing statistics and correlates-connects "data dots" with real life.The final chapters of the book (chapters 10 through 13) offer many helps and much hope with practical suggestions for engaging children in the development of their spirituality ...their development as human beings. I think, these chapters are just as helpful for the adult who might be reading them and still working through their own self-awareness. I'm convinced the information presented in this book can be the first steps for much inner healing for many people and likely holds the possibility of a second awakening and second chance for better life for them as well.I am looking forward to reading and rereading this book, hopefully in a group of people, so I might glean from the insights of others. Truly, a brilliant study and presentation. 5-stars!

I'm adding my voice to the favorable reviews for this HBS-800 Bluetooth Headset. At this juncture, my primary usage has been for phone conversations, but I have also enjoyed it for music listening as well. Here's the rundown on my experience thus far.This headset was ridiculously easy to set up. I literally charged it up, turned it on, and it paired with my Galaxy S3 phone. There was nothing more to do. Nothing. Perfect.I'm not overly fond of in-ear plugs, but these seem to work fine (what I mean by work is they stay in place). There is no over-ear hook or other retaining device, but the  contents of the shipping package include a couple pairs of rubber ear bud sleeves in various sizes that accommodate larger/smaller ear canals. I've tested the snugness of the fit by jumping around and turning my head from side to side at extreme angles and the headset and ear buds stay in place fine for me. the around-the-neck design of this unit is a little awkward for me and it's taken some time for me to get used to it, but it does seem to work and after a few days of use, it does seem more comfortable and natural. The controls are easy to find by feel and intuitively located. I'll have to note that the first time I received an incoming phone call, I was a bit freaked out by the vibration buzz around my neck...almost thinking I had on a shock collar. Suffice it to say, I didn't miss the call.Fidelity of sound for my music listening is very good in my opinion. I own several pairs of high quality headphones, both over ear and in ear styles and this headset holds its own with them. I think perspective is important, so it should be said that these in-ear buds will likely not compete with your higher end over-ear headphones... not in comfort, not in style, not in sound quality, but for $75 they perform admirably. I have found bass response much higher than expected and the mid-range is crisp with no "muddiness" in the tones. Trebles are okay for my taste, but I would like to hear them a bit cleaner. I should note that the headset has an equalizer feature for bass boost -> normal -> treble boost, but I did not discern a noticeable difference when toggling through those settings. Likewise, there is a Ambient Noise Cancelling feature that I did not notice any discernable difference.All the audio streaming functions (Play, Pause, Stop, Next, Previous, FFwd, and Back) worked perfectly with my Samsung Galaxy S3. There is an additional feature for reading your SMS messages, but I have not downloaded the Android App to test this as of yet. As noted, this is a very feature-packed headset and a great value for the price point. I'm please with it and become more attached to it the more I use it. I still prefer an over-ear headset and the around-the-neck design is still not my favorite (although it is growing on me). It is these two reasons I'm rating the HBS-800 four out of five stars.

I've had the opportunity to run this 12-cup mill and brew coffee maker through it paces after a few weeks with it now. I think there are several very positive things about it that I really like and there are a couple of minor frustrations, but overall with the cost of the machine considered, this is a very satisfying coffee maker.For those who might be less experienced in working with whole beans and grinders, there are no worries. This brewer is very intuitive and the instructions included with the machine are very clear and easy to understand. You can seriously expect to be up and running almost from the moment you unpack the maker from its box. There have been a few reviewers that have been a bit disappointed about the quality of the machine parts, most of which are high impact plastic, but that doesn't seem to present a real problem with function. I've noticed not warping from steam and/or hot water.The all-in-one process is convenient, but this is where some of the frustration comes in to play. The "grinder" is not really a grinder, its a chopper, and the "grind" will be inconsistent with this type of process. There is some trial and error involved in getting an acceptable consistency to your bean grind, but this is an eighty dollar all-in-one machine we're talking about here and not a commercial grade device. Likewise, cleanup is a bit of a pain as other reviewers have noted. It would be nice to be able to separate the chopper blade from the brew basket, but it is something one can get used to. I have yet to try, but I think I could get away with top rack cleaning in my dishwasher. If I mess the brew basket up, it can be purchased separately (part# CM5000 03).Other than the minor inconveniences I've mentioned, I think this is a very nicely made unit for the cost. I can certainly vouch for a good cup of coffee... not a magnificent cup of coffee as made from my Breville burr grinder and my French press, but a good cup of coffee nonetheless.

I have two people in our household using this cream... my wife has been using it since it arrived and I've been using it for the past two weeks. She reports that she cannot tell a significant improvement over her "wrinkles," but that is not my reason for use...First I should report that with this product a little goes a long, long way. It is expensive, but I think it might last through a year...or more, which makes the cost much more bearable (it's relative). Second, it smells ok (not bad not good) and it is greaseless. It absorbs quickly into the skin too.For me, I suffer from Diabetes Type II and as a consequence I have very dry skin on my face, my nose and eyes in particular. I have used several major brand facial creams and lotions with minimal results for re-hydrating my skin. this Scalisi cream has worked wonders with my skin and the blotchiness I've had for a couple years. If for no other reason, I am a new convert for this product.Product review update when my wife provides the details of her experience.

I received this very nice LED flashlight for review and after giving it a go for a couple days can say I'm very pleased with it. It has three primary light functions (1) a precision focused beam that is VERY bright--do not shine this light directly in the eyes of someone. (2) a sidebar illuminating spectrum light--think lantern, but still very bright if you look at it directly (3) flashing red LED caution or emergency light.The light functions are all very helpful in each respective use, but I see myself using the "white light" focused beam and spread bar lantern the most. This would make a great backpack or automobile emergency light.I tried the magnetic base on several surfaces and was a little disappointed with my first results as the light would stick securely to some of the metal surfaces I tried. I tested on some other metals like paperclips and noticed a very strong attraction, so I went outside and tested the light on the side of my car. The light stuck securely standing on its side as shown in the company provided photos.I have no complaints about the light, but do wish the magnetic was a bit stronger.

This TP-LINK RE200 AC750 was super easy to setup. I was literally under 10-minutes from unboxing to connected with my LAN and online. The included instructions and the internal admin webpage were intuitive and easy to navigate; I have no qualms or critique about any of this.I ran the TP-LINK for almost two-weeks and didn't experience any dropouts or other network hiccups. I had several devices connected through the range extender (wireless printer, desktop system, notepad, and cellphone). This past week my son returned home for college break and another son arrived for holiday visit. The load on the system increased by 5 additional devices and I suddenly started experiencing disconnects and intermittent bandwidth issues. At this juncture, I'm not entirely convinced it was the AC750, but after removing it and reinstalling a Netgear range extender my aforementioned network problems ceased. My router is a single channel older D-LINK DIR-601, so it might be the source of the issues too. I will need to do further testing and troubleshooting at a later date.At this juncture, I'm not inclined to place blame on the AC750 and feel that based on my earlier experience before the influx of visitors on my network, it is a solid device. I plan to purchase or procure a new router following the Christmas holidays (a dual-band AC router) and will do further testing once this is in place. I will update my review with my findings.

Hand size may be an issue for some, but I love these oven/grill gloves! I've only had the opportunity to use these in the kitchen, but they excel at every place and use I've employed them. Whether it's stove top cooking, removing pans from the oven, or using these for washing dishes, my expectations have been met time after time. I plan to use these as my exclusive "grill gloves" when the next grilling season rolls around and can't wait to see how awesome they will be in that arena...I think they'll be great.I don't have any real critique, but as I mentioned small hands or big hands may have a bit of trouble with these silicone mitts. Average sized hands shouldn't have any issues. These clean up very easy and they can be trusted as dishwasher safe.I'll likely be getting myself a backup pair ...or two.

NOTE::: This review represents an ongoing case (beginning 12/05/14 and running through 01/09/15). My review began with a defective console and quickly degraded into a very poor customer service experience. After a few days of frustration with the technical support and customer service depts., I was able to be connected with someone within the DELL-Alienware organization who pledged to see my case through resolution. Since the day my case was "owned" by this or these individual(s), my experience has been the stuff customer service awards are made for. The case isn't fully resolved or closed just yet, but I am including my experience in the full in the following review. Updates as they are received are posted at the close of this review.UPDATE 01/09/15 see near the bottom of this review of the Alienware Alpha ASM100-2980 Console (2.9 GHz Intel Core i3-4130T Processor, 8GB DDR3, 1TB HDD, Windows 8)----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Begin: 12/15/14I have put off writing any review for my Alienware Alpha until now for two reasons. Reason one is the limited experience of use I've had with it due to equipment malfunction. Reason two is my reluctance to post a review based primarily on the customer service experience. I've thought that the CS aspect of my experience is potentially part of any owner experience and worth reporting, so I'll share my experience thus far with the promise to update my review as the case is resolved...or not.Unboxing experience: All is good with adequate documentation, but I got the most helpful information for installing and connecting the unit to my TV and network from online reviews and illustrations. Most of this information I studied before the unit actually arrived at my home and I attempted my first connect and power up.Powering up: This was my first indication there was something wrong with the unit. The power supply has a bright blue LED that indicates it is receiving power, so my suspicion was it was "good to go." When I pressed the console power button (a little button in the shape of the Alien head) there was nothing. No power up. I checked the connections to the console and jiggled the unit around while pressing the power button repeatedly and at some point the unit powered up.Running through the paces: Initial setup was mostly a breeze and I was aware (from my online pre-research) that there might be updates and driver installs before the unit completed the first use start up. This was exactly what happened, but following the various driver installs and updates, I followed the onscreen prompts to complete setup. I chose to set this unit up in desktop mode as I intend to use it as a media server as well as a Steam console. Everything went great. Following the setup, I started to map network drives in my LAN and installed PLEX Server to manage my movies. I have a lot of music and movies so I let the console go as it processed and indexed files. This step required leaving the console powered up and online for the next 24-48 hours.Powering Down:  after a day or two, my media files were fully indexed and I ran through PLEX server paces, played some music and started to roll a movie. I connected to the STEAM server and was thrilled at how everything was working and enthusiastically looked forward to the coming days to start really enjoying the possibilities of entertainment this little Alpha unit promised... I powered down the unit and went to bed for the evening.Powering Back Up: A couple days later and a day off work I attempted to power the unit back up. Nada. "Oh no," I thought. The unit was doing the same thing I experienced from the first time I tried to turn the console on. I checked connections, PSU, and jiggled the console while pressing the power button. Nothing. This time I could not get the unit to turn on again.Service Dept and Technical Support: I contacted Dell/Alienware for technical support for the first time on Dec. 4, 2014. I followed all the instructions for over-the-telephone troubleshooting and the CS Agent determined the unit needed to be replaced. The CSA advised me of escalation of the service order to a specialty resolution team that would call me within 72 hours to advise me of whether my unit would be approved for replacement. I waited.After 72 hours I had not rec'd the promised call from the resolution specialist but waited two more days (120 hours) before I contacted Technical Support for a follow up. At this point the CSA returned my inquiry with an email that I cut and paste the following:"Let me tell you it's been cancelled but because of a good new the workshop is ready for your computer and I'd like to send send you the box so that you can send it in to get it repaired, Could you please tell me this information for me to create the dispatch?"??? Did you all get that? I think I could read between the lines, but you might guess I was a little confused as to what was going on. The end result was this: The CSAs request for replacement was cancelled. No resolution specialist contacted me. The CSA was now advising that the repair dept was going to "fix or diagnose" the problem with my console...and a box with RMA would be sent to me in order for me to return the unit to Dell/Alienware directly. I was bummed out, but okay...at least we were headed toward resolution. The promised box was estimated to arrive within two business days.6 Days Later: Today, four full business days have elapsed and no return box. I contacted Alienware/DELL again to follow up and the CSA advised that my ticket could be found, but there is no information indicating the return box was shipped to me. The agent was kind and profusely apologized for the error, but they would take "ownership" of the ticket and would ensure that a "resolution specialist" would contact me within 24 hours to see that my ticket is resolved. Is it wrong to sound skeptical?At this juncture, I am extremely dubious as to the resolution process. Regarding the console unit itself, I'm very positive about the potential of providing huge amounts of entertainment. My hopes and prayers for any prospective owners (in light of my present experience), is that you do not experience any mechanical malfunctions...or really have any need of technical assistance.My review is subject to change and upgrade based on the resolution (or not) of this case. Stay tuned.Update: 12/16/14 [1:30pm EST] Some interaction today with various CS agents. I received an email from an agent that told me I would have to wait until parts were available to fix the unit. No box would be shipped until parts were available. I responded with an email to inform the agent this was an unacceptable solution. I attempted to engage a chat agent to help me find an escalation point to locate a supervisor and was advised a supervisor would contact me shortly. Approximately 2-3 hours later I have heard from a supervisor who has advised me they will be handling my case from this point and a box has been FedEx'd to me for return/repair of the console. I was advised I would receive a tracking number for the box, which should come to via my email. Updates to follow.Update: 12/17/14 [4:00pm EST] A little over 24 hours since last update and I've received the RMA return box, dutifully packaged the console unit and power cord for it's trip back to DELL Austin, TX. The estimated deliver to the warehouse and "fixit" shop is around 5-days FedEx Ground. I have been advised, if I understand the email communication process, the entire process will incur 5-7 business days. In any event, the communication I received stated I could follow the status of the process with a tracking number as well as the promise to provide me with status updates when the unit is fixed and ready for return shipping. Updates to follow.Update: 12/18/14 [8:00am EST] Received a phone call this morning from a resolution specialist who has taken ownership of my case. We talked some over the issues surrounding my complaint. I advised the agent that my issues at this juncture were not with the console as I understand things may happen. This being an electronic device, it may not even be a quality control issue, but possible damage during shipping. Stuff happens. The problem occurs when stuff happens and it is not resolved in a timely and professional manner...this is my complaint. At this juncture, despite the frustration of the last two weeks, it seems we are on track for some kind of equitable resolution. My resolution specialist has assured me they will walk with me through completion of this process to ensure that my experience is a positive one. I will continue to update my review as the case proceeds. For the moment, the console is in route back to Texas for repair or replacement. It is expected to arrive at the warehouse early next week. I expect there may be some holiday delays for which I am forgiving and understanding. Updates to follow.Update: 12/22/14 [3:45pm EST] Things seem to have taken a decided turn for the better. I received an email follow up over the weekend to let me know that the resolution specialist was tracking my console on its return to the DELL warehouse in Texas. Today, I received another email to inform me that the console had arrived in Texas and would be undergoing diagnostics as quickly as possible. We still do not have resolution, but this is the kind of customer service support that I had experienced with DELL before and what I expected from the outset with this experience. We are definitely moving in the right direction and I am hopeful that I will be conducting a full review of this console very soon. Updates to follow.Update: 12/23/14 [2:00pm EST] Contact with the case manager continues to be regular and informative. I was emailed today to advise that diagnostics have begun on my console with expectations that resolution would soon follow. I continue to have expectations that this case will be resolved and have a very happy ending. The interactions and experience of the past week are serving to reinforce my expectations. Updates to follow.Update: 12/31/14 [08:00am EST] Over the past few days I have rec'd a couple emails from the CS Resolution Specialist to advise me that my  console repair is in process. We've not rec'd any description of the process or the findings, only that the console is in diagnostics and repair. The last update (yesterday midmorning advised the console was with the testing engineer...). Last night I checked the Depot Online Status that updates where the console is in the diag/repair process to see that my console has been updated to "repaired" status and is now in the FedEx pipeline on the way back to me. Still no further update as to the diagnostic and repair itself, but I am hopeful to hear back from the resolution specialist at some point ...maybe today. The system is scheduled to return to me by end of day on Jan 02, 2015 and I am hopeful to complete my review. At this juncture, I've officially been in process (from opening the box upon original receipt of the console to today) for four weeks.Update: 01/09/14 [08:00am EST] I received my repaired console a little over a week ago. The unit now operates as it was intended with the power button having been repaired. The repair order stated the power button was improperly seated. The repair from start to finish was just under a month counting for the headaches of the initial poor customer service. Once the issue was handed off to a "resolution specialist" (Andrew), I cannot offer anything but sterling kudos. Andrew was superb, keeping me updated (as he promised) every step of the way with phone calls and emails. This was through the middle of the Christmas / New Year holiday mind you. So, some expected delay was expected from my part.Since having the unit online and the physical function of the equipment operating as designed, I have had the opportunity to run the console through its paces. I've fully integrated the Alienware Alpha as a centerpiece in my entertainment system, serving as a server for multimedia (movies and music) in addition to gaming entertainment via Steam Server. I'm using PLEX to serve movies and music throughout my LAN and my HD TV. PLEX and the LAN service works perfect with no stuttering or other problems and my music rocks with my surround 5.1 sound system. NETFLIX, Amazon Prime, HULU, VUDU and several other streaming services work perfectly through this unit. Also, while it's not my prefered browser, Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube videos are also available with the click of a mouse. This is the great advantage of the combined desktop / console gaming platform approach here.I'm not nearly the gaming connoisseur as my 20-something sons, so I let them be the discriminating voices for the Steam side of things. Both of them gave the system 5-star ratings for game play and responsiveness (from a system hardware perspective as well as online bandwidth). Their gaming choices were Dragon Age and Civilization IV for their tests.I have not found any glitch in any aspect of my testing and evaluation since having the system repaired. I do recommend that a user/owner purchase a keyboard and mouse for the most satisfactory experience if  you intend to use the system outside of just a gaming platform. Honestly, I think the keyboard and mouse are more functional than the handset for most RPG games as well, but that is a user experience preference.I have more things I intend to test and hopefully will further integrate the console into my multimedia uses. I rate the console itself as 5 STAR but on the basis of the initial poor experience with customer service I have to rate an overall experience to 4 STAR. While unfortunate, it was a part of my experience and must be counted. If you should encounter issues with customer service for any reason, be persistent. A few bad eggs do not reflect the whole organization or the product itself.

Well-made, solid little interface box. Installation was relatively easy with my Windows 7 laptop recognizing the device and installing drivers automatically. There was one driver failure, but I went to the Tascam site and downloaded the updates for firmware and drivers and after they were installed my device manager showed the US2X2 device properly installed and ready for action.If there is any complaint about this package, I point to the included software (Sonar LE and Ableton Live). I admit I have limited experience with advanced audio software, but it seems to me that it should be at least intuitive enough to capture direct line-in sound files. I accept the responsibility for my failure in capturing audio with either of these softwares, but I'm disappointed I was unable to use either of them successfully. I was able to use Audacity (freeware), Soundbooth (Adobe) that I already had installed, and Presonus Studio One. In these software applications, I was able to verify that the problem wasn't hardware installation, but likely my lack of understanding the proper settings and input selections to capture my audio files.The two line inputs are more than sufficient for my purposes, I play acoustic guitar and sing, so two inputs are more than adequate for my needs. I rate the hardware as five-stars and software as two-stars. My overall rating is 4-star.

I was not expecting what I got when I first ordered this book for review from Kregel Publishing. I ordered the book based on the title Elders in the Life of the Church: Rediscovering the Biblical Model for Church Leadership and after reading it, I think the original title should have remained intact (Elders in Congregational Life).I was hopeful this book would speak more generically to the structure of church leadership from a historical and early (ancient) church perspective. I admit that I did not read any reviews or summaries of the book before I ordered I should have. Before I proceed with my review, it is only fair for me to state the book is well written and engaging. The writing is full of references, both Scripture and bibliography, and contains many personal anecdotes. It is in these regards that I offer my highest praises for Elders in the Life of the Church.My criticisms for this work are not related to the information presented or the experience of the men who have written it. My criticism is directed to the narrow focus of the subject framed in a very restricted context. There are multiple facets and forms of church government and some of the oldest forms of that government, while not congregationally driven, can be identified as benefiting from the leadership of elders. I do not feel that this subject was addressed sufficiently. The authors framed their thesis using Scripture and interpreted those texts almost exclusively for their particular model of government, almost as if to say, This is the most accurate understanding of what the Scriptures intended. The framework of this model is also decidedly from a Calvinist perspective, which once again, alienates other traditions and models for Church government.  Once the original thesis is established the authors choose to follow the experience of a particular church (a Baptist Church in North America) to illustrate their findings and support their model. As I stated earlier, this particular context is very limiting; consequently, I felt out of my context and quite alienated in understanding how this was rediscovering the Biblical model for church leadership.Personally, what I found most prominent in this book was an institutional model and not truly the role of elders in a church. I was disappointed that the scope of this book was so limited. I think there was an opportunity for more inclusivity of other traditions and a broader look at the role of elder leadership in the body of the Church regardless of the form and function of administrative governance.Disclosure of Material Connection: I received this book free from Kregel Ministry Publishing to read and post a review on my site. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissions 16 CFR, Part 255 Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.

This is a short book, but very dense; this is to say, it might not be for everybody. When I was first offered this book for review, I was excited and looked forward to learning more about the Jewish perspective on the writings of James or Ya'akov from the collection of Scripture known as the New Testament. My goal in ordering this book was to hopefully learn more about the actual intent of these writings and perhaps understand more clearly, what may get lost in English interpretation.Truthfully, there are some gems to be gleaned from this little book, but it was a difficult and cumbersome read for me. I'm not a Biblical languages scholar, nor am I a Biblical history expert; consequently, I struggled with finding a rhythm while reading through James the Just. There are many references to the original languages of Hebrew and Greek throughout the texts; likewise, there are quite a few transliterations of the texts that also added to the slowing down of my reading. These details contributed to my inability to digest approximately thirty to forty percent of the book. It is for this reason that I refer to the "mining of gems." It was, in a very real sense, my experience. I would read, skim, read, skim... find a nugget that piqued my interest and then try to understand and polish up the nugget I had found. The ultimate end of this experience was that it made my level of enjoyment minimal; I felt my reading was more inclined toward work than anything else.The book is well-annotated, complete with bibliography, reference tables, endnotes, and glossary. My experience will likely not be the average experience. I expect that most persons ordering this book will have a better background with the original languages and the socio-political history of the Jewish people. This is a very academic book and not something easily understood by the average Bible student.As I have already said, there are some wonderful gems to be gleaned in this book. I particularly enjoyed chapter five, which seemed most like a commentary for me. I do caution you, before you order, evaluate what your purposes and expectations are for this book.

Last year I had the fortunate opportunity to read and review Sybil Macbeth's Praying in Color, which I loved dearly. When her latest book, The Season of the Nativity, arrived to remind me of the upcoming Advent Season, I was sure it was going to be packed with joy-filled activities and insights. I was right!This little book, published by Paraclete Press, is a delight on so many levels. You can "hear" the exuberance of the season in every word Sybil writes. Not only does MacBeth tell the Advent-Christmas-Epiphany story in her words, but much like her Praying in Color books, she makes the season a full-body experience including ideas for crafts, visual tools, memory-making opportunities, songs, and smells...all of these ways of entering and living into this beginning of the Christian calendar and celebrating the birth of the Christ child.The opening chapters of the book provide background and give insight to the reader who might not be familiar with the Liturgical Calendar. I know my Christian tradition did not practice the seasons of the Christian year and the information sections here in the early chapters of the book can be helpful for those persons who aren't familiar with these ancient practices. Another thing I enjoy so much about Sybil's books, she is mindful of the learning styles of people. She doesn't simply "shoot from the hip" with a bunch of dry information and fact spewing to tell the story; no, she is also a visual and tactile learner who includes beautiful full-color illustrations as well as suggesting physical sensory aids to help inform and tell the story.As I've alluded, the book is an appeal to every facet of the human experience. I liken it to the idea that we are invited to enter into the season with all our "heart, soul, mind, and strength." Likewise, the appeal isn't just to specific age groups, but spans the entirety of the seasons of life... no child is left behind, from the youngest soul to the most advanced soul, there is something to be experienced and something to be shared.Just this past week, as my church was preparing to enter into this Advent-Christmas season, we used The Season of the Nativity to frame what we called The Advent Prayer Encounter. This was our opportunity to teach and introduce this deeply moving and very important time of the year to our church family. We used a number of ideas from Sybil's book to engage people from five years old to seventy plus years old in the telling of this story. I believe the evening was a huge success, in part because of the wonderful diversity of styles and activities for telling and actively inviting participants to experience the story with all their senses through words, songs, art, sights, smells, and the invocation of memories.This is another delightful addition to my Advent resource shelf and I'm sure it will be for anyone who is interested in living into the intimacy and mystery of this Yuletide season. Young or old, new to the season or seasoned veteran in all things Advent to Epiphany, you'll find something to engage and freshen your perspective. Thanks to Sybil Macbeth and Paraclete Press for another delightful read.

The DE Lipstick Style Powerbank and Flashlight is an excellent quick pack charger for your phone. I have several batterybank chargers and this is the "lightest" (pun intended) of them all. I think, when evaluating products and writing reviews, it is important to keep perspective and expectations in balance. While I have been testing this product, my perspective has been filtered by what this powerbank will be used for, the relative cost of this product, and feature/benefit set.This is a low cost device. There are similar lipstick style powerbanks on the market, but this one does feature a multi-function flashlight. I'm not sure that the functionality of the flashlight is adequate compensation for the price differences in other similar products, but this feature does add function to the flashlight/charger. The flashlight itself is bright, very bright... likely one of the brightest I've ever used. This is a benefit on my scorecard. The brightness of the flashlight ensures that I will be using it.The charger seems to work well for the task that it was created (remember perspective). This powerpack charges my phone. It charges it relatively quickly and it charges my battery (Samsung Galaxy SIII battery 2100 mAh) completely, which is an adequate expectation for this device measures at 2600 mAh. I do not expect this tiny lipstick charger to recharge my tablet (Nexus 10) or recharge any other large capacity battery. I see this as an emergency backup with the added function of an emergency flashlight. Considering my uses, this device is a great choice for my needs.As I mentioned, there are competing devices that are available at lower cost. I've not tested those and cannot comment on the build quality or the test results, but the prices are lower than the DE device. Likewise, I noticed a couple of design features missing that I would have loved to see at this price point. The first think I would have liked is an addition of a connector ring on the body of the light, something I might have used to hang this from a keyring for instance. Secondly, it would be nice if there were a rubberized fitting that covered the charging ports to lessen the possibility of contaminants.All things considered, I offer a solid 4-stars for this device.Thank you, GE and Filltech  for the opportunity to review this much appreciated Powerbank/Flashlight combo.

Ive appreciated the writing of Fr Thomas Dubay since the first works that were recommended to me. It seems odd to me in the context that his books were recommended, I was studying for certification in the field of spiritual direction, that this very book wasnt one of the required readings. I was fortunate to have stumbled upon it in the library of a monastery that I frequent and I am so very, very glad I found it.What sets this book apart from others I have read on the subject of spiritual direction is the straight-forwardness of the conversation. Fr Dubay is very clarifying in setting foundations, establishing definitions, and clearing up blurred lines and misinformation with regard to this neglected and needful gift to the Church.All of Part One addresses various aspects of spiritual direction and clarifies definitions. It is appropriately called A Foundation for Spiritual Direction. A couple of the more pertinent topics dealt with in this first section are What is Spiritual Direction? and Do I Need Spiritual Direction. I like that Fr Dubay is very direct, yet his answers and points made seem very thorough.Part Two of the book is a unique departure from the format of the first section. The questions presented, Practical Questions and Problems, are considered and responded to in an interview format. This worked very well for me as I felt myself drawn into a conversation; it was almost as if I were in the room with Fr Dubay and some anonymous interviewer. My attention was rapt and I learned much while topics such as Key Concerns in Spiritual Direction, Self Direction, and Problem that Come up in Spiritual Direction were discussed. Again, the content of the answers was very direct, but no lacking in detail and thoroughness.Part Three, Making Progress, returned to the same format of section one; instead of questions, there were bulleted discussion points, which Fr Dubay shared insights. This section spoke to measuring spiritual growth and discernment in the process of spiritual maturity.A very detailed notes section and an index are included helping the reader to have additional resources for follow up study and/or finding particular topics of interest in this book. It should be noted that the book and accompanying paradigm with which it is written is decidedly Roman Catholic. Let me state unequivocally that this fact alone should not deter reading if your background is that of another Christian tradition. There is a wealth, a cornucopia of spiritual wisdom in this book, Seeking Spiritual Wisdom. My background comes from the Protestant Evangelical stream of Christianity and I will continue to recommend this book with highest regard as one of the best books to clarify what spiritual direction is and the importance of its place and practice in the life of the Christian.

I was first introduced to Sadhu Sundar Singh through the Devotional Classics (Richard Foster) around ten years ago. Reviewing my notes and highlights in my copy of Devotional Classics reminds me of how impacted and awed I was by the deep wisdom of Sundar Singh.Sadhu Sundar Singhs dramatic encounter with the living Christ, his refusal to clothe his faith with western trappings, and his absolute devotion to the way of Jesus make for compelling reading. I highly recommend this book. (Richard Fosterfrom the back cover)Im a big fan of devotional writing, so Im left with a big question mark to the reason Ive never added other works from the Sadhu to my personal library. Regardless, that omission will no longer be the source of questions for me as Ive added this latest compilation, Wisdom of the Sadhu: Teachings of Sundar Singh to my library. Not only has this volume inspired me since coming into my possession, but it has encouraged me to purchase more works produced by this profoundly spiritual and incredibly wise man.Wisdom of the Sadhu is a beautiful and delightful collection of sayings, parables, interviews, articles, and teachings from Sundar Singh. These collections are organized into themes and edited by Kim Comer. I feel Comer has done an excellent job with the collection and editing process; as Ive said already, this is a remarkable book and it will give the reader a fabulous introduction to the breadth and depth of the Sadhus teaching.So many people are impressed by human ingenuity and our ability to tap the power of lightning, wind, light, and all the other myriad forces of nature. Yet, to overcome the passions and seductions of this world and to gain mastery over oneself is truly a much greater achievement. By leading a life of prayer, we receive from God the gift to dwell in the spiritual realm even while we remain in the material world. If we live in prayer, no force of evil or temptation can overcome us; we remain in safe communion with God without any fear. If we abandon the gift of prayer, we become like well-trained animals and no longer recognize our own imperfection, our relationship with God, or our responsibility for our neighbors. -Sundar Singh; oneness with God, pg. 100As much as I enjoyed this book, I do have a small nit to pick. While there is a source listing at the end of the book, I prefer a more extensive citation and bibliography section. Perhaps this source list is enough, I havent researched it yet. Aside from this tiny peeve, I feel this is an excellent book and will enjoy dipping into the Wisdom of Sundar Singh again and again.I was provided a free copy by Plough Publishing House for a fair and honest review

As a pastor and a teacher in the ways of the Christian faith, I am always interested in the materials that can be helpful with my efforts to lead others in following Christ. This latest book from the Anglican Church in North America is a wonderful addition to my list of favorite resources.About the Book itself:Made of bonded black leather and embossed with gold lettering, the book is handsome with a clean aesthetic. It has dimensions of approximately 6 X 8 and weighs in with about 160 pages. It is not a thick book, but the weight of the paper and quality is such that it leaves me with no fears that I must handle the pages with a delicate touch to keep them from tearing. This book is meant to be used. There is also a single ribbon marker.Content and Instruction Philosophy:I love the premise for instruction and the flow of material presented. Truly, there is nothing new here and that is (in my opinion) part of the beauty. Likewise, I think there is an ecumenical bond when we hearken back to our most common denominators of the Christian faith. I believe this spirit is evident in the work produced in this Anglican Catechism.The primary teaching tools included in this work follow: Part One begins with the Gospel and the primary teachings of Christ concerning salvation; Part Two proceeds with Believing in Christ and enlists the Apostle's Creed as the center of focus for teaching "what we believe." A format of questions and answers following each line of the Creed helps to detail and explain the essence of each belief statement. Part Three introduces what it means to belong to Christ, Being Christ's, and teaches the basics of the Christian Life through the Lord's Prayer. The same line-by-line format of Q&A used with the Apostle's Creed is utilized in this section devoted to the Lord's Prayer. Part Four, Behaving Christianly, ventures deeper into the lifestyle of the Christian and continues the very effective format of line-by-line question and answer, this time using the Decalogue or Ten Commandments.  While not novel, I think this "common denominator" approach is brilliant in simplicity and consists of the most basic foundations of our Christian faith. In a day of consumeristic zeal for newer, fresher, better, and improved... I think there is a beauty and a grace for this approach to making disciples of Jesus Christ. It has worked for two millennia; there is no reason to attempt to reinvent the wheel.The Anglican Church has produced a beautiful and well-constructed catechism (discipleship tool). There are more exhaustive volumes available, but for the sake of simplicity and thoroughness as well as faithfulness to the core teaching of the Christian faith, I do not think you will find a better resource. You may find equals, but I am doubtful you will find better. This is a winner and I am blessed to add it to my favorite discipleship tools.

Pictures, charts, maps, graphs, stories, details and more make up this beautifully bound edition of the World Atlas of Coffee. What's not to love about one of the world's greatest beverages? This book covers it all from berry to bean to brew and every point in between. There is no "bean" left uncovered as Hoffman (the author) journals the beginnings of the brew and teaches about all the variations of how the beverage is consumed. This edition is truly a global tour that leaves no question unanswered.The quality of the book is exceptional. The paper grade is very heavy and a semi-gloss finish. As mentioned, there are ample photographs and graphical details to appeal to the visual learner as much as the reader who loves their words. This is an excellent "coffee" table book or would make a great waiting room piece.If you're a coffee aficionado, you'll love this one!

So far, this one is very good! There are some significant positives about this pillow (natural filling, hypo-allergenic, memory foam), and all of them seem to be right on spec. and I have no serious qualms or complaints. There are, however, a couple of small nits that keep me from ranking this pillow with 5-stars. First, it came with a acrid smell. It seems to be dissipating, but it lingers yet. It is possible that a washing and air dry will resolve this odor issue. Secondly, I wish the pillow had more fill. It lies a bit flat for my personal preference. I love the feel, but it could use more fill...

I'm still trying to squeeze more love out of this very pretty, but minimalist watch/activity tracker.There's plenty here that I want to like, but *yawn* it's a bit boring. Quite honestly the novelty wore off almost before I finished the initial setup. It seems to me with the technology available (and inexpensively so), this watch could really excel with functionality. I think it misses the mark on several levels.First, my "pro" comments, I think it is a pretty watch. It is sleek and attractive in a minimalist design aesthetic. Construction is top quality. Ease of use is fairly intuitive, but borders on frustration with the two-button menu operation.Now, on the not-so-exciting side of the Wellograph Wellness Watch are these thoughts: (1) more practical functionality could be built-in at little or no additional cost. It's a digital watch. Why not a calendar or reminder alarms? (2) So far, the estimated distances and "activity monitor" have been way less than accurate. I'm not convinced that I will be able to trust the counters. It seems, again, that with a watch of this build, it would not have been too much difficulty to add an onboard GPS to help with the accuracy of distance traveled.I think my expectations might be skewed by my interactions with other technology and software. I believe a partnership with Wellograph and Android might have positioned this watch to really become a market force. Unfortunately, in my opinion it falls a little flat in everything that it tries to sell itself as.

Based upon what I've experienced thus far, this is an exceptional printer for all that it offers and at this particular price point. I believe a buyer would be hard-pressed to get more performance and value for the buck. Seriously.My out-of-the-box experience was average. I think every experience is likely to vary, but from unboxing to setup on my WiFi network and actual print time was approximately 45 minutes. The majority of that time was spent during auto-setup when the printer was doing a "head alignment" (this took 15-20 minutes). Once the setup was complete, I have had nothing short of exemplary experience.I confess that I have not put the printer through all of its paces, there will be several functions that I will likely not use. I know I won't use the FAX feature, and it is unlikely I will do any printing from the cloud services, but scanning, copying, printing from USB devices and general document printing will be my mainstays. In all of these services and functions, this machine flat out excels. I have personally never owned a home or small business sized printer that is as fast as this one is. The first exercise of copying a document, I actually thought I had made an error in feeding the document...it was almost instantaneous. The printed document was printed almost simultaneously with the document being scanned through the ADF. Seriously. I was incredulous.Letter clarity and color reproduction seem very good. I think I'll see a significant improvement on photo print quality when I use photo grade paper, but I don't have any on hand to evaluate that just yet, but photo imaging on regular paper is quite good.As I mentioned, this system has many, many features and possibilities and I've not even begun to scratch the surface. The manual is in .pdf for and measures a whopping 41mb in size and over 900 pages!!! I do not know what the output of prints will be for the inkwells, but if they are anything like my MP560, I'll be a happy fellow.I've enjoyed Canon print products in the past and still have a MP-560 in service at this very moment. This Maxify line continues the quality products that Canon distributes. Buy with confidence, this one is a winner.

I'm generally a little skeptical of energy/protein bars as they are often confused about their identity. Some think they are "candy" bars and others think they are nutrition bars disguised to taste like candy (and often failing). I took the chance on the V8 Protein bars and I'm glad I did.There are things to like and things that may be "so-so" with this product. As other reviewers have noted, it's not particularly peanut-buttery, but there are hints of the flavor. I noted a slight chalky aftertaste at times, but it wasn't such that I found it bad. I suppose the point is that this is a healthier choice than a snickers and it has served as a breakfast or lunch substitute for me when I've been on the go.

I appreciated reading Preston Yancey's Tables in the Wilderness. I also respect his articulation of his spiritual journey. There are certainly differences in interpretation and experience of encountering God...and I didn't expect his journey to necessarily align with my own. It was with this openness and acceptance to listen that I "listened and heard" Yancey's story.Tables in the Wilderness is the story of a "package" unraveled and then reassembled. So many people who have a Christian belief system assume to have God figured out along with all the nuanced postures, rites, and religious doo-dahs in place to function as a member of their specific Jesus tribe. Yancey proceeds to share his systems, the worlds that formed them...and the worlds that were their undoing, and ultimately when they were deconstructed, how his understanding and experience of God started to be reconstructed.I don't understand some of the negative reviews of this book. Yancey seems to write from a very bare and vulnerable place. It is difficult for me to accept the harsh criticism of some of the more insensitive reviews concerning details of Yancey's Christian views in his memoir, especially when the subject of this book is a "personal experience" and confession of sorts...and not a theological treatise. Every Christian's journey is going to be a personal experience, often born out of corporate interactions, but personal nonetheless and this is what Yancey reveals in his memoir. Some of what is written is "heady" and perhaps comes across as being over-thought, but this is the personality of the writer being revealed. I very much appreciated the authenticity.It is possible the fond connection I have to Yancey's story are the similarities I found with my own story. I understood precisely what he was trying to convey when he was confronted with his false self and judgemental views of other Christian pilgrims when I read the following words:"It happens slowly, the way it becomes about us and not about God. It happens when we change our email signatures to include that we are pastors, when we sit a little straighter in our chairs when we talk about the Bible, when we look at people like they should defer to us because we are the ones who know. We aren't a Family anymore. We are two people and those other people. We are us and they are them. It happens before you realize it has happened. It happens the moment you believe that your spirituality has surpassed that of someone else, that you can be their Holy Spirit." (pg. 85).Similarly, as Yancey begins opening himself to the undoing of the false self and allows God the Holy Spirit to transform his own mind and heart, his perspective of others begins to be a revelation of grace, compassion, patience, and love. I connected with this maturing grace and Christian love when I read the following:"If we get tripped up by the words about God, we miss God in the process. It took me a long time, but I eventually gave up the need to always call the Eucharist the Eucharist and instead use the words Communion, Lord's Supper, and Eucharist with an interchangeable grace. I let circumstance dictate my word choice, I let context determine my response. Because there was a time there where I and The Church of the Windowless Resurrection were essentially one and the same. We were both fighting, clawing, thrashing to prove who we were not." (pg. 225).This is a book about grace. This is a book about self-knowing. This is a book about seeking and searching. It is not systematic theology and it is not about articles of faith. It is the soul of one man baring a personal experience and inner conversations with the Triune Godhead. If Tables in the Wilderness is read from this perspective, it is likely you will find connections with your own journey and even more likely you will enjoy the conversation as you get to know Preston Yancey.

The price on this medal was very, very good...actually too good as it turns out. The casting was very poor and the detail of the Cross and lettering inscription as well as the detail in St Benedict is lacking tremendously. This poor casting coupled with the propensity to tarnish quickly has made this medal look like a dirty bronze disc after just a few wearings. I would not buy again, but I will remember "you get what you pay for."

This review is for the Turtle Beach Ear Force XO One Amplified Stereo Gaming Headset for Xbox One and Mobile Devices... catch those last words "and mobile devices." Understand from the outset that all the nifty features of this headset are specifically targeted to the Xbox One and you'll be delighted. If, on the other hand, you think any of those features will be cross-platform (eg., "and mobile devices") you will be let down.I was most hopeful I would be able to use the detachable mic for Skype calls and phone calls with my Samsung S3. I figured the attachable controler piece was platform specific, but had expectations that I would be at least able to use the boom mic with other "mobile devices." *sigh*I was enticed by "and mobile devices" and hopeful some of the features might be capable of working with my Xbox 360. Not so, at least in my experience. What I have received is a decent pair of headphones...comfortable to wear and capable in the realm of fair-to-good sound reproduction for almost any device. It's likely I will see a gaming platform upgrade (to the Xbox One) and these headphones will be experienced in the way they were intended, but until then it is likely I will have a mildly disappointed attitude toward the phrase "and mobile devices."

This is Targus quality, which means good construction...although surprisingly affordable. I've owned several Targus camera bags and camera backpacks and never have been disappointed. This backpack continues in like fashion. I'm using it with an ASUS 13 inch laptop and it has a little room, but I think a 16 inch might be tight (although I can't confirm this). I've got plenty of room for portfolio folder and computer accessories. Simply put, for under $30, this is a great bag you can trust with your computer or any other uses.

I was a little bit skeptical at the time I ordered this phone mount. I was unsure if it would be secure in the vent, I was unsure if it would hold my phone securely, and I was unsure of its longevity and durability. I've been using if for almost a week now and I'm confident about 2 out of 3 of my concerns. It holds securely in the vent of my car (Ford Taurus) and it holds my big Samsung S3 in its Otter Box case just fine...over bumps and my fiddling with it pressing buttons and generally putting the phone through its paces.I'm not sure how it will hold up in the long run, but I'm more confident about the build quality now that I've had it in my hands than I was before I actually knew how this little grip was put together. I'm not sure this would be the right product for every phone or vehicle (certainly not), but it's definitely in contention for one of the better products I've seen and used. My son has a dash mount grip (same phone and case), but it barely fits around the phone in its case.If you've done your homework and assessed your needs, this might be the phone mount grip for you.

I'm a long time user of the George Foreman Grill line. My older grill continues to see service in my kitchen despite the non-stick coating on it failing in various spots. I was pretty stoked when I was given the opportunity to review one the newer GF grills, especially when a couple of the selling points like "new and improved" non-stick surface and easier cleanup were revealed.One of the minor issues I had with my old grill was some leakage from the grill top to the drip pan. Right away I noticed an improvement in the new grill drip pan. A tiny design change has made the drip catcher much more effective. I count this a win before ever plugging the grill up.I think the effectiveness of the non-stick coating will take awhile before knowing how much better (if any) it is, but my first uses show that it works just fine. I was making panini last night and the grill functioned fine. My sandwiches started out 2-2.5 inches when i put them on the grill and the grill had ample range of motion to "sandwich" the panini with even pressure all around.If I have any critique, it would be in the advertisement of this particular size being a 4-serving surface. Serving size might be subjective, but I'm not sure I could fit two sandwiches on this grill side-by-side. Nothing negative to say about the machine though. It works perfectly and looks to be a little improved over the previous models I've owned.

Spiritual wisdom can come from almost anywhere if one takes the time to look closely and listen deeply. This little book is a prime example of this timeless advice to slow down, look closely, and listen deeply.Using the example and metaphor of the vineyard and vinedresser (one that is used in the Christian Bible quite often), Judith Sutera, with illustrations by Paul Soupiset, help their reader to see the work of God in spiritual lessons found in the nursing and care of vines and grapes. This is not a difficult book to read and the terms used are not hard to understand. Each devotional thought is only a couple pages long (not counting the illustrations), and a single topic reading will only take a matter of minutes. The beauty of this simplicity is the depth of reflection and personal application that comes from the insight gleaned from the  vinedresser's care and feeding of his vineyard.Wisdom doesn't always have to be hard-earned. Sometimes it can be received as the gift it is. The Vinedresser's Notebook is one of those gifts.

This is a really handsome french press. The brushed steel, glass decanter sleeve, is very clean looking as well as functional, helping to keep the contents hot/warm much longer than if the glass were exposed.Functionality is good and the press lives up to the claims of OXO as long as you observe their instructions. French press coffee is normally made with a coarser grind of the beans. Finer grinds can escape the plunger screen and get into the final pour, but with a little experimentation you'll find the right grind blend and those problems will be resolved. I have found no loss in taste quality with a coarser blend, although a slightly longer steep time may be necessary. Again, experimentation is encouraged to find the right mix of grind consistency, steep time, to taste expectations.The silicon grounds holder is a nice feature and works mostly as advertised. I wonder how long the little ladle will last as I'm not convinced that repeated use under the high heat conditions won't warp or disfigure it otherwise. For now, it works fine, but time will be the determining judge of this design feature.I've long thought cleanup of french press coffee makers was a pain, this unit is no different except that OXO recommends NOT using a dishwasher. I may disregard those instructions just to test whether or not it really effects the function of the parts. I suspect placing the pieces on the top rack of my dishwasher might prove that all works just fine, but this also is test I've yet to try.My summary is that this is a good Press. As I mentioned, a little experimentation can go a long way to help ensure a pleasant experience.

Wow! Am I loving this little grater! I must admit that starting out (due to my own inept setup) I struggled a bit with this very simple and effective kitchen gadget. I failed to "snap" the handle into place securely, so turning the drum was a bit cumbersome with the handle slipping off the gear. Additionally, I did not fully secure the vacuum suction seal, which made the grater slip along my counter top. I was a little concerned about these things and wondered about the build quality, but after slowing down my setup and reassembling the unit after its first cleaning I realized the mistakes I had made.Once I secured the handle and figured out I was only turning the "suction ring" halfway, my problems were a distant blur. I have had nothing but delightful experiences with this little guy since my faux pas during the first encounter.I usually use a flat hand-held grater from most of the tasks I am using this drum unit (and it has not been uncommon for me to cut or scrape my fingers in the process). What a world of difference! Cheese grating? A snap! root vegetables? No problem! Clean up? A breeze! Cut fingers? A thing of my past :)

These are nice in-ear headphones. They do everything that they advertise very well. Sound quality is near the best I've experienced for in-ear devices and the assortment of earbuds for comfort fit is impressive; there should not be any problem for anyone finding the "right fit" for their ears. I happen to have a Samsung Galaxy S3 smartphone, so this headset should work flawlessly with my phone, since it is listed as a compatible device on the Samsung product page. Unfortunately, I am unable to get the remote to advance tracks and have only been able to adjust volume and pause. The S-Voice function works with advancing tracks or skipping tracks, but that's a bit cumbersome for me as I don't want to "tell" my phone what to do, I'd simple like to quickly skip a track (and without taking my phone out of my pocket). Also, I wish the remote was not located so high and close to my chin.I've owned and tested quite a few sets of headphones: in-ear, over ear, and on ear. These are not the best. They're good, but not worth the price point. There are multiple choices available today and at the $149 mark, there are numerous contenders that blow these away.

I've been running this little WiFi extender for about two weeks now. It has been absolutely flawless in performance and function.To start, this device is ridiculously easy to setup and install. From unboxing to online and extending my LAN was under 15 minutes. The setup was as easy as plugging the extender into a powerstrip next to my router and waiting for the device link light to sync (this indicates there has been a connection between the LAN router and the extender). Once the extender connected to the router, I simply selected the extender from the list of available WiFi connections on my laptop, typed in an admin address in my browser and followed a very simple little network setup wizard, which totaled maybe four clicks of the mouse. That's it. Setup complete.Following setup, I installed a Netgear WiFi Analytics app on my Android smartphone, which helped me locate the best possible placement of the extender in my home. This app is available for free in the Android App Play Store. This is a cool little app that measures Router signal strength, conducts throughput tests from various rooms and locations in your home, and shows other networks that might be competing on the channel spectrums around you. It does some other helpful stuff too.I placed my extender in the best place for my network and connected a couple of devices to it. I've experienced zero down time and no reported dropouts. Signal strength to both devices that are connecting to the extender are showing 100% and throughput is showing 39Mbps and 54Mbps respectively. This is certainly not hardline speeds, but gaming and video streams are solid as a rock after initial buffering.I've had other extenders operating on my LAN (Namely the Linksys N300) and this little wonder beats it like a drum. Count me one very, very happy network extended camper.

This isn't our first Bissell vacuum; in fact, this 1322 Model is upgrading our present Powerforce 6579 model... and it is an upgrade in almost every measurable sense.First, the vacuum required some minor assembly, which was a literal snap to put together with the exception of two small screws used to secure the handle. The remaining pieces, hose and accessories "snapped" right into place in various fitted spaces on the vacuum itself. While there is an instruction manual with images detailing the assembly, it was so intuitive I did not even need it. Total assembly time including opening boxes and disposal of boxes... maybe 15 minutes.Next, was the basic sweeper test over standard pile shag carpet. As I mentioned, we are moving from a Bissell bagless upright, so I liken our comparison as apple to apple. I read one review that stated this machine was loud. I'll have to report that review claim as subjective because comparing to our 6579 model this 1322 is MUCH quieter, so we count the engine noise as a noticeable improvement. Ergonomics as reported by my wife was not as much an improvement in this newer model. She complained that the weight of the new 1322 unit was substantially more than the older vacuum and it tired her arm out before she was finished with the living room floor. I should note that physically, the units are almost identical in build form and size...I'm not sure where the additional weight comes from, but when I picked them up to compare heft, the 1322 did feel heavier.Continuing with our actual test, the 1322 proved itself a clear winner in the cleaning department. I was amazed at the amount of dust, dirt, lint, and stuff that this thing brushed and sucked out of the floor carpet. I'm not sure where to attribute this noticeable improvement in capability from, but I think the brush design is likely part of the reason. This vacuum features a Triple Action Brush Roll in its PR write-ups and it is very different than the brush roller on the 6579 model we had before it. The write-up says "it improves cleaning performance." It most definitely did for us!A couple of additional bonus finds with this new unit was 2 more foot of power cord. The length of the power cord in the older unit was 25ft. and this unit comes in at 27ft. Also, the self rewinding feature of the cord and its internal housing make it super convenient. The "wow factor" that had my wife squeeing and smiling was the turbo brush attachment that can be used for stairs and close in cleaning. This little attachment head has a rotating brush head similar to the main brush roller on the primary unit! Not only is this a great idea, but it works great! As the saying goes, it's the little things that matter and these little things added up in a big way.All things considered, this is a great upgrade for us. I'm sure there will be some reviews that might not be as glowing as our experience, but I'm sure it depends on what you're comparing this unit to. Our comparison is to another Bissell of similar build and capability. This newer unit seems to have added some enhanced features that truly make a difference.
