We noted that it cleans much better, it is quieter than our older Bissell, the retractable cord and the turbo brush attachment are both improvements, and the cost factor at $120 is very reasonable for this vacuum. Our only negative comment is minor and that would be the weight of the unit, but with all the other positive improvements this is a minor issue we'll easily get over soon.

I've been working with this NAS device now for a little over a week. I've devoted somewhere in the neighborhood of 40 or more hours of actual time invested to get it operable with the basic functions I would expect (which are advertised) for my needs. Let me state that (1) I am not a neophyte when it comes to WAN/LAN operations (2) I'm not a hardware tech newbie (3) I have networking experience across several platforms and operating systems. I should also qualify that I'm not an expert in these areas, but I have vocational experience that has been adequate for all my technical needs.Spec details: On Comcast Cable, DLINK Router, Primary OS's Windows XP, Windows 7, Ubuntu Linux, Android 4.3 and 4.4 (Samsung Galaxy S3 and Nexus 10)I've read quite a few of the reviews for this device and while I won't say that this device isn't "plug and play," I will say that has NOT been my experience. I think each user might find a different experience with the out-of-the-box set up. There are simply too many variables to consider for this to be a one-size-fits-all device. My experience has been rather frustrating to finally arrive at the point where my WD My Cloud NAS is working to my reasonable satisfaction. I have spent a number of hours on the http://community.wd.com/t5/WD-My-Cloud/bd-p/mycloud forum seeking information for setup tweaks and workarounds to get this device up and running. The tone of the reviews states that this has not been everyone's experience, but from time spent on the WD community forums, I am not alone.General headaches experienced is stablilizing the DHCP assignment so the device remains constant (you can do this by statically assigning an IP Address or reserving a DHCP address in your router). This step will be necessary to prevent drop-outs or intermittant connectivity issues. Another is minor conflict with Antivirus Software and Firewall system (slowing data transfer speeds and disappearing NAS from network).One of the primary roles I wanted for this NAS was for media streaming (movies and music). The promotional information pushes this feature rather prominently, but I had problems from the get go. First, the WD My Cloud uses the Twonky Media Server DLNA software (embedded in the firmware I assume) and this software does not play well with the formatting of my movies. I admit that I have movies in multiple formats (AVI, MKV, MP4, XVID, and DiVXX to name a few), but I have no problems streaming these movies with PLEX media server. I also have a ROKU device that should be able to work with DLNA media servers, but it does not like the Twonky Server very much either. This created quite the headache for me. I was able to eventually get the push the movie files through my ROKU, but in order to do this my computer (where the PLEX server is hosted) must be on and it is necessary to run the movies through the PLEX channel on my ROKU.Another headache is that the NAS does not simply "show up" in my network across all the devices connected. I'm not sure why this is, but I have narrowed it down to firewall protection on some devices (by disabling the firewall, the NAS shows up), but I'm unable to figure out yet why this happens on other devices... I'm still troubleshooting and working through this issue. It is curious to me why this occurs, it might be easy to blame my firewall, but the problem doesn't occur with other UPnP devices like my wireless printers or even another NAS (Buffalo 1TB NAS). Both of the aforementioned devices showed up immediately when connected to my LAN.Still another headache came with mobile connections. The implied understanding of the software for the mobile apps (I have an Android Smartphone Galaxy S3 and Android Nexus 10 pad) is run the software, send a assignment code to the mobile device and you're up and running. Simple enough right? No. I was able to connect with ease across my network, but when tested outside on the 4G/3G network I could not login. Back to the forum for answers and I found multiple persons with the same issue. The fix turned out to be port forwarding assignments in the router config. This was not a big deal, but I point it out for people who might not be comfortable messing with this type of config in their router. Even more on point, this was not a plug it in and go ordeal either.I'm not overly satisfied with data transfer either. There is no way that I've figured yet to plug directly into the NAS for device to device data transfer. The recommended "hardwire" transfer config is to go with a hardwire connection to the network (direct CAT5 connect to your router) and of course the direct CAT5 to the NAS WD Cloud device. Reports from other owners state this is a fast connection; however, it is inconvenient to set this up for my setup and my wireless transfers havee been between 3MB and 7MB at best. I do not understand why the engineers did not enable the possibility of a USB3 direct connection to the NAS from your transfering device. Seems like a neglectful oversight to me.There are still some applications I've yet to setup and test, like an auto backup schedule, but for the most part I do have the system operational and meeting the most of my needs...albeit much headache. I think the device is suitable for the needs it meets, but it is not universally plug and play. If you lack tech savvy, you might be gambling whether this will work for you out of the box. If you've got some tech savvy and don't mind the possibility of some legwork to get this thing up and running... it's a decent answer for you personal Cloud Storage.

After receiving this book as a gift some weeks ago and reading it probably several dozen times, I came to amazon to write a glowing review about its content and was pretty surprised to see the number of negative reviews concerning the book's ability to "teach your child to whine" or the "lack of punishment" for the young main character.To sum up the book, young Bella describes all the ways in which she was a major brat on a particular day. You got everything in the toddler arsenal here: refusing a certain food, taking shoes off randomly, complaining about crap that doesn't amount to a hill of beans, yelling in public, etc. etc. Then (SPOILER ALERT!), Bella apologizes to her mommy at the end of the book and said it was a rough day, to which her mommy replies, "We all have those days sometimes." Then, Bella is shown as being "CHEERFUL ALL DAY LONG!" the following day.I love this book because the pictures are really entertaining. The text changes places on almost every page and varies in size. When Bella's words are HUGE and in bold black text, I scream them and my kid laughs uncontrollably. Bella's baby brother's name is Bob, and a toddler pointing to a baby and saying, "Bob!" is hilarious. I can't stress enough the entertainment value of the way this book is composed. It is lots of fun for kids and lots of fun for the adult reading it. You can be as subdued or as outrageous as you want when you narrate this book to your child.Now, all my personal additions:If you're on the fence about the book, allow me to pull you off to my side. This book is HILARIOUS. I am 32 years old, I have two toddlers, and I am sick. to. death. of reading some of these books in my kids' room. I mean just sick. Like if my kid pulls out the "Let's All Share and Be Kind to Everyone!" book one more time I'm going to scream. "My No, No, NO Day" is a breath of fresh air from the usual "if you read this to your kids surely they'll be perfectly behaved little robots, no?" fodder that eats up my children's bookshelves. This book is about a real kid, and her real mom, on a real bad day. This book is real life down here in the trenches of parenthood, and stay-at-home parenthood in particular.Look, children are simply small adults. In fact, they really have it worse because they're small yet have all these feelings and urges that they don't understand. I have long taken exception to the idea that children will be (or even should be!) perfectly-behaved all the time. Decent human beings and decent citizens of their community? Yes. But taking off their shoes or complaining that their peas are too hot? Is this really worthy of a poor review? I consider someone who complains about this book to be the type who either does not know how or does not want to discipline his or her child. A book is not going to teach your child to complain about toothpaste. My toddler knows the difference between acting nice and acting mean. But we all manage to have a good laugh together at this funny and entertaining little book. It's just a book.

This case is probably not one I would choose if I abused my CD/DVD case, but for my purposes it's fine. This is the case that holds all my toddlers' assorted Little Einstein and Sesame Street DVDs - along with the ones their grandparents keep buying them even though I've said a thousand times they have more than enough. Anyway, the case is sturdy enough that I believe it will hold up to some toddler mischief. The plastic sleeves don't seem all that sturdy (and you have to pull the tab out of every sleeve before you use it - see my photo) and I do worry that eventually they're going to start ripping out, especially as little kids aren't typically the most gentle with their belongings. But in the end, you know, I paid 8 bucks for the case including Prime shipping, so if it lasts longer than 6 months then I'm good with that.

I LOVE these shoes! I actually meant to order a different style, but added these to my cart instead. I'm glad I did; these are wonderfully comfortable. My only small issue is that the arch seems almost a little too high. Now, I have very high natural arches, so this is fine for me, but I feel like some people with a lower arch may find this uncomfortable. For a purchase like this, I would definitely try them on somewhere first. I love these shoes and I know we're going to have some great adventures together.

VERY comfortable! These will be great socks for light hiking. I've worn them out and about several times now. They were a bit expensive, but not when compared to other hiking socks. Reading the reviews, I feel confident that these are going to last forever!I was worried about the cushion - would it be too much? Too little? It is the perfect amount of cushion. My shoes still fit great, but my feet feel like I'm walking on clouds.

These are ok, but I prefer other brands to the Ponds. I love my Ponds face cream, but these towelettes feel like they leave a residue on my face, so I don't like to use them at night and then sleep on my pillow. I have had great luck with the Clearasil products for a fresh, clean face.

Several times I've purchased these bags. They are great quality. My only advice is to purchase them if you see a good deal, because I had some in my cart and over 24 hours they went up something like $12! So buy if you see a price you like. :-)

Finally! A potty that does not have a thousand sounds and buttons on it but is also less than $20.We bought the Bjorn potty based on a recommendation from a book I read about potty training. My almost-3 year old is doing great! But I did want one that I can put upstairs in his Granny's room, toss into the car for adventures, etc. while still having his trusty Bjorn in the same place all the time (our bathroom). I can't freakin' believe this potty is $7; if I had seen this before I bought my Bjorn I definitely would have gotten this one!The size is perfect, I love the raised back so he can kindof lean back like an adult does when having a leisurely turn at the potty. :-) Not that I know what that's like anymore. The colors are simple and not too distracting. I'm of the opinion that a potty seat needs to be just a potty seat: not bright colors, not musical, not making sounds. Just a potty. Regular toilets don't play you a song when you pee, and besides, what parent (especially us stay-at-home parents) wants to hear ANOTHER musical or talking toy??! Not me!Love this potty and really want to buy 2 or 3 more but I'm afraid my husband will call me a hoarder.

Beautiful bag, but doesn't hold a 17" laptop as the description states: "Designed to hold laptops up to 17 inches measured on the diagonal." I was really disappointed as I had specifically searched amazon to find a fun case that would fit my big laptop. Now I'm dubious about purchasing something online and having to return it, so I'll probably have to try to find something locally, which is a pain, which is why I searched amazon. Laptops are commonly measured across the SCREEN ONLY, not the entire laptop. This bag would fit a laptop that is 17" TOTAL size including the  area around the screen. But no, it will not fit an actual 17" laptop.

My toddler really, really loves this bed. I thought the price was a little ridiculous for a toddler bed, but specialty ones like this are all in this range. We sold a few furniture items around the house to save up some extra money for this particular bed. It was so worth it. It doesn't look like amazon still allows videos in reviews, but I took a video of his reaction when he walked into the room.The bed came in two large, heavy boxes. It was easy to assemble - I entertained two toddlers while my husband put it together in less than an hour. It's big and sturdy and I can see it as a bedroom favorite through our next toddler, too! I'm really glad we "splurged" on this purchase.
Works great in my multi-needle Brother embroidery machine. Have had it about two months and have had no problems at all.
